sentences.latin: Gallia est omnis divisa in partes tres, quarum unam incolunt Belgae, aliam Aquitani, tertiam qui ipsorum lingua Celtae, nostra Galli appellantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Gaul is as a whole divided into parts three, of which one inhabit the Belgae, another the Aquitani, the third [those] who in their own language Celts, in ours Gauls are called.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] All Gaul is divided into three parts, one of which the Belgae inhabit, the Aquitani another, those who in their own language are called Celts, in our Gauls, the third.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaul as a whole is divided into three parts, one of which the Belgae inhabit, another the Aquitani, and the third those who in their own language are called Celts, and in ours Gauls.

sentences.latin: Hi omnes lingua, institutis, legibus inter se differunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These all in language, institutions, laws among themselves differ.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] All Gaul is divided into three parts, one of which the Belgae inhabit, the Aquitani another, those who in their own language are called Celts, in our Gauls, the third.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All these differ from one another in language, institutions, and laws.

sentences.latin: Gallos ab Aquitanis Garumna flumen, a Belgis Matrona et Sequana dividit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Gauls from the Aquitanians the Garonne river, from the Belgae the Marne and Seine divides.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All these differ from each other in language, customs and laws.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Garonne River separates the Gauls from the Aquitani, while the Marne and the Seine separate them from the Belgae.

sentences.latin: Horum omnium fortissimi sunt Belgae, propterea quod a cultu atque humanitate provinciae longissime absunt, minimeque ad eos mercatores saepe commeant atque ea quae ad effeminandos animos pertinent important,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of these all the bravest are the Belgae, because of that because from the culture and humanity of the province furthest they are away, and least to them merchants often resort and those things which to weakening minds pertain import,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The river Garonne separates the Gauls from the Aquitani; the Marne and the Seine separate them from the Belgae.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Of all these, the Belgae are the bravest, because they are furthest from the culture and refinement of the Province, and merchants least often visit them to import those things which tend to weaken the spirit,

sentences.latin: proximique sunt Germanis, qui trans Rhenum incolunt, quibuscum continenter bellum gerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and nearest they are to the Germans, who across the Rhine inhabit, with whom continually war they wage.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Of all these, the Belgae are the bravest, because they are furthest from the civilization and refinement of [our] Province, and merchants least frequently resort to them, and import those things which tend to effeminate the mind; and they are the nearest to the Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they are continually waging war; for which reason the Helvetii also surpass the rest of the Gauls in valor, as they contend with the Germans in almost daily battles, when they either repel them from their own territories, or themselves wage war on their frontiers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and they are nearest to the Germans, who live across the Rhine, with whom they are continually at war.

sentences.latin: Qua de causa Helvetii quoque reliquos Gallos virtute praecedunt, quod fere cotidianis proeliis cum Germanis contendunt, cum aut suis finibus eos prohibent aut ipsi in eorum finibus bellum gerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For which cause the Helvetii also the remaining Gauls in courage surpass, because almost daily battles with the Germans they contend, when either from their own borders them they prohibit or themselves in their borders war they wage.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Of all these, the Belgae are the bravest, because they are furthest from the civilization and refinement of [our] Province, and merchants least frequently resort to them, and import those things which tend to effeminate the mind; and they are the nearest to the Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they are continually waging war; for which reason the Helvetii also surpass the rest of the Gauls in valor, as they contend with the Germans in almost daily battles, when they either repel them from their own territories, or themselves wage war on their frontiers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this reason the Helvetii also surpass the rest of the Gauls in courage, because they fight with the Germans in almost daily battles, either when they keep them out of their own territory or wage war in the Germans' territory.

sentences.latin: [Eorum una, pars, quam Gallos obtinere dictum est, initium capit a flumine Rhodano, continetur Garumna flumine, Oceano, finibus Belgarum, attingit etiam ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, vergit ad septentriones.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of them one part, which the Gauls to possess it has been said, beginning takes from the river Rhone, is contained by the Garonne river, the Ocean, the borders of the Belgae, touches also from the Sequani and Helvetii the river Rhine, slopes toward the north.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One part of these, which it has been said that the Gauls occupy, takes its beginning at the river Rhone; it is bounded by the river Garonne, the ocean, and the territories of the Belgae; it borders, too, on the side of the Sequani and the Helvetii, upon the river Rhine, and stretches toward the north.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One part of these, which it has been said the Gauls occupy, begins at the Rhone River, is bounded by the Garonne River, the Ocean, and the territory of the Belgae; it also reaches the Rhine River on the side of the Sequani and Helvetii, and stretches toward the north.

sentences.latin: Belgae ab extremis Galliae finibus oriuntur, pertinent ad inferiorem partem fluminis Rheni, spectant in septentrionem et orientem solem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Belgae from the furthest of Gaul borders arise, pertain to the lower part of the river Rhine, look into the north and the rising sun.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Belgae rises from the extreme frontier of Gaul, extend to the lower part of the river Rhine; and look toward the north and the rising sun.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Belgae begin at the furthest borders of Gaul, extend to the lower part of the Rhine River, and face north and the rising sun.

sentences.latin: Aquitania a Garumna flumine ad Pyrenaeos montes et eam partem Oceani quae est ad Hispaniam pertinet; spectat inter occasum solis et septentriones.]
sentences.referenceTranslation: Aquitania from the Garonne river to the Pyrenees mountains and that part of the Ocean which is at Spain pertains; it looks between the setting of the sun and the north.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Aquitania extends from the river Garonne to the Pyrenaean mountains and to that part of the ocean which is near Spain: it looks between the setting of the sun, and the north star.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Aquitania extends from the Garonne River to the Pyrenees Mountains and that part of the Ocean which is near Spain; it faces between the sunset and the north.

sentences.latin: Apud Helvetios longe nobilissimus fuit et ditissimus Orgetorix.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Among the Helvetii by far most noble was and richest Orgetorix.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Among the Helvetii, Orgetorix was by far the most distinguished and wealthy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among the Helvetii, Orgetorix was by far the most noble and the wealthiest.

sentences.latin: Is M. Messala, [et P.] M. Pisone consulibus regni cupiditate inductus coniurationem nobilitatis fecit et civitati persuasit ut de finibus suis cum omnibus copiis exirent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: He, Marcus Messala and Marcus Piso being consuls, by desire of kingship induced, a conspiracy of the nobility made and the state persuaded that from borders their own with all forces they should go out:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Among the Helvetii, Orgetorix was by far the most distinguished and wealthy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the consulship of Marcus Messala and Marcus Piso, he, driven by a desire for sovereignty, formed a conspiracy among the nobility and persuaded the state to leave their territory with all their forces:

sentences.latin: perfacile esse, cum virtute omnibus praestarent, totius Galliae imperio potiri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: very easy to be, since in courage all they surpassed, of whole Gaul the supreme power to get possession of.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He, when Marcus Messala and Marcus Piso were consuls, incited by lust of sovereignty, formed a conspiracy among the nobility, and persuaded the people to go forth from their territories with all their possessions, [saying] that it would be very easy, since they excelled all in valor, to acquire the supremacy of the whole of Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: arguing that it was very easy, since they surpassed all in courage, to get possession of the sovereignty of all Gaul.

sentences.latin: Id hoc facilius iis persuasit, quod undique loci natura Helvetii continentur: una ex parte flumine Rheno latissimo atque altissimo, qui agrum Helvetium a Germanis dividit; altera ex parte monte Iura altissimo, qui est inter Sequanos et Helvetios; tertia lacu Lemanno et flumine Rhodano, qui provinciam nostram ab Helvetiis dividit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It this more easily to them he persuaded, because on all sides by the place's nature the Helvetii are contained: from one part by the river Rhine widest and deepest, which the field Helvetian from the Germans divides; from another part by mountain Jura highest, which is between the Sequani and Helvetii; third by lake Lemannus and the river Rhone, which province our from the Helvetii divides.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] To this he the more easily persuaded them, because the Helvetii, are confined on every side by the nature of their situation; on one side by the Rhine, a very broad and deep river, which separates the Helvetian territory from the Germans; on a second side by the Jura, a very high mountain, which is [situated] between the Sequani and the Helvetii; on a third by the Lake of Geneva, and by the river Rhone, which separates our Province from the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He persuaded them of this more easily because the Helvetii are hemmed in on all sides by the nature of the terrain: on one side by the Rhine, a very wide and deep river, which separates the Helvetian territory from the Germans; on a second side by the very high Jura mountain range, which is between the Sequani and the Helvetii; on the third by Lake Geneva and the Rhone River, which separates our Province from the Helvetii.

sentences.latin: His rebus fiebat ut et minus late vagarentur et minus facile finitimis bellum inferre possent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things it happened that both less widely they wandered and less easily to neighbors war to bring they were able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] To this he the more easily persuaded them, because the Helvetii, are confined on every side by the nature of their situation; on one side by the Rhine, a very broad and deep river, which separates the Helvetian territory from the Germans; on a second side by the Jura, a very high mountain, which is [situated] between the Sequani and the Helvetii; on a third by the Lake of Geneva, and by the river Rhone, which separates our Province from the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because of these things, it happened that they wandered less widely and could less easily wage war upon their neighbors;

sentences.latin: qua ex parte homines bellandi cupidi magno dolore adficiebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from which part men of warring desirous with great grief were affected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From these circumstances it resulted, that they could range less widely, and could less easily make war upon their neighbors; for which reason men fond of war [as they were] were affected with great regret.
sentences.naturalTranslation: for this reason, being men fond of war, they were affected by great resentment.

sentences.latin: Pro multitudine autem hominum et pro gloria belli atque fortitudinis angustos se fines habere arbitrabantur, qui in longitudinem milia passuum CCXL, in latitudinem CLXXX patebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For the multitude however of men and for the glory of war and of bravery narrow themselves borders to have they thought, which in length thousands of paces 240, in width 180 extended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They thought, that considering the extent of their population, and their renown for warfare and bravery, they had but narrow limits, although they extended in length 240, and in breadth 180 [Roman] miles.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Considering the size of their population and their reputation for warfare and bravery, they thought they had narrow borders, which extended 240 miles in length and 180 in width.

sentences.latin: His rebus adducti et auctoritate Orgetorigis permoti constituerunt ea quae ad proficiscendum pertinerent comparare, iumentorum et carrorum quam maximum numerum coemere, sementes quam maximas facere, ut in itinere copia frumenti suppeteret, cum proximis civitatibus pacem et amicitiam confirmare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things led and by the authority of Orgetorix moved, they decided those things which to setting out pertained to prepare, of beasts of burden and of wagons as greatest a number to buy up, sowings as greatest to make, so that on the journey a supply of grain might be available, with the nearest states peace and friendship to confirm.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Induced by these considerations, and influenced by the authority of Orgetorix, they determined to provide such things as were necessary for their expedition - to buy up as great a number as possible of beasts of burden and wagons - to make their sowings as large as possible, so that on their march plenty of corn might be in store - and to establish peace and friendship with the neighboring states.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Induced by these factors and moved by the authority of Orgetorix, they decided to prepare what was necessary for their departure: to buy up as many pack animals and wagons as possible, to make their sowings as large as possible so that a supply of grain would be available on the journey, and to establish peace and friendship with the neighboring states.

sentences.latin: Ad eas res conficiendas biennium sibi satis esse duxerunt; in tertium annum profectionem lege confirmant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For these things to be completed a two-year period for themselves enough to be they reckoned; into the third year the departure by law they confirm.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Induced by these considerations, and influenced by the authority of Orgetorix, they determined to provide such things as were necessary for their expedition - to buy up as great a number as possible of beasts of burden and wagons - to make their sowings as large as possible, so that on their march plenty of corn might be in store - and to establish peace and friendship with the neighboring states.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They reckoned that two years would be enough for them to complete these preparations; they fixed their departure by law for the third year.

sentences.latin: Ad eas res conficiendas Orgetorix deligitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For these things to be completed Orgetorix is chosen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They reckoned that a term of two years would be sufficient for them to execute their designs; they fix by decree their departure for the third year.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Orgetorix was chosen to complete these arrangements.

sentences.latin: Is sibi legationem ad civitates suscipit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He for himself an embassy to the states undertakes.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Orgetorix is chosen to complete these arrangements.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He took upon himself the office of ambassador to the states.

sentences.latin: In eo itinere persuadet Castico, Catamantaloedis filio, Sequano, cuius pater regnum in Sequanis multos annos obtinuerat et a senatu populi Romani amicus appellatus erat, ut regnum in civitate sua occuparet, quod pater ante habuerit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that journey he persuades Casticus, of Catamantaloedes the son, a Sequanian, whose father the kingdom among the Sequani for many years had held and by the senate of the people Roman a friend had been called, that the kingdom in state his own he should seize, which the father before had held;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Orgetorix is chosen to complete these arrangements.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During that journey, he persuaded Casticus, a Sequanian and the son of Catamantaloedes, to seize the kingship in his own state, which his father had held before him and who had been named a friend of the Roman people by the senate.

sentences.latin: itemque Dumnorigi Haeduo, fratri Diviciaci, qui eo tempore principatum in civitate obtinebat ac maxime plebi acceptus erat, ut idem conaretur persuadet eique filiam suam in matrimonium dat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and likewise Dumnorix the Haeduan, to the brother of Diviciacus, who at that time the leadership in the state was holding and especially to the common people acceptable was, that the same thing he should attempt he persuades and to him daughter his own in marriage he gives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He took upon himself the office of embassador to the states: on this journey he persuades Casticus, the son of Catamantaledes (one of the Sequani, whose father had possessed the sovereignty among the people for many years, and had been styled "friend" by the senate of the Roman people), to seize upon the sovereignty in his own state, which his father had held before him, and he likewise persuades Dumnorix, an Aeduan, the brother of Divitiacus, who at that time possessed the chief authority in the state, and was exceedingly beloved by the people, to attempt the same, and gives him his daughter in marriage.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He likewise persuaded Dumnorix the Haeduan, the brother of Diviciacus, who at that time held the leadership of the state and was very popular with the common people, to attempt the same thing, and he gave him his daughter in marriage.

sentences.latin: Perfacile factu esse illis probat conata perficere, propterea quod ipse suae civitatis imperium obtenturus esset:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Very easy in the doing to be to them he proves the attempts to complete, because that he himself of his own state the supreme power about to obtain was:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He proves to them that to accomplish their attempts was a thing very easy to be done, because he himself would obtain the government of his own state; that there was no doubt that the Helvetii were the most powerful of the whole of Gaul; he assures them that he will, with his own forces and his own army, acquire the sovereignty for them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He demonstrated to them that it was very easy to accomplish these attempts, because he himself was about to obtain the supreme power of his own state.

sentences.latin: non esse dubium quin totius Galliae plurimum Helvetii possent; se suis copiis suoque exercitu illis regna conciliaturum confirmat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: not to be doubt but that of all Gaul most the Helvetii were able; himself with his own resources and his own army for them the kingdoms about to win over he confirms.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He proves to them that to accomplish their attempts was a thing very easy to be done, because he himself would obtain the government of his own state; that there was no doubt that the Helvetii were the most powerful of the whole of Gaul; he assures them that he will, with his own forces and his own army, acquire the sovereignty for them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He asserted there was no doubt that the Helvetii were the most powerful of all Gaul; he assured them that he would win over the kingdoms for them with his own resources and his own army.

sentences.latin: Hac oratione adducti inter se fidem et ius iurandum dant et regno occupato per tres potentissimos ac firmissimos populos totius Galliae sese potiri posse sperant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this speech influenced among themselves faith and an oath they give and the kingdom having been seized through three most powerful and most firm peoples of all Gaul themselves to get possession to be able they hope.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Incited by this speech, they give a pledge and oath to one another, and hope that, when they have seized the sovereignty, they will, by means of the three most powerful and valiant nations, be enabled to obtain possession of the whole of Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by this speech, they exchanged a pledge and an oath, hoping that once they had seized royal power, they could gain control of all Gaul through these three most powerful and stable nations.

sentences.latin: Ea res est Helvetiis per indicium enuntiata.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing was to the Helvetii through informers announced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When this scheme was disclosed to the Helvetii by informers, they, according to their custom, compelled Orgetorix to plead his cause in chains; it was the law that the penalty of being burned by fire should await him if condemned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This plot was revealed to the Helvetii through informers.

sentences.latin: Moribus suis Orgetoricem ex vinculis causam dicere coegerunt; damnatum poenam sequi oportebat, ut igni cremaretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By customs their own Orgetorix from chains the cause to plead they compelled; the condemned man the punishment to follow it was necessary, that by fire he should be burned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When this scheme was disclosed to the Helvetii by informers, they, according to their custom, compelled Orgetorix to plead his cause in chains; it was the law that the penalty of being burned by fire should await him if condemned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: According to their customs, they compelled Orgetorix to plead his case in chains; if condemned, the law required that he be burned to death.

sentences.latin: Die constituta causae dictionis Orgetorix ad iudicium omnem suam familiam, ad hominum milia decem, undique coegit, et omnes clientes obaeratosque suos, quorum magnum numerum habebat, eodem conduxit; per eos ne causam diceret se eripuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the day appointed of the cause pleading Orgetorix to the trial all his household, to of men thousands ten, from everywhere collected, and all clients and debtors his own, of whom a great number he had, to the same place he led; through them lest the cause he should plead himself he rescued.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On the day appointed for the pleading of his cause, Orgetorix drew together from all quarters to the court, all his vassals to the number of ten thousand persons; and led together to the same place all his dependents and debtor-bondsmen, of whom he had a great number; by means of those he rescued himself from [the necessity of] pleading his cause.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the day appointed for the trial, Orgetorix gathered his entire household from all sides, about ten thousand men, and brought all his clients and debtors, of whom he had a great number, to the same place; through their help, he escaped having to plead his case.

sentences.latin: Cum civitas ob eam rem incitata armis ius suum exequi conaretur multitudinemque hominum ex agris magistratus cogerent, Orgetorix mortuus est;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When the state on account of that thing incited by arms right its own to enforce was attempting and a multitude of men from the fields the magistrates were collecting, Orgetorix died;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On the day appointed for the pleading of his cause, Orgetorix drew together from all quarters to the court, all his vassals to the number of ten thousand persons; and led together to the same place all his dependents and debtor-bondsmen, of whom he had a great number; by means of those he rescued himself from [the necessity of] pleading his cause.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While the state, incensed by this event, was attempting to enforce its law by arms and the magistrates were gathering a multitude of men from the countryside, Orgetorix died.

sentences.latin: neque abest suspicio, ut Helvetii arbitrantur, quin ipse sibi mortem consciverit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not is absent suspicion, as the Helvetii think, but that he himself for himself death resolved upon.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While the state, incensed at this act, was endeavoring to assert its right by arms, and the magistrates were mustering a large body of men from the country, Orgetorix died; and there is not wanting a suspicion, as the Helvetii think, of his having committed suicide.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There is no lack of suspicion, as the Helvetii believe, that he committed suicide.

sentences.latin: Post eius mortem nihilo minus Helvetii id quod constituerant facere conantur, ut e finibus suis exeant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After his death by nothing less the Helvetians that which they had decided to do they attempt, that from borders their own they might go out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After his death, the Helvetii nevertheless attempt to do that which they had resolved on, namely, to go forth from their territories.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After his death, the Helvetians nevertheless attempted to do what they had decided, namely, to depart from their territory.

sentences.latin: Ubi iam se ad eam rem paratos esse arbitrati sunt, oppida sua omnia, numero ad duodecim, vicos ad quadringentos, reliqua privata aedificia incendunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When now themselves for that thing prepared to be they thought, towns their own all, in number to twelve, villages to four hundred, remaining private buildings they burn;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When they thought that they were at length prepared for this undertaking, they set fire to all their towns, in number about twelve - to their villages about four hundred - and to the private dwellings that remained; they burn up all the corn, except what they intend to carry with them; that after destroying the hope of a return home, they might be the more ready for undergoing all dangers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they thought they were now ready for this undertaking, they set fire to all their towns, about twelve in number, their villages, about four hundred, and the rest of their private buildings.

sentences.latin: frumentum omne, praeter quod secum portaturi erant, comburunt, ut domum reditionis spe sublata paratiores ad omnia pericula subeunda essent; trium mensum molita cibaria sibi quemque domo efferre iubent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: grain all, except what with themselves about to carry they were, they burn up, so that of home returning hope having been removed more prepared for all dangers to be undergone they might be; of three months ground food for himself each one from home to carry out they order.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They order every one to carry forth from home for himself provisions for three months, ready ground.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They burned all the grain, except what they were going to carry with them, so that, by removing the hope of returning home, they might be more ready to face all dangers; they ordered everyone to bring from home three months' worth of ground provisions for themselves.

sentences.latin: Persuadent Rauracis et Tulingis et Latobrigis finitimis, uti eodem usi consilio oppidis suis vicisque exustis una cum iis proficiscantur, Boiosque, qui trans Rhenum incoluerant et in agrum Noricum transierant Noreiamque oppugnabant, receptos ad se socios sibi adsciscunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They persuade the Rauraci and Tulingi and Latobrigi neighbors, that having used the same plan towns their own and villages having been burned up together with them they should set out, and the Boii, who across the Rhine had dwelt and into territory Norican had crossed and Noreia were attacking, having been received to themselves as allies to themselves they join.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They persuade the Rauraci, and the Tulingi, and the Latobrigi, their neighbors, to adopt the same plan, and after burning down their towns and villages, to set out with them: and they admit to their party and unite to themselves as confederates the Boii, who had dwelt on the other side of the Rhine, and had crossed over into the Norican territory, and assaulted Noreia.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They persuaded their neighbors, the Rauraci, Tulingi, and Latobrigi, to adopt the same plan and, after burning their towns and villages, to set out with them; and they received and joined to themselves as allies the Boii, who had lived across the Rhine, had crossed into Norican territory, and were attacking Noreia.

sentences.latin: Erant omnino itinera duo, quibus itineribus domo exire possent: unum per Sequanos, angustum et difficile, inter montem Iuram et flumen Rhodanum, vix qua singuli carri ducerentur, mons autem altissimus impendebat, ut facile perpauci prohibere possent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There were in all routes two, by which routes from home to go out they were able: one through the Sequani, narrow and difficult, between mountain Jura and river Rhone, scarcely where single carts might be led, a mountain however very high overhung, so that easily very few to prohibit were able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] There were in all two routes, by which they could go forth from their country one through the Sequani narrow and difficult, between Mount Jura and the river Rhone (by which scarcely one wagon at a time could be led; there was, moreover, a very high mountain overhanging, so that a very few might easily intercept them; the other, through our Province, much easier and freer from obstacles, because the Rhone flows between the boundaries of the Helvetii and those of the Allobroges, who had lately been subdued, and is in some places crossed by a ford.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There were only two routes by which they could leave home: one through the Sequani, narrow and difficult, between Mount Jura and the Rhone River, where carts could scarcely be led one at a time, and a very high mountain overhung it, so that a very few men could easily block the way.

sentences.latin: alterum per provinciam nostram, multo facilius atque expeditius, propterea quod inter fines Helvetiorum et Allobrogum, qui nuper pacati erant, Rhodanus fluit isque non nullis locis vado transitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the other through province our, by much easier and more unimpeded, because between borders of Helvetians and of Allobroges, who recently subdued had been, the Rhone flows and it in not some places by a ford is crossed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] There were in all two routes, by which they could go forth from their country one through the Sequani narrow and difficult, between Mount Jura and the river Rhone (by which scarcely one wagon at a time could be led; there was, moreover, a very high mountain overhanging, so that a very few might easily intercept them; the other, through our Province, much easier and freer from obstacles, because the Rhone flows between the boundaries of the Helvetii and those of the Allobroges, who had lately been subdued, and is in some places crossed by a ford.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The other route was through our province, much easier and more direct, because the Rhone flows between the borders of the Helvetians and the Allobroges, who had recently been pacified, and it is crossed in several places by a ford.

sentences.latin: Extremum oppidum Allobrogum est proximumque Helvetiorum finibus Genava.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The furthest town of the Allobroges is and nearest to of the Helvetians borders Geneva.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The furthest town of the Allobroges, and the nearest to the territories of the Helvetii, is Geneva.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Geneva is the furthest town of the Allobroges and the nearest to the borders of the Helvetians.

sentences.latin: Ex eo oppido pons ad Helvetios pertinet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From that town a bridge to the Helvetians extends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] From this town a bridge extends to the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A bridge extends from that town to the Helvetians.

sentences.latin: Allobrogibus sese vel persuasuros, quod nondum bono animo in populum Romanum viderentur, existimabant vel vi coacturos ut per suos fines eos ire paterentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the Allobroges themselves either about to persuade, because not yet in good mind toward people Roman they seemed, they were thinking or by force about to compel that through their own borders them to go they should allow.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] From this town a bridge extends to the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They thought they would either persuade the Allobroges, because they did not yet seem well-disposed toward the Roman people, or compel them by force to allow them to pass through their territory.

sentences.latin: Omnibus rebus ad profectionem comparatis diem dicunt, qua die ad ripam Rhodani omnes conveniant. is dies erat a. d. V.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All things for departure having been prepared a day they appoint, on which day at bank of Rhone all should assemble. This day was before day fifth.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They thought that they should either persuade the Allobroges, because they did not seem as yet well-affected toward the Roman people, or compel them by force to allow them to pass through their territories.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having prepared everything for their departure, they appointed a day on which everyone was to assemble on the bank of the Rhone. This day was the fifth day before the Kalends of April.

sentences.latin: Kal.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Kalends
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Having provided every thing for the expedition, they appoint a day, on which they should all meet on the bank of the Rhone.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Kalends

sentences.latin: Apr.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of April.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Having provided every thing for the expedition, they appoint a day, on which they should all meet on the bank of the Rhone.
sentences.naturalTranslation: of April.

sentences.latin: L. Pisone, A. Gabinio consulibus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lucius Piso, Aulus Gabinius being consuls.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This day was the fifth before the kalends of April [i.e. the 28th of March], in the consulship of Lucius Piso and Aulus Gabinius [B.C. 58.]
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the consulship of Lucius Piso and Aulus Gabinius.

sentences.latin: Caesari cum id nuntiatum esset, eos per provinciam nostram iter facere conari, maturat ab urbe proficisci et quam maximis potest itineribus in Galliam ulteriorem contendit et ad Genavam pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To Caesar when it had been announced, them through our province a journey to make to be attempting, he hastens from the city to set out and by as great as he can marches into Gaul farther he hastens and to Geneva arrives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When it was reported to Caesar that they were attempting to make their route through our Province he hastens to set out from the city, and, by as great marches as he can, proceeds to Further Gaul, and arrives at Geneva.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar was informed that they were attempting to march through our province, he hurried to leave the city and, traveling by the longest possible stages, hurried into farther Gaul and reached Geneva.

sentences.latin: Provinciae toti quam maximum potest militum numerum imperat (erat omnino in Gallia ulteriore legio una), pontem, qui erat ad Genavam, iubet rescindi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the province whole as great as he can of soldiers a number he levies (there was altogether in Gaul farther legion one), the bridge, which was at Geneva, he orders to be cut down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When it was reported to Caesar that they were attempting to make their route through our Province he hastens to set out from the city, and, by as great marches as he can, proceeds to Further Gaul, and arrives at Geneva.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He requisitioned the largest possible number of soldiers from the whole province (there was only one legion in farther Gaul) and ordered the bridge at Geneva to be destroyed.

sentences.latin: Ubi de eius aventu Helvetii certiores facti sunt, legatos ad eum mittunt nobilissimos civitatis, cuius legationis Nammeius et Verucloetius principem locum obtinebant, qui dicerent sibi esse in animo sine ullo maleficio iter per provinciam facere, propterea quod aliud iter haberent nullum: rogare ut eius voluntate id sibi facere liceat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When about his arrival the Helvetii more certain were made, ambassadors to him they send the most noble of the state, of which embassy Nammeius and Verucloetius the chief place were holding, who were to say to them to be in mind without any mischief a journey through the province to make, because other journey they had none: to ask that by his will it to them to do this be permitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He orders the whole Province [to furnish] as great a number of soldiers as possible, as there was in all only one legion in Further Gaul: he orders the bridge at Geneva to be broken down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the Helvetii were informed of his arrival, they sent their most distinguished citizens as ambassadors to him, led by Nammeius and Verucloetius. They were to say that they intended to march through the province without doing any harm, as they had no other route, and to request his permission to do so.

sentences.latin: Caesar, quod memoria tenebat L. Cassium consulem occisum exercitumque eius ab Helvetiis pulsum et sub iugum missum, concedendum non putabat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, because in memory he was holding Lucius Cassius the consul killed and the army of him by the Helvetii beaten and under the yoke sent, to be granted not was thinking;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He orders the whole Province [to furnish] as great a number of soldiers as possible, as there was in all only one legion in Further Gaul: he orders the bridge at Geneva to be broken down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, remembering that the consul Lucius Cassius had been killed and his army routed and sent under the yoke by the Helvetii, did not think their request should be granted.

sentences.latin: neque homines inimico animo, data facultate per provinciam itineris faciundi, temperaturos ab iniuria et maleficio existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor men with an unfriendly mind, given the opportunity through the province of a journey being made, would refrain from injury and mischief he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When the Helvetii are apprized of his arrival they send to him, as embassadors, the most illustrious men of their state (in which embassy Numeius and Verudoctius held the chief place), to say "that it was their intention to march through the Province without doing any harm, because they had" [according to their own representations,] "no other route: that they requested, they might be allowed to do so with his consent." Caesar, inasmuch as he kept in remembrance that Lucius Cassius, the consul, had been slain, and his army routed and made to pass under the yoke by the Helvetii, did not think that [their request] ought to be granted: nor was he of opinion that men of hostile disposition, if an opportunity of marching through the Province were given them, would abstain from outrage and mischief.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nor did he believe that people of such hostile intent, if given the opportunity to march through the province, would refrain from damage and outrages.

sentences.latin: Tamen, ut spatium intercedere posset dum milites quos imperaverat convenirent, legatis respondit diem se ad deliberandum sumpturum: si quid vellent, ad Id.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nevertheless, so that a space could intervene while the soldiers whom he had commanded might come together, to the ambassadors he replied a day himself for deliberating would take: if anything they wished, by the Ides
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When the Helvetii are apprized of his arrival they send to him, as embassadors, the most illustrious men of their state (in which embassy Numeius and Verudoctius held the chief place), to say "that it was their intention to march through the Province without doing any harm, because they had" [according to their own representations,] "no other route: that they requested, they might be allowed to do so with his consent." Caesar, inasmuch as he kept in remembrance that Lucius Cassius, the consul, had been slain, and his army routed and made to pass under the yoke by the Helvetii, did not think that [their request] ought to be granted: nor was he of opinion that men of hostile disposition, if an opportunity of marching through the Province were given them, would abstain from outrage and mischief.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, to allow time for the soldiers he had requisitioned to assemble, he replied to the ambassadors that he would take a day to deliberate: if they wanted anything, by the Ides

sentences.latin: April. reverterentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of April they should return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Yet, in order that a period might intervene, until the soldiers whom he had ordered [to be furnished] should assemble, he replied to the ambassadors, that he would take time to deliberate; if they wanted any thing, they might return on the day before the ides of April [on April 12th].
sentences.naturalTranslation: of April they should return.

sentences.latin: Interea ea legione quam secum habebat militibusque, qui ex provincia convenerant, a lacu Lemanno, qui in flumen Rhodanum influit, ad montem Iuram, qui fines Sequanorum ab Helvetiis dividit, milia passuum XVIIII murum in altitudinem pedum sedecim fossamque perducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile with that legion which with himself he was having and the soldiers, who from the province had assembled, from lake Geneva, which into the river Rhone flows, to mountain Jura, which the borders of the Sequani from the Helvetii divides, thousands of paces 19 a wall into height of feet sixteen and a ditch he leads through.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile, with the legion which he had with him and the soldiers which had assembled from the Province, he carries along for nineteen [Roman, not quite eighteen English] miles a wall, to the height of sixteen feet, and a trench, from the Lake of Geneva, which flows into the river Rhone, to Mount Jura, which separates the territories of the Sequani from those of the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, using the legion he had with him and the soldiers who had arrived from the province, Caesar constructed a wall sixteen feet high and a ditch for nineteen miles, from Lake Geneva, which flows into the Rhone, to the Jura Mountains, which separate the territory of the Sequani from the Helvetii.

sentences.latin: Eo opere perfecto praesidia disponit, castella communit, quo facilius, si se invito transire conentur, prohibere possit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That work having been finished, garrisons he distributes, forts he fortifies, by which more easily, if him being unwilling to cross they should attempt, to prohibit he might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When that work was finished, he distributes garrisons, and closely fortifies redoubts, in order that he may the more easily intercept them, if they should attempt to cross over against his will.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When that work was finished, he stationed garrisons and fortified outposts so that he could more easily stop them if they attempted to cross against his will.

sentences.latin: Ubi ea dies quam constituerat cum legatis venit et legati ad eum reverterunt, negat se more et exemplo populi Romani posse iter ulli per provinciam dare et, si vim lacere conentur, prohibiturum ostendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When that day which he had appointed with the envoys came and the envoys to him returned, he denies himself by the custom and precedent of the people Roman to be able a way to anyone through the province to give and, if force to make they should attempt, that he will prohibit he showed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When the day which he had appointed with the embassadors came, and they returned to him; he says, that he can not, consistently with the custom and precedent of the Roman people, grant any one a passage through the Province; and he gives them to understand, that, if they should attempt to use violence he would oppose them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the day he had appointed with the envoys arrived and they returned to him, he stated that, following the custom and precedent of the Roman people, he could not grant anyone passage through the province; he made it clear that he would stop them if they tried to use force.

sentences.latin: Helvetii ea spe deiecti navibus iunctis ratibusque compluribus factis, alii vadis Rhodani, qua minima altitudo fluminis erat, non numquam interdiu, saepius noctu si perrumpere possent conati, operis munitione et militum concursu et telis repulsi, hoc conatu destiterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetii from that hope cast down, with ships joined and rafts several made, others by the fords of the Rhone, where the least depth of the river was, not never by day, more often by night if to break through they were able having attempted, by the fortification of the work and the onset of the soldiers and by weapons repulsi, from this attempt they desisted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetii, disappointed in this hope, tried if they could force a passage (some by means of a bridge of boats and numerous rafts constructed for the purpose; others, by the fords of the Rhone, where the depth of the river was least, sometimes by day, but more frequently by night), but being kept at bay by the strength of our works, and by the concourse of the soldiers, and by the missiles, they desisted from this attempt.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Disappointed in this hope, the Helvetii tried to break through, some by joining boats and building many rafts, others by the fords of the Rhone where the water was shallowestsometimes by day, but more often by night. However, repulsed by the strength of the fortifications, the charge of the soldiers, and the volleys of missiles, they abandoned the attempt.

sentences.latin: Relinquebatur una per Sequanos via, qua Sequanis invitis propter angustias ire non poterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was left one through the Sequani way, by which the Sequani being unwilling on account of the narrowness to go they were not able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was left one way, [namely] through the Sequani, by which, on account of its narrowness, they could not pass without the consent of the Sequani.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Only one route remained, through the territory of the Sequani, but they could not take it if the Sequani were unwilling, because of the narrow passes.

sentences.latin: His cum sua sponte persuadere non possent, legatos ad Dumnorigem Haeduum mittunt, ut eo deprecatore a Sequanis impetrarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These since by their own influence to persuade they were not able, envoys to Dumnorix the Haeduan they send, so that with him as intercessor from the Sequani they might obtain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As they could not of themselves prevail on them, they send embassadors to Dumnorix the Aeduan, that through his intercession, they might obtain their request from the Sequani.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since they could not persuade the Sequani on their own, they sent envoys to Dumnorix the Haeduan, so that through his mediation they might obtain permission from the Sequani.

sentences.latin: Dumnorix gratia et largitione apud Sequanos plurimum poterat et Helvetiis erat amicus, quod ex ea civitate Orgetorigis filiam in matrimonium duxerat, et cupiditate regni adductus novis rebus studebat et quam plurimas civitates suo beneficio habere obstrictas volebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Dumnorix by favor and bribery among the Sequani very much was able and to the Helvetii was a friend, because from that state Orgetorix's daughter into marriage he had led, and by desire of kingship influenced for new things he was eager and as many as possible states by his own kindness to have bound he was wishing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Dumnorix, by his popularity and liberality, had great influence among the Sequani, and was friendly to the Helvetii, because out of that state he had married the daughter of Orgetorix; and, incited by lust of sovereignty, was anxious for a revolution, and wished to have as many states as possible attached to him by his kindness toward them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Dumnorix had great influence among the Sequani through his popularity and bribery, and he was a friend to the Helvetii because he had married the daughter of Orgetorix. Driven by a desire for sovereignty, he was anxious for a revolution and wanted to have as many states as possible bound to him by his favors.

sentences.latin: Itaque rem suscipit et a Sequanis impetrat ut per fines suos Helvetios ire patiantur, obsidesque uti inter sese dent perficit: Sequani, ne itinere Helvetios prohibeant, Helvetii, ut sine maleficio et iniuria transeant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so the matter he undertakes and from the Sequani he obtains that through borders their own the Helvetii to go they should allow, and hostages that between themselves they should give he brings about: the Sequani, lest from the journey the Helvetii they should prohibit, the Helvetii, so that without mischief and injury they might cross.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He, therefore, undertakes the affair, and prevails upon the Sequani to allow the Helvetii to march through their territories, and arranges that they should give hostages to each other - the Sequani not to obstruct the Helvetii in their march - the Helvetii, to pass without mischief and outrage.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he took up the matter and persuaded the Sequani to allow the Helvetii to pass through their territory. He also arranged for them to exchange hostages: the Sequani to ensure they would not block the Helvetii's march, and the Helvetii to ensure they would cross without causing damage or injury.

sentences.latin: Caesari renuntiatur Helvetiis esse in animo per agrum Sequanorum et Haeduorum iter in Santonum fines facere, qui non longe a Tolosatium finibus absunt, quae civitas est in provincia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To Caesar it is reported to the Helvetii to be in mind through the land of the Sequani and Haedui a journey into the Santoni's borders to make, which not far from the Tolosates' borders are distant, which state is in the province.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is again told Caesar, that the Helvetii intended to march through the country of the Sequani and the Aedui into the territories of the Santones, which are not far distant from those boundaries of the Tolosates, which [viz.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar was informed that the Helvetii intended to march through the territory of the Sequani and the Haedui into the lands of the Santoni, which are not far from the borders of the Tolosates, a tribe within the Roman province.

sentences.latin: Id si fieret, intellegebat magno cum periculo provinciae futurum ut homines bellicosos, populi Romani inimicos, locis patentibus maximeque frumentariis finitimos haberet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This if it should happen, he was understanding with great danger of the province it would be that men warlike, of the people Roman enemies, in places open and especially grain-producing as neighbors he should have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Tolosa, Toulouse] is a state in the Province.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He realized that if this happened, it would be very dangerous for the province to have warlike men, who were enemies of the Roman people, as neighbors in an open and highly productive grain-growing region.

sentences.latin: Ob eas causas ei munitioni quam fecerat T. Labienum legatum praeficit; ipse in Italiam magnis itineribus contendit duasque ibi legiones conscribit et tres, quae circum Aquileiam hiemabant, ex hibernis educit et, qua proximum iter in ulteriorem Galliam per Alpes erat, cum his quinque legionibus ire contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For these reasons to that fortification which he had made Titus Labienus the legate he puts in charge; himself into Italy by great marches hastens and two there legions enrolls and three, which around Aquileia were wintering, from winter quarters leads out and, where nearest route into farther Gaul through the Alps was, with these five legions to go he hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If this took place, he saw that it would be attended with great danger to the Province to have warlike men, enemies of the Roman people, bordering upon an open and very fertile tract of country. For these reasons he appointed Titus Labienus, his lieutenant, to the command of the fortification which he had made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For these reasons, he put the legate Titus Labienus in charge of the fortification he had built; he himself hastened to Italy by forced marches, enrolled two legions there, and led out from winter quarters three more that were wintering around Aquileia. Then, where the shortest route to Farther Gaul lay through the Alps, he hastened to march with these five legions.

sentences.latin: Ibi Ceutrones et Graioceli et Caturiges locis superioribus occupatis itinere exercitum prohibere conantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There the Ceutrones and Graioceli and Caturiges the places higher having been occupied from the march the army to prohibit try.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself proceeds to Italy by forced marches, and there levies two legions, and leads out from winter-quarters three which were wintering around Aquileia, and with these five legions marches rapidly by the nearest route across the Alps into Further Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There the Ceutrones, Graioceli, and Caturiges, having occupied the higher ground, attempted to block the army's march.

sentences.latin: Compluribus his proeliis pulsis ab Ocelo, quod estoppidumciterioris provinciae extremum, in fines Vocontiorum ulterioris provinciae die septimo pervenit; inde in Allobrogum fines, ab Allobrogibus in Segusiavos exercitum ducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several these in battles having been repulsed from Ocelum, which is a town of the hither province furthest, into the borders of the Vocontii of the farther province on day seventh he arrived; from there into of the Allobroges borders, from the Allobroges into the Segusiavi the army he leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Here the Centrones and the Graioceli and the Caturiges, having taken possession of the higher parts, attempt to obstruct the army in their march.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After repulsing these groups in several battles, he arrived from Ocelumthe last town of the Nearer Provinceat the borders of the Vocontii in the Farther Province on the seventh day. From there, he led his army into the territory of the Allobroges, and from the Allobroges to the Segusiavi.

sentences.latin: Hi sunt extra provinciam trans Rhodanum primi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These are outside the province across the Rhone first.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After having routed these in several battles, he arrives in the territories of the Vocontii in the Further Province on the seventh day from Ocelum, which is the most remote town of the Hither Province; thence he leads his army into the country of the Allobroges, and from the Allobroges to the Segusiani.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These are the first people outside the province across the Rhone.

sentences.latin: Helvetii iam per angustias et fines Sequanorum suas copias traduxerant et in Haeduorum fines pervenerant eorumque agros populabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetii already through the narrows and borders of the Sequani their forces had led across and into of the Haedui borders had arrived and their fields were pillaging.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] The Helvetii had by this time led their forces over through the narrow defile and the territories of the Sequani, and had arrived at the territories of the Aedui, and were ravaging their lands.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Helvetii had already led their forces through the narrow pass and the territory of the Sequani, had reached the borders of the Haedui, and were plundering their lands.

sentences.latin: Haedui, cum se suaque ab iis defendere non possent, legatos ad Caesarem mittunt rogatum auxilium:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Haedui, when themselves and their things from them to defend not they were able, envoys to Caesar send to ask help:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] The Helvetii had by this time led their forces over through the narrow defile and the territories of the Sequani, and had arrived at the territories of the Aedui, and were ravaging their lands.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Haedui, since they could not defend themselves or their property from them, sent envoys to Caesar to ask for help:

sentences.latin: ita se omni tempore de populo Romano meritos esse ut paene in conspectu exercitus nostri agri vastari, liberi [eorum] in servitutem abduci, oppida expugnari non debuerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so themselves at every time of the people Roman to have deserved that almost in sight of army our fields to be devastated, children [their] into slavery to be led away, towns to be stormed not they ought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Aedui, as they could not defend themselves and their possessions against them, send embassadors to Caesar to ask assistance, [pleading] that they had at all times so well deserved of the Roman people, that their fields ought not to have been laid waste - their children carried off into slavery - their towns stormed, almost within sight of our army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: stating that they had always deserved so well of the Roman people that their fields ought not to be devastated, their children led into slavery, and their towns stormed almost within sight of our army.

sentences.latin: Eodem temporequoHaedui Ambarri, necessarii et consanguinei Haeduorum, Caesarem certiorem faciunt sese depopulatis agris non facile ab oppidis vim hostium prohibere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time in which the Haedui the Ambarri, kinsmen and blood-relations of the Haedui, Caesar more certain make themselves having been devastated fields not easily from the towns the force of the enemies to prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] At the same time the Ambarri, the friends and kinsmen of the Aedui, apprize Caesar, that it was not easy for them, now that their fields had been devastated, to ward off the violence of the enemy from their towns: the Allobroges likewise, who had villages and possessions on the other side of the Rhone, betake themselves in flight to Caesar, and assure him that they had nothing remaining, except the soil of their land.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time as the Haedui, the Ambarrikinsmen and relatives of the Haeduiinformed Caesar that their fields had been devastated and they could not easily keep the enemy's violence away from their towns.

sentences.latin: Item Allobroges, qui trans Rhodanum vicos possessionesque habebant, fuga se ad Caesarem recipiunt et demonstrant sibi praeter agri solum nihil esse reliqui.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Likewise the Allobroges, who across the Rhone villages and possessions were having, by flight themselves to Caesar betake and show to themselves except of the field the soil nothing to be of remaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] At the same time the Ambarri, the friends and kinsmen of the Aedui, apprize Caesar, that it was not easy for them, now that their fields had been devastated, to ward off the violence of the enemy from their towns: the Allobroges likewise, who had villages and possessions on the other side of the Rhone, betake themselves in flight to Caesar, and assure him that they had nothing remaining, except the soil of their land.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Likewise, the Allobroges, who had villages and possessions across the Rhone, fled to Caesar and pointed out that they had nothing left except the bare soil of their fields.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus adductus Caesar non expectandum sibi statuit dum, omnibus, fortunis sociorum consumptis, in Santonos Helvetii pervenirent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which things influenced Caesar not to be waited for by him decided until, all fortunes of the allies having been consumed, into the Santoni the Helvetii should arrive.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, induced by these circumstances, decides, that he ought not to wait until the Helvetii, after destroying all the property of his allies, should arrive among the Santones.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by these events, Caesar decided that he should not wait until the Helvetii reached the Santoni after all the resources of his allies had been exhausted.

sentences.latin: Flumen est Arar, quod per fines Haeduorum et Sequanorum in Rhodanum influit, incredibili lenitate, ita ut oculis in utram partem fluat iudicari non possit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A river is the Arar, which through the borders of the Haedui and Sequani into the Rhone flows, with incredible slowness, so that by eyes into which part it flows to be judged not it is able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There is a river [called] the Saone, which flows through the territories of the Aedui and Sequani into the Rhone with such incredible slowness, that it can not be determined by the eye in which direction it flows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There is a river called the Arar, which flows through the territory of the Haedui and Sequani into the Rhone with such incredible slowness that it cannot be determined by the eye in which direction it flows.

sentences.latin: Id Helvetii ratibus ac lintribus iunctis transibant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It the Helvetii by rafts and boats joined were crossing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This the Helvetii were crossing by rafts and boats joined together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Helvetii were crossing it by means of rafts and boats joined together.

sentences.latin: Ubi per exploratores Caesar certior factus est tres iam partes copiarum Helvetios id flumen traduxisse, quartam vero partem citra flumen Ararim reliquam esse, de tertia vigilia cum legionibus tribus e castris profectus ad eam partem pervenit quae nondum flumen transierat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When through scouts Caesar more certain was made three already parts of forces the Helvetii that river to have led across, fourth indeed part on this side of the river Arar remaining to be, from the third watch with legions three from the camp having set out to that part he arrived which not yet the river had crossed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When Caesar was informed by spies that the Helvetii had already conveyed three parts of their forces across that river, but that the fourth part was left behind on this side of the Saone, he set out from the camp with three legions during the third watch, and came up with that division which had not yet crossed the river.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar was informed by scouts that the Helvetii had already led three-quarters of their forces across that river, but that the fourth part remained on this side of the Arar, he set out from camp during the third watch with three legions and reached the part that had not yet crossed the river.

sentences.latin: Eos impeditos et inopinantes adgressus magnam partem eorum concidit; reliqui sese fugae mandarunt atque in proximas silvas abdiderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Them encumbered and not expecting having attacked a great part of them he cut down; the rest themselves to flight committed and into the nearest woods hid.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Attacking them encumbered with baggage, and not expecting him, he cut to pieces a great part of them; the rest betook themselves to flight, and concealed themselves in the nearest woods.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Attacking them while they were encumbered and off-guard, he cut down a great number of them; the rest took to flight and hid themselves in the nearest woods.

sentences.latin: Is pagus appellabatur Tigurinus; nam omnis civitas Helvetia in quattuor pagos divisa est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This canton was called Tigurinus; for all the state Helvetian into four cantons divided is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That canton [which was cut down] was called the Tigurine; for the whole Helvetian state is divided into four cantons.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This canton was called the Tigurine; for the whole Helvetian state is divided into four cantons.

sentences.latin: Hic pagus unus, cum domo exisset, patrum nostrorum memoria L. Cassium consulem interfecerat et eius exercitum sub iugum miserat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This canton alone, when from home it had gone out, of fathers our in memory Lucius Cassius the consul had killed and his army under the yoke had sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This single canton having left their country, within the recollection of our fathers, had slain Lucius Cassius the consul, and had made his army pass under the yoke.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This single canton, when it had left home within the memory of our fathers, had killed the consul Lucius Cassius and sent his army under the yoke.

sentences.latin: Ita sive casu sive consilio deorum immortalium quae pars civitatis Helvetiae insignem calamitatem populo Romano intulerat, ea princeps poenam persolvit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus whether by chance or by design of the gods immortal which part of the state Helvetian a signal calamity on the people Roman had brought, that first the penalty paid.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus, whether by chance, or by the design of the immortal gods, that part of the Helvetian state which had brought a signal calamity upon the Roman people, was the first to pay the penalty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, whether by chance or by the design of the immortal gods, that part of the Helvetian state which had brought a signal disaster upon the Roman people was the first to pay the penalty.

sentences.latin: Qua in re Caesar non solum publicas, sed etiam privatas iniurias ultus est, quod eius soceri L. Pisonis avum, L. Pisonem legatum, Tigurini eodem proelio quo Cassium interfecerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which matter Caesar not only public, but also private injuries avenged, because of his father-in-law Lucius Piso the grandfather, Lucius Piso the legate, the Tigurini in the same battle in which Cassius they had killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In this Caesar avenged not only the public but also his own personal wrongs, because the Tigurini had slain Lucius Piso the lieutenant [of Cassius], the grandfather of Lucius Calpurnius Piso, his [Caesar's] father-in-law, in the same battle as Cassius himself.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this matter, Caesar avenged not only public but also private wrongs, because the Tigurini had killed the legate Lucius Piso, the grandfather of his father-in-law Lucius Piso, in the same battle in which they killed Cassius.

sentences.latin: Hoc proelio facto, reliquas copias Helvetiorum ut consequi posset, pontem in Arari faciendum curat atque ita exercitum traducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This battle having been done, the remaining forces of the Helvetii so that he might follow, a bridge on the Arar to be made he cares for and thus the army leads across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] This battle ended, that he might be able to come up with the remaining forces of the Helvetii, he procures a bridge to be made across the Saone, and thus leads his army over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this battle was over, in order to pursue the remaining forces of the Helvetii, he arranged for a bridge to be built over the Arar and thus led his army across.

sentences.latin: Helvetii repentino eius adventu commoti cum id quod ipsi diebus XX aegerrime confecerant, ut flumen transirent, illum uno die fecisse intellegerent, legatos ad eum mittunt; cuius legationis Divico princeps fuit, qui bello Cassiano dux Helvetiorum fuerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetii by the sudden his arrival moved when that which themselves in days 20 with great difficulty had accomplished, that the river they cross, him in one day to have done they understood, envoys to him they send; of which embassy Divico the leader was, who in the war Cassian leader of the Helvetii had been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] This battle ended, that he might be able to come up with the remaining forces of the Helvetii, he procures a bridge to be made across the Saone, and thus leads his army over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Helvetii, alarmed by his sudden arrival, when they realized that he had done in a single day what they themselves had accomplished with great difficulty in twenty daysnamely, crossing the riversent envoys to him. Divico, who had been the leader of the Helvetii during the war with Cassius, was the head of this embassy.

sentences.latin: Is ita cum Caesare egit: si pacem populus Romanus cum Helvetiis faceret, in eam partem ituros atque ibi futuros Helvetios ubi eos Caesar constituisset atque esse voluisset;
sentences.referenceTranslation: He thus with Caesar treated: if peace the people Roman with the Helvetians should make, into that part would go and there would be the Helvetians where them Caesar had established and to be had wished;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetii, confused by his sudden arrival, when they found that he had effected in one day, what they, themselves had with the utmost difficulty accomplished in twenty namely, the crossing of the river, send embassadors to him; at the head of which embassy was Divico, who had been commander of the Helvetii, in the war against Cassius.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He addressed Caesar as follows: if the Roman people would make peace with the Helvetians, the Helvetians would go to and remain in whatever place Caesar assigned and desired them to be;

sentences.latin: sin bello persequi perseveraret, reminisceretur et veteris incommodi populi Romani et pristinae virtutis Helvetiorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but if in war to pursue he should persist, he should remember both the old setback of the people Roman and the former valor of the Helvetians.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He thus treats with Caesar: - that, "if the Roman people would make peace with the Helvetii they would go to that part and there remain, where Caesar might appoint and desire them to be; but if he should persist in persecuting them with war that he ought to remember both the ancient disgrace of the Roman people and the characteristic valor of the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but if he persisted in pursuing them in war, he should remember both the old disaster of the Roman people and the ancient valor of the Helvetians.

sentences.latin: Quod improviso unum pagum adortus esset, cum ii qui flumen transissent suis auxilium ferre non possent, ne ob eam rem aut suae magnopere virtuti tribueret aut ipsos despiceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As to the fact that unexpectedly one canton he had attacked, when those who the river had crossed to their own help to bring were not able, let him not on account of that thing either to his own greatly valor attribute or themselves despise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He thus treats with Caesar: - that, "if the Roman people would make peace with the Helvetii they would go to that part and there remain, where Caesar might appoint and desire them to be; but if he should persist in persecuting them with war that he ought to remember both the ancient disgrace of the Roman people and the characteristic valor of the Helvetii.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As for his unexpected attack on a single canton while those who had crossed the river could not help their comrades, he should not attribute this too much to his own prowess or look down on them.

sentences.latin: Se ita a patribus maioribusque suis didicisse, ut magis virtute contenderent quam dolo aut insidiis niterentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That they thus from fathers and ancestors their own had learned, that more by valor they should contend than by craft or by ambushes they should rely.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As to his having attacked one canton by surprise, [at a time] when those who had crossed the river could not bring assistance to their friends, that he ought not on that account to ascribe very much to his own valor, or despise them; that they had so learned from their sires and ancestors, as to rely more on valor than on artifice and stratagem.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had learned from their fathers and ancestors to fight more by courage than to rely on trickery or ambush.

sentences.latin: Quare ne committeret ut is locus ubi constitissent ex calamitate populi Romani et internecione exercitus nomen caperet aut memoriam proderet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore let him not allow that that place where they had stood from the calamity of the people Roman and the slaughter of the army a name should take or the memory hand down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Wherefore let him not bring it to pass that the place, where they were standing, should acquire a name, from the disaster of the Roman people and the destruction of their army or transmit the remembrance [of such an event to posterity]."
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he should not allow the place where they stood to take its name from a Roman disaster and the destruction of an army, or to pass down such a memory.

sentences.latin: His Caesar ita respondit: eo sibi minus dubitationis dari, quod eas res quas legati Helvetii commemorassent memoria teneret, atque eo gravius ferre quo minus merito populi Romani accidissent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these Caesar thus responded: for this reason to him less of doubt to be given, because those things which the envoys Helvetian had mentioned in memory he held, and for this reason more heavily to bear by how much less by the merit of the people Roman they had happened;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] To these words Caesar thus replied: - that "on that very account he felt less hesitation, because he kept in remembrance those circumstances which the Helvetian embassadors had mentioned, and that he felt the more indignant at them, in proportion as they had happened undeservedly to the Roman people: for if they had been conscious of having done any wrong, it would not have been difficult to be on their guard, but for that very reason had they been deceived, because neither were they aware that any offense had been given by them, on account of which they should be afraid, nor did they think that they ought to be afraid without cause.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar replied to them as follows: he felt less hesitation because he remembered the events the Helvetian envoys mentioned, and he took them more to heart because they had happened through no fault of the Roman people;

sentences.latin: qui si alicuius iniuriae sibi conscius fuisset, non fuisse difficile cavere; sed eo deceptum, quod neque commissum a se intellegeret quare timeret neque sine causa timendum putaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who if of any injury to itself conscious it had been, not to have been difficult to be on guard; but by this deceived, because neither committed by itself it understood why it should fear nor without cause to be feared it thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] To these words Caesar thus replied: - that "on that very account he felt less hesitation, because he kept in remembrance those circumstances which the Helvetian embassadors had mentioned, and that he felt the more indignant at them, in proportion as they had happened undeservedly to the Roman people: for if they had been conscious of having done any wrong, it would not have been difficult to be on their guard, but for that very reason had they been deceived, because neither were they aware that any offense had been given by them, on account of which they should be afraid, nor did they think that they ought to be afraid without cause.
sentences.naturalTranslation: if the Roman people had been aware of any wrongdoing on their part, it would not have been difficult to be on guard; but they were deceived because they did not realize they had done anything to fear, nor did they think they should fear without reason.

sentences.latin: Quod si veteris contumeliae oblivisci vellet, num etiam recentium iniuriarum, quod eo invito iter per provinciam per vim temptassent, quod Haeduos, quod Ambarros, quod Allobrogas vexassent, memoriam deponere posse?
