sentences.referenceTranslation: But if of the old insult to forget he were willing, whether also of recent injuries, because him unwilling a journey through the province by force they had attempted, because the Haedui, because the Ambarri, because the Allobroges they had harassed, the memory to lay aside he was able?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] But even if he were willing to forget their former outrage, could he also lay aside the remembrance of the late wrongs, in that they had against his will attempted a route through the Province by force, in that they had molested the Aedui, the Ambarri, and the Allobroges?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Even if he were willing to forget the old insult, could he also set aside the memory of recent outragestheir attempt to force a way through the province against his will, and their harassment of the Haedui, the Ambarri, and the Allobroges?

sentences.latin: Quod sua victoria tam insolenter gloriarentur quodque tam diu se impune iniurias tulisse admirarentur, eodem pertinere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That in their victory so insolently they boasted and that so long themselves with impunity injuries to have inflicted they wondered, to the same thing tended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] But even if he were willing to forget their former outrage, could he also lay aside the remembrance of the late wrongs, in that they had against his will attempted a route through the Province by force, in that they had molested the Aedui, the Ambarri, and the Allobroges?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their insolent boasting about their victory and their surprise that they had committed outrages for so long with impunity both pointed to the same conclusion.

sentences.latin: Consuesse enim deos immortales, quo gravius homines ex commutatione rerum doleant, quos pro scelere eorum ulcisci velint, his secundiores interdum res et diuturniorem impunitatem concedere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To have been accustomed for the gods immortal, by which more heavily men from a change of things might grieve, whom for the crime of them to punish they might wish, to these more favorable sometimes things and longer impunity to grant.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] That as to their so insolently boasting of their victory, and as to their being astonished that they had so long committed their outrages with impunity, [both these things] tended to the same point; for the immortal gods are wont to allow those persons whom they wish to punish for their guilt sometimes a greater prosperity and longer impunity, in order that they may suffer the more severely from a reverse of circumstances.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the immortal gods are accustomed, in order that men may suffer more severely from a change of fortune, to sometimes grant prosperity and longer impunity to those whom they wish to punish for their crimes.

sentences.latin: Cum ea ita sint, tamen, si obsides ab iis sibi dentur, uti ea quae polliceantur facturos intellegat, et si Haeduis de iniuriis quas ipsis sociisque eorum intulerint, item si Allobrogibus satis faciunt, sese cum iis pacem esse facturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Although these things so are, nevertheless, if hostages by them to him should be given, so that those things which they promise they will do he might understand, and if to the Haedui concerning the injuries which to themselves and to the allies of them they brought, likewise if to the Allobroges satisfaction they make, he with them peace would make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] That as to their so insolently boasting of their victory, and as to their being astonished that they had so long committed their outrages with impunity, [both these things] tended to the same point; for the immortal gods are wont to allow those persons whom they wish to punish for their guilt sometimes a greater prosperity and longer impunity, in order that they may suffer the more severely from a reverse of circumstances.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although this was the case, he would still make peace with them if they gave him hostages to show they would perform their promises, and if they gave satisfaction to the Haedui for the injuries inflicted on them and their allies, and likewise to the Allobroges.

sentences.latin: Divico respondit: ita Helvetios a maioribus suis institutos esse uti obsides accipere, non dare, consuerint; eius rei populum Romanum esse testem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Divico responded: thus the Helvetians by ancestors their own to have been trained that hostages to receive, not to give, they were accustomed; of that thing the people Roman to be a witness.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Although these things are so, yet, if hostages were to be given him by them in order that he may be assured these will do what they promise, and provided they will give satisfaction to the Aedui for the outrages which they had committed against them and their allies, and likewise to the Allobroges, he [Caesar] will make peace with them." Divico replied, that "the Helvetii had been so trained by their ancestors, that they were accustomed to receive, not to give hostages; of that fact the Roman people were witness." Having given this reply, he withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Divico replied: the Helvetians had been so trained by their ancestors that they were accustomed to receive hostages, not to give them; the Roman people were witnesses to this.

sentences.latin: Hoc responso dato discessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This response having been given he departed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Although these things are so, yet, if hostages were to be given him by them in order that he may be assured these will do what they promise, and provided they will give satisfaction to the Aedui for the outrages which they had committed against them and their allies, and likewise to the Allobroges, he [Caesar] will make peace with them." Divico replied, that "the Helvetii had been so trained by their ancestors, that they were accustomed to receive, not to give hostages; of that fact the Roman people were witness." Having given this reply, he withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having given this reply, he departed.

sentences.latin: Postero die castra ex eo loco movent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day the camp from that place they move.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On the following day they move their camp from that place; Caesar does the same, and sends forward all his cavalry, to the number of four thousand (which he had drawn together from all parts of the Province and from the Aedui and their allies), to observe toward what parts the enemy are directing their march.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day they moved their camp from that spot.

sentences.latin: Idem facit Caesar equitatumque omnem, ad numerum quattuor milium, quem ex omni provincia et Haeduis atque eorum sociis coactum habebat, praemittit, qui videant quas in partes hostes iter faciant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The same thing does Caesar and the cavalry all, to the number of four thousand, which from every province and the Haedui and their allies collected he had, he sends ahead, who might see into which parts the enemy a journey were making.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On the following day they move their camp from that place; Caesar does the same, and sends forward all his cavalry, to the number of four thousand (which he had drawn together from all parts of the Province and from the Aedui and their allies), to observe toward what parts the enemy are directing their march.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar did the same and sent ahead all the cavalry, numbering four thousand, which he had collected from the whole province and from the Haedui and their allies, to see in what direction the enemy were marching.

sentences.latin: Qui cupidius novissimum agmen insecuti alieno loco cum equitatu Helvetiorum proelium committunt; et pauci de nostris cadunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who too eagerly the rear column having followed in an unfavorable place with the cavalry of the Helvetians battle join; and a few of ours fall.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These, having too eagerly pursued the enemy's rear, come to a battle with the cavalry of the Helvetii in a disadvantageous place, and a few of our men fall.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These followed the rear guard too eagerly and engaged in battle with the Helvetian cavalry on unfavorable ground; a few of our men fell.

sentences.latin: Quo proelio sublati Helvetii, quod quingentis equitibus tantam multitudinem equitum propulerant, audacius subsistere non numquam et novissimo agmine proelio nostros lacessere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which battle elated the Helvetians, because with five hundred horsemen so great a multitude of horsemen they had driven back, more boldly to halt sometimes and with the rear column in battle our men to provoke began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetii, elated with this battle, because they had with five hundred horse repulsed so large a body of horse, began to face us more boldly, sometimes too from their rear to provoke our men by an attack.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Elated by this battle, because they had driven back so large a force of cavalry with only five hundred horsemen, the Helvetians began to halt more boldly at times and to provoke our men to battle with their rear guard.

sentences.latin: Caesar suos a proelio continebat, ac satis habebat in praesentia hostem rapinis, pabulationibus populationibusque prohibere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar his own from battle was restraining, and enough he held for the present the enemy from plunderings, foraging, and ravaging to prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar [however] restrained his men from battle, deeming it sufficient for the present to prevent the enemy from rapine, forage, and depredation.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar kept his men from battle, and for the time being he considered it sufficient to prevent the enemy from plundering, foraging, and ravaging.

sentences.latin: Ita dies circiter XV iter fecerunt uti inter novissimum hostium agmen et nostrum primum non amplius quinis aut senis milibus passuum interesset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus for days about fifteen a journey they made so that between the rear of the enemy column and our front not more than five or six thousands of paces there was between.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They marched for about fifteen days in such a manner that there was not more than five or six miles between the enemy's rear and our van.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They marched in this way for about fifteen days, so that there was no more than five or six miles between the enemy's rear guard and our vanguard.

sentences.latin: Interim cotidie Caesar Haeduos frumentum, quod essent publice polliciti, flagitare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile daily Caesar the Haedui for grain, which they had publicly promised, was demanding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 3x] Meanwhile, Caesar kept daily importuning the Aedui for the corn which they had promised in the name of their state; for, in consequence of the coldness (Gaul, being as before said, situated toward the north), not only was the corn in the fields not ripe, but there was not in store a sufficiently large quantity even of fodder: besides he was unable to use the corn which he had conveyed in ships up the river Saone, because the Helvetii, from whom he was unwilling to retire had diverted their march from the Saone.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Caesar was daily demanding from the Haedui the grain which they had promised in the name of the state.

sentences.latin: Nam propter frigora [quod Gallia sub septentrionibus, ut ante dictum est, posita est,] non modo frumenta in agris matura non erant, sed ne pabuli quidem satis magna copia suppetebat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For on account of the colds [because Gaul under the north, as before has been said, is placed,] not only the grains in the fields ripe were not, but not even of fodder indeed a sufficiently large supply was available;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For on account of the colds [because Gaul under the north, as before has been said, is placed,] not only the grains in the fields ripe were not, but not even of fodder indeed a sufficiently large supply was available;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For because of the cold (since Gaul is located in the north, as previously mentioned), not only was the grain in the fields not yet ripe, but there was not even a sufficient supply of fodder available.

sentences.latin: eo autem frumento quod flumine Arari navibus subvexerat propterea uti minus poterat quod iter ab Arari Helvetii averterant, a quibus discedere nolebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that however grain which by the river Arar in ships he had conveyed up for this reason to use less he was able because the march from the Arar the Helvetii had turned away, from whom to depart he was unwilling.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by that however grain which by the river Arar in ships he had conveyed up for this reason to use less he was able because the march from the Arar the Helvetii had turned away, from whom to depart he was not wishing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, he was less able to use the grain which he had brought up the Arar in ships because the Helvetii had turned their march away from the river, and he was unwilling to leave them.

sentences.latin: Diem ex die ducere Haedui: conferri, comportari, adesse dicere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Day from day to lead [on] the Haedui: to be collected, to be brought together, to be at hand they were saying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Day from day to lead the Haedui: to be collected, to be brought together, to be at hand they were saying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Haedui kept putting him off day after day, saying that the grain was being collected, was being brought in, and was nearly there.

sentences.latin: Ubi se diutius duci intellexit et diem instare quo die frumentum militibus metiri oporteret, convocatis eorum principibus, quorum magnam copiam in castris habebat, in his Diviciaco et Lisco, qui summo magistratui praeerat, quem vergobretum appellant Haedui, qui creatur annuus et vitae necisque in suos habet potestatem, graviter eos accusat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When himself longer to be led [on] he understood and the day to be pressing on which day grain to the soldiers to measure out it behooved, having been called together of them the leading men, of whom a large number in the camp he was having, among these Diviciacus and Liscus, who over the highest magistracy was presiding, whom vergobretus call the Haedui, who is created annually and of life and of death over his own [people] has power, severely them he accuses,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When himself longer to be led he understood and the day to be near on which day grain to the soldiers to measure out it was necessary, having been called together of them the chiefs, of whom a large number in the camp he was having, among these Diviciacus and Liscus, who over the highest magistrate was presiding, whom vergobretus call the Haedui, who is created annually and of life and of death over his own has power, heavily them he accuses,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he realized he was being put off for too long and that the day was approaching on which he was required to measure out grain to the soldiers, he summoned their leading men, many of whom he had in camp, including Diviciacus and Liscus, who held the highest office (whom the Haedui call the Vergobret, who is elected annually and holds the power of life and death over his people); he severely censured them,

sentences.latin: quod, cum neque emi neque ex agris sumi possit, tam necessario tempore, tam propinquis hostibus ab iis non sublevetur, praesertim cum magna ex parte eorum precibus adductus bellum susceperit[; multo etiam gravius quod sit destitutus queritur].
sentences.referenceTranslation: because, since neither to be bought nor from the fields to be taken it is able, at so necessary a time, with so near enemies by them he is not assisted, especially since in large part by their prayers influenced the war he undertook; much even more severely that he has been abandoned he complains.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because, when neither to be bought nor from the fields to be taken it is able, at so necessary a time, so near the enemies by them not he is helped, especially since in large part by their prayers having been influenced the war he undertook; much even more heavily that he has been abandoned he complains.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because, since grain could neither be purchased nor taken from the fields, he was not being supported by them at such a critical time and with the enemy so near, especially since he had undertaken the war largely at their request; he complained even more bitterly that he had been abandoned.

sentences.latin: Tum demum Liscus oratione Caesaris adductus quod antea tacuerat proponit: esse non nullos, quorum auctoritas apud plebem plurimum valeat, qui privatim plus possint quam ipsi magistratus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then at last Liscus by the speech of Caesar influenced what before he had kept silent sets forth: to be some, whose authority among the common people very much is strong, who privately more are able than the themselves magistrates.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then finally Liscus by the speech of Caesar influenced what before he had kept silent sets forth: to be some, whose authority among the common people very much is strong, who privately more are able than the themselves magistrates.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then at last, moved by Caesar's speech, Liscus revealed what he had previously kept secret: that there were some individuals whose influence with the common people was very great, and who had more power as private citizens than the magistrates themselves.

sentences.latin: Hos seditiosa atque improba oratione multitudinem deterrere, ne frumentum conferant quod debeant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: These by seditious and wicked speech the multitude to deter, lest grain they bring together which they owe:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These by seditious and wicked speech the multitude to deter, lest grain they bring together which they owe:
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men, by seditious and wicked talk, were deterring the masses from bringing in the grain they were required to provide:

sentences.latin: praestare, si iam principatum Galliae obtinere non possint, Gallorum quam Romanorum imperia perferre,
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be better, if now the leadership of Gaul to obtain they are not able, of Gauls than of Romans the commands to endure,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to be better, if now the supremacy of Gaul to obtain not they are able, of Gauls than of Romans the commands to endure,
sentences.naturalTranslation: saying it was better, if they could no longer hold the sovereignty of Gaul, to endure the rule of Gauls rather than Romans,

sentences.latin: neque dubitare [debeant] quin, si Helvetios superaverint Romani, una cum reliqua Gallia Haeduis libertatem sint erepturi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor to doubt [they ought] but that, if the Helvetii have overcome the Romans, together with the rest of Gaul from the Haedui liberty they are about to snatch away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not to doubt [they ought] but that, if the Helvetii they overcome the Romans, together with the rest of Gaul from the Haedui liberty they are about to take away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and that they should not doubt that, if the Romans defeated the Helvetii, they would strip the Haedui of their liberty along with the rest of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Ab isdem nostra consilia quaeque in castris gerantur hostibus enuntiari; hos a se coerceri non posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the same [men] our plans and what in the camp are done to the enemies are reported; these by him to be restrained not to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the same our plans and what in the camp are done to the enemies are reported; these by him to be restrained not to be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said that our plans and everything done in camp were reported to the enemy by these same men, and that he was unable to restrain them.

sentences.latin: Quin etiam, quod necessariam rem coactus Caesari enuntiarit, intellegere sese quanto id cum periculo fecerit, et ob eam causam quam diu potuerit tacuisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nay even, because a necessary thing compelled to Caesar he has reported, to understand himself with how great it danger he has done, and for that cause as long as he was able to have kept silent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nay even, because the necessary thing forced to Caesar he reported, to understand himself with how great it with danger he did, and for that cause as long as he was able to have been silent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, he said he understood at what great risk he had reported this necessary matter to Caesar under compulsion, and for that reason he had remained silent as long as he could.

sentences.latin: Caesar hac oratione Lisci Dumnorigem, Diviciaci fratrem, designari sentiebat, sed, quod pluribus praesentibus eas res iactari nolebat, celeriter concilium dimittit, Liscum retinet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar by this speech of Liscus Dumnorix, of Diviciacus the brother, to be pointed out was perceiving, but, because with more [people] present those things to be discussed he was unwilling, quickly the council he dismisses, Liscus he retains.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar by this speech of Liscus Dumnorix, of Diviciacus the brother, to be designated was feeling, but, because with more present those things to be discussed he was not wishing, quickly the council he dismisses, Liscus he retains.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar perceived that Dumnorix, the brother of Diviciacus, was being indicated by this speech of Liscus, but because he did not want these matters discussed with so many people present, he quickly dismissed the council and kept Liscus back.

sentences.latin: Quaerit ex solo ea quae in conventu dixerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He asks from [him] alone those things which in the meeting he had said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He asks from him alone those things which in the meeting he had said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He questioned him in private about the things he had said in the meeting.

sentences.latin: Dicit liberius atque audacius.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He speaks more freely and more boldly.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He speaks more freely and more boldly.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He spoke more freely and boldly.

sentences.latin: Eadem secreto ab aliis quaerit; reperit esse vera:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The same things secretly from others he asks; he finds to be true:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The same things secretly from others he asks; he finds to be true:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar asked others about the same matters in secret; he found them to be true:

sentences.latin: ipsum esse Dumnorigem, summa audacia, magna apud plebem propter liberalitatem gratia, cupidum rerum novarum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the very one to be Dumnorix, of the highest audacity, of great among the common people on account of liberality popularity, desirous of things new.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that the very one was Dumnorix, of the highest audacity, of great among the common people on account of liberality favor, desirous of new things.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that Dumnorix was the very man, a person of extreme audacity, of great popularity among the common people because of his generosity, and eager for a revolution.

sentences.latin: Complures annos portoria reliquaque omnia Haeduorum vectigalia parvo pretio redempta habere, propterea quod illo licente contra liceri audeat nemo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For several years the tolls and the rest all of the Haedui taxes at a small price bought up to have, for the reason that with him bidding against to bid dares no one.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For several years the tolls and the rest all of the Haedui taxes at a small price bought up he has, for the reason that with him bidding against to bid dares no one.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For several years he had held the tolls and all the other taxes of the Haedui farmed out at a low price, because when he bid, no one dared to bid against him.

sentences.latin: His rebus et suam rem familiarem auxisse et facultates ad largiendum magnas comparasse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things both his own property family he had increased and resources for bribing large he had prepared;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things both his own property family he increased and resources for bribing large he prepared;
sentences.naturalTranslation: By these means he had both increased his private fortune and acquired great resources for bribery;

sentences.latin: magnum numerum equitatus suo sumptu semper alere et circum se habere,
sentences.referenceTranslation: a large number of cavalry at his own expense always to maintain and around himself to have,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a large number of cavalry at his own expense always to feed and around himself to have,
sentences.naturalTranslation: he always maintained a large number of cavalry at his own expense and kept them around him,

sentences.latin: neque solum domi, sed etiam apud finitimas civitates largiter posse, atque huius potentiae causa matrem in Biturigibus homini illic nobilissimo ac potentissimo conlocasse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor only at home, but even among neighboring states extensively to be able, and of this power for the sake of [his] mother among the Bituriges to a man there most noble and most powerful to have placed [in marriage];
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not only at home, but even among the neighboring states extensively to be able, and of this power for the sake his mother among the Bituriges to a man there most noble and most powerful he had placed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: and he was powerful not only at home but also among neighboring states, and for the sake of this power he had married his mother to a man of the highest nobility and power among the Bituriges;

sentences.latin: ipsum ex Helvetiis uxorem habere, sororum ex matre et propinquas suas nuptum in alias civitates conlocasse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that he himself from the Helvetians a wife has, his sister from his mother and female relations his to marry into other states he has placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that he himself from the Helvetii a wife has, sisters from his mother and female relatives his to be married into other states he has placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself had a wife from the Helvetians, and he had given his half-sister and his other female relatives in marriage to other states.

sentences.latin: Favere et cupere Helvetiis propter eam adfinitatem, odisse etiam suo nomine Caesarem et Romanos, quod eorum adventu potentia eius deminuta et Diviciacus frater in antiquum locum gratiae atque honoris sit restitutus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To favor and to desire well for the Helvetians on account of that affinity, to hate also on his own account Caesar and the Romans, because by their arrival power his was diminished and Diviciacus his brother into his ancient place of favor and of honor has been restored.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To favor and to desire well for the Helvetii on account of that alliance, to hate also on his own account Caesar and the Romans, because by their arrival power his was diminished and Diviciacus his brother into his ancient place of favor and of honor has been restored.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He favored and supported the Helvetians because of that family connection; he also hated Caesar and the Romans on his own account, because by their arrival his power had been diminished and his brother Diviciacus had been restored to his former position of influence and honor.

sentences.latin: Si quid accidat Romanis, summam in spem per Helvetios regni obtinendi venire; imperio populi Romani non modo de regno, sed etiam de ea quam habeat gratia desperare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If anything should happen to the Romans, into the highest hope through the Helvetians of the kingdom being obtained he comes; under the empire of the people Roman not only concerning the kingdom, but even concerning that which he has influence he despairs.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If anything should happen to the Romans, into the highest hope through the Helvetii of the kingdom being obtained he comes; under the rule of the people Roman not only concerning the kingdom, but even concerning that which he has influence he despairs.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If anything should happen to the Romans, he had the highest hopes of gaining the throne through the Helvetians; but under the rule of the Roman people, he despaired not only of the kingship but even of the influence he currently possessed.

sentences.latin: Reperiebat etiam in quaerendo Caesar, quod proelium equestre adversum paucis ante diebus esset factum, initium eius fugae factum a Dumnorige atque eius equitibus (nam equitatui, quem auxilio Caesari Haedui miserant, Dumnorix praeerat): eorum fuga reliquum esse equitatum perterritum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He was finding also in inquiring Caesar, that as to the battle cavalry unsuccessful a few before days had been made, the beginning of that flight was made by Dumnorix and his horsemen (for the cavalry, which for aid to Caesar the Haedui had sent, Dumnorix was in command of): by their flight that the rest was cavalry terrified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He was finding out also in inquiring, Caesar, that as to the battle cavalry unsuccessful a few before days had been made, the beginning of that flight was made by Dumnorix and his horsemen (for the cavalry, which for aid to Caesar the Haedui had sent, Dumnorix was in command of): by their flight to be the rest of the cavalry terrified.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar also discovered during his inquiry that, regarding the unsuccessful cavalry battle that had occurred a few days before, the start of that flight had been made by Dumnorix and his horsemen (for Dumnorix commanded the cavalry which the Haedui had sent to Caesar's aid); by their flight, the rest of the cavalry had been terrified.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus cognitis, cum ad has suspiciones certissimae res accederent, quod per fines Sequanorum Helvetios traduxisset, quod obsides inter eos dandos curasset, quod ea omnia non modo iniussu suo et civitatis sed etiam inscientibus ipsis fecisset, quod a magistratu Haeduorum accusaretur, satis esse causae arbitrabatur quare in eum aut ipse animadverteret aut civitatem animadvertere iuberet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been learned, when to these suspicions most certain facts were added, that through the borders of the Sequani the Helvetians he had led across, that hostages between them to be given he had cared for, that those all things not only without order his and of the state but even with them being unaware he had done, that by the magistrate of the Haedui he was accused, enough to be of cause he was thinking why against him either he himself should punish or the state to punish he should order.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been learned, when to these suspicions most certain facts were added, that through the territories of the Sequani the Helvetii he had led across, that hostages between them to be given he had cared for, that those all things not only without order his and of the state but even with them being unaware themselves he had done, that by the magistrate of the Haedui he was accused, enough to be of cause he was thinking why against him either he himself should punish or the state to punish he should order.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After learning these things, since most certain facts were added to these suspicionsthat he had led the Helvetians through the territory of the Sequani, that he had arranged for hostages to be exchanged between them, that he had done all these things not only without his own order and that of the state but even without their knowledge, and that he was being accused by the magistrate of the HaeduiCaesar thought there was sufficient reason why he should either punish him himself or order the state to do so.

sentences.latin: His omnibus rebus unum repugnabat, quod Diviciaci fratris summum in populum Romanum studium, summum in se voluntatem, egregiam fidem, iustitiam, temperantiam cognoverat; nam ne eius supplicio Diviciaci animum offenderet verebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these all things one thing was resisting, that of Diviciacus his brother the highest toward the people Roman zeal, the highest toward himself goodwill, excellent loyalty, justice, moderation he had known; for lest by his punishment of Diviciacus the mind he might offend he was fearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These all things one thing was opposing, that of Diviciacus his brother the highest toward the people Roman devotion, the highest toward himself goodwill, excellent loyalty, justice, moderation he had known; for lest by his punishment of Diviciacus the mind he might offend he was fearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One thing stood against all these facts: he knew his brother Diviciacus's supreme devotion to the Roman people, his great goodwill toward himself, and his excellent loyalty, justice, and moderation; for he feared that by punishing Dumnorix he might offend the feelings of Diviciacus.

sentences.latin: Itaque prius quam quicquam conaretur, Diviciacum ad se vocari iubet et, cotidianis interpretibus remotis, per C. Valerium Troucillum, principem Galliae provinciae, familiarem suum, cui summam omnium rerum fidem habebat, cum eo conloquitur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so before than anything he should attempt, Diviciacus to himself to be called he orders and, the daily interpreters having been removed, through C. Valerius Troucillus, a leading man of the Gallic province, an intimate friend his, to whom the highest of all things trust he was having, with him he speaks;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so before than anything he should attempt, Diviciacus to himself to be called he orders and, the everyday interpreters having been removed, through C. Valerius Troucillus, a leading man of the Gallic province, an intimate friend his, to whom the highest of all things trust he was having, with him he speaks;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, before attempting anything, he ordered Diviciacus to be called to him and, having removed the usual interpreters, he spoke with him through Gaius Valerius Troucillus, a leading man of the Gallic province and his own close friend, in whom he had the highest confidence in all matters.

sentences.latin: simul commonefacit quae ipso praesente in concilio [Gallorum] de Dumnorige sint dicta, et ostendit quae separatim quisque de eo apud se dixerit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at the same time he reminds him what things with himself present in the council of the Gauls concerning Dumnorix had been said, and he shows what things separately each one concerning him in his presence had said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time he reminds him what things with himself present in the council of the Gauls concerning Dumnorix have been said, and shows what things separately each person concerning him in his presence has said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, he reminded him of what had been said about Dumnorix in the council of the Gauls while he himself was present, and pointed out what each person had said about him individually in his presence.

sentences.latin: Petit atque hortatur ut sine eius offensione animi vel ipse de eo causa cognita statuat vel civitatem statuere iubeat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He asks and urges that without his offense of mind either he himself concerning him the cause having been learned should decide or the state to decide he should order.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He asks and urges that without his offense of mind either he himself concerning him the cause having been learned should decide or the state to decide he should order.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He requested and urged that, without offending Diviciacus's feelings, he might either pass judgment on him himself after investigating the case or order the state to do so.

sentences.latin: Diviciacus multis cum lacrimis Caesarem complexus obsecrare coepit ne quid gravius in fratrem statueret:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Diviciacus many with tears Caesar having embraced to beseech began lest anything more severe against his brother he should decide:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Diviciacus many with tears Caesar having embraced to beseech began lest anything more severe against his brother he should decide:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Diviciacus, embracing Caesar with many tears, began to beseech him not to pass too severe a sentence against his brother.

sentences.latin: scire se illa esse vera, nec quemquam ex eo plus quam se doloris capere, propterea quod, cum ipse gratia plurimum domi atque in reliqua Gallia, ille minimum propter adulescentiam posset, per se crevisset;
sentences.referenceTranslation: to know himself those things to be true, nor anyone from it more than himself of grief to take, for the reason that, when he himself in influence most at home and in the rest of Gaul, he least on account of youth was able, through him he had grown;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To know himself those things to be true, nor anyone from it more than himself of grief to take, because, when he himself in influence most at home and in the rest of Gaul, he least on account of youth was able, through him he had grown;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said he knew those things were true, and no one felt more grief from it than he did, because while he himself had the greatest influence at home and in the rest of Gaul, and Dumnorix had very little due to his youth, the latter had grown powerful through his help.

sentences.latin: quibus opibus ac nervis non solum ad minuendam gratiam, sed paene ad perniciem suam uteretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which resources and strengths not only for diminishing his influence, but almost for destruction his own he was using.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which resources and strengths not only for diminishing his influence, but almost to destruction his own he was using.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Dumnorix was using these resources and strengths not only to diminish Diviciacus's influence but almost for his destruction.

sentences.latin: Sese tamen et amore fraterno et existimatione vulgi commoveri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself however both by love brotherly and by the opinion of the common people to be moved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Himself however both by love brotherly and by the opinion of the common people to be moved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was, however, moved both by brotherly love and by public opinion.

sentences.latin: Quod si quid ei a Caesare gravius accidisset, cum ipse eum locum amicitiae apud eum teneret, neminem existimaturum non sua voluntate factum; qua ex re futurum uti totius Galliae animi a se averterentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Because if anything to him by Caesar more severe should happen, since he himself that place of friendship with him was holding, no one would think not by his will it was done; from which thing it would be that of all Gaul the minds from him would be turned away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because if anything to him by Caesar more severe should have happened, when he himself that place of friendship with him was holding, no one would think not by his will it was done; from which thing it would be that of all Gaul the minds from him would be turned away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For if anything severe should happen to Dumnorix at Caesar's hands while he himself held such a high place of friendship with him, no one would believe it had not been done with his consent; as a result, the hearts of all Gaul would be turned away from him.

sentences.latin: Haec cum pluribus verbis flens a Caesare peteret, Caesar eius dextram prendit; consolatus rogat finem orandi faciat; tanti eius apud se gratiam esse ostendit uti et rei publicae iniuriam et suum dolorem eius voluntati ac precibus condonet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things when with more words weeping from Caesar he was asking, Caesar his right hand took; having consoled him he asks an end of praying he should make; of so much his with himself the influence to be he shows that both of the republic the injury and his own grief to his will and prayers he pardons.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things when with more words weeping from Caesar he was seeking, Caesar his right hand took; having consoled him he asks an end of praying he should make; of so much his with him influence to be he showed that both of the republic the injury and his own grief to his will and prayers he should pardon.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While he was asking these things of Caesar with many words and tears, Caesar took his right hand; having consoled him, he asked him to end his entreaties. He showed that his influence with him was so great that he would pardon both the injury to the state and his own personal grief for the sake of his wishes and prayers.

sentences.latin: Dumnorigem ad se vocat, fratrem adhibet; quae in eo reprehendat ostendit; quae ipse intellegat, quae civitas queratur proponit; monet ut in reliquum tempus omnes suspiciones vitet; praeterita se Diviciaco fratri condonare dicit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Dumnorix to himself he calls, his brother he brings in; what things in him he blames he shows; what things he himself understands, what things the state complains of he sets forth; he warns that for the remaining time all suspicions he should avoid; past things himself to Diviciacus the brother to pardon he says.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Dumnorix to himself he calls, the brother he brings in; what things in him he blames he shows; what things he himself understands, what things the state complains of he sets forth; he warns that for the remaining time all suspicions he should avoid; the past things himself to Diviciacus the brother to pardon he says.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He summoned Dumnorix to him and brought in his brother; he pointed out what he found fault with in him, set forth what he himself knew and what the state complained of, and warned him to avoid all suspicion in the future. He said that he pardoned the past for the sake of his brother Diviciacus.

sentences.latin: Dumnorigi custodes ponit, ut quae agat, quibuscum loquatur scire possit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For Dumnorix guards he places, so that what things he does, with whom he speaks to know he can.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For Dumnorix guards he places, so that what things he does, with whom he speaks to know he might be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He placed guards over Dumnorix so that he could know what he was doing and with whom he spoke.

sentences.latin: Eodem die ab exploratoribus certior factus hostes sub monte consedisse milia passuum ab ipsius castris octo, qualis esset natura montis et qualis in circuitu ascensus qui cognoscerent misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the same day by scouts more certain made the enemy under a mountain to have settled thousands of paces from his own camp eight, of what sort was the nature of the mountain and of what sort in the circuit the ascent those who should learn he sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the same day by scouts more certain made the enemy under a mountain to have settled thousands of paces from his own camp eight, of what sort was the nature of the mountain and of what sort in the circuit the ascent those who should learn he sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the same day, having been informed by scouts that the enemy had encamped at the foot of a mountain eight miles from his own camp, he sent men to find out the nature of the mountain and what the ascent was like on the other side.

sentences.latin: Renuntiatum est facilem esse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was reported back easy to be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was reported back easy to be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was reported back that it was easy.

sentences.latin: De tertia vigilia T. Labienum, legatum pro praetore, cum duabus legionibus et iis ducibus qui iter cognoverant summum iugum montis ascendere iubet; quid sui consilii sit ostendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: About the third watch T. Labienus, legate with praetorian power, with two legions and those guides who the way had known the highest ridge of the mountain to ascend he orders; what of his plan is he shows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: About the third watch T. Labienus, lieutenant with praetorian powers, with two legions and those guides who the way had known the highest ridge of the mountain to ascend he orders; what of his plan may be he shows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the third watch, he ordered Titus Labienus, his lieutenant-general, to climb to the highest ridge of the mountain with two legions and the guides who had scouted the way; he explained what his plan was.

sentences.latin: Ipse de quarta vigilia eodem itinere quo hostes ierant ad eos contendit equitatumque omnem ante se mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself about the fourth watch by the same route by which the enemies had gone toward them hastened and the cavalry all before himself he sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself from the fourth watch by the same route by which the enemies had gone toward them hastens and the cavalry all before himself sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the fourth watch, he set out toward them by the same route the enemy had taken, sending all the cavalry ahead of him.

sentences.latin: P. Considius, qui rei militaris peritissimus habebatur et in exercitu L. Sullae et postea in M. Crassi fuerat, cum exploratoribus praemittitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: P. Considius, who of military matters most skilled was held and in the army of L. Sulla and afterwards in [that] of M. Crassus had been, with scouts is sent ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: P. Considius, who of military matter most skilled was held and in the army of L. Sulla and afterwards in [that] of M. Crassi had been, with scouts is sent ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Publius Considius, who was considered highly experienced in military affairs and had served in the army of Lucius Sulla and later in that of Marcus Crassus, was sent ahead with the scouts.

sentences.latin: Prima luce, cum summus mons a [Lucio] Labieno teneretur, ipse ab hostium castris non longius mille et quingentis passibus abesset neque, ut postea ex captivis comperit, aut ipsius adventus aut Labieni cognitus esset,
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light, when the top of the mountain by [Lucius] Labienus was being held, he himself from the camp of the enemies not further than a thousand and five hundred paces was away and not, as afterwards from captives he learned, either of himself the arrival or of Labienus known had been,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light, when the top of the mountain by [Lucius] Labienus was being held, he himself from the enemies' camp not farther than a thousand and five hundred paces was away nor, as afterwards from captives he found out, either his own arrival or Labienus's known had been,
sentences.naturalTranslation: At daybreak, while the summit of the mountain was held by Labienus and Caesar himself was no more than a mile and a half from the enemy's camp, andas he later learned from prisonersneither his own arrival nor that of Labienus had been discovered,

sentences.latin: Considius equo admisso ad eum accurrit, dicit montem, quem a Labieno occupari voluerit, ab hostibus teneri: id se a Gallicis armis atque insignibus cognovisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Considius with horse let go to him runs, says the mountain, which by Labienus to be occupied he had wished, by the enemies to be held: that he from Gallic arms and ornaments had recognized.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Considius with horse let go to him runs, says the mountain, which by Labienus to be occupied he had wished, by the enemies is held: this he from Gallic arms and insignias had recognized.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Considius rode up to him at full gallop and reported that the mountain he had wanted Labienus to occupy was held by the enemy; he said he had recognized this by their Gallic weapons and insignia.

sentences.latin: Caesar suas copias in proximum collem subducit, aciem instruit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar his own troops onto the nearest hill draws up, the battle line he forms.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar his own troops onto the nearest hill draws up, the battle line draws up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar withdrew his forces to the nearest hill and formed a line of battle.

sentences.latin: Labienus, ut erat ei praeceptum a Caesare ne proelium committeret, nisi ipsius copiae prope hostium castra visae essent, ut undique uno tempore in hostes impetus fieret, monte occupato nostros expectabat proelioque abstinebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus, as it had been to him commanded by Caesar lest battle he join, unless his own forces near the camp of the enemies seen had been, so that from all sides at one time against the enemies an attack might be made, the mountain having been occupied, our [men] was awaiting and from battle was abstaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus, as it had been to him commanded by Caesar lest battle he join, unless his own troops near the enemies' camp seen were, so that from all sides at one time against the enemies an attack might be made, the mountain having been occupied, our [men] was waiting for and from battle was abstaining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus, having been instructed by Caesar not to join battle unless Caesar's own forces were seen near the enemy's camp, so that an attack might be made from all sides at once, waited for our men after occupying the mountain and refrained from combat.

sentences.latin: Multo denique die per exploratores Caesar cognovit et montem a suis teneri et Helvetios castra, movisse et Considium timore perterritum quod non vidisset pro viso sibi renuntiavisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Late finally in the day through scouts Caesar learned both the mountain by his own [men] to be held and the Helvetians the camp to have moved and Considius by fear terrified what not he had seen as seen to him had reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Late finally in the day through scouts Caesar learned both the mountain by his own [men] to be held and the Helvetians the camp to have moved and Considius by fear terrified what he had not seen as seen to him had reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Late in the day, Caesar finally learned from scouts that the mountain was held by his own men, that the Helvetians had moved camp, and that Considius, struck with fear, had reported seeing what he had not actually seen.

sentences.latin: Eo die quo consuerat intervallo hostes sequitur et milia passuum tria ab eorum castris castra ponit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that day at which he had been accustomed interval the enemies he follows and thousands of paces three from their camp a camp he places.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On that day with which he had been accustomed interval the enemies he follows and miles of paces three from their camp camp he places.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On that day, he followed the enemy at his usual distance and pitched camp three miles from theirs.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei, quod omnino biduum supererat, cum exercitui frumentum metiri oporteret, et quod a Bibracte, oppido Haeduorum longe maximo et copiosissimo, non amplius milibus passuum XVIII aberat, rei frumentariae prospiciendum existimavit;itaqueiter ab Helvetiis avertit ac Bibracte ire contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the day after that day, because altogether two days remained, when for the army grain to measure out it was necessary, and because from Bibracte, a town of the Haedui by far the largest and most well-supplied, not more than miles of paces 18 he was away, for the matter of grain to be provided for he thought; therefore the journey from the Helvetians he turned away and to Bibracte to go he hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the day after that day, because altogether two days remained, when to the army grain to measure out it was necessary, and because from Bibracte, a town of the Haedui by far greatest and most well-supplied, not more than miles of paces 18 he was away, for the matter of grain to be provided for he thought; therefore the journey from the Helvetians he turns away and to Bibracte to go he hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, since only two days remained before the grain ration had to be distributed to the army, and because he was no more than eighteen miles from Bibracte, the largest and wealthiest town of the Haedui, he decided he must provide for the grain supply; accordingly, he turned his march away from the Helvetians and hastened toward Bibracte.

sentences.latin: Ea res per fugitivos L. Aemilii, decurionis equitum Gallorum, hostibus nuntiatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That matter through deserters of L. Aemilius, a decurion of the cavalry of the Gauls, to the enemies is announced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This matter through deserters of L. Aemilius, a decurion of the cavalry of the Gauls, to the enemies is announced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This move was reported to the enemy by deserters from Lucius Aemilius, a captain of the Gallic cavalry.

sentences.latin: Helvetii, seu quod timore perterritos Romanos discedere a se existimarent, eo magis quod pridie superioribus locis occupatis proelium non commisissent, sive eo quod re frumentaria intercludi posse confiderent, commutato consilio atque itinere converso nostros a novissimo agmine insequi ac lacessere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetians, whether because by fear terrified the Romans to depart from them they thought, by that more because on the day before the higher places having been occupied battle not they had joined, or by that because from the matter of grain to be cut off to be able they were confident, the plan having been changed and the journey having been turned, our [men] from the newest line to follow and to harass they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetians, whether because by fear terrified the Romans to depart from them they thought, by that more because on the day before the higher places having been occupied battle they had not joined, or by that because from the matter of grain to be cut off to be able they were confident, the plan having been changed and the route turned, our [men] from the newest line to follow and to harass they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Helvetians, either because they thought the Romans were retreating out of fearespecially since they had not joined battle the day before despite occupying the higher groundor because they believed the Romans could be cut off from their grain supply, changed their plan, reversed their direction, and began to pursue and harass our men from the rear.

sentences.latin: Postquam id animum advertit, copias suas Caesar in proximum collem subduxit equitatumque, qui sustineret hostium petum, misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After that [to] the mind he turned, his own forces Caesar onto the nearest hill withdrew and the cavalry, which might sustain the enemies' attack, he sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After this to the mind he turned, his own troops Caesar onto the nearest hill withdrew and the cavalry, who might sustain the enemies' attack, he sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After he noticed this, Caesar withdrew his forces to the nearest hill and sent the cavalry to hold back the enemy's attack.

sentences.latin: Ipse interim in colle medio triplicem aciem instruxit legionum quattuor veteranarum; in summo iugo duas legiones quas in Gallia citeriore proxime conscripserat et omnia auxilia conlocavit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself meanwhile on the hill middle a triple battle line drew up of legions four veteran; on the highest ridge two legions which in Gaul hither most recently he had enrolled and all the auxiliaries he placed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself meanwhile on the hill middle a triple battle line drew up of legions four veteran; on the highest ridge two legions which in Gaul hither most recently he had enrolled and all auxiliaries he placed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, halfway up the hill, he drew up a triple line of four veteran legions; on the summit, he stationed the two legions he had recently recruited in Nearer Gaul, along with all the auxiliary troops,

sentences.latin: ita ut supra se totum montem hominibus compleret; impedimenta sarcinasque in unum locum conferri et eum ab iis qui in superiore acie constiterant muniri iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so that above himself the whole mountain with men he might fill; the baggage and packs into one place to be brought and it by those who in the higher line had stood to be fortified he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: so that above himself the whole mountain with men he might fill; the baggage and packs into one place to be brought and it by those who in the higher line had stood to be fortified he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: so that he filled the whole mountain above him with men; he ordered the baggage and packs to be collected in one place and that spot to be fortified by those who had been stationed in the upper line.

sentences.latin: Helvetii cum omnibus suis carris secuti impedimenta in unum locum contulerunt; ipsi confertissima acie, reiecto nostro equitatu, phalange facta sub primam nostram aciem successerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetians with all their wagons having followed the baggage into one place they brought; they themselves in a very dense line, having driven back our cavalry, a phalanx having been made, under the first our line they advanced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetians with all their wagons having followed the baggage into one place brought; they themselves in a most dense line, driven back our cavalry, a phalanx having been made, under the first our line they advanced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Helvetians, following with all their wagons, collected their baggage in one place; then, in a very dense formation, after driving back our cavalry, they formed a phalanx and advanced toward our front line.

sentences.latin: Caesar primum suo, deinde omnium ex conspectu remotis equis, ut aequato omnium periculo spem fugae tolleret, cohortatus suos proelium commisit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar first his own, then of all from sight the horses having been removed, so that the danger of all having been made equal the hope of flight he might take away, having encouraged his own [men] battle he joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar first his own, then of all from sight removed horses, so that equalized of all the danger the hope of flight he might take away, having encouraged his own [men] battle joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar first had his own horse and then the horses of all the others removed from sight, so that by making the danger equal for everyone he might take away any hope of flight; then, after encouraging his men, he joined battle.

sentences.latin: Milites loco superiore pilis missis facile hostium phalangem perfregerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The soldiers from the place higher javelins having been sent easily the enemies' phalanx broke through.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The soldiers from the place higher javelins having been sent easily the enemies' phalanx broke through.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The soldiers, by hurling their javelins from the higher ground, easily broke through the enemy's phalanx.

sentences.latin: Ea disiecta gladiis destrictis in eos impetum fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That having been scattered with swords drawn against them an attack they made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It [the phalanx] having been scattered, with swords drawn against them an attack they made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the phalanx was broken, they drew their swords and charged them.

sentences.latin: Gallis magno ad pugnam erat impedimento quod pluribus eorum scutis uno ictu pilorum transfixis et conligatis, cum ferrum se inflexisset, neque evellere neque sinistra impedita satis commode pugnare poterant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the Gauls for a great to the fight it was hindrance because several of their shields by one blow of javelins having been pierced and fastened together, when the iron itself had bent, neither to pull out nor the left hand hindered well enough conveniently to fight they were able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the Gauls for a great to the fight it was for a hindrance because several of their shields by one blow of javelins pierced through and fastened together, when the iron itself had bent, neither to pull out nor the left hand hindered well enough conveniently to fight they were able,
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was a great hindrance to the Gauls in the fight that several of their shields were often pierced and pinned together by a single javelin throw; since the iron point would bend, they could neither pull it out nor fight effectively with their left arms encumbered,

sentences.latin: multi ut diu iactato bracchio praeoptarent scutum manu emittere et nudo corpore pugnare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: many so that for a long time the arm having been tossed they preferred the shield from the hand to drop and with naked body to fight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: many so that for a long time tossed the arm they preferred the shield from the hand to drop and with naked body to fight.
sentences.naturalTranslation: so that many, after shaking their arms for a long time, preferred to drop the shield from their hand and fight with their bodies unprotected.

sentences.latin: Tandem vulneribus defessi et pedem referre et, quod mons suberit circiter mille passuumspatio, eo se recipere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At last by wounds exhausted both foot to bring back and, because a mountain was near about a thousand of paces in distance, thither themselves to withdraw they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At last by wounds exhausted both foot to bring back and, because a mountain was near about a thousand of paces in space, thither themselves to withdraw they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Finally, exhausted by their wounds, they began to retreat and, since there was a mountain about a mile away, to withdraw to that location.

sentences.latin: Capto monte et succedentibus nostris, Boi et Tulingi, qui hominum milibus circiter XV agmen hostium claudebant et novissimis praesidio erant, ex itinere nostrosablatere aperto adgressi circumvenire, et id conspicati Helvetii, qui in montem sese receperant, rursus instare et proelium redintegrare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been taken the mountain and following up our (men), the Boii and Tulingi, who with of men thousands about fifteen the line of the enemies were closing and for the newest (rear) as a protection were, from the march our (men) from the side open having attacked to surround, and this having observed the Helvetii, who onto the mountain themselves had withdrawn, again to press on and the battle to renew began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The mountain having been taken and our men coming up, the Boii and Tulingi, who with men thousands about 15 the line of the enemies were closing and for the newest rear as a protection were, from the march our men from the side open having attacked began to surround, and this having observed the Helvetii, who onto the mountain themselves had withdrawn, again to press on and the battle to renew began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the mountain was reached and our men were following up, the Boii and Tulingiwho with about fifteen thousand men closed the enemy's line of march and served as a guard for the rearattacked our men on their exposed flank during the march and began to surround them; seeing this, the Helvetii, who had retreated to the mountain, began to press forward again and renew the battle.

sentences.latin: Romani [conversa] signa bipertito intulerunt: prima et secunda acies, ut victis ac submotis resisteret, tertia, ut venientes sustineret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Romans [turned] standards in two parts bore in: the first and second line, so that the conquered and driven back (ones) it might resist, the third, so that the coming (ones) it might withstand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Romans turned standards in two directions advanced: the first and second line, so that the conquered and driven back men it might resist, the third, so that the coming men it might sustain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Romans advanced their standards in two directions: the first and second lines to resist those already defeated and driven back, and the third to withstand those now arriving.

sentences.latin: Ita ancipiti proelio diu atque acriter pugnatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus in a double-headed battle for a long time and sharply it was fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus in a double-fronted battle for a long time and sharply it was fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus the battle was fought long and fiercely on two fronts.

sentences.latin: Diutius cum sustinere nostrorum impetus non possent, alteri se, ut coeperant, in montem receperunt, alteri ad impedimenta et carros suos se contulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Longer when to withstand of our (men) the attacks not they were able, the ones themselves, as they had begun, onto the mountain withdrew, the others to the baggage and wagons their own themselves they betook.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Longer when to sustain of our men the attacks not they were able, the ones themselves, as they had begun, onto the mountain withdrew, the others to the baggage and wagons their own themselves betook.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they could no longer withstand the attacks of our men, one division retreated to the mountain as they had started to do, while the others withdrew to their baggage and wagons.

sentences.latin: Nam hoc toto proelio, cum ab hora septima ad vesperum pugnatum sit, aversum hostem videre nemo potuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For in this whole battle, although from the hour seventh to evening it was fought, a turned away enemy to see no one was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For in this whole battle, although from the hour seventh to evening it was fought, a turned enemy to see no one was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For throughout this entire battle, although the fighting lasted from one o'clock in the afternoon until evening, no one could see an enemy in flight.

sentences.latin: Ad multam noctem etiam ad impedimenta pugnatum est, propterea quod pro vallo carros obiecerunt et e loco superiore in nostros venientes tela coiciebant et non nulli inter carros rotasque mataras ac tragulas subiciebant nostrosque vulnerabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To much night even at the baggage it was fought, because for a rampart wagons they threw in the way and from the place higher into our (men) coming weapons they were hurling and not some between the wagons and wheels pikes and javelins were throwing from beneath and our (men) were wounding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Until much night even at the baggage it was fought, because for a rampart wagons they threw in the way and from a place higher against our men coming weapons they were hurling and some between the wagons and wheels pikes and darts were throwing from beneath and our men were wounding.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The fighting continued even late into the night at the baggage, because they had placed their wagons as a rampart and were hurling weapons from the higher ground at our advancing men, and some were thrusting pikes and javelins from beneath between the wagons and wheels, wounding our soldiers.

sentences.latin: Diu cum esset pugnatum, impedimentis castrisque nostri potiti sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Long when it had been fought, of the baggage and the camp our (men) got possession.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Long when it had been fought, of the baggage and camp our men got possession.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a long struggle, our men captured the baggage and the camp.

sentences.latin: Ibi Orgetorigis filia atque unus e filiis captus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There of Orgetorix the daughter and one from the sons was captured.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There of Orgetorix the daughter and one from the sons was captured.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, Orgetorix's daughter and one of his sons were taken prisoner.

sentences.latin: Ex eo proelio circiter hominum milia CXXX superfuerunt eaque tota nocte continenter ierunt [nullam partem noctis itinere intermisso]; in fines Lingonum die quarto pervenerunt, cum et propter vulnera militum et propter sepulturam occisorum nostri [triduum morati] eos sequi non potuissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From that battle about of men thousands 130 survived and that whole night continuously they went [no part of the night the march having been interrupted]; into the borders of the Lingones on the day fourth they arrived, since both on account of the wounds of the soldiers and on account of the burial of the slain our (men) [three days having delayed] them to follow not had been able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From that battle about of men thousands 130 survived and that whole night continuously they went no part of the night the march having been interrupted; into the borders of the Lingones on the day fourth they arrived, since both because of the wounds of the soldiers and because of the burial of the slain our men three days having delayed them to follow not had been able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: About 130,000 people survived that battle and marched continuously throughout the entire night without stopping; they reached the territory of the Lingones on the fourth day, since our men, delayed for three days by the wounds of the soldiers and the burial of the dead, had been unable to pursue them.

sentences.latin: Caesar ad Lingonas litteras nuntiosque misit, ne eos frumento neve alia re iuvarent: qui si iuvissent, se eodem loco quo Helvetios habiturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar to the Lingones letters and messengers sent, lest them with grain nor with other thing they should help: who if they should have helped, himself in the same place in which the Helvetians he would hold.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar to the Lingones letters and messengers sent, that not them with grain nor with other thing they should help: who if they should have helped, himself in the same place in which the Helvetii he would have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar sent letters and messengers to the Lingones, warning them not to assist the Helvetians with grain or any other resource; if they did help, he would treat them in the same manner as the Helvetians.

sentences.latin: Ipse triduo intermisso cum omnibus copiis eos sequi coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself, three days having intervened, with all forces them to follow began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself three days having intervened with all forces them to follow began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a three-day delay, he himself began to pursue them with all his forces.

sentences.latin: Helvetii omnium rerum inopia adducti legatos de deditione ad eum miserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetians by of all things lack influenced ambassadors about surrender to him sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetii of all things by the lack driven ambassadors about surrender to him sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Driven by a lack of all necessities, the Helvetians sent ambassadors to him to discuss surrender.

sentences.latin: Qui cum eum in itinere convenissent seque ad pedes proiecissent suppliciterque locuti flentes pacem petissent, atque eos in eo loco quo tum essent suum adventum expectare iussisset, paruerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when him on the journey they had met and themselves at his feet had thrown and suppliantly having spoken weeping peace had sought, and them in that place in which then they were his arrival to await he had ordered, they obeyed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who when him on the march they had met and themselves at his feet had thrown and humbly having spoken weeping peace had sought, and them in that place in which then they were his arrival to await he had ordered, they obeyed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these met him on the march, threw themselves at his feet, and speaking as suppliants with tears sought peace, he ordered them to wait for his arrival in the place where they were at that time; they obeyed.

sentences.latin: Eo postquam Caesar pervenit, obsides, arma, servos qui ad eos perfugissent, poposcit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There after Caesar arrived, hostages, arms, slaves who to them had fled, he demanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thither after Caesar arrived, hostages, arms, slaves who to them had fled, he demanded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After Caesar arrived there, he demanded hostages, their weapons, and the slaves who had deserted to them.

sentences.latin: Dum ea conquiruntur et conferuntur, [nocte intermissa] circiter hominum milia VI eius pagi qui Verbigenus appellatur, sive timore perterriti, ne armis traditis supplicio adficerentur, sive spe salutis inducti, quod in tanta multitudine dediticiorum suam fugam aut occultari aut omnino ignorari posse existimarent, prima nocte e castris Helvetiorum egressi ad Rhenum finesque Germanorum contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While those things are being sought and brought together, [night having intervened] about of men thousands six of that district which Verbigenus is called, whether by fear thoroughly terrified, lest arms having been handed over with punishment they might be afflicted, or by hope of safety led, because in so great a multitude of surrendered people their flight either to be hidden or entirely to be ignored to be able they thought, at first night from the camp of the Helvetians having gone out to the Rhine and the borders of the Germans they hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things are being sought and brought together, the night having intervened about of men thousands 6 of that canton which Verbigenus is called, whether by fear terrified, lest the arms having been handed over with punishment they might be afflicted, or by hope of safety led, because in so great a multitude of those surrendering their flight either to be hidden or entirely to be ignored to be able they thought, at the first night from the camp of the Helvetii having gone out to the Rhine and the borders of the Germans they hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these things were being searched for and collected, during the night, about six thousand men of the district called Verbigenuseither terrified by fear that they would be executed once their arms were surrendered, or led by the hope of safety, thinking that in such a vast multitude of captives their flight could be hidden or entirely overlookedleft the Helvetian camp at nightfall and hurried toward the Rhine and the German borders.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi Caesar resciit, quorum per fines ierant his uti conquirerent et reducerent, si sibi purgati esse vellent, imperavit; reductos in hostium numero habuit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when Caesar found out, of whom through territories they had gone to these that they should seek out and bring back, if to him cleared to be they wished, he commanded; those brought back in the of enemies number he held;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when Caesar found out, those through whose borders they had gone to these that they should seek out and bring back, if to him cleared to be they wished, he commanded; those brought back in of enemies the number he held;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar learned of this, he ordered those through whose territory they had passed to search for and bring them back, if they wished to be cleared of guilt in his eyes; once brought back, he treated them as enemies.

sentences.latin: reliquos omnes obsidibus, armis, perfugis traditis in deditionem accepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the remaining all, hostages, arms, deserters having been handed over, into surrender he accepted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the remaining all, hostages, arms, deserters having been handed over, into surrender he accepted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All the rest he accepted in surrender after the hostages, weapons, and deserters were handed over.

sentences.latin: Helvetios, Tulingos, Latobrigos in fines suos, unde erant profecti, reverti iussit, et, quod omnibus frugibus amissis domi nihil erat quo famem tolerarent, Allobrogibus imperavit ut iis frumenti copiam facerent; ipsos oppida vicosque, quos incenderant, restituere iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Helvetians, Tulingi, Latobrigi into territories their own, whence they had set out, to return he ordered, and, because all crops having been lost at home nothing was by which hunger they might endure, to the Allobroges he commanded that for them of grain a supply they should make; themselves towns and villages, which they had burned, to restore he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Helvetii, Tulingi, Latobrigi into borders their own, whence they had set out, to return he ordered, and, because all crops having been lost at home nothing was by which hunger they might endure, to the Allobroges he commanded that for them of grain a supply they should make; them the towns and villages, which they had burned, to restore he ordered.
