sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the Helvetians, Tulingi, and Latobrigi to return to their own territories from which they had set out; and, because all their crops were lost and there was nothing at home to sustain them, he commanded the Allobroges to provide them with a supply of grain; he ordered the Helvetians themselves to rebuild the towns and villages they had burned.

sentences.latin: Id ea maxime ratione fecit, quod noluit eum locum unde Helvetii discesserant vacare, ne propter bonitatem agrorum Germani, qui trans Rhenum incolunt,exsuis finibus in Helvetiorum fines transirent et finitimi Galliae provinciae Allobrogibusque essent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This for that especially reason he did, because he did not want that place whence the Helvetians had departed to be empty, lest on account of the goodness of the fields the Germans, who across the Rhine dwell, from their own territories into the Helvetians' territories should cross and neighbors to the Gallic province and to the Allobroges should be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This for that especially reason he did, because he did not want that place whence the Helvetii had departed to be empty, lest on account of the goodness of the fields the Germans, who across the Rhine dwell, from their own borders into of the Helvetii borders should cross and neighbors to the Gallic province and to the Allobroges should be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He did this primarily because he did not want the land the Helvetians had left to remain unoccupied, fearing that the Germans across the Rhine might be drawn by the fertility of the soil to migrate from their own lands into Helvetian territory, thereby becoming neighbors to the Roman province of Gaul and the Allobroges.

sentences.latin: Boios petentibus Haeduis, quod egregia virtute erant cogniti, ut in finibus suis conlocarent, concessit; quibus illi agros dederunt quosque postea in parem iuris libertatisque condicionem atque ipsi erant receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the Boii, the Haedui requesting, because by excellent valor they were known, that in borders their own they might settle, he granted; to whom those fields gave and whom afterwards into equal of law and of liberty condition as they themselves were they received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the Boii, the Haeduans requesting, because with distinguished valor they had been known, that in their own borders they might settle, he granted; to whom those gave lands and whom afterwards into an equal of right and of liberty condition as they themselves were they received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the request of the Haedui, Caesar allowed the Boii to settle in their territory because they were known for their exceptional valor; the Haedui gave them land and later granted them the same legal rights and freedoms that they themselves enjoyed.

sentences.latin: In castris Helvetiorum tabulae repertae sunt litteris Graecis confectae et ad Caesarem relatae, quibus in tabulis nominatim ratio confecta erat, qui numerus domo exisset eorum qui arma ferre possent, et item separatim,quotpueri, senes mulieresque.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In camp of the Helvetians tablets were found in letters Greek made and to Caesar brought back, in which tablets by name an account made was, what number from home had gone out of those who arms to bear were able, and likewise separately, how many boys, old men and women.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the camp of the Helvetians tablets were found in Greek letters made and to Caesar brought back, in which tablets by name an account had been made, what number from home had gone out of those who arms to bear were able, and likewise separately, how many boys, old men and women.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the Helvetian camp, tablets written in Greek characters were found and brought to Caesar; in these tablets, a detailed list had been drawn up showing the number of those who had left home capable of bearing arms, and likewise separate lists for children, the elderly, and women.

sentences.latin: [Quarum omnium rerum] summa erat capitum Helvetiorum milium CCLXIII, Tulingorum milium XXXVI, Latobrigorum XIIII, Rauracorum XXIII, Boiorum XXXII; ex his qui arma ferre possent ad milia nonaginta duo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which all things the sum was of heads of Helvetians thousands 263, of Tulingi thousands 36, of Latobrigi 14, of Rauraci 23, of Boii 32; out of these who arms to bear were able about thousands ninety two.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of all which things the sum was of heads of Helvetians thousands 263, of Tulingi thousands 36, of Latobrigi 14, of Rauraci 23, of Boii 32; out of these who arms to bear were able about thousands ninety-two.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The total number of all these groups was 263,000 Helvetians, 36,000 Tulingi, 14,000 Latobrigi, 23,000 Rauraci, and 32,000 Boii; of these, about 92,000 were capable of bearing arms.

sentences.latin: Summa omnium fuerunt ad milia CCCLXVIII.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The sum of all were about thousands 368.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The sum of all were about thousands 368.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The grand total was approximately 368,000.

sentences.latin: Eorum qui domum redierunt censu habito, ut Caesar imperaverat, repertus est numerus milium C et X.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of those who home returned, a census having been held, as Caesar had commanded, was found the number of thousands 100 and 10.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of those who home returned a census having been held, as Caesar had commanded, there was found the number of thousands 100 and 10.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a census was taken of those who returned home, as Caesar had ordered, the number was found to be 110,000.

sentences.latin: Bello Helvetiorum confecto totius fere Galliae legati, principes civitatum, ad Caesarem gratulatum convenerunt:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The war of the Helvetians having been finished, of all almost Gaul ambassadors, leaders of states, to Caesar to congratulate came together:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The war of the Helvetians having been finished of whole almost Gaul ambassadors, chiefs of states, to Caesar to congratulate assembled:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the war with the Helvetians was over, ambassadors from almost all of Gaul, the leading men of their states, came to Caesar to offer their congratulations.

sentences.latin: intellegere sese, tametsi pro veteribus Helvetiorum iniuriis populi Romani ab his poenas bello repetisset, tamen eam rem non minus ex usu [terrae] Galliae quam populi Romani accidisse,
sentences.referenceTranslation: to understand themselves, although for old of the Helvetians injuries of the people Roman from these penalties by war he had sought, nevertheless that thing not less from use of the land of Gaul than of the people Roman had happened,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to understand they, although for old of the Helvetians injuries of the people Roman from these punishments by war he had sought back, nevertheless that thing not less from use of the land of Gaul than of the people Roman had happened,
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said they understood that, although he had sought satisfaction from the Helvetians in war for their past outrages against the Roman people, nevertheless this event had happened no less to the advantage of Gaul than to that of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: propterea quod eo consilio florentissimis rebus domos suas Helvetii reliquissent uti toti Galliae bellum inferrent imperioque potirentur, locumque domicilio ex magna copia deligerent quem ex omni Gallia oportunissimum ac fructuosissimum iudicassent, reliquasque civitates stipendiarias haberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because with that plan in most flourishing things homes their own the Helvetians had left so that on all Gaul war they might bring and of the empire might get possession, and a place for a home out of a great supply might choose which out of all Gaul most convenient and most fruitful they had judged, and the remaining states tributary might have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because for that reason with most flourishing things homes their the Helvetians had left so that to whole Gaul war they might bring in and of the empire might get possession, and a place for a home out of a great abundance they might choose which out of all Gaul most suitable and most fruitful they had judged, and the remaining states tributary they might have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was because the Helvetians, even while their affairs were most prosperous, had left their homes with the intent of making war on all of Gaul and seizing supreme power; they planned to select from the vast territory the most convenient and fertile spot for their home and to make the other states their tributaries.

sentences.latin: Petierunt uti sibi concilium totius Galliae in diem certam indicere idque Caesaris facere voluntate liceret: sese habere quasdam res quas ex communi consensu ab eo petere vellent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They requested that for themselves a council of all Gaul for a day certain to proclaim and that of Caesar to do by the will it might be permitted: themselves to have certain things which from common consent from him to request they wished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They asked that to them a council of whole Gaul for a day certain to appoint and that of Caesar to do by the will it might be permitted: they to have certain things which from common consent from him to ask they wished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They requested permission to call a general council of all Gaul for a fixed day and to do so with Caesar's consent, stating that they had certain matters which they wished to ask of him by common agreement.

sentences.latin: Ea re permissa diem concilio constituerunt et iure iurando ne quis enuntiaret, nisi quibus communi consilio mandatum esset, inter se sanxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That thing having been permitted a day for the council they appointed and by an oath that not anyone should disclose, except to whom by common counsel it had been mandated, among themselves they bound.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That thing permitted a day for the council they appointed and by oath that not anyone should disclose, except to whom by common council it had been mandated, among themselves they sanctioned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This request being granted, they fixed a day for the council and bound themselves by an oath that no one should disclose its proceedings except those to whom the task was assigned by common agreement.

sentences.latin: Eo concilio dimisso, idem princeps civitatum qui ante fuerant ad Caesarem reverterunt petieruntque uti sibi secreto in occulto de sua omniumque salute cum eo agere liceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That council having been dismissed, the same leaders of states who before had been [present] to Caesar returned and requested that to them secretly in private concerning their own and of all safety with him to treat it might be permitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That council dismissed, the same chiefs of states who before had been to Caesar returned and asked that to them secretly in private concerning their own and of all safety with him to treat it might be permitted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the council was dismissed, the same leaders of the states who had been present before returned to Caesar and requested that they be allowed to discuss their own safety and that of everyone else with him in secret.

sentences.latin: Ea re impetrata sese omnes flentes Caesari ad pedes proiecerunt: non minus se id contendere et laborare ne ea quae dixissent enuntiarentur quam uti ea quae vellent impetrarent, propterea quod, si enuntiatum esset, summum in cruciatum se venturos viderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That thing having been obtained, themselves all weeping to Caesar at the feet threw: not less themselves that to strive and to labor lest those things which they had said should be reported than that those things which they wished they might obtain, because, if it should have been reported, into the highest torture themselves about to come they saw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That thing obtained themselves all weeping to Caesar at the feet threw: not less they that to strive and to labor lest those things which they had said should be disclosed than that those things which they wished they might obtain, because, if it should be disclosed, highest into torture themselves to come they saw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this request was granted, they all threw themselves weeping at Caesar's feet, stating that they were no less anxious and concerned that what they said should not be disclosed than they were to obtain what they desired; for they saw that if it were disclosed, they would face the most extreme torture.

sentences.latin: Locutus est pro his Diviciacus Haeduus: Galliae totius factiones esse duas; harum alterius principatum tenere Haeduos, alterius Arvernos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Spoke on behalf of these Diviciacus the Haeduan: of Gaul whole factions to be two; of these of the one the leadership to hold the Haeduans, of the other the Arverni.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Spoke for these Diviciacus the Haeduan: of Gaul whole factions to be two; of these of the one leadership to hold the Haeduans, of the other the Arverni.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Diviciacus the Haeduan spoke on their behalf: he said that there were two factions in all of Gaul, one led by the Haeduans and the other by the Arverni.

sentences.latin: Hi cum tantopere de potentatu inter se multos annos contenderent, factum esse uti ab Arvernis Sequanisque Germani mercede arcesserentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These when so greatly concerning the supremacy among themselves many years were contending, it was brought about that by the Arverni and the Sequani Germans for pay were summoned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These when so greatly concerning power among themselves many years they contended, it was done that by the Arverni and Sequani Germans for pay were summoned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since these two groups had been struggling fiercely for supremacy for many years, it happened that the Arverni and the Sequani hired German mercenaries to come to their aid.

sentences.latin: Horum primo circiter milia XV Rhenum transisse; postea quam agros et cultum et copias Gallorum homines feri ac barbari adamassent, traductos plures; nunc esse in Gallia ad C et XX milium numerum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of these at first about thousands 15 the Rhine to have crossed; after that the fields and the civilization and the resources of the Gauls men wild and barbarian had fallen in love with, led across more; now to be in Gaul to 100 and 20 thousands in number.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these first about thousands 15 the Rhine to have crossed; after than the fields and the culture and the resources of the Gauls men fierce and barbarian had fallen in love with, led across more; now to be in Gaul to 100 and 20 thousands number.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first, about fifteen thousand of these Germans crossed the Rhine; but after these wild and barbarian men grew fond of the lands, the lifestyle, and the wealth of the Gauls, more were brought over; there were now about a hundred and twenty thousand of them in Gaul.

sentences.latin: Cum his Haeduos eorumque clientes semel atque iterum armis contendisse; magnam calamitatem pulsos accepisse, omnem nobilitatem, omnem senatum, omnem equitatum amisisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these the Haeduans and of them the clients once and again with arms to have contended; great calamity having been beaten to have received, all the nobility, all the senate, all the cavalry to have lost.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these the Haeduans and their clients once and again by arms had contended; great calamity driven back they had received, all the nobility, all the senate, all the cavalry they had lost.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Haeduans and their dependents had fought against them more than once; they had been defeated and suffered a great disaster, losing all their nobility, their entire senate, and all their cavalry.

sentences.latin: Quibus proeliis calamitatibusque fractos, qui et sua virtute et populi Romani hospitio atque amicitia plurimum ante in Gallia potuissent, coactos esse Sequanis obsides dare nobilissimos civitatis et iure iurando civitatem obstringere sese neque obsides repetituros neque auxilium a populo Romano imploraturos neque recusaturos quo minus perpetuo sub illorum dicione atque imperio essent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which battles and calamities broken, who both by their own valor and of the people Roman by the hospitality and friendship most before in Gaul had been able, to have been compelled to the Sequani hostages to give the most noble of the state and by oath the state to bind themselves neither hostages to seek back nor help from the people Roman to implore nor to refuse by which less perpetually under of those the sway and command they should be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which battles and calamities broken, who both by their own valor and of the people Roman hospitality and friendship most before in Gaul had been able, forced to be to the Sequani hostages to give the most noble of the state and by oath the state to bind themselves neither hostages would seek back nor help from the people Roman would implore nor would refuse why less perpetually under of those the sway and command they should be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Broken by these battles and disasters, those who previously, through their own courage and the hospitality and friendship of the Roman people, had been the most powerful in Gaul, were forced to give their most noble citizens as hostages to the Sequani and to bind their state by an oath that they would neither demand the return of the hostages, nor seek help from the Roman people, nor refuse to remain forever under the Sequani's rule and authority.

sentences.latin: Unum se esse ex omni civitate Haeduorum qui adduci non potuerit ut iuraret aut liberos suos obsides daret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One himself to be out of all the state of the Haeduans who to be induced not was able that he should swear or children his own hostages should give.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One himself to be out of all the state of the Haeduans who to be led could not that he should swear or children his hostages should give.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said that he was the only person in the entire Haeduan state who could not be induced to take the oath or to give his children as hostages.

sentences.latin: Ob eam rem se ex civitate profugisse et Romam ad senatum venisse auxilium postulatum, quod solus neque iure iurando neque obsidibus teneretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On account of that thing himself from the state to have fled and to Rome to the senate to have come help to demand, because alone neither by oath nor by hostages he was held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For that thing himself from the state to have fled and to Rome to the senate to have come help to ask, because alone neither by oath nor by hostages he was held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this reason, he had fled from his state and come to Rome to the Senate to request help, because he was the only one not bound by either an oath or hostages.

sentences.latin: Sed peius victoribus Sequanis quam Haeduis victis accidisse, propterea quod Ariovistus, rex Germanorum, in eorum finibus consedisset tertiamque partem agri Sequani, qui esset optimus totius Galliae, occupavisset et nunc de altera parte tertia Sequanos decedere iuberet, propterea quod paucis mensibus ante Harudum milia hominum XXIIII ad eum venissent, quibus locus ac sedes pararentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But worse to the victors Sequani than to the Haeduans conquered to have happened, because Ariovistus, king of the Germans, in their borders had settled and a third part of the land Sequanian, which was the best of all Gaul, had occupied and now from another part third the Sequani to depart he was ordering, because a few months before of the Harudes thousands of men 24 to him had come, for whom a place and settlements were being prepared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But worse to the victors Sequani than to the Haeduans conquered to have happened, because Ariovistus, king of the Germans, in their borders had settled and a third part of the land Sequanian, which was best of whole Gaul, had occupied and now from another part third the Sequani to depart he ordered, because a few months before of the Harudes thousands of men 24 to him had come, for whom a place and seats were being prepared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But a worse fate had befallen the victorious Sequani than the conquered Haeduans, because Ariovistus, the king of the Germans, had settled within their borders and seized a third of the Sequanian land, which was the best in all Gaul, and was now ordering the Sequani to vacate another third, because a few months earlier twenty-four thousand of the Harudes had joined him, for whom a place and homes had to be provided.

sentences.latin: Futurum esse paucis annis uti omnes ex Galliae finibus pellerentur atque omnes Germani Rhenum transirent; neque enim conferendum esse Gallicum cum Germanorum agro neque hanc consuetudinem victus cum illa comparandam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It to be about to be in a few years that all from Gaul's borders should be driven and all Germans the Rhine should cross; for neither to be compared the Gallic with the Germans' land nor this custom of living with that one to be compared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That it would be in a few years that all from Gaul's borders would be driven and all Germans the Rhine would cross; for neither to be compared was the Gallic with the Germans' land nor this custom of living with that to be compared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In a few years, it would happen that all the Gauls would be driven from their borders and all the Germans would cross the Rhine; for the Gallic land was not to be compared with that of the Germans, nor was their way of life to be compared with this one.

sentences.latin: Ariovistum autem, ut semel Gallorum copias proelio vicerit, quod proelium factum sit ad Magetobrigam, superbe et crudeliter imperare, obsides nobilissimi cuiusque liberos poscere et in eos omnia exempla cruciatusque edere, si qua res non ad nutum aut ad voluntatem eius facta sit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ariovistus however, as once of the Gauls the forces in battle he conquered, which battle happened at Magetobriga, proudly and cruelly to rule, hostages of most noble each one children to demand and against them all examples and tortures to put forth, if any thing not at the nod or at the will of him done was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ariovistus however, as once the Gauls' forces in battle he conquered, which battle happened at Magetobriga, haughtily and cruelly to rule, hostages of each most noble [person] children to demand and on them all examples and tortures to inflict, if any thing not at the nod or at the will of him was done.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ariovistus, however, since he had once defeated the Gallic forces in a battle that took place at Magetobriga, ruled proudly and cruelly, demanding the children of all the highest nobles as hostages and inflicting all kinds of punishments and tortures upon them if anything was not done at his nod or according to his will.

sentences.latin: Hominem esse barbarum, iracundum, temerarium: non posse eius imperia, diutius sustineri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The man to be barbarian, passionate, reckless: not to be able his commands longer to be endured.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That the man was barbarian, passionate, reckless: not to be able his commands longer to be endured.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was a barbarian, passionate and reckless; his commands could no longer be endured.

sentences.latin: Nisi quid in Caesare populoque Romano sit auxilii, omnibus Gallis idem esse faciendum quod Helvetii fecerint, ut domo emigrent, aliud domicilium, alias sedes, remotas a Germanis, petant fortunamque, quaecumque accidat, experiantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Unless some in Caesar and the people Roman there be of help, by all Gauls the same thing to be done which the Helvetii did, that from home they emigrate, another domicile, other seats, remote from the Germans, they seek and fortune, whatever happens, they experience.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Unless some in Caesar and the people Roman there be of help, by all Gauls the same to be done which the Helvetii did, that from home they emigrate, another domicile, other seats, remote from the Germans, they seek and fortune, whatever happens, they experience.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Unless there was some help in Caesar and the Roman people, all the Gauls would have to do the same thing the Helvetii did: emigrate from their homes, seek another dwelling and other settlements far from the Germans, and endure whatever fortune might befall them.

sentences.latin: Haec si enuntiata Ariovisto sint, non dubitare quin de omnibus obsidibus qui apud eum sint gravissimum supplicium sumat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things if announced to Ariovistus should be, not to doubt but that from all hostages who with him are most heavy punishment he would take.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things if reported to Ariovistus should be, [he] did not doubt but that from all hostages who with him are the heaviest punishment he would take.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If these things were reported to Ariovistus, he did not doubt that he would inflict the severest punishment on all the hostages who were in his power.

sentences.latin: Caesarem vel auctoritate sua atque exercitus vel recenti victoria vel nomine populi Romani deterrere posse ne maior multitudo Germanorum Rhenum traducatur, Galliamque omnem ab Ariovisti iniuria posse defendere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar either by authority his and of the army or by recent victory or by name of the people Roman to deter to be able lest a greater multitude of Germans the Rhine be led across, and Gaul all from Ariovistus's injury to be able to defend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar either by authority his and of the army or by recent victory or by name of the people Roman to deter to be able lest a greater multitude of Germans the Rhine be led across, and Gaul all from Ariovistus's injury to be able to defend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, either by his own authority and that of his army, or by his recent victory, or by the name of the Roman people, could prevent a greater number of Germans from being led across the Rhine and could defend all of Gaul from the outrages of Ariovistus.

sentences.latin: Hac oratione ab Diviciaco habita omnes qui aderant magno fletu auxilium a Caesare petere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This speech by Diviciacus having been delivered, all who were present with great weeping help from Caesar to seek began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This speech by Diviciacus having been delivered, all who were present with great weeping help from Caesar to seek began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this speech had been delivered by Diviciacus, all who were present began to beg Caesar for help with loud weeping.

sentences.latin: Animadvertit Caesar unos ex omnibus Sequanos nihil earum rerum facere quas ceteri facerent sed tristes capite demisso terram intueri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Noticed Caesar alone out of all the Sequani nothing of those things to do which the others were doing but sad with head lowered the ground to gaze at.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Noticed Caesar alone out of all the Sequani nothing of those things to do which the others were doing but sad with head bowed the ground to gaze at.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar noticed that the Sequani alone of all those present did none of the things that the others were doing, but stood sadly with their heads bowed, gazing at the ground.

sentences.latin: Eius rei quae causa esset miratus ex ipsis quaesiit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this thing what the cause was having wondered from themselves he asked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this thing what the cause was having wondered from themselves he asked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Wondering what the cause of this behavior was, he questioned them.

sentences.latin: Nihil Sequani respondere, sed in eadem tristitia taciti permanere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nothing the Sequani to answer, but in the same sadness silent to remain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nothing the Sequani replied, but in the same sadness silent they remained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Sequani made no answer, but remained silent in the same state of sadness.

sentences.latin: Cum ab his saepius quaereret neque ullam omnino vocem exprimere posset, idem Diviacus Haeduus respondit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: When from these more often he was asking and not any at all voice to press out he was able, the same Diviciacus the Haeduan replied:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When from them more often he asked and not any at all voice to press out he was able, the same Diviciacus the Haeduan replied:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he repeatedly questioned them and could not elicit a single word, the same Diviciacus the Haeduan replied:

sentences.latin: hoc esse miseriorem et graviorem fortunam Sequanorum quam reliquorum, quod soli ne in occulto quidem queri neque auxilium implorare auderent absentisque Ariovisti crudelitatem,
sentences.referenceTranslation: this to be more miserable and more heavy the fortune of the Sequani than of the rest, because alone not even in secret indeed to complain nor help to implore they dared and of the absent Ariovistus the cruelty,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: this to be more wretched and heavier the fortune of the Sequani than of the rest, because alone not in secret even to complain nor help to implore they dared and of absent Ariovistus the cruelty,
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the fortune of the Sequani was more wretched and more severe than that of the others, because they alone did not dare to complain even in secret or to beg for help, and the cruelty of Ariovistus, though he was absent,

sentences.latin: velut si cora adesset, horrerent, propterea quod reliquis tamen fugae facultas daretur, Sequanis vero, qui intra fines suos Ariovistum recepissent, quorum oppida omnia in potestate eius essent, omnes cruciatus essent perferendi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: just as if in person he were present, they shuddered at, for the reason that to the rest nevertheless of flight the opportunity was given, to the Sequani truly, who within borders their own Ariovistus had received, of whom towns all in power his were, all tortures were to be endured.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: just as if face to face he were present, they shuddered, because to the rest however of flight the opportunity was given, to the Sequani truly, who within borders their own Ariovistus had received, whose towns all in power of him were, all tortures were to be endured.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they dreaded just as if he were present in person; for while others had the chance to flee, the Sequani, who had admitted Ariovistus within their borders and whose towns were all in his power, had to endure every kind of torture.

sentences.latin: His rebus cognitis Caesar Gallorum animos verbis confirmavit pollicitusque est sibi eam rem curae futuram; magnam se habere spem et beneficio suo et auctoritate adductum Ariovistum finem iniuriis facturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned Caesar of the Gauls the minds with words encouraged and promised he that to him that matter for a care would be; great himself to have hope both by benefit his and by authority influenced Ariovistus an end to injuries would make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been learned Caesar the Gauls' minds with words encouraged and promised that to him that matter for a care would be; great he to have hope both by benefit his and authority influenced Ariovistus an end to injuries would make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After learning these things, Caesar encouraged the Gauls with his words and promised that he would take charge of the matter; he said he had great hope that Ariovistus, influenced by both his previous favor and his authority, would put an end to his outrages.

sentences.latin: Hac oratione habita, concilium dimisit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This speech having been delivered, the council he dismissed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This speech having been delivered, the council he dismissed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having delivered this speech, he dismissed the council.

sentences.latin: Et secundum ea multae res eum hortabantur quare sibi eam rem cogitandam et suscipiendam putaret, in primis quod Haeduos, fratres consanguineosque saepe numero a senatu appellatos, in servitute atque [in] dicione videbat Germanorum teneri eorumque obsides esse apud Ariovistum ac Sequanos intellegebat; quod in tanto imperio populi Romani turpissimum sibi et rei publicae esse arbitrabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And according to those many things him were urging why for himself that matter to be thought about and to be undertaken he should think, in the first things because the Haeduans, brothers and kinsmen often in number by the senate called, in slavery and under the sway he saw of the Germans to be held and of them hostages to be with Ariovistus and the Sequani he understood; which in so great an empire of the people Roman most shameful to himself and to the republic to be he judged.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And according to those many things him were urging why for him that matter to be thought and to be undertaken he thought, in first because the Haedui, brothers and kinsmen often in number by the senate called, in slavery and in dominion he saw of the Germans to be held and of them hostages to be with Ariovistus and the Sequani he understood; which in so great an empire of the people Roman most shameful to himself and to the republic to be he judged.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In addition to these points, many factors urged him to think that he must consider and undertake this matter, especially because he saw that the Haeduans, who had often been called brothers and kinsmen by the senate, were held in slavery and under the dominion of the Germans, and he knew that their hostages were with Ariovistus and the Sequani; this he considered a great disgrace to himself and the republic, given the greatness of the Roman Empire.

sentences.latin: Paulatim autem Germanos consuescere Rhenum transire et in Galliam magnam eorum multitudinem venire populo Romano periculosum videbat, neque sibi homines feros ac barbaros temperaturos existimabat quin, cum omnem Galliam occupavissent, ut ante Cimbri Teutonique fecissent, in provinciam exirent atque inde in Italiam contenderent [, praesertim cum Sequanos a provincia nostra Rhodanus divideret]; quibus rebus quam maturrime occurrendum putabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Little by little however the Germans to become accustomed the Rhine to cross and into Gaul a great of them multitude to come to the people Roman dangerous he saw, nor for themselves men fierce and barbarian would restrain themselves he thought but that, when all Gaul they had occupied, as before the Cimbri and Teutoni had done, into the province they would go out and from there into Italy they would hasten, especially since the Sequani from province our the Rhone divided; which things as most maturely to be met he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Gradually however the Germans to become accustomed the Rhine to cross and into Gaul a great of them multitude to come to the people Roman dangerous he saw, nor for themselves men fierce and barbarian would restrain he thought but that, when all Gaul they had occupied, as before Cimbri and Teutoni had done, into the province they would go out and from there into Italy they would hasten, especially since the Sequani from province our the Rhone divided; which things as most speedily to be met he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, he saw it was dangerous for the Roman people that the Germans should gradually become accustomed to crossing the Rhine and that a great number of them should come into Gaul; nor did he think that such fierce and barbarian men would restrain themselves from invading the Province and then marching into Italy once they had seized all of Gaul, as the Cimbri and Teutoni had done before, especially since only the Rhone separated the Sequani from our province; he thought these developments must be countered as quickly as possible.

sentences.latin: Ipse autem Ariovistus tantos sibi spiritus, tantam arrogantiam sumpserat, ut ferendus non videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself however Ariovistus so great for himself spirits, so great arrogance had taken up, that to be endured not he seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Himself however Ariovistus so great to himself spirits, so great arrogance had taken, that to be endured not he seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ariovistus himself, moreover, had assumed such airs and such arrogance that he seemed unbearable.

sentences.latin: Quam ob rem placuit ei ut ad Ariovistum legatos mitteret, qui ab eo postularent uti aliquem locum medium utrisque conloquio deligeret: velle sese de re publica et summis utriusque rebus cum eo agere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which on account of thing it pleased him that to Ariovistus ambassadors he should send, who from him should demand that some place middle for both for a conference he should choose: to wish himself about the republic and highest of both matters with him to discuss.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which for reason it pleased him that to Ariovistus envoys he send, who from him should demand that some place middle for both for a conference he choose: to wish himself about the republic and highest of both matters with him to treat.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this reason, he decided to send ambassadors to Ariovistus to request that he choose some place midway between them for a conference, stating that he wished to discuss state business and matters of the highest importance to both of them.

sentences.latin: Ei legationi Ariovistus respondit: si quid ipsi a Caesare opus esset, sese ad eum venturum fuisse; si quid ille se velit, illum ad se venire oportere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To that embassy Ariovistus replied: if anything for himself from Caesar need there were, himself to him to have come would have; if anything he from him wants, that one to him to come it behooves.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To that embassy Ariovistus replied: if anything for himself from Caesar need there were, himself to him would have come; if anything he from him wants, that man to him to come it behooves.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this embassy Ariovistus replied: if he himself needed anything from Caesar, he would have gone to him; if Caesar wanted anything from him, Caesar ought to come to him.

sentences.latin: Praeterea se neque sine exercitu in eas partes Galliae venire audere quas Caesar possideret, neque exercitum sine magno commeatu atque molimento in unum locum contrahere posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Furthermore himself neither without army into those parts of Gaul to come to dare which Caesar was possessing, nor army without great supply and effort into one place to collect to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Furthermore that he neither without an army into those parts of Gaul to come dared which Caesar possessed, nor an army without great provision and effort into one place to collect was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, he dared not come without an army into those parts of Gaul which Caesar occupied, nor could he concentrate his army in one place without great supply and effort.

sentences.latin: Sibi autem mirum videri quid in sua Gallia, quam bello vicisset, aut Caesari aut omnino populo Romano negotii esset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To himself however strange to seem what in his own Gaul, which in war he had conquered, either to Caesar or at all to the people Roman of business there was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To him however strange it seemed what in his own Gaul, which in war he had conquered, either to Caesar or at all to the people Roman of business there was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Moreover, it seemed strange to him what business either Caesar or the Roman people at all had in his Gaul, which he had conquered in war.

sentences.latin: His responsis ad Caesarem relatis, iterum ad eum Caesar legatos cum his mandatis mittit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: These responses to Caesar having been brought back, again to him Caesar envoys with these mandates sends:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These responses to Caesar having been reported, again to him Caesar ambassadors with these mandates sends:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these replies were brought back to Caesar, he sent envoys to him again with the following instructions:

sentences.latin: quoniam tanto suo populique Romani beneficio adfectus, cum in consulatu suo rex atque amicus a senatu appellatus esset, hanc sibi populoque Romano gratiam referret ut in conloquium venire invitatus gravaretur neque de communi re dicendum sibi et cognoscendum putaret, haec esse quae ab eo postularet:
sentences.referenceTranslation: since by so great his and of the people Roman benefit having been treated, when in consulship his king and friend by the senate he had been called, this to himself and to the people Roman thanks he was returning that into conference to come having been invited he was reluctant nor about common matter to be spoken by him and to be learned he thought, these to be [the things] which from him he was demanding:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: since by so great his and the people Roman's benefit having been treated, when in consulship his king and friend by the senate called he had been, this to him and the people Roman thanks he returned that into a conference to come having been invited he was reluctant nor about the common matter to be spoken by him and to be learned he thought, these to be the things which from him he demanded:
sentences.naturalTranslation: since, after being treated with such great kindness by himself and the Roman people (having been called king and friend by the senate during his consulship), he was returning such gratitude to himself and the Roman people that he was reluctant to come to a conference when invited and did not think he should speak or learn about their common interests, these were the things he demanded of him:

sentences.latin: primum ne quam multitudinem hominum amplius trans Rhenum in Galliam traduceret; deinde obsides quos haberet ab Haeduis redderet Sequanisque permitteret ut quos illi haberent voluntate eius reddere illis liceret; neve Haeduos iniuria lacesseret neve his sociisque eorum bellum inferret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: first that not any multitude of men further across the Rhine into Gaul he should lead; then hostages whom he was holding from the Haedui he should return and to the Sequani he should permit that [those] whom they were holding by will of him to return to them it might be allowed; nor the Haedui with injury he should provoke nor on these and allies of them war he should bring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: first that not any multitude of men further across the Rhine into Gaul he should lead; then hostages whom he had from the Haedui he should return and to the Sequani he should permit that those whom they had by will of him to return to them it should be allowed; nor the Haedui with injury he should provoke nor on these and allies of them war he should bring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: first, that he should not lead any more large numbers of men across the Rhine into Gaul; second, that he should return the hostages he held from the Haedui and permit the Sequani to return those they held with his consent; and that he should not provoke the Haedui by injury nor make war upon them or their allies.

sentences.latin: Si [id] ita fecisset, sibi populoque Romano perpetuam gratiam atque amicitiam cum eo futuram; si non impetraret, sese, quoniam M. Messala, M. Pisone consulibus senatus censuisset uti quicumque Galliam provinciam obtineret, quod commodo rei publicae lacere posset, Haeduos ceterosque amicos populi Romani defenderet, se Haeduorum iniurias non neglecturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If [it] so he had done, to himself and to the people Roman perpetual gratitude and friendship with him would be; if not he should obtain [his request], himself, since Marcus Messala, Marcus Piso being consuls the senate had decreed that whoever Gaul the province should hold, as far as for the advantage of the republic he could do, the Haedui and other friends of the people Roman he should defend, himself of the Haedui injuries not would neglect.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If [it] so he had done, to him and the people Roman perpetual gratitude and friendship with him would be; if not he should obtain [his request], he himself, since Marcus Messala, Marcus Piso being consuls the senate had decreed that whoever Gaul the province should hold, as far as to the advantage of the republic to do he was able, the Haedui and other friends of the people Roman he should defend, he the Haedui's injuries not would neglect.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he did this, there would be lasting gratitude and friendship with him on the part of himself and the Roman people; if he did not obtain his request, thensince the senate had decreed in the consulship of Marcus Messala and Marcus Piso that whoever held the province of Gaul should, as far as he could do so with advantage to the republic, defend the Haedui and other friends of the Roman peoplehe would not overlook the wrongs done to the Haedui.

sentences.latin: Ad haec Ariovistus respondit: ius esse belli ut qui vicissent iis quos vicissent quem ad modum vellent imperarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these Ariovistus replied: the right to be of war that [those] who had conquered those whom they had conquered in what way they wished they should command.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these Ariovistus replied: the right to be of war that those who had conquered those whom they had conquered in what manner they wished should command.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this Ariovistus replied: that it was the right of war that conquerors should command those they had conquered in whatever way they pleased.

sentences.latin: Item populum Romanum victis non ad alterius praescriptum, sed ad suum arbitrium imperare consuesse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Likewise the people Roman over the conquered not according to of another prescription, but according to their own judgment to command to have been accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Likewise the people Roman the conquered not according to another's dictate, but according to their own judgment to rule were accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Likewise, the Roman people were accustomed to command the conquered not according to the dictates of another, but according to their own judgment.

sentences.latin: Si ipse populo Romano non praescriberet quem ad modum suo iure uteretur, non oportere se a populo Romano in suo iure impediri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If he himself to the people Roman not was prescribing in what way their own right they should use, not to be right himself by the people Roman in his own right to be hindered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If he himself to the people Roman not did dictate in what manner their own right they should use, not it was right himself by the people Roman in his own right to be hindered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he himself did not dictate to the Roman people how they should exercise their rights, it was not right that he should be hindered by the Roman people in the exercise of his own rights.

sentences.latin: Haeduos sibi, quoniam belli fortunam temptassent et armis congressi ac superati essent, stipendiarios esse factos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Haedui to himself, since the fortune of war they had tried and in arms having met and having been overcome they were, tributary to have been made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Haedui to him, since of war fortune they had tried and in arms having met and overcome they had been, tributary to have been made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Haedui, since they had tried the fortune of war and had been met and overcome in arms, had become tributary to him.

sentences.latin: Magnam Caesarem iniuriam facere, qui suo adventu vectigalia sibi deteriora faceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Great Caesar injury to do, who by his arrival revenues for him worse was making.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Great Caesar injury to do, who by his arrival revenues for him worse was making.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar was doing a great injustice, since by his arrival he was making the revenues less profitable for Ariovistus.

sentences.latin: Haeduis se obsides redditurum non esse neque his neque eorum sociis iniuria bellum inlaturum, si in eo manerent quod convenisset stipendiumque quotannis penderent; si id non fecissent, longe iis fraternum nomen populi Romani afuturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the Haedui himself hostages to return not to be nor on these nor on their allies with injury war to bring, if in that they should remain which had been agreed and tribute yearly they should pay; if that not they had done, far from them the brotherly name of the people Roman would be away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the Haedui himself hostages to return not to be nor on these nor their allies with injury war to bring, if in that they remained which had been agreed and tribute yearly they paid; if it not they had done, far from them the brotherly name of the people Roman would be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He would not return the hostages to the Haedui, but he would not make war unjustly on them or their allies if they stood by their agreement and paid the annual tribute; if they did not, the title of 'brothers' given by the Roman people would be of little use to them.

sentences.latin: Quod sibi Caesar denuntiaret se Haeduorum iniurias non neglecturum, neminem secum sine sua pernicie contendisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As to what to him Caesar was declaring himself of the Haedui injuries not to be about to neglect, no one with him without his own destruction had contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As to that to him Caesar declared himself the Haedui's injuries not would neglect, no one with him without his own destruction had contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As for Caesar's declaration that he would not overlook the wrongs done to the Haedui, Ariovistus replied that no one had ever fought him without being destroyed.

sentences.latin: Cum vellet, congrederetur: intellecturum quid invicti Germani, exercitatissimi in armis, qui inter annos XIIII tectum non subissent, virtute possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When he wished, let him engage: he would understand what the unconquered Germans, most trained in arms, who during years fourteen a roof not had gone under, in valor were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When he wished, let him engage: he would understand what the unconquered Germans, most practiced in arms, who during years fourteen a roof not had gone under, by valor were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Let Caesar attack whenever he wished: he would learn what the invincible Germans, highly trained in arms, who had not lived under a roof for fourteen years, could achieve by their bravery.

sentences.latin: Haec eodem tempore Caesari mandata referebantur et legati ab Haeduis et a Treveris veniebant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: These at the same time to Caesar messages were being reported and ambassadors from the Haedui and from the Treveri were coming:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These at the same time to Caesar messages were being reported and ambassadors from the Haedui and from the Treveri were coming:
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time that these messages were being reported to Caesar, ambassadors arrived from the Haedui and the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Haedui questum quod Harudes, qui nuper in Galliam transportati essent, fines eorum popularentur: sese ne obsidibus quidem datis pacem Ariovisti redimere potuisse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Haedui to complain because the Harudes, who recently into Gaul transported had been, the territories of them were ravaging: themselves not even with hostages given the peace of Ariovistus to buy back had been able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the Haedui to complain because the Harudes, who recently into Gaul transported had been, borders of them were ravaging: themselves not even hostages having been given peace of Ariovistus to buy back had been able;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Haedui came to complain that the Harudes, who had recently been brought into Gaul, were ravaging their territory, and that they had not been able to buy peace from Ariovistus even by giving hostages.

sentences.latin: Treveri autem, pagos centum Sueborum ad ripas Rheni consedisse, qui Rhemum transire conarentur; his praeesse Nasuam et Cimberium fratres.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Treveri however, that cantons a hundred of the Suebi at the banks of the Rhine had settled, who the Rhine to cross were trying; over these to be in command Nasua and Cimberius brothers.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the Treveri however, cantons a hundred of the Suebi at the banks of the Rhine to have settled, who the Rhine to cross were trying; over these to be in command Nasua and Cimberius brothers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Treveri reported that a hundred cantons of the Suebi had settled on the banks of the Rhine and were attempting to cross it, led by the brothers Nasua and Cimberius.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus Caesar vehementer commotus maturandum sibi existimavit, ne, si nova manus Sueborum cum veteribus copiis Ariovisti sese coniunxisset, minus facile resisti posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which things Caesar violently moved to be hastened by him thought, lest, if a new band of Suebi with the old forces of Ariovistus itself had joined, less easily it could be resisted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which things Caesar violently moved to be hastened by him thought, lest, if a new band of Suebi with the old forces of Ariovistus itself had joined, less easily it could be resisted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Greatly disturbed by these reports, Caesar decided he must act quickly, fearing that if this new band of Suebi joined Ariovistus's veteran forces, it would be harder to resist them.

sentences.latin: Itaque re frumentaria quam celerrime potuit comparata magnis itineribus ad Ariovistum contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so the matter grain as quickly as he could having been prepared by great marches toward Ariovistus he hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so the matter grain as quickly as he could having been prepared by great marches to Ariovistus he hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, after arranging for grain supplies as quickly as possible, he advanced toward Ariovistus by forced marches.

sentences.latin: Cum tridui viam processisset, nuntiatum est ei Ariovistum cum suis omnibus copiis ad occupandum Vesontionem, quod est oppidum maximum Sequanorum, contendere [triduique viam a suis finibus processisse].
sentences.referenceTranslation: When of three days a way he had advanced, it was announced to him Ariovistus with his all forces to seizing Vesontio, which is the town largest of the Sequani, to be hastening [and of three days a way from his borders to have advanced].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When of three days way he had advanced, it was announced to him Ariovistus with his all forces to seizing Vesontio, which is the town largest of the Sequani, to hasten [and of three days way from his borders to have advanced].
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had advanced for three days, it was reported to him that Ariovistus was hastening with all his forces to seize Vesontio, the largest town of the Sequani, and had already advanced three days' journey from his own borders.

sentences.latin: Id ne accideret, magnopere sibi praecavendum Caesar existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That lest it should happen, greatly by himself to be guarded against Caesar was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That not it might happen, greatly for himself to be guarded against Caesar was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar thought he should take great precautions to prevent this from happening.

sentences.latin: Namque omnium rerum quae ad bellum usui erant summa erat in eo oppido facultas,
sentences.referenceTranslation: For indeed of all things which for war for use were, the greatest was in that town supply,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For indeed of all things which for war for use were the greatest was in that town supply,
sentences.naturalTranslation: For in that town there was a very great supply of all things which were useful for war,

sentences.latin: idque natura loci sic muniebatur ut magnam ad ducendum bellum daret facultatem, propterea quod flumen [alduas] Dubis ut circino circumductum paene totum oppidum cingit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: and it by the nature of the place so was being fortified that a great for prolonging the war it gave opportunity, because the river Dubis as if by a pair of compasses drawn around almost the whole town encircles,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and it by the nature of the place so was being fortified that a great for prolonging the war it gave opportunity, because the river Dubis as if by a compass drawn around almost the whole town encircles,
sentences.naturalTranslation: and it was so fortified by the nature of its site that it offered a great opportunity for prolonging the war, because the river Dubis, as if traced by a pair of compasses, encircles almost the entire town,

sentences.latin: reliquum spatium, quod est non amplius pedum MDC, qua flumen intermittit, mons continet magna altitudine, ita ut radices eius montis ex utraque parte ripae fluminis contingant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: the remaining space, which is not more of feet 1600, where the river leaves a gap, a mountain contains of great height, so that the roots of that mountain from each part and the banks of the river touch,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the remaining space, which is not more of feet 1600, where the river leaves a gap, a mountain contains of great height, so that the roots of that mountain from each part the banks of the river touch,
sentences.naturalTranslation: the remaining space, which is not more than sixteen hundred feet where the river breaks off, is occupied by a mountain of great height, so that the base of that mountain and the banks of the river touch on both sides,

sentences.latin: hunc murus circumdatus arcem efficit et cum oppido coniungit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: this a wall placed around a citadel makes and with the town joins.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: this a wall thrown around a citadel makes and with the town joins.
sentences.naturalTranslation: a wall built around this mountain makes it a citadel and connects it with the town.

sentences.latin: Huc Caesar magnis nocturnis diurnisque itineribus contendit occupatoque oppido ibi praesidium conlocat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hither Caesar by great nocturnal and diurnal marches hastened and the town having been occupied there a garrison he places.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hither Caesar by great nocturnal and diurnal marches hastened and the town having been occupied there a garrison he places.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar hastened here by forced marches by night and day, and having seized the town, he stationed a garrison there.

sentences.latin: Dum paucos dies ad Vesontionem rei frumentariae commeatusque causa moratur, ex percontatione nostrorum vocibusque Gallorum ac mercatorum, qui ingenti magnitudine corporum Germanos, incredibili virtute atque exercitatione in armis esse praedicabant (saepe numero sese cum his congressos ne vultum quidem atque aciem oculorum dicebant ferre potuisse), tantus subito timor omnem exercitum occupavit ut non mediocriter omnium mentes animosque perturbaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While for a few days at Vesontio of the grain matter and of supplies for the sake he delays, from the questioning of our men and the voices of the Gauls and of the merchants, who of huge size of bodies the Germans, of incredible valor and training in arms to be were declaring (often in number themselves with these having met not even the face and the flash of the eyes they were saying to bear to have been able), so great suddenly fear the whole army seized that not moderately of all the minds and spirits it was disturbing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While for a few days at Vesontio of grain supply and of provisions for the sake he delays, from the questioning of our men and the voices of the Gauls and merchants, who with huge magnitude of bodies the Germans, with incredible valor and practice in arms to be were declaring (often in number themselves with these having met not even the face and the flash of the eyes they were saying to bear to have been able), so great suddenly fear the whole army seized that not moderately of all the minds and spirits it disturbed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While he delayed for a few days at Vesontio for the sake of grain and supplies, from the inquiries of our men and the reports of the Gauls and merchantswho declared that the Germans were of huge physical size, incredible valor, and training in arms (saying that they themselves, having often encountered them, had not been able to bear even their expression and the flash of their eyes)a sudden fear so seized the whole army that it disturbed the minds and spirits of everyone to no small degree.

sentences.latin: Hic primum ortus est a tribunis militum, praefectis, reliquisque qui ex urbe amicitiae causa Caesarem secuti non magnum in re militari usum habebant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This first arose from the tribunes of the soldiers, the prefects, and the rest who from the city of friendship for the sake Caesar having followed not great in military matter experience were having:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This first arose from the tribunes of the soldiers, the prefects, and the rest who from the city for friendship's sake Caesar had followed not great in military matters experience were having:
sentences.naturalTranslation: This fear first arose from the military tribunes, the prefects, and the others who, having followed Caesar from the city for the sake of friendship, did not have much experience in military affairs:

sentences.latin: quorum alius alia causa inlata, quam sibi ad proficiscendum necessariam esse diceret, petebat ut eius voluntate discedere liceret; non nulli pudore adducti, ut timoris suspicionem vitarent, remanebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom one another cause having been brought forward, which for himself for setting out necessary to be he was saying, was asking that by his will to depart it might be permitted; some by shame influenced, so that of fear the suspicion they might avoid, were remaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom one another cause having been brought forward, which for himself for setting out necessary to be he was saying, was asking that by his will to depart it might be permitted; some by shame influenced, so that of fear suspicion they might avoid, were remaining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: of these, one after another, bringing forward different reasons which they said made it necessary for them to leave, asked that they might be allowed to depart with his permission; some, moved by shame, remained to avoid the suspicion of fear.

sentences.latin: Hi neque vultum fingere neque interdum lacrimas tenere poterant: abditi in tabernaculis aut suum fatum querebantur aut cum familiaribus suis commune periculum miserabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These neither their face to disguise nor sometimes tears to hold back were able: hidden in tents either their own fate they were bewailing or with their intimates the common danger they were lamenting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These neither their expression to disguise nor sometimes tears to hold back were able: hidden in tents either their own fate they were bewailing or with their friends the common danger they were lamenting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men were able neither to control their expressions nor at times to hold back their tears: hidden in their tents, they either bewailed their own fate or lamented the common danger with their friends.

sentences.latin: Vulgo totis castris testamenta obsignabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Commonly in the whole camp wills were being sealed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Commonly in the whole camp wills were being sealed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Throughout the entire camp, wills were being signed and sealed everywhere.

sentences.latin: Horum vocibus ac timore paulatim etiam ii qui magnum in castris usum habebant, milites centurionesque quique equitatui praeerant, perturbabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the voices and fear of these gradually even those who great in camp experience had, soldiers and centurions and who over the cavalry were in command, were being disturbed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these men's voices and fear gradually even those who great in the camp experience were having, soldiers and centurions and those who over the cavalry were in command, were being disturbed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By the talk and fear of these men, even those who had great experience in the fieldsoldiers, centurions, and cavalry commandersgradually became unsettled.

sentences.latin: Qui se ex his minus timidos existimari volebant, non se hostem vereri, sed angustias itineris et magnitudinem silvarum quae intercederent inter ipsos atque Ariovistum, aut rem frumentariam, ut satis commode supportari posset, timere dicebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who themselves from these less timid to be thought were wishing, not themselves the enemy to fear, but the narrowness of the journey and the greatness of the forests which were coming between between themselves and Ariovistus, or the grain supply, that sufficiently conveniently to be brought up it might be able, to fear were saying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Those who themselves from these less fearful to be thought were wishing, not that they the enemy feared, but the narrowness of the route and the magnitude of the forests which were coming between between themselves and Ariovistus, or the grain supply, that sufficiently conveniently to be brought up it might be able, to fear they were saying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those among them who wished to be thought less timid claimed they did not fear the enemy, but rather the narrowness of the route, the vastness of the forests between them and Ariovistus, or that the grain supply might not be brought up easily enough.

sentences.latin: Non nulli etiam Caesari nuntiabant, cum castra moveri ac signa ferri iussisset, non fore dicto audientes milites neque propter timorem signa laturos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not some even to Caesar were announcing, when the camp to be moved and the standards to be carried he had ordered, not to be to the word hearing the soldiers nor on account of fear the standards would carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Some even to Caesar were announcing, when the camp to be moved and the standards to be carried he had ordered, not they would be to the word obedient the soldiers nor on account of fear the standards they would carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some even informed Caesar that when he gave the order to break camp and advance, the soldiers would not obey and would refuse to carry the standards because of their fear.

sentences.latin: Haec cum animadvertisset, convocato consilio omniumque ordinum ad id consilium adhibitis centurionibus, vehementer eos incusavit: primum, quod aut quam in partem aut quo consilio ducerentur sibi quaerendum aut cogitandum putarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things when he had noticed, with a council called and of all ranks to that council admitted centurions, vehemently them he rebuked: first, because either into what part or with what plan they were being led for themselves to be asked or to be thought they were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things when he had noticed, a council having been called and of all ranks to that council having been summoned the centurions, vehemently them he blamed: first, because either into what part or with what plan they were being led for themselves to be asked or to be thought they were thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he noticed these things, he called a council and, having summoned the centurions of all ranks, severely rebuked them: first, because they thought it was their business to ask or wonder where or with what purpose they were being led.

sentences.latin: Ariovistum se consule cupidissime populi Romani amicitiam adpetisse; cur hunc tam temere quisquam ab officio discessurum iudicaret?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ariovistus himself being consul most eagerly of the people Roman the friendship had sought; why this one so rashly anyone from duty to depart would judge?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ariovistus he being consul most eagerly of the Roman people the friendship had sought; why this one so blindly anyone from duty to be about to depart would judge?
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stated that Ariovistus had most eagerly sought the friendship of the Roman people during Caesar's own consulship; why should anyone judge that he would so rashly abandon his obligations?

sentences.latin: Sibi quidem persuaderi cognitis suis postulatis atque aequitate condicionum perspecta eum neque suam neque populi Romani gratiam repudiaturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To himself indeed it was being persuaded with known his demands and the fairness of the conditions perceived him neither his own nor of the people Roman the favor would reject.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To himself indeed it was being persuaded his demands having been known and the fairness of the conditions having been seen that he neither his own nor of the Roman people the favor would reject.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was personally convinced that once his demands were known and the fairness of his terms understood, Ariovistus would reject neither his own favor nor that of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Quod si furore atque amentia impulsum bellum intulisset, quid tandem vererentur?
sentences.referenceTranslation: But if by madness and insanity driven war he had brought in, what finally should they fear?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But if by fury and madness driven war he had brought on, what finally would they fear?
sentences.naturalTranslation: But if, driven by madness and insanity, he did start a war, what, after all, did they have to fear?

sentences.latin: Aut cur de sua virtute aut de ipsius diligentia desperarent?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Or why about their own courage or about of himself the diligence should they despair?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Or why about their own valor or about his own care would they despair?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Or why should they despair of their own courage or of his own careful leadership?

sentences.latin: Factum eius hostis periculum patrum nostrorum memoria Cimbris et Teutonis a C. Mario pulsis [cum non minorem laudem exercitus quam ipse imperator meritus videbatur]; factum etiam nuper in Italia servili tumultu, quos tamen aliquid usus ac disciplina, quam a nobis accepissent, sublevarint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Made of this enemy a trial in of fathers our memory with the Cimbri and Teutoni by C. Marius driven [when not less praise the army than himself the commander having deserved was seen]; made also recently in Italy in the slave uprising, whom however some use and discipline, which from us they had received, assisted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Made [was] a trial of this enemy in the memory of our fathers, the Cimbri and Teutons having been driven off by C. Marius [when the army seemed to have deserved no less praise than the commander himself]; it was made also recently in Italy in the slave revolt, whom nevertheless some experience and discipline, which they had received from us, assisted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A trial of this enemy had been made in the memory of our fathers, when the Cimbri and Teutoni were defeated by Gaius Marius (at which time the army was seen to have deserved no less praise than the commander himself); it had also been made recently during the slave revolt in Italy, whom experience and the discipline they had learned from us assisted to some extent.

sentences.latin: Ex quo iudicari posse quantum haberet in se boni constantia, propterea quod quos aliquam diu inermes sine causa timuissent hos postea armatos ac victores superassent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From which to be judged to be able how much it might have in itself of good firmness, because those whom for some time unarmed without cause they had feared these afterwards armed and victors they had overcome.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From which to be judged to be able how much it might have in itself of good, resolution, because those whom for some time unarmed without cause they had feared, these afterwards armed and victors they had overcome.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From this, it could be judged how much advantage firmness possesses, because those whom they had feared for some time without cause while unarmed, they later overcame even when they were armed and victorious.

sentences.latin: Denique hos esse eosdem Germanos quibuscum saepe numero Helvetii congressi non solum in suis sed etiam in illorum finibus plerumque superarint, qui tamen pares esse nostro exercitui non potuerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Finally these to be the same Germans with whom often in number the Helvetii having met not only in their own but also in those ones' territories for the most part have overcome, who however equal to be to our army have not been able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Finally these to be the same Germans with whom often in number the Helvetii having met not only in their own but also in those ones' territories mostly have overcome, who however equal to be to our army have not been able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Finally, these were the same Germans whom the Helvetii had frequently encountered and defeated, not only in their own territory but also in that of the Germans; yet the Helvetii had not been able to equal our army.

sentences.latin: Si quos adversum proelium et fuga Gallorum commoveret, hos, si quaererent, reperire posse diuturnitate belli defatigatis Gallis Ariovistum, cum multos menses castris se ac paludibus tenuisset neque sui potestatem fecisset, desperantes iam de pugna et dispersos subito adortum magis ratione et consilio quam virtute vicisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If any the adverse battle and flight of the Gauls moved, these, if they should inquire, to be able to find by the long duration of the war the Gauls having been exhausted Ariovistus, when for many months in camps himself and in marshes he had held nor of himself opportunity he had made, despairing now of battle and scattered suddenly having attacked more by strategy and by counsel than by valor to have conquered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If any the adverse battle and flight of the Gauls moved, these, if they should ask, to be able to find by the long duration of the war having been exhausted the Gauls Ariovistus, when many months in camps himself and in marshes he had held nor of himself opportunity he had made, despairing now of battle and dispersed suddenly having attacked more by reason and by plan than by valor to have conquered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If any were troubled by the Gauls' defeat and flight, they could discover, if they inquired, that Ariovistus had waited until the Gauls were exhausted by the long war; after keeping himself in his camp and marshes for many months without offering an opportunity for battle, he had suddenly attacked them while they were despairing of a fight and dispersed, thus conquering them more by strategy and cunning than by courage.

sentences.latin: Cui rationi contra homines barbaros atque imperitos locus fuisset, hac ne ipsum quidem sperare nostros exercitus capi posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For which strategy against men barbarian and unskilled a place had been, by this not even himself to hope our armies to be able to be caught.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For which strategy against men barbarian and unskilled a place had been, by this not even himself to hope our armies to be able to be caught.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although there had been a place for such a strategy against uncivilized and inexperienced men, not even Ariovistus himself expected that our armies could be caught by it.

sentences.latin: Qui suum timorem in rei frumentariae simulationem angustiasque itineris conferrent, facere arroganter, cum aut de officio imperatoris desperare aut praescribere viderentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who their own fear into of the grain supply pretense and narrowness of the route might bring, to act arrogantly, since either of the duty of the commander to despair or to dictate they seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who their own fear into of the grain supply pretense and narrowness of the route might bring, to act arrogantly, since either about the duty of the commander to despair or to dictate they seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who attributed their fear to a pretense about the grain supply or the narrowness of the route were acting arrogantly, as they seemed either to lack confidence in their commander's sense of duty or to be dictating to him.

sentences.latin: Haec sibi esse curae; frumentum Sequanos, Leucos, Lingones subministrare, iamque esse in agris frumenta matura; de itinere ipsos brevi tempore iudicaturos.
