sentences.referenceTranslation: These things to himself to be for a care; grain the Sequani, Leuci, Lingones to supply, and already to be in the fields the crops ripe; about the route themselves in a short time to be about to judge.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things to himself to be for a care; grain the Sequani, Leuci, Lingones to supply, and now to be in the fields grains ripe; about the route themselves in a short time to be about to judge.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These matters were his concern; the Sequani, Leuci, and Lingones were supplying grain, and the crops were already ripe in the fields; as for the route, they would soon be able to judge for themselves.

sentences.latin: Quod non fore dicto audientes neque signa laturi dicantur, nihil se ea re commoveri: scire enim, quibuscumque exercitus dicto audiens non fuerit, aut male re gesta fortunam defuisse aut aliquo facinore comperto avaritiam esse convictam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As to that not to be about to be to the word hearing nor the standards about to carry they are said, in no way himself by that thing to be moved: to know for, to whomsoever the army to the word hearing has not been, either badly the thing having been done fortune to have failed or some crime having been discovered greed to have been proved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because not to be about to be to the word hearing nor the standards about to carry they are said, nothing himself by that thing to be moved: to know for, for whomsoever an army to the word hearing not has been, either badly the thing having been done fortune to have failed or some crime having been discovered greed to have been proved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As for the report that they would not be obedient to his command or carry the standards, he was not at all disturbed by it; for he knew that whenever an army had not been obedient to its commander, it was either because fortune had failed them through some disaster or because greed had been proven by the discovery of some crime.

sentences.latin: Suam innocentiam perpetua vita, felicitatem Helvetiorum bello esse perspectam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: His own integrity by perpetual life, luck by of the Helvetii the war to have been seen through.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: His own integrity in his whole life, his luck in the Helvetian war to have been seen through.
sentences.naturalTranslation: His own integrity had been clearly seen throughout his whole life, and his good fortune in the war with the Helvetii.

sentences.latin: Itaque se quod in longiorem diem conlaturus fuisset repraesentaturum et proxima nocte de quarta, vigilia castra moturum, ut quam primum intellegere posset utrum apud eos pudor atque officium an timor plus valeret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore himself what into a longer day he had been about to put off to be about to do at once and on the next night from the fourth watch the camp to be about to move, so that as soon as possible to understand he might be able whether among them shame and duty or fear more might prevail.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore himself what into a longer day he had been about to postpone to be about to do now and on the next night from the fourth watch the camp to be about to move, so that as soon as possible to understand he might be able whether among them shame and duty or fear more might prevail.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he would do immediately what he had intended to postpone to a later day, and would move camp during the fourth watch of the coming night, so that he might find out as soon as possible whether a sense of honor and duty or fear had more influence over them.

sentences.latin: Quod si praeterea nemo sequatur, tamen se cum sola decima legione iturum, de qua non dubitet, sibique eam praetoriam cohortem futuram.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But if besides no one should follow, yet himself with the alone tenth legion to be about to go, about which not he might doubt, and to himself it the praetorian cohort to be about to be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But if besides no one should follow, nevertheless himself with only the tenth legion to be about to go, about which not he doubts, and to himself it the praetorian cohort to be about to be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But if no one else should follow, he would nevertheless go with the tenth legion alone, of which he had no doubt, and it would serve as his bodyguard.

sentences.latin: Huic legioni Caesar et indulserat praecipue et propter virtutem confidebat maxime.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this legion Caesar both had indulged especially and on account of courage was trusting most.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this legion Caesar both had been indulgent especially and on account of valor was trusting most.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar had both shown special favor to this legion and placed the greatest confidence in it because of its courage.

sentences.latin: Hac oratione habita mirum in modum conversae sunt omnium mentes summaque alacritas et cupiditas belli gerendi innata est,
sentences.referenceTranslation: This speech having been delivered, in a wonderful manner turned were of all the minds and the highest eagerness and desire of war waging was born,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This speech having been delivered in a wonderful manner turned were of all the minds and the highest eagerness and desire of the war to be waged was born,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this speech was delivered, the minds of all were changed in a wonderful way, and the highest enthusiasm and desire for waging war were inspired.

sentences.latin: princepsque X. legio per tribunos militum ei gratias egit quod de se optimum iudicium fecisset, seque esse ad bellum gerendum paratissimam confirmavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and first the 10th legion through the tribunes of soldiers to him thanks gave because about themselves the best judgment he had made, and themselves to be for war waging most ready confirmed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and first the 10th legion through the tribunes of the soldiers to him thanks gave because about themselves the best judgment he had made, and themselves to be for the war to be waged most ready it confirmed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Tenth Legion was the first to return thanks to him through their military tribunes for having formed such an excellent opinion of them, and they confirmed that they were fully prepared to wage war.

sentences.latin: Deinde reliquae legiones cum tribunis militum et primorum ordinum centurionibus egerunt uti Caesari satis facerent: se neque umquam dubitasse neque timuisse neque de summa belli suum iudicium sed imperatoris esse existimavisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then the remaining legions with the tribunes of soldiers and of the first ranks centurions acted so that to Caesar satisfaction they might make: themselves neither ever to have doubted nor to have feared nor about the sum of the war their own judgment but the commander's to be they had thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then the remaining legions with the tribunes of the soldiers and of the first ranks the centurions arranged so that to Caesar enough they might do: themselves neither ever to have doubted nor to have feared nor about the sum of the war their own judgment but the commander's to be to have thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then the remaining legions arranged with their military tribunes and the centurions of the first rank to apologize to Caesar, explaining that they had never hesitated nor felt fear, nor had they thought that the decision regarding the conduct of the war belonged to them, but rather to their commander.

sentences.latin: Eorum satisfactione accepta et itinere exquisito per Diviciacum, quod ex Gallis ei maximam fidem habebat, ut milium amplius quinquaginta circuitu locis apertis exercitum duceret, de quarta vigilia, ut dixerat, profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Their apology having been accepted and the route having been searched out through Diviciacus, because from the Gauls in him the greatest faith he was having, so that of miles more than fifty by a circuit in places open the army he might lead, from the fourth watch, as he had said, he set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Their apology having been accepted and the route having been searched out through Diviciacus, because from the Gauls in him the greatest faith he was having, so that of miles more than fifty by a circuit in places open the army he might lead, from the fourth watch, as he had said, he set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having accepted their apology and having scouted the route through Diviciacuswhom he trusted most among the Gaulsso that he could lead the army through open country by a detour of more than fifty miles, he set out during the fourth watch, as he had said.

sentences.latin: Septimo die, cum iter non intermitteret, ab exploratoribus certior factus est Ariovisti copias a nostris milia passuum IIII et XX abesse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the seventh day, since the march he was not interrupting, by scouts more certain he was made Ariovistus's forces from ours thousands of paces 4 and 20 to be away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the seventh day, when the march not he was interrupting, by scouts more certain he was made the of Ariovistus forces from ours miles of paces 24 to be away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the seventh day, as he did not interrupt his march, he was informed by scouts that Ariovistus's forces were twenty-four miles away from our own.

sentences.latin: Cognito Caesaris adventu Ariovistus legatos ad eum mittit: quod antea de conloquio postulasset, id per se fieri licere, quoniam propius accessisset seque id sine periculo facere posse existimaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been known Caesar's arrival, Ariovistus ambassadors to him sends: what before about a conference he had requested, that through himself to happen it was permitted, since nearer he had approached and himself that without danger to do to be able he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been known of Caesar the arrival Ariovistus ambassadors to him sends: what before about a conference he had demanded, that through himself to be done to be permitted, since nearer he had approached and himself it without danger to be able to do he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar's arrival was known, Ariovistus sent ambassadors to him: stating that what he had previously requested regarding a conference could now happen as far as he was concerned, since Caesar had approached closer and he thought he could do it without danger.

sentences.latin: Non respuit condicionem Caesar iamque eum ad sanitatem reverti arbitrabatur, cum id quod antea petenti denegasset ultro polliceretur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not rejected the condition Caesar and now him to sanity to return he was thinking, when that which before to him seeking he had denied of his own accord he was promising,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not rejected the condition Caesar and now him to sanity to return he was thinking, when that which before to [him] seeking he had denied of his own accord he was promising,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar did not reject the proposal and began to think that Ariovistus was returning to his senses, since he was now voluntarily promising what he had previously refused when requested.

sentences.latin: magnamque in spem veniebat pro suis tantis populique Romani in eum beneficiis cognitis suis postulatis fore uti pertinacia desisteret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and into great hope he was coming in return for his so great and of the people Roman toward him benefits, having been known his demands, it would be that from stubbornness he might desist.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and into great hope he was coming in return for his own so great and of the people Roman toward him benefits having been known his own demands it would be that from stubbornness he might desist.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He began to have great hope that, in consideration of his own and the Roman people's great favors toward him, Ariovistus would abandon his stubbornness once he learned Caesar's demands.

sentences.latin: Dies conloquio dictus est ex eo die quintus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A day for the conference appointed was from that day the fifth.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A day for the conference appointed was from that day the fifth.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The fifth day from that one was appointed for the conference.

sentences.latin: Interim saepe cum legati ultro citroque inter eos mitterentur, Ariovistus postulavit ne quem peditem ad conloquium Caesar adduceret: vereri se ne per insidias ab eo circumveniretur; uterque cum equitatu veniret: alia ratione sese non esse venturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile often when envoys back and forth between them were sent, Ariovistus demanded that not any foot-soldier to the conference Caesar should bring: to fear himself lest through ambushes by him he be surrounded; each with cavalry should come: by other reason himself not to be about to come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile often when envoys back and forth between them were being sent, Ariovistus demanded that not any foot-soldier to the conference Caesar should lead: to fear himself lest through ambushes by him he might be surrounded; each with cavalry should come: by other reason himself not to be about to come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, as envoys were frequently sent back and forth between them, Ariovistus demanded that Caesar bring no infantry to the conference, stating that he feared he might be ambushed by him; he insisted that both should come with cavalry, otherwise he would not attend.

sentences.latin: Caesar, quod neque conloquium interposita causa tolli volebat neque salutem suam Gallorum equitatui committere audebat, commodissimum esse statuit omnibus equis Gallis equitibus detractis eo legionarios milites legionis X., cui quam maxime confidebat, imponere, ut praesidium quam amicissimum, si quid opus facto esset, haberet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, because neither the conference an introduced cause being put in the way to be removed he was wishing nor safety his own to the Gallic cavalry to entrust he was daring, most convenient to be he decided all horses from the Gallic horsemen having been taken away there legionary soldiers of the 10th legion, in whom as much as possible he was trusting, to put on, so that a protection as friendly as possible, if any need for action should be, he might have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, because neither the conference an excuse having been interposed to be cancelled he was wishing nor safety his own to the Gauls' cavalry to entrust he was daring, most convenient to be he decided all horses from the Gallic horsemen having been taken away there legionary soldiers of the 10th legion, in whom as much as possible he was trusting, to place, so that a protection as friendly as possible, if any need for action should be, he might have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, because he did not want the conference to be canceled on any pretext and did not dare entrust his safety to the Gallic cavalry, decided the most convenient course was to take all the horses from the Gallic horsemen and mount the legionary soldiers of the Tenth Legion (whom he trusted most) upon them, so that he would have the most loyal escort possible if any action were needed.

sentences.latin: Quod cum fieret, non inridicule quidam ex militibus X. legionis dixit: plus quam pollicitus esset Caesarem facere; pollicitum se in cohortis praetoriae loco X. legionem habiturum ad equum rescribere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when it was being done, not without wit a certain one from the soldiers of the 10th legion said: more than what he had promised Caesar to be doing; having promised himself in the cohort praetorian's place the 10th legion he would have, to the horse he was re-enrolling.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when it was being done, not without wit a certain one from the soldiers of the 10th legion said: more than what he had promised Caesar to be doing; having promised himself in the cohort praetorian's place the 10th legion he would have, to the horse he was enrolling.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While this was being done, a soldier of the Tenth Legion remarked quite wittily that Caesar was doing more than he had promised; for having promised to treat the Tenth Legion as his bodyguard, he was now enrolling them among the cavalry.

sentences.latin: Planities erat magna et in ea tumulus terrenus satis grandis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A plain there was large and in it a mound of earth sufficiently big.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A plain there was large and in it a mound of earth sufficiently big.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a large plain, and in it a mound of earth of considerable size.

sentences.latin: Hic locus aequum fere spatium a castris Ariovisti et Caesaris aberat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This place an equal almost distance from the camps of Ariovistus and of Caesar was distant.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This place an equal nearly distance from the camps of Ariovistus and of Caesar was away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This spot was almost equally distant from the camps of Ariovistus and Caesar.

sentences.latin: Eo, ut erat dictum, ad conloquium venerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To there, as it had been said, to the conference they came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To there, as it had been said, to the conference they came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They came there to the conference, as had been agreed.

sentences.latin: Legionem Caesar, quam equis devexerat, passibus CC ab eo tumulo constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The legion Caesar, which on horses he had carried, by paces 200 from that mound he stationed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The legion Caesar, which on horses he had carried, by paces 200 from that mound he stationed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar stationed the legion which he had brought on horseback two hundred paces from the mound.

sentences.latin: Item equites Ariovisti pari intervallo constiterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Likewise the horsemen of Ariovistus at an equal interval took their stand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Likewise the horsemen of Ariovistus at an equal distance halted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Likewise, the horsemen of Ariovistus took their position at an equal distance.

sentences.latin: Ariovistus ex equis ut conloquerentur et praeter se denos ad conloquium adducerent postulavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ariovistus from horses that they should confer and besides themselves ten each to the conference they should bring demanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ariovistus from horses that they should speak and besides themselves ten each to the conference they should lead he demanded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ariovistus demanded that they should confer on horseback and that each should bring ten men with him to the conference.

sentences.latin: Ubi eo ventum est, Caesar initio orationis sua senatusque in eum beneficia commemoravit, quod rex appellatus esset a senatu, quod amicus, quod munera amplissime missa; quam rem et paucis contigisse et pro magnis hominum officiis consuesse tribui docebat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When to there it was come, Caesar at the beginning of his speech his own and the senate's toward him benefits mentioned, that king he had been called by the senate, that friend, that gifts most generously had been sent; which thing both to few to have happened and in return for great of men services to be accustomed to be granted he was showing;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When to there it was come, Caesar at the beginning of his speech his own and the senate's toward him favors recounted, because king he had been called by the senate, because friend, because gifts most generously sent; which thing both to few to have happened and for great of men services to be accustomed to be granted he was showing;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they arrived there, Caesar began his speech by mentioning the favors bestowed upon Ariovistus by himself and the senate: that he had been called king and friend by the senate, and that gifts had been sent to him most generously. He pointed out that such a distinction had fallen to few and was usually granted only in return for great personal services.

sentences.latin: illum, cum neque aditum neque causam postulandi iustam haberet, beneficio ac liberalitate sua ac senatus ea praemia consecutum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that he, since neither access nor cause of requesting just he had, by benefit and liberality his own and of the senate those rewards had obtained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that he, although neither access nor cause of demanding just he had, by the favor and generosity of his own and the senate's those rewards had obtained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He explained that, although Ariovistus had no right of approach or just cause for his request, he had obtained those rewards through the kindness and generosity of Caesar himself and the senate.

sentences.latin: Docebat etiam quam veteres quamque iustae causae necessitudinis ipsis cum Haeduis intercederent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: He was showing also how old and how just causes of alliance to themselves with the Haedui existed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He was showing also how old and how just causes of alliance to themselves with the Haedui were existing,
sentences.naturalTranslation: He also pointed out how ancient and how just were the reasons for the alliance existing between the Romans and the Haedui,

sentences.latin: quae senatus consulta quotiens quamque honorifica in eos facta essent, ut omni tempore totius Galliae principatum Haedui tenuissent, prius etiam quam nostram amicitiam adpetissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: what senate decrees how often and how honorable toward them made had been, how in all time of all Gaul the leadership the Haedui had held, before even than our friendship they had sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: what senate decrees how often and how honorable toward them had been made, how at every time of all Gaul the leadership the Haedui had held, before even than our friendship they had sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: what decrees of the senate had been passed in their favor, how often, and how honorable they were; and how the Haedui had held the leadership of all Gaul at all times, even before they had sought our friendship.

sentences.latin: Populi Romani hanc esse consuetudinem, ut socios atque amicos non modo sui nihil deperdere, sed gratia, dignitate, honore auctiores velit esse; quod vero ad amicitiam populi Romani attulissent, id iis eripi quis pati posset?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the people Roman this to be the custom, that allies and friends not only of their own nothing to lose, but in influence, dignity, honor increased he wishes to be; what indeed to the friendship of the people Roman they had brought, that from them to be snatched away who to endure could?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the people Roman this to be the custom, that allies and friends not only of their own nothing to lose, but in influence, dignity, honor more increased he wishes to be; what indeed to the friendship of the people Roman they had brought, that from them to be snatched away who to endure could?
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was the custom of the Roman people to desire that their allies and friends should not only lose nothing of their own, but should be advanced in influence, dignity, and honor; who, then, could endure that what they had brought with them to the friendship of the Roman people should be torn from them?

sentences.latin: Postulavit deinde eadem quae legatis in mandatis dederat: ne aut Haeduis aut eorum sociis bellum inferret, obsides redderet, si nullam partem Germanorum domum remittere posset, at ne quos amplius Rhenum transire pateretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He demanded then the same things which to the ambassadors in instructions he had given: that not either on the Haedui or their allies war he should bring, hostages he should return, if no part of the Germans home to send back he was able, at least not any more the Rhine to cross he should allow.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He demanded then the same things which to the envoys in instructions he had given: that not either on the Haedui or their allies war he should bring, hostages he should return, if no part of the Germans home to send back he was able, yet not any more the Rhine to cross he should allow.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He then made the same demands which he had given in his instructions to the ambassadors: that he should not make war on either the Haedui or their allies, that he should return the hostages, and if he could not send any part of the Germans back home, he should at least not allow any more to cross the Rhine.

sentences.latin: Ariovistus ad postulata Caesaris pauca respondit, de suis virtutibus multa praedicavit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ariovistus to the demands of Caesar few things replied, about his own virtues many things he proclaimed:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ariovistus to the demands of Caesar few things replied, about his own virtues many things he proclaimed:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ariovistus replied briefly to Caesar's demands, but spoke at great length about his own merits:

sentences.latin: transisse Rhenum sese non sua sponte, sed rogatum et arcessitum a Gallis; non sine magna spe magnisque praemiis domum propinquosque reliquisse; sedes habere in Gallia ab ipsis concessas, obsides ipsorum voluntate datos; stipendium capere iure belli, quod victores victis imponere consuerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to have crossed the Rhine himself not of his own accord, but asked and summoned by the Gauls; not without great hope and great rewards home and kinsmen to have left; settlements to have in Gaul by themselves granted, hostages by their own will given; tribute to take by right of war, which victors on the vanquished to impose are accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to have crossed the Rhine himself not by his own will, but asked and summoned by the Gauls; not without great hope and great rewards home and kinsmen to have left; settlements to have in Gaul by themselves granted, hostages by their own will given; tribute to take by the law of war, which victors on the vanquished to impose are accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said that he had crossed the Rhine not of his own accord, but because he had been requested and summoned by the Gauls; that he had left his home and kinsmen not without great expectations and great rewards; that he held settlements in Gaul granted by the Gauls themselves, and hostages given of their own free will; and that he took tribute by the right of war, which victors are accustomed to impose on the vanquished.

sentences.latin: Non sese Gallis sed Gallos sibi bellum intulisse: omnes Galliae civitates ad se oppugnandum venisse ac contra se castra habuisse; eas omnes copias a se uno proelio pulsas ac superatas esse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not himself on the Gauls but the Gauls on him war had brought: all of Gaul states to himself to attack had come and against him camps had held; those all forces by him in one battle routed and overcome had been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not himself on the Gauls but the Gauls on him war to have brought: all of Gaul's states to himself to be attacked to have come and against him camps to have had; those all forces by himself in one battle routed and overcome to have been.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He had not made war on the Gauls, but the Gauls on him; all the states of Gaul had come to attack him and had encamped against him; all those forces had been routed and conquered by him in a single battle.

sentences.latin: Si iterum experiri velint, se iterum paratum esse decertare; si pace uti velint, iniquum esse de stipendio recusare, quod sua voluntate ad id tempus pependerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If again to try they wish, himself again ready to be to fight it out; if peace to use they wish, unfair to be about the tribute to refuse, which by their own will to that time they had paid.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If again to try they wish, himself again ready to be to fight it out; if peace to use they wish, unfair to be about the tribute to refuse, which by their own will to that time they have paid.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If they wished to try the fortune of war again, he was ready to fight again; if they wished to enjoy peace, it was unfair to refuse the tribute which they had paid of their own free will up to that time.

sentences.latin: Amicitiam populi Romani sibi ornamento et praesidio, non detrimento esse oportere, atque se hac spe petisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Friendship of the people Roman to him for an ornament and protection, not for a detriment to be it behooved, and himself with this hope had sought [it].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The friendship of the people Roman to himself for an ornament and protection, not for a detriment to be it ought, and himself with this hope to have sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The friendship of the Roman people ought to be an honor and a protection to him, not a disadvantage, and it was with this expectation that he had sought it.

sentences.latin: Si per populum Romanum stipendium remittatur et dediticii subtrahantur, non minus libenter sese recusaturum populi Romani amicitiam quam adpetierit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If through the people Roman the tribute should be remitted and the surrendered ones should be withdrawn, not less willingly himself to be about to reject of the people Roman the friendship than he sought [it].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If through the people Roman the tribute should be remitted and the surrendered ones withdrawn, not less gladly he himself would reject of the people Roman the friendship than he had sought [it].
sentences.naturalTranslation: If the Roman people were to remit the tribute and withdraw those who had surrendered, he would reject the friendship of the Roman people as readily as he had sought it.

sentences.latin: Quod multitudinem Germanorum in Galliam traducat, id se sui muniendi, non Galliae oppugnandae causa facere; eius rei testimonium esse quod nisi rogatus non venerit et quod bellum non intulerit sed defenderit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That a multitude of Germans into Gaul he leads across, that himself of himself strengthening, not of Gaul attacking for the sake to do; of this thing the testimony to be that unless asked not he came and that war not he brought in but fended off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As to that a multitude of Germans into Gaul he leads across, that he himself of himself protecting, not of Gaul attacking for the sake does; of this thing the proof to be that unless asked not he had come and that war not he had brought in but had warded off.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As for his leading a multitude of Germans into Gaul, he was doing it for the sake of strengthening himself, not for attacking Gaul; the proof of this was that he had not come unless requested and that he had not initiated war but had acted in self-defense.

sentences.latin: Se prius in Galliam venisse quam populum Romanum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself earlier into Gaul to have come than the people Roman.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That he earlier into Gaul had come than the people Roman.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He had come into Gaul before the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Numquam ante hoc tempus exercitum populi Romani Galliae provinciae finibus egressum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Never before this time the army of the people Roman of Gaul the province from the borders to have gone out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Never before this time an army of the people Roman from of the Gaul province the borders had gone out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Never before this time had an army of the Roman people gone beyond the borders of the Province of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Quid sibi vellet?
sentences.referenceTranslation: What for himself did he want?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: What for himself did he want?
sentences.naturalTranslation: What did Caesar want for himself?

sentences.latin: Cur in suas possessiones veniret?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Why into his possessions was he coming?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Why into his possessions was he coming?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Why was he entering his possessions?

sentences.latin: Provinciam suam hanc esse Galliam, sicut illam nostram.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Province his own this to be Gaul, just as that [one] ours.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Province his own this to be Gaul, just as that one [to be] ours.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This part of Gaul was his province, just as that other one was ours.

sentences.latin: Ut ipsi concedi non oporteret, si in nostros fines impetum faceret, sic item nos esse iniquos, quod in suo iure se interpellaremus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As to himself to be yielded not it ought, if into our borders an attack he should make, so likewise us to be unfair, because in his right him we were interrupting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As to himself to be yielded not it ought, if into our borders an attack he should make, so likewise us to be unfair, because in his right him we were interrupting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Just as no concession should be made to him if he were to make an attack on our borders, so likewise we were being unfair because we were interfering with him in his own right.

sentences.latin: Quod fratres a senatu Haeduos appellatos diceret, non se tam barbarum neque tam imperitum esse rerum ut non sciret neque bello Allobrogum proximo Haeduos Romanis auxilium tulisse neque ipsos in iis contentionibus quas Haedui secum et cum Sequanis habuissent auxilio populi Romani usos esse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That brothers by the senate the Haedui called he said, not himself so barbarian nor so unskilled to be of things that not he knew neither in the war of the Allobroges nearest the Haedui to the Romans help to have brought nor themselves in those struggles which the Haedui with himself and with the Sequani had had the help of the people Roman to have used.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As to that brothers by the senate the Haedui called he said, not himself so barbarian nor so unskilled to be of things that not he knew neither in the war of the Allobroges most recent the Haedui to the Romans help to have brought nor themselves in those struggles which the Haedui with himself and with the Sequani had had the help of the people Roman to have used.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As for Caesar's statement that the Haedui had been called brothers by the senate, he was not so much a barbarian nor so ignorant of affairs as not to know that the Haedui had neither brought help to the Romans in the recent war with the Allobroges, nor had they themselves used the help of the Roman people in those struggles which the Haedui had had with him and with the Sequani.

sentences.latin: Debere se suspicari simulata Caesarem amicitia, quod exercitum in Gallia habeat, sui opprimendi causa habere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To ought himself to suspect with feigned Caesar friendship, because an army in Gaul he has, of himself crushing for the sake to have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To ought himself to suspect with pretended Caesar friendship, because an army in Gaul he has, of himself crushing for the sake to have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He had reason to suspect that Caesar, under the pretense of friendship, was keeping an army in Gaul for the purpose of crushing him.

sentences.latin: Qui nisi decedat atque exercitum deducat ex his regionibus, sese illum non pro amico sed pro hoste habiturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who unless he should depart and army lead away from these regions, himself him not for friend but for enemy would hold.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who unless he should depart and the army lead away from these regions, himself him not for a friend but for an enemy would hold.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Unless he departed and withdrew his army from these regions, he would treat him not as a friend but as an enemy.

sentences.latin: Quod si eum interfecerit, multis sese nobilibus principibusque populi Romani gratum esse facturum (id se ab ipsis per eorum nuntios compertum habere), quorum omnium gratiam atque amicitiam eius morte redimere posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But if him he should kill, to many himself noblemen and leaders of the people Roman a favor to be about to do (this himself from themselves through their messengers discovered to have), of whom all favor and friendship by his death to buy back he would be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because if him he should kill, to many himself nobles and leading men of the people Roman a favor to be about to do (that himself from themselves through their messengers discovered to have), of whom all the favor and friendship by his death to buy back he would be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he were to kill him, he would be doing a favor to many nobles and leaders of the Roman people (a fact he claimed to have learned from them through their own messengers), and he could purchase the gratitude and friendship of them all by Caesar's death.

sentences.latin: Quod si decessisset et liberam possessionem Galliae sibi tradidisset, magno se illum praemio remuneraturum et quaecumque bella geri vellet sine ullo eius labore et periculo confecturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But if he had departed and free possession of Gaul to him had handed over, with a great himself him reward would repay and whatever wars to be carried out he wished without any of his labor and danger would finish.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But if he had departed and free possession of Gaul to him had handed over, with a great himself him reward would repay and whatever wars to be waged he wished without any of him labor and danger would finish.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he withdrew and left him in free possession of Gaul, he would reward him with a great prize and would finish whatever wars he wanted fought without any effort or danger on his part.

sentences.latin: Multa a Caesare in eam sententiam dicta sunt quare negotio desistere non posset: neque suam neque populi Romani consuetudinem pati ut optime meritos socios desereret, neque se iudicare Galliam potius esse Ariovisti quam populi Romani.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Many things by Caesar in that opinion were said why from the business to desist not he was able: neither his own nor of the people Roman custom to allow that best deserving allies he should desert, nor himself to judge Gaul rather to be of Ariovistus than of the people Roman.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Many things by Caesar into that opinion were said why from the business to desist not he was able: neither his own nor of the people Roman custom to allow that best deserving allies he should desert, nor himself to judge Gaul rather to be of Ariovistus than of the people Roman.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar spoke at length to the effect that he could not abandon the business: neither his own custom nor that of the Roman people allowed him to desert allies who had served them so well, nor did he judge that Gaul belonged to Ariovistus rather than to the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Bello superatos esse Arvernos et Rutenos a Q. Fabio Maximo, quibus populus Romanus ignovisset neque in provinciam redegisset neque stipendium posuisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In war overcome to have been the Arverni and Ruteni by Q. Fabius Maximus, whom the people Roman had pardoned and not into a province had reduced nor tribute had imposed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In war overcome to have been the Arverni and Ruteni by Q. Fabius Maximus, whom the people Roman had pardoned and not into a province had reduced nor tribute had imposed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He noted that the Arverni and Ruteni had been conquered in war by Quintus Fabius Maximus, but the Roman people had pardoned them and had neither reduced them to a province nor imposed a tribute.

sentences.latin: Quod si antiquissimum quodque tempus spectari oporteret, populi Romani iustissimum esse in Gallia imperium; si iudicium senatus observari oporteret, liberam debere esse Galliam, quam bello victam suis legibus uti voluisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But if most ancient each time to be looked at it behooved, of the people Roman most just to be in Gaul the command; if the judgment of the senate to be observed it behooved, free to ought to be Gaul, which in war conquered with its own laws to use it had wished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because if most ancient each time to be looked at it ought, of the people Roman most just to be in Gaul the sovereignty; if the judgment of the senate to be observed it ought, free to ought to be Gaul, which in war conquered with its own laws to use it had wished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If priority of time was to be the criterion, then the Roman people's claim to sovereignty in Gaul was most just; if the judgment of the Senate was to be followed, Gaul ought to be free, since the Senate had decreed that, though conquered in war, it should be allowed to use its own laws.

sentences.latin: Dum haec in conloquio geruntur, Caesari nuntiatum est equites Ariovisti propius tumulum accedere et ad nostros adequitare, lapides telaque in nostros coicere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things in the parley are being done, to Caesar it was announced the horsemen of Ariovistus nearer the mound to approach and toward our men to ride, stones and weapons against our men to hurl.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things in the conference are being done, to Caesar it was announced the horsemen of Ariovistus nearer the mound to approach and toward our men to ride, stones and weapons against our men to hurl.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these things were being discussed in the parley, Caesar was informed that Ariovistus' horsemen were approaching closer to the mound, riding toward our men, and hurling stones and weapons at them.

sentences.latin: Caesar loquendi finem fecit seque ad suos recepit suisque imperavit ne quod omnino telum in hostes reicerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar of speaking an end made and himself to his own withdrew and to his own commanded that not any at all weapon against the enemies they should throw back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar of speaking an end made and himself to his own [men] withdrew and to his own [men] commanded that not any at all weapon against the enemies they should throw back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar ended the discussion, withdrew to his own men, and ordered them not to throw back a single weapon at the enemy.

sentences.latin: Nam etsi sine ullo periculo legionis delectae cum equitatu proelium fore videbat, tamen committendum non putabat ut, pulsis hostibus, dici posset eos ab se per fidem in conloquio circumventos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For although without any danger of the legion chosen with the cavalry a battle to be about to be he saw, yet to be joined not he thought so that, having been driven back the enemies, to be said it could be them by him through faith in parley surrounded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For although without any danger of the legion chosen with the cavalry a battle to be about to be he saw, yet to be joined not he thought that, having been driven back the enemies, to be said it could they by him through faith in conference [were] surrounded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For although he saw that a battle between his elite legion and the cavalry would be without any danger, he still did not think he should engage, so that it could not be said, once the enemy were routed, that they had been trapped by him through a breach of faith during a parley.

sentences.latin: Postea quam in vulgus militum elatum est qua arrogantia in conloquio Ariovistus usus omni Gallia Romanis interdixisset, impetumque in nostros eius equites fecissent, eaque res conloquium ut diremisset, multo maior alacritas studiumque pugnandi maius exercitui iniectum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After that into the common crowd of soldiers it was spread with what arrogance in the parley Ariovistus having used from all Gaul the Romans he had forbidden, and an attack against our men his horsemen had made, and that thing the parley how it had broken off, much greater alacrity and zeal of fighting greater to the army was injected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After that into the common [crowd] of soldiers it was spread with what arrogance in the conference Ariovistus having used from all Gaul the Romans he had excluded, and an attack against our men his horsemen had made, and that thing the conference how it had broken off, much greater eagerness and desire of fighting greater to the army was infused.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After it was reported to the rank and file with what arrogance Ariovistus had behaved in the parley, how he had forbidden the Romans from all Gaul, how his horsemen had attacked our men, and how that event had broken off the conference, a much greater alacrity and a greater zeal for fighting was infused into the army.

sentences.latin: Biduo post Ariovistus ad Caesarem legatos misit: velle se de iis rebus quae inter eos egi coeptae neque perfectae essent agere cum eo: uti aut iterum conloquio diem constitueret aut, si id minus vellet, ex suis legatis aliquem ad se mitteret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Two days after Ariovistus to Caesar ambassadors sent: to want himself about those things which between them to be discussed begun and not finished were to treat with him: that either again for a conference a day he should appoint or, if that less he wished, from his own lieutenants someone to himself he should send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Two days after, Ariovistus sends embassadors to Caesar, to state "that he wished to treat with him about those things which had been begun to be treated of between them, but had not been concluded;" [and to beg] that "he would either again appoint a day for a conference; or, if he were not willing to do that, that he would send one of his [officers] as an embassador to him." There did not appear to Caesar any good reason for holding a conference; and the more so as the day before the Germans could not be restrained from casting weapons at our men.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Two days later, Ariovistus sent ambassadors to Caesar, stating that he wished to discuss with him those matters which they had begun to treat but had not finished; he asked that Caesar either appoint a day for a conference again or, if he were unwilling to do that, send one of his lieutenants to him.

sentences.latin: Conloquendi Caesari causa visa non est, et eo magis quod pridie eius diei Germani retineri non potuerant quin tela in nostros coicerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of conferring to Caesar a cause seen was not, and by that more because on the day before of that day the Germans to be held back not had been able but that weapons against ours they threw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He thought he should not without great danger send to him as embassador one of his [Roman] officers, and should expose him to savage men.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar saw no reason for a conference, all the more so because on the previous day the Germans could not be restrained from hurling missiles at our men.

sentences.latin: Legatum ex suis sese magno cum periculo ad eum missurum et hominibus feris obiecturum existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A lieutenant from his own he himself with great danger to him about to send and to men savage about to expose was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It seemed [therefore] most proper to send to him C. Valerius Procillus, the son of C.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He thought that sending one of his own lieutenants to him would be at great risk and would expose him to savage men.

sentences.latin: Commodissimum visum est C. Valerium Procillum, C. Valerii Caburi filium, summa virtute et humanitate adulescentem, cuius pater a C. Valerio Flacco civitate donatus erat, et propter fidem et propter linguae Gallicae scientiam, qua multa iam Ariovistus longinqua consuetudine utebatur, et quod in eo peccandi Germanis causa non esset, ad eum mittere, et una M. Metium, qui hospitio Ariovisti utebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Most convenient it seemed Gaius Valerius Procillus, of Gaius Valerius Caburus the son, of highest virtue and refinement a young man, whose father by Gaius Valerius Flacco with citizenship presented had been, both on account of loyalty and on account of of the Gallic language knowledge, which much now Ariovistus by long habit was using, and because in him of offending for the Germans a cause not was, to him to send, and together Marcus Metius, who the hospitality of Ariovistus was using.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Valerius Caburus, a young man of the highest courage and accomplishments (whose father had been presented with the freedom of the city by C.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It seemed most suitable to send to him Gaius Valerius Procillus, son of Gaius Valerius Caburus, a young man of the highest merit and refinementwhose father had been granted citizenship by Gaius Valerius Flaccoboth for his loyalty and his knowledge of the Gallic language, which Ariovistus now used extensively from long habit, and because the Germans had no reason to mistreat him; and with him, Marcus Metius, who enjoyed the hospitality of Ariovistus.

sentences.latin: His mandavit quae diceret Ariovistus cognoscerent et ad se referrent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these he entrusted what might say Ariovistus they should learn and to him report back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Valerius Flaccus), both on account of his fidelity and on account of his knowledge of the Gallic language, which Ariovistus, by long practice, now spoke fluently; and because in his case the Germans would have no motive for committing violence; and [as his colleague] M. Mettius, who had shared the hospitality of Ariovistus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He instructed them to learn what Ariovistus had to say and report back to him.

sentences.latin: Quos cum apud se in castris Ariovistus conspexisset, exercitu suo praesente conclamavit: quid ad se venirent? an speculandi causa?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom when among himself in the camp Ariovistus had seen, with army his present he shouted: why to him were they coming? or of spying for the sake?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He commissioned them to learn what Ariovistus had to say, and to report to him.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Ariovistus saw them in his camp, he shouted in the presence of his army: "Why are you coming to me? Is it for the sake of spying?"

sentences.latin: Conantes dicere prohibuit et in catenas coniecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Attempting to speak he prevented and into chains threw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But when Ariovistus saw them before him in his camp, he cried out in the presence of his army, "Why were they come to him? Was it for the purpose of acting as spies?" He stopped them when attempting to speak, and cast them into chains.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stopped them as they attempted to speak and threw them into chains.

sentences.latin: Eodem die castra promovit et milibus passuum VI a Caesaris castris sub monte consedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the same day the camp he moved forward and by thousands of paces six from of Caesar the camp under a mountain settled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] The same day he moved his camp forward and pitched under a hill six miles from Caesar's camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the same day, he moved his camp forward and took up a position at the foot of a mountain six miles from Caesar's camp.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei praeter castra Caesaris suas copias traduxit et milibus passuum duobus ultra eum castra fecit eo consilio uti frumento commeatuque qui ex Sequanis et Haeduis supportaretur Caesarem intercluderet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the day after of that day past the camp of Caesar his own troops he led across and by thousands of paces two beyond him a camp made with that plan that from grain and supplies which from the Sequani and Haedui were being brought Caesar he might cut off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] The same day he moved his camp forward and pitched under a hill six miles from Caesar's camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following day, he led his troops past Caesar's camp and pitched camp two miles beyond him, with the intention of cutting Caesar off from the grain and supplies being brought in from the Sequani and the Haedui.

sentences.latin: Ex eo die dies continuos V Caesar pro castris suas copias produxit et aciem instructam habuit, ut, si vellet Ariovistus proelio contendere, ei potestas non deesset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From that day days continuous five Caesar before the camp his own troops led out and a battle line drawn up held, so that, if he wished Ariovistus in battle to contend, to him the opportunity not might be lacking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The day following he led his forces past Caesar's camp, and encamped two miles beyond him; with this design that he might cut off Caesar from the corn and provisions, which might be conveyed to him from the Sequani and the Aedui.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For five consecutive days after that, Caesar led his troops out in front of the camp and kept his battle line formed, so that if Ariovistus wished to engage in battle, the opportunity would not be lacking.

sentences.latin: Ariovistus his omnibus diebus exercitum castris continuit, equestri proelio cotidie contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ariovistus on these all days the army in camp held, in cavalry battle daily he contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For five successive days from that day, Caesar drew out his forces before the camp, and put them in battle order, that, if Ariovistus should be willing to engage in battle, an opportunity might not be wanting to him.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During all these days, Ariovistus kept his army in camp, but engaged in cavalry skirmishes every day.

sentences.latin: Genus hoc erat pugnae, quo se Germani exercuerant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Kind this was of battle, in which themselves the Germans had trained:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ariovistus all this time kept his army in camp: but engaged daily in cavalry skirmishes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was the type of combat in which the Germans had trained themselves:

sentences.latin: equitum milia erant VI, totidem numero pedites velocissimi ac fortissimi, quos ex omni copia singuli singulos suae salutis causa delegerant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: of horsemen thousands there were six, just as many in number foot-soldiers swiftest and bravest, whom from all the force individuals individual [men] for their own safety's sake had chosen:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The method of battle in which the Germans had practiced themselves was this.
sentences.naturalTranslation: there were six thousand cavalry, and an equal number of the swiftest and bravest infantry, whom the horsemen had selected individually from the whole force for their own protection:

sentences.latin: cum his in proeliis versabantur, ad eos se equites recipiebant; hi, si quid erat durius, concurrebant, si qui graviore vulnere accepto equo deciderat, circumsistebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: with these in battles they were engaged, to them themselves the horsemen were retreating; these, if anything was harder, ran together, if anyone a more serious wound having been received from horse had fallen, they stood around;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There were 6,000 horse, and as many very active and courageous foot, one of whom each of the horse selected out of the whole army for his own protection.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they were accompanied by these in battle, and the cavalry would retreat to them; if the situation became difficult, the infantry would charge forward, and if anyone fell from his horse due to a serious wound, they would surround and protect him;

sentences.latin: si quo erat longius prodeundum aut celerius recipiendum, tanta erat horum exercitatione celeritas ut iubis sublevati equorum cursum adaequarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if to any place it was further to be advanced or more quickly to be retreated, so great was of these by training the speed that by manes lifted up of the horses the pace they equaled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these [foot] they were constantly accompanied in their engagements; to these the horse retired; these on any emergency rushed forward; if any one, upon receiving a very severe wound, had fallen from his horse, they stood around him: if it was necessary to advance further than usual, or to retreat more rapidly, so great, from practice, was their swiftness, that, supported by the manes of the horses, they could keep pace with their speed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: if it was necessary to advance further or retreat more quickly than usual, their training made them so swift that, by holding onto the horses' manes, they could keep pace with them.

sentences.latin: Ubi eum castris se tenere Caesar intellexit, ne diutius commeatu prohiberetur, ultra eum locum, quo in loco Germani consederant, circiter passus DC ab his, castris idoneum locum delegit acieque triplici instructa ad eum locum venit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When him in camp himself to keep Caesar understood, lest longer from supplies he be prohibited, beyond that place, in which place the Germans had encamped, about paces 600 from them, for a camp a suitable place he chose and with a line triple drawn up to that place he came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Perceiving that Ariovistus kept himself in camp, Caesar, that he might not any longer be cut off from provisions, chose a convenient position for a camp beyond that place in which the Germans had encamped, at about 600 paces from them, and having drawn up his army in three lines, marched to that place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar realized that Ariovistus was keeping himself in camp, he chose a suitable spot for a camp about six hundred paces beyond the Germans' position to avoid being cut off from supplies, and marched there with his army drawn up in a triple line.

sentences.latin: Primam et secundam aciem in armis esse, tertiam castra munire iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The first and second line in arms to be, the third the camp to fortify he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He ordered the first and second lines to be under arms; the third to fortify the camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the first and second lines to remain under arms, and the third to fortify the camp.

sentences.latin: [Hic locus ab hoste circiter passus DC, uti dictum est, aberat.] Eo circiter hominum XVI milia expedita cum omni equitatu Ariovistus misit, quae copiae nostros terrerent et munitione prohiberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: [This place from the enemy about paces 600, as it was said, was distant.] To there about of men 16 thousands light-armed with all the cavalry Ariovistus sent, which forces our [men] might terrify and from the fortification might prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This place was distant from the enemy about 600 paces, as has been stated.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ariovistus sent about sixteen thousand light-armed troops with all his cavalry to that spot to intimidate our men and prevent them from completing the fortification.

sentences.latin: Nihilo setius Caesar, ut ante constituerat, duas acies hostem propulsare, tertiam opus perficere iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By nothing less Caesar, as before he had decided, two lines the enemy to drive back, the third the work to complete he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thither Ariovistus sent light troops, about 16,000 men in number, with all his cavalry; which forces were to intimidate our men, and hinder them in their fortification.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, Caesar, as he had previously decided, ordered two lines to drive back the enemy and the third to finish the work.

sentences.latin: Munitis castris duas ibi legiones reliquit et partem auxiliorum, quattuor reliquas legiones in castra maiora reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been fortified the camp two there legions he left and part of the auxiliaries, four remaining legions into the camp larger he led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar nevertheless, as he had before arranged, ordered two lines to drive off the enemy: the third to execute the work. The camp being fortified, he left there two legions and a portion of the auxiliaries; and led back the other four legions into the larger camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the camp was fortified, he left two legions and part of the auxiliary troops there, and led the remaining four legions back to the larger camp.

sentences.latin: Proximo die instituto suo Caesar ex castris utrisque copias suas eduxit paulumque a maioribus castris progressus aciem instruxit hostibusque pugnandi potestatem fecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day by his custom Caesar from camps both forces his led out and a little from the larger camp having advanced a battle line drew up and to the enemies of fighting the opportunity made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the next day by his custom Caesar from camps both forces his led out and a little from the larger camps having advanced battle line he drew up and to the enemies of fighting opportunity he made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following day, according to his custom, Caesar led his forces out of both camps and, having advanced a short distance from the larger camp, drew up his battle line and offered the enemy the opportunity to fight.

sentences.latin: Ubi ne tum quidem eos prodire intellexit, circiter meridiem exercitum in castra reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When not even then indeed them to come forward he understood, around noon the army into the camp he led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When not then even them to come forward he understood, around midday the army into camps he led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he realized that they would not come forward even then, he led the army back into camp around midday.

sentences.latin: Tum demum Ariovistus partem suarum copiarum, quae castra minora oppugnaret, misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then finally Ariovistus a part of his forces, which the camp smaller might attack, sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then at last Ariovistus part of his forces, which the camps smaller should attack, sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Only then did Ariovistus send a part of his forces to attack the smaller camp.

sentences.latin: Acriter utrimque usque ad vesperum pugnatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sharply on both sides all the way to evening it was fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sharply on both sides up to evening it was fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was fierce fighting on both sides until evening.

sentences.latin: Solis occasu suas copias Ariovistus multis et inlatis et acceptis vulneribus in castra reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the sun's setting his forces Ariovistus many both inflicted and received wounds with into the camp led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the sun's setting his forces Ariovistus many both inflicted and received wounds with into camps led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At sunset, after many wounds had been both inflicted and received, Ariovistus led his forces back into camp.

sentences.latin: Cum ex captivis quaereret Caesar quam ob rem Ariovistus proelio non decertaret, hanc reperiebat causam, quod apud Germanos ea consuetudo esset ut matres familiae eorum sortibus et vaticinationibus declararent utrum proelium committi ex usu esset necne; eas ita dicere:
sentences.referenceTranslation: When from the captives was asking Caesar for what reason Ariovistus in battle not would fight to a finish, this he was finding the cause, because among the Germans this custom was that the mothers of family of them by lots and by divinations should declare whether a battle to be joined of advantage was or not; that they thus said:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When from captives was asking Caesar for what reason Ariovistus in battle not would fight to a finish, this he was finding cause, because among the Germans this custom was that mothers of family of them by lots and by divinations should declare whether battle to be joined from advantage was or not; them thus to say:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar asked the captives why Ariovistus would not engage in a decisive battle, he discovered the reason: it was the custom among the Germans for their matrons to declare by lots and divinations whether it was advantageous to join battle or not; they said:

sentences.latin: non esse fas Germanos superare, si ante novam lunam proelio contendissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: not to be right the Germans to conquer, if before the new moon in battle they had contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not to be right the Germans to conquer, if before the new moon in battle they had contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that it was not divinely permitted for the Germans to conquer if they fought before the new moon.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei Caesar praesidio utrisque castris quod satis esse visum est reliquit, alarios omnes in conspectu hostium pro castris minoribus constituit, quod minus multitudine militum legionariorum pro hostium numero valebat, ut ad speciem alariis uteretur; ipse triplici instructa acie usque ad castra hostium accessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the day after of that day Caesar for a guard for both camps what enough to be seemed left, the auxiliaries all in the sight of the enemies before the camps smaller stationed, because less in the multitude of soldiers legionary for the enemies' number he was strong, so that for appearance the auxiliaries he might use; he himself with a triple drawn up line all the way to the camp of the enemies approached.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the day after of that day Caesar for a guard for both camps what enough to be seemed he left, the auxiliaries all in sight of the enemies before the camps smaller he stationed, because less in multitude of soldiers legionary for the enemies' number he was strong, so that for appearance the auxiliaries he might use; he himself triple having been drawn up battle line up to the camps of the enemies approached.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, Caesar left what seemed to be a sufficient guard for both camps and stationed all the auxiliaries in sight of the enemy in front of the smaller camp; because he was weak in the number of legionary soldiers compared to the enemy's numbers, he used the auxiliaries for show. He himself, having drawn up a triple line, advanced right up to the enemy's camp.

sentences.latin: Tum demum necessario Germani suas copias castris eduxerunt generatimque constituerunt paribus intervallis, Harudes, Marcomanos, Tribocos, Vangiones, Nemetes, Sedusios, Suebos, omnemque aciem suam raedis et carris circumdederunt, ne qua spes in fuga relinqueretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then finally by necessity the Germans their forces from the camp led out and by tribes stationed at equal intervals, the Harudes, Marcomanni, Triboci, Vangiones, Nemetes, Sedusii, Suebi, and all the line their with wagons and carts they surrounded, lest any hope in flight should be left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then at last by necessity the Germans their forces from the camps led out and by tribes stationed at equal intervals, Harudes, Marcomani, Triboci, Vangiones, Nemetes, Sedusii, Suebi, and all the battle line their with wagons and carts they surrounded, lest any hope in flight should be left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then at last, the Germans were forced to lead their forces out of camp and they stationed them by tribe at equal intervalsthe Harudes, Marcomanni, Triboci, Vangiones, Nemetes, Sedusii, and Suebiand they surrounded their entire line with wagons and carts so that no hope might be left in flight.

sentences.latin: Eo mulieres imposuerunt, quae ad proelium proficiscentes milites passis manibus flentes implorabant ne se in servitutem Romanis traderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There the women they placed, who to the battle setting out the soldiers with outstretched hands weeping were imploring that not themselves into slavery to the Romans they should deliver.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There women they placed, who to battle setting out soldiers with outstretched hands weeping were imploring lest themselves into slavery to the Romans they should hand over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They placed the women on these, who, with outstretched hands and weeping, implored the soldiers as they set out for battle not to surrender them into slavery to the Romans.

sentences.latin: Caesar singulis legionibus singulos legatos et quaestorem praefecit, uti eos testes suae quisque virtutis haberet;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar to individual legions individual legates and a quaestor put in charge, so that them witnesses of his own each courage he might have;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar to each legions each legates and a quaestor put in charge, so that them witnesses of his own each virtue he might have;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar placed a legate and a quaestor over each individual legion, so that every man might have them as witnesses of his own valor;

sentences.latin: ipse a dextro cornu, quod eam partem minime firmam hostium esse animadverterat, proelium commisit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself from the right wing, because that part least strong of the enemies to be he had noticed, battle joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he himself from the right wing, because that part least firm of the enemies to be he had noticed, battle joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself joined battle from the right wing, because he had noticed that that part of the enemy's line was the least strong.

sentences.latin: Ita nostri acriter in hostes signo dato impetum fecerunt itaque hostes repente celeriterque procurrerunt, ut spatium pila in hostes coiciendi non daretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus our [men] fiercely against the enemies the signal having been given an attack made and thus the enemies suddenly and quickly ran forward, so that space javelins against the enemies of throwing not was given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: So our men sharply against the enemies the signal having been given an attack made and so the enemies suddenly and quickly ran forward, that space javelins against the enemies of throwing not was given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men attacked the enemy so fiercely when the signal was given, and the enemy rushed forward so suddenly and quickly, that there was no time to hurl javelins at them.

sentences.latin: Relictis pilis comminus gladiis pugnatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been abandoned the javelins hand-to-hand with swords it was fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been left javelins hand to hand with swords it was fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Setting aside their javelins, they fought hand-to-hand with swords.

sentences.latin: At Germani celeriter ex consuetudine sua phalange facta impetus gladiorum exceperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the Germans quickly from custom their own a phalanx having been made the attacks of the swords received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the Germans quickly from custom their a phalanx having been made attacks of swords received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the Germans, quickly forming a phalanx according to their custom, sustained the sword attacks.

sentences.latin: Reperti sunt complures nostri qui in phalanga insilirent et scuta manibus revellerent et desuper vulnerarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Found were several our [men] who onto the phalanx would leap and shields with hands would tear away and from above would wound.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Were found several our men who onto the phalanx would leap and shields with hands would tear away and from above would wound.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Several of our soldiers were found who would leap onto the phalanx, tear away the shields with their hands, and inflict wounds from above.

sentences.latin: Cum hostium acies a sinistro cornu pulsa atque in fugam coniecta esset, a dextro cornu vehementer multitudine suorum nostram aciem premebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When of the enemies the line from the left wing repulsed and into flight thrown had been, from the right wing violently by the multitude of their [men] our line they were pressing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When of the enemies battle line from the left wing beaten and into flight cast had been, from the right wing strongly by the multitude of their own our battle line they were pressing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the enemy's line on the left wing had been routed and put to flight, on the right wing they were hard-pressing our line by the sheer weight of their numbers.

sentences.latin: Id cum animadvertisset P. Crassus adulescens, qui equitatui praeerat, quod expeditior erat quam ii qui inter aciem versabantur, tertiam aciem laborantibus nostris subsidio misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This when had noticed P. Crassus the younger, who the cavalry was in command of, because more unencumbered he was than those who within the line were engaged, the third line to the laboring our [men] as a relief he sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This when had noticed P. Crassus the younger, who to the cavalry was in charge, because more unencumbered he was than those who between the battle line were engaged, the third line to the laboring our men for a help he sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the younger Publius Crassus, who commanded the cavalry, noticed this, because he was more free to move than those engaged in the battle line, he sent the third line as a reinforcement to our struggling men.

sentences.latin: Cum esset Caesar in citeriore Gallia [in hibernis], ita uti supra demonstravimus, crebri ad eum rumores adferebantur litterisque item Labieni certior fiebat omnes Belgas, quam tertiam esse Galliae partem dixeramus, contra populum Romanum coniurare obsidesque inter se dare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When was Caesar in hither Gaul [in winter quarters], so as above we have shown, frequent to him rumors were brought and by letters likewise of Labienus more certain he was made all the Belgae, whom a third to be of Gaul part we had said, against the people Roman to be conspiring and hostages among themselves to be giving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When was Caesar in hither Gaul [in winter quarters], so as above we have shown, frequent to him rumors were being brought and by letters likewise of Labienus more certain he was being made all the Belgae, whom third to be of Gaul part we had said, against the people Roman to be conspiring and hostages among themselves to be giving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While Caesar was in Hither Gaul in winter quarters, as we have shown above, frequent rumors were brought to him, and he was likewise informed by letters from Labienus that all the Belgae, who we had said constitute a third part of Gaul, were conspiring against the Roman people and exchanging hostages.

sentences.latin: Coniurandi has esse causas: primum quod vererentur ne, omni pacata Gallia, ad eos exercitus noster adduceretur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of conspiring these to be the causes: first because they feared lest, all having been subdued Gaul, to them army our might be led;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of conspiring these to be the causes: first because they feared lest, all having been pacified Gaul, to them army our should be led;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The reasons for the conspiracy were these: first, because they feared that, once all Gaul was subdued, our army would be led against them;

sentences.latin: deinde quod ab non nullis Gallis sollicitarentur, partim qui, ut Germanos diutius in Gallia versari noluerant, ita populi Romani exercitum hiemare atque inveterascere in Gallia moleste ferebant, partim qui mobilitate et levitate animi novis imperiis studebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: then because by not none Gauls they were being stirred up, partly (those) who, as Germans longer in Gaul to stay they had not wanted, so of the people Roman the army to winter and to grow old in Gaul annoyingly they were bearing, partly (those) who by mobility and lightness of mind for new commands were eager;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: then because by not none Gauls they were being stirred up, partly who, as Germans longer in Gaul to stay they had been unwilling, so of the people Roman the army to winter and to grow old in Gaul annoyingly they were bearing, partly who by mobility and lightness of mind for new commands were eager;
sentences.naturalTranslation: furthermore, because they were being incited by several Gauls, some of whom were as reluctant to have a Roman army wintering and settling in Gaul as they had been to have the Germans stay there any longer, while others, through instability and fickleness of mind, were eager for a change in government;

sentences.latin: ab non nullis etiam quod in Gallia a potentioribus atque iis qui ad conducendos homines facultates habebant vulgo regna occupabantur; qui minus facile eam rem imperio nostro consequi poterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: by not none also because in Gaul by more powerful and those who for to be hired men resources were having commonly kingdoms were being seized; who less easily that thing under command our to attain were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by not none also because in Gaul by more powerful and those who for hiring men resources were having commonly kingdoms were being seized; who less easily that thing under command our to attain were able.
