sentences.naturalTranslation: they were also incited by some because in Gaul kingdoms were commonly seized by the more powerful and by those who had the resources to hire mercenaries; these men could less easily achieve such an object under our rule.

sentences.latin: His nuntiis litterisque commotus Caesar duas legiones in citeriore Gallia novas conscripsit et inita aestate in ulteriorem Galliam qui deduceret Q. Pedium legatum misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these messages and letters moved Caesar two legions in hither Gaul new enrolled and begun summer into farther Gaul who should lead Q. Pedius the lieutenant sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these messages and letters moved Caesar two legions in hither Gaul new enrolled and begun summer into further Gaul who should lead Quintus Pedius the lieutenant sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Alarmed by these reports and letters, Caesar enrolled two new legions in Hither Gaul and, at the beginning of summer, sent the lieutenant Quintus Pedius to lead them into Farther Gaul.

sentences.latin: Ipse, cum primum pabuli copia esse inciperet, ad exercitum venit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself, when first of fodder plenty to be began, to the army came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself, when first of forage abundance to be began to begin, to the army came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself joined the army as soon as there began to be a plentiful supply of forage.

sentences.latin: Dat negotium Senonibus reliquisque Gallis qui finitimi Belgis erant uti ea quae apud eos gerantur cognoscant seque de his rebus certiorem faciant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He gives business to the Senones and remaining Gauls who neighbors to the Belgae were that those things which among them are being done they should learn and himself about these things more certain they should make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He gives business to the Senones and the remaining Gauls who neighbors to the Belgae were that those things which among them are being done they learn and themselves about these things more certain make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He assigned the Senones and the other Gauls who were neighbors of the Belgae the task of finding out what was happening among them and keeping him informed of these matters.

sentences.latin: Hi constanter omnes nuntiaverunt manus cogi, exercitum in unum locum conduci.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These consistently all reported bands to be collected, an army into one place to be brought together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These consistently all reported bands to be collected, an army into one place to be led together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They all consistently reported that bands of men were being collected and an army was being concentrated in one place.

sentences.latin: Tum vero dubitandum non existimavit quin ad eos proficisceretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then indeed to be hesitated not he thought but that to them he should set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then indeed to be hesitated not he thought but that to them he should set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then indeed he did not think he should hesitate to set out against them.

sentences.latin: Re frumentaria provisa castra movet diebusque circiter XV ad fines Belgarum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thing grain-related provided for camp he moves and in days about 15 to the borders of the Belgae he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Matter grain-related provided camp he moves and in days about 15 to the borders of the Belgae he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having provided for the grain supply, he broke camp and arrived at the borders of the Belgae in about fifteen days.

sentences.latin: Eo cum de improviso celeriusque omnium opinione venisset, Remi, qui proximi Galliae ex Belgis sunt, ad eum legatos Iccium et Andebrogium, primos civitatis, miserunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when from unforeseen and more quickly than of all opinion he had come, the Remi, who nearest to Gaul from the Belgae are, to him ambassadors Iccius and Andebrogius, first men of the state, sent,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when unexpectedly and more quickly than of all opinion he had come, the Remi, who nearest of Gaul from the Belgae are, to him ambassadors Iccius and Andebrogius, first of the state, sent,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had arrived there unexpectedly and more quickly than anyone had anticipated, the Remi, who are the nearest of the Belgae to Gaul, sent Iccius and Andebrogius, the leading men of their state, as ambassadors to him,

sentences.latin: qui dicerent se suaque omnia in fidem atque potestatem populi Romani permittere, neque se cum reliquis Belgis consensisse neque contra populum Romanum coniurasse,
sentences.referenceTranslation: who should say themselves and their things all into the faith and power of the people Roman to entrust, and not themselves with the remaining Belgae to have agreed nor against the people Roman to have conspired,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who should say themselves and their all into the faith and power of the people Roman to entrust, and not themselves with the remaining Belgae to have agreed nor against the people Roman to have conspired,
sentences.naturalTranslation: to say that they entrusted themselves and all their possessions to the protection and power of the Roman people, and that they had neither joined with the rest of the Belgae nor conspired against the Roman people,

sentences.latin: paratosque esse et obsides dare et imperata facere et oppidis recipere et frumento ceterisque rebus iuvare;
sentences.referenceTranslation: and that [they] were ready both to give hostages and to do things commanded and to receive in towns and to help with grain and other things;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and prepared to be both hostages to give and commands to do and in towns to receive and with grain and other things to help;
sentences.naturalTranslation: and that they were ready to give hostages, carry out orders, receive the Romans into their towns, and provide grain and other supplies;

sentences.latin: reliquos omnes Belgas in armis esse, Germanosque qui cis Rhenum incolant sese cum his coniunxisse,
sentences.referenceTranslation: that all the remaining Belgians were in arms, and the Germans who dwell on this side of the Rhine had joined themselves with these,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the remaining all Belgae in arms to be, and the Germans who this side the Rhine dwell themselves with these to have joined,
sentences.naturalTranslation: that all the rest of the Belgians were under arms, and that the Germans living on this side of the Rhine had joined forces with them,

sentences.latin: tantumque esse eorum omnium furorem ut ne Suessiones quidem, fratres consanguineosque suos, qui eodem iure et isdem legibus utantur, unum imperium unumque magistratum cum ipsis habeant, deterrere potuerint quin cum iis consentirent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and so great was the madness of them all that not even the Suessiones, their brothers and kinsmen, who use the same right and the same laws, [and] have one command and one magistrate with themselves, they were able to deter from-the-fact-that they agreed with them.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so great to be of them all the madness that not even the Suessiones indeed, brothers and kinsmen their, who the same right and the same laws use, one command and one magistrate with themselves have, to deter they were able but that with them they should agree.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and so great was the madness of them all that they could not even dissuade the Suessionestheir own brothers and kinsmen, who share the same rights and laws and have a common government and magistracy with themfrom joining the conspiracy.

sentences.latin: Cum ab iis quaereret quae civitates quantaeque in armis essent et quid in bello possent, sic reperiebat: plerosque Belgas esse ortos a Germanis Rhenumque antiquitus traductos propter loci fertilitatem ibi consedisse Gallosque qui ea loca incolerent expulisse, solosque esse qui,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When from them he was inquiring which states and how great were in arms and what in war they were able [to do], thus he was finding out: that most Belgians were descended from Germans and having been led across the Rhine in ancient times because of the fertility of the place there had settled and the Gauls who were inhabiting those places had driven out, and were the only ones who,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When from them he was asking what states and how great in arms were and what in war they were able, thus he was finding: most Belgae to be descended from Germans and the Rhine anciently led across because of of the place fertility there to have settled and the Gauls who those places were inhabiting to have driven out, and alone to be who,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he asked them which states were in arms, how large they were, and what their military strength was, he learned the following: most of the Belgians were descended from Germans; they had crossed the Rhine long ago and settled there because of the fertility of the soil, driving out the Gauls who lived there; and they were the only ones who,

sentences.latin: patrum nostrorum memoria omni Gallia vexata, Teutonos Cimbrosque intra suos fines ingredi prohibuerint;
sentences.referenceTranslation: in the memory of our fathers, all Gaul having been harassed, the Teutones and Cimbri within their own borders to enter had prohibited;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of fathers our in memory all Gaul harassed, the Teutones Cimbrique within their borders to enter prohibited;
sentences.naturalTranslation: within the memory of our fathers, when all Gaul was being harassed, had prevented the Teutones and Cimbri from entering their territory;

sentences.latin: qua ex re fieri uti earum rerum memoria magnam sibi auctoritatem magnosque spiritus in re militari sumerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from which thing it happened that by the memory of those things great for themselves authority and great spirits in military matter they took up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from which thing to happen that of those things by memory great for themselves authority and great spirits in matter military they took.
sentences.naturalTranslation: as a result, the memory of these events led them to assume great authority and a high spirit in military affairs.

sentences.latin: De numero eorum omnia se habere explorata Remi dicebant, propterea quod propinquitatibus adfinitatibus quo coniuncti quantam quisque multitudinem in communi Belgarum concilio ad id bellum pollicitus sit cognoverint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Concerning the number of them all things themselves to have explored the Remi were saying, because by relationships and kinships by which joined how great a multitude each one in the common council of the Belgians for that war had promised they had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Concerning the number of them all things themselves to have explored the Remi were saying, because by proximities and affinities by which joined how great each multitude in the common of the Belgae council for that war promised had they knew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Remi said they had full information regarding their numbers, because, being joined to them by ties of kinship and marriage, they knew exactly what size force each state had promised for that war in the general council of the Belgians.

sentences.latin: Plurimum inter eos Bellovacos et virtute et auctoritate et hominum numero valere: hos posse conficere armata milia centum, pollicitos ex eo numero electa milia LX totiusque belli imperium sibi postulare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Most among them the Bellovaci both in valor and in authority and in number of men were strong: these to be able to muster armed thousands a hundred, having promised from that number chosen thousands sixty and of the whole war the command for themselves to demand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Most among them the Bellovaci both in valor and authority and of men in number to be strong: these to be able to muster armed thousands a hundred, having promised from that number chosen thousands 60 and of the whole war the command for themselves to demand.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among them, the Bellovaci were the most powerful in courage, influence, and population; they could muster a hundred thousand armed men, had promised sixty thousand picked troops from that number, and were demanding the supreme command of the entire war for themselves.

sentences.latin: Suessiones suos esse finitimos; fines latissimos feracissimosque agros possidere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Suessiones were their own neighbors; very wide borders and very fertile fields to possess.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Suessiones their to be neighbors; borders widest and most fertile fields to possess.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Suessiones were their own neighbors; they possessed very extensive territory and highly fertile lands.

sentences.latin: Apud eos fuisse regem nostra etiam memoria Diviciacum, totius Galliae potentissimum, qui cum magnae partis harum regionum, tum etiam Britanniae imperium obtinuerit; nunc esse regem Galbam: ad hunc propter iustitiam prudentiamque summam totius belli omnium voluntate deferri; oppida habere numero XII, polliceri milia armata L; totidem Nervios,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Among them had been king even in our memory Diviciacus, of all Gaul the most powerful, who not only of a great part of these regions, but also of Britain the command held; now to be king Galba: to this one because of justice and wisdom the highest of the whole war by the will of all [the command] was being deferred; towns to have in number 12, to promise thousands armed 50; just as many the Nervii,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Among them to have been king our even in memory Diviciacus, of all Gaul most powerful, who when of great part of these regions, then also of Britain command obtained; now to be king Galba: to this one because of justice and prudence highest of the whole war by all's will to be deferred; towns to have in number 12, to promise thousands armed 50; as many the Nervii,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Within even our own memory, Diviciacus had been their king, the most powerful man in all Gaul, who held sovereignty not only over a large part of these regions but also over Britain; now Galba was king, and to him, because of his supreme justice and wisdom, the direction of the whole war was being deferred by common consent; they had twelve towns and promised fifty thousand armed men; the Nervii promised the same number,

sentences.latin: qui maxime feri inter ipsos habeantur longissimeque absint;
sentences.referenceTranslation: who most fierce among themselves are held and furthest are away;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who most fierce among themselves are held and furthest are away;
sentences.naturalTranslation: who are considered the fiercest among them and are located the furthest away;

sentences.latin: XV milia Atrebates, Ambianos X milia, Morinos XXV milia, Menapios VII milia, Caletos X milia, Veliocasses et Viromanduos totidem, Atuatucos XVIIII milia;
sentences.referenceTranslation: 15 thousand Atrebates, Ambiani 10 thousand, Morini 25 thousand, Menapii 7 thousand, Caleti 10 thousand, Veliocasses and Viromandui just as many, Atuatuci 19 thousand;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: 15 thousand Atrebates, Ambiani 10 thousand, Morini 25 thousand, Menapii 7 thousand, Caleti 10 thousand, Veliocasses and Viromandui just as many, Atuatuci 19 thousand;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Atrebates promised 15,000 men, the Ambiani 10,000, the Morini 25,000, the Menapii 7,000, the Caleti 10,000, the Veliocasses and Viromandui the same number, and the Atuatuci 19,000;

sentences.latin: Condrusos, Eburones, Caerosos, Paemanos, qui uno nomine Germani appellantur, arbitrari ad XL milia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Condrusi, Eburones, Caerosi, Paemani, who by one name Germans are called, to be thought at 40 thousand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Condrusi, Eburones, Caerosi, Paemani, who by one name Germans are called, they think to 40 thousand.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They estimated that the Condrusi, Eburones, Caerosi, and Paemaniwho are collectively called Germansnumbered about 40,000.

sentences.latin: Caesar Remos cohortatus liberaliterque oratione prosecutus omnem senatum ad se convenire principumque liberos obsides ad se adduci iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar the Remi having encouraged and generously with a speech having addressed all the senate to himself to assemble and of the leaders the children as hostages to himself to be brought ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar the Remi having encouraged and generously in speech having addressed all the senate to himself to come and of the leaders the children as hostages to himself to be brought ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having encouraged the Remi and addressed them with a generous speech, ordered their entire senate to assemble before him and the children of their leaders to be brought to him as hostages.

sentences.latin: Quae omnia ab his diligenter ad diem facta sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which all things by them diligently at the day done were.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which all things by them diligently to the day were done.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All of these orders were diligently carried out by them by the appointed day.

sentences.latin: Ipse Diviciacum Haeduum magnopere cohortatus docet quanto opere rei publicae communisque salutis intersit manus hostium distineri, ne cum tanta multitudine uno tempore confligendum sit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself Diviciacus the Haeduan greatly having encouraged shows by how much work for the republic and of the common safety it is of interest the bands of the enemy to be kept apart, lest with so great a multitude at one time it must be fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself Diviciacus the Haeduan greatly having encouraged shows by how much work of the republic and of the common safety it interests the hands of the enemies to be kept apart, lest with so great a multitude at one time it must be fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself, having strongly encouraged Diviciacus the Haeduan, explained how much it concerned the republic and their common safety that the enemy's forces be kept divided, so that they would not have to fight such a great multitude at once.

sentences.latin: Id fieri posse, si suas copias Haedui in fines Bellovacorum introduxerint et eorum agros populari coeperint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This to be able to be done, if their own forces the Haedui into the borders of the Bellovaci shall have led and their fields to ravage shall have begun.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That to be able to be done, if their own forces the Haedui into the territories of the Bellovaci shall have led and their fields to ravage shall have begun.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This could be achieved if the Haedui led their forces into the territory of the Bellovaci and began to lay waste to their fields.

sentences.latin: Hisdatismandatis eum a se dimittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been given instructions him from himself he sends away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been given instructions him from himself he sends away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having given these instructions, he dismissed him.

sentences.latin: Postquam omnes Belgarum copias in unum locum coactas ad se venire vidit neque iam longe abesse ab iis quos miserat exploratoribus et ab Remis cognovit, flumen Axonam, quod est in extremis Remorum finibus, exercitum traducere maturavit atque ibi castra posuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After all of the Belgae the forces into one place collected toward himself to come he saw and no longer far to be away from those whom he had sent scouts and from the Remi he learned, the river Axona, which is in the furthest of the Remi borders, the army to lead across he hastened and there the camp placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After all of the Belgae forces into one place collected toward himself to come he saw and no longer far to be away from those whom he had sent scouts and from the Remi he learned, the river Axona, which is in the furthest of the Remi borders, the army to lead across he hastened and there camp he placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After he saw that all the forces of the Belgae had been collected into one place and were coming toward him, and learned from the scouts he had sent and from the Remi that they were no longer far away, he hastened to lead his army across the river Axona, which is on the furthest borders of the Remi, and there he pitched camp.

sentences.latin: Quae res et latus unum castrorum ripis fluminis muniebat et post eum quae erant tuta ab hostibus reddebat et commeatus ab Remis reliquisque civitatibus ut sine periculo ad eum portari possent efficiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing both side one of the camp by the banks of the river was fortifying and behind him which things were safe from the enemy was rendering and supplies from the Remi and the rest of the states so that without danger to him to be carried they could be was effecting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing both side one of the camp by the banks of the river was fortifying and behind him which were safe from the enemies was rendering and supplies from the Remi and the rest of the states so that without danger to him to be carried they could be was effecting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This position both fortified one side of the camp with the river banks and rendered the area behind him safe from the enemy, and it ensured that supplies could be brought to him from the Remi and the other states without danger.

sentences.latin: In eo flumine pons erat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that river a bridge was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that river a bridge was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a bridge over that river.

sentences.latin: Ibi praesidium ponit et in altera parte fluminis Q. Titurium Sabinum legatum cum sex cohortibus relinquit; castra in altitudinem pedum XII vallo fossaque duodeviginti pedum muniri iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There a guard he places and in the other part of the river Quintus Titurius Sabinus the legate with six cohorts he leaves; the camp to a height of feet twelve with a rampart and a ditch of eighteen feet to be fortified he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There a guard he places and on the other part of the river Q. Titurius Sabinus the legate with six cohorts he leaves; the camp to a height of feet 12 with a rampart and a ditch of eighteen feet to be fortified he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stationed a guard there and left the legate Quintus Titurius Sabinus on the other side of the river with six cohorts; he ordered the camp to be fortified with a twelve-foot rampart and an eighteen-foot ditch.

sentences.latin: Ab his castris oppidum Remorum nomine Bibrax aberat milia passuum VIII.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From this camp a town of the Remi by name Bibrax was distant thousands of paces eight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From this camp a town of the Remi by name Bibrax was away thousands of paces 8.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A town of the Remi called Bibrax was eight miles away from this camp.

sentences.latin: Id ex itinere magno impetu Belgae oppugnare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That from the march with great force the Belgians to attack began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It from the march with great force the Belgae to attack began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Belgians began to attack it with great force directly from their march.

sentences.latin: Aegre eo die sustentatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With difficulty on that day it was sustained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With difficulty on that day it was sustained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The defense was maintained with difficulty that day.

sentences.latin: Gallorum eadem atque Belgarum oppugnatio est haec: ubi circumiecta multitudine hominum totis moenibus undique in murum lapides iaci coepti sunt murusque defensoribus nudatus est, testudine facta portas succedunt murumque subruunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the Gauls the same as of the Belgians the attack is this: when, having been thrown around a multitude of men for the whole walls from all sides against the wall stones to be thrown have begun and the wall of defenders has been stripped, a testudo having been made, the gates they approach and the wall they undermine.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the Gauls the same as of the Belgae the assault is this: when having been thrown around a multitude of men for the whole walls from all sides onto the wall stones to be thrown have begun and the wall of defenders has been stripped, a testudo having been made the gates they approach and the wall they undermine.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The method of attack used by the Gauls and Belgians is this: when a large number of men have been spread around the entire fortifications and stones begin to be thrown at the wall from all sides, stripping the wall of its defenders, they form a testudo, advance to the gates, and undermine the wall.

sentences.latin: Quod tum facile fiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which then easily was done.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which then easily was being done.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was easily accomplished at that time.

sentences.latin: Nam cum tanta multitudo lapides ac tela coicerent, in muro consistendi potestas erat nulli.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For when so great a multitude stones and weapons were throwing, on the wall of standing the power was to no one.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For when so great a multitude stones and weapons were throwing, on the wall of standing the power was to no one.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For since such a great number of men were hurling stones and weapons, no one was able to remain standing on the wall.

sentences.latin: Cum finem oppugnandi nox fecisset, Iccius Remus, summa nobilitate et gratia inter suos, qui tum oppido praeerat, unus ex iis qui legati de pace ad Caesarem venerant, nuntium ad eum mittit, nisi subsidium sibi submittatur, sese diutius sustinere non posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When an end of attacking night had made, Iccius the Reman, of highest nobility and influence among his own, who then the town was in charge of, one from those who envoys concerning peace to Caesar had come, a messenger to him sends, [saying] unless reinforcement to him be sent, himself longer to hold out not to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When an end of attacking night had made, Iccius the Reman, of the highest nobility and influence among his own, who then the town was in charge of, one from those who ambassadors concerning peace to Caesar had come, a messenger to him sends, unless help to him be sent, himself longer to hold out not to be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When night had ended the attack, Iccius, a Reman of the highest rank and influence among his people, who was then in command of the town and was one of those who had come as envoys to Caesar to seek peace, sent a messenger to him to say that unless reinforcements were sent, he could no longer hold out.

sentences.latin: Eo de media nocte Caesar isdem ducibus usus qui nuntii ab Iccio venerant, Numidas et Cretas sagittarios et funditores Baleares subsidio oppidanis mittit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There about middle of night Caesar the same guides having used who messengers from Iccius had come, Numidian and Cretan archers and slingers Balearic as a reinforcement for the townsmen sends;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There about middle of night Caesar the same guides having used who as messengers from Iccius had come, Numidians and Cretan archers and slingers Balearic as a help for the townsmen sends;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Around midnight, Caesar used the same men who had come as messengers from Iccius as guides and sent Numidian and Cretan archers and Balearic slingers to reinforce the townsmen.

sentences.latin: quorum adventu et Remis cum spe defensionis studium propugnandi accessit et hostibus eadem de causa spes potiundi oppidi discessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whose arrival both to the Remi with the hope of defense the zeal of fighting back approached and from the enemies for the same cause the hope of gaining the town departed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By whose arrival both to the Remi with hope of defense the zeal of fighting for increased and to the enemies from the same cause the hope of gaining the town departed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their arrival inspired the Remi with hope for their defense and a zeal for fighting back, while for the same reason, the enemy's hope of capturing the town vanished.

sentences.latin: Itaque paulisper apud oppidum morati agrosque Remorum depopulati, omnibus vicis aedificiisque quo adire potuerant incensis, ad castra Caesaris omnibus copiis contenderunt et a milibus passuum minus duobus castra posuerunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so for a short time near the town having delayed and the fields of the Remi having ravaged, all villages and buildings to which they had been able to approach having been burned, toward the camp of Caesar with all forces they hastened and at miles of paces less than two the camp they placed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so for a little while near the town having delayed and the fields of the Remi having ravaged, all villages and buildings to which to go they had been able having been burned, to the camp of Caesar with all forces they hastened and at miles of paces less than two the camp they placed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, after lingering near the town for a short time and ravaging the lands of the Remi, they burned all the villages and buildings they could reach, then hastened toward Caesars camp with all their forces and pitched camp less than two miles away.

sentences.latin: quae castra, ut fumo atque ignibus significabatur, amplius milibus passuum VIII latitudinem patebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which camp, as by smoke and fires was indicated, more than miles of paces eight in width extended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which camp, as by smoke and fires was indicated, more than miles of paces 8 in width extended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This camp, as indicated by the smoke and fires, extended more than eight miles in width.

sentences.latin: Caesar primo et propter multitudinem hostium et propter eximiam opinionem virtutis proelio supersedere statuit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar at first both on account of the multitude of the enemies and on account of the exceptional reputation of valor from battle to refrain decided;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar at first both on account of the multitude of the enemies and on account of the exceptional reputation of valor from battle to refrain decided;
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first, Caesar decided to avoid a general engagement, both because of the enemy's numbers and their extraordinary reputation for bravery.

sentences.latin: cotidie tamen equestribus proeliis quid hostis virtute posset et quid nostri auderent periclitabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: daily however by cavalry battles what the enemy in valor was able and what our men dared he was testing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: daily however by cavalry battles what the enemy in valor was able and what our men dared he was testing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, he used daily cavalry skirmishes to test what the enemy could achieve by their valor and how much our own men dared to do.

sentences.latin: Ubi nostros non esse inferiores intellexit, loco pro castris ad aciem instruendam natura oportuno atque idoneo, quod is collis ubi castra posita erant paululum ex planitie editus tantum adversus in latitudinem patebat quantum loci acies instructa occupare poterat, atque ex utraque parte lateris deiectus habebat et in fronte leniter fastigatus paulatim ad planitiem redibat, ab utroque latere eius collis transversam fossam obduxit circiter passuum CCCC
sentences.referenceTranslation: When our men not to be inferior he understood, in a place before the camp for the battle line to be drawn up by nature opportune and suitable, because that hill where the camp placed had been a little from the plain raised up so much facing in width extended as of space a battle line drawn up to occupy was able, and from each part of the side slopes it had and in front gently sloping gradually to the plain it returned, from each side of that hill a transverse ditch he extended about of paces 400
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When our men not to be inferior he understood, in a place before the camp for the line to be drawn up by nature opportune and suitable, because that hill where the camp placed had been a little from the plain raised as much facing in width extended as of space a line drawn up to occupy was able, and from each part of the side slopes it had and in front gently sloping little by little to the plain it returned, from each side of that hill a transverse ditch he drew about of paces 400
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he realized our men were not inferior, he chose a spot in front of the camp naturally suited for drawing up a battle line. Since the hill where the camp stood rose slightly above the plain and was as wide in front as a deployed line could occupy, with steep slopes on both sides and a gentle incline in front leading back to the plain, he dug a transverse ditch of about four hundred paces on each side of the hill.

sentences.latin: et ad extremas fossas castella constituit ibique tormenta conlocavit, ne, cum aciem instruxisset, hostes, quod tantum multitudine poterant, ab lateribus pugnantes suos circumvenire possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and at the ends of the ditches redoubts he established and there engines he placed, lest, when the battle line he had drawn up, the enemies, because so much in multitude they were able, from the sides fighting his men to surround they might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and at the ends of the ditches redoubts he established and there engines he placed, lest, when the line he had drawn up, the enemies, because so much in multitude they were able, from the sides fighting his men to surround they might be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the ends of these ditches he constructed redoubts and positioned siege engines there, so that once he had formed his line, the enemywho were so superior in numberswould not be able to surround his men from the flanks during the fighting.

sentences.latin: Hoc facto, duabus legionibus quas proxime conscripserat in castris relictis ut, si quo opus esset, subsidio duci possent, reliquas VI legiones pro castris in acie constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This having been done, two legions which most recently he had enrolled in the camp having been left so that, if anywhere need there was, for a reinforcement to be led they might be able, the remaining 6 legions before the camp in battle line he stationed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been done, two legions which most recently he had enrolled in the camp having been left so that, if anywhere need there was, for a reinforcement to be led they might be able, the remaining 6 legions before the camp in line he stationed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having done this, he left the two legions he had most recently recruited in the camp so they could be brought up as reinforcements if needed, and stationed the remaining six legions in battle formation in front of the camp.

sentences.latin: Hostes item suas copias ex castris eductas instruxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies likewise their forces from the camp led out drew up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies likewise their own forces from the camp led out drew up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy likewise led their forces out of camp and drew them up.

sentences.latin: Palus erat non magna inter nostrum atque hostium exercitum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A marsh was not large between our and the enemies' army.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A marsh was not large between our and the enemies' army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a small marsh between our army and that of the enemy.

sentences.latin: Hanc si nostri transirent hostes expectabant; nostri autem, si ab illis initium transeundi fieret, ut impeditos adgrederentur parati in armis erant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This if our [men] should cross the enemies were waiting; our [men] however, if by them a beginning of crossing should be made, so that [the enemies] hindered they might attack ready in arms were.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This if our men should cross the enemies were waiting; our men however, if by them a beginning of crossing should be made, so that hindered they might attack ready in arms were.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy were waiting to see if our men would cross this marsh; our men, however, were standing ready in arms to attack them while encumbered, should they be the first to attempt the crossing.

sentences.latin: Interim proelio equestri inter duas acies contendebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile in a battle equestrian between the two lines it was being contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile by a battle equestrian between the two lines it was being contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, a cavalry skirmish was taking place between the two armies.

sentences.latin: Ubi neutri transeundi initium faciunt, secundiore equitum proelio nostris Caesar suos in castra reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When neither of crossing a beginning make, with a more favorable of the horsemen battle for our [men] Caesar his own into the camp led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When neither of crossing a beginning make, more favorable of the horsemen battle for our men Caesar his own into the camp led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When neither side began the crossing, Caesar led his troops back into camp, the cavalry engagement having been more favorable for our men.

sentences.latin: Hostes protinus ex eo loco ad flumen Axonam contenderunt, quod esse post nostra castra demonstratum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies immediately from that place to the river Axona hastened, which to be behind our camp shown has been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies immediately from that place to the river Axona hastened, which to be behind our camp has been shown.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy immediately hastened from that spot to the river Axona, which, as has been pointed out, was behind our camp.

sentences.latin: Ibi vadis repertis partem suarum copiarum traducere conati sunt eo consilio ut, si possent, castellum, cui praeerat Q. Titurius legatus, expugnarent pontemque interscinderent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: There fords having been found a part of their forces to lead across they tried with that plan that, if they were able, the fort, which was in charge of Q. Titurius the lieutenant, they might take by storm and the bridge cut down,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There fords having been found a part of their forces to lead across they tried with that plan that, if they could, the redoubt, which over was Q. Titurius the lieutenant, they might take by storm and the bridge cut down,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having found fords there, they attempted to lead part of their forces across with the intention of storming the fort commanded by the lieutenant Quintus Titurius and breaking down the bridge, if they could.

sentences.latin: si minus potuissent, agros Remorum popularentur, qui magno nobis usui ad bellum gerendum erant, commeatuque nostros prohiberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if less they had been able, the fields of the Remi they might ravage, which of great to us use for the war to be waged were, and from supplies our [men] they might prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if less they had been able, the fields of the Remi they might ravage, which for great to us use for the war to be waged were, and from supplies our men they might prohibit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: or, if they were unable to do so, of ravaging the lands of the Remi, which were of great use to us in waging the war, and cutting off our men from supplies.

sentences.latin: Caesarcertior factus ab Titurio onlnem equitatum et levis armaturae Numidas, funditores sagittariosque pontem traducit atque ad eos contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar more certain made by Titurius all the cavalry and of light armor Numidians, slingers and archers across the bridge leads and to them hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar more certain made by Titurius all the cavalry and of light armor Numidians, slingers and archers the bridge leads across and to them hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having been informed by Titurius, led all the cavalry and light-armed Numidians, the slingers and the archers, across the bridge and hastened toward them.

sentences.latin: Acriter in eo loco pugnatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sharply in that place it was fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sharply in that place it was fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A fierce battle was fought in that place.

sentences.latin: Hostes impeditos nostri in flumine adgressi magnum eorum numerum occiderunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies hindered our [men] in the river having attacked a great of them number killed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies hindered our men in the river having attacked a large of them number killed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men, attacking the enemy while they were encumbered in the river, killed a great number of them.

sentences.latin: per eorum corpora reliquos audacissime transire conantes multitudine telorum reppulerunt primosque, qui transierant, equitatu circumventos interfecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: over their bodies the rest most boldly to cross trying with a multitude of weapons they drove back and the first, who had crossed, by the cavalry surrounded they killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: over their bodies the rest most boldly to cross trying with a multitude of weapons they drove back and the first, who had crossed, by the cavalry surrounded they killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They drove back the rest with a shower of missiles as they most daringly attempted to cross over the bodies of the slain, and they surrounded with cavalry and killed the first who had managed to cross.

sentences.latin: Hostes, ubi et de expugnando oppido et de flumine transeundo spem se fefellisse intellexerunt neque nostros in locum iniquiorum progredi pugnandi causa viderunt atque ipsos res frumentaria deficere coepit, concilio convocato constituerunt optimum esse domum suam quemque reverti, et quorum in fines primum Romani exercitum introduxissent, ad eos defendendos undique convenirent, ut potius in suis quam in alienis finibus decertarent et domesticis copiis rei frumentariae uterentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies, when both about the town to be stormed and about the river to be crossed hope [that] it had deceived them they understood and not our [men] into a place of more unfavorable [ground] to advance for the sake of fighting they saw and themselves the grain supply to fail began, a council having been called, they decided [it] to be best home his own each to return, and of whom into the territories first the Romans the army had introduced, to those to be defended from all sides they should assemble, so that rather in their own than in foreign territories they might fight it out and domestic supplies of grain they might use.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies, when both concerning the town being stormed and concerning the river being crossed hope themselves to have deceived they understood nor our [men] into a place more unfavorable to proceed for the sake of fighting they saw and themselves the grain supply to fail began, a council having been called they decided best to be home their own each to return, and into whose borders first the Romans the army had introduced, to those to be defended from all sides they should assemble, so that rather in their own than in foreign borders they might fight it out and domestic supplies of grain they might use.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the enemy realized that their hopes of storming the town and crossing the river had failed, and saw that our men would not advance onto unfavorable ground to fight, and as their own grain supplies began to run low, they called a council and decided that the best course was for everyone to return to their own homes. They agreed to assemble from all sides to defend those whose territory the Roman army had invaded first, so that they could fight in their own lands rather than in foreign ones and rely on their own local food supplies.

sentences.latin: Ad eam sententiam cum reliquis causis haec quoque ratio eos deduxit, quod Diviciacum atque Haeduos finibus Bellovacorum adpropinquare cognoverant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this opinion with the remaining causes this also reason them led, because Diviciacus and the Haedui to the territories of the Bellovaci to approach they had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To that opinion with the remaining causes this reason also them led, because Diviciacus and the Haedui the borders of the Bellovaci to be approaching they had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In addition to the other reasons, this consideration also led them to that decision: they had learned that Diviciacus and the Haedui were approaching the territory of the Bellovaci.

sentences.latin: His persuaderi ut diutius morarentur neque suis auxilium terrent non poterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these to be persuaded that longer they should delay and not to their own help they should bring not it was possible.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these to be persuaded that longer they should delay nor to their own help they should bring not it was possible.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men could not be persuaded to stay any longer or to withhold help from their own people.

sentences.latin: Ea re constituta, secunda vigilia magno cum, strepitu ac tumultu castris egressi nullo certo ordine neque imperio, cum sibi quisque primum itineris locum peteret et domum pervenire properaret, fecerunt ut consimilis fugae profectio videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing having been decided, at the second watch with great noise and tumult from the camp having gone out with no certain order nor command, since for himself each the first of the journey place was seeking and home to arrive was hastening, they made that very like a flight the departure seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That thing having been decided, at the second watch with great noise and tumult from the camp having gone out with no certain order nor command, since for himself each the first place of the journey was seeking and home to arrive was hastening, they made that similar to a flight the departure seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once this was decided, they left camp during the second watch with great noise and confusion. With no fixed order or command, as everyone sought the first place on the road for himself and hurried to reach home, they made their departure look like a headlong flight.

sentences.latin: Hac re statim Caesar per speculatores cognita insidias veritus, quod qua de causa discederent nondum perspexerat, exercitum equitatumque castris continuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing immediately Caesar through scouts having been known, ambushes having feared, because for what reason they were departing not yet he had perceived, the army and the cavalry in the camp he kept.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This thing immediately Caesar through scouts having learned, the ambush having feared, because for what cause they were departing not yet he had perceived, the army and the cavalry in the camp he kept.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar was immediately informed of this by his scouts, but fearing an ambush because he did not yet understand their reason for leaving, he kept his army and cavalry in camp.

sentences.latin: Prima luce, confirmata re ab exploratoribus, omnem equitatum, qui novissimum agmen moraretur, praemisit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light, the thing having been confirmed by scouts, all the cavalry, which the rear line might delay, he sent ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light, the thing having been confirmed by scouts, all the cavalry, which the rear guard should delay, he sent ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At daybreak, after the scouts had confirmed the news, he sent all the cavalry ahead to delay the enemy's rear guard.

sentences.latin: His Q. Pedium et L. Aurunculeium Cottam legatos praefecit; T. Labienum legatum cum legionibus tribus subsequi iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over these Quintus Pedius and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta lieutenants he put in command; Titus Labienus the lieutenant with legions three to follow closely he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Over these Q. Pedius and L. Aurunculeium Cotta legates he put in charge; T. Labienus the legate with legions three to follow closely he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He placed the legates Quintus Pedius and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta in command of the cavalry, and ordered the legate Titus Labienus to follow closely with three legions.

sentences.latin: Hi novissimos adorti et multa milia passuum prosecuti magnam multitudinem eorum fugientium conciderunt, cum ab extremo agmine, ad quos ventum erat, consisterent fortiterque impetum nostrorum militum sustinerent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These the rear having attacked and many thousands of paces having followed a great multitude of them fleeing cut down, while from the end of the line, to whom it had been come, they were standing fast and bravely the attack of our soldiers they were sustaining,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These the last [men] having attacked and many thousands of paces having followed a great multitude of them fleeing they cut down, since from the end of the line, to whom it had been come, they were standing and bravely the attack of our soldiers they were sustaining,
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men attacked the rear and, after pursuing them for many miles, cut down a great number of the fugitives; for while those at the very end of the column, whom our men had reached, stood their ground and bravely withstood the attack of our soldiers,

sentences.latin: priores, quod abesse a periculo viderentur neque ulla necessitate neque imperio continerentur, exaudito clamore perturbatis ordinibus omnes in fuga sibi praesidium ponerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the ones in front, because to be away from danger they seemed and by no necessity nor command they were contained, the shout having been heard, the ranks having been disturbed, all in flight for themselves protection they were placing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the ones in front, because to be away from danger they seemed nor by any necessity nor command they were held, the shout having been heard, the ranks having been disturbed, all in flight for themselves protection they were placing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: those in the front, believing they were far from danger and being restrained by neither necessity nor command, broke ranks when they heard the shouting and all sought safety in flight.

sentences.latin: Ita sine ullo periculo tantam eorum multitudinem nostri interfecerunt quantum fuit diei spatium; sub occasum solis sequi destiterunt seque in castra, ut erat imperatum, receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus without any danger so great of them a multitude our [men] killed as much as was of the day the space; toward the setting of the sun to follow they ceased and themselves into the camp, as it had been commanded, they withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus without any danger so great a multitude of them our [men] killed as much as was of the day the space; toward the setting of the sun to follow they ceased and themselves into the camp, as it had been ordered, they betook.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, without any danger to themselves, our men killed as many of the enemy as the length of the day allowed; at sunset they stopped the pursuit and returned to camp as they had been ordered.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei Caesar, prius quam se hostes ex terrore ac fuga reciperent, in fines Suessionum, qui proximi Remis erant, exercitum duxit et magno itinere [confecto] ad oppidum Noviodunum contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day of that day Caesar, before than themselves the enemies from terror and flight might recover, into the borders of the Suessiones, who nearest to the Remi were, the army led and a great march having been finished to the town Noviodunum hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the day after that day Caesar, before than themselves the enemies from terror and flight might recover, into the borders of the Suessiones, who nearest to the Remi were, the army he led and a great march [having been completed] to the town Noviodunum he hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following day, before the enemy could recover from their terror and flight, Caesar led his army into the territory of the Suessiones, who were neighbors of the Remi, and after completing a long march, he hurried toward the town of Noviodunum.

sentences.latin: Id ex itinere oppugnare conatus, quod vacuum ab defensoribus esse audiebat, propter latitudinem fossae murique altitudinem paucis defendentihus expugnare non potuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It from the march to assault having attempted, because empty from defenders to be he was hearing, on account of the width of the ditch and of the wall the height with few defending to take by storm not he was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It from the march to attack having tried, because empty from defenders to be he was hearing, on account of the width of the ditch and the wall's height with few defending to storm it not he was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having attempted to assault it directly from the march because he heard it was empty of defenders, he was unable to take it by storm, despite the few defenders, due to the width of the ditch and the height of the wall.

sentences.latin: Castris munitis vineas agere quaeque ad oppugnandum usui erant comparare coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The camp having been fortified, vineae to move and what things for assaulting for use were to prepare he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The camp having been fortified, mantlets to move and which things for attacking for use were to prepare he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After fortifying the camp, he began to move up the mantlets and prepare whatever was needed for a siege.

sentences.latin: Interim omnis ex fuga Suessionum multitudo in oppidum proxima nocte convenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile all from the flight of the Suessiones multitude into the town on the next night assembled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile all from flight of the Suessiones the multitude into the town the next night assembled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the entire multitude of Suessiones who had fled assembled in the town during the following night.

sentences.latin: Celeriter vineis ad oppidum actis, aggere iacto turribusque constitutis, magnitudine operum, quae neque viderant ante Galli neque audierant, et celeritate Romanorum permoti legatos ad Caesarem de deditione mittunt et petentibus Remis ut conservarentur impetrant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly the vineae to the town having been moved, a mound having been thrown up and towers having been set up, by the greatness of the works, which neither had seen before the Gauls nor had heard of, and by the speed of the Romans moved, ambassadors to Caesar about surrender they send and with the Remi asking that they might be preserved they obtain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly the mantlets to the town having been moved, a ramp having been thrown up and towers having been set up, by the magnitude of the works, which neither had seen before the Gauls nor had heard of, and by the speed of the Romans moved, legates to Caesar concerning surrender they send and the Remi asking that they might be preserved they obtain [their request].
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the mantlets were quickly moved up to the town, a rampart thrown up, and towers erected, the Gauls were so moved by the scale of the worksthe likes of which they had never seen or heard of beforeand by the speed of the Romans, that they sent envoys to Caesar to discuss surrender; at the request of the Remi, they obtained their plea to be spared.

sentences.latin: Caesar, obsidibus acceptis primis civitatis atque ipsius Galbae regis duobus filiis armisque omnibus ex oppido traditis, in deditionem Suessiones accipit exercitumque in Bellovacos ducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, hostages having been received the first of the state and of Galba himself the king two sons and arms all from the town having been handed over, into surrender the Suessiones receives and the army into the Bellovaci leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, hostages having been received the first [men] of the state and of Galba himself the king two sons and arms all from the town having been handed over, into surrender the Suessiones he accepts and the army into the Bellovaci he leads.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After receiving as hostages the leading men of the state and the two sons of King Galba himself, and after all the weapons in the town were handed over, Caesar accepted the surrender of the Suessiones and led his army into the territory of the Bellovaci.

sentences.latin: Qui cum se suaque omnia in oppidum Bratuspantium contulissent atque ab eo oppido Caesar cum exercitu circiter milia passuum V abesset, omnes maiores natu ex oppido egressi manus ad Caesarem tendere et voce significare coeperunt sese in eius fidem ac potestatem venire neque contra populum Romanum armis contendere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when themselves and their things all into the town Bratuspantium they had brought and from that town Caesar with the army about thousands of paces five was away, all greater by birth from the town having gone out hands to Caesar to stretch and with voice to signify they began themselves into his faith and power to come nor against the people Roman with arms to contend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who when themselves and their own all into the town Bratuspantium they had brought and from that town Caesar with the army about miles of paces 5 was away, all the older by birth from the town having gone out hands to Caesar to stretch and with voice to signify they began themselves into his faith and power to come nor against the people Roman with arms to contend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they had brought themselves and all their possessions into the town of Bratuspantium, and Caesar with his army was about five miles away from that town, all the elders came out of the town and began to stretch out their hands to Caesar and signify with their voices that they were placing themselves under his protection and power, and were not contending in arms against the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Item, cum ad oppidum accessisset castraque ibi poneret, pueri mulieresque ex muro passis mallibus suo more pacem ab Romanis petierunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Likewise, when to the town he had approached and the camp there he was placing, the boys and women from the wall with spread hands in their own custom peace from the Romans sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Likewise, when to the town he had approached and camp there he was placing, the boys and women from the wall with spread hands in their own custom peace from the Romans sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Similarly, when he had approached the town and was pitching camp there, the children and women, with hands outstretched from the wall in their customary manner, sought peace from the Romans.

sentences.latin: Pro his Diviciacus (nam post discessum Belgarum dimissis Haeduorum copiis ad Cum reverterat) facit verba:
sentences.referenceTranslation: On behalf of these Diviciacus (for after the departure of the Belgae having been dismissed of the Haedui the forces to him he had returned) makes words:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For these Diviciacus (for after the departure of the Belgae having been dismissed of the Haedui the forces to him he had returned) makes words:
sentences.naturalTranslation: On their behalf, Diviciacus (for after the departure of the Belgae he had dismissed the Haeduan forces and returned to Caesar) spoke as follows:

sentences.latin: Bellovacos omni tempore in fide atque amicitia civitatis Haeduae fuisse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Bellovaci at all time in the faith and friendship of the state Haeduan to have been;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Bellovaci at all time in the faith and friendship of the state Haeduan to have been;
sentences.naturalTranslation: [He said] that the Bellovaci had at all times been under the protection and in the friendship of the Haeduan state;

sentences.latin: impulsos ab suis principibus, qui dicerent Haeduos a Caesare in servitutem redacto. omnes indignitates contumeliasque perferre, et ab Haeduis defecisse et populo Romano bellum intulisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: [that they had been] impelled by their own leaders, who were saying [that] the Haedui, by Caesar into slavery having been reduced, all indignities and insults were enduring, and from the Haedui they had revolted and on the Roman people war they had brought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [that they had been] impelled by their own leaders, who said [that] the Haedui, having been reduced into slavery by Caesar, were enduring all indignities and insults, and [that they] had revolted from the Haedui and had brought war upon the Roman people.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had been driven by their leaders, who claimed that the Haedui, reduced to slavery by Caesar, were enduring every kind of indignity and insult; consequently, they had revolted from the Haedui and declared war on the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Qui eius consilii principes fuissent, quod intellegerent quantam calamitatem civitati intulissent, in Britanniam profugisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who of that plan the leaders had been, because they understood how great a calamity on the state they had brought, into Britain had fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Those who had been the leaders of this plan, because they understood how great a calamity they had brought upon the state, had fled into Britain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who had been the leaders of that plot, realizing how great a disaster they had brought upon the state, had fled to Britain.

sentences.latin: Petere non solum Bellovacos, sed etiam pro his Haeduos, ut sua clementia ac mansuetudine in eos utatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To beg not only the Bellovaci, but also on behalf of these the Haedui, that his own clemency and mildness toward them he use.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To beg not only the Bellovaci, but also on behalf of these the Haedui, that his own clemency and mildness toward them he might use.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Not only the Bellovaci, but also the Haedui on their behalf, begged that he would exercise his characteristic clemency and kindness toward them.

sentences.latin: Quod si fecerit, Haeduorum auctoritatem apud omnes Belgas amplificaturum, quorum auxiliis atque opibus, si qua bella inciderint, sustentare consuerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which if he should do, the Haedui's authority among all Belgians he would increase, by whose aids and resources, if any wars should happen, to sustain they were accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which if he should do, [that] he would increase the authority of the Haedui among all the Belgae, by whose aids and resources, if any wars should happen, they were accustomed to sustain [themselves].
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he did this, he would increase the prestige of the Haedui among all the Belgae, whose assistance and resources they were accustomed to rely on whenever wars broke out.

sentences.latin: Caesar honoris Diviciaci atque Haeduorum causa sese eos in fidem recepturum et conservaturum dixit, et quod erat civitas magna inter Belgas auctoritate atque hominum multitudine praestabat, DC obsides poposcit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar for the sake of the honor of Diviciacus and the Haedui himself them into protection would receive and would preserve said, and because was the state of great among the Belgians authority and in of men multitude was outstanding, 600 hostages he demanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar for the sake of the honor of Diviciacus and the Haedui said [that] he would receive them into protection and would preserve [them], and because the state was of great authority among the Belgae and excelled in a multitude of men, he demanded 600 hostages.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar stated that out of respect for Diviciacus and the Haedui, he would take them under his protection and spare them; however, because the state possessed great influence among the Belgae and was preeminent in population, he demanded 600 hostages.

sentences.latin: His traditis omnibusque armis ex oppido conlatis, ab eo loco in fines Ambianorum pervenit; qui se suaque omnia sine mora dediderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been handed over and all arms from the town having been collected, from that place into the borders of the Ambiani he arrived; who themselves and their all things without delay surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been handed over and all arms from the town having been collected, from that place into the borders of the Ambiani he arrived; who themselves and all their [things] without delay surrendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these were handed over and all weapons were collected from the town, he proceeded from that place into the territory of the Ambiani, who surrendered themselves and all their possessions without delay.

sentences.latin: Eorum fines Nervii attingebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Their borders the Nervii were touching.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Their borders the Nervii were touching.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Nervii bordered their territory.

sentences.latin: Quorum de natura moribusque Caesar cum quaereret, sic reperiebat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom about the nature and customs Caesar when he was inquiring, thus he was finding out:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom concerning the nature and customs Caesar when he was inquiring, thus he was finding out:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar inquired about their nature and customs, he learned the following:

sentences.latin: nullum esse aditum ad eos mercatoribus; nihil pati vini reliquarumque rerum ad luxuriam pertinentium inferri, quod his rebus relanguescere animos eorum et remitti virtutem existimarent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: no to be access to them for merchants; nothing to allow of wine and of remaining things to luxury pertaining to be brought in, because by these things to be weakened the minds of them and to be relaxed courage they thought;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [that] there was no access to them for merchants; [that] they allowed nothing of wine and of remaining things pertaining to luxury to be brought in, because by these things they thought their minds to grow weak and courage to be relaxed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: that merchants had no access to them; that they allowed no wine or other luxury items to be imported, because they believed that such things weakened their spirit and diminished their courage;

sentences.latin: esse homines feros magnaeque virtutis; increpitare atque incusare reliquos Belgas, qui se populo Romano dedidissent patriamque virtutem proiecissent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be men fierce and of great courage; to rebuke and to blame the remaining Belgians, who themselves to the Roman people had surrendered and their ancestral courage had cast away;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [that] they were fierce men and of great courage; [that] they rebuked and accused the remaining Belgae, who had surrendered themselves to the Roman people and had cast away ancestral courage;
sentences.naturalTranslation: that they were a fierce people of great bravery; they rebuked and blamed the rest of the Belgae for surrendering to the Roman people and abandoning their ancestral valor.

sentences.latin: confirmare sese neque legatos missuros neque ullam condicionem pacis accepturos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to confirm themselves neither envoys about to send nor any condition of peace about to accept.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [that] they declared [that] they would neither send ambassadors nor accept any condition of peace.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They asserted that they would neither send ambassadors nor accept any terms of peace.

sentences.latin: Cum per eorum fines triduum iter fecisset, inveniebat ex captivis Sabim flumen a castris suis non amplius milibus passuum X abesse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When through their territories for three days a journey he had made, he was finding from captives the Sambre river from camps his own not more than thousands of paces 10 to be away;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When through their borders for three days he had made a journey, he was finding out from captives [that] the river Sambre from his camps not more than 10 miles was away;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After marching through their territory for three days, he learned from prisoners that the river Sambre was no more than ten miles from his camp;

sentences.latin: trans id flumen omnes Nervios consedisse adventumque ibi Romanorum expectare una cum Atrebatibus et Viromanduis, finitimis suis
sentences.referenceTranslation: across that river all the Nervii to have settled and the arrival there of the Romans to be awaiting together with the Atrebates and Viromandui, neighbors their own
sentences.originalMITTranslation: across that river all the Nervii had settled and the arrival there of the Romans were awaiting together with the Atrebates and Viromandui, their neighbors
sentences.naturalTranslation: that all the Nervii had settled across that river and were there awaiting the arrival of the Romans, along with their neighbors, the Atrebates and the Viromandui;

sentences.latin: (nam his utrisque persuaserant uti eandem belli fortunam experirentur);
sentences.referenceTranslation: (for these both they had persuaded that the same of war fortune they should experience);
sentences.originalMITTranslation: (for these both they had persuaded that they should experience the same fortune of war);
sentences.naturalTranslation: (for they had persuaded both of these tribes to share the same fortune of war);

sentences.latin: expectari etiam ab iis Atuatucorum copias atque esse in itinere;
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be expected also by them of the Atuatuci the forces and to be on the journey;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [that] were expected also by them the forces of the Atuatuci and were on the journey;
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the forces of the Atuatuci were also expected by them and were already on the march;

sentences.latin: mulieres quique per aetatem ad pugnam inutiles viderentur in eum locum coniecisse quo propter paludes exercitui aditus non esset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: women and those who through age for battle useless seemed into that place to have thrown where on account of marshes to the army access not was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the women and [those] who through age for battle useless seemed into that place they had thrown where on account of marshes to the army access was not.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and that they had put the women and those who because of their age seemed useless for battle into a place where, because of the marshes, there was no access for an army.

sentences.latin: His rebus cognitis, exploratores centurionesque praemittit qui locum castris idoneum deligant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned, scouts and centurions he sends ahead who a place for the camp suitable might choose.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been learned, scouts and centurions he sends ahead who a place for the camp suitable might choose.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned these facts, he sent scouts and centurions ahead to choose a suitable place for the camp.

sentences.latin: Cum ex dediticiis Belgis reliquisque Gallis complures Caesarem secuti una iter facerent, quidam ex his, ut postea ex captivis cognitum est, eorum dierum consuetudine itineris nostri exercitus perspecta, nocte ad Nervios pervenerunt atque his demonstrarunt inter singulas legiones impedimentorum magnum numerum intercedere, neque esse quicquam negotii, cum prima legio in castra venisset reliquaeque legiones magnum spatium abessent, hanc sub sarcinis adoriri;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When from the surrendered Belgae and the remaining Gauls several Caesar having followed together a journey were making, certain from these, as afterwards from captives known it was, of those days the custom of the march of our army having been observed, by night to the Nervii arrived and to these demonstrated between individual legions of baggage a great number to intervene, and not to be anything of difficulty, when the first legion into camp had come and the remaining legions a great distance were away, this one under packs to attack;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When from the surrendered Belgae and the remaining Gauls several having followed Caesar together were making a journey, certain from these, as afterwards from captives was learned, of those days the custom of the march of our army having been observed, by night to the Nervii arrived and to these demonstrated [that] between individual legions of baggage a great number intervened, and [that] there was not any of difficulty, when the first legion into the camp had come and the remaining legions a great space were away, this [one] under packs to attack;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since several of the surrendered Belgae and other Gauls had followed Caesar and were marching with him, some of these, as was later learned from prisoners, having observed our army's marching routine during those days, went to the Nervii by night and showed them that a great amount of baggage intervened between each legion, and that it would be no trouble to attack the first legion while it was encumbered with packs, as soon as it reached the camp and while the other legions were still a great distance away;

sentences.latin: qua pulsa impedimentisque direptis, futurum ut reliquae contra consistere non auderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which having been driven back and the baggage having been plundered, it would be that the remaining against to stand not would dare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which [legion] having been repulsed and the baggage having been plundered, it would be that the remaining [legions] against [them] to stand would not dare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: arguing that once this legion was routed and its baggage plundered, the rest would not dare to make a stand.

sentences.latin: Adiuvabat etiam eorum consilium qui rem deferebant quod Nervii antiquitus, cum equitatu nihil possent (neque enim ad hoc tempus ei rei student, sed quicquid possunt, pedestribus valent copiis), quo facilius finitimorum equitatum, si praedandi causa ad eos venissent, impedirent, teneris arboribus incisis atque inflexis crebrisque in latitudinem ramis enatis [et] rubis sentibusque interiectis effecerant ut instar muri hae saepes munimentum praeberent, quo non modo non intrari sed ne perspici quidem posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was helping also their plan who the matter were reporting because the Nervii from ancient times, since with cavalry nothing they could (for not indeed to this time to that matter they study, but whatever they can, in infantry they are strong forces), so that more easily of neighbors the cavalry, if for the sake of plundering to them they had come, they might impede, young trees having been cut and bent and numerous in width branches having grown out [and] brambles and thorns having been placed between they had brought about that like a wall these hedges a defense might provide, where not only not to be entered but not even to be seen through indeed it was possible.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was helping also the plan of those who the matter were reporting because the Nervii from ancient times, since with cavalry nothing they could [do] (for not even to this time to that thing they give attention, but whatever they can, in foot forces they are strong), so that more easily the neighbors' cavalry, if for the sake of plundering to them they should have come, they might impede, young trees having been cut and bent and numerous in width branches having grown and brambles and thorns having been placed between they had brought about that like a wall these hedges a defense provided, where not only not to be entered but not even to be seen through indeed it was possible.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The advice of those who reported the matter was also aided by the fact that the Nervii, having no strength in cavalry from ancient times (for even now they do not attend to that branch, but whatever strength they have lies in their infantry), had devised a way to more easily hinder the cavalry of their neighbors if they should come to plunder them; by cutting into and bending young trees, and by letting numerous branches grow out sideways, and by intertwining brambles and thorns, they had created hedges that provided a defense like a wall, which could not only not be entered, but could not even be seen through.

sentences.latin: His rebus cum iter agminis nostri impediretur, non omittendum sibi consilium Nervii existimaverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things since the march of our column was being hindered, not to be omitted by them the plan the Nervii thought.
