sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things since the march of our column was being hindered, not to be omitted by them the plan the Nervii thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since these obstacles were hindering our column's march, the Nervii believed they should not abandon their plan.

sentences.latin: Loci natura erat haec, quem locum nostri castris delegerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the place the nature was this, which place our men for the camp had chosen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the place the nature was this, which place our [men] for the camp had chosen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The nature of the ground which our men had chosen for the camp was as follows.

sentences.latin: Collis ab summo aequaliter declivis ad flumen Sabim, quod supra nominavimus, vergebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A hill from the top evenly sloping to the river Sambre, which above we have named, was inclining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A hill from the top evenly sloping to the river Sambre, which above we have named, was inclining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A hill sloped down evenly from its summit to the river Sambre, which we mentioned above.

sentences.latin: Ab eo flumine pari acclivitate collis nascebatur adversus huic et contrarius, passus circiter CC infimus apertus, ab superiore parte silvestris, ut non facile introrsus perspici posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From that river with equal steepness a hill was rising opposite to this and facing, paces about 200 at the bottom open, from the upper part wooded, so that not easily inside to be seen it was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From that river with equal steepness a hill was rising opposite to this [one] and facing, paces about 200 at the bottom open, from the upper part wooded, so that not easily inside to be seen it was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From that river, another hill rose with an equal slope directly opposite and facing the first; it was open for about two hundred paces at the bottom, but wooded on the upper part, so that it was difficult to see into the interior.

sentences.latin: Intra eas silvas hostes in occulto sese continebant; in aperto loco secundum flumen paucae stationes equitum videbantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Within those woods the enemy in secret themselves were keeping; in the open place along the river a few outposts of cavalry were seen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Within those woods the enemy in secret themselves were keeping; in open place along the river a few outposts of cavalry were seen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy kept themselves hidden within those woods; in the open ground along the river, a few cavalry outposts were visible.

sentences.latin: Fluminis erat altitudo pedum circiter trium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the river was the depth of feet about three.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the river was the depth of feet about three.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The depth of the river was about three feet.

sentences.latin: Caesar equitatu praemisso subsequebatur omnibus copiis; sed ratio ordoque agminis aliter se habebat ac Belgae ad Nervios detulerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar with the cavalry having been sent ahead was following with all forces; but the system and order of the column otherwise itself was having than the Belgians to the Nervii had reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar with the cavalry sent ahead was following with all forces; but the plan and order of the column otherwise itself was having than the Belgians to the Nervii had reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having sent the cavalry ahead, followed with all his forces; however, the arrangement and order of the column was different from what the Belgae had reported to the Nervii.

sentences.latin: Nam quod hostibus adpropinquabat, consuetudine sua Caesar VI legiones expeditas ducebat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For because to the enemy he was approaching, by custom his own Caesar six legions unencumbered was leading;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For because to the enemy he was approaching, by custom his own Caesar six legions unencumbered was leading;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For because he was approaching the enemy, Caesar, according to his custom, was leading six legions in light marching order.

sentences.latin: post eas totius exercitus impedimenta conlocarat; inde duae legiones quae proxime conscriptae erant totum agmen claudebant praesidioque impedimentis erant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: behind those of the whole army the baggage he had placed; then two legions which most recently enrolled had been the whole column were closing and for a guard to the baggage were.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: after those of the whole army the baggage he had placed; then two legions which most recently enrolled had been the whole column were closing and for a guard to the baggage were.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Behind these he had placed the baggage of the entire army; then the two legions which had been most recently recruited brought up the rear and served as a guard for the baggage.

sentences.latin: Equites nostri cum funditoribus sagittariisque flumen transgressi cum hostium equitatu proelium commiserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cavalry our with slingers and archers the river having crossed with of the enemy the cavalry battle joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cavalry our with slingers and archers the river having crossed with of the enemy cavalry battle joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our cavalry, having crossed the river with the slingers and archers, engaged in battle with the enemy's cavalry.

sentences.latin: Cum se illi identidem in silvis ad suos reciperent ac rursus ex silva in nostros impetum facerent, neque nostri longius quam quem ad finem porrecta [ac] loca aperta pertinebant cedentes insequi auderent, interim legiones VI quae primae venerant, opere dimenso, castra munire coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When themselves they repeatedly into the woods to their own retreated and again out of the wood into ours an attack made, nor ours further than to which end stretched and places open extended [them] retreating to follow dared, meanwhile legions six which first had come, the work having been measured out, the camp to fortify began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When themselves they repeatedly in the woods to their own were retreating and again from the wood against our [men] an attack were making, and not our [men] further than which to end extended and open places reached [them] retreating to follow were daring, meanwhile legions six which first had come, the work having been measured out, the camp to fortify began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While the enemy repeatedly retreated into the woods to their comrades and then charged out again at our men, and while our soldiers did not dare to pursue them as they retreated further than the limit of the open ground, the six legions that had arrived first began to fortify the camp after measuring out the work.

sentences.latin: Ubi prima impedimenta nostri exercitus ab iis qui in silvis abditi latebant visa sunt, quod tempus inter eos committendi proelii convenerat, ut intra silvas aciem ordinesque constituerant atque ipsi sese confirmaverant, subito omnibus copiis provolaverunt impetumque in nostros equites fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When the first baggage of our army by those who in the woods hidden were lurking were seen, which time among them of joining battle had been agreed upon, as within the woods the line and ranks they had organized and themselves they had encouraged, suddenly with all forces they rushed forward and an attack on our cavalry made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When the first baggage of our army by those who in the woods hidden were lurking was seen, which time among them of joining battle had been agreed, as within the woods the line and ranks they had established and themselves they had encouraged, suddenly with all forces they flew forward and an attack against our cavalry made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As soon as the first part of our army's baggage train was sighted by those hiding in the woodsthe moment they had agreed upon for starting the battlethey suddenly rushed out with all their forces in the same formation and ranks they had organized within the woods, having encouraged one another, and charged our cavalry.

sentences.latin: His facile pulsis ac proturbatis, incredibili celeritate ad flumen decucurrerunt, ut paene uno tempore et ad silvas et in flumine [et iam in manibus nostris] hostes viderentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These easily having been repulsed and thrown into confusion, with incredible speed to the river they ran down, so that almost at one time both at the woods and in the river and now in hands our the enemy were seen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These easily having been repulsed and thrown into confusion, with incredible speed to the river they ran down, so that almost at one time both at the woods and in the river and already in hands our the enemy were seen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having easily repulsed and scattered the cavalry, they dashed down to the river with such incredible speed that the enemy seemed to be at the woods, in the river, and already upon us all at the same time.

sentences.latin: Eadem autem celeritate adverso colle ad nostra castra atque eos qui in opere occupati erant contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the same however speed up the hill to our camp and those who in the work occupied were they hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the same however speed up the hill to our camp and those who in the work occupied were they hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With that same speed, they pushed up the hill toward our camp and the men who were busy with the construction work.

sentences.latin: Caesari omnia uno tempore erant agenda: vexillum proponendum, quod erat insigne, cum ad arma concurri oporteret; signum tuba dandum; ab opere revocandi milites; qui paulo longius aggeris petendi causa processerant arcessendi; acies instruenda; milites cohortandi; signum dandum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By Caesar all things at one time were to be done: the flag to be displayed, which was the signal, when to arms to be run it was necessary; the signal by trumpet to be given; from the work to be recalled the soldiers; who a little further of material seeking for the sake had proceeded to be summoned; the line to be drawn up; the soldiers to be encouraged; the signal to be given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By Caesar all things at one time were to be done: the flag to be displayed, which was the signal, when to arms to be run it was necessary; the signal by trumpet to be given; from the work to be recalled the soldiers; [those] who a little further of rampart seeking for the sake had proceeded to be summoned; the line to be drawn up; the soldiers to be encouraged; the signal to be given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar had to do everything at once: display the flag, which was the signal for the call to arms; sound the trumpet; recall the soldiers from their work; summon those who had gone a bit further to find materials for the rampart; draw up the battle line; encourage the troops; and give the final signal.

sentences.latin: Quarum rerum magnam partem temporis brevitas et incursus hostium impediebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which things a great part the shortness of time and the attack of the enemy was hindering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of which things a great part the shortness of time and the attack of the enemy was hindering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The lack of time and the enemy's rapid onset prevented many of these tasks from being completed.

sentences.latin: His difficultatibus duae res erant subsidio, scientia atque usus militum, quod superioribus proeliis exercitati quid fieri oporteret non minus commode ipsi sibi praescribere quam ab aliis doceri poterant, et quod ab opere singulisque legionibus singulos legatos Caesar discedere nisi munitis castris vetuerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these difficulties two things were for a help, the knowledge and experience of the soldiers, because in previous battles trained what to be done was necessary not less conveniently themselves for themselves to prescribe than by others to be taught they were able, and because from the work and the individual legions the individual lieutenants Caesar to depart unless the camp fortified had forbidden.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For these difficulties two things were for a help, the knowledge and experience of the soldiers, because in previous battles trained what to be done was necessary not less conveniently themselves for themselves to prescribe than by others to be taught they were able, and because from the work and individual legions individual legates Caesar to depart unless fortified the camp he had forbidden.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Two things helped alleviate these difficulties: the knowledge and experience of the soldiers, who, having been trained in previous battles, could determine for themselves what needed to be done as easily as they could be instructed by others; and the fact that Caesar had forbidden the individual legates to leave their respective legions or the work until the camp was fortified.

sentences.latin: Hi propter propinquitatem et celeritatem hostium nihil iam Caesaris imperium expectabant, sed per se quae videbantur administrabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These on account of the proximity and speed of the enemy nothing now Caesar's command were waiting for, but by themselves what seemed [best] they were carrying out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These because of the proximity and speed of the enemy nothing now Caesar's command were waiting for, but by themselves what seemed [best] were managing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because the enemy was so close and moving so fast, these officers did not wait for orders from Caesar but took whatever measures seemed necessary on their own initiative.

sentences.latin: Caesar, necessariis rebus imperatis, ad cohortandos milites, quam [in] partem fors obtulit, decucurrit et ad legionem decimam devenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, the necessary things having been ordered, to encouraging the soldiers, into which part chance offered, ran down and to the tenth legion came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, necessary things having been ordered, to encouraging the soldiers, which into part chance offered, ran down and to the tenth legion came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After giving the necessary orders, Caesar hurried down to encourage the soldiers, going wherever chance took him, and eventually reached the Tenth Legion.

sentences.latin: Milites non longiore oratione cohortatus quam uti suae pristinae virtutis memoriam retinerent neu perturbarentur animo hostiumque impetum fortiter sustinerent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The soldiers with not a longer speech having encouraged than that of their former valor the memory they should retain nor be disturbed in mind and the enemy's attack bravely they should sustain,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The soldiers with not a longer speech having encouraged than that of their former valor the memory they should retain and not be disturbed in mind and of the enemy the attack bravely they should sustain,
sentences.naturalTranslation: He encouraged the soldiers with a speech no longer than was necessary to remind them to maintain their former courage, not to be unnerved, and to bravely withstand the enemy's charge,

sentences.latin: quod non longius hostes aberant quam quo telum adigi posset, proelii committendi signum dedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because not farther the enemies were away than where a weapon to be hurled was able, of the battle to be joined the signal he gave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because not farther the enemies were away than to where a spear to be hurled was able, of the battle to be joined the signal he gave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because the enemy were no further away than the range of a javelin, he gave the signal to begin the battle.

sentences.latin: Atque in alteram item cohortandi causa profectus pugnantibus occurrit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And into the other likewise for the sake of encouraging having set out, those fighting he met.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And into the other likewise for the sake of encouraging having set out, those fighting he met.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And having set out likewise to the other side to encourage the men, he came upon them already fighting.

sentences.latin: Temporis tanta fuit exiguitas hostiumque tam paratus ad dimicandum animus ut non modo ad insignia accommodanda sed etiam ad galeas induendas scutisque tegimenta detrahenda tempus defuerit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of time so great was the shortness and of the enemies so prepared for fighting the mind that not only for decorations to be fitted but even for helmets to be put on and from shields covers to be pulled off time was lacking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of time so great was the shortness and of the enemies so prepared for fighting the mind that not only for decorations to be fitted but even for helmets to be put on and from shields the covers to be pulled off time was lacking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The shortage of time was so great and the enemy's mind so ready for battle that time was lacking not only for fixing insignia, but even for putting on helmets and removing the covers from the shields.

sentences.latin: Quam quisque ab opere in partem casu devenit quaeque prima signa conspexit, ad haec constitit, ne in quaerendis suis pugnandi tempus dimitteret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Into which each one from the work part by chance arrived and which first standards he caught sight of, at these he stood, lest in seeking his own of fighting the time he might lose.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Into which each one from the work part by chance arrived and which first standards he caught sight of, at these he stood, lest in seeking his own of fighting the time he might lose.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Each man, coming from his work, stood by whatever part he happened upon and whichever standards he first saw, so as not to lose time for fighting while searching for his own unit.

sentences.latin: Instructo exercitu magis ut loci natura [delectusque collis] et necessitas temporis quam ut rei militaris ratio atque ordo postulabat, cum diversae legiones aliae alia in parte hostibus resisterent saepibusque densissimis, ut ante demonstravimus, interiectis prospectus impediretur, neque certa subsidia conlocari neque quid in quaque parte opus esset provideri neque ab uno omnia imperia administrari poterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the army drawn up more as the nature of the place [and the slope of the hill] and the necessity of the time than as of military science the system and order was demanding, since separated legions some in one part others in another to the enemies were resisting and with hedges very thick, as before we have shown, placed between the view was hindered, neither fixed reserves to be stationed nor what in each part need was to be foreseen nor by one man all commands to be administered were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the army drawn up more as the nature of the place and the slope of the hill and the necessity of the time than as of military science the theory and order was demanding, when the separated legions some in one part some in another to the enemies were resisting and with hedges very thick, as before we showed, placed between the view was hindered, neither fixed reserves to be stationed nor what in each part need was to be foreseen nor by one all commands to be managed were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The army being drawn up more as the nature of the ground and the urgency of the moment required than according to military theory and order, since the legions were separated and resisting the enemy in different places, and the view was obstructed by the very thick hedges we mentioned before, it was impossible to post fixed reserves, to foresee what was needed in each sector, or for all commands to be issued by a single person.

sentences.latin: Itaque in tanta rerum iniquitate fortunae quoque eventus varii sequebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so in so great of things inequality of fortune also outcomes various were following.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so in so great of things inequality of fortune also outcomes various were following.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, in such an unfavorable state of affairs, the outcomes of fortune were also varied.

sentences.latin: Legionis VIIII. et X. milites, ut in sinistra parte aciei constiterant, pilis emissis cursu ac lassitudine exanimatos vulneribusque confectos Atrebates (nam his ea pars obvenerat) celeriter ex loco superiore in flumen compulerunt et transire conantes insecuti gladiis magnam partem eorum impeditam interfecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the 9th and 10th legion the soldiers, as on the left part of the line they had stood, with javelins sent forth by running and weariness breathless and by wounds exhausted the Atrebates (for to these that part had fallen) quickly from the higher place into the river they drove and trying to cross having followed with swords a great part of them hindered they killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the legion 9th and 10th the soldiers, as on the left part of the battle line they had stood, with javelins sent forth by running and weariness breathless and by wounds exhausted the Atrebates (for to these that part had fallen) quickly from the higher place into the river they drove and to cross attempting having followed with swords a great part of them hindered they killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The soldiers of the 9th and 10th legions, stationed on the left of the line, discharged their javelins and quickly drove the Atrebates (who had faced that section) from the higher ground into the river, as they were breathless from running and fatigue and exhausted by wounds; following them as they tried to cross, they slew a great number of them with swords while they were hampered in the water.

sentences.latin: Ipsi transire flumen non dubitaverunt et in locum iniquum progressi rursus resistentes hostes redintegrato proelio in fugam coniecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Themselves to cross the river did not hesitate and into a place unfavorable having advanced again resisting enemies with the battle renewed into flight they threw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They themselves to cross the river did not hesitate and into a place unfavorable having advanced again resisting enemies with the battle renewed into flight they threw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did not hesitate to cross the river themselves, and having advanced onto unfavorable ground, they renewed the battle and put to flight the enemy who were again resisting.

sentences.latin: Item alia in parte diversae duae legiones, XI. et VIII., profligatis Viromanduis, quibuscum erant congressae, ex loco superiore in ipsis fluminis ripis proeliabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Likewise in another part separated two legions, 11th and 8th, having been routed the Viromandui, with whom they had engaged, from the higher place on the very of the river banks were fighting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Likewise in another part separated two legions, 11th and 8th, having been routed the Viromandui, with whom they had engaged, from the higher place on the very of the river banks were fighting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Likewise in another part, two other legions, the 11th and the 8th, having routed the Viromandui with whom they had engaged, were fighting from the higher ground on the very banks of the river.

sentences.latin: At totis fere castris a fronte et a sinistra parte nudatis, cum in dextro cornu legio XII. et non magno ab ea intervallo VII. constitisset, omnes Nervii confertissimo agmine duce Boduognato, qui summam imperii tenebat, ad eum locum contenderunt; quorum parsabaperto latere legiones circumvenire, pars summum castrorum locum petere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But with almost the whole camp from the front and from the left part stripped, since on the right wing the 12th legion and at a not great from it interval the 7th had stood, all the Nervii in a very dense column with leader Boduognatus, who the chief of command was holding, to that place hastened; of whom part from the open side the legions to surround, part the highest of the camp place to seek began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But with the whole almost camp from the front and from the left part stripped, when on the right wing legion 12th and not by a great from it interval the 7th had stood, all the Nervii in a very dense column with leader Boduognatus, who the supreme of command was holding, to that place hastened; of whom part from the open side the legions to surround, part the highest of the camp place to seek began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But with almost the entire camp exposed on the front and left side, since the 12th legion and the 7th at a short distance from it had taken their position on the right wing, all the Nervii in a very dense column, led by Boduognatus, who held the chief command, hastened to that spot; some of them began to surround the legions on their exposed flank, while others made for the highest point of the camp.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore equites nostri levisque armaturae pedites, qui cum iis una fuerant, quos primo hostium impetu pulsos dixeram, cum se in castra reciperent, adversis hostibus occurrebant ac rursus aliam in partem fugam petebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time our horsemen and the foot-soldiers of light armor, who with them together had been, whom in the first attack of the enemies repulsed I had said, when themselves into the camp they were retreating, with the opposite enemies were meeting and again into another part flight were seeking;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time the horsemen our and of light armor the foot-soldiers, who with them together had been, whom in the first of the enemies attack pushed back I had said, when themselves into the camp they were withdrawing, with the opposite enemies they were meeting and again another into part flight they were seeking;
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, our cavalry and light-armed infantry, who had been with those I previously mentioned as being routed in the enemy's first charge, encountered the enemy face-to-face as they were retreating to camp and once again fled in a different direction;

sentences.latin: et calones, qui ab decumana porta ac summo iugo collis nostros victores flumen transire conspexerant, praedandi causa egressi, cum respexissent et hostes in nostris castris versari vidissent, praecipites fugae sese mandabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and the camp-servants, who from the decuman gate and the highest ridge of the hill our [men] victors the river to cross had seen, for the sake of plundering having gone out, when they had looked back and the enemies in our camp to be moving about they had seen, headlong to flight themselves they were committing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and the camp-servants, who from the decuman gate and the highest ridge of the hill our victors the river to cross had seen, for the sake of plundering having gone out, when they had looked back and the enemies in our camp to be moving about they had seen, headlong to flight themselves they were committing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The camp servants, who had seen our victorious troops cross the river from the rear gate and the crest of the hill and had gone out to plunder, looked back and saw the enemy moving about in our camp; they then took to headlong flight.

sentences.latin: Simul eorum qui cum impedimentis veniebant clamor fremitusque oriebatur, aliique aliam in partem perterriti ferebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time of those who with the baggage were coming the shouting and noise was arising, and some into another part terrified were being carried.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time of those who with the baggage were coming the shouting and noise was arising, and some into one part some into another terrified were being carried.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Simultaneously, a shout and uproar arose from those arriving with the baggage train, and they fled in all directions in a state of panic.

sentences.latin: Quibus omnibus rebus permoti equites Treveri, quorum inter Gallos virtutis opinio est singularis, qui auxilii causa a civitate missi ad Caesarem venerant, cum multitudine hostium castra [nostra] compleri, legiones premi et paene circumventas teneri, calones, equites, tunditores, Numidas diversos dissipatosque in omnes partes fugere vidissent, desperatis nostris rebus domum contenderunt:
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which all things moved the horsemen Treveri, of whom among the Gauls of valor the reputation is singular, who for the sake of aid by the state sent to Caesar had come, when with a multitude of enemies the camp [our] to be filled, the legions to be pressed and almost surrounded to be held, the camp-servants, horsemen, slingers, Numidians separated and scattered into all parts to flee they had seen, despaired of our affairs, for home they hastened:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which all things moved the horsemen Treveri, of whom among the Gauls of valor the reputation is singular, who for the sake of aid by the state sent to Caesar had come, when with a multitude of enemies the camp our to be filled, the legions to be pressed and almost surrounded to be held, the camp-servants, horsemen, slingers, Numidians separated and scattered into all parts to flee they had seen, having been despaired of our affairs home they hastened:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Alarmed by all these developments, the Treveri cavalrywho have a unique reputation for valor among the Gauls and had been sent by their state to Caesar as reinforcementssaw our camp being filled with a multitude of enemies, the legions hard-pressed and nearly surrounded, and the servants, cavalry, slingers, and Numidians fleeing scattered in every direction; despairing of our situation, they hurried home:

sentences.latin: Romanos pulsos superatosque, castris impedimentisque eorum hostes potitos civitati renuntiaverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Romans repulsed and overcome, of the camp and baggage of them the enemies to have gained possession to the state they reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Romans pushed back and overcome, of the camp and the baggage of them the enemies to have gained possession to the state they reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They reported to their state that the Romans had been routed and defeated, and that the enemy had captured their camp and baggage.

sentences.latin: Caesar ab X. legionis cohortatione ad dextrum cornu prolectus, ubi suos urgeri signisque in unum locum conlatis XII. legionis confertos milites sibi ipsos ad pugnam esse impedimento vidit, quartae cohortis omnibus centurionibus occisis signiferoque interfecto, signo amisso, reliquarum cohortium omnibus fere centurionibus aut vulneratis aut occisis, in his primipilo P. Sextio Baculo, fortissimo viro, multis gravibusque vulneribus confecto, ut iam se sustinere non posset, reliquos esse tardiores et non nullos ab novissimis desertolocoproelio excedere ac tela vitare, hostes neque a fronte ex inferiore loco subeuntes intermittere et ab utroque latere instare et rem esse in angusto vidit, neque ullum esse subsidium quod submitti posset,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar from the 10th legion's encouragement to the right wing having proceeded, where his own [men] to be pressed and with the standards into one place brought together of the 12th legion the crowded soldiers to themselves themselves for the fight to be for a hindrance he saw, of the fourth cohort all centurions killed and the signifer slain, the standard lost, of the remaining cohorts all almost centurions either wounded or killed, among these the primipilus P. Sextius Baculus, a very brave man, with many and heavy wounds exhausted, so that now himself to sustain he was not able, the rest to be slower and some from the rear-most [ranks] deserting the place the battle to leave and weapons to avoid, the enemies neither from the front from a lower place coming up to stop and from both sides to press and the matter to be in a narrow [strait] he saw, nor any to be reserve which to be sent could,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar from of the 10th legion the encouragement to the right wing having set out, where his own to be pressed and with the standards into one place brought together of the 12th legion the crowded soldiers to themselves themselves for the fight to be for a hindrance he saw, of the fourth cohort all the centurions killed and the standard-bearer slain, the standard lost, of the remaining cohorts all almost centurions either wounded or killed, among these the first-centurion P. Sextius Baculus, a very brave man, by many and heavy wounds exhausted, so that already himself to sustain he was not able, the rest to be slower and some from the rear having deserted the place from the battle to withdraw and weapons to avoid, the enemies neither from the front from the lower place coming up to stop and from both sides to press and the matter to be in a narrow place he saw, nor any to be reserve which to be sent could,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar proceeded from encouraging the Tenth Legion to the right wing. There he saw his men hard-pressed and the soldiers of the Twelfth Legion, with their standards crowded together, so packed that they hindered their own fighting. All the centurions of the fourth cohort were dead, the standard-bearer slain, and the standard lost; almost all the centurions of the other cohorts were either wounded or killed, including the chief centurion P. Sextius Baculus, a man of great courage, who was so exhausted by many severe wounds that he could no longer stand. He noticed that the others were losing spirit, some in the rear were leaving the battle and dodging missiles, while the enemy did not stop advancing from the lower ground in front and were pressing in on both flanks. Seeing that the situation was critical and no reserves were available,

sentences.latin: scuto ab novissimis [uni] militi detracto, quod ipse eo sine scuto venerat, in primam aciem processit centurionibusque nominatim appellatis reliquos cohortatus milites signa inferre et manipulos laxare iussit, quo facilius gladiis uti possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: a shield from the rear-most [one] soldier snatched, because he himself thither without a shield had come, into the first battle-line he advanced and the centurions by name called the remaining having encouraged soldiers the standards to carry forward and the maniples to open up he ordered, by which more easily swords to use they could.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a shield from the rear to one soldier snatched, because he himself there without a shield had come, into the first battle-line he advanced and the centurions by name having been called the rest having encouraged the soldiers the standards to carry forward and the maniples to open up he ordered, by which more easily with swords to use they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Snatching a shield from a soldier in the rearsince he had come there without onehe advanced to the front line. Calling the centurions by name and encouraging the rest of the soldiers, he ordered them to advance and open up their ranks so they could use their swords more effectively.

sentences.latin: Cuius adventu spe inlata militibus ac redintegrato animo, cum pro se quisque in conspectu imperatoris etiam in extremis suis rebus operam navare cuperet, paulum hostium impetus tardatus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whose arrival hope brought in to the soldiers and renewed spirit, since for himself each in the sight of the commander even in extreme his own affairs effort to perform was desiring, a little the of the enemies attack slowed was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By whose arrival hope brought in to the soldiers and renewed the mind, when for himself each one in the sight of the commander even in extreme his own affairs work to perform was desiring, a little of the enemies the attack slowed was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: His arrival inspired the soldiers with hope and renewed their spirit, as every man was eager to do his best in the sight of his commander even in his own extreme peril; thus, the enemy's onset was slowed down a little.

sentences.latin: Caesar, cum VII. legionem, quae iuxta constiterat, item urgeri ab hoste vidisset, tribunos militum monuit ut paulatim sese legiones coniungerent et conversa signa in hostes inferrent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, when the 7th legion, which nearby had stood, likewise to be pressed by the enemy he had seen, the tribunes of the soldiers he warned that gradually themselves the legions should join and turned standards against the enemies they should carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, when the 7th legion, which nearby had stood, likewise to be pressed by the enemy he had seen, the tribunes of the soldiers he warned that little by little themselves the legions should join and turned standards against the enemies they should carry in.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar saw that the Seventh Legion, which was stationed nearby, was also being hard-pressed by the enemy, he instructed the military tribunes to gradually bring the legions together and face the enemy on all sides.

sentences.latin: Quo facto cum aliis alii subsidium ferrent neque timerent ne aversi ab hoste circumvenirentur, audacius resistere ac fortius pugnare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which done when to others others aid they were bringing nor were fearing lest turned away by the enemy they might be surrounded, more boldly to resist and more bravely to fight they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been done when to some others aid they were bringing nor they were fearing lest turned away by the enemy they might be surrounded, more boldly to resist and more bravely to fight they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once this was done, since they were now supporting one another and no longer feared being surrounded from the rear, they began to resist more boldly and fight with greater courage.

sentences.latin: Interim milites legionum duarum quae in novissimo agmine praesidio impedimentis fuerant, proelio nuntiato, cursu incitato in summo colle ab hostibus conspiciebantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile the soldiers of the two legions which in the newest line for a protection to the baggage had been, the battle having been announced, with speed quickened on the top of the hill by the enemies were being seen,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile soldiers of legions two who in newest line for protection for baggage had been, battle having been announced, speed having been quickened on top of hill by enemies were being seen,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the soldiers of the two legions that had been guarding the baggage at the rear of the column, having heard news of the battle, quickened their pace and were spotted by the enemy on the crest of the hill.

sentences.latin: et T. Labienus castris hostium potitus et ex loco superiore quae res in nostris castris gererentur conspicatus X. legionem subsidio nostris misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and Titus Labienus the camp of the enemies having gained possession of and from a higher place what things in our camp were being done having observed the 10th legion for a reinforcement to ours sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and T. Labienus camp of enemies having gained and from place higher what things in our camp were being done having seen 10th legion for help to ours sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, Titus Labienus, having captured the enemy's camp and observed from the higher ground what was happening in our own camp, sent the Tenth Legion as a reinforcement to our men.

sentences.latin: Qui cum ex equitum et calonum fuga quo in loco res esset quantoque in periculo et castra et legiones et imperator versaretur cognovissent, nihil ad celeritatem sibi reliqui fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when from the of the horsemen and of the camp-servants flight in what place the matter was and in how great danger both the camp and the legions and the general were involved they had learned, nothing for speed to themselves of remaining they made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who when from of cavalry and of camp-servants flight in what place matter was and in how great danger both camp and legions and commander were involved had learned, nothing for speed for themselves of remaining made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they realized from the flight of the cavalry and camp servants the state of affairs and the great danger facing the camp, the legions, and the commander, they spared no effort to reach them as quickly as possible.

sentences.latin: Horum adventu tanta rerum commutatio est facta ut nostri, etiam qui vulneribus confecti procubuissent, scutis innixi proelium redintegrarent, calones perterritos hostes conspicati etiam inermes armatis occurrerent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: By of these the arrival so great of things a change was made that our men, even who by wounds exhausted had fallen down, on shields leaning the battle renewed, the camp-servants the terrified enemies having seen even unarmed the armed met,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these by arrival so great of things change was made that ours, even who by wounds exhausted had fallen down, on shields leaning battle renewed, camp-servants terrified enemies having seen even unarmed against armed ran,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their arrival caused such a change in the situation that our men, even those who had collapsed exhausted from wounds, leaned on their shields and renewed the fight; the camp servants, seeing the enemy's terror, charged even while unarmed against the armed foe.

sentences.latin: equites vero, ut turpitudinem fugae virtute delerent, omnibus in locis pugnae se legionariis militibus praeferrent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the horsemen indeed, so that the shame of flight by courage they might wipe out, in all in places of the fight themselves to the legionary soldiers they were preferring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: cavalry indeed, so that shame of flight by valor they might wipe out, in all in places of battle themselves to legionary soldiers were preferring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cavalry, moreover, in an effort to wipe out the shame of their flight by displays of courage, strove to outdo the legionary soldiers in every part of the field.

sentences.latin: At hostes, etiam in extrema spe salutis, tantam virtutem praestiterunt ut, cum primi eorum cecidissent, proximi iacentibus insisterent atque ex eorum corporibus pugnarent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the enemies, even in the last hope of safety, so great courage showed that, when the first of them had fallen, the next on the lying ones stood and from of them the bodies fought,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But enemies, even in extreme hope of safety, so great valor showed that, when first of them had fallen, next ones on lying ones stood and from of them bodies were fighting,
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the enemy, even in their final hope of survival, displayed such courage that when their front ranks fell, those behind stood upon the fallen and fought from atop their bodies.

sentences.latin: his deiectis et coacervatis cadaveribus qui superessent ut ex tumulo tela in nostros coicerent et pila intercepta remitterent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: these having been cast down and piled up the corpses those who survived as if from a mound weapons against ours threw and javelins intercepted sent back:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: these having been cast down and piled up corpses who survived so that from mound weapons into ours they might hurl and javelins intercepted send back:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these too were struck down and the corpses piled high, the survivors used the heap like a mound to hurl missiles at our men and return the javelins they had caught.

sentences.latin: ut non nequiquam tantae virtutis homines iudicari deberet ausos esse transire latissimum flumen, ascendere altissimas ripas, subire iniquissimum locum; quae facilia ex difficillimis animi magnitudo redegerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so that not in vain of so great courage men to be judged it ought having dared to cross a very wide river, to climb very high banks, to enter a very unfavorable place; which things easy from very difficult greatness of mind had rendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: so that not in vain of so great valor men to be judged ought to have dared to cross widest river, to climb highest banks, to go under most unfavorable place; which things easy from most difficult greatness of mind had rendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was clear that men of such great courage had not without reason dared to cross a very wide river, climb very high banks, and advance onto most unfavorable ground; their greatness of spirit had rendered these difficult tasks easy.

sentences.latin: Hoc proelio facto et prope ad internecionem gente ac nomine Nerviorum redacto, maiores natu, quos una cum pueris mulieribusque in aestuaria ac paludes coniectos dixeramus, hac pugna nuntiata, cum victoribus nihil impeditum, victis nihil tutum arbitrarentur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: This battle having been finished and almost to destruction the race and name of the Nervii having been reduced, the greater by birth, whom together with the boys and women into the estuaries and marshes cast we had said, this battle having been announced, since for the victors nothing hindered, for the vanquished nothing safe they thought,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This battle having been done and almost to destruction race and name of Nervii having been reduced, elders by birth, whom together with boys and women into estuaries and marshes cast we had said, this battle having been announced, since for victors nothing hindered, for vanquished nothing safe they thought,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this battle, when the Nervian people and their name were reduced almost to extinction, the elderswho, as we mentioned, had been placed with the children and women in the tidal creeks and marshesheard the news of the fight and, believing that nothing could stop the victors and nothing was safe for the vanquished,

sentences.latin: omnium qui supererant consensu legatos ad Caesarem miserunt seque ei dediderunt; et in commemoranda civitatis calamitate ex DC ad tres senatores, ex hominum milibus LX vix ad D, qui arma ferre possent, sese redactos esse dixerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of all who were surviving by the consent ambassadors to Caesar they sent and themselves to him surrendered; and in recounting of the state the calamity from 600 to three senators, from of men thousands 60 scarcely to 500, who arms to bear were able, themselves to have been reduced they said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of all who survived by consent envoys to Caesar sent and themselves to him surrendered; and in mentioning of state calamity from 600 to three senators, from of men thousands 60 scarcely to 500, who arms to bear were able, themselves to have been reduced they said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: sent ambassadors to Caesar with the consent of all the survivors and surrendered to him. In recounting the disaster that had befallen their state, they stated that they had been reduced from six hundred senators to only three, and from sixty thousand men capable of bearing arms to barely five hundred.

sentences.latin: Quos Caesar, ut in miseros ac supplices usus misericordia videretur, diligentissime conservavit suisque finibus atque oppidis uti iussit et finitimis imperavit ut ab iniuria et maleficio se suosque prohiberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom Caesar, so that toward the wretched and suppliants having used mercy he might be seen, most diligently preserved and their own territories and towns to use he ordered and to the neighbors he commanded that from injury and wrongdoing themselves and theirs they should restrain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom Caesar, so that in miserable and suppliants used mercy he might seem, most carefully preserved and their own territories and towns to use ordered and neighbors commanded so that from injury and mischief themselves and theirs they should prohibit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, in order to be seen as showing mercy toward the wretched and suppliant, spared them most carefully; he ordered them to occupy their own lands and towns, and commanded their neighbors to refrain from doing them or their property any harm.

sentences.latin: Atuatuci, de quibus supra diximus, cum omnibus copiis auxilio Nerviis venirent, hac pugna nuntiata ex itinere domum reverterunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Atuatuci, about whom above we have spoken, when with all forces for an aid to the Nervii they were coming, this battle having been announced, from the march home they returned;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Atuatuci, about whom above we spoke, when with all forces for help to Nervii they were coming, this battle having been announced from journey home returned;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Atuatuci, whom we mentioned above, were coming with all their forces to help the Nervii, but when they heard the news of this battle, they abandoned their march and returned home.

sentences.latin: cunctis oppidis castellisque desertis sua omnia in unum oppidum egregie natura munitum contulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: all towns and forts having been deserted, their own all things into one town excellently by nature fortified they brought together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: all towns and forts having been deserted their all into one town remarkably by nature fortified they brought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Abandoning all their towns and forts, they gathered all their possessions into a single town that was remarkably well-fortified by nature.

sentences.latin: Quod cum ex omnibus in circuitu partibus altissimas rupes deiectusque haberet, una ex parte leniter acclivis aditus in latitudinem non amplius pedum CC relinquebatur; quem locum duplici altissimo muro munierant; tum magni ponderis saxa et praeacutas trabes in muro conlocabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which since from all in circuit parts very high rocks and precipices it had, from one part a gently sloping approach in width not more of feet 200 was left; which place with a double very high wall they had fortified; then of great weight rocks and sharpened beams on the wall they were placing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which since from all in circuit parts highest rocks and precipices had, from one from part gently sloping approach in width not more of feet 200 was left; which place with double highest wall they had fortified; then of great weight stones and sharpened beams on wall they were placing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since this place was surrounded on all sides by very high cliffs and precipices, there remained on one side a gently sloping approach no more than two hundred feet wide; they had fortified this spot with a very high double wall, and were now placing heavy stones and sharpened beams upon it.

sentences.latin: Ipsi erant ex Cimbris Teutonisque prognati, qui, cum iter in provinciam nostram atque Italiam; facerent, iis impedimentis quae secum agere ac portare non poterant citra flumen Rhenum depositis custodiae [ex suis] ac praesidio VI milia hominum una reliquerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They themselves were from the Cimbri and Teutones descended, who, when a journey into province our and Italy they were making, those encumbrances which with themselves to drive and to carry they were not able on this side of the river Rhine having been deposited, for a guard and for a protection 6 thousand of men together they had left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Themselves were from Cimbri and Teutones descended, who, when journey into province our and Italy were making, those baggages which with themselves to drive and carry not they were able this side river Rhine having been deposited for guard and for protection 6 thousands of men together had left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They were descended from the Cimbri and Teutones, who, when marching into our Province and Italy, had left behind on this side of the Rhine such baggage as they could not drive or carry with them, leaving six thousand of their men there as a guard and garrison.

sentences.latin: Hi post eorum obitum multos annos a finitimis exagitati, cum alias bellum inferrent, alias inlatum defenderent, consensu eorum omnium pace facta hunc sibi domicilio locum delegerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These after of them the death many years by neighbors harassed, when at one time war they were bringing in, at another time brought in they were defending, by consent of them all peace having been made, this for themselves for a dwelling place they had chosen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These after of them death many years by neighbors harassed, when at one time war they brought, at another time brought defended, by consent of them all peace having been made this for themselves for home place had chosen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the destruction of their kinsmen, these men were harassed for many years by their neighbors, sometimes waging offensive war and sometimes defending themselves; eventually, with the consent of all parties, peace was made, and they chose this spot as their home.

sentences.latin: Ac primo adventu exercitus nostri crebras ex oppido excursiones faciebant parvulisque proeliis cum nostris contendebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: And at the first arrival of army our, frequent from the town sallies they were making and in small battles with ours they were contending;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And at first arrival of army our frequent from town excursions they were making and in small battles with ours were contending;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon the first arrival of our army, they made frequent sallies from the town and engaged in minor skirmishes with our troops.

sentences.latin: postea vallo pedum XII in circuitu XV milium crebrisque castellis circummuniti oppido sese continebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: afterwards by a rampart of feet 12 in circuit of 15 miles and by frequent forts surrounded, in the town themselves they were containing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: afterwards by rampart of feet 12 in circuit 15 thousands and frequent forts surrounded in town themselves were keeping.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Later, after being hemmed in by a twelve-foot rampart with a fifteen-mile circumference and numerous forts, they confined themselves within the town.

sentences.latin: Ubi vineis actis aggere extructo turrim procul constitui viderunt, primum inridere ex muro atque increpitare vocibus, quod tanta machinatio a tanto spatio institueretur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: When the mantlets having been moved forward, the mound having been built, a tower far off to be set up they saw, first to mock from the wall and to taunt with voices, because so great a machine from so great a distance was being set up:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When sheds having been moved rampart having been built tower far off to be set up they saw, first to mock from wall and to taunt with voices, because so great machine from so great distance was being set up:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they saw the mantlets moved forward, the siege-mound constructed, and a tower being erected in the distance, they began to mock us from the wall and taunt us with shouts, asking why such a massive machine was being built so far away.

sentences.latin: quibusnam mallibus aut quibus viribus praesertim homines tantulae staturae (nam plerumque omnibus Gallis prae magnitudine corporum quorum brevitas nostra contemptui est) tanti oneris turrim in muro seseposseconlocare confiderent?
sentences.referenceTranslation: with what hands or with what strengths especially men of so small stature (for generally to all Gauls in comparison with the size of bodies of whom shortness our for a contempt is) of so great a weight a tower on the wall themselves to be able to place they were trusting?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: with what indeed hands or with what strengths especially men of so small stature (for mostly to all Gauls before greatness of bodies of whom shortness our for contempt is) of so great weight tower on wall themselves to be able to place they were trusting?
sentences.naturalTranslation: With what hands or what strength, they asked, did men of such small staturefor our short height is generally a matter of contempt to the Gauls compared to their own great sizeexpect to be able to mount a tower of such weight upon the wall?

sentences.latin: Ubi vero moveri et adpropinquare muris viderunt, nova atque inusitata specie commoti legatos ad Caesarem de pace miserunt, qui ad hunc modum locuti,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When indeed to be moved and to approach the walls they saw, by the new and unusual sight moved, ambassadors to Caesar concerning peace they sent, who in this manner spoke,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When indeed to be moved and to approach the walls they saw, by the new and unusual sight moved, ambassadors to Caesar concerning peace they sent, who in this manner having spoken,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they saw the tower actually moving and approaching the walls, they were so shaken by the strange and unusual sight that they sent envoys to Caesar to sue for peace, who spoke in this manner:

sentences.latin: non se existimare Romanos sine ope divina bellum gerere, qui tantae altitudinis machinationes tanta celeritate promovere possent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: not themselves to think the Romans without help divine war to wage, who of so great height machines with so great speed to move forward were able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not themselves to think the Romans without help divine war to wage, who of such great height machines with such great speed to move forward were able,
sentences.naturalTranslation: that they did not believe the Romans waged war without divine aid, since they were able to move forward machines of such great height with such speed;

sentences.latin: se suaque omnia eorum potestati permittere dixerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: themselves and their things all to their power to entrust they said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: themselves and their things all to their power to entrust they said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they said they surrendered themselves and all their possessions to their power.

sentences.latin: Unum petere ac deprecari: si forte pro sua clementia ac mansuetudine, quam ipsi ab aliis audirent, statuisset Atuatucos esse conservandos, ne se armis despoliaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One thing to seek and to pray for: if by chance according to his clemency and gentleness, which they themselves from others heard of, he had decided the Atuatuci to be preserved, that not them of arms he should despoil.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One thing to seek and to pray for: if by chance according to his own clemency and gentleness, which they themselves from others heard of, he had decided the Atuatuci to be preserved, that not them of arms he should despoil.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They begged and pleaded for one thing: if by chance, in accordance with his mercy and kindness, which they had heard of from others, he decided that the Atuatuci should be spared, that he would not strip them of their arms.

sentences.latin: Sibi omnes fere finitimos esse inimicos ac suae virtuti invidere; a quibus se defelldere traditis armis non possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To them all nearly neighbors to be enemies and their valor to envy; from whom themselves to defend with surrendered arms not they were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To them all nearly neighbors to be enemies and of their valor to be envious; from whom themselves to defend, given up arms, not they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nearly all their neighbors were enemies and envied their courage; they would be unable to defend themselves from them if their arms were surrendered.

sentences.latin: Sibi praestare, si in eum casum deducerentur, quamvis fortunam a populo Romano pati quam ab his per cruciatum interfici inter quos dominari consuessent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For them to be better, if into that situation they were led, any fortune from the people Roman to suffer than by these through torture to be killed among whom to rule they had been accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For them to be better, if into that situation they were led, any fortune from the people Roman to suffer than by these through torture to be killed among whom to rule they had been accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It would be better for them, if they were reduced to such a state, to suffer any fate at the hands of the Roman people than to be tortured to death by those over whom they had been used to ruling.

sentences.latin: Ad haec Caesar respondit: se magis consuetudine sua quam merito eorum civitatem conservaturum, si prius quam murum aries attigisset se dedidissent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these things Caesar replied: himself more by custom his than by merit of them the state would preserve, if before than the wall the ram had touched themselves they had surrendered;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these things Caesar replied: himself more by custom his own than by merit of them the state about to preserve, if before than the wall the ram had touched themselves they had surrendered;
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this Caesar replied: that he would spare their state more out of his own custom than because of their merit, provided they surrendered before the battering ram touched the wall;

sentences.latin: sed deditionis nullam esse condicionem nisi armis traditis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but of surrender no to be condition except with arms surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but of surrender no to be condition unless arms having been handed over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but there would be no terms of surrender unless their arms were handed over.

sentences.latin: Se id quod in Nerviis fecisset facturum finitimisque imperaturum ne quam dediticiis populi Romani iniuriam inferrent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself that which in the Nervii he had done would do and to the neighbors would command lest any to the surrendered of the people Roman injury they bring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Himself that which in the Nervii he had done about to do and to the neighbors about to command lest any to the surrendered of the people Roman injury they should bring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He would do what he had done in the case of the Nervii and command their neighbors not to inflict any injury upon those who had surrendered to the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Re renuntiata ad suos illi se quae imperarentur facere dixerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The matter reported back to their own people they themselves what were commanded to do they said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The matter reported back to their own, they themselves what were commanded to do they said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported back to their people, they said they would perform what was commanded.

sentences.latin: Armorum magna multitudine de muro in fossam, quae erat ante oppidum, iacta, sic ut prope summam muri aggerisque altitudinem acervi armorum adaequarent, et tamen circiter parte tertia, ut postea perspectum est, celata atque in oppido retenta, portis patefactis eo die pace sunt usi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of arms a great multitude from the wall into the ditch, which was before the town, having been thrown, so that almost the top height of the wall and the rampart the heaps of arms equaled, and yet about a third part, as afterwards was perceived, concealed and in the town retained, the gates having been opened on that day peace they used.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of arms a great multitude from the wall into the ditch, which was before the town, thrown, so that nearly the top of the wall and of the rampart height the heaps of arms equaled, and yet about part third, as afterwards was seen, hidden and in the town retained, the gates opened on that day peace they used.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A vast quantity of weapons was thrown from the wall into the ditch in front of the town, so that the heaps of arms almost reached the top of the wall and the rampart; nevertheless, about a third part was concealed and kept back in the town, as was discovered later. The gates were then opened, and they enjoyed peace for that day.

sentences.latin: Sub vesperum Caesar portas claudi militesque ex oppido exire iussit, ne quam noctu oppidani a militibus iniuriam acciperent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Towards evening Caesar the gates to be closed and the soldiers out of the town to go out ordered, lest any in the night the townsmen from the soldiers injury should receive.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Towards evening Caesar the gates to be closed and the soldiers out of the town to go out ordered, lest any by night the townsmen from the soldiers injury should receive.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Towards evening, Caesar ordered the gates to be closed and the soldiers to leave the town, so that the townsfolk would not suffer any injury from the soldiers during the night.

sentences.latin: Illi ante inito, ut intellectum est, consilio, quod deditione facta nostros praesidia deducturos aut denique indiligentius servaturos crediderant, partim cum iis quae retinuerant et celaverant armis, partim scutis ex cortice factis aut viminibus intextis, quae subito, ut temporis exiguitas postulabat, pellibus induxerant, tertia vigilia, qua minime arduus ad nostras munitiones accensus videbatur, omnibus copiis repente ex oppido eruptionem fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, a plan beforehand having been entered into, as it was understood, because a surrender having been made our men the guards would lead away or at last more carelessly would keep watch they had believed, partly with those which they had retained and had concealed arms, partly with shields from bark made or with osiers interwoven, which suddenly, as the shortness of time was demanding, with skins they had covered, at the third watch, where least steep to our fortifications the approach was seen, with all forces suddenly out of the town a sally they made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, before entered into, as was understood, a plan, because surrender having been made our men the guards would withdraw or at last more carelessly would watch they had believed, partly with those which they had retained and had hidden arms, partly with shields from bark made or with twigs woven, which suddenly, as of time the shortness demanded, with skins they had covered, at the third watch, where least steep to our fortifications the approach seemed, with all forces suddenly from the town a sally they made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having previously formed a plan, as was later understoodbecause they believed that after the surrender our men would withdraw the guards or at least keep watch less diligentlythey suddenly made a sally from the town with all their forces during the third watch. They used the weapons they had kept back and hidden, as well as shields made of bark or woven osiers, which they had hastily covered with skins as the short time required, at a point where the ascent to our fortifications seemed least steep.

sentences.latin: Celeriter, ut ante Caesar imperaverat, ignibus significatione facta, ex proximis castellis eo concursum est,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly, as before Caesar had commanded, by fires a signal having been made, from the nearest forts to that place it was run together,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly, as before Caesar had commanded, by fires a signal having been made, from the nearest forts thither it was run together,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Quickly, as Caesar had previously ordered, a signal was given by fires, and the soldiers rushed there from the nearest forts.

sentences.latin: pugnatumque ab hostibus ita acriter est ut a viris fortibus in extrema spe salutis iniquo loco contra eos qui ex vallo turribusque tela iacerent pugnari debuit, cum in una virtute omnis spes consisteret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and it was fought by the enemies so fiercely as by men brave in the last hope of safety in an unfavorable place against those who from the rampart and towers weapons were throwing it ought to be fought, since in valor alone all hope was consisting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and it was fought by the enemies so fiercely as by men brave in extreme hope of safety in an unfavorable place against those who from the rampart and towers weapons were throwing it ought to be fought, since in valor alone all hope consisted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy fought as fiercely as brave men ought to fight when in the last hope of safety, on unfavorable ground, against those who were throwing missiles from the rampart and towers, since their entire hope rested on valor alone.

sentences.latin: Occisis ad hominum milibus IIII reliqui in oppidum reiecti sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been killed about of men thousands four, the rest into the town were driven back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been killed about of men thousands four, the rest into the town were driven back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: About four thousand men were killed, and the rest were driven back into the town.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei refractis portis, cum iam defenderet nemo, atque intromissis militibus nostris, sectionem eius oppidi universa Caesar vendidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day of that day, the gates having been broken open, when now was defending no one, and having been sent in our soldiers, the auction-lot of that town entire Caesar sold.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the next day of that day, broken open the gates, when now was defending no one, and sent in soldiers our, the auction-lot of that town entire Caesar sold.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following day, after the gates had been broken open and since no one was now defending them, our soldiers were sent in, and Caesar sold the entire booty of that town in one lot.

sentences.latin: Ab iis qui emerant capitum numerus ad eum relatus est milium LIII.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By those who had bought, of heads the number to him was reported of thousands fifty-three.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By those who had bought, of heads the number to him was reported of thousands fifty-three.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The purchasers reported to him that the number of persons was fifty-three thousand.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore a P. Crasso, quem cum legione una miserat ad Venetos, Venellos, Osismos, Coriosolitas, Esuvios, Aulercos, Redones, quae sunt maritimae civitates Oceanumque attingunt, certior factus est omnes eas civitates in dicionem potestatemque populi Romani esse redactas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time by P. Crassus, whom with one legion he had sent to the Veneti, Venelli, Osismi, Coriosolitae, Esuvii, Aulerci, Redones, which are maritime states and the Ocean touch, more certain he was made all those states into the sway and power of the Roman people to have been reduced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time by P. Crassus, whom with legion one he had sent to the Veneti, Venelli, Osismi, Coriosolitae, Esuvii, Aulerci, Redones, which are maritime states and the Ocean touch, more certain he was made all those states into the dominion and power of the people Roman to have been reduced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, Caesar was informed by Publius Crassus, whom he had sent with a single legion to the Veneti, Venelli, Osismi, Coriosolitae, Esuvii, Aulerci, and Redones (which are maritime states bordering the Ocean), that all these states had been brought under the dominion and power of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: His rebus gestis omni Gallia pacata, tanta huius belli ad barbaros opinio perlata est uti ab iis nationibus quae trans Rhenum incolerent legationes ad Caesarem mitterentur, quae se obsides daturas, imperata facturas pollicerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been done, all Gaul having been pacified, so great of this war to the barbarians the report was carried that by those nations which across the Rhine were dwelling embassies to Caesar were sent, which themselves hostages would give, commands would do were promising.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been done, all Gaul having been pacified, so great of this war to the barbarians the report was carried that by those nations which across the Rhine were dwelling embassies to Caesar were sent, which themselves hostages about to give, commands about to do promised.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these events and the pacification of all Gaul, such a high opinion of this war spread among the barbarians that embassies were sent to Caesar by the nations living across the Rhine, promising that they would give hostages and carry out his commands.

sentences.latin: Quas legationes Caesar, quod in Italiam Illyricumque properabat, inita proxima aestate ad se reverti iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which embassies Caesar, because into Italy and Illyricum he was hastening, having been entered the next summer to himself to return ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which embassies Caesar, because into Italy and Illyricum he was hastening, having been entered the next summer to himself to return ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because he was hastening to Italy and Illyricum, Caesar ordered these embassies to return to him at the beginning of the following summer.

sentences.latin: Ipse in Carnutes, Andes, Turonos quaeque civitates propinquae iis locis erant ubi bellum gesserat, legionibus in hiberna deductis, in Italiam profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself into the Carnutes, Andes, Turoni and which states near to those places were where war he had waged, the legions into winter quarters having been led, into Italy set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Himself into the Carnutes, Andes, Turoni and which states near to those places were where war he had waged, the legions into winter quarters having been led down, into Italy set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After leading the legions into winter quarters, he himself set out for Italy, passing through the territories of the Carnutes, Andes, Turoni, and those states which were near the places where he had waged war.

sentences.latin: Ob easque res ex litteris Caesaris dierum XV supplicatio decreta est, quod ante id tempus accidit nulli.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And on account of those things from the letters of Caesar of days fifteen a thanksgiving was decreed, which before that time happened to no one.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And on account of these things from the letters of Caesar of days 15 a thanksgiving was decreed, which before that time happened to no one.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because of these achievements, a fifteen-day thanksgiving was decreed based on Caesar's dispatches, an honor which had happened to no one before that time.

sentences.latin: Cum in Italiam proficisceretur Caesar, Ser.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When into Italy was setting out Caesar, Ser.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When into Italy was setting out Caesar, Ser.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar was setting out for Italy, Servius...

sentences.latin: Galbam cum legione XII. et parte equitatus in Nantuates, Veragros Sedunosque misit, qui a finibus Allobrogum et lacu Lemanno et flumine Rhodano ad summas Alpes pertinent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Galba with the twelfth legion and part of the cavalry into the Nantuates, Veragri, and Seduni he sent, who from the borders of the Allobroges and lake Lemannus and the river Rhone to the highest Alps extend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Galba with legion 12th and part of the cavalry into the Nantuates, Veragri and Seduni he sent, who from the borders of the Allobroges and lake Lemannus and river Rhone to the highest Alps extend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent Servius Galba with the Twelfth Legion and part of the cavalry into the territory of the Nantuates, Veragri, and Seduni, who occupy the region extending from the borders of the Allobroges, Lake Geneva, and the Rhone River to the high Alps.

sentences.latin: Causa mittendi fuit quod iter per Alpes, quo magno cum periculo magnisque cum portoriis mercatores ire consuerant, patefieri volebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The cause of sending was because the route through the Alps, by which with great danger and with great tolls merchants to go had been accustomed, to be opened he was wishing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The cause of sending was because the route through the Alps, by which with great danger and with great tolls merchants to go had been accustomed, to be opened he was wishing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The reason for sending him was that he wished to open the route through the Alps, where merchants were accustomed to travel only at great risk and by paying heavy tolls.

sentences.latin: Huic permisit, si opus esse arbitraretur, uti in his locis legionem hiemandi causa conlocaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To him he permitted, if necessary to be he should judge, that in these places the legion for the sake of wintering he might station.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this [man] he permitted, if necessary to be he should judge, that in these places the legion for the sake of wintering he might station.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He gave him permission, if he thought it necessary, to station the legion in these places for the purpose of wintering.
