sentences.latin: Galba secundis aliquot proeliis factis castellisque compluribus eorum expugnatis, missis ad eum undique legatis obsidibusque datis et pace facta, constituit cohortes duas in Nantuatibus conlocare et ipse cum reliquis eius legionis cohortibus in vico Veragrorum, qui appellatur Octodurus hiemare;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Galba, successful several battles having been made and forts several of them having been stormed, having been sent to him from all sides envoys and hostages given and peace made, decided cohorts two in the Nantuates to station and himself with the remaining of that legion cohorts in a village of the Veragri, which is called Octodurus, to winter;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Galba, successful some battles having been made and forts several of them having been stormed, having been sent to him from all sides envoys and hostages given and peace made, decided cohorts two among the Nantuates to station and himself with the remaining of that legion cohorts in a village of the Veragri, which is called Octodurus, to winter;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After fighting several successful battles and storming many of their forts, Galba received envoys from all sides, took hostages, and established peace; he then decided to station two cohorts among the Nantuates and to winter himself with the remaining cohorts of that legion in a village of the Veragri called Octodurus.

sentences.latin: qui vicus positus in valle non magna adiecta planitie altissimis montibus undique continetur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which village placed in a valley not large, an adjacent plain, by very high mountains on all sides is hemmed in.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which village placed in a valley not large, an adjacent plain, by very high mountains from all sides is hemmed in.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This village, situated in a small valley with an adjacent plain, is surrounded on all sides by very high mountains.

sentences.latin: Cum hic in duas partes flumine divideretur, alteram partem eius vici Gallis [ad hiemandum] concessit, alteram vacuam ab his relictam cohortibus attribuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Since this into two parts by a river was divided, one part of that village to the Gauls [for wintering] he granted, the other empty by them left to the cohorts he assigned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Since this into two parts by a river was divided, one part of that village to the Gauls [for wintering] he granted, the other empty by them left to the cohorts he assigned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the village was divided into two parts by a river, he granted one part to the Gauls for their wintering and assigned the other part, left vacant by them, to his cohorts.

sentences.latin: Eum locum vallo fossaque munivit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That place with a rampart and a ditch he fortified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That place with a rampart and a ditch he fortified.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He fortified that place with a rampart and a ditch.

sentences.latin: Cum dies hibernorum complures transissent frumentumque eo comportari iussisset, subito per exploratores certior factus est ex ea parte vici, quam Gallis concesserat, omnes noctu discessisse montesque qui impenderent a maxima multitudine Sedunorum et Veragrorum teneri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When days of the winter quarters several had passed and grain there to be brought he had ordered, suddenly through scouts more certain he was made from that part of the village, which to the Gauls he had granted, all by night had departed and the mountains which were overhanging by a very great multitude of the Seduni and Veragri were held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When days of winter quarters several had passed and grain there to be brought he had ordered, suddenly through scouts more certain he was made from that part of the village, which to the Gauls he had granted, all by night had departed and the mountains which were overhanging by a very great multitude of Seduni and Veragri were held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When several days had passed in winter quarters and he had ordered grain to be brought there, he was suddenly informed by scouts that everyone had left during the night from that part of the village he had granted to the Gauls, and that the overhanging mountains were held by a massive force of Seduni and Veragri.

sentences.latin: Id aliquot de causis acciderat, ut subito Galli belli renovandi legionisque opprimendae consilium caperent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This for several from causes had happened, that suddenly the Gauls of the war renewing and of the legion crushing a plan they took:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That from some of causes had happened, that suddenly the Gauls of war renewing and of the legion crushing a plan should take:
sentences.naturalTranslation: This had happened for several reasons, leading the Gauls to suddenly adopt a plan of renewing the war and crushing the legion:

sentences.latin: primum, quod legionem neque eam plenissimam detractis cohortibus duabus et compluribus singillatim, qui commeatus petendi causa missi erant, absentibus propter paucitatem despiciebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: first, because the legion and not it very full having been withdrawn cohorts two and several individually, who of supplies seeking for the sake had been sent, being absent on account of the small number they were despising;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: first, because the legion and that not very full, having been withdrawn cohorts two and several individually, who of supplies seeking for the sake had been sent, being absent, on account of smallness they were despising;
sentences.naturalTranslation: first, because they looked down on the legionwhich was not at full strength since two cohorts had been detached and several individuals were absent, having been sent to seek suppliesdue to its small numbers;

sentences.latin: tum etiam, quod propter iniquitatem loci, cum ipsi ex montibus in vallem decurrerent et tela coicerent, ne primum quidem impetum suum posse sustineri existimabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: then also, because on account of the inequality of the place, when themselves from the mountains into the valley they would run down and weapons they would hurl, not even the first indeed attack their own to be able to be sustained they were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: then also, because on account of the inequality of the place, when themselves from the mountains into the valley should run down and weapons should hurl, not even the first attack their own to be able to be sustained they were thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: then also, because they thought that, due to the disadvantageous terrain, their very first charge could not be withstood when they themselves ran down from the mountains into the valley and hurled their weapons.

sentences.latin: Accedebat quod suos ab se liberos abstractos obsidum nomine dolebant, et Romanos non solum itinerum causa sed etiam perpetuae possessionis culmina Alpium occupare conari et ea loca finitimae provinciae adiungere sibi persuasum habebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was added that their own from themselves children dragged away of hostages under the name they were grieving, and the Romans not only of journeys for the sake but also of perpetual possession the peaks of the Alps to occupy to try and those places to the neighboring province to join to themselves persuaded they had.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was added that their own from them children dragged away of hostages in the name they were grieving, and the Romans not only of routes for the sake but also of perpetual possession the peaks of the Alps to occupy to try and those places to the neighboring province to join to themselves persuaded they were having.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Added to this was their grief that their children had been dragged away from them under the name of hostages, and they were convinced that the Romans were trying to occupy the Alpine peaks not just for the sake of travel, but for permanent possession and to annex those places to the neighboring province.

sentences.latin: His nuntiis acceptis Galba, cum neque opus hibernorum munitionesque plene essent perfectae neque de frumento reliquoque commeatu satis esset provisum quod deditione facta obsidibusque acceptis nihil de bello timendum existimaverat, consilio celeriter convocato sententias exquirere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These messages having been received Galba, when neither the work of the winter quarters and the fortifications fully had been completed nor concerning grain and the rest of the supply enough had been provided because surrender having been made and hostages having been received nothing concerning war to be feared he had thought, a council quickly having been called opinions to seek out he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These messages having been received Galba, since neither the work of winter quarters and the fortifications fully had been finished nor concerning grain and the rest of the supplies enough had been provided because surrender having been made and hostages received nothing concerning war to be feared he had thought, a council quickly having been called opinions to seek out he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon receiving these reports, Galbasince neither the winter works nor the fortifications were fully completed, and since insufficient provision had been made for grain and other supplies because he had thought nothing was to be feared regarding war after the surrender and the taking of hostagesquickly called a council and began to seek out opinions.

sentences.latin: Quo in consilio, cum tantum repentini periculi praeter opinionem accidisset ac iam omnia fere superiora loca multitudine armatorum completa conspicerentur neque subsidio veniri neque commeatus supportari interclusis itineribus possent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which in council, when so much of sudden danger beyond expectation had happened and now all almost higher places by a multitude of armed men filled were seen and neither for help to be come nor supplies to be brought in having been blocked the routes they were able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which in council, when so much of sudden danger beyond expectation had happened and already all almost higher places by a multitude of armed men filled were seen and neither for help to be come nor supplies to be brought up, having been blocked the routes, were able,
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this council, since such a great and unexpected danger had arisen, and since almost all the higher ground was now seen to be filled with a multitude of armed men, and neither could reinforcements arrive nor supplies be brought in because the routes were blocked,

sentences.latin: prope iam desperata salute non nullae eius modi sententiae dicebantur, ut impedimentis relictis eruptione facta isdem itineribus quibus eo pervenissent ad salutem contenderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nearly now having been despaired of safety not some of that kind opinions were being said, that the baggage having been left a breakout having been made by the same routes by which there they had arrived to safety they should hasten.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nearly now despaired of safety some of that kind opinions were being said, that the baggage having been left, a breakout having been made, by the same routes by which there they had arrived to safety they should hasten.
sentences.naturalTranslation: with safety now almost despaired of, several opinions of this kind were expressed: that they should leave the baggage behind, make a breakout, and hasten to safety by the same routes they had used to arrive there.

sentences.latin: Maiori tamen parti placuit, hoc reservato ad extremumcasumconsilio interim rei eventum experiri et castra defendere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the greater however part it pleased, this having been reserved for the final case plan meanwhile of the matter the outcome to try and the camp to defend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the greater however part it pleased, this having been reserved to the extreme case plan, meanwhile of the matter the outcome to try and the camp to defend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, the majority decided to reserve that plan for a final emergency and, in the meantime, to await the outcome of the situation and defend the camp.

sentences.latin: Brevi spatio interiecto, vix ut iis rebus quas constituissent conlocandis atque administrandis tempus daretur, hostes ex omnibus partibus signo dato decurrere, lapides gaesaque in vallum coicere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A short space having been interposed, scarcely so that for those things which they had decided for arranging and managing time was given, the enemies from all parts a signal having been given to run down, stones and javelins onto the rampart to throw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A short space having been interposed, scarcely so that for those things which they had decided on arranging and managing time was given, the enemies from all parts the signal having been given ran down, stones and javelins into the rampart to hurl.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a short interval, so brief that there was hardly time to arrange and carry out the measures they had decided upon, the enemy, at a given signal, rushed down from all sides and began hurling stones and javelins at the rampart.

sentences.latin: Nostri primo integris viribus fortiter propugnare neque ullum flustra telum ex loco superiore mittere, et quaecumque pars castrorum nudata defensoribus premi videbatur, eo occurrere et auxilium ferre,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our men at first with fresh strengths bravely to fight back and not any weapon in vain from the higher place to send, and whatever part of the camp stripped of defenders to be pressed seemed, thither to run and help to bring,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men at first with fresh strengths bravely to fight back and not any in vain weapon from the place higher to send, and whatever part of the camp stripped of defenders to be pressed seemed, there to run and help to bring,
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first, our men fought back bravely with unimpaired strength, throwing no weapon in vain from their higher position; whenever any part of the camp seemed stripped of defenders and hard-pressed, they hurried there to bring assistance.

sentences.latin: sed hoc superari quod diuturnitate pugnae hostes defessi proelio excedebant, alii integris viribus succedebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: but in this to be surpassed because by the long duration of the battle the enemies tired from the battle were withdrawing, others with fresh strengths were succeeding;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but in this to be surpassed because by the long duration of the fight the enemies exhausted from the battle were withdrawing, others with fresh strengths were succeeding;
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, they were at a disadvantage because the enemy, when exhausted by the long duration of the fight, could retire from the battle while others with fresh strength took their place.

sentences.latin: quarum rerum a nostris propter paucitatem fieri nihil poterat, ac non modo defesso ex pugna excedendi, sed ne saucio quidem eius loci ubi constiterat relinquendi ac sui recipiendi facultas dabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of which things by our men on account of smallness to be done nothing was able, and not only to a tired man from the battle of withdrawing, but not even to a wounded man indeed of that place where he had stood of leaving and of himself recovering the opportunity was given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of which things by our men on account of the fewness to be done nothing was able, and not only to the exhausted from the battle of withdrawing, but not even to the wounded indeed of that place where he had stood of leaving and of himself recovering the opportunity was given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: None of this could be done by our men because of their small numbers; not only was an exhausted man unable to withdraw from the fight, but even a wounded man was given no opportunity to leave the spot where he stood or to recover himself.

sentences.latin: Cum iam amplius horis sex continenter pugnaretur, ac non solum vires sed etiam tela nostros deficerent, atque hostes acrius instarent languidioribusque nostris vallum scindere et fossas complere coepissent, resque esset iam ad extremum perducta casum,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When now more than hours six continuously it was being fought, and not only strengths but also weapons our men were failing, and the enemies more fiercely were pressing on and with our men being more weary the rampart to tear down and the ditches to fill they had begun, and the matter had been now to the extreme crisis led,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When now more than hours six continuously it was being fought, and not only strengths but also weapons our men were failing, and the enemies more fiercely were pressing and our men being more faint the rampart to tear down and the ditches to fill they had begun, and the matter was now to the extreme brought crisis,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the fighting had now continued for more than six hours without interruption, and not only strength but even weapons were failing our men, while the enemy pressed on more fiercely and, as our men grew more weary, had begun to tear down the rampart and fill the ditches, and the situation had reached a desperate crisis,

sentences.latin: P. Sextius Baculus, primi pili centurio, quem Nervico proelio compluribus confectum vulneribus diximus, et item C. Volusenus, tribunus militum, vir et consilii magni et virtutis, ad Galbam accurrunt atque unam esse spem salutis docent, si eruptione facta extremum auxilium experirentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: P. Sextius Baculus, of the first rank centurion, whom in the Nervian battle with several finished wounds we have said, and likewise C. Volusenus, tribune of soldiers, a man both of counsel great and of courage, to Galba run and one to be the hope of safety they show, if a sally having been made the extreme aid they should try.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: P. Sextius Baculus, of the first rank centurion, whom in the Nervian battle by many finished off wounds we have said, and likewise C. Volusenus, tribune of the soldiers, a man both of counsel great and of virtue, to Galba run and that one is the hope of safety they teach, if a breakout having been made the extreme help they should try.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Publius Sextius Baculus, a centurion of the first rank, whom we have mentioned as being exhausted by many wounds in the battle against the Nervii, and also Gaius Volusenus, a military tribune, a man of great resourcefulness and courage, hurried to Galba and informed him that the only hope of safety was to make a sally and try their last resource.

sentences.latin: Itaque convocatis centurionibus celeriter milites certiores facit, paulisper intermitterent proelium ac tantum modo tela missa exciperent seque ex labore reficerent, post dato signo ex castris erumperent, atque omnem spem salutis in virtute ponerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore having called together the centurions quickly the soldiers more certain he makes, for a little while they should interrupt the battle and only weapons sent they should catch and themselves from labor they should refresh, afterwards a signal having been given from the camp they should break out, and all hope of safety in courage they should place.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore having called together the centurions quickly the soldiers more certain he makes, for a little while they should stop the battle and only just weapons sent they should receive and themselves from labor refresh, after the signal having been given from the camp they should break out, and all hope of safety in virtue they should place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having summoned the centurions, he quickly instructed the soldiers to pause the fight for a short time and merely parry the weapons thrown at them to recover from their fatigue; then, at a given signal, they were to burst out of the camp and place all their hope of safety in their courage.

sentences.latin: Quod iussi sunt faciunt, ac subito omnibus portis eruptione facta neque cognoscendi quid fieret neque sui colligendi hostibus facultatem relinquunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which they were ordered they do, and suddenly from all gates a sally having been made neither of learning what was happening nor of themselves collecting to the enemies the opportunity they leave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: What they were ordered they do, and suddenly from all gates a breakout having been made neither of learning what was happening nor of themselves collecting to the enemies the opportunity they leave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did as they were ordered, and suddenly making a sally from all the gates, they left the enemy no opportunity either to understand what was happening or to regroup.

sentences.latin: Ita commutata fortuna eos qui in spem potiundorum castrorum venerant undique circumventos intercipiunt, et ex hominum milibus amplius XXX, quem numerum barbarorum ad castra venisse constabat, plus tertia parte interfecta reliquos perterritos in fugam coiciunt ac ne in locis quidem superioribus consistere patiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus changed fortune those who into the hope of getting possession of the camp had come from all sides surrounded they intercept, and from of men thousands more than 30, which number of barbarians to the camp to have come it was established, more than a third part having been killed the rest terrified into flight they throw and not even in the places indeed higher to stand they allow.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus changed fortune those who into the hope of getting possession of the camp had come from all sides surrounded they intercept, and out of of men thousands more than 30, which number of barbarians to the camp to have come it was certain, more than the third part having been killed the rest terrified into flight they throw and not even in the places indeed higher to stand they allow.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, with fortune reversed, they surrounded and cut down on all sides those who had come with the hope of seizing the camp; of more than thirty thousand menthe number of barbarians known to have come to the campmore than a third were killed, and the rest were driven in terror into flight, not even being allowed to make a stand on the higher ground.

sentences.latin: Sic omnibus hostium copiis fusis armisque exutis se intra munitiones suas recipiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus all of the enemies' forces having been routed and of arms stripped themselves within fortifications their own they withdraw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus all of the enemies forces routed and of arms stripped themselves within fortifications their own they take back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having thus routed all the enemy's forces and stripped them of their arms, they withdrew within their own fortifications.

sentences.latin: Quo proelio facto, quod saepius fortunam temptare Galba nolebat atque alio se in hiberna consilio venisse meminerat, aliis occurrisse rebus videbat, maxime frumenti [commeatusque] inopia permotus postero die omnibus eius vici aedificiis incensis in provinciam reverti contendit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which battle having been done, because more often fortune to tempt Galba was unwilling and with another plan himself into winter quarters to have come he remembered, with other things to have met he saw, especially by grain and supplies lack moved, on the next day all of that village buildings having been burned, into the province to return he hastened,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which battle having been done, because too often fortune to tempt Galba was not wishing and to another himself into winter quarters plan to have come he remembered, with other he had met things he saw, especially of grain and of supplies by the lack moved on the following day all of that village buildings having been burned into the province to return he hastened,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this battle was over, Galba, unwilling to tempt fortune any further and remembering that he had come into winter quarters with one plan but saw he had met with a different state of affairs, was especially moved by the lack of grain and supplies; therefore, on the following day, after burning all the buildings of that village, he hastened to return to the Province.

sentences.latin: ac nullo hoste prohibente aut iter demorante incolumem legionem in Nantuates, inde in Allobroges perduxit ibique hiemavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and with no enemy prohibiting or the journey delaying, the safe legion into the Nantuates, then into the Allobroges he led through and there wintered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and with no enemy prohibiting or the journey delaying safe the legion into the Nantuates, then into the Allobroges he led and there wintered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With no enemy hindering him or delaying his march, he led the legion safely into the territory of the Nantuates, then to the Allobroges, and there he spent the winter.

sentences.latin: His rebus gestis cum omnibus de causis Caesar pacatam Galliam existimaret, [superatis Belgis, expulsis Germanis, victis in Alpibus Sedunis,] atque ita inita hieme in Illyricum profectus esset, quod eas quoque nationes adire et regiones cognoscere volebat, subitum bellum in Gallia coortum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been done, when for all reasons Caesar pacified Gaul thought, the Belgae having been overcome, the Germans expelled, the Seduni in the Alps conquered, and thus winter having been entered into Illyricum he had set out, because those also nations to visit and regions to learn he was wishing, a sudden war in Gaul arose.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been done when for all from causes Caesar pacified Gaul thought, the Belgae having been overcome, the Germans driven out, defeated in the Alps the Seduni, and thus having begun winter into Illyricum he had set out, because those also nations to visit and regions to learn he was wishing, a sudden war in Gaul arisen is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these events, when Caesar had every reason to believe Gaul was at peacethe Belgae having been subdued, the Germans driven out, and the Seduni in the Alps defeatedand had consequently set out for Illyricum at the start of winter to visit those nations and learn about the region, a sudden war broke out in Gaul.

sentences.latin: Eius belli haec fuit causa.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this war this was the cause.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this war this was the cause.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cause of this war was as follows.

sentences.latin: P. Crassus adulescens cum legione VII. proximus mare Oceanum in Andibus hiemabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: P. Crassus the young man with the seventh legion nearest the sea Ocean among the Andes was wintering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: P. Crassus the young man with the 7th legion nearest the sea Ocean in the Andes was wintering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The young Publius Crassus was wintering with the Seventh Legion among the Andes, very close to the Atlantic Ocean.

sentences.latin: Is, quod in his locis inopia frumenti erat, praefectos tribunosque militum complures in finitimas civitates frumenti causa dimisit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: He, because in these places a lack of grain was, prefects and tribunes of soldiers several into neighboring states for the sake of grain sent out;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He, because in these places a lack of grain was, prefects and tribunes of the soldiers several into the neighboring states for the sake of grain sent away;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because there was a scarcity of grain in these parts, he sent several prefects and military tribunes into the neighboring states to obtain supplies.

sentences.latin: quo in numero est T. Terrasidius missus in Esuvios, M. Trebius Gallus in Coriosolites, Q. Velanius eum T. Silio in Venetos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: in which number is T. Terrasidius sent into the Esuvii, M. Trebius Gallus into the Coriosolites, Q. Velanius with T. Silius into the Veneti.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: in which number is T. Terrasidius sent into the Esuvii, M. Trebius Gallus into the Coriosolites, Q. Velanius with T. Silius into the Veneti.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among these were Titus Terrasidius, sent to the Esuvii; Marcus Trebius Gallus, to the Coriosolites; and Quintus Velanius with Titus Silius, to the Veneti.

sentences.latin: Huius est civitatis longe amplissima auctoritas omnis orae maritimae regionum earum, quod et naves habent Veneti plurimas, quibus in Britanniam navigare consuerunt, et scientia atque usu rerum nauticarum ceteros antecedunt et in magno impetu maris atque aperto paucis portibus interiectis, quos tenent ipsi, omnes fere qui eo mari uti consuerunt habent vectigales.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this state is by far the most ample authority of all the maritime coast of those regions, because both ships have the Veneti very many, with which into Britain to sail they are accustomed, and in knowledge and use of things nautical others they surpass and in the great force of the sea and open, few ports being scattered, which they hold themselves, all almost who that sea to use are accustomed they have as tributaries.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this is state by far the most ample authority of all the coast maritime of regions those, because both ships have the Veneti very many, with which into Britain to sail they have been accustomed, and in knowledge and use of things nautical the others they surpass and in the great force of the sea and open few ports having been interposed, which they hold themselves, all almost who that sea to use have been accustomed they have as taxpayers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This state possesses by far the greatest influence of any on the whole sea-coast of those regions, because the Veneti have a very large number of ships in which they are accustomed to sail to Britain, they surpass others in the knowledge and practice of navigation, and since the sea is violent and open with only a few scattered harbors which they themselves control, they hold as tributaries almost all who are accustomed to sail those waters.

sentences.latin: Ab his fit initium retinendi Silii atque Velanii, quod per eos suos se obsides, quos Crasso dedissent, recuperaturos existimabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these is made a beginning of retaining Silius and Velanius, because through them their own hostages, whom to Crassus they had given, to recover they were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these is made the beginning of retaining Silius and Velanius, because through them their own they hostages, whom to Crassus they had given, to recover they were thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These people took the first step by detaining Silius and Velanius, thinking that through them they would recover their own hostages whom they had given to Crassus.

sentences.latin: Horum auctoritate finitimi adducti, ut sunt Gallorum subita et repentina consilia, eadem de causa Trebium Terrasidiumque retinent et celeriter missis legatis per suos principes inter se coniurant nihil nisi communi consilio acturos eundemque omnes fortunae exitum esse laturos,
sentences.referenceTranslation: By their authority the neighbors influenced, as are of the Gauls sudden and unexpected plans, for the same cause Trebius and Terrasidius they retain and quickly having sent envoys through their leaders among themselves they conspire nothing except by common plan they will do and the same of fortune end all to be going to bear,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these by the authority the neighbors led, as are of the Gauls sudden and repentant plans, for the same cause Trebius and Terrasidius they retain and quickly having sent legates through their leaders among themselves they conspire nothing except by common counsel they will do and the same of fortune outcome they all will bear,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by their authority, their neighborsas the designs of the Gauls are often sudden and impulsivedetained Trebius and Terrasidius for the same reason; quickly sending envoys through their leading men, they bound themselves by a mutual oath to do nothing except by common counsel and to share whatever end of fortune might come.

sentences.latin: reliquasque civitates sollicitant, ut in ea libertate quam a maioribus acceperint permanere quam Romanorum servitutem perferre malint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and the remaining states they stir up, so that in that liberty which from ancestors they received to remain than of the Romans slavery to endure they might prefer.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and the remaining states they incite, so that in that liberty which from ancestors they received to remain than of Romans slavery to endure they might prefer.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They also incited the remaining states to prefer remaining in the liberty they had inherited from their ancestors rather than enduring Roman slavery.

sentences.latin: Omni ora maritima celeriter ad suam sententiam perducta communem legationem ad P. Crassum mittunt, si velit suos recuperare, obsides sibi remittat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All the sea coast quickly to their opinion having been led, a common embassy to P. Crassus they send, if he wishes his own [men] to recover, hostages to them he should send back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All the sea coast quickly to their opinion having been led, a common embassy to P. Crassus they send, if he should wish his own to recover, the hostages to them he should send back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having quickly brought the entire sea coast over to their way of thinking, they sent a joint embassy to Publius Crassus, stating that if he wished to recover his men, he must return their hostages to them.

sentences.latin: Quibus de rebus Caesar a Crasso certior factus, quod ipse aberat longius, naves interim longas aedificari in flumine Ligeri, quod influit in Oceanum, remiges ex provincia institui, nautas gubernatoresque comparari iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: About which things Caesar by Crassus more certain having been made, because he himself was away further, ships meanwhile long to be built in the river Loire, which flows into the Ocean, rowers from the province to be drafted, sailors and pilots to be prepared he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: About which things Caesar by Crassus more certain having been made, because he himself was away further, ships meanwhile long to be built in the river Loire, which flows into the Ocean, rowers from the province to be trained, sailors and pilots to be prepared he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar was informed of these events by Crassus, since he himself was quite far away, he ordered warships to be built in the Loire river, which flows into the Ocean, rowers to be drafted from the province, and sailors and pilots to be assembled.

sentences.latin: His rebus celeriter administratis ipse, cum primum per anni tempus potuit, ad exercitum contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things quickly having been administered, he himself, when first through the time of year he was able, to the army hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things quickly having been managed he himself, when first through the time of year he was able, to the army hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these matters were quickly arranged, he himself hastened to the army as soon as the time of year permitted.

sentences.latin: Veneti reliquaeque item civitates cognito Caesaris adventu [certiores facti], simul quod quantum in se facinus admisissent intellegebant, [legatos, quod nomen ad omnes nationes sanctum inviolatumque semper fuisset, retentos ab se et in vincula coniectos,] pro magnitudine periculi bellum parare et maxime ea quae ad usum navium pertinent providere instituunt, hoc maiore spe quod multum natura loci confidebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Veneti and remaining likewise states having been known Caesar's arrival [having been made more certain], at the same time because how great against themselves a crime they had admitted they understood, [ambassadors, which name to all nations sacred and inviolate always had been, retained by themselves and into chains thrown,] according to the greatness of the danger war to prepare and especially those things which to the use of ships pertain to provide they begin, by this greater hope because much in the nature of the place they were trusting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Veneti and the remaining likewise states having known of Caesar's arrival [having been made more certain], at the same time because how great against themselves a crime they had admitted they understood, [ambassadors, which name to all nations sacred and inviolate always had been, retained by themselves and into chains thrown,] for the magnitude of the danger war to prepare and especially those things which to the use of ships pertain to provide they begin, with this greater hope because much in the nature of the place they were trusting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Veneti and the other states, learning of Caesar's arrival and realizing the magnitude of the crime they had committedhaving detained and imprisoned ambassadors, whose title had always been sacred and inviolate among all nationsbegan to prepare for war in proportion to the danger and especially to provide for their naval needs, with greater hope because they relied heavily on the nature of their terrain.

sentences.latin: Pedestria esse itinera concisa aestuariis, navigationem impeditam propter inscientiam locorum paucitatemque portuum sciebant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: On-foot to be journeys cut up by estuaries, navigation hindered on account of ignorance of places and scarcity of ports they knew,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On-foot to be journeys cut up by estuaries, navigation hindered on account of ignorance of places and scarcity of harbors they knew,
sentences.naturalTranslation: They knew that land routes were intersected by estuaries and that navigation was hindered by a lack of knowledge of the area and a scarcity of harbors,

sentences.latin: neque nostros exercitus propter inopiam frumenti diutius apud se morari posse confidebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor our armies on account of lack of grain longer among them to stay to be able they were confident;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor our armies on account of lack of grain longer among them to be able to stay they were confident;
sentences.naturalTranslation: and they were confident that our armies would be unable to stay among them for long due to a lack of grain;

sentences.latin: ac iam ut omnia contra opinionem acciderent, tamen se plurimum navibus posse, [quam] Romanos neque ullam facultatem habere navium, neque eorum locorum ubi bellum gesturi essent vada, portus, insulas novisse;
sentences.referenceTranslation: and even if all things against expectation should happen, nevertheless themselves most by ships to be able, [while] the Romans neither any supply to have of ships, nor of those places where war they were about to wage the shallows, ports, islands to have known;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and even if all things against expectation should happen, nevertheless themselves most with ships to be able, [than] the Romans neither any supply to have of ships, nor of those places where war they were about to wage the shallows, harbors, islands to have known;
sentences.naturalTranslation: and even if everything should turn out contrary to their expectations, they still believed they were superior in naval power, whereas the Romans had no supply of ships and were unfamiliar with the shallows, harbors, and islands of the regions where they would be fighting;

sentences.latin: ac longe aliam esse navigationem in concluso mari atque in vastissimo atque apertissimo Oceano perspiciebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and far other to be navigation in a closed sea than in the most vast and most open Ocean they perceived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and far other to be navigation in a closed sea than in the most vast and most open Ocean they perceived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they also realized that navigation in a landlocked sea was far different from navigation in the vast and open Ocean.

sentences.latin: His initis consiliis oppida muniunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been entered plans the towns they fortify,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been entered plans the towns they fortify,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having formed these plans, they fortified their towns,

sentences.latin: frumenta ex agris in oppida comportant, naves in Venetiam, ubi Caesarem primum bellum gesturum
sentences.referenceTranslation: Grain from the fields into the towns they carry together, ships into Venetia, where Caesar first the war to be about to wage
sentences.originalMITTranslation: grain from the fields into the towns they carry, ships into Venetia, where Caesar first war about to wage
sentences.naturalTranslation: They gathered grain from the fields into the towns and assembled ships in Venetia, where it was certain Caesar would first wage war.

sentences.latin: constabat, quam plurimas possunt cogunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: it was evident, as many as they are able they collect.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: it was evident, as many as they are able they collect.
sentences.naturalTranslation: it was known he would begin; they collected as many ships as possible.

sentences.latin: Socios sibi ad id bellum Osismos, Lexovios, Namnetes, Ambiliatos, Morinos, Diablintes, Menapios adsciscunt; auxilia ex Britannia, quae contra eas regiones posita est, arcessunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Allies to themselves for that war the Osismi, Lexovii, Namnetes, Ambiliati, Morini, Diablintes, Menapii they admit; reinforcements from Britain, which opposite those regions placed is, they summon.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Allies to themselves for that war the Osismi, Lexovii, Namnetes, Ambiliati, Morini, Diablintes, Menapii they admit; reinforcements from Britain, which against those regions placed is, they summon.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They allied themselves for that war with the Osismi, Lexovii, Namnetes, Ambiliati, Morini, Diablintes, and Menapii; they also summoned reinforcements from Britain, which lies opposite those regions.

sentences.latin: Erant hae difficultates belli gerendi quas supra ostendimus, sed tamen multa Caesarem ad id bellum incitabant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: There were these difficulties of the war to be waged which above we showed, but nevertheless many things Caesar to that war were inciting:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There were these difficulties of war to be waged which above we have shown, but nevertheless many things Caesar to that war were inciting:
sentences.naturalTranslation: These were the difficulties of waging war that we have shown above, but nevertheless many factors incited Caesar to that war:

sentences.latin: iniuria retentorum equitum Romanorum, rebellio facta post deditionem, defectio datis obsidibus, tot civitatum coniuratio, in primis ne hac parte neglecta reliquae nationes sibi idem licere arbitrarentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the injury of the retained Roman knights, a rebellion made after surrender, a revolt after hostages having been given, of so many states a conspiracy, in the first things lest this part having been neglected the remaining nations to themselves the same to be allowed might think.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the outrage of the retained Roman knights, the rebellion made after surrender, the revolt after given hostages, of so many states the conspiracy, in the first place lest this part having been neglected the remaining nations to themselves the same to be allowed they might think.
sentences.naturalTranslation: the outrage of the detained Roman knights, the rebellion following their surrender, the revolt after hostages had been given, the conspiracy of so many states, and above all, the fear that if this region were overlooked, other nations might think they were allowed to do the same.

sentences.latin: Itaque cum intellegeret omnes fere Gallos novis rebus studere et ad bellum mobiliter celeriterque excitari, omnes autem homines natura libertati studere et condicionem servitutis odisse, prius quam plures civitates conspirarent, partiendum sibi ac latius distribuendum exercitum putavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so when he understood all almost Gauls for new things to be eager and to war easily and quickly to be excited, all moreover men by nature for liberty to be eager and the condition of slavery to hate, before more states might conspire, to be divided by him and more widely to be distributed the army he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so when he understood all nearly Gauls for new things to be eager and to war easily and quickly to be excited, all moreover men by nature for liberty to be eager and the condition of slavery to hate, before more states should conspire, to be divided by him and more widely to be distributed the army he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, understanding that almost all Gauls were eager for revolution and easily and quickly incited to warand that all men naturally desire liberty and hate the condition of slaveryhe decided he must divide and distribute his army more widely before more states could join the conspiracy.

sentences.latin: Itaque T. Labienum legatum in Treveros, qui proximi flumini Rheno sunt, cum equitatu mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so Titus Labienus the lieutenant into the Treveri, who nearest to the river Rhine are, with the cavalry he sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so T. Labienus the lieutenant into the Treveri, who nearest to the river Rhine are, with the cavalry he sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Accordingly, he sent the lieutenant Titus Labienus with the cavalry to the Treveri, who are closest to the river Rhine.

sentences.latin: Huic mandat, Remos reliquosque Belgas adeat atque in officio contineat Germanosque, qui auxilio a Belgis arcessiti dicebantur, si per vim navibus flumen transire conentur, prohibeat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this man he mandates, the Remi and remaining Belgians he should go to and in duty should hold and the Germans, who for help by the Belgians summoned were said, if through force by ships the river to cross they should try, he should prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this man he mandates, the Remi and remaining Belgians he should go to and in duty should hold and the Germans, who for help by the Belgians summoned were said, if through force by ships the river to cross they should try, he should prohibit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He instructed him to visit the Remi and the rest of the Belgae to keep them in their allegiance, and to prevent the Germanswho were said to have been summoned by the Belgae for helpif they should attempt to cross the river by force in ships.

sentences.latin: P. Crassum cum cohortibus legionariis XII et magno numero equitatus in Aquitaniam proficisci iubet, ne ex his nationibus auxilia in Galliam mittantur ac tantae nationes coniungantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Publius Crassus with cohorts legionary twelve and a great number of cavalry into Aquitania to set out he orders, lest from these nations reinforcements into Gaul be sent and so great nations be joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: P. Crassus with cohorts legionary 12 and a great number of cavalry into Aquitania to set out he orders, lest from these nations reinforcements into Gaul be sent and so great nations be joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered Publius Crassus to set out for Aquitania with twelve legionary cohorts and a large number of cavalry, to prevent reinforcements from being sent from those nations into Gaul and to keep such powerful tribes from uniting.

sentences.latin: Q. Titurium Sabinum legatum cum legionibus tribus in Venellos, Coriosolites Lexoviosque mittit, qui eam manum distinendam curet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quintus Titurius Sabinus the lieutenant with legions three into the Venelli, Coriosolites and Lexovii he sends, who that force to be kept apart should care for.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Q. Titurius Sabinus the lieutenant with legions three into the Venelli, Coriosolites and Lexovii he sends, who that band to be kept apart should care for.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent the lieutenant Quintus Titurius Sabinus with three legions among the Venelli, Coriosolites, and Lexovii, to ensure that their forces were kept separate.

sentences.latin: D. Brutum adulescentem classi Gallicisque navibus, quas ex Pictonibus et Santonis reliquisque pacatis regionibus convenire iusserat, praeficit et, cum primum possit, in Venetos proficisci iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Decimus Brutus the young man over the fleet and Gallic ships, which from the Pictones and Santoni and the rest of the pacified regions to assemble he had ordered, he puts in command and, as soon as he might be able, into the Veneti to set out he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Decimus Brutus the young man over the fleet and Gallic ships, which from the Pictones and Santoni and remaining pacified regions to assemble he had ordered, he puts in command and, when first he is able, into the Veneti to set out he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He put the young Decimus Brutus in command of the fleet and the Gallic ships, which he had ordered to assemble from the Pictones, the Santoni, and other pacified regions, and ordered him to set out against the Veneti as soon as possible.

sentences.latin: Ipse eo pedestribus copiis contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself to that place with infantry forces hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself thither with infantry forces hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself marched there with the infantry.

sentences.latin: Erant eius modi fere situs oppidorum ut posita in extremis lingulis promunturiisque neque pedibus aditum haberent, cum ex alto se aestus incitavisset, quod [bis] accidit semper horarum XII spatio, neque navibus, quod rursus minuente aestu naves in vadis adflictarentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Were of this kind generally the sites of the towns that placed on the ends of tongues and promontories neither by feet access they had, when from the deep itself the tide had incited, which [twice] happens always of hours 12 in the space, nor by ships, because again with the tide lessening the ships on the shallows would be damaged.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Were of this kind generally the sites of the towns that placed on the ends of tongues and promontories neither by feet access they had, when from the deep itself the tide had urged, which [twice] happens always of hours 12 in the space, nor by ships, because again with the tide lessening the ships in the shallows would be damaged.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The sites of the towns were generally such that, being situated on the ends of tongues of land and promontories, they had no access by foot when the tide rushed in from the deep (which happens twice every twelve hours), nor by ship, because when the tide ebbed again, the vessels would be damaged on the shoals.

sentences.latin: Ita utraque re oppidorum oppugnatio impediebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus by each thing the towns' siege was being hindered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus by each thing of the towns the storming was hindered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, for both reasons, the siege of the towns was obstructed.

sentences.latin: Ac si quando magnitudine operis forte superati, extruso mari aggere ac molibus atque his oppidi moenibus adaequatis, suis fortunis desperare coeperant, magno numero navium adpulso, cuius rei summam facultatem habebant, omnia sua deportabant seque in proxima oppida recipiebant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: And if ever by the magnitude of the work by chance overcome, with the sea shut out by a mound and dikes and these to the town's walls made equal, of their fortunes to despair they had begun, with a great number of ships brought to, of which thing the greatest supply they had, all their things they were carrying away and themselves into the nearest towns were withdrawing:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And if ever by the greatness of the work by chance overcome, with the sea shut out by a mound and dikes and these to the town's walls made equal, of their fortunes to despair they had begun, with a great number of ships brought to land, of which thing the greatest supply they had, all their things they would carry away and themselves into the nearest towns they would betake:
sentences.naturalTranslation: And if ever they were overcome by the scale of the siege workswhen the sea had been shut out by a mound and dikes and these were raised to the height of the town wallsand began to despair of their fortunes, they would bring up a great number of ships (of which they had an abundant supply), carry off all their property, and retreat to the nearest towns.

sentences.latin: ibi se rursus isdem oportunitatibus loci defendebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: there themselves again by the same advantages of the place they were defending.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: there themselves again by the same advantages of the place they would defend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There they would defend themselves again, using the same advantages of the terrain.

sentences.latin: Haec eo facilius magnam partem aestatis faciebant quod nostrae naves tempestatibus detinebantur summaque erat vasto atque aperto mari, magnis aestibus, raris ac prope nullis portibus difficultas navigandi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things by that more easily a great part of the summer they were doing because our ships by storms were being detained and greatest was on the vast and open sea, with great tides, with rare and almost no harbors the difficulty of navigating.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things by this more easily a great part of the summer they did because our ships by storms were detained and greatest was on the vast and open sea, with great tides, rare and nearly no harbors the difficulty of sailing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did this more easily for a large part of the summer because our ships were detained by storms, and the difficulty of navigation was extreme on that vast and open sea, with its high tides and few, if any, harbors.

sentences.latin: Namque ipsorum naves ad hunc modum factae armataeque erant: carinae aliquanto planiores quam nostrarum navium, quo facilius vada ac decessum aestus excipere possent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For indeed of themselves the ships to this manner made and equipped were: the hulls somewhat flatter than of our ships, by which more easily shallows and the ebb of the tide to take they might be able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For indeed of themselves the ships to this manner made and armed were: the hulls somewhat flatter than of our ships, by which more easily shallows and the ebb of the tide they could meet;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For their own ships were built and equipped in this way: the hulls were considerably flatter than those of our ships, so that they could more easily handle the shallows and the ebbing tide;

sentences.latin: prorae admodum erectae atque item puppes, ad magnitudinem fluctuum tempestatumque accommodatae;
sentences.referenceTranslation: the prows very much upright and likewise the sterns, to the magnitude of the waves and storms adapted;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the prows very much upright and likewise the sterns, to the magnitude of the waves and storms adapted;
sentences.naturalTranslation: the prows and sterns were very high, adapted to the size of the waves and storms;

sentences.latin: naves totae factae ex robore ad quamvis vim et contumeliam perferendam;
sentences.referenceTranslation: the ships entirely made from oak for whatever force and outrage to be endured;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the ships entirely made from oak for any force and outrage to be endured;
sentences.naturalTranslation: the ships were built entirely of oak to endure any force or violence;

sentences.latin: transtra ex pedalibus in altitudinem trabibus, confixa clavis ferreis digiti pollicis crassitudine;
sentences.referenceTranslation: the cross-beams [were] from foot-thick in height beams, fastened with nails iron of a finger thumb's thickness;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the cross-beams from foot-thick in height beams, fastened with nails iron of a thumb's thickness;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cross-beams were made of beams a foot thick and were fastened with iron nails as thick as a thumb;

sentences.latin: ancorae pro funibus ferreis catenis revinctae;
sentences.referenceTranslation: anchors instead of ropes with iron chains [were] fastened;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the anchors instead of ropes with iron chains bound;
sentences.naturalTranslation: the anchors were secured with iron chains instead of ropes;

sentences.latin: pelles pro velis alutaeque tenuiter confectae, [hae] sive propter inopiam lini atque eius usus inscientiam, sive eo, quod est magis veri simile, quod tantas tempestates Oceani tantosque impetus ventorum sustineri ac tanta onera navium regi velis non satis commode posse arbitrabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: skins instead of sails and leathers thinly prepared, [these] either because of lack of flax and of its use ignorance, or for that, which is more of truth similar, because so great storms of the Ocean and so great attacks of winds to be sustained and so great weights of ships to be guided by sails not sufficiently conveniently to be able they were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: skins instead of sails and leathers thinly prepared, [these] either on account of the lack of flax and of its use ignorance, or by that, which is more of truth similar, because such great storms of the Ocean and such great attacks of winds to be sustained and such great weights of ships to be ruled by sails not enough conveniently to be able they thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Skins and thinly dressed leather were used for sails, either because of a lack of flax and ignorance of its use, or more likely because they thought that sails could not withstand the great storms of the Ocean and the violent force of the winds, nor could such heavy ships be easily managed with them.

sentences.latin: Cum his navibus nostrae classi eius modi congressus erat ut una celeritate et pulsu remorum praestaret, reliqua pro loci natura, pro vi tempestatum illis essent aptiora et accommodatiora.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these ships to our fleet of this kind the encounter was that in only speed and stroke of oars it excelled, the remaining things according to the place's nature, according to the force of storms for those were more fit and more adapted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these ships for our fleet of this kind the encounter was that in only speed and the stroke of oars it excelled, the remaining things for the nature of the place, for the force of storms for them were more fit and more adapted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The encounter of our fleet with these ships was such that we excelled only in speed and the stroke of oars, while everything else, considering the nature of the place and the violence of the storms, was better suited and adapted to them.

sentences.latin: Neque enim iis nostrae rostro nocere poterant (tanta in iis erat firmitudo), neque propter altitudinem facile telum adigebatur, et eadem de causa minus commode copulis continebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For neither to them ours with the beak to harm were able (so great in them was the strength), nor because of height easily a weapon was being driven, and for the same cause less conveniently by grappling hooks they were being held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor for them ours with the beak to harm were able (so great in them was the strength), nor on account of the height easily a weapon was driven, and for the same cause less conveniently by grappling-hooks they were held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our ships could not damage them with their beaks (so great was their strength), nor could a weapon be easily thrown because of their height, and for the same reason, they were less easily held by grappling hooks.

sentences.latin: Accedebat ut, cum [saevire ventus coepisset et] se vento dedissent, et tempestatem ferrent facilius et in vadis consisterent tutius et ab aestu relictae nihil saxa et cotes timerent; quarum rerum omnium nostris navibus casus erat extimescendus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was added that, when [to rage the wind had begun and] themselves to the wind they had given, both the storm they bore more easily and in the shallows they stood more safely and by the tide left behind nothing rocks and reefs they feared; of which things all by our ships the risk was to be greatly feared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was added that, when [to rage the wind had begun and] themselves to the wind they had given, both the storm they bore more easily and in the shallows they stood more safely and by the tide left behind nothing the rocks and reefs they feared; of which things all for our ships the risk was to be greatly feared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, when the wind began to rage and they ran before it, they weathered the storm more easily, anchored more safely in the shallows, and when left by the tide, had no fear of rocks or reefs; all of which circumstances were greatly to be feared by our ships.

sentences.latin: Compluribus expugnatis oppidis Caesar, ubi intellexit frustra tantum laborem sumi neque hostium fugam captis oppidis reprimi neque iis noceri posse, statuit expectandam classem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several having been stormed towns Caesar, when he understood in vain so great labor to be taken and neither the enemies' flight by captured towns to be checked nor to them to be harmed to be able, he decided to be waited for the fleet.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Several having been stormed towns Caesar, when he understood in vain so much labor to be taken nor the enemies' flight by captured towns to be restrained nor them to be harmed to be able, decided to be waited for the fleet.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After several towns had been stormed, Caesar, realizing that so much effort was being spent in vain and that the enemy's flight could not be checked by capturing towns nor could they be harmed, decided that he must wait for the fleet.

sentences.latin: Quae ubi convenit ac primum ab hostibus visa est, circiter CCXX naves eorum paratissimae atque omni genere armorum ornatissimae profectae ex portu nostris adversae constiterunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when it assembled and first by the enemies was seen, about 220 ships of them most prepared and with every kind of arms most equipped having set out from the harbor against ours they stood;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when it assembled and first by the enemies was seen, about 220 ships of them most prepared and with every kind of arms most equipped having set out from the harbor against ours stood;
sentences.naturalTranslation: As soon as the fleet assembled and was seen by the enemy, about 220 of their ships, fully prepared and equipped with every kind of weapon, sailed out of the harbor and took up a position opposite ours;

sentences.latin: neque satis Bruto, qui classi praeerat, vel tribunis militum centurionibusque, quibus singulae naves erant attributae, constabat quid agerent aut quam rationem pugnae insisterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: neither sufficiently to Brutus, who the fleet was in command of, or to the tribunes of soldiers and centurions, to whom individual ships had been assigned, it was clear what they should do or what plan of battle they should adopt.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor enough to Brutus, who over the fleet was in command, or to the tribunes of soldiers and centurions, to whom individual ships had been assigned, was it clear what they should do or what plan of battle they should adopt.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was not clear to Brutus, who commanded the fleet, nor to the military tribunes and centurions assigned to individual ships, what they should do or what tactic of battle they should adopt.

sentences.latin: Rostro enim noceri non posse cognoverant; turribus autem excitatis tamen has altitudo puppium ex barbaris navibus superabat, ut neque ex inferiore loco satis commode tela adigi possent et missa a Gallis gravius acciderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the beak for to be harmed not to be able they had learned; with towers however having been raised nevertheless these the height of the sterns from the barbarian ships was overtopping, so that neither from a lower place sufficiently conveniently weapons to be driven were able and those sent by the Gauls more heavily fell.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the beak for to be harmed not to be able they had learned; with towers however raised nevertheless these the height of the sterns from the barbarian ships surpassed, so that neither from a lower place enough conveniently weapons to be driven were able and those sent by the Gauls more heavily fell.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For they had learned that no damage could be done with the beak; moreover, even when towers were erected, the height of the sterns of the barbarian ships still overtopped them, so that weapons could not be thrown effectively from the lower position, while those thrown by the Gauls fell with greater force.

sentences.latin: Una erat magno usui res praeparata a nostris, falces praeacutae insertae adfixaeque longuriis, non absimili forma muralium falcium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One was for great use a thing prepared by our men, hooks sharpened inserted and fixed to long poles, not in dissimilar form of mural hooks.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One was for great use thing prepared by our (men), hooks sharpened-at-the-end inserted and fixed to long poles, not in dissimilar form of mural hooks.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One device prepared by our men was of great service: sharpened hooks inserted into and fixed to long poles, not unlike the shape of mural hooks.

sentences.latin: His cum funes qui antemnas ad malos destinabant comprehensi adductique erant, navigio remis incitato praerumpebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these when the ropes which the yards to the masts were binding were grasped and pulled, the ship by oars having been incited they were broken off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these when the ropes which the yards to the masts were binding were caught and pulled, the vessel by oars being urged on they were broken off.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the ropes that fastened the yards to the masts were caught and pulled by these hooks, they were snapped by driving the ship forward with oars.

sentences.latin: Quibus abscisis antemnae necessario concidebant, ut, cum omnis Gallicis navibus spes in velis armamentisque consisteret, his ereptis omnis usus navium uno tempore eriperetur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which having been cut the yards necessarily fell down, so that, since all for the Gallic ships hope in sails and rigging consisted, these having been snatched away all use of the ships at one time was snatched away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been cut the yards necessarily fell down, so that, since all for the Gallic ships hope in sails and rigging consisted, these having been snatched away all use of the ships at one time was snatched away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these were cut, the yards necessarily fell; since all the Gallic ships' hope depended on their sails and rigging, the loss of these instantly rendered the ships useless.

sentences.latin: Reliquum erat certamen positum in virtute, qua nostri milites facile superabant, atque eo magis quod in conspectu Caesaris atque omnis exercitus res gerebatur, ut nullum paulo fortius factum latere posset;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Remaining was the contest placed in valor, in which our soldiers easily were surpassing, and by that more because in the sight of Caesar and of all the army the thing was being carried on, so that no a little braver deed to lie hidden was able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Remaining was the contest placed in valor, in which our soldiers easily were surpassing, and by that more because in the sight of Caesar and of all the army the thing was being done, so that no a little braver deed to be hidden was able;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The rest of the contest depended on valor, in which our soldiers easily excelled, all the more so because the action took place in the sight of Caesar and the whole army, so that no deed of even slight bravery could go unnoticed.

sentences.latin: omnes enim colles ac loca superiora, unde erat propinquus despectus in mare, ab exercitu tenebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: all for the hills and places higher, from where was a near view into the sea, by the army were being held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: all for the hills and places higher, from where was a near view onto the sea, by the army were being held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For all the hills and high ground, from which there was a close view of the sea, were occupied by the army.

sentences.latin: Deiectis, ut diximus, antemnis, cum singulas binae ac ternae naves circumsteterant, milites summa vi transcendere in hostium naves contendebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been cast down, as we said, the yards, when individual ships two and three ships had surrounded, the soldiers with greatest force to climb over into the of the enemies ships were striving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been cast down, as we said, the yards, when individual (ships) two and three ships had surrounded, the soldiers with greatest force to climb over into the of the enemies ships were striving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the yards were brought down, as we mentioned, and two or three of our ships had surrounded each of theirs, our soldiers strove with all their might to board the enemy vessels.

sentences.latin: Quod postquam barbari fieri animadverterunt, expugnatis compluribus navibus, cum ei rei nullum reperiretur auxilium, fuga salutem petere contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which after the barbarians to happen noticed, having been captured several ships, since for that thing no was found help, by flight safety to seek they strove.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which after the barbarians to happen noticed, having been captured several ships, since for that thing no was found help, by flight safety to seek they hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the barbarians noticed this happening and several ships had been captured, finding no remedy for the situation, they attempted to seek safety in flight.

sentences.latin: Ac iam conversis in eam partem navibus quo ventus ferebat, tanta subito malacia ac tranquillitas extitit ut se ex loco movere non possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And already having been turned into that part the ships where the wind was carrying, so great suddenly a calm and stillness stood forth that themselves from the place to move they were not able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And now having been turned into that part the ships where the wind was carrying, so great suddenly a calm and stillness arose that themselves from the place to move they were not able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But just as they had turned their ships in the direction the wind was blowing, a sudden and complete calm came on, so that they could not move from the spot.

sentences.latin: Quae quidem res ad negotium conficiendum maximae fuit oportunitati:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which indeed thing for the business to be finished of greatest was for opportunity:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which indeed thing for the business to be finished of greatest was for opportunity:
sentences.naturalTranslation: This circumstance was extremely fortunate for finishing the business:

sentences.latin: nam singulas nostri consectati expugnaverunt, ut perpaucae ex omni numero noctis interventu ad terram per venirent, cum ab hora fere IIII usque ad solis occasum pugnaretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: for individual ships our men having followed captured, so that very few from all the number by the night's intervention to land arrived, since from the hour nearly fourth until to of the sun the setting it was being fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: for individual (ships) our (men) having followed captured, so that very few from all the number by the night's intervention to land arrived, since from the hour nearly fourth until to of the sun setting it was being fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: for our men pursued and captured the ships one by one, so that very few out of the whole number reached land when night intervened, the battle having lasted from about ten in the morning until sunset.

sentences.latin: Quo proelio bellum Venetorum totiusque orae maritimae confectum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which battle the war of the Veneti and of the whole maritime coast finished was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which battle the war of the Veneti and of all the coast maritime finished was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With this battle, the war against the Veneti and the entire sea coast was brought to an end.

sentences.latin: Nam cum omnis iuventus, omnes etiam gravioris aetatis in quibus aliquid consilii aut dignitatis fuit eo convenerant, tum navium quod ubique fuerat in unum locum coegerant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For since all the youth, all also of more serious age in whom some of counsel or of dignity was thither had assembled, then of ships what everywhere had been into one place they had collected;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For since all the youth, all also of more serious age in whom anything of counsel or of dignity was there had assembled, then of ships what everywhere had been into one place they had collected;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For since all the young men, and even all those of more mature age who possessed any wisdom or status, had assembled there, they had also collected in one place every ship they had from everywhere.

sentences.latin: quibus amissis reliqui neque quo se reciperent neque quem ad modum oppida defenderent habebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which having been lost the remaining neither whither themselves they might retreat nor in what manner the towns they might defend were having.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which having been lost the remaining neither where themselves they might retreat nor in what manner the towns they might defend were having.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these were lost, the survivors had nowhere to retreat and no way to defend their towns.

sentences.latin: Itaque se suaque omnia Caesari dediderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore themselves and their all things to Caesar they surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so themselves and their all (things) to Caesar they surrendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, they surrendered themselves and all their possessions to Caesar.

sentences.latin: In quos eo gravius Caesar vindicandum statuit quo diligentius in reliquum tempus a barbaris ius legatorum conservaretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Against whom by so much more severely Caesar to be punished decided by how much more carefully for the remaining time by the barbarians the right of ambassadors might be preserved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Against whom by that more severely Caesar to be punished decided by which more carefully for the remaining time by the barbarians the right of ambassadors might be preserved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar decided that they should be punished all the more severely so that, in the future, the rights of ambassadors might be more carefully respected by barbarians.

sentences.latin: Itaque omni senatu necato reliquos sub corona vendidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore all the senate having been killed the rest under the crown he sold.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so all the senate having been killed the rest under the crown he sold.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, after executing the entire senate, he sold the rest of the population into slavery.

sentences.latin: Dum haec in Venetis geruntur, Q. Titurius Sabinus cum iis copiis quas a Caesare acceperat in fines Venellorum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things among the Veneti are being done, Q. Titurius Sabinus with those forces which from Caesar he had received into the borders of the Venelli arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these (things) among the Veneti are being done, Q. Titurius Sabinus with those forces which from Caesar he had received into the borders of the Venelli arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these events were taking place among the Veneti, Quintus Titurius Sabinus arrived in the territory of the Venelli with the troops he had received from Caesar.

sentences.latin: His praeerat Viridovix ac summam imperii tenebat earum omnium civitatum quae defecerant, ex quibus exercitum [magnasque copias] coegerat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over these was in command Viridovix and the height of command was holding of those all states which had revolted, from which an army [and great forces] he had collected;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These he was in command of Viridovix and the highest of power was holding of those all states which had revolted, from which an army [and great forces] he had collected;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Viridovix was in command of these people and held supreme authority over all the states that had revolted, from which he had raised an army and large forces.

sentences.latin: atque his paucis diebus Aulerci Eburovices Lexoviique, senatu suo interfecto quod auctores belli esse nolebant, portas clauserunt seque cum Viridovice coniunxerunt;
