sentences.referenceTranslation: and in these few days the Aulerci Eburovices and the Lexovii, their senate having been killed because authors of the war to be they were unwilling, the gates closed and themselves with Viridovix joined;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and in these few days the Aulerci Eburovices and the Lexovii, the senate their own having been killed because authors of the war to be they were unwilling, the gates closed and themselves with Viridovix joined;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Within these few days, the Aulerci Eburovices and the Lexovii, having executed their senate because they refused to authorize the war, closed their gates and joined Viridovix.

sentences.latin: magnaque praeterea multitudo undique ex Gallia perditorum hominum latronumque convenerat, quos spes praedandi studiumque bellandi ab agri cultura et cotidiano labore revocabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and a great besides multitude from everywhere out of Gaul of ruined men and of robbers had assembled, whom the hope of plundering and the eagerness of warring from agriculture and daily labor was calling away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and a great besides multitude from everywhere out of Gaul of desperate men and of robbers had assembled, whom the hope of plundering and the zeal of warring from agriculture and daily labor was calling away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In addition, a large number of desperate men and bandits had gathered from all over Gaul, drawn away from farming and daily labor by the hope of plunder and a passion for war.

sentences.latin: Sabinus idoneo omnibus rebus loco castris sese tenebat, cum Viridovix contra eum duorum milium spatio consedisset cotidieque productis copiis pugnandi potestatem faceret, ut iam non solum hostibus in contemptionem Sabinus veniret, sed etiam nostrorum militum vocibus non nihil carperetur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sabinus in a suitable for all things place in camp himself was holding, when Viridovix against him at a distance of two miles had settled and daily with led out forces of fighting opportunity was making, so that now not only to the enemies into contempt Sabinus came, but also by our soldiers' voices not a little he was being criticized;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sabinus in a suitable for all things place for the camp himself was holding, when Viridovix against him of two miles in space had settled and daily with led out forces of fighting the power was making, so that now not only to the enemies into contempt Sabinus was coming, but also by our soldiers' voices not nothing he was being carped at;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Sabinus kept himself within his camp in a location suitable in every respect, while Viridovix had taken up a position two miles away and was daily leading out his troops to offer battle, so that Sabinus now not only fell into contempt among the enemy but was also being criticized quite a bit by the remarks of our own soldiers;

sentences.latin: tantamque opinionem timoris praebuit ut iam ad vallum castrorum hostes accedere auderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and so great an impression of fear he provided that now to the rampart of the camp the enemies to approach dared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so great an impression of fear he provided that now to the rampart of the camp the enemies to approach were daring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He created such a strong impression of fear that the enemy now dared to approach the very rampart of the camp.

sentences.latin: Id ea de causa faciebat quod cum tanta multitudine hostium, praesertim eo absente qui summam imperii teneret, nisi aequo loco aut oportunitate aliqua data legato dimicandum non existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This for that reason he was doing because with so great a multitude of enemies, especially him being absent who the highest of command held, unless on favorable ground or some opportunity given he did not think it must be fought by a legate.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This for that reason he was doing because with so great a multitude of enemies, especially with him absent who the supreme command held, unless on level ground or with opportunity some given by a lieutenant it must be fought not he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He did this because he did not think a legate should fight against such a large number of enemiesespecially in the absence of the commander-in-chiefunless on favorable ground or if some special opportunity presented itself.

sentences.latin: Hac confirmata opinione timoris idoneum quendam hominem et callidum deligit, Gallum, ex iis quos auxilii causa secum habebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With this confirmed impression of fear a suitable certain man and shrewd he chooses, a Gaul, from those whom for the sake of help with himself he was having.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been confirmed impression of fear a suitable certain man and clever he chooses, a Gaul, from those whom for the sake of help with himself he was having.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once this impression of fear was established, he chose a certain suitable and shrewd man, a Gaul, from among those he had with him as auxiliaries.

sentences.latin: Huic magnis praemiis pollicitationibusque persuadet uti ad hostes transeat, et quid fieri velit edocet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This one with great rewards and promises he persuades that to the enemies he should go over, and what to be done he wants he explains.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This man with great rewards and promises he persuades that to the enemies he should cross over, and what to be done he wishes he thoroughly teaches.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He persuaded this man with great rewards and promises to go over to the enemy, and instructed him on what he wanted done.

sentences.latin: Qui ubi pro perfuga ad eos venit, timorem Romanorum proponit, quibus angustiis ipse Caesar a Venetis prematur docet,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when as a deserter to them he came, the fear of the Romans he sets forth, by what difficulties himself Caesar by the Veneti is pressed he teaches,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who when as a deserter to them he came, the fear of the Romans he sets forth, by what straits himself Caesar by the Veneti is pressed he teaches,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this man came to them as a deserter, he described the Romans' fear and explained the difficulties Caesar himself was facing from the Veneti,

sentences.latin: neque longius abesse quin proxima nocte Sabinus clam ex castris exercitum educat et ad Caesarem auxilii ferendi causa proficiscatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and that it was not further away but that on the next night Sabinus secretly from the camp the army should lead out and to Caesar for the sake of help bringing should set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not further to be away but that on the next night Sabinus secretly from the camp the army should lead out and to Caesar for the sake of help bringing should set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and he added that Sabinus was on the verge of leading his army out of camp secretly the following night to set out to bring help to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi auditum est, conclamant omnes occasionem negotii bene gerendi amittendam non esse:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when heard it was, they shout out all the opportunity of the business well of conducting to be lost not to be:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when heard it was, they shout out all the opportunity of the business well of conducting to be lost not to be:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was heard, they all shouted that the opportunity for a successful operation must not be lost:

sentences.latin: ad castra iri oportere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to the camp to be gone it was necessary.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to the camp to be gone it was necessary.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they insisted that they should march on the camp.

sentences.latin: Multae res ad hoc consilium Gallos hortabantur: superiorum dierum Sabini cunctatio, perfugae confirmatio, inopia cibariorum, cui rei parum diligenter ab iis erat provisum, spes Venetici belli, et quod fere libenter homines id quod volunt credunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Many things to this plan the Gauls were encouraging: of the previous days Sabinus's delay, the deserter's confirmation, the lack of provisions, for which thing too little carefully by them it had been provided, the hope of the Venetian war, and because generally gladly men that which they want they believe.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Many things to this plan the Gauls were encouraging: of the previous days Sabinus's hesitation, the deserter's confirmation, the lack of provisions, for which thing too little diligently by them it had been provided, the hope of the Venetian war, and because generally gladly men that which they want they believe.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Many factors encouraged the Gauls in this plan: Sabinus's hesitation during the previous days, the deserter's confirmation, the lack of provisions (for which they had made insufficient preparation), the hope of success in the Venetian war, and the fact that men generally believe what they want to believe.

sentences.latin: His rebus adducti non prius Viridovicem reliquosque duces ex concilio dimittunt quam ab iis sit concessum arma uti capiant et ad castra contendant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things influenced not sooner Viridovix and the remaining leaders from the council they dismiss than by them it was granted arms that they take up and to the camp they hasten.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things led they not sooner Viridovix and the remaining leaders from the council dismiss than by them it was granted arms that they should take and to the camp should hasten.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by these factors, they did not allow Viridovix and the other leaders to leave the council until they had granted permission for them to take up arms and march on the camp.

sentences.latin: Qua re concessa laeti, ut explorata victoria, sarmentis virgultisque collectis, quibus fossas Romanorum compleant, ad castra pergunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing granted joyful, as if with victory ascertained, with brushwood and twigs collected, with which the ditches of the Romans they might fill, to the camp they proceed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing granted joyful, as if with explored victory, brushwood and twigs collected, with which the ditches of the Romans they might fill, to the camp they proceed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once this was granted, they set out for the camp in high spirits, as if victory were already certain, carrying bundles of brushwood and twigs to fill in the Roman trenches.

sentences.latin: Locus erat castrorum editus et paulatim ab imo acclivis circiter passus mille.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The place was of the camp elevated and gradually from the bottom sloping about paces a thousand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The place was of the camp elevated and gradually from the bottom sloping upward about paces a thousand.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The site of the camp was on high ground, sloping gradually upward from the base for about a thousand paces.

sentences.latin: Huc magno cursu contenderunt, ut quam minimum spatii ad se colligendos armandosque Romanis daretur, exanimatique pervenerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hither with great speed they hastened, so that as little as possible of space for themselves to be collected and armed to the Romans might be given, and out of breath they arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To here with a great run they hastened, so that as little as possible of space for themselves collecting and arming to the Romans might be given, and exhausted they arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They rushed to this spot at great speed to give the Romans as little time as possible to assemble and arm themselves, arriving completely exhausted.

sentences.latin: Sabinus suos hortatus cupientibus signum dat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sabinus his men having encouraged to them desiring the signal gives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sabinus his own having encouraged to the desiring ones the signal gives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After encouraging his men, Sabinus gave the signal to those who were already eager for battle.

sentences.latin: Impeditis hostibus propter ea quae ferebant onera subito duabus portis eruptionem fieri iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the enemies hindered on account of those which they were carrying burdens suddenly from two gates a sally to be made he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the enemies hindered because of those which they were carrying loads suddenly from two gates a sally to be made he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the enemy were hampered by the loads they were carrying, he suddenly ordered a breakout from two gates.

sentences.latin: Factum est oportunitate loci, hostium inscientia ac defatigatione, virtute militum et superiorum pugnarum exercitatione, ut ne unum quidem nostrorum impetum ferrent ac statim terga verterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was done by the advantage of the place, by the enemies' ignorance and exhaustion, by the courage of the soldiers and of previous battles the training, that not even one indeed of our men's attack they bore and immediately backs they turned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was done by the opportunity of the place, the enemies' ignorance and exhaustion, the valor of the soldiers and of previous battles the practice, that not one indeed of our own attack they might bear and immediately backs they turned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Due to the advantage of the position, the enemy's lack of skill and exhaustion, and the courage and training of our soldiers from previous battles, the enemy could not withstand even a single charge of our men and immediately turned and fled.

sentences.latin: Quos impeditos integris viribus milites nostri consecuti magnum numerum eorum occiderunt; reliquos equites consectati paucos, qui ex fuga evaserant, reliquerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom hindered with fresh strength soldiers our having followed a great number of them killed; the rest the cavalry having pursued few, who from flight had escaped, they left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom hindered with fresh strengths soldiers our having followed a great number of them killed; the remaining the cavalry having pursued a few, who from flight had escaped, they left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our soldiers followed the hampered enemy with fresh strength and killed a great number of them; the cavalry pursued the rest and left only a few who had managed to escape the rout.

sentences.latin: Sic uno tempore et de navali pugna Sabinus et de Sabini victoria Caesar est certior factus, civitatesque omnes se statim Titurio dediderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus at one time both about the naval battle Sabinus and about Sabinus's victory Caesar was more certain made, and the states all themselves immediately to Titurius surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus at one time both about the naval battle Sabinus and about Sabinus's victory Caesar was more certain made, and states all themselves immediately to Titurius surrendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, at the same time, Sabinus was informed of the naval battle and Caesar of Sabinus's victory, and all the states immediately surrendered to Titurius.

sentences.latin: Nam ut ad bella suscipienda Gallorum alacer ac promptus est animus, sic mollis ac minime resistens ad calamitates ferendas mens eorum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For as to wars to be undertaken of the Gauls eager and ready is the spirit, so soft and least resisting to calamities to be borne the mind of them is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For as to wars to be undertaken of the Gauls eager and ready is the mind, so soft and least resisting to calamities to be borne the mind of them is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For just as the Gallic spirit is quick and eager to undertake wars, their minds are equally weak and lack the resilience to endure disasters.

sentences.latin: Eodem fere tempore P. Crassus., cum in Aquitaniam pervenisset, quae [pars], ut ante dictum est, [et regionum latitudine et multitudine hominum] tertia pars Galliae est [aestimanda], cum intellegeret in iis locis sibi bellum gerendum ubi paucis ante annis L. Valerius Praeconinus legatus exercitu pulso interfectus esset atque unde L. Manlius proconsul impedimentis amissis profugisset, non mediocrem sibi diligentiam adhibendam intellegebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At almost the same time P. Crassus, when into Aquitania he had arrived, which part, as before it has been said, both by the extent of regions and by the multitude of men the third part of Gaul is to be estimated, when he understood in those places by him war was to be waged where a few before years L. Valerius Praeconinus the legate his army having been routed had been killed and from where L. Manlius the proconsul his baggage having been lost had fled, not a moderate to himself diligence to be applied he was understanding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At almost the same time P. Crassus, when into Aquitania he had arrived, which part, as before said is, both by regions' width and multitude of men third part of Gaul is to be estimated, when he understood in those places for himself war to be waged where a few before years L. Valerius Praeconinus legate army having been beaten had been killed and from where L. Manlius proconsul baggage having been lost had fled, not mediocre for himself diligence to be applied he was understanding.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At about the same time, Publius Crassus arrived in Aquitania. This region, as previously mentioned, is considered a third of Gaul in terms of both its geographical extent and its population. Realizing that he had to wage war in a place where, a few years earlier, the legate Lucius Valerius Praeconinus had been defeated and killed, and from which the proconsul Lucius Manlius had fled after losing his baggage, Crassus understood that he needed to exercise extraordinary care.

sentences.latin: Itaque re frumentaria provisa, auxiliis equitatuque comparato, multis praeterea viris fortibus Tolosa et Carcasone et Narbone, quae sunt civitates Galliae provinciae finitimae, ex his regionibus nominatim evocatis, in Sotiatium fines exercitum introduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so the grain supply having been provided for, reinforcements and cavalry having been prepared, many besides brave men from Tolosa and Carcaso and Narbo, which are states of the Gallic province neighboring, from these regions by name having been called out, into the Sotiates' borders his army he led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore grain matter having been provided for, reinforcements and cavalry having been prepared, many besides men brave from Toulouse and Carcassonne and Narbonne, which are states of the Gallic province neighboring, from these regions by name having been called out, into Sotiates' borders army he led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, after securing the grain supply and organizing reinforcements and cavalry, he personally summoned many brave men from Tolosa, Carcaso, and Narbostates in the Gallic province bordering the regionand led his army into the territory of the Sotiates.

sentences.latin: Cuius adventu cognito Sotiates magnis copiis coactis, equitatuque, quo plurimum valebant, in itinere agmen nostrum adorti primum equestre proelium commiserunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whose arrival having been learned the Sotiates great forces having been collected, and cavalry, in which most they were strong, on the march the column our having attacked first a cavalry battle they joined,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whose arrival having been known Sotiates great forces having been collected, and cavalry, in which most they were strong, on the march column our having attacked first cavalry battle they joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning of his arrival, the Sotiates gathered large forces and, using their cavalrytheir strongest armattacked our column on the march and initiated a cavalry engagement.

sentences.latin: deinde equitatu suo pulso atque insequentibus nostris subito pedestres copias, quas in convalle in insidiis conlocaverant, ostenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: then their cavalry having been beaten and following our men suddenly infantry forces, which in a valley in ambush they had placed, they showed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: then cavalry their own having been beaten and following our [men] suddenly infantry forces, which in a valley in ambush they had placed, they showed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, after their cavalry had been driven back and our men were in pursuit, they suddenly revealed their infantry forces, which they had hidden in ambush in a valley.

sentences.latin: Hi nostros disiectos adorti proelium renovarunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These our men scattered having attacked the battle they renewed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These our [men] scattered having attacked battle they renewed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These troops attacked our scattered soldiers and renewed the battle.

sentences.latin: Pugnatum est diu atque acriter, cum Sotiates superioribus victoriis freti in sua virtute totius Aquitaniae salutem positam putarent, nostri autem quid sine imperatore et sine reliquis legionibus adulescentulo duce efficere possent perspici cuperent; tandem confecti vulneribus hostes terga verterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was fought long and fiercely, since the Sotiates on previous victories relying in their own valor of all Aquitania the safety placed they thought, our men however what without a commander and without the remaining legions with a very young leader they could accomplish to be seen they desired; at last exhausted by wounds the enemies their backs turned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was fought long and fiercely, since Sotiates previous victories relying on in their own valor of all Aquitania safety placed they thought, our [men] however what without commander and without remaining legions with a young man leader to effect they were able to be seen they were desiring; finally exhausted by wounds enemies backs they turned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The battle was long and fierce; the Sotiates, emboldened by past victories, believed the safety of all Aquitania rested on their courage, while our men were eager to see what they could achieve under a very young leader without their commander-in-chief or the other legions. Finally, exhausted by wounds, the enemy turned and fled.

sentences.latin: Quorum magno numero interfecto Crassus ex itinere oppidum Sotiatium oppugnare coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom a great number having been killed Crassus from the march the town of the Sotiates to besiege began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom great number having been killed Crassus from the march town of Sotiates to besiege began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a great number of them were killed, Crassus immediately began to besiege the town of the Sotiates.

sentences.latin: Quibus fortiter resistentibus vineas turresque egit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who bravely resisting sheds and towers he moved forward.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom bravely resisting mantlets and towers he moved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since they resisted bravely, he moved forward mantlets and siege towers.

sentences.latin: Illi alias eruptione temptata, alias cuniculis ad aggerem vineasque actis (cuius rei sunt longe peritissimi Aquitani, propterea quod multis locis apud eos aerariae secturaeque sunt), ubi diligentia nostrorum nihil his rebus profici posse intellexerunt, legatos ad Crassum mittunt seque in deditionem ut recipiat petunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They at one time a sortie having been attempted, at another time by mines to the mound and sheds driven (of which thing are by far most skilled the Aquitanians, because in many places among them copper mines and excavations are), when by the diligence of our men nothing by these things to be accomplished could they understood, ambassadors to Crassus they send and themselves into surrender that he receive they beg.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They at one time sortie having been attempted, at another time mines to the rampart and mantlets having been driven (of which thing are by far most skilled Aquitanians, because in many places among them copper mines and pits are), when diligence of our [men] nothing by these things to be profited to be able they understood, legates to Crassus they send and themselves into surrender that he receive they ask.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having attempted a sortie at one time and driven mines toward the rampart and mantlets at anotheran art in which the Aquitanians are by far the most skilled because of the many copper mines and quarries in their territorythey realized that our men's vigilance made these efforts futile; consequently, they sent envoys to Crassus and requested that he accept their surrender.

sentences.latin: Qua re impetrata arma tradere iussi faciunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been granted arms to hand over having been ordered they do.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been obtained arms to hand over ordered they do.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this request was granted, they obeyed the order to hand over their weapons.

sentences.latin: Atque in eam rem omnium nostrorum intentis animis alia ex parte oppidi Adiatunnus, qui summam imperii tenebat, cum DC devotis, quos illi soldurios appellant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: And into that matter of all our [men] intent minds from another part of the town Adiatunnus, who the highest of command was holding, with 600 devoted [men], whom those [people] soldurii call,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And in that matter of all our [men] intent minds from another part of town Adiatunnus, who supreme of command was holding, with 600 devoted [men], whom those soldurii call,
sentences.naturalTranslation: While the attention of all our men was focused on that matter, Adiatunnus, who held supreme command, emerged from another part of the town with 600 devoted followers, whom they call 'soldurii.'

sentences.latin: quorum haec est condicio, ut omnibus in vita commodis una cum iis fruantur quorum se amicitiae dediderint, si quid his per vim accidat, aut eundem casum una ferant aut sibi mortem consciscant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom this is the condition, that all in life advantages together with those they enjoy of whom themselves to friendship they have surrendered, if anything to these through violence should happen, either the same fate together they bear or for themselves death they resolve upon;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom this is condition, that all in life comforts together with those they enjoy of whom themselves to friendship they have given, if anything to these by violence should happen, either same fate together they bear or for themselves death they resolve;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their condition of service is this: they enjoy all the benefits of life together with those to whose friendship they have committed themselves; if anything violent happens to these leaders, they either share the same fate or commit suicide.

sentences.latin: neque adhuc hominum memoria repertus est quisquam qui, eo interfecto cuius se amicitiae devovisset, mortem recusaret---
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor yet in human memory found has been anyone who, that [one] having been killed to whose friendship himself he had devoted, death refused
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor yet of men memory found has been anyone who, him having been killed of whose himself to friendship he had devoted, death refused---
sentences.naturalTranslation: And within human memory, no one has yet been found who refused to die after the person to whose friendship he had devoted himself was killed.

sentences.latin: cum his Adiatunnus eruptionem facere conatus clamore ab ea parte munitionis sublato cum ad arma milites concurrissent vehementerque ibi pugnatum esset, repulsus in oppidum tamen uti eadem deditionis condicione uteretur a Crasso impetravit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: with these Adiatunnus a sortie to make having attempted a shout from that part of the fortification having been raised when to arms the soldiers had run together and fiercely there it had been fought, driven back into the town nevertheless that the same of surrender condition he might use from Crassus he obtained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: with these Adiatunnus sortie to make having tried shout from that part of fortification having been raised when to arms soldiers had run together and fiercely there it had been fought, driven back into town however that same of surrender condition he might use from Crassus he obtained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Adiatunnus attempted to make a sortie with these men, but when a shout was raised from that part of the fortification and our soldiers rushed to arms, a fierce battle ensued; although he was driven back into the town, he nevertheless obtained permission from Crassus to accept the same terms of surrender.

sentences.latin: Armis obsidibusque acceptis, Crassus in fines Vocatium et Tarusatium profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Arms and hostages having been received, Crassus into the borders of the Vocates and Tarusates set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Arms and hostages having been received, Crassus into borders of Vocates and Tarusates set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After receiving arms and hostages, Crassus set out for the territory of the Vocates and the Tarusates.

sentences.latin: Tum vero barbari commoti, quod oppidum et natura loci et manu munitum paucis diebus quibus eo ventum erat expugnatum cognoverant, legatos quoque versus dimittere, coniurare, obsides inter se dare, copias parare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then indeed the barbarians moved, because a town both by nature of place and by hand fortified in a few days in which there it had been come captured they had learned, ambassadors in every direction to send, to conspire, hostages among themselves to give, forces to prepare they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then indeed barbarians moved, because town both by nature of place and by hand fortified in few days in which there it had been come had been stormed they had learned, legates everywhere to send, to conspire, hostages among themselves to give, forces to prepare they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then indeed the barbarians were alarmed because they learned that a town fortified both by its natural position and by hand had been captured within a few days of the Romans' arrival; they began to send envoys in every direction, to form a league, to exchange hostages, and to prepare their forces.

sentences.latin: Mittuntur etiam ad eas civitates legati quae sunt citerioris Hispaniae finitimae Aquitaniae: inde auxilia ducesque arcessuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Are sent also to those states ambassadors which are of hither Spain neighboring to Aquitania: from there reinforcements and leaders are summoned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They are sent also to those states legates which are of hither Spain neighboring to Aquitania: from there reinforcements and leaders are summoned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Envoys were also sent to those states of Hither Spain that border Aquitania, and reinforcements and leaders were summoned from there.

sentences.latin: Quorum adventu magna cum auctoritate et magna [cum] hominum multitudine bellum gerere conantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whose arrival with great authority and with a great of men multitude war to wage they attempt.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom by arrival great with authority and great with of men multitude war to wage they attempt.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon their arrival, the barbarians attempted to wage war with great prestige and a large number of men.

sentences.latin: Duces vero ii deliguntur qui una cum Q. Sertorio omnes annos fuerant summamque scientiam rei militaris habere existimabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Leaders indeed those are chosen who together with Q. Sertorius all the years had been and the highest knowledge of thing military to have were thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Leaders indeed those are chosen who together with Q. Sertorius all years had been and highest knowledge of matter military to have were thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For leaders, they chose those who had served with Quintus Sertorius throughout his campaigns and were believed to possess the highest level of military skill.

sentences.latin: Hi consuetudine populi Romani loca capere, castra munire, commeatibus nostros intercludere instituunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These by the custom of the people Roman places to take, camps to fortify, from supplies our [men] to shut off they begin.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These by custom of people Roman places to take, camp to fortify, from supplies our [men] to shut off they begin.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men, following the Roman custom, began to choose strategic positions, fortify their camps, and cut off our troops from supplies.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi Crassus animadvertit, suas copias propter exiguitatem non facile diduci, hostem et vagari et vias obsidere et castris satis praesidii relinquere, ob eam causam minus commode frumentum commeatumque sibi supportari, in dies hostium numerum augeri, non cunctandum existimavit quin pugna decertaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when Crassus noticed, his own forces on account of smallness not easily to be drawn out, the enemy both to roam and the roads to blockade and for the camp enough of a guard to leave, for that reason less conveniently grain and supplies to himself to be brought, from day to day of the enemies the number to be increased, not to be delayed he thought but that by a battle he should decide.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when Crassus noticed, his forces on account of smallness not easily to be divided, the enemy both to wander and the roads to blockade and for the camp enough of a guard to leave, for this cause less conveniently grain and supplies to him to be brought, daily the of the enemies number to be increased, not to be hesitated he thought but that in battle he should decide.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Crassus noticed that his forces could not easily be divided because of their small number, while the enemy was roaming about, blockading the roads, and leaving a sufficient guard for their campmeaning that grain and supplies were being brought to him less easily while the enemy's numbers grew dailyhe decided he must not delay in coming to a decisive battle.

sentences.latin: Hac re ad consilium delata, ubi omnes idem sentire intellexit, posterum diem pugnae constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This matter to a council having been brought, when all the same thing to feel he understood, the next day for battle he appointed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This matter to a council having been reported, when all the same thing to feel he understood, the following day for battle he appointed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After bringing this matter before a council, when he realized that everyone shared the same opinion, he set the following day for the battle.

sentences.latin: Prima luce productis omnibus copiis duplici acie instituta, auxiliis in mediam aciem coniectis, quid hostes consilii caperent expectabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light having been led out all forces with a double line having been drawn up, the auxiliaries into the middle line having been thrown, what of a plan the enemies were taking he was waiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light having been led out all forces a double line having been formed, the auxiliaries into the middle line having been thrown, what of a plan the enemies might take he was waiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At daybreak, having led out all his forces and formed a double line with the auxiliaries placed in the center, he waited to see what plan the enemy would adopt.

sentences.latin: Illi, etsi propter multitudinem et veterem belli gloriam paucitatemque nostrorum se tuto dimicaturos existimabant, tamen tutius esse arbitrabantur obsessis viis commeatu intercluso sine vulnere victoria potiri,
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, although on account of the multitude and old of war glory and the smallness of ours themselves safely to be about to fight they were thinking, nevertheless safer to be they were judging with the roads blockaded with supplies cut off without a wound victory to get possession of,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, although on account of the multitude and old of war glory and the fewness of ours themselves safely would fight they thought, nevertheless safer to be they judged the roads having been blocked supplies having been cut off without a wound victory to gain,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the enemy believed they could fight safely because of their great numbers, their ancient military glory, and the small number of our men, they nevertheless thought it would be safer to gain victory without bloodshed by blockading the roads and cutting off supplies.

sentences.latin: et si propter inopiam rei frumentariae Romani se recipere coepissent, impeditos in agmine et sub sarcinis infirmiores animo adoriri cogitabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and if on account of the lack of the grain matter the Romans themselves to retreat had begun, hindered in the line of march and under packs weaker in spirit to attack they were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and if on account of the lack of thing grain the Romans themselves to withdraw had begun, hindered in the line and under packs weaker in spirit to attack they were thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They also intended to attack the Romans while they were encumbered on the march and burdened by their packsand thus weaker in spiritshould they begin to retreat due to a lack of grain.

sentences.latin: Hoc consilio probato ab ducibus, productis Romanorum copiis, sese castris tenebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This plan having been approved by the leaders, having been led out of the Romans the forces, themselves in the camp they were keeping.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This plan having been approved by the leaders, having been led out of the Romans the forces, themselves in the camp they were keeping.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This plan being approved by their leaders, they kept themselves within their camp even after the Roman forces had been led out.

sentences.latin: Hac re perspecta Crassus, cum sua cunctatione atque opinione timoris hostes nostros milites alacriores ad pugnandum effecissent atque omnium voces audirentur expectari diutius non oportere quin ad castra iretur, cohortatus suos omnibus cupientibus ad hostium castra contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This matter having been perceived Crassus, since by their own delay and the reputation of fear the enemies our soldiers more eager for fighting had made and of all the voices were heard to be waited longer not to be proper but that to the camp it should be gone, having encouraged his own with all desiring to the of the enemies camp he hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This matter having been perceived Crassus, since by their own hesitation and the opinion of fear the enemies our soldiers more eager for fighting had made and of all the voices were heard to be waited longer not it ought but that to the camp it should be gone, having encouraged his own all desiring to the of the enemies camp he hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Crassus perceived this, seeing that the enemy's delay and the impression of fear they gave had made our soldiers more eager for battle, and hearing everyone say that they should no longer wait to march on the camp, he encouraged his men and, with everyone's support, advanced toward the enemy's camp.

sentences.latin: Ibi cum alii fossas complerent, alii multis telis coniectis defensores vallo munitionibusque depellerent, auxiliaresque, quibus ad pugnam non multum Crassus confidebat, lapidibus telisque subministrandis et ad aggerem caespitibus comportandis speciem atque opinionem pugnantium praeberent, cum item ab hostibus constanter ac non timide pugnaretur telaque ex loco superiore missa non frustra acciderent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when some the ditches were filling, others many weapons having been thrown the defenders from the rampart and fortifications were driving away, and the auxiliaries, in whom for battle not much Crassus was trusting, by stones and weapons being supplied and to the mound sods being carried the appearance and reputation of fighting ones were providing, when likewise by the enemies steadily and not timidly it was being fought and weapons from the higher place sent not in vain were falling,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when some the ditches were filling, others many weapons having been thrown the defenders from the rampart and fortifications were driving, and the auxiliaries, in whom for the fight not much Crassus was trusting, by stones and weapons supplying and to the mound sods carrying the appearance and opinion of fighters were providing, when likewise by the enemies steadily and not fearfully it was fought and weapons from a place higher sent not in vain were falling,
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, while some were filling the ditches and others were driving the defenders from the rampart and fortifications with a shower of missiles, the auxiliariesin whom Crassus did not have much confidence for actual fightinggave the appearance and impression of combatants by supplying stones and weapons and carrying sods for the rampart; meanwhile, the enemy fought steadily and fearlessly, and the missiles they hurled from the higher ground were not falling without effect.

sentences.latin: equites circumitis hostium castris Crasso renuntiaverunt non eadem esse diligentia ab decumana porta castra munita facilemque aditum habere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the horsemen having gone around of the enemies the camp to Crassus reported not with the same diligence from the decuman gate the camp to be fortified and an easy approach to have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the horsemen having been gone around of the enemies the camp to Crassus reported not with the same diligence from the decuman gate the camp to be fortified and an easy approach to have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After riding around the enemy's camp, the cavalry reported to Crassus that the camp was not fortified with the same care at the decuman gate and offered an easy approach.

sentences.latin: Crassus equitum praefectos cohortatus, ut magnis praemiis pollicitationibusque suos excitarent, quid fieri vellet ostendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Crassus the of the horsemen officers having encouraged, that with great rewards and promises their own they should rouse, what to be done he was wishing he showed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Crassus of the horsemen the officers having encouraged, that with great rewards and promises their own they should excite, what to be done he wished he showed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Crassus, having encouraged the cavalry officers to rouse their men with great rewards and promises, explained what he wanted to be done.

sentences.latin: Illi, ut erat imperatum, eductis iis cohortibus quae praesidio castris relictae intritae ab labore erant, et longiore itinere circumductis, ne ex hostium castris conspici possent, omnium oculis mentibusque ad pugnam intentis celeriter ad eas quas diximus munitiones pervenerunt
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, as it had been commanded, having led out those cohorts which for a protection to the camp having been left unwearied by labor were, and by a longer route having been led around, lest from the enemy's camp they could be seen, of all the eyes and minds toward the fight being intent, quickly to those which we have mentioned fortifications they arrived
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, as it had been commanded, having been led out those cohorts which for a guard to the camp having been left unwearied from labor were, and by a longer journey having been led around, lest from the of the enemies camp to be seen they could, of all the eyes and minds to the fight intent quickly to those which we have said fortifications they arrived
sentences.naturalTranslation: As ordered, they led out the cohorts that had been left to guard the camp and were fresh from labor. After leading them around by a longer route so they would not be seen from the enemy's camp, they quickly reached the aforementioned fortifications while everyone's attention was fixed on the battle.

sentences.latin: atque his prorutis prius in hostium castris constiterunt quam plane ab his videri aut quid rei gereretur cognosci posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and these having been demolished, sooner in the enemy's camp they stood than clearly by them to be seen or what of the matter was being done to be known could.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and these having been thrown down sooner in the of the enemies camp they stood than clearly by these to be seen or what of a thing was being done to be known it could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After tearing these down, they established themselves in the enemy's camp before they could be clearly seen or it could be understood what was happening.

sentences.latin: Tum vero clamore ab ea parte audito nostri redintegratis viribus, quod plerumque in spe victoriae accidere consuevit, acrius impugnare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then indeed a shout from that part having been heard, our men with renewed strengths, which mostly in the hope of victory to happen is accustomed, more fiercely to attack began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then indeed a shout from that part having been heard our men with renewed strengths, which mostly in the hope of victory to happen is accustomed, more fiercely to attack began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, upon hearing a shout from that direction, our men renewed their strengthas usually happens when victory is in sightand began to attack even more fiercely.

sentences.latin: Hostes undique circumventi desperatis omnibus rebus se per munitiones deicere et fuga salutem petere contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemy from all sides surrounded, having been despaired of all things, themselves through the fortifications to throw down and by flight safety to seek they hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies from all sides surrounded having despaired of all things themselves over the fortifications to throw down and by flight safety to seek they strove.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Surrounded on all sides and despairing of their situation, the enemy threw themselves over the fortifications and sought safety in flight.

sentences.latin: Quos equitatus apertissimis campis consectatus ex milium L numero, quae ex Aquitania Cantabrisque convenisse constabat, vix quarta parte relicta, multa nocte se in castra recepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom the cavalry in the very open plains having followed, out of fifty thousand in number, who from Aquitania and the Cantabri to have assembled it was certain, scarcely a fourth part having been left, late at night themselves into the camp they withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom the cavalry in very open plains having followed out of of thousands 50 the number, which from Aquitania and the Cantabri to have assembled it was certain, scarcely the fourth part having been left, late at night itself into the camp it withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cavalry pursued them across the open plains; of the fifty thousand men known to have assembled from Aquitania and the Cantabri, barely a fourth were left when the cavalry returned to camp late at night.

sentences.latin: Hac audita pugna maxima pars Aquitaniae sese Crasso dedidit obsidesque ultro misit; quo in numero fuerunt Tarbelli, Bigerriones, Ptianii, Vocates, Tarusates, Elusates, Gates, Ausci, Garumni, Sibusates, Cocosates:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This having been heard battle, the greatest part of Aquitania itself to Crassus surrendered and hostages voluntarily sent; in which number were the Tarbelli, Bigerriones, Ptianii, Vocates, Tarusates, Elusates, Gates, Ausci, Garumni, Sibusates, Cocosates:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been heard battle the greatest part of Aquitania itself to Crassus surrendered and hostages voluntarily sent; in which number were the Tarbelli, Bigerriones, Ptianii, Vocates, Tarusates, Elusates, Gates, Ausci, Garumni, Sibusates, Cocosates:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When news of this battle spread, the greater part of Aquitania surrendered to Crassus and voluntarily sent hostages; among these were the Tarbelli, Bigerriones, Ptianii, Vocates, Tarusates, Elusates, Gates, Ausci, Garumni, Sibusates, and Cocosates.

sentences.latin: paucae ultimae nationes anni tempore confisae, quod hiems suberat, id facere neglexerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: a few most distant nations in the time of year having trusted, because winter was near, that to do neglected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a few most distant nations in the of the year time having trusted, because winter was near, this to do neglected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A few of the most distant tribes, relying on the time of year because winter was approaching, neglected to do so.

sentences.latin: Eodem fere tempore Caesar, etsi prope exacta iam aestas erat, tamen, quod omni Gallia pacata Morini Menapiique supererant, qui in armis essent neque ad eum umquam legatos de pace misissent, arbitratus id bellum celeriter confici posse eo exercitum duxit; qui longe alia ratione ac reliqui Galli bellum gerere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same almost time Caesar, although nearly finished already the summer was, nevertheless, because all Gaul having been pacified the Morini and Menapii remained, who in arms were and not to him ever legates about peace had sent, having thought that war quickly to be finished could, thither the army led; who by a far other method than the rest of the Gauls war to wage began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same almost time Caesar, although almost finished already the summer was, nevertheless, because all Gaul having been pacified the Morini and Menapii remained, who in arms were and to him ever envoys about peace had sent, thinking that war quickly to be finished could thither the army he led; who by far other a manner than the rest of the Gauls war to wage began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At almost the same time, although the summer was nearly over, Caesar led his army against the Morini and Menapii. Since all the rest of Gaul was pacified, they alone remained in arms and had never sent envoys to him to seek peace. He believed the war could be finished quickly, but they began to wage war in a manner very different from the other Gauls.

sentences.latin: Nam quod intellegebant maximas nationes, quae proelio contendissent, pulsas superatasque esse, continentesque silvas ac paludes habebant, eo se suaque omnia contulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For because they understood the greatest nations, which in battle had contended, beaten and overcome to be, and continuous forests and marshes they had, thither themselves and their all things they betook.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For because they were understanding the greatest nations, which in battle had contended, beaten and conquered to have been, and continuous forests and marshes they were having, thither themselves and their own all things they brought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because they realized that the greatest nations who had fought in open battle had been defeated and conquered, and since they possessed vast stretches of forest and marsh, they moved themselves and all their possessions there.

sentences.latin: Ad quarum initium silvarum cum Caesar pervenisset castraque munire instituisset neque hostis interim visus esset, dispersis in opere nostris subito ex omnibus partibus silvae evolaverunt et in nostros impetum fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To of which the beginning of the forests when Caesar had arrived and the camp to fortify had begun and not the enemy meanwhile seen had been, having been dispersed in the work our men, suddenly from all parts of the forest they flew out and against our men an attack they made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To of which the beginning of the forests when Caesar had arrived and the camp to fortify had begun and no enemy meanwhile seen had been, dispersed in the work our men suddenly from all parts of the forest they flew out and upon our men an attack they made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar reached the edge of these forests and began to fortify a camp, no enemy had been seen in the meantime; however, while our men were dispersed at their work, the enemy suddenly rushed out from all parts of the forest and attacked them.

sentences.latin: Nostri celeriter arma ceperunt eosque in silvas repulerunt et compluribus interfectis longius impeditioribus locis secuti paucos ex suis deperdiderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our [men] quickly arms took and them into the woods drove back and many having been killed further in more difficult places having followed few from their own [men] lost.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men quickly arms took and them into the forests drove back and, many having been killed, further in more hindered places having followed, few from their own they lost.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men quickly took up arms and drove them back into the woods; after killing many of them and pursuing the rest further into difficult terrain, they lost only a few of their own men.

sentences.latin: Reliquis deinceps diebus Caesar silvas caedere instituit, et ne quis inermibus imprudentibusque militibus ab latere impetus fieri posset, omnem eam materiam quae erat caesa conversam ad hostem conlocabat et pro vallo ad utrumque latus extruebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the remaining successively days Caesar woods to cut down decided, and lest any on the unarmed and unaware soldiers from the side attack to be made could, all that material which had been cut turned toward the enemy he was placing and as a rampart on each side was piling up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the remaining in succession days Caesar forests to cut down began, and lest any on the unarmed and unaware soldiers from the side attack to be made could, all that material which had been cut turned toward the enemy he placed and for a rampart on each side he piled up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the following days, Caesar decided to cut down the forests; to prevent any flank attacks on his soldiers while they were unarmed and off guard, he piled up all the felled timber facing the enemy, stacking it like a rampart on both sides.

sentences.latin: Incredibili celeritate magno spatio paucis diebus confecto, cum iam pecus atque extrema impedimenta a nostris tenerentur, ipsi densiores silvas peterent, eius modi sunt tempestates consecutae uti opus necessario intermitteretur et continuatione imbrium diutius sub pellibus milites contineri non possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With incredible speed a great space in a few days having been completed, when already cattle and the rear of the baggage by our [men] were being held, [the enemy] themselves the denser woods were seeking, of such a kind followed storms that the work by necessity was interrupted and by the continuation of rains longer under skins the soldiers to be kept could not.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With incredible speed a great space in a few days having been completed, when already the cattle and the last of the baggage by our men were held, they themselves denser forests were seeking, of such sort storms followed that the work by necessity was interrupted and by the continuation of rains longer under skins the soldiers to be kept not were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With incredible speed, a vast area was cleared in just a few days. But just as our men were capturing the enemy's cattle and the rear of their baggage train, and the enemy themselves were fleeing into the thicker woods, such violent storms broke out that the work was forced to stop, and the continuous rain made it impossible to keep the soldiers under tents any longer.

sentences.latin: Itaque vastatis omnibus eorum agris, vicis aedificiisque incensis, Caesar exercitum reduxit et in Aulercis Lexoviisque, reliquis item civitatibus quae proxime bellum fecerant, in hibernis conlocavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore having been devastated all their fields, villages and buildings having been burned, Caesar the army led back and in the Aulerci and Lexovii, the remaining likewise states which recently war had made, in winter quarters placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore having been devastated all of their fields, villages buildings-and having been burned, Caesar the army led back and in the Aulerci Lexoviique, the remaining likewise states which recently war had made, in winter quarters he placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, after laying waste to all their fields and burning their villages and buildings, Caesar led his army back and settled them in winter quarters among the Aulerci, the Lexovii, and the other tribes that had recently waged war.

sentences.latin: Ea quae secuta est hieme, qui fuit annus Cn.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In that which followed winter, which was the year of Gnaeus
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that which followed winter, which was the year of Gnaeus
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the following winter, in the year when Gnaeus

sentences.latin: Pompeio, M. Crasso consulibus, Usipetes Germani et item Tencteri magna [cum] multitudine hominum flumen Rhenum transierunt, non longe a mari, quo Rhenus influit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Pompey [and] Marcus Crassus being consuls, the Usipetes Germans and likewise the Tencteri with a great multitude of humans the river Rhine crossed, not far from the sea, where the Rhine flows in.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Pompey, Marcus Crassus being consuls, the Usipetes Germans and likewise the Tencteri with a great multitude of men the river Rhine crossed, not far from the sea, where the Rhine flows in.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the consulship of Gnaeus Pompey and Marcus Crassus, the German Usipetes and Tencteri crossed the Rhine in great numbers, not far from where the river flows into the sea.

sentences.latin: Causa transeundi fuit quod ab Suebis complures annos exagitati bello premebantur et agri cultura prohibebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The cause of crossing was because by the Suebi for several years harassed by war they were being pressed and from agriculture were being prohibited.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The cause of crossing was because by the Suebi for several years having been harassed by war they were pressed and from agriculture they were prohibited.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The reason for their migration was that they had been harassed for several years by the Suebi, who pressured them with war and prevented them from farming their land.

sentences.latin: Sueborum gens est longe maxima et bellicosissima Germanorum omnium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the Suebi the nation is by far the greatest and most warlike of Germans all.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the Suebi the nation is by far the largest and most warlike of Germans all.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Suebi are by far the largest and most warlike nation of all the Germans.

sentences.latin: Hi centum pagos habere dicuntur, ex quibus quotannis singula milia armatorum bellandi causa ex finibus educunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These a hundred cantons to have are said, from which every year single thousands of armed [men] for the sake of waging war from the borders they lead out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These a hundred cantons to have are said, from which yearly single thousands of armed men for the sake of warring from the borders they lead out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They are said to possess a hundred cantons, from each of which they lead out a thousand armed men every year to wage war beyond their borders.

sentences.latin: Reliqui, qui domi manserunt, se atque illos alunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The rest, who at home remained, themselves and those [others] nourish;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The remaining, who at home remained, themselves and those feed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who remain at home provide food for themselves and for those in the field.

sentences.latin: hi rursus in vicem anno post in armis sunt, illi domi remanent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: these again in turn a year after in arms are, those at home remain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: these again in turn a year after in arms are, those at home remain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These in turn are under arms a year later, while the others remain at home.

sentences.latin: Sic neque agri cultura nec ratio atque usus belli intermittitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus neither of field cultivation nor method and practice of war is interrupted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus neither agriculture nor the method and practice of war is interrupted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this way, neither the cultivation of the land nor the theory and practice of war is interrupted.

sentences.latin: Sed privati ac separati agri apud eos nihil est, neque longius anno remanere uno in loco colendi causa licet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But of private and separate land among them nothing is, nor longer than a year to remain in one place for the sake of tilling is it permitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But of private and separate land among them nothing is, nor longer than a year to remain in one in place for the sake of tilling is it permitted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But there is no private or separate land among them, nor is it permitted to remain in one place longer than a year for the purpose of farming.

sentences.latin: Neque multum frumento, sed maximam partem lacte atque pecore vivunt multum sunt in venationibus;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor much on grain, but for the greatest part on milk and cattle they live [and] much are in huntings;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor much on grain, but for the most part on milk and cattle they live and much are in huntings;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They do not live much on grain, but for the most part on milk and livestock, and they spend much time in hunting;

sentences.latin: quae res et cibi genere et cotidiana exercitatione et libertate vitae, quod a pueris nullo officio aut disciplina adsuefacti nihil omnino contra voluntatem faciunt, et vires alit et immani corporum magnitudine homines efficit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which thing both by food's kind and daily exercise and freedom of life, because from boys with no duty or discipline accustomed nothing at all against will they do, both strengths nourishes and with immense of bodies size men makes.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which thing both by the food kind and daily exercise and freedom of life, because from boys by no duty or discipline accustomed nothing at all against will they do, both strengths nourishes and with immense of bodies magnitude men makes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This practicedue to the type of food, daily exercise, and freedom of life, since from boyhood they are accustomed to no duty or discipline and do nothing at all against their willboth nourishes their strength and makes them men of immense physical size.

sentences.latin: Atque in eam se consuetudinem adduxerunt ut locis frigidissimis neque vestitus praeter pelles habeant quicquam, quarum propter exiguitatem magna est corporis pars aperta, et laventur in fluminibus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And into that habit themselves they have led that in places coldest neither of clothing except skins they have anything, of which because of smallness a great is of body part open, and they are washed in rivers.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And into that themselves custom they have led that in places coldest neither clothing except skins they have anything, of which because of smallness a great is of the body part open, and they are washed in rivers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And they have brought themselves to such a habit that, even in the coldest places, they have no clothing except skinsthe smallness of which leaves a great part of the body exposedand they bathe in the rivers.

sentences.latin: Mercatoribus est aditus magis eo ut quae bello ceperint quibus vendant habeant, quam quo ullam rem ad se importari desiderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To merchants there is access more for this [reason] that what in war they have taken [those] to whom they may sell they may have, than because any thing to themselves to be imported they desire.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To merchants is access more for that that what in war they have taken to whom they may sell they may have, than because any thing to themselves to be imported they desire.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Merchants have access to them more so that the Germans may have people to whom they can sell what they have captured in war, than because they desire any commodity to be imported to them.

sentences.latin: Quin etiam iumentis, quibus maxime Galli delectantur quaeque impenso parant pretio, Germani importatis non utuntur, sed quae sunt apud eos nata, parva atque deformia, haec cotidiana exercitatione summi ut sint laboris efficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nay even pack-animals, in which greatly Gauls are delighted and which at a huge they procure price, the Germans imported [ones] do not use, but those which are among them born, small and misshapen, these by daily exercise of highest that they be of labor they make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nay even pack-animals, in which greatly the Gauls are delighted and which at a high they procure price, the Germans imported not use, but those which are among them born, small and deformed, these by daily exercise of the highest that they be of labor they make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, the Germans do not use imported pack-animals, in which the Gauls take great pleasure and which they purchase at a high price; instead, by daily exercise, they render their own native-born animals, though small and misshapen, capable of the hardest labor.

sentences.latin: Equestribus proeliis saepe ex equis desiliunt ac pedibus proeliantur, equos eodem remanere vestigio adsue fecerunt, ad quos se celeriter, cum usus est, recipiunt:
sentences.referenceTranslation: In cavalry battles often from horses they leap down and on feet they battle, horses in the same to remain spot they have accustomed, to which themselves quickly, when use is, they retreat:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In cavalry battles often from horses they leap down and on feet they fight, the horses in the same to remain spot they have accustomed, to which themselves quickly, when use is, they betake:
sentences.naturalTranslation: In cavalry battles, they often leap down from their horses and fight on foot; they have trained their horses to stay in the same spot, to which they retreat quickly when there is need.

sentences.latin: neque eorum moribus turpius quicquam aut inertius habetur quam ephippiis uti.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor in their customs more shameful anything or more lazy is held than saddles to use.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor in their customs more shameful anything or more lazy is held than saddles to use.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And in their customs, nothing is considered more shameful or more lazy than to use saddles.

sentences.latin: Itaque ad quemvis numerum ephippiatorum equitum quamvis pauci adire audent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so against any number of saddled horsemen however few to approach they dare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore to any number of saddled horsemen however few to approach they dare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, however few they may be, they dare to attack any number of cavalry using saddles.

sentences.latin: Vinum omnino ad se importari non patiuntur, quod ea re ad laborem ferendum remollescere homines atque effeminari arbitrantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Wine at all to themselves to be imported not they allow, because by that thing to labor to be endured to grow soft men and to be weakened they think.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Wine at all to themselves to be imported not they allow, because by that thing to labor to be borne to grow soft men and to be effeminated they think.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They do not allow wine to be imported to them at all, because they believe that it causes men to grow soft and become too weak to endure hardship.

sentences.latin: Publice maximam putant esse laudem quam latissime a suis finibus vacare agros: hac re significari magnum numerum civitatum suam vim sustinere non posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Publicly the greatest they think to be praise as widely as possible from their borders to be empty the lands: by this thing to be signified a great number of states their force to sustain not to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Publicly the greatest they think to be praise as widely as possible from their borders to be empty the lands: by this thing to be signified a great number of states their force to sustain not to be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They consider it the greatest public glory for the lands to lie empty as far as possible from their borders; they believe this shows that a great number of states are unable to withstand their power.

sentences.latin: Itaque una ex parte a Suebis circiter milia passuum C agri vacare dicuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so on one side from the Suebi about thousands of paces 100 of land to be empty are said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore on one from part from the Suebi about thousands of paces 100 the lands to be empty are said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, on one side of the Suebi, the lands are said to lie empty for about a hundred miles.

sentences.latin: Ad alteram partem succedunt Ubii, quorum fuit civitas ampla atque florens, ut est captus Germanorum; ii paulo, quamquam sunt eiusdem generis, sunt ceteris humaniores, propterea quod Rhenum attingunt multum ad eos mercatores ventitant et ipsi propter propinquitatem [quod] Gallicis sunt moribus adsuefacti.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the other side succeed the Ubii, of whom was a state large and flourishing, as is the capacity of Germans; they a little, although they are of the same race, are than the rest more civilized, because that the Rhine they touch much to them merchants come often and they themselves because of proximity [because] to Gallic are customs accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the other part follow the Ubii, of whom was the state large and flourishing, as is the capacity of Germans; they a little, although they are of the same race, are than the rest more civilized, because that the Rhine they touch much to them merchants come often and they themselves because of proximity because to Gallic they are customs accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the other side, the Ubii follow, whose state was large and flourishing by German standards; although they are of the same race, they are a little more civilized than the others because they border the Rhine, merchants visit them frequently, and they themselves have become accustomed to Gallic customs due to their proximity.

sentences.latin: Hos cum Suebi multis saepe bellis experti propter amplitudinem gravitatem civitatis finibus expellere non potuissent, tamen vectigales sibi fecerunt ac multo humiliores infirmiores redegerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These when the Suebi in many often wars having tried on account of the size and importance of the state from borders to expel not had been able, nevertheless taxpayers to themselves they made and much more humble and weaker they reduced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These when the Suebi in many often wars having tried because of the size and importance of the state from borders to expel not had been able, nevertheless tributary to themselves they made and much more humble and weaker they reduced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the Suebi had often tried to drive them from their territory in many wars, they were unable to do so because of the size and importance of the state; nevertheless, they made them their tributaries and reduced them to a much humbler and weaker condition.

sentences.latin: In eadem causa fuerunt Usipetes et Tencteri, quos supra diximus; qui complures annos Sueborum vim sustinuerunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the same situation were the Usipetes and Tencteri, whom above we mentioned; who for several years of the Suebi the force sustained,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the same cause were the Usipetes and Tencteri, whom above we have mentioned; who for several years of the Suebi the force sustained,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Usipetes and Tencteri, whom we mentioned above, were in the same situation; they withstood the power of the Suebi for several years,

sentences.latin: ad extremum tamen agris expulsi et multis locis Germaniae triennium vagati ad Rhenum pervenerunt, quas regiones Menapii incolebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at the last however from lands expelled and in many places of Germany for a three-year period having wandered to the Rhine they arrived, which regions the Menapii were inhabiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at the last however from lands expelled and in many places of Germany for three years having wandered to the Rhine they arrived, which regions the Menapii were inhabiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but finally, having been driven from their lands and having wandered through many parts of Germany for three years, they reached the Rhine, in the regions inhabited by the Menapii.

sentences.latin: Hi ad utramque ripam fluminis agros, aedificia vicosque habebant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These on each bank of the river lands, buildings and villages were having;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These on each bank of the river lands, buildings and villages were having;
sentences.naturalTranslation: These people had lands, buildings, and villages on both banks of the river;

sentences.latin: sed tantae multitudinis adventu perterriti ex iis aedificiis quae trans flumen habuerant demigraverant, et cis Rhenum dispositis praesidiis Germanos transire prohibebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but by so great a multitude's arrival terrified from those buildings which across the river they had had they had moved away, and on this side of the Rhine having been stationed garrisons the Germans to cross they were prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but of so great a multitude by the arrival terrified from those buildings which across the river they had had they had moved away, and on this side of the Rhine having been placed garrisons the Germans to cross they were prohibiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but terrified by the arrival of such a great multitude, they abandoned the buildings they had held across the river and, by stationing garrisons on this side of the Rhine, they prevented the Germans from crossing.

sentences.latin: Illi omnia experti, cum neque vi contendere propter inopiam navium neque clam transire propter custodias Menapiorum possent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: They all things having tried, since neither by force to contend on account of lack of ships nor secretly to cross on account of guards of the Menapii they were able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They all things having tried, since neither by force to contend because of lack of ships nor secretly to cross because of the guards of the Menapii they were able,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having tried every resource, since they could neither force a crossing due to a lack of ships nor cross secretly because of the Menapian guards,

sentences.latin: reverti se in suas sedes regiones simulaverunt et tridui viam progressi rursus reverterunt atque omni hoc itinere una nocte equitatu confecto inscios inopinantes Menapios oppresserunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: to return themselves into their own seats [and] regions they pretended and of three days a way having advanced again they returned and all this journey in one night by the cavalry having been completed the unaware [and] unsuspecting Menapii they crushed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to return themselves into their own seats and regions they feigned and of three days a journey having advanced again they returned and all this journey in one night by the cavalry completed the unaware and unsuspecting Menapii they overwhelmed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: they pretended to return to their own homes and regions, but after marching for three days, they turned back; completing the entire return journey in a single night with their cavalry, they overwhelmed the unsuspecting and off-guard Menapii,

sentences.latin: qui de Germanorum discessu per exploratores certiores facti sine metu trans Rhenum in suos vicos remigraverant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who about of the Germans departure through scouts more certain having been made without fear across the Rhine into their own villages had moved back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who about of the Germans the departure through scouts more certain made without fear across the Rhine into their own villages had moved back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: who, having been informed of the Germans' departure by scouts, had moved back across the Rhine into their villages without fear.

sentences.latin: His interfectis navibus eorum occupatis, prius quam ea pars Menapiorum quae citra Rhenum erat certior fieret, flumen transierunt atque omnibus eorum aedificiis occupatis reliquam partem hiemis se eorum copiis aluerunt.
