sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been killed [and] ships of them having been seized, before than that part of the Menapii which on this side of the Rhine was more certain might be made, the river they crossed and all of them buildings having been seized the remaining part of winter themselves by their supplies they nourished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been killed ships of them having been seized, before than that part of the Menapii which on this side of the Rhine was more certain might be made, the river they crossed and all of them the buildings having been seized the remaining part of winter themselves with their supplies they nourished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After killing these people and seizing their ships, they crossed the river before the part of the Menapii on this side of the Rhine could be informed; then, having seized all their buildings, they sustained themselves for the rest of the winter on their supplies.

sentences.latin: His de rebus Caesar certior factus et infirmitatem Gallorum veritus, quod sunt in consiliis capiendis mobiles et novis plerumque rebus student, nihil his committendum existimavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These about things Caesar more certain having been made and the weakness of the Gauls having feared, because they are in plans to be taken changeable and to new mostly things they are eager, nothing to these to be entrusted he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These about things Caesar more certain made and the weakness of the Gauls having feared, because they are in plans to be taken changeable and to new mostly things they are eager, nothing to these to be entrusted he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Informed of these events and fearing the instability of the Gaulswho are fickle in making plans and generally eager for changeCaesar decided that nothing should be entrusted to them.

sentences.latin: Est enim hoc Gallicae consuetudinis, uti et viatores etiam invitos consistere cogant et quid quisque eorum de quaque re audierit aut cognoverit quaerant et mercatores in oppidis vulgus circumsistat quibus ex regionibus veniant quas ibi res cognoverint pronuntiare cogat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It is for this of Gallic custom, that both travelers even unwilling to stop they compel and what each of them about each thing has heard or has learned they ask and merchants in towns the crowd surrounds from which regions they come [and] what there things they have learned to declare it compels.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is for this of Gallic custom, that both travelers even unwilling to stop they compel and what each of them about each thing has heard or has learned they ask and merchants in towns the crowd surrounds from which regions they come what there things they have learned to declare it compels.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For it is a Gallic custom to compel travelers to stop even against their will and ask what each has heard or learned about any matter; likewise, in the towns, a crowd will surround merchants and force them to declare what regions they come from and what news they learned there.

sentences.latin: His rebus atque auditionibus permoti de summis saepe rebus consilia ineunt, quorum eos in vestigio paenitere necesse est, cum incertis rumoribus serviant et pleri ad voluntatem eorum ficta respondeant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things and hearsay moved about highest often things plans they enter, of which them on the spot to repent it is necessary, since to uncertain rumors they are slaves and most to the wish of them feigned things answer.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things and reports moved about the highest often things plans they enter, of which them on the spot to repent it is necessary, since to uncertain rumors they are slaves and most to the will of them things feigned answer.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by these reports and hearsay, they often make decisions on matters of the highest importance, which they must necessarily regret immediately, since they are slaves to uncertain rumors and most people give them fabricated answers tailored to their wishes.

sentences.latin: Qua consuetudine cognita Caesar, ne graviori bello, occurreret, maturius quam consuerat ad exercitum proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which custom having been known Caesar, lest a more serious war he might encounter, earlier than he had been accustomed to the army sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which custom having been known Caesar, lest a more serious war he might encounter, earlier than he had been accustomed to the army sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Aware of this custom, Caesar set out for the army earlier than usual to avoid encountering a more serious war.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, ea quas fore suspicatus erat facta cognovit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, those things which to be about to happen he had suspected done he learned:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had come, those things which to be about to be he had suspected done he learned:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, he discovered that the things he had suspected would happen had indeed taken place:

sentences.latin: missas legationes ab non nullis civitatibus ad Germanos invitatos eos uti ab Rheno discederent: omnia quae[que] postulassent ab se fore parata.
sentences.referenceTranslation: sent embassies by some states to the Germans invited them that from the Rhine they should depart: all things which they had demanded by them would be prepared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: sent embassies by some states to the Germans invited them that from the Rhine they should depart: all things which they had demanded by themselves to be about to be prepared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: embassies had been sent by several states to the Germans, inviting them to move away from the Rhine and promising that everything they demanded would be made ready by them.

sentences.latin: Qua spe adducti Germani latius iam vagabantur et in fines Eburonum et Condrusorum, qui sunt Treverorum clientes, pervenerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which hope led the Germans more widely now were wandering and into the borders of the Eburones and Condrusi, who are of the Treveri clients, had arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which hope led the Germans more widely now were wandering and into the borders of the Eburones and Condrusi, who are of the Treveri clients, had arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Influenced by this hope, the Germans were now wandering more widely and had reached the territories of the Eburones and Condrusi, who are dependents of the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Principibus Gallice evocatis Caesar ea quae cognoverat dissimulanda sibi existimavit, eorumque animis permulsis et confirmatis equitatu imperato bellum cum Germanis gerere constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The leaders of Gaul having been summoned, Caesar those things which he had learned to be concealed by him thought, and their minds having been soothed and strengthened, cavalry having been requisitioned, war with the Germans to wage he decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The leaders of Gaul having been summoned, Caesar those things which he had learned to be concealed by him thought, and their minds having been soothed and strengthened, cavalry having been requisitioned, war with the Germans to wage he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After summoning the Gallic leaders, Caesar decided he should conceal what he had learned; having reassured and encouraged them, he ordered a levy of cavalry and resolved to wage war against the Germans.

sentences.latin: Re frumentaria comparata equitibusque delectis iter in ea loca facere coepit, quibus in locis esse Germanos audiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Grain supply having been prepared and cavalrymen having been selected, a march into those places to make he began, in which places to be the Germans he was hearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Grain supply having been prepared and horsemen chosen, a journey into those places to make he began, in which places to be the Germans he was hearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having arranged for grain supplies and selected his cavalry, he began to march toward the regions where he heard the Germans were located.

sentences.latin: A quibus cum paucorum dierum iter abesset, legati ab iis venerunt, quorum haec fuit oratio:
sentences.referenceTranslation: From whom when of a few days' journey he was away, ambassadors from them came, of whom this was the speech:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From whom when of a few days journey he was away, ambassadors from them came, of whom this was the speech:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he was only a few days' march away from them, ambassadors arrived from the Germans, whose speech was as follows:

sentences.latin: Germanos neque priores populo Romano bellum inferre neque tamen recusare, si lacessantur, quin armis contendant, quod Germanorum consuetudo [haec] sit a maioribus tradita, Quicumque bellum inferant, resistere neque deprecari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That the Germans neither first on the Roman people war bring nor however refuse, if they are provoked, but that with arms they contend, because of the Germans the custom [this] is from ancestors handed down, whoever war bring, to resist and not to beg for mercy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Germans neither first on the Roman people war to bring nor however to refuse, if they are provoked, but that with arms they contend, because of the Germans the custom this is from ancestors handed down, whoever war bring, to resist and not to beg off.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They stated that the Germans were not the first to make war on the Roman people, yet they did not refuse to fight if provoked, because it was a tradition handed down from their ancestors to resist anyone who attacked them and not to plead for peace.

sentences.latin: Haec tamen dicere venisse invitos, eiectos domo;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things however to say that they had come unwilling, driven out from home;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things however to say they had come unwilling, cast out from home;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said, however, that they had come against their will, having been driven from their homes;

sentences.latin: si suam gratiam Romani velint, posse iis utiles esse amicos; vel sibi agros attribuant vel patiantur eos tenere quos armis possederint:
sentences.referenceTranslation: if their favor the Romans want, to be able to them useful to be friends; either to them lands they should assign or they should allow them to hold those which by arms they had possessed:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if their favor the Romans want, to be able to them useful to be friends; either to them lands they should assign or allow them to hold those which by arms they had possessed:
sentences.naturalTranslation: if the Romans wanted their friendship, they could be useful allies; the Romans should either assign them lands or allow them to keep those they had acquired by force of arms.

sentences.latin: sese unis Suebis concedere, quibus ne di quidem immortales pares esse possint; reliquum quidem in terris esse neminem quem non superare possint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that they to the Suebi alone yield, to whom not even the gods indeed immortal equal to be are able; remaining indeed on the lands to be no one whom not to overcome they are able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: themselves to the Suebi alone to yield, to whom not even the gods indeed immortal equal to be are able; remaining indeed on earth to be no one whom not to overcome they are able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they yielded to the Suebi alone, to whom not even the immortal gods could be a match; there was no one else on earth whom they could not defeat.

sentences.latin: Ad haec Caesar quae visum est respondit; sed exitus fuit orationis: sibi nullam cum iis amicitiam esse posse, si in Gallia remanerent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these things Caesar what seemed [proper] responded; but the end was of the speech: to him no with them friendship to be able, if in Gaul they should remain;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these things Caesar what seemed [fit] responded; but the end was of the speech: to him no with them friendship to be able, if in Gaul they remained;
sentences.naturalTranslation: To these remarks Caesar replied as he saw fit; but the conclusion of his speech was that there could be no friendship between him and them if they remained in Gaul;

sentences.latin: neque verum esse, qui suos fines tueri non potuerint alienos occupare; neque ullos in Gallia vacare agros qui dari tantae praesertim multitudini sine iniuria possint;
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor true to be, [those] who their own borders to protect not were able others' to occupy; nor any in Gaul to be vacant lands which to be given to so great especially a multitude without injury are able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor true to be, [those] who their own borders to protect not were able others' to occupy; nor any in Gaul to be empty lands which to be given to so great especially a multitude without injury are able;
sentences.naturalTranslation: nor was it right that those who could not protect their own territories should seize those of others; furthermore, there were no vacant lands in Gaul that could be given to such a vast multitude without doing injustice to others.

sentences.latin: sed licere, si velint, in Ubiorum finibus considere, quorum sint legati apud se et de Sueborum iniuriis querantur et a se auxilium petant: hoc se Ubiis imperaturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but to be permitted, if they should wish, in the Ubii's territories to settle, of whom there are ambassadors with him and about the Suebi's injuries complain and from him help seek: this he to the Ubii would command.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but to be permitted, if they wish, in of the Ubii borders to settle, of whom are ambassadors with him and about of the Suebi injuries complain and from him help seek: this he to the Ubii would command.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But he said they were permitted, if they wished, to settle in the territories of the Ubii, whose ambassadors were then with him complaining of the wrongs done by the Suebi and seeking his aid; he promised to give this command to the Ubii.

sentences.latin: Legati haec se ad suos relaturos dixerunt et re deliberata post diem tertium ad Caesarem reversuros: interea ne propius se castra moveret petierunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The ambassadors these things themselves to their own people would report they said and the matter having been deliberated after the third day to Caesar would return: meanwhile that not nearer themselves the camp he should move they requested.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The ambassadors these things themselves to their own people would report said and the matter having been deliberated after the third day to Caesar would return: meanwhile that not nearer to them the camp he move they asked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The ambassadors said they would report these things to their people and, after deliberating on the matter, would return to Caesar in three days; meanwhile, they requested that he not move his camp any closer to them.

sentences.latin: Ne id quidem Caesar ab se impetrari posse dixit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not even that Caesar from himself to be obtained to be able said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not that even Caesar from himself to be obtained to be able said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar said that not even this request could be granted by him.

sentences.latin: Cognoverat enim magnam partem equitatus ab iis aliquot diebus ante praedandi frumentandi causa ad Ambivaritos trans Mosam missam: hos expectari equites atque eius rei causa moram interponi arbitrabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He had learned for a large part of the cavalry by them some days before for the sake of plundering and foraging to the Ambivariti across the Meuse sent: these to be expected horsemen and of this thing for the sake delay to be interposed he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He had learned for a great part of the cavalry by them some days before for the sake of plundering [and] foraging to the Ambivariti across the Meuse sent: these to be expected horsemen and of this thing for the sake delay to be interposed he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he had learned that a large part of their cavalry had been sent by them across the Meuse to the Ambivariti a few days earlier for the purpose of plundering and foraging; he believed they were waiting for these horsemen and that a delay was being introduced for this reason.

sentences.latin: [Mosa profluit ex monte Vosego, qui est in finibus Lingonum, et parte quadam ex Rheno recepta, quae appellatur Vacalus insulam efficit Batavorum, in Oceanum influit
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Meuse flows forth from mountain Vosges, which is in the territories of the Lingones, and a part certain from the Rhine having been received, which is called Waal the island makes of the Batavians, into the Ocean flows
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Meuse flows out from mountain Vosges, which is in the borders of the Lingones, and a part certain from the Rhine received, which is called Waal, the island makes of the Batavians, into the Ocean flows
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Meuse flows from Mount Vosges, which is in the territory of the Lingones, and having received a certain branch from the Rhine, which is called the Waal, it forms the island of the Batavians and then flows into the Ocean.

sentences.latin: neque longius ab Oceano milibus passuum LXXX in Rhenum influit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not further from the Ocean thousands of paces 80 into the Rhine flows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor further from the Ocean miles eighty into the Rhine flows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and not more than eighty miles from the Ocean, it flows into the Rhine.

sentences.latin: Rhenus autem oritur ex Lepontiis, qui Alpes incolunt, et longo spatio per fines Nantuatium, Helvetiorum, Sequanorum, Mediomatricorum, Tribocorum, Treverorum citatus fertur et,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Rhine however rises from the Lepontii, who the Alps inhabit, and in a long space through the territories of the Nantuates, Helvetii, Sequani, Mediomatrici, Tribocorum, Treveri swiftly is carried and,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Rhine however rises from the Lepontii, who the Alps inhabit, and in a long space through the borders of the Nantuates, Helvetii, Sequani, Mediomatrici, Triboci, Treveri swiftly is carried and,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Rhine, however, rises in the country of the Lepontii, who inhabit the Alps, and is carried swiftly for a long distance through the territories of the Nantuates, Helvetii, Sequani, Mediomatrici, Triboci, and Treveri, and,

sentences.latin: ubi Oceano adpropinquavit, in plures diffluit partes multis ingentibus insulis effectis, quarum pars magna a feris barbaris nationibus incolitur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: when to the Ocean it has approached, into several it flows apart parts many huge islands having been formed, of which a part large by wild barbarian nations is inhabited,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: when to the Ocean it has approached, into several it flows apart parts, many huge islands having been formed, of which a part great by wild barbarian nations is inhabited,
sentences.naturalTranslation: when it approaches the Ocean, it divides into several channels, forming many large islands, a great part of which is inhabited by fierce and barbarian nations,

sentences.latin: ex quibus sunt qui piscibus atque ovis avium vivere existimantur, multis capitibus in Oceanum influit.]
sentences.referenceTranslation: from which there are those who on fish and eggs of birds to live are thought, by many heads into the Ocean it flows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from which there are [those] who on fish and eggs of birds to live are thought, by many heads into the Ocean it flows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: among whom there are some who are believed to live on fish and birds' eggs; it flows into the Ocean by many mouths.

sentences.latin: Caesar cum ab hoste non amplius passuum XII milibus abesset, ut erat constitutum, ad eum legati revertuntur; qui in itinere congressi magnopere ne longius progrederetur orabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar when from the enemy not more of paces 12 thousands was distant, as had been arranged, to him the ambassadors return; who on the march having met greatly that not further he should proceed were begging.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar when from the enemy not more of paces 12 thousand was away, as had been arranged, to him the ambassadors return; who on the journey having met greatly that not further he should advance were begging.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar was not more than twelve miles from the enemy, the ambassadors returned to him as had been arranged; meeting him on the march, they earnestly entreated him not to advance any further.

sentences.latin: Cum id non impetrassent, petebant uti ad eos [equites] qui agmen antecessissent praemitteret eos pugna prohiberet, sibique ut potestatem faceret in Ubios legatos mittendi;
sentences.referenceTranslation: When that not they had obtained, they were asking that to those [cavalrymen] who the column had preceded he should send ahead (and) them from fighting he should prohibit, and for themselves that power he should make into the Ubii ambassadors of sending;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When that not they had obtained, they were asking that to those [cavalry] who the line of march had preceded he should send forward [and] them from battle he should prohibit, and for themselves that power he should make into the Ubii ambassadors of sending;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they did not obtain this, they requested that he send word to the cavalry who had preceded the main column to prevent them from fighting, and that he grant them the opportunity to send ambassadors to the Ubii;

sentences.latin: quorum si principes ac senatus sibi iure iurando fidem fecisset, ea condicione quae a Caesare ferretur se usuros ostendebant: ad has res conficiendas sibi tridui spatium daret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom if the leading men and senate to them by oath-taking faith had made, that condition which by Caesar was being offered themselves would use they were showing: for these things to be finished to them of three days space he should give.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom if the chiefs and senate to them by oath-taking faith had made, that condition which by Caesar was offered they would use they were showing: for these things to be finished to them of three days space he should give.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They declared that if the Ubian leaders and senate gave them a sworn guarantee, they would accept the terms offered by Caesar; they asked that he give them three days to finalize these matters.

sentences.latin: Haec omnia Caesar eodem illo pertinere arbitrabatur ut tridui mora interposita equites eorum qui abessent reverterentur; tamen sese non longius milibus passuum IIII aquationis causa processurum eo die dixit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: These all things Caesar to same that (point) to pertain was thinking that of three days delay having been interposed the cavalry of them who were away might return; nevertheless himself not further than miles of paces 4 for the sake of water-getting would proceed on that day he said:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These all things Caesar to the same that [point] to pertain was thinking that a three days delay having been interposed the cavalry of them who were away might return; however himself not further miles of paces 4 for the sake of watering to proceed on that day he said:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar believed all these requests tended toward the same goalthat by interposing a three-day delay, their absent cavalry might return; nevertheless, he stated that he would not proceed further than four miles that day for the purpose of obtaining water:

sentences.latin: huc postero die quam frequentissimi convenirent, ut de eorum postulatis cognosceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to here on the following day as numerous as possible they should come together, so that about their demands he might learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: hither on the following day as most frequent they should come together, so that about their demands he might learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he told them to assemble there the next day in as large numbers as possible, so that he might take cognizance of their demands.

sentences.latin: Interim ad praefectos, qui cum omni equitatu antecesserant, mittit qui nuntiarent ne hostes proelio lacesserent, et si ipsi lacesserentur, sustinerent quoad ipse cum exercitu propius accessisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile to the prefects, who with all the cavalry had preceded, he sends (those) who should announce lest the enemy in battle they should provoke, and if themselves they were provoked, they should hold out until himself with the army nearer had approached.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile to the prefects, who with all the cavalry had preceded, he sends who should announce lest the enemies in battle they should provoke, and if themselves they were provoked, they should hold out until himself with the army nearer had approached.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, he sent messengers to the officers who had gone ahead with all the cavalry, instructing them not to provoke the enemy to battle, and if they were attacked themselves, to hold their ground until he had drawn closer with the main army.

sentences.latin: At hostes, ubi primum nostros equites conspexerunt, quorum erat V milium numerus, cum ipsi non amplius DCCC equites haberent, quod ii qui frumentandi causa ierant trans Mosam profecti nondum redierant, nihil timentibus nostris, quod legati eorum paulo ante a Caesare discesserant atque is dies indutiis erat ab his petitus, impetu facto celeriter nostros perturbaverunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the enemy, when first our cavalry they caught sight of, of whom was of 5 thousand the number, although themselves not more than 800 cavalry they were having, because those who for the sake of foraging had gone across the Meuse having set out not yet had returned, nothing fearing our (men), because the ambassadors of them a little before from Caesar had departed and that day for a truce had been by them requested, an attack having been made quickly our (men) they threw into confusion;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the enemies, when first our cavalry they saw, of whom was of 5 thousands the number, although themselves not more than 800 cavalry were having, because those who for the sake of foraging had gone across the Meuse having set out not yet had returned, nothing fearing our [men], because ambassadors of them a little before from Caesar had departed and that day for a truce had been by these requested, an attack having been made quickly our [men] they threw into confusion;
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the enemy, as soon as they saw our cavalry, which numbered five thousand, although they themselves had no more than eight hundred because those who had gone across the Meuse to forage had not yet returned, made an attack and quickly threw our men into confusion; our men feared nothing because their ambassadors had left Caesar only a little while before and that day had been requested by them for a truce.

sentences.latin: rursus his resistentibus consuetudine sua ad pedes desiluerunt subfossis equis compluribus nostris deiectis reliquos in fugam coniecerunt atque ita perterritos egerunt ut non prius fuga desisterent quam in conspectum agminis nostri venissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: again these resisting by custom their to feet they leaped down having been stabbed from below horses several our (men) having been thrown down the rest into flight they threw and so terrified they drove (them) that not before from flight they ceased than into the sight of the column our they had come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: again these resisting by custom their to feet they leaped down with stabbed horses several our [men] thrown down the rest into flight they cast and so terrified they drove that not before from flight they ceased than into sight of the line of march our they had come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When our men resisted, they followed their custom and leaped down to their feet, and by stabbing the horses from below and unhorsing several of our men, they put the rest to flight and drove them away in such terror that they did not stop fleeing until they had come in sight of our main column.

sentences.latin: In eo proelio ex equitibus nostris interficiuntur IIII et LXX,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In that battle from the cavalry our are killed 4 and 70,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that battle from cavalry our are killed 4 and 70,
sentences.naturalTranslation: In that battle, seventy-four of our cavalry were killed,

sentences.latin: in his vir fortissimus Piso Aquitanus, amplissimo genere natus, cuius avus in civitate sua regnum obtinuerat amicus a senatu nostro appellatus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: among these a man most brave Piso the Aquitanian, from a most distinguished family born, whose grandfather in state his royal power had held friend by senate our called.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: among these a man most brave Piso an Aquitanian, from a most noble race born, whose grandfather in state his royal power had held friend by senate our called.
sentences.naturalTranslation: among them Piso the Aquitanian, a very brave man born of a most distinguished family, whose grandfather had held sovereign power in his own state and had been called "friend" by our senate.

sentences.latin: Hic cum fratri intercluso ab hostibus auxilium ferret, illum ex periculo eripuit, ipse equo vulnerato deiectus, quoad potuit, fortissime restitit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This (man) when to (his) brother cut off by the enemy help he was bringing, that one from danger he rescued, himself horse having been wounded thrown down, as long as he was able, most bravely resisted;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This [man] when to [his] brother cut off by the enemies help he was bringing, him from danger he rescued, himself horse wounded thrown down, as long as he could, most bravely he resisted;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he was bringing help to his brother who had been cut off by the enemy, he rescued him from danger, but he himself was unhorsed when his horse was wounded, and he resisted most bravely as long as he could;

sentences.latin: cum circumventus multis vulneribus acceptis cecidisset atque id frater, qui iam proelio excesserat, procul animadvertisset, incitato equo se hostibus obtulit atque interfectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: when surrounded many wounds having been received he had fallen and this the brother, who already from the battle had departed, from afar had noticed, with incited horse himself to the enemies he offered and was killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: when surrounded many wounds having been received he had fallen and that the brother, who already from the battle had withdrawn, from afar had noticed, with incited horse himself to the enemies he offered and killed was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had fallen, surrounded and having received many wounds, and his brother, who had already left the battle, noticed this from a distance, he spurred on his horse, threw himself at the enemy, and was killed.

sentences.latin: Hoc facto proelio Caesar neque iam sibi legatos audiendos neque condiciones accipiendas arbitrabatur ab iis qui per dolum atque insidias petita pace ultro bellum intulissent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This battle having been done Caesar neither now for himself ambassadors to be heard nor conditions to be accepted thought from those who through deceit and treachery peace having been sought of their own accord war had brought in;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been done battle Caesar neither now for himself ambassadors to be heard nor conditions to be accepted was thinking from those who through deceit and treachery having sought peace of their own accord war had brought in;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this battle was over, Caesar decided that he should no longer listen to envoys or accept terms from those who, after seeking peace, had voluntarily started a war through deceit and treachery.

sentences.latin: expectare vero dum hostium copiae augerentur equitatus reverteretur summae dementiae esse iudicabat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: to wait indeed until of the enemies the forces were increased the cavalry returned of the highest madness to be he judged,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to wait truly until of the enemies the forces were increased [and] the cavalry returned of the highest madness to be he was judging,
sentences.naturalTranslation: He judged that to wait until the enemy's forces were increased and their cavalry returned would be the height of madness.

sentences.latin: et cognita Gallorum infirmitate quantum iam apud eos hostes uno proelio auctoritatis essent consecuti sentiebat; quibus ad consilia capienda nihil spatii dandum existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and the weakness of the Gauls having been known how much already among them the enemies by one battle of authority had obtained he perceived; to whom for plans to be taken nothing of space to be given he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and having been known of the Gauls the weakness how much already among those enemies by one battle of authority they had gained he was sensing; to whom for plans to be taken nothing of space to be given he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Knowing the weakness of the Gauls, he realized how much prestige the enemy had already gained among them from a single battle; he believed that no time should be given to them to form plans.

sentences.latin: His constitutis rebus et consilio cum legatis et quaestore communicato, ne quem diem pugnae praetermitteret, oportunissima res accidit, quod postridie eius diei mane eadem et perfidia et simulatione usi Germani frequentes, omnibus principibus maioribusque natu adhibitis, ad eum in castra venerunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been arranged and the plan with the legates and the quaestor shared, lest any day of battle he might let pass, a most opportune thing happened, because on the next day of that day in the morning with the same both treachery and pretense having used the Germans in great numbers, all the chiefs and elders having been brought, to him into the camp came,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been decided things and the plan with the legates and the quaestor shared, lest any day of battle he should let pass, a most opportune thing happened, because on the day after of that day in the morning with the same both perfidy and simulation having used the Germans in crowds, all the chiefs and older by birth having been brought, to him into the camp they came,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having arranged these matters and shared his plan with the legates and the quaestor so as not to lose a single day of fighting, a very fortunate thing happened: on the morning of the following day, the Germans, using the same treachery and pretense, came to him in camp in large numbers, bringing all their chiefs and elders.

sentences.latin: simul, ut dicebatur, sui purgandi causa, quod contra atque esset dictum et ipsi petissent, proelium pridie commisissent, simul ut, si quid possent, de indutiis fallendo impetrarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at the same time, as it was said, of themselves clearing for the sake, because contrary to and it had been said and they themselves had requested, battle on the day before they had joined, at the same time that, if anything they could, concerning a truce by deceiving they might obtain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at the same time, as it was being said, of themselves purging for the sake, because contrary and than it had been said and themselves had asked, battle the day before they had joined, at the same time so that, if anything they could, about the truce by deceiving they might obtain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They came ostensibly to clear themselves because they had engaged in battle the day before contrary to what had been agreed and what they themselves had requested, and also to see if they could obtain anything regarding a truce through further deception.

sentences.latin: Quos sibi Caesar oblatos gavisus illos retineri iussit; ipse omnes copias castris eduxit equitatumque, quod recenti proelio perterritum esse existimabat, agmen subsequi iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom to himself Caesar offered having rejoiced those to be retained he ordered; himself all forces from the camp led out and the cavalry, because in the recent battle terrified to be he thought, the line to follow he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom to himself Caesar offered having rejoiced those to be retained he ordered; himself all forces from the camp he led out and the cavalry, because in the recent battle to be terrified he was thinking, the line of march to follow he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, delighted that they had put themselves in his power, ordered them to be detained; he himself led all his forces out of camp and ordered the cavalry to follow the rear of the column, as he believed they were still terrified from the recent battle.

sentences.latin: Acie triplici instituta et celeriter VIII milium itinere confecto, prius ad hostium castra pervenit quam quid ageretur Germani sentire possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A line triple having been drawn up and quickly of 8 miles the journey having been completed, sooner at of the enemies the camp he arrived than what was being done the Germans to perceive were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Line of march triple having been arranged and quickly of 8 miles the journey having been finished, earlier to of the enemies the camp he arrived than what was being done the Germans to sense could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having drawn up a triple line of battle and quickly completed an eight-mile march, he arrived at the enemy's camp before the Germans could realize what was happening.

sentences.latin: Qui omnibus rebus subito perterriti et celeritate adventus nostri et discessu suorum, neque consilii habendi neque arma capiendi spatio dato perturbantur, copiasne adversus hostem ducere an castra defendere an fuga salutem petere praestaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who by all things suddenly terrified both by the speed of the arrival of ours and by the departure of their own, neither of a plan to be had nor arms to be taken space given they are thrown into confusion, whether forces against the enemy to lead or the camp to defend or by flight safety to seek it were better.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who by all things suddenly terrified both by the speed of arrival our and by the departure of their own, neither of a plan to be held nor arms to be taken space given they are thrown into confusion, forces-whether against the enemy to lead or camp to defend or by flight safety to seek it were better.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Suddenly terrified by everythingthe speed of our arrival and the absence of their own menand given no time to form a plan or take up arms, they were thrown into confusion as to whether it was better to lead their forces against the enemy, defend the camp, or seek safety in flight.

sentences.latin: Quorum timor cum fremitu et concursu significaretur, milites nostri pristini diei perfidia incitati in castra inruperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom the fear when by noise and running about was indicated, soldiers our of the former day by the treachery incited into the camp burst.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom the fear when by shouting and running together was signified, soldiers our of the former day by the perfidy incited into the camp burst.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When their fear was made evident by their shouting and running about, our soldiers, incited by the treachery of the previous day, burst into the camp.

sentences.latin: Quo loco qui celeriter arma capere potuerunt paulisper nostris restiterunt atque inter carros impedimenta proelium commiserunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which place those who quickly arms to take were able for a little while to ours resisted and among the carts and baggage battle joined;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which place those who quickly arms to take were able for a little while to ours resisted and among the carts [and] baggage battle joined;
sentences.naturalTranslation: At that spot, those who were able to take up arms quickly resisted our men for a short time and joined battle among the carts and baggage;

sentences.latin: at reliqua multitudo puerorum mulierumque (nam eum omnibus suis domo excesserant Rhenum transierant) passim fugere coepit, ad quos consectandos Caesar equitatum misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but the remaining multitude of boys and of women (for with all their own from home they had departed and the Rhine had crossed) everywhere to flee began, to whom to be pursued Caesar the cavalry sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but the remaining multitude of boys and of women (for with all their [people] from home they had departed [and] the Rhine had crossed) everywhere to flee began, to whom to be pursued Caesar the cavalry sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but the rest of the crowd, consisting of women and children (for they had left home with all their possessions and crossed the Rhine), began to flee in all directions, and Caesar sent the cavalry to hunt them down.

sentences.latin: Germani post tergum clamore audito, eum suos interfici viderent, armis abiectis signis militaribus relictis se ex castris eiecerunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Germans after their back a shout having been heard, when their own to be killed they saw, arms having been thrown away and standards military abandoned, themselves from the camp threw out,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Germans after [their] back a shout having been heard, when their [men] to be killed they saw, arms having been thrown away [and] standards military having been abandoned, themselves from the camp threw out,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the Germans heard the shouting behind them and saw their own people being killed, they threw away their weapons, abandoned their military standards, and rushed out of the camp.

sentences.latin: et eum ad confluentem Mosae et Rheni pervenissent, reliqua fuga desperata, magno numero interfecto, reliqui se in flumen praecipitaverunt atque ibi timore, lassitudine, vi fluminis oppressi perierunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and when to the confluence of the Meuse and of the Rhine they had arrived, further flight having been despaired of, a great number having been killed, the rest themselves into the river threw and there by fear, by exhaustion, by the force of the river overwhelmed they perished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and when to the confluence of the Meuse and of the Rhine they had arrived, the remaining flight having been despaired of, a great number having been killed, the rest themselves into the river threw and there by fear, by exhaustion, [and] by the force of the river overwhelmed they perished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they reached the confluence of the Meuse and the Rhine, despairing of further escape and with many already killed, the survivors threw themselves into the river and perished there, overcome by fear, exhaustion, and the force of the current.

sentences.latin: Nostri ad unum omnes incolumes, perpaucis vulneratis, ex tanti belli timore, cum hostium numerus capitum CCCCXXX milium fuisset, se in castra receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our [men] to one all safe, very few having been wounded, from of so great a war the fear, since of the enemy the number of heads 430 thousands had been, themselves into the camp withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our [men] to one all safe, very few having been wounded, from of so great a war the fear, since of the enemy the number of heads 430 thousands had been, themselves into the camp withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men, all safe to a man with only a very few wounded, returned to camp after the fear of so great a war, in which the enemy's numbers had reached 430,000.

sentences.latin: Caesar iis quos in castris retinuerat discedendi potestatem fecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar to those whom in the camp he had retained of departing the power made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar to those whom in the camp he had retained of departing the power made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar gave those whom he had detained in the camp permission to depart.

sentences.latin: Illi supplicia cruciatusque Gallorum veriti, quorum agros vexaverant, remanere se apud eum velle dixerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They the punishments and tortures of the Gauls having feared, whose fields they had harassed, to remain themselves with him to wish said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They the punishments and tortures of the Gauls having feared, whose fields they had harassed, to remain themselves with him to wish said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fearing the punishments and tortures of the Gauls, whose lands they had ravaged, they said they wished to stay with him.

sentences.latin: His Caesar libertatem concessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these Caesar liberty granted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these Caesar liberty granted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar granted them their freedom.

sentences.latin: Germanico bello confecto multis de causis Caesar statuit sibi Rhenum esse transeundum; quarum illa fuit iustissima quod, cum videret Germanos tam facile impelli ut in Galliam venirent, suis quoque rebus eos timere voluit, cum intellegerent et posse et audere populi Romani exercitum Rhenum transire.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The German war having been finished for many from causes Caesar decided for himself the Rhine to be to be crossed; of which that [one] was most just because, when he saw the Germans so easily to be impelled that into Gaul they came, for their own also things them to fear he wished, when they understood both to be able and to dare of the people Roman the army the Rhine to cross.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The German war having been finished for many from causes Caesar decided for himself the Rhine to be to be crossed; of which that [one] was most just because, when he saw the Germans so easily to be impelled that into Gaul they came, for their own also things them to fear he wished, when they understood both to be able and to dare of the people Roman the army the Rhine to cross.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the German war was over, Caesar decided for several reasons that he must cross the Rhine; the most compelling of these was that, seeing how easily the Germans were induced to enter Gaul, he wanted them to fear for their own safety as well, once they realized that the army of the Roman people had both the power and the courage to cross the Rhine.

sentences.latin: Accessit etiam quod illa pars equitatus Usipetum et Tencterorum, quam supra commemoravi praedandi frumentandique causa Mosam transisse neque proelio interfuisse, post fugam suorum se trans Rhenum in fines Sugambrorum receperat seque cum his coniunxerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was added also that that part of the cavalry of the Usipetes and of the Tencteri, which above I mentioned for the sake of plundering and of foraging the Meuse to have crossed and not in the battle to have been present, after the flight of their own themselves across the Rhine into the territories of the Sugambri had withdrawn and themselves with these had joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was added also that that part of the cavalry of the Usipetes and of the Tencteri, which above I mentioned for the sake of plundering and of foraging the Meuse to have crossed and not in the battle to have been present, after the flight of their [men] themselves across the Rhine into the territories of the Sugambri had withdrawn and themselves with these had joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was also the fact that the division of the cavalry of the Usipetes and Tencteri, which I mentioned above had crossed the Meuse to plunder and forage and had not taken part in the battle, had retreated across the Rhine into the territory of the Sugambri after the flight of their countrymen and had joined forces with them.

sentences.latin: Ad quos cum Caesar nuntios misisset, qui postularent eos qui sibi Galliae bellum intulissent sibi dederent, responderunt:
sentences.referenceTranslation: To whom when Caesar messengers had sent, who might demand those who to him of Gaul war had brought to him they should surrender, they replied:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To whom when Caesar messengers had sent, who should demand those who to themselves [and] to Gaul war had brought to him they should surrender, they replied:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar sent messengers to them demanding that they surrender those who had made war on him and Gaul, they replied:

sentences.latin: populi Romani imperium Rhenum finire; si se invito Germanos in Galliam transire non aequum existimaret, cur sui quicquam esse imperii aut potestatis trans Rhenum postularet?
sentences.referenceTranslation: of the people Roman the empire the Rhine to limit; if him being unwilling Germans into Gaul to cross not fair he thought, why of him anything to be of empire or of power across the Rhine he should demand?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of the people Roman the empire the Rhine to limit; if him being unwilling the Germans into Gaul to cross not fair he thought, why of his anything to be of empire or of power across the Rhine he should demand?
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the Rhine bounded the empire of the Roman people; if he thought it unfair for the Germans to cross into Gaul against his will, why did he claim any authority or power across the Rhine?

sentences.latin: Ubii autem, qui uni ex Transrhenanis ad Caesarem legatos miserant, amicitiam fecerant, obsides dederant, magnopere orabant ut sibi auxilium ferret, quod graviter ab Suebis premerentur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Ubii however, who alone from those across the Rhine to Caesar ambassadors had sent, friendship had made, hostages had given, greatly were begging that to them help he should bring, because heavily by the Suebi they were being pressed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Ubii however, who alone from the Transrhenani to Caesar ambassadors had sent, friendship had made, hostages had given, greatly were begging that to them help he should bring, because heavily by the Suebi they were being pressed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Ubii, however, who alone of the trans-Rhenane tribes had sent ambassadors to Caesar, formed an alliance, and given hostages, earnestly entreated him to bring them aid, as they were being hard pressed by the Suebi;

sentences.latin: vel, si id facere occupationibus rei publicae prohiberetur, exercitum modo Rhenum transportaret: id sibiadauxilium spemque reliqui temporis satis futurum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: or, if that to do by occupations of the state he were prohibited, the army only the Rhine he should transport: that to them for help and hope of the remaining time enough would be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: or, if that to do by the occupations of the republic he were prohibited, the army only the Rhine he should transport: that for them for help and for hope of the remaining time enough would be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: or, if he were prevented from doing so by the business of the state, that he should at least transport his army across the Rhine; this would be sufficient for their protection and their hope for the future.

sentences.latin: Tantum esse nomen atque opinionem eius exercitus Ariovisto pulso et hoc novissimo proelio facto etiam ad ultimas Germanorum nationes, uti opinione et amicitia populi Romani tuti esse possint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: So great to be the name and reputation of his army Ariovistus having been defeated and this most recent battle having been fought even to the farthest of the Germans nations, so that by the reputation and friendship of the people Roman safe to be they might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: So great to be the name and the reputation of his army Ariovistus having been defeated and this most recent battle having been fought even to the farthest of the Germans nations, that by the reputation and friendship of the people Roman safe to be they could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They claimed that the reputation and prestige of his army, following the defeat of Ariovistus and this most recent battle, were so great even among the most distant German tribes that they could be safe through the prestige and friendship of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Navium magnam copiam ad transportandum exercitum pollicebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of ships a great supply for transporting the army they were promising.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of ships a great supply for transporting the army they were promising.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They promised a large number of ships for transporting the army.

sentences.latin: Caesar his de causis quas commemoravi Rhenum transire decreverat; sed navibus transire neque satis tutum esse arbitrabatur neque suae neque populi Romani dignitatis esse statuebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar for these from causes which I have mentioned the Rhine to cross had decided; but by ships to cross neither enough safe to be he was thinking nor of his own nor of the people Roman dignity to be he was determining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar for these from causes which I have mentioned the Rhine to cross had decided; but by ships to cross neither enough safe to be he was thinking nor of his own nor of the people Roman the dignity to be he was determining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For these reasons I have mentioned, Caesar had decided to cross the Rhine; however, he thought that crossing by boat was not sufficiently safe and determined it was not consistent with his own dignity or that of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Itaque, etsi summa difficultas faciendi pontis proponebatur propter latitudinem, rapiditatem altitudinemque fluminis, tamen id sibi contendendum aut aliter non traducendum exercitum existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so, although the greatest difficulty of making a bridge was being put forward on account of the width, speed, and depth of the river, nevertheless that by him must be attempted or otherwise not to be led across the army he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so, although the greatest difficulty of making a bridge was being proposed on account of the width, the speed, and the depth of the river, nevertheless that by him to be striven for or otherwise not to be led across the army he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, although the greatest difficulty in building a bridge was presented by the width, speed, and depth of the river, he nevertheless thought he must attempt it or else not lead his army across at all.

sentences.latin: Rationem pontis hanc instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The plan of the bridge this he established.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The plan of the bridge this [one] he established.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He adopted the following design for the bridge.

sentences.latin: Tigna bina sesquipedalia. paulum ab imo praeacuta dimensa ad altitudinem fluminis intervallo pedum duorum inter se iungebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Beams in pairs a foot and a half thick, a little from the bottom sharpened, measured to the depth of the river, at an interval of feet two between themselves he was joining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Beams in pairs one and a half feet [thick], a little from the bottom sharpened, measured to the depth of the river, at an interval of feet two among themselves he was joining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He joined together pairs of beams, each a foot and a half thick, sharpened slightly at the lower end and measured to suit the depth of the river, leaving a two-foot space between them.

sentences.latin: Haec cum machinationibus immissa in flumen defixerat fistucisque adegerat, non sublicae modo derecte ad perpendiculum, sed prone ac fastigate, ut secundum naturam fluminis procumberent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These when by machines let down into the river he had fixed and with pile-drivers had driven, not in the manner of a pile straight to the perpendicular, but leaning and sloped, so that according to the nature of the river they might lean forward,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These when by machines let down into the river he had fixed and with rammers had driven home, not in the manner of a pile straight to the perpendicular, but leaning and sloping, so that according to the nature of the river they might lie forward,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these had been lowered into the river by machines and driven home with pile-drivers, they were set not vertically like a stake, but inclined at an angle, so that they leaned in the direction of the current.

sentences.latin: iis item contraria duo ad eundem modum iuncta intervallo pedum quadragenum ab inferiore parte contra vim atque impetu fluminis conversa statuebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to these likewise opposite two in the same manner joined at a distance of feet forty from the lower part against the force and onset of the river turned he was setting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to these likewise opposite two in the same manner joined at a distance of feet forty from the lower part against the force and onset of the river turned he was placing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Opposite these, he also set two others joined in the same way, forty feet apart at the lower end, turned against the force and onset of the river.

sentences.latin: Haec utraque insuper bipedalibus trabibus immissis, quantum eorum tignorum iunctura distabat, binis utrimque fibulis ab extrema parte distinebantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These both from above with two-foot beams let in, as much as of those beams the joining was distant, by two on each side braces from the end part were kept apart;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These both from above two-foot beams having been let in, as much as of those timbers the joining was distant, by two on each side braces from the end part were kept apart;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Both pairs were kept apart by two-foot beams let in from above, equal to the width of the joint between the piles, and secured at the ends by two braces on each side.

sentences.latin: quibus disclusis atque in contrariam partem revinctis, tanta erat operis firmitudo atque ea rerum natura ut, quo maior vis aquae se incitavisset, hoc artius inligata tenerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which being kept apart and in the opposite direction bound back, so great was of the work the strength and that of things the nature that, by how much greater the force of water itself had incited, by this more tightly bound they were held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which being kept apart and in the opposite direction bound back, so great was of the work the firmness and that of things the nature that, by how much greater the force of water itself had incited, by this more closely bound they were held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since these were kept apart and secured in opposite directions, the strength of the structure and the nature of the design were such that the greater the force of the water, the more tightly the parts were held together.

sentences.latin: Haec derecta materia iniecta contexebantur ac longuriis cratibusque consternebantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These with straight timber thrown on were being woven together and with poles and hurdles were being covered;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These with straight timber thrown on were being woven together and with poles and hurdles were being covered;
sentences.naturalTranslation: These were connected by straight timbers laid across them and then covered with poles and hurdles.

sentences.latin: ac nihilo setius sublicae et ad inferiorem partem fluminis oblique agebantur, quae pro ariete subiectae et cum omni opere coniunctae vim fluminis exciperent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: and by nothing less piles also at the lower part of the river obliquely were being driven, which as a buttress placed under and with the whole work joined the force of the river might receive,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and by nothing less piles also at the lower part of the river obliquely were being driven, which as a buttress placed under and with the whole work joined the force of the river might take up,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, piles were also driven obliquely on the downstream side of the river to serve as a buttress and, being connected to the whole structure, to sustain the force of the current.

sentences.latin: et aliae item supra pontem mediocri spatio, ut, si arborum trunci sive naves deiciendi operis causa essent a barbaris missae, his defensoribus earum rerum vis minueretur neu ponti nocerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and others likewise above the bridge at a moderate distance, so that, if of trees trunks or ships for the sake of throwing down the work had been by the barbarians sent, by these defenders of those things the force might be lessened nor to the bridge they might do harm.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and others likewise above the bridge at a moderate distance, so that, if of trees trunks or ships for the sake of throwing down the work had been by the barbarians sent, by these defenders of those things the force might be diminished nor to the bridge they might do harm.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Other piles were also placed a short distance upstream so that if the barbarians sent down tree trunks or ships to destroy the work, these protectors might lessen the force of such things and prevent them from damaging the bridge.

sentences.latin: Diebus X, quibus materia coepta erat comportari, omni opere effecto exercitus traducitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Within days ten, in which the material begun had been to be collected, the whole work having been finished the army is led across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Within days ten, in which the material had begun to be collected, the whole work being finished the army is led across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Within ten days of the time the collection of materials began, the entire work was completed and the army was led across.

sentences.latin: Caesar ad utramque partem pontis firmo praesidio relicto in fines Sugambrorum contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar at each part of the bridge a strong guard having been left into the territories of the Sugambri hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar at each part of the bridge a strong guard having been left into the territories of the Sugambri hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Leaving a strong guard at both ends of the bridge, Caesar hastened into the territory of the Sugambri.

sentences.latin: Interim a compluribus civitatibus ad eum legati veniunt; quibus pacem atque amicitiam petentibus liberaliter respondet obsidesque ad se adduci iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile from several states to him ambassadors come; to whom peace and friendship seeking generously he responds and hostages to himself to be brought he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile from several states to him ambassadors come; to these peace and friendship seeking kindly he responds and hostages to himself to be brought he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, ambassadors from several states came to him; to these, who were seeking peace and friendship, he responded generously and ordered hostages to be brought to him.

sentences.latin: At Sugambri, ex eo tempore quo pons institui coeptus est fuga comparata, hortantibus iis quos ex Tencteris atque Usipetibus apud se habebant, finibus suis excesserant suaque omnia exportaverant seque in solitudinem ac silvas abdiderant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the Sugambri, from that time in which the bridge to be built was begun, flight having been prepared, those urging whom from the Tencteri and Usipetes among themselves they were having, from their own borders had departed and their own all things had carried out and themselves into solitude and woods had hidden.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the Sugambri, from that time in which the bridge to be built was begun flight having been prepared, urging those whom from the Tencteri and Usipetes among themselves they were having, from territories their own had departed and their own all things had carried away and themselves into solitude and woods had hidden.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the Sugambri, from the moment the bridge began to be built, prepared for flight; encouraged by those of the Tencteri and Usipetes whom they were sheltering, they left their territory, carried away all their possessions, and hid themselves in the wilderness and the forests.

sentences.latin: Caesar paucos dies in eorum finibus moratus, omnibus vicis aedificiisque incensis frumentisque succisis, se in fines Ubiorum recepit atque his auxilium suum pollicitus, si a Suebis premerentur, haec ab iis cognovit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar a few days in their borders having delayed, all villages and buildings having been burned and crops having been cut down, himself into the borders of the Ubii withdrew and to these his own help having promised, if by the Suebi they were pressed, these things from them he learned:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar a few days in their territories having delayed, all villages and buildings being burned and crops being cut down, himself into the territories of the Ubii withdrew and to these help his own having promised, if by the Suebi they should be pressed, these things from them he learned:
sentences.naturalTranslation: After staying a few days in their territory, burning all the villages and buildings and cutting down the crops, Caesar withdrew into the territory of the Ubii; having promised them his assistance if they were hard-pressed by the Suebi, he learned the following from them:

sentences.latin: Suebos, postea quam per exploratores pontem fieri comperissent, more suo concilio habito nuntios in omnes partes dimisisse, uti de oppidis demigrarent, liberos, uxores suaque omnia in silvis deponerent atque omnes qui arma ferre possent unum in locum convenirent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That the Suebi, after that through scouts the bridge to be made they had found out, in their own custom a council having been held, messengers into all parts had sent out, that from towns they should depart, children, wives and their own all things in the woods they should place and all who arms to bear were able into one place should assemble.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That the Suebi, after that through scouts the bridge to be made they had found out, in manner their own a council having been held messengers into all parts had sent out, that from towns they should depart, children, wives and their own all things in the woods they should deposit and all who arms to bear were able into one place should assemble.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He learned that the Suebi, after discovering through scouts that the bridge was being built, had held a council according to their custom and sent messengers in all directions, ordering the people to leave their towns, place their children, wives, and all their property in the forests, and that all who could bear arms should assemble in one place.

sentences.latin: Hunc esse delectum medium fere regionum earum quas Suebi obtinerent; hic Romanorum adventum expectare atque ibi decertare constituisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This to be chosen the middle nearly of regions those which the Suebi were holding; here of the Romans the arrival to wait for and there to fight it out they had decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This to be chosen the center nearly of regions those which the Suebi were occupying; here of the Romans the arrival to wait for and there to fight it out they had decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This spot had been chosen as being near the center of the regions which the Suebi occupied; here they had decided to await the arrival of the Romans and to fight a decisive battle.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi Caesar comperit, omnibus iis rebus confectis, quarum rerum causa exercitum traducere constituerat, ut Germanis metum iniceret, ut Sugambros ulcisceretur, ut Ubios obsidione liberaret, diebus omnino XVIII trans Rhenum consumptis, satis et ad laudem et ad utilitatem profectum arbitratus se in Galliam recepit pontemque rescidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when Caesar found out, all those things having been finished, of which things for the sake the army to lead across he had decided, so that to the Germans fear he might inspire, so that the Sugambri he might punish, so that the Ubii from siege he might free, days in all eighteen across the Rhine having been spent, enough both for honor and for utility having been accomplished thinking, himself into Gaul he withdrew and the bridge he cut down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when Caesar found out, all those things being finished, of which things for the sake the army to lead across he had decided, that to the Germans fear he might strike, that the Sugambri he might punish, that the Ubii from siege he might free, days in all eighteen across the Rhine having been spent, enough both for honor and for utility having been accomplished thinking, himself into Gaul he withdrew and the bridge he cut down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar learned this, having accomplished all the objectives for which he had decided to lead his army acrossto strike fear into the Germans, to punish the Sugambri, and to relieve the Ubii from their siegeafter spending eighteen days in total across the Rhine, he decided that enough had been achieved for both prestige and practical purpose, and so he returned to Gaul and broke down the bridge.

sentences.latin: Exigua parte aestatis reliqua Caesar, etsi in his locis, quod omnis Gallia ad septentriones vergit, maturae sunt hiemes, tamen in Britanniam proficisci contendit, quod omnibus fere Gallicis bellis hostibus nostris inde subministrata auxilia intellegebat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: A small part of summer remaining Caesar, although in these places, because all Gaul toward the north turns, early are the winters, nevertheless into Britain to set out he hastened, because in all nearly Gallic wars to enemies our from there supplied reinforcements he was understanding,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A small part of summer remaining Caesar, although in these places, because all Gaul toward the north turns, early are the winters, nevertheless into Britain to set out hastened, because in all nearly Gallic wars to enemies our from there supplied reinforcements he was understanding,
sentences.naturalTranslation: With only a small part of the summer remaining, Caesar hastened to set out for Britain; although winters are early in these regions because all of Gaul lies toward the north, he nevertheless pushed forward because he understood that in almost all the Gallic wars, reinforcements had been supplied to our enemies from that source,

sentences.latin: et si tempus anni ad bellum gerendum deficeret, tamen magno sibi usui fore arbitrabatur, si modo insulam adiisset, genus hominum perspexisset, loca, portus, aditus cognovisset; quae omnia fere Gallis erant incognita.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and if the time of year for war to be waged was failing, nevertheless of great to him use to be he was thinking, if only the island he had approached, the race of men he had seen, the places, harbors, approaches he had learned; which all things nearly to the Gauls were unknown.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and if the time of year for war to be waged should fail, nevertheless of great to himself use to be it would be he was thinking, if only the island he had visited, the race of men he had seen, the places, ports, approaches he had learned; which all things nearly to the Gauls were unknown.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and even if the time of year was insufficient for waging war, he still thought it would be of great use to him if he only visited the island, saw the character of the people, and became acquainted with the terrain, the harbors, and the landing-places, nearly all of which were unknown to the Gauls.

sentences.latin: Neque enim temere praeter mercatores illo adit quisquam, neque his ipsis quicquam praeter oram maritimam atque eas regiones quae sunt contra Galliam notum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For neither blindly except merchants to that place goes anyone, nor to these themselves anything except the shore maritime and those regions which are opposite Gaul known is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For neither blindly except merchants thither goes anyone, nor to these themselves anything except the shore maritime and those regions which are opposite Gaul known is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For no one goes there without good reason except merchants, and even to them, nothing is known except the sea coast and those regions which face Gaul.

sentences.latin: Itaque vocatis ad se undique mercatoribus, neque quanta esset insulae magnitudo neque quae aut quantae nationes incolerent, neque quem usum belli haberent aut quibus institutis uterentur, neque qui essent ad maiorem navium multitudinem idonei portus reperire poterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so having been called to himself from all sides merchants, neither how great was of the island the size nor what or how great nations were inhabiting, nor what practice of war they were having or what customs they were using, nor which were for a greater of ships multitude suitable harbors to find he was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore having called to himself from all sides merchants, neither how great was of the island the size nor what or how great nations were inhabiting, nor what practice of war they were having or what customs they were using, nor which were for a larger of ships multitude suitable ports to find out he was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, although he summoned merchants from all quarters, he could not learn the size of the island, which or how many nations inhabited it, what system of war they practiced, what customs they followed, or which harbors were suitable for a large fleet of ships.

sentences.latin: Ad haec cognoscenda, prius quam periculum faceret, idoneum esse arbitratus C. Volusenum cum navi longa praemittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For these things to be learned, before that a trial he should make, suitable to be thinking Gaius Volusenus with a ship long he sends ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For these things to be learned, before that a trial he should make, suitable to be thinking Gaius Volusenus with a ship long he sends ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To find out these things, before making the attempt himself, he sent Gaius Volusenus ahead with a warship, considering him a suitable person for the task.

sentences.latin: Huic mandat ut exploratis omnibus rebus ad se quam primum revertatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this [man] he mandates that, all things having been explored, to him as first as possible he should return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one he mandates that, having explored all things, to himself as soon as possible he should return.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered this man to return to him as soon as possible after investigating everything.

sentences.latin: Ipse cum omnibus copiis in Morinos proficiscitur, quod inde erat brevissimus in Britanniam traiectus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself with all forces into the Morini sets out, because from there was the shortest into Britain crossing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself with all forces into the Morini sets out, because from there was the shortest into Britain crossing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself set out for the territory of the Morini with all his forces, because the crossing to Britain from there was the shortest.

sentences.latin: Huc naves undique ex finitimis regionibus et quam superiore aestate ad Veneticum bellum fecerat classem iubet convenire.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To here ships from all sides from neighboring regions and which in the previous summer for the Venetic war he had made the fleet he orders to assemble.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To here ships from all sides from the neighboring regions and which in the previous summer for the Venetian war he had made a fleet he orders to assemble.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered ships from all the neighboring regions and the fleet he had built the previous summer for the war against the Veneti to assemble here.

sentences.latin: Interim, consilio eius cognito et per mercatores perlato ad Britannos, a compluribus insulae civitatibus ad eum legati veniunt, qui polliceantur obsides dare atque imperio populi Romani obtemperare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile, his plan having been known and through merchants carried to the Britons, from several of the island's states to him ambassadors come, who might promise hostages to give and to the command of the Roman people to obey.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile, his plan having been known and through merchants carried to the Britons, from several of the island's states to him ambassadors come, who might promise hostages to give and to the command of the Roman people to obey.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, his plan having become known and reported to the Britons by merchants, ambassadors from several of the island's states came to him to promise to give hostages and to submit to the authority of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Quibus auditis, liberaliter pollicitus hortatusque ut in ea sententia permanerent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been heard, generously having promised and having exhorted that in that purpose they should remain,
