sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been heard, liberally having promised and having encouraged that in that sentiment they should remain,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After hearing them, he made generous promises and encouraged them to remain true to that intention,

sentences.latin: eos domum remittit et cum iis una Commium, quem ipse Atrebatibus superatis regem ibi constituerat, cuius et virtutem et consilium probabat et quem sibi fidelem esse arbitrabatur cuiusque auctoritas in his regionibus magni habebatur, mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: them home he sends back and with them together Commius, whom he himself, the Atrebates having been overcome, king there had appointed, whose both courage and counsel he approved and whom to himself faithful to be he thought and whose authority in these regions of great [value] was held, he sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: them home he sends back and with them together Commius, whom he himself, the Atrebates having been overcome, king there had established, of whom both the virtue and counsel he was approving and whom to himself faithful to be he was thinking and whose authority in these regions great was held, he sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he sent them back home and along with them Commius, whom he had appointed king there after defeating the Atrebates; he respected Commius's courage and judgment, believed him to be loyal, and knew his influence was highly regarded in those regions.

sentences.latin: Huic imperat quas possit adeat civitates horteturque ut populi Romani fidem sequantur seque celeriter eo venturum nuntiet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this [man] he commands which he can he should visit states and should exhort that of the Roman people the protection they should follow and himself quickly there to be about to come he should announce.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one he commands what he can he should visit states and should encourage that of the Roman people the protection they should follow and himself quickly there to be about to come he should announce.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered him to visit as many states as possible, to urge them to seek the protection of the Roman people, and to announce that he himself would soon arrive there.

sentences.latin: Volusenus perspectis regionibus omnibus quantum ei facultatis dari potuit, qui navi egredi ac se barbaris committere non auderet, V die ad Caesarem revertitur quaeque ibi perspexisset renuntiat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Volusenus, having examined regions all as much as to him of opportunity to be given was able, who from the ship to go out and himself to the barbarians to entrust not did dare, on the fifth day to Caesar returns and what things there he had examined he reports.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Volusenus, having surveyed regions all as much as to him of opportunity to be given was able, who from the ship to go out and himself to the barbarians to commit not was daring, on the fifth day to Caesar returns and what things there he had surveyed he reports.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Volusenus, having observed all the regions as much as opportunity allowed for one who did not dare to disembark or entrust himself to the barbarians, returned to Caesar on the fifth day and reported what he had discovered there.

sentences.latin: Dum in his locis Caesar navium parandarum causa moratur, ex magna parte Morinorum ad eum legati venerunt, qui se de superioris temporis consilio excusarent, quod homines barbari et nostrae consuetudinis imperiti bellum populo Romano fecissent, seque ea quae imperasset facturos pollicerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While in these places Caesar of ships to be prepared for the sake delays, from a great part of the Morini to him ambassadors came, who themselves concerning of the previous time the plan might excuse, because men barbarian and of our custom unskilled war on the Roman people they had made, and themselves those things which he had commanded to be about to do they might promise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While in these places Caesar for the sake of ships to be prepared lingers, from a great part of the Morini to him ambassadors came, who themselves concerning the previous time's plan might excuse, because men barbarian and of our custom unskilled war on the Roman people they had made, and themselves those things which he had commanded they would do they were promising.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While Caesar delayed in these parts to prepare his ships, ambassadors from a large portion of the Morini came to him to excuse their past conduct, claiming that as barbarians unfamiliar with our customs they had made war on the Roman people, and promising to do whatever he commanded.

sentences.latin: Hoc sibi Caesar satis oportune accidisse arbitratus, quod neque post tergum hostem relinquere volebat neque belli gerendi propter anni tempus facultatem habebat neque has tantularum rerum occupationes Britanniae anteponendas iudicabat, magnum iis numerum obsidum imperat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This for himself Caesar sufficiently opportunely to have happened having thought, because neither after his back an enemy to leave he was wishing nor of war to be waged on account of of the year the time opportunity he was having nor these of so small things preoccupations to Britain to be preferred he was judging, a large to them number of hostages he commands.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This for himself Caesar sufficiently opportunely to have happened thinking, because neither after his back the enemy to leave he was wishing nor of war to be waged on account of the year's time the opportunity he was having nor these of such small things occupations to Britain to be preferred he was judging, a great to them number of hostages he commands.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, thinking this had happened quite opportunely for him because he did not want to leave an enemy behind him, nor did he have the opportunity to wage war due to the time of year, nor did he judge that these trivial matters should take precedence over Britain, demanded a large number of hostages from them.

sentences.latin: Quibus adductis eos in fidem recipit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which [hostages] having been brought, them into [his] protection he receives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been brought, them into protection he receives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these hostages were brought to him, he took them under his protection.

sentences.latin: Navibus circiter LXXX onerariis coactis contractisque, quot satis esse ad duas transportandas legiones existimabat, quod praeterea navium longarum habebat quaestori, legatis praefectisque distribuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ships about 80 transport having been collected and brought together, as many as enough to be for two to-be-transported legions he was thinking, what besides of ships long [warships] he was having to the quaestor, legates and prefects he distributed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ships about eighty transport collected and brought together, as many as enough to be for two to be transported legions he was thinking, what besides of ships long he was having to the quaestor, to the legates and to the prefects he distributed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having collected and brought together about eighty transport ships, which he considered sufficient for transporting two legions, he assigned the warships he had in addition to the quaestor, legates, and prefects.

sentences.latin: Huc accedebant XVIII onerariae naves, quae ex eo loco a milibus passuum VIII vento tenebantur quo minus in eundem portum venire possent: has equitibus tribuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To here were added 18 transport ships, which from that place by miles of paces 8 by wind were being held back by which less into the same harbor to come they were able: these to the horsemen he assigned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To here were added eighteen transport ships, which from that place from miles of paces eight by the wind were being held so that less into the same port to come they were able: these to the cavalry he assigned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To these were added eighteen transport ships which were being held back by the wind eight miles from that place, preventing them from reaching the same harbor; these he assigned to the cavalry.

sentences.latin: Reliquum exercitum Q. Titurio Sabino et L. Aurunculeio Cottae legatis in Menapios atque in eos pagos Morinorum a quibus ad eum legati non venerant ducendum dedit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The remaining army to Quintus Titurius Sabinus and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta legates into the Menapii and into those districts of the Morini from whom to him ambassadors not had come to-be-led he gave;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The remaining army to Q. Titurius Sabinus and L. Aurunculeius Cotta legates into the Menapii and into those districts of the Morini from which to him ambassadors not had come to be led he gave;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He gave the rest of the army to his legates, Quintus Titurius Sabinus and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta, to be led against the Menapii and those districts of the Morini from which ambassadors had not come to him.

sentences.latin: Sulpicium Rufum legatum cum eo praesidio quod satis esse arbitrabatur portum tenere iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sulpicius Rufus the legate with that garrison which enough to be he was judging the harbor to hold he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sulpicius Rufus the legate with that garrison which enough to be he was thinking the port to hold he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the legate Sulpicius Rufus to hold the harbor with a garrison he considered sufficient.

sentences.latin: His constitutis rebus, nactus idoneam ad navigandum tempestatem III. fere vigilia solvit equitesque in ulteriorem portum progredi et naves conscendere et se sequi iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been arranged things, having obtained suitable for sailing weather at the third nearly watch he set sail and the horsemen into the further harbor to proceed and the ships to board and himself to follow he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These established things, having obtained suitable for sailing weather at the third almost watch he set sail and the cavalry into the further port to proceed and ships to board and himself to follow he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After making these arrangements, having found weather suitable for sailing, he set sail at about the third watch and ordered the cavalry to proceed to the further harbor, board the ships, and follow him.

sentences.latin: A quibus cum paulo tardius esset administratum, ipse hora diei circiter IIII. cum primis navibus Britanniam attigit atque ibi in omnibus collibus expositas hostium copias armatas conspexit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whom when a little more slowly it had been administered, himself at hour of day about the fourth with the first ships Britain he reached and there on all the hills displayed of the enemies forces armed he saw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By whom when a little too slowly it had been administered, himself at the hour of the day about the fourth with the first ships Britain reached and there on all the hills displayed of the enemies forces armed he beheld.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since they carried out these orders a little too slowly, he himself reached Britain with the first ships at about the fourth hour of the day, and there he saw the armed forces of the enemy displayed on all the hills.

sentences.latin: Cuius loci haec erat natura atque ita montibus angustis mare continebatur, uti ex locis superioribus in litus telum adigi posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which place this was the nature and so by mountains narrow the sea was being hemmed in, that from places higher onto the shore a weapon to be hurled was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of which place this was the nature and so by mountains narrow the sea was contained, that from places higher onto the shore a weapon to be thrown was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The nature of this place was such, and the sea was so closely hemmed in by steep cliffs, that a weapon could be hurled from the higher ground onto the shore.

sentences.latin: Hunc ad egrediendum nequaquam idoneum locum arbitratus, dum reliquae naves eo convenirent ad horam nonam in ancoris expectavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This for disembarking by no means suitable place having judged, until the remaining ships there should come together to the hour ninth in anchors he waited.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This for disembarking by no means suitable place thinking, while the remaining ships there should assemble until the hour ninth in anchors he waited.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Judging this place to be by no means suitable for landing, he waited at anchor until the ninth hour for the rest of the ships to assemble there.

sentences.latin: Interim legatis tribunisque militum convocatis et quae ex Voluseno cognovisset et quae fieri vellet ostendit monuitque, ut rei militaris ratio, maximeque ut maritimae res postularent, ut, cum celerem atque instabilem motum haberent, ad nutum et ad tempus D omnes res ab iis administrarentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile the legates and tribunes of soldiers having been called together both what from Volusenus he had learned and what to be done he was wishing he showed and warned, as of military matter the system, and especially as maritime matters were demanding, that, since a swift and unstable motion they were having, at a nod and at the time all things by them should be administered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile legates and tribunes of soldiers having been called together and what from Volusenus he had learned and what to be done he was wishing he showed and warned, as military science's method, and especially as maritime matters were demanding, that, since a swift and unstable motion they were having, at a nod and at the time all things by them should be administered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, having summoned the legates and military tribunes, he revealed what he had learned from Volusenus and what he wanted done; he warned them that, as military science and especially maritime affairs requiredsince they involve swift and unstable movementall orders must be carried out by them at a moment's notice and on time.

sentences.latin: His dimissis et ventum et aestum uno tempore nactus secundum, dato signo et sublatis ancoris, circiter milia passuum VII ab eo loco progressus aperto ac plano litore naves constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been dismissed, both wind and tide at one time having obtained favorable, the signal having been given and the anchors having been raised, about miles of paces seven from that place having advanced, on an open and flat shore the ships he stationed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been dismissed, and both wind and tide at one time having obtained favorable, the signal having been given and anchors having been raised, about miles of paces seven from that place having advanced, on an open and flat shore the ships he stationed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After dismissing them, having found both the wind and the tide favorable at the same time, he gave the signal, weighed anchor, and advanced about seven miles from that spot, where he stationed the ships on an open and level beach.

sentences.latin: At barbari, consilio Romanorum cognito praemisso equitatu et essedariis, quo plerumque genere in proeliis uti consuerunt, reliquis copiis subsecuti nostros navibus egredi prohibebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the barbarians, the plan of the Romans having been known, having sent ahead the cavalry and the charioteers, which mostly kind in battles to use they were accustomed, with the remaining forces having followed, our [men] from the ships to depart they were prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the barbarians, the plan of the Romans having been learned, the cavalry and charioteers having been sent ahead, which type mostly in battles to use they were accustomed, with the remaining forces having followed, our men from the ships to go out they were preventing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the barbarians, upon learning the Romans' plan, sent forward their cavalry and charioteersa type of force they were accustomed to using in battleand followed with the rest of their troops, attempting to prevent our men from disembarking.

sentences.latin: Erat ob has causas summa difficultas, quod naves propter magnitudinem nisi in alto constitui non poterant, militibus autem, ignotis locis, impeditis manibus, magno et gravi onere armorum oppressis simul et de navibus desiliendum et in fluctibus consistendum et cum hostibus erat pugnandum,
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was for these causes the greatest difficulty, because the ships on account of size except in the deep to be stationed were not able, by the soldiers however, in unknown places, with hindered hands, by a great and heavy burden of arms oppressed, at the same time both from the ships it had to be jumped down and in the waves it had to be stood and with the enemies it had to be fought,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was for these causes the greatest difficulty, because the ships on account of size except in the deep to be stationed were not able, by the soldiers however, in unknown places, with hindered hands, by a great and heavy burden of arms oppressed, at the same time both from the ships it must be jumped down and in the waves it must be stood and with the enemies it had to be fought,
sentences.naturalTranslation: For these reasons, there was the greatest difficulty: the ships, because of their size, could only be stationed in deep water; meanwhile, the soldiers, in unfamiliar places, with their hands encumbered and weighed down by a heavy load of armor, had to jump from the ships, keep their footing in the waves, and fight the enemy all at once.

sentences.latin: cum illi aut ex arido aut paulum in aquam progressi omnibus membris expeditis, notissimis locis, audacter tela coicerent et equos insuefactos incitarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: while those either from the dry [land] or a little into the water having advanced, with all limbs unencumbered, in very well-known places, boldly weapons were hurling and horses trained [to this] were urging on.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: while those either from the dry land or a little into the water having advanced, with all limbs unencumbered, in very well-known places, boldly weapons were hurling and horses trained [to this] were urging on.
sentences.naturalTranslation: while the enemy, either from dry land or having advanced only a little into the water, with all their limbs free and in places they knew perfectly, were boldly hurling weapons and spurring on horses trained for such conditions.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus nostri perterriti atque huius omnino generis pugnae imperiti, non eadem alacritate ac studio quo in pedestribus uti proeliis consuerant utebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which things our [men] terrified and of this altogether kind of battle unskilled, not with the same alacrity and zeal which in infantry to use battles they had been accustomed were using.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which things our men terrified and of this altogether kind of battle unskilled, not with the same alacrity and zeal which in infantry to use battles they had been accustomed were using.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by these circumstances and being completely inexperienced in this kind of fighting, our men did not display the same eagerness and zeal they were accustomed to showing in battles on land.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi Caesar animadvertit, naves longas, quarum et species erat barbaris inusitatior et motus ad usum expeditior, paulum removeri ab onerariis navibus et remis incitari et ad latus apertum hostium constitui atque inde fundis, sagittis, tormentis hostes propelli ac submoveri iussit; quae res magno usui nostris fuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when Caesar noticed, the long ships, of which both the appearance was to the barbarians more unusual and the movement for use more ready, a little to be removed from the transport ships and by oars to be incited and at the side open of the enemies to be stationed and from there with slings, arrows, engines the enemies to be driven off and moved back he ordered; which thing for great use to ours was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when Caesar noticed, the long ships, of which both the appearance was to the barbarians more unusual and the movement for use more ready, a little to be moved back from the transport ships and by oars to be incited and at the side open of the enemies to be stationed and from there with slings, arrows, engines the enemies to be driven off and moved away he ordered; which thing for great use to our men was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar noticed this, he ordered the warshipswhose appearance was less familiar to the barbarians and whose movement was more agileto be moved back slightly from the transport ships, rowed forward, and stationed against the enemy's exposed flank. From there, the enemy was to be driven back and cleared away with slings, arrows, and artillery; this maneuver proved to be of great use to our men.

sentences.latin: Nam et navium figura et remorum motu et inusitato genere tormentorum permoti barbari constiterunt ac paulum modo pedem rettulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For both by the ships' shape and the oars' motion and the unusual kind of engines moved the barbarians stopped and a little only the foot they brought back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For both by the ships' shape and the oars' movement and the unusual kind of engines moved, the barbarians stopped and a little only the foot they brought back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the barbarians, startled by the shape of the ships, the motion of the oars, and the unfamiliar nature of the artillery, halted and retreated just a little.

sentences.latin: Atque nostris militibus cunctantibus, maxime propter altitudinem maris, qui X legionis aquilam gerebat, obtestatus deos, ut ea res legioni feliciter eveniret, ' desilite', inquit, ' milites, nisi vultis aquilam hostibus prodere; ego certe meum rei publicae atque imperatori officium praestitero.'
sentences.referenceTranslation: And our soldiers hesitating, mostly on account of the depth of the sea, [he] who of the 10th legion the eagle was carrying, having called to witness the gods, that that thing for the legion happily might turn out, "Jump down," he said, "soldiers, unless you wish the eagle to the enemies to betray; I certainly my to the republic and to the commander duty shall have performed."
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And our soldiers hesitating, mostly on account of the depth of the sea, he who of the 10th legion the eagle was carrying, having called to witness the gods, that this thing for the legion happily might turn out, 'Jump down,' he said, 'soldiers, unless you wish the eagle to the enemies to betray; I certainly my to the republic and to the commander duty shall have performed.'
sentences.naturalTranslation: While our soldiers were hesitating, chiefly because of the depth of the sea, the man who carried the eagle of the Tenth Legion, after calling upon the gods to let the action turn out well for the legion, cried out: "Jump down, soldiers, unless you wish to betray the eagle to the enemy; I, at any rate, shall have done my duty to the republic and my general."

sentences.latin: Hoc cum voce magna dixisset, se ex navi proiecit atque in hostes aquilam ferre coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This when with a voice loud he had said, himself from the ship he threw and into the enemies the eagle to carry he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This when with a voice loud he had said, himself from the ship he threw and into the enemies the eagle to carry he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had said this with a loud voice, he threw himself from the ship and began to carry the eagle toward the enemy.

sentences.latin: Tum nostri cohortati inter se, ne tantum dedecus admitteretur, universi ex navi desiluerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then our [men] having encouraged among themselves, lest so great a disgrace be admitted, all together from the ship jumped down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then our men having encouraged among themselves, lest so great a disgrace be admitted, all together from the ship jumped down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then our men, having encouraged one another not to allow such a disgrace, jumped from the ship in a body.

sentences.latin: Hos item ex proximis primi navibus cum conspexissent, subsecuti hostibus adpropinquaverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These likewise from the nearest ships the first [men] when they had caught sight of, having followed closely to the enemies they approached.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These likewise from the nearest first ships when they had seen, having followed to the enemies they approached.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the men on the nearest ships saw this, they followed suit and advanced toward the enemy.

sentences.latin: Pugnatum est ab utrisque acriter.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was fought by both sides fiercely.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was fought by both sides fiercely.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Both sides fought fiercely.

sentences.latin: Nostri tamen, quod neque ordines servare neque firmiter insistere neque signa subsequi poterant atque alius alia ex navi quibuscumque signis occurrerat se adgregabat, magnopere perturbabantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our [men] however, because neither ranks to keep nor firmly to stand nor standards to follow they were able and one from one ship [and] another from another to whatever standards he had met himself was joining, greatly were being disturbed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men however, because neither ranks to keep nor firmly to stand nor standards to follow they were able and one from one ship with whatever standards he had met himself was joining, greatly were being disturbed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men, however, were thrown into great confusion because they could neither keep their ranks, stand firmly, nor follow their standards; instead, men from different ships would attach themselves to whatever standards they happened to encounter.

sentences.latin: hostes vero, notis omnibus vadis, ubi ex litore aliquos singulares ex navi egredientes conspexerant, incitatis equis impeditos adoriebantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: the enemies indeed, known all the shallows, when from the shore some scattered [men] from the ship disembarking they had caught sight of, urged on horses the hindered [men] they were attacking,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the enemies indeed, known all the shallows, when from the shore some single [men] from the ship coming out they had seen, with urged-on horses the hindered they were attacking,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy, on the other hand, knowing all the shallows, would spur on their horses and attack our hindered soldiers whenever they saw small groups disembarking from a ship.

sentences.latin: plures paucos circumsistebant, alii ab latere aperto in universos tela coniciebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: more [men] few [men] were surrounding, others from the side open against the whole [group] weapons were throwing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: many the few were surrounding, others from the side open against the whole [group] weapons were hurling.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Large numbers would surround a few of our men, while others threw weapons at the entire group from their exposed flank.

sentences.latin: Quod cum animadvertisset Caesar, scaphas longarum navium, item speculatoria navigia militibus compleri iussit, et quos laborantes conspexerat, his subsidia submittebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when had noticed Caesar, the skiffs of the long ships, likewise the scouting vessels with soldiers to be filled he ordered, and whom struggling he had caught sight of, to these reinforcements he was sending.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when had noticed Caesar, the skiffs of the long ships, likewise the scouting vessels with soldiers to be filled he ordered, and whom struggling he had seen, to these reinforcements he was sending.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar noticed this, he ordered the warships' boats and the scouting vessels to be filled with soldiers, and he sent reinforcements to those he saw struggling.

sentences.latin: Nostri, simul in arido constiterunt, suis omnibus consecutis, in hostes impetum fecerunt atque eos in fugam dederunt; neque longius prosequi potuerunt, quod equites cursum tenere atque insulam capere non potuerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our [men], as soon as on dry [land] they stood, their [comrades] all having followed, against the enemies an attack they made and them into flight they gave; nor further to pursue they were able, because the horsemen the course to hold and the island to reach not had been able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men, as soon as on dry land they stood, their own all having followed, against the enemies an attack they made and them into flight they gave; nor further to follow they were able, because the cavalry the course to hold and the island to reach had not been able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As soon as our men stood on dry land and all their comrades had joined them, they charged the enemy and put them to flight; however, they could not pursue them very far because the cavalry had been unable to maintain their course and reach the island.

sentences.latin: Hoc unum ad pristinam fortunam Caesari defuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This one [thing] to the former fortune to Caesar was lacking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This one [thing] to the former fortune to Caesar was lacking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was the only thing lacking from Caesar's previous good fortune.

sentences.latin: Hostes proelio superati, simul atque se ex fuga receperunt, statim ad Caesarem legatos de pace miserunt; obsides sese daturos quaeque imperasset facturos polliciti sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies in battle overcome, as soon as themselves from flight they recovered, immediately to Caesar envoys concerning peace they sent; hostages themselves to be about to give and what things he had commanded to be about to do they promised.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies in battle overcome, as soon as themselves from flight they recovered, immediately to Caesar envoys about peace they sent; hostages themselves to be about to give and what he had commanded to be about to do they promised.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy, defeated in battle, immediately sent envoys to Caesar to sue for peace as soon as they recovered from their flight; they promised to give hostages and to carry out whatever he commanded.

sentences.latin: Una cum his legatis Commius Atrebas venit, quem supra demonstraveram a Caesare in Britanniam praemissum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Together with these envoys Commius the Atrebatian came, whom above I had shown by Caesar into Britain sent ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Together with these envoys Commius the Atrebatian came, whom above I had shown by Caesar into Britain sent ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Commius the Atrebatian, whom I mentioned earlier had been sent ahead by Caesar into Britain, came along with these envoys.

sentences.latin: Hunc illi e navi egressum, cum ad eos oratoris modo Caesaris mandata deferret, comprehenderant atque in vincula coniecerant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man they, having stepped out from the ship, when to them in the manner of an envoy Caesar's mandates he was carrying, they had seized and into chains had thrown;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This [man] they, having stepped out from the ship, when to them in the manner of an envoy Caesar's mandates he was delivering, had seized and into chains had thrown;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had seized this man after he disembarked from the ship, while he was delivering Caesar's instructions to them in the character of an envoy, and had thrown him into chains;

sentences.latin: tum proelio facto remiserunt et in petenda pace eius rei culpam in multitudinem contulerunt et propter imprudentiam ut ignosceretur petiverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: then the battle having been made they sent back and in seeking peace of this thing the blame onto the multitude they laid and on account of ignorance that it might be pardoned they sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: then, a battle having been made, they sent [him] back and in seeking peace the blame of this thing onto the multitude they cast and on account of ignorance that it be pardoned they sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, after the battle was over, they sent him back; in seeking peace, they blamed the common people for the incident and requested that they be pardoned on the grounds of ignorance.

sentences.latin: Caesar questus quod, cum ultro in continentem legatis missis pacem ab se petissent, bellum sine causa intulissent, ignoscereseimprudentiae dixit obsidesque imperavit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar having complained because, when of their own accord onto the continent with envoys sent peace from him they had sought, war without cause they had brought on, to pardon himself to their ignorance he said and hostages he ordered;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar having complained because, when voluntarily into the continent with legates having been sent peace from him they had sought, war without cause they had brought, to pardon their ignorance he said and hostages he ordered;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar complained that although they had sent envoys to the continent of their own accord to seek peace from him, they had started a war without cause; nevertheless, he said he would pardon their ignorance and demanded hostages;

sentences.latin: quorum illi partem statim dederunt, partem ex longinquioribus locis arcessitam paucis diebus sese daturos dixerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of which they a part immediately gave, a part from more distant places summoned in a few days themselves to be about to give they said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom they a part immediately gave, a part from more distant places summoned in a few days themselves to be about to give they said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They gave a portion of these immediately and said they would deliver the rest in a few days once they had been summoned from more distant locations.

sentences.latin: Interea suos in agros remigrare iusserunt, principesque undique convenire et se civitatesque suas Caesari commendare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile their own into the fields to return they ordered, and the leaders from all sides to assemble and themselves and states their own to Caesar to commend they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile their [people] into the fields to return they ordered, and the chiefs from everywhere to assemble and themselves and states their own to Caesar to commend they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, they ordered their people to return to the fields, and the leaders began to assemble from all sides and entrust themselves and their states to Caesar.

sentences.latin: His rebus pace confirmata, post diem quartum quam est in Britanniam ventum naves XVIII, de quibus supra demonstratum est, quae equites sustulerant, ex superiore portu leni vento solverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things by peace having been confirmed, after the day fourth than it was into Britain come, ships 18, about which above it has been shown, which the cavalry had taken up, from the upper port with a gentle wind set sail.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things with peace having been confirmed, after the fourth day than it was into Britain come, ships 18, about which above it was shown, which cavalry had taken up, from the upper port with a gentle wind set sail.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Peace having been established by these terms, four days after the arrival in Britain, the eighteen ships mentioned above, which had taken the cavalry on board, set sail from the upper harbor with a gentle breeze.

sentences.latin: Quae cum adpropinquarent Britanniae et ex castris viderentur, tanta tempestas subito coorta est ut nulla earum cursum tenere posset, sed aliae eodem unde erant profectae referrentur, aliae ad inferiorem partem insulae, quae est propius solis occasum, magno suo cum periculo deicerentur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when they were approaching Britain and from the camp were seen, so great a storm suddenly arose that none of them course to hold was able, but some to the same place whence they had set out were carried back, others to the lower part of the island, which is nearer the sun's setting, with great their own with danger were driven down;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when they were approaching Britain and from the camp were seen, so great a storm suddenly arose that none of them [their] course to hold was able, but some to the same [place] whence they had set out were carried back, others to the lower part of the island, which is nearer the sun's setting, with great their own with danger were cast down;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these were approaching Britain and were visible from the camp, such a great storm suddenly arose that none of them could hold their course; instead, some were carried back to the same place they had started from, while others were driven down to the lower part of the island, which is closer to the west, at great risk to themselves;

sentences.latin: quae tamen ancoris iactis cum fluctibus complerentur, necessario adversa nocte in altum provectae continentem petierunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which however anchors having been cast when by the waves they were being filled, by necessity with the night being unfavorable into the deep having put out the continent they sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which however with anchors having been cast when with waves they were being filled, by necessity with the night being adverse into the deep having been carried the continent sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although they had cast anchor, they began to fill with water from the waves; consequently, they were forced to put out into the open sea despite the darkness and head for the continent.

sentences.latin: Eadem nocte accidit ut esset luna plena, qui dies a maritimos aestus maximos in Oceano efficere consuevit, nostrisque id erat incognitum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the same night it happened that there was a moon full, which day by the maritime tides greatest in the Ocean to cause is accustomed, and to our men this was unknown.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the same night it happened that there was a moon full, which day the maritime tides greatest in the Ocean to effect is accustomed, and to our [men] it was unknown.
sentences.naturalTranslation: That same night it happened to be a full moon, a time which usually causes the highest maritime tides in the Ocean, a fact unknown to our men.

sentences.latin: Ita uno tempore et longas naves, [quibus Caesar exercitum transportandum curaverat,] quas Caesar in aridum subduxerat, aestus complebat, et onerarias, quae ad ancoras erant deligatae, tempestas adflictabat, neque ulla nostris facultas aut administrandi aut auxiliandi dabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus at one time both the long ships, [by which Caesar the army to be transported had cared for,] which Caesar onto the dry land had drawn up, the tide was filling, and the transport ships, which to anchors had been fastened, the storm was distressing, nor any to our men opportunity either of managing or of helping was given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus at one time both the long ships, [by which Caesar the army to be transported had cared for,] which Caesar onto dry [land] had drawn up, the tide was filling, and the transport ships, which to anchors had been fastened, the storm was afflicting, nor any to our [men] opportunity either of managing or of helping was given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus at the same time the tide was filling the warships which Caesar had used to transport the army and had drawn up onto the dry land, while the storm was battering the transport ships which were fastened at anchor; nor was any opportunity given to our men to manage the ships or provide assistance.

sentences.latin: Compluribus navibus fractis, reliquae cum essent funibus, ancoris reliquisque armamentis amissis ad navigandum inutiles, magna, id quod necesse erat accidere, totius exercitus perturbatio facta est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several ships having been broken, the remaining since they were, ropes, anchors, and other tackle having been lost, for navigating useless, a great, that which necessary was to happen, of the whole army a disturbance was made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With several ships having been broken, the rest since they were with ropes, anchors, and the rest of the tackle having been lost for navigating useless, a great, that which necessary was to happen, of the whole army perturbation was made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With several ships wrecked, the rest were useless for sailing because their ropes, anchors, and other rigging had been lost; consequently, as was bound to happen, a great panic spread throughout the whole army.

sentences.latin: Neque enim naves erant aliae quibus reportari possent, et omnia deerant quae ad reficiendas naves erant usui, et, quod omnibus constabat hiemari in Gallia oportere, frumentum in his locis in hiemem provisum non erat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For neither ships were others by which they could be carried back, and all things were lacking which for repairing ships were for a use, and, because to all it was evident to winter in Gaul to be necessary, grain in these places for the winter provided had not been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For neither ships were others by which they could be carried back, and all things were lacking which for repairing ships were for use, and, because to all it was clear to winter in Gaul to be necessary, grain in these places for the winter provided was not.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For there were no other ships available to carry them back, and everything needed for repairing ships was lacking; furthermore, since it was clear to everyone that they must winter in Gaul, no grain had been provided in these parts for the winter.

sentences.latin: optimum factu esse duxerunt rebellione facta frumento commeatuque nostros prohibere et rem in hiemem producere, quod his superatis aut reditu interclusis neminem postea belli inferendi causa in Britanniam transiturum confidebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The best thing to do to be they thought, a rebellion having been made, from grain and supplies our men to prohibit and the matter into winter to prolong, because these having been overcome or from return shut off, no one afterwards of war bringing for the sake into Britain would cross they were confident.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: best to be done they considered, a rebellion having been made, from grain and supplies our [men] to prohibit and the matter into winter to prolong, because these having been overcome or from return shut off no one afterward of war bringing for the sake into Britain to cross would they were confident.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They decided that the best course of action was to renew the war, cut off our men from grain and supplies, and prolong the campaign into the winter; they were confident that if these troops were defeated or cut off from their return, no one would ever again cross into Britain to wage war.

sentences.latin: Itaque rursus coniuratione facta paulatim ex castris discedere et suos clam ex agris deducere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so again a conspiracy having been made, little by little from the camp to depart and their own men secretly from the fields to lead out they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore again a conspiracy having been made gradually from the camp to depart and their [men] secretly from the fields to lead out they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having renewed their oath of conspiracy, they began to slip away from the camp little by little and secretly lead their men out of the fields.

sentences.latin: At Caesar, etsi nondum eorum consilia cognoverat, tamen et ex eventu navium suarum et ex eo quod obsides dare intermiserant fore id quod accidit suspicabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Caesar, although not yet their plans he had learned, nevertheless both from the fate of his ships and from that that hostages to give they had ceased, would be that which happened he was suspecting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Caesar, although not yet their plans he had learned, yet both from the outcome of ships his own and from that because hostages to give they had ceased to be about to be that which happened he was suspecting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Caesar, although he had not yet learned of their plans, nevertheless suspected what would happen, both from the disaster that had befallen his ships and from the fact that they had stopped sending hostages.

sentences.latin: Itaque ad omnes casus subsidia comparabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so for all emergencies resources he was preparing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore for all cases resources he was preparing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, he began preparing resources for every contingency.

sentences.latin: Nam et frumentum ex agris cotidie in castra conferebat et, quae gravissime adflictae erant naves, earum materia atque aere ad reliquas reficiendas utebatur et quae ad eas res erant usui ex continenti comportari iubebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For both grain from the fields daily into the camp he was bringing and, which most seriously damaged had been ships, of them the timber and bronze for the rest to be repaired he was using and what for those things were for a use from the continent to be brought he was ordering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For both grain from the fields daily into the camp he was bringing and, which most seriously afflicted had been ships, of them the timber and bronze for the rest to be repaired he was using and what for these things were for use from the continent to be brought he was ordering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he brought grain from the fields into the camp every day, used the timber and bronze from the most severely damaged ships to repair the others, and ordered whatever else was needed for these repairs to be brought from the continent.

sentences.latin: Itaque, cum summo studio a militibus administraretur, XII navibus amissis, reliquis ut navigarisatiscommode posset effecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so, since with the greatest zeal by the soldiers it was managed, twelve ships having been lost, with the rest that it could be sailed well enough he brought about.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore, since with greatest zeal by the soldiers it was managed, 12 ships having been lost, the rest that it could be sailed sufficiently conveniently he brought about.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, since the work was carried out with great zeal by the soldiers, although twelve ships were lost, he managed to make it possible for the rest to sail safely.

sentences.latin: Dum ea geruntur, legione ex consuetudine una frumentatum missa, quae appellabatur VII., neque ulla ad id tempus belli suspicione interposita, cum pars hominum in agris remaneret, pars etiam in castra ventitaret, ii qui pro portis castrorum in statione erant Caesari nuntiaverunt pulverem maiorem quam consuetudo ferret in ea parte videri quam in partem legio iter fecisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things are done, a legion according to custom one to forage having been sent, which was called the 7th, nor any at that time of war suspicion having been introduced, since part of the men in the fields was remaining, part also into the camp was coming often, those who before the gates of the camp on guard were to Caesar reported a dust larger than custom would bear in that part to be seen into which part the legion a march had made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things are being done, with a legion from custom one to forage sent, which was called the 7th, nor any to that time of war suspicion having been interposed, when part of the men in the fields was remaining, part also into the camp was coming often, those who before the gates of the camp on guard were to Caesar reported dust greater than custom would bear in that part to be seen than into which part the legion a journey had made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these things were going on, one legion (the 7th) had been sent out to forage as usual, and since no suspicion of war had arisen at that timewith some men remaining in the fields and others coming and going from the campthe guards on duty before the camp gates reported to Caesar that an unusually large cloud of dust was visible in the direction the legion had gone.

sentences.latin: Caesar---id quod erat---suspicatus aliquid novi a barbaris initum consilii, cohortes quae in statione erant secum in eam partem proficisci, ex reliquis duas in stationem succedere, reliquas armari et confestim sese subsequi iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesarthat which washaving suspected something of new by the barbarians to have been entered of a plan, the cohorts which on guard were with him into that part to set out, from the rest two into the guard post to succeed, the rest to be armed and immediately him to follow he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesarthat which washaving suspected something of new by the barbarians entered upon of plan, the cohorts which on guard were with him into that part to set out, from the rest two into the guard to succeed, the rest to be armed and immediately himself to follow he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, suspecting the truththat some new plot had been formed by the barbariansordered the cohorts on guard to set out with him in that direction, two of the others to take their place on guard, and the rest to arm themselves and follow him immediately.

sentences.latin: Cum paulo longius a castris processisset, suos ab hostibus premi atque aegre sustinere et conferta legione ex omnibus partibus tela coici animadvertit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When a little farther from the camp he had proceeded, his own [men] by the enemies to be pressed and with difficulty to hold out and, with the legion crowded together, from all parts weapons to be thrown he noticed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When a little farther from the camps he had proceeded, his own [men] by the enemies to be pressed and with difficulty to hold out and, the legion being crowded together, from all parts weapons to be thrown he noticed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had advanced a little way from the camp, he noticed that his men were being hard pressed by the enemy and were barely holding their ground, and that, with the legion packed closely together, missiles were being hurled from all sides.

sentences.latin: Nam quod omni ex reliquis partibus demesso frumento pars una erat reliqua, suspicati hostes huc nostros esse venturos noctu in silvis delituerant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For because, all from the remaining parts having been reaped grain, part one was remaining, having suspected the enemies hither our [men] to be about to come, by night in the woods they had hidden;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For because, all from the remaining parts having been reaped grain, part one was remaining, having suspected the enemies hither our [men] to be about to come by night in the woods they had hidden;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For because the grain had been reaped from all other areas and only one part remained, the enemy, suspecting our men would come here, had hidden in the woods during the night.

sentences.latin: tum dispersos depositis armis in metendo occupatos subito adorti paucis interfectis reliquos incertis ordinibus perturbaverant, simul equitatu atque essedis circumdederant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: then [them] dispersed, having laid down arms, in reaping occupied, suddenly having attacked, a few having been killed, the rest with uncertain ranks they had thrown into confusion, at the same time with cavalry and with chariots they had surrounded [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: then [them] dispersed, weapons having been laid down, in reaping occupied, suddenly having attacked, a few having been killed, the rest, ranks being uncertain, they had thrown into confusion, at the same time with cavalry and chariots they had surrounded [them].
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, suddenly attacking them while they were scattered and busy reaping with their arms laid aside, they killed a few and threw the rest into confusion in their disorganized ranks, while simultaneously surrounding them with cavalry and chariots.

sentences.latin: Genus hoc est ex essedis pugnae.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Kind this is from chariots of fighting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Kind this is from chariots of fighting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This is their way of fighting from chariots.

sentences.latin: Primo per omnes partes perequitant et tela coiciunt atque ipso terrore equorum et strepitu rotarum ordines plerumque perturbant, et cum se inter equitum turmas insinuaverunt, ex essedis desiliunt et pedibus proeliantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: First through all parts they ride through and weapons they throw and by the very terror of the horses and the noise of the wheels the ranks generally they throw into confusion, and when themselves among the of-cavalry troops they have insinuated, from the chariots they leap down and on feet they fight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: First through all parts they ride through and weapons they throw and by the very terror of the horses and the noise of the wheels the ranks for the most part they throw into confusion, and when themselves among the troops of cavalry they have insinuated, from the chariots they leap down and on feet they fight.
sentences.naturalTranslation: First they ride through all parts and hurl missiles, generally throwing the ranks into confusion by the mere terror of the horses and the noise of the wheels; and when they have worked their way among the troops of cavalry, they leap down from their chariots and fight on foot.

sentences.latin: Aurigae interim paulatim ex proelio excedunt atque ita currus conlocant ut, si illi a multitudine hostium premantur, expeditum ad suos receptum habeant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The drivers meanwhile little by little from the battle withdraw and so the chariots they station that, if those by a multitude of enemies should be pressed, an unimpeded to their own [men] retreat they might have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The charioteers meanwhile little by little from the battle withdraw and so the chariots they station that, if those by a multitude of enemies should be pressed, an unimpeded to their own [men] retreat they might have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the drivers gradually withdraw from the battle and position the chariots so that, if the fighters are hard pressed by a swarm of enemies, they have a clear line of retreat to their own side.

sentences.latin: Ita mobilitatem equitum, stabilitatem peditum in proeliis praestant, ac tantum usu cotidiano et exercitatione efficiunt uti in declivi ac praecipiti loco incitatos equos sustinere et brevi moderari ac flectere et per temonem percurrere et in iugo insistere et se inde in currus citissime recipere consuerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus the mobility of cavalry, the stability of infantry in battles they exhibit, and so much by use daily and by practice they effect that in a sloping and steep place urged-on horses to check and in a short [space] to manage and to turn and along the pole to run and on the yoke to stand and themselves from there into the chariots very quickly to recover they have become accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus the mobility of cavalry, the stability of infantry in battles they exhibit, and so much by use daily and exercise they effect that in sloping and steep place incited horses to check and in a short [space] to manage and to turn and along the pole to run through and on the yoke to stand and themselves from there into the chariots very quickly to recover they have become accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus they display the mobility of cavalry and the stability of infantry in battle, and through daily practice and exercise they become so proficient that they are accustomed to checking their horses at full gallop on steep and sloping ground, managing and turning them in a narrow space, running along the pole, standing on the yoke, and recovering themselves very quickly from there back into the chariots.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus perturbatis nostris [novitate pugnae] tempore oportunissimo Caesar auxilium tulit: namque eius adventu hostes constiterunt, nostri se ex timore receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which things, having been thrown into confusion our [men] [by the novelty of the fight], at a time most opportune Caesar help brought: for by his arrival the enemies stopped, our [men] themselves from fear recovered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which things, our [men] having been thrown into confusion [by the novelty of the fight], at a time most opportune Caesar help brought: for by his arrival the enemies halted, our [men] themselves from fear recovered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While our men were thrown into confusion by these tactics and the novelty of the fighting, Caesar brought help at a most opportune time; for at his arrival the enemy halted, and our men recovered from their fear.

sentences.latin: Quo facto, ad lacessendum hostem et committendum proelium alienum esse tempus arbitratus suo se loco continuit et brevi tempore intermisso in castra legiones reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which having been done, for the purpose of provoking the enemy and joining battle unfavorable to be the time having thought, in his own place himself he kept and, a short time having intervened, into the camp the legions he led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been done, for the provoking the enemy and the joining battle unfavorable to be the time having judged, in his own place himself he kept and, a short time having intervened, into the camp the legions he led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This being done, thinking the time was unfavorable for provoking the enemy and engaging in battle, he kept his position and, after a short interval, led the legions back to camp.

sentences.latin: Dum haec geruntur, nostris omnibus occupatis qui erant in agris reliqui discesserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these [things] are being done, our [men] all being occupied, [those] who were in the fields remaining departed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things are being done, our [men] all being occupied, [those] who were in the fields remaining departed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these things were going on and all our men were occupied, the rest of the enemy who were in the fields departed.

sentences.latin: Secutae sunt continuos complures dies tempestates, quae et nostros in castris continerent et hostem a pugna prohiberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Followed for continuous several days storms, which both our [men] in camps might keep and the enemy from battle might prohibit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Followed for continuous several days storms, which both our [men] in the camps might keep and the enemy from battle might prohibit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Storms followed for several consecutive days, which both kept our men in camp and prevented the enemy from fighting.

sentences.latin: Interim barbari nuntios in omnes partes dimiserunt paucitatemque nostrorum militum suis praedicaverunt et quanta praedae faciendae atque in perpetuum sui liberandi facultas daretur, si Romanos castris expulissent, demonstraverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile the barbarians messengers into all parts sent away and the small number of our soldiers to their [people] they proclaimed and how great of booty making and into perpetuity of themselves freeing opportunity might be given, if the Romans from the camps they had expelled, they demonstrated.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile the barbarians messengers into all parts sent out and the small number of our soldiers to their own [people] they proclaimed and how great of booty to be made and into perpetuity of themselves being freed opportunity was being given, if the Romans from the camp they had expelled, they demonstrated.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the barbarians sent messengers in all directions, reporting the small number of our soldiers to their people and pointing out what a great opportunity was offered for obtaining plunder and liberating themselves forever, if they could drive the Romans from their camp.

sentences.latin: His rebus celeriter magna multitudine peditatus equitatusque coacta ad castra venerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things quickly a great multitude of infantry and of cavalry having been collected to the camps they came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things quickly a large multitude of infantry and of cavalry having been collected, to the camp they came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By these means, having quickly collected a large force of infantry and cavalry, they advanced toward the camp.

sentences.latin: Caesar, etsi idem quod superioribus diebus acciderat fore videbat, ut, si essent hostes pulsi, celeritate periculum effugerent, tamen nactus equites circiter XXX, quos Commius Atrebas, de quo ante dictum est, secum transportaverat, legiones in acie pro castris constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, although the same thing which on previous days had happened would be he saw, that, if had been the enemies repulsed, by speed the danger they would escape, nevertheless having obtained horsemen about 30, whom Commius the Atrebatian, about whom before it has been said, with himself had transported, the legions in battle line before the camps he stationed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, although the same which on previous days had happened would be he saw, that, if should be the enemies repulsed, by speed the danger they would escape, nevertheless having obtained horsemen about 30, whom Commius the Atrebatian, about whom before it has been said, with himself had transported, the legions in battle line before the camp he stationed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar saw that the same thing that had happened on previous days would occurthat if the enemy were repulsed, they would use their speed to escape dangerhe nevertheless obtained about thirty horsemen whom Commius the Atrebatian (mentioned previously) had brought over with him, and drew up the legions in line of battle in front of the camp.

sentences.latin: Commisso proelio diutius nostrorum militum impetum hostes ferre non potuerunt ac terga verterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been joined the battle longer of our soldiers the attack the enemies to bear not were able and backs they turned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Joined the battle, longer of our soldiers the attack the enemies to bear not were able and backs they turned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once battle was joined, the enemy could no longer withstand the attack of our soldiers and turned their backs in flight.

sentences.latin: Quos tanto spatio secuti quantum cursu et viribus efficere potuerunt, complures ex iis occiderunt, deinde omnibus longe lateque aedificiis incensis se in castra receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom for as much space having followed as by running and by strengths to accomplish they were able, several from them they killed, then all far and wide buildings having been burned themselves into the camps they withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom for as much space having followed as by running and by strengths to effect they were able, several from them they killed, then all far and wide buildings having been set on fire themselves into the camp they withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having pursued them as far as their speed and strength allowed, they killed many of them, then, after burning all the buildings far and wide, they returned to camp.

sentences.latin: Eodem die legati ab hostibus missi ad Caesarem de pace venerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the same day ambassadors by the enemies sent to Caesar concerning peace came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the same day envoys by the enemies sent to Caesar concerning peace came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the same day, ambassadors sent by the enemy came to Caesar to treat for peace.

sentences.latin: His Caesar numerum obsidum quem ante imperaverat duplicavit eosque in continentem adduci iussit, quod propinqua die aequinoctii infirmis navibus hiemi navigationem subiciendam non existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these Caesar the number of hostages which before he had commanded doubled and them into the continent to be led he ordered, because with near the day of the equinox with weak ships to winter the navigation to be subjected not he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For these [men] Caesar the number of hostages which before he had commanded doubled and them into the continent to be brought he ordered, because, near being the day of the equinox, with weak ships to winter the navigation to be subjected not he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar doubled the number of hostages he had previously demanded from them and ordered them to be brought to the continent, because, with the equinox approaching, he did not think his voyage should be exposed to winter storms while his ships were in a weakened state.

sentences.latin: Ipse idoneam tempestatem nactus paulo post mediam noctem naves solvit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself suitable weather having obtained a little after middle night the ships he loosed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself suitable weather having obtained, a little after middle night the ships he loosed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having obtained favorable weather, he set sail a little after midnight,

sentences.latin: quae omnes incolumes ad continentem pervenerunt; sed ex iis onerariae duae eosdem portus quos reliquae capere non potuerunt et paulo infra delatae sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which all safe to the continent reached; but from them transport [ships] two the same ports which the rest to take not were able and a little below were carried down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which all safe to the continent reached; but from them transport ships two the same ports which the rest to reach not were able and a little below were carried down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and all the vessels reached the continent safely; however, two of the transport ships were unable to make the same ports as the rest and were carried a little further down the coast.

sentences.latin: Quibus ex navibus cum essent expositi milites circiter CCC atque in castra contenderent, Morini, quos Caesar in Britanniam proficiscens pacatos reliquerat, spe praedae adducti primo non ita magno suorum numero circumsteterunt ac, si sese interfici nollent, arma ponere iusserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From which ships when had been set out soldiers about 300 and into the camp were hastening, the Morini, whom Caesar setting out into Britain peaceful had left, by hope of booty led at first with not so great a number of their own surrounded [them] and, if themselves to be killed they did not wish, arms to put down they ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From which ships when there had been set out soldiers about 300 and into the camp they were hastening, the Morini, whom Caesar into Britain setting out pacified had left, by hope of booty led at first with a not so great of their own number surrounded [them] and, if themselves to be killed they did not wish, arms to put down they ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When about 300 soldiers had disembarked from these ships and were making for the camp, the Morini, whom Caesar had left in a state of peace when he set out for Britain, were drawn by the hope of plunder; they initially surrounded our men with a relatively small number of their own and ordered them to lay down their arms if they did not wish to be killed.

sentences.latin: Cum illi orbe facto sese defenderent, celeriter ad clamorem hominum circiter milia VI convenerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When those a circle having been made themselves were defending, quickly to the shout of men about thousands 6 came together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When those a circle having been made themselves were defending, quickly to the shout of men about thousands 6 came together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While our men defended themselves by forming a circle, about 6,000 of the enemy quickly assembled at the sound of the shouting.

sentences.latin: Qua re nuntiata, Caesar omnem ex castris equitatum suis auxilio misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been announced, Caesar all from the camp cavalry to his own for an aid sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been announced, Caesar all from the camp cavalry to his own for an aid sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported, Caesar sent all the cavalry from the camp to assist his men.

sentences.latin: Interim nostri milites impetum hostium sustinuerunt atque amplius horis IIII fortissime pugnaverunt et paucis vulneribus acceptis complures ex iis occiderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile our soldiers the attack of the enemies sustained and more than hours 4 most bravely fought and few wounds having been received several from them they killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile our soldiers the attack of the enemies sustained and more than hours 4 most bravely fought and few wounds having been received several from them they killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, our soldiers withstood the enemy's attack and fought most bravely for more than four hours; having received only a few wounds, they killed many of the enemy.

sentences.latin: Postea vero quam equitatus noster in conspectum venit, hostes abiectis armis terga verterunt magnusque eorum numerus est occisus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After truly than cavalry our into sight came, the enemies thrown away arms backs turned and a great of them number was killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After truly than cavalry our into sight came, the enemies thrown away arms backs turned and a great of them number was killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But as soon as our cavalry came into sight, the enemy threw down their arms and fled, and a great number of them were killed.

sentences.latin: Caesar postero die T. Labienum legatum cum iis legionibus quas ex Britannia reduxerat in Morinos qui rebellionem fecerant misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar on the next day T. Labienus the lieutenant with those legions which from Britain he had brought back into the Morini who rebellion had made sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar on the next day Titus Labienus the lieutenant with those legions which from Britain he had led back into the Morini who rebellion had made sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, Caesar sent the lieutenant Titus Labienus with the legions he had brought back from Britain against the Morini, who had revolted.

sentences.latin: Qui cum propter siccitates paludum quo se reciperent non haberent, quo perfugio superiore anno erant usi, omnes fere in potestatem Labieni venerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when on account of the droughts of the marshes whither themselves they might retreat not they had, which refuge in the previous year they had used, all almost into the power of Labienus came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who when on account of the droughts of the marshes whither themselves they might withdraw not they had, which refuge in the previous year they had used, all almost into the power of Labienus came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the marshes were dry, they had no place to retreat toa refuge they had used the previous yearand almost all of them fell into Labienus's power.

sentences.latin: At Q. Titurius et L. Cotta legati, qui in Menapiorum fines legiones duxerant, omnibus eorum agris vastatis, frumentis succisis, aedificiis incensis, quod Menapii se omnes in densissimas silvas abdiderant, se ad Caesarem receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Q. Titurius and L. Cotta lieutenants, who into of the Menapii borders the legions had led, all of them fields having been devastated, crops cut down, buildings burned, because the Menapii themselves all into the thickest woods had hidden, themselves to Caesar they withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Quintus Titurius and Lucius Cotta lieutenants, who into of the Menapii borders the legions had led, all of them fields having been devastated, crops cut down, buildings burned, because the Menapii themselves all into the thickest forests had hidden, themselves to Caesar they withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the lieutenants Quintus Titurius and Lucius Cotta, who had led legions into the territory of the Menapii, returned to Caesar after laying waste to all their fields, cutting down their crops, and burning their buildings, because the Menapii had all hidden themselves in the densest forests.

sentences.latin: Caesar in Belgis omnium legionum hiberna constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar in the Belgae of all the legions winter quarters established.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar among the Belgae of all the legions winter quarters established.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar established winter quarters for all the legions among the Belgae.

sentences.latin: Eo duae omnino civitates ex Britannia obsides miserunt, reliquae neglexerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thither two altogether states from Britain hostages sent, the rest neglected [to do so].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thither two altogether states from Britain hostages sent, the rest neglected [to do so].
sentences.naturalTranslation: Only two British states sent hostages there; the rest failed to do so.

sentences.latin: His rebus gestis ex litteris Caesaris dierum XX supplicatio a senatu decreta est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been done, from the letters of Caesar, a thanksgiving of twenty days by the senate was decreed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been done from the letters of Caesar of days 20 a thanksgiving by the senate was decreed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these events, upon receiving Caesar's dispatches, the senate decreed a public thanksgiving of twenty days.

sentences.latin: L. Domitio Ap.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lucius Domitius, Appius.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Lucius Domitius, Appius
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the consulship of Lucius Domitius and Appius...

sentences.latin: Claudio consulibus, discedens ab hibernis Caesar in Italiam, ut quotannis facere consuerat, legatis imperat quos legionibus praefecerat uti quam plurimas possent hieme naves aedificandas veteresque reficiendas curarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Claudius being consuls, departing from winter quarters Caesar into Italy, as every year to do he had been accustomed, to the legates he commands whom over the legions he had put in charge that as many as possible they could in winter ships to be built and old ones to be repaired they should care for.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Claudius being consuls, departing from winter quarters Caesar into Italy, as every year to do he had been accustomed, to the lieutenants he commands whom over the legions he had put in charge that as many as possible they could in winter ships to be built and old ones to be repaired they should care for.
sentences.naturalTranslation: ...Claudius, Caesar, leaving winter quarters for Italy as was his annual custom, instructed the legates he had placed in command of the legions to have as many ships as possible built during the winter and the old ones repaired.

sentences.latin: Earum modum formamque demonstrat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of them the measure and form he shows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of them the measure and shape he describes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He specified their dimensions and design.

sentences.latin: Ad celeritatem onerandi subductionesque paulo facit humiliores quam quibus in nostro mari uti consuevimus, atque id eo magis, quod propter crebras commutationes aestuum minus magnos ibi fluctus fieri cognoverat; ad onera, ad multitudinem iumentorum transportandam paulo latiores quam quibus in reliquis utimur maribus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For speed of loading and beachings a little he makes lower than those which in our sea to use we have been accustomed, and that by this more, because on account of frequent changes of tides less large there waves to be made he had learned; for loads, for a multitude of beasts of burden to be transported, a little wider than those which in other we use seas.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For speed of loading and beachings a little he makes [them] lower than those which in our sea to use we have been accustomed, and that by that more, because on account of frequent changes of tides less great there waves to be made he had learned; for loads, for a multitude of beasts of burden to be transported a little wider than those which in other we use seas.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To facilitate quick loading and beaching, he made them slightly lower than those we usually use in the Mediterranean, especially since he had learned that the waves there are smaller due to the frequent changes of the tides; for carrying cargo and a large number of pack animals, he made them slightly wider than those used in other seas.

sentences.latin: Has omnes actuarias imperat fieri, quam ad rem multum humilitas adiuvat.
