sentences.referenceTranslation: These all row-driven he commands to be made, which for thing much the low height helps.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These all fast-sailing he commands to be made, for which thing much the low height helps.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered all of these to be built as row-galleys, a purpose for which their low profile was very helpful.

sentences.latin: Ea quae sunt usui ad armandas naves ex Hispania apportari iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Those things which are for use for fitting out ships from Spain to be brought he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Those things which are for a use to equipping ships from Spain to be brought he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the equipment necessary for outfitting the ships to be brought from Spain.

sentences.latin: Ipse conventibus Galliae citerioris peractis in Illyricum proficiscitur, quod a Pirustis finitimam partem provinciae incursionibus vastari audiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself the assemblies of Gaul hither having been finished into Illyricum sets out, because by the Pirustae the neighboring part of the province by incursions to be devastated he was hearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself the assemblies of Gaul hither having been finished into Illyricum sets out, because by the Pirustae the neighboring part of the province by incursions to be devastated he was hearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After finishing the judicial circuits in Cisalpine Gaul, he set out for Illyricum because he heard that the Pirustae were devastating the neighboring part of the province with raids.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, civitatibus milites imperat certumque in locum convenire iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, from the states soldiers he levies and into a certain place to assemble he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thither when he had come, from the states soldiers he levies and to a certain place to assemble he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon his arrival there, he requisitioned soldiers from the states and ordered them to assemble at a specific location.

sentences.latin: Qua re nuntiata Pirustae legatos ad eum mittunt qui doceant nihil earum rerum publico factum consilio, seseque paratos esse demonstrant omnibus rationibus de iniuriis satisfacere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been announced the Pirustae ambassadors to him send who should show nothing of those things by public done plan, and themselves ready to be they demonstrate by all means concerning the injuries to give satisfaction.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been announced the Pirustae ambassadors to him send who might show nothing of those things by public done plan, and themselves ready to be they demonstrate by all means concerning the injuries to give satisfaction.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported, the Pirustae sent ambassadors to him to explain that none of those actions had been taken by official policy, and they declared themselves ready to give full satisfaction for the damages.

sentences.latin: Accepta oratione eorum Caesar obsides imperat eosque ad certam diem adduci iubet; nisi ita fecerint, sese bello civitatem persecuturum demonstrat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having accepted the speech of them, Caesar hostages commands and those to a certain day to be brought orders; unless so they will have done, himself by war the state about to pursue he declares.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having accepted the speech of them, Caesar hostages commands and those to a certain day to be brought orders; unless thus they will have done, himself in war the state to be about to pursue he demonstrates.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After hearing their speech, Caesar demanded hostages and ordered them to be brought by a specific date; he declared that if they failed to do so, he would prosecute the state with war.

sentences.latin: Eis ad diem adductis, ut imperaverat, arbitros inter civitates dat qui litem aestiment poenamque constituant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Those to the day having been brought, as he had commanded, arbitrators among the states he gives who the dispute might estimate and the penalty might determine.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These to the day having been brought, as he had commanded, arbitrators among the states he gives who the dispute should estimate and the penalty should determine.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these were brought by the appointed day, as he had ordered, he appointed arbitrators between the states to assess the damages and determine the penalty.

sentences.latin: His confectis rebus conventibusque peractis, in citeriorem Galliam revertitur atque inde ad exercitum proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been finished and the assemblies having been completed, into hither Gaul he returns and from there to the army sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been finished and the assemblies having been completed, into hither Gaul he returns and from there to the army sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having finished these matters and concluded the legal assemblies, he returned to Hither Gaul and from there set out for the army.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, circumitis omnibus hibernis, singulari militum studio in summa omnium rerum inopia circiter sescentas eius generis cuius supra demonstravimus naves et longas XXVIII invenit instructas neque multum abesse ab eo quin paucis diebus deduci possint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, having gone around all the winter quarters, by the singular zeal of the soldiers in the greatest of all things scarcity, about six hundred of that kind of which above we have shown ships and long [ships] 28 he found equipped and not much to be away from that but that in a few days to be launched they are able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had come, having gone around all winter quarters, by the singular zeal of the soldiers in the greatest of all things scarcity, about six hundred of that kind of which above we have shown ships and warships 28 he found equipped and not much to be away from that but that in a few days to be launched they are able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, having inspected all the winter quarters, he found that despite an extreme shortage of all supplies, the soldiers' extraordinary zeal had resulted in the construction of about six hundred ships of the type described above and twenty-eight warships, all nearly ready to be launched within a few days.

sentences.latin: Collaudatis militibus atque eis qui negotio praefuerant, quid fieri velit ostendit atque omnes ad portum Itium convenire iubet, quo ex portu commodissimum in Britanniam traiectum esse cognoverat, circiter milium passuum XXX transmissum a continenti: huic rei quod satis esse visum est militum reliquit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having praised the soldiers and those who over the business had been in charge, what to be done he wishes he shows and all to port Itius to assemble he orders, from which port the most convenient into Britain passage to be he had learned, about of miles of paces 30 a crossing from the continent: for this matter what enough to be seemed of soldiers he left;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having praised the soldiers and those who over the business had been in charge, what to be done he wishes he shows and all to port Itius to assemble he orders, from which port the most convenient into Britain crossing to be he had learned, about of miles of paces 30 a passage from the continent: for this matter what enough to be seemed of soldiers he left;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After commending the soldiers and those who had overseen the work, he explained his plan and ordered everyone to assemble at Port Itius. He had learned that the crossing to Britain from this port was the most convenient, being about thirty miles from the mainland. He left behind what he considered a sufficient number of soldiers for this purpose.

sentences.latin: ipse cum legionibus expeditis IIII et equitibus DCCC in fines Treverorum proficiscitur, quod hi neque ad concilia veniebant neque imperio parebant Germanosque Transrhenanos sollicitare dicebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself with legions light-armed 4 and horsemen 800 into the borders of the Treveri sets out, because these neither to the councils were coming nor the command were obeying and the Germans across-the-Rhine to stir up were said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself with legions light-armed 4 and horsemen 800 into the borders of the Treveri sets out, because these neither to the councils were coming nor the command were obeying and the Germans across-the-Rhine to stir up they were said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself set out for the territory of the Treveri with four light-armed legions and 800 cavalry, because they were neither attending the councils nor obeying his commands, and were reported to be inciting the Germans across the Rhine.

sentences.latin: Haec civitas longe plurimum totius Galliae equitatu valet magnasque habet copias peditum Rhenumque, ut supra demonstravimus, tangit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This state by far the most of all Gaul in cavalry is strong and great has forces of infantry and the Rhine, as above we have shown, touches.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This state by far the most of all Gaul in cavalry is strong and great has forces of infantry and the Rhine, as above we have shown, touches.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This state is by far the most powerful in all of Gaul in terms of cavalry, possesses large forces of infantry, and, as we have mentioned before, borders the Rhine.

sentences.latin: In ea civitate duo de principatu inter se contendebant, Indutiomarus et Cingetorix;
sentences.referenceTranslation: In that state two concerning the leadership among themselves were contending, Indutiomarus and Cingetorix;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that state two concerning the leadership among themselves were contending, Indutiomarus and Cingetorix;
sentences.naturalTranslation: In that state, two men, Indutiomarus and Cingetorix, were struggling with each other for the leadership.

sentences.latin: e quibus alter, simul atque de Caesaris legionumque adventu cognitum est, ad eum venit, se suosque omnes in officio futuros neque ab amicitia populi Romani defecturos confirmavit quaeque in Treveris gererentur ostendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From whom the one, as soon as about of Caesar and of the legions the arrival it was known, to him came, himself and his own all in duty to be about to be and not from the friendship of the people Roman to be about to revolt he confirmed and what in the Treveri were being done he showed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From whom the one, as soon as concerning Caesar's and the legions' arrival it was known, to him came, himself and his own all in duty to be about to be and not from the friendship of the people Roman to be about to revolt he confirmed and what in the Treveri were being done he showed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One of them, as soon as he learned of the arrival of Caesar and his legions, came to him and assured him that he and all his people would remain loyal and not abandon their friendship with the Roman people, and he reported what was happening among the Treveri.

sentences.latin: At Indutiomarus equitatum peditatumque cogere, eisque qui per aetatem in armis esse non poterant in silvam Arduennam abditis, quae ingenti magnitudine per medios fines Treverorum a flumine Rheno ad initium Remorum pertinet, bellum parare instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Indutiomarus cavalry and infantry to collect, and those who through age in arms to be were not able in the forest Ardennes having been hidden, which with huge magnitude through the middle borders of the Treveri from the river Rhine to the beginning of the Remi extends, war to prepare he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Indutiomarus cavalry and infantry to collect, and those who through age in arms to be were not able in the forest Ardennes having been hidden, which with huge magnitude through the middle borders of the Treveri from the river Rhine to the beginning of the Remi extends, war to prepare he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Indutiomarus, however, began to raise cavalry and infantry and, after hiding those who were too young or too old to bear arms in the Ardennes forestwhich is of vast size and extends through the middle of the Treveri's territory from the Rhine to the borders of the Remihe prepared for war.

sentences.latin: Sed posteaquam nonnulli principes ex ea civitate et familiaritate Cingetorigis adducti et adventu nostri exercitus perterriti ad Caesarem venerunt et de suis privatim rebus ab eo petere coeperunt, quoniam civitati consulere non possent, veritus ne ab omnibus desereretur Indutiomarus legatos ad Caesarem mittit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: But after some leaders from that state both by friendship of Cingetorix influenced and by arrival of our army terrified to Caesar came and about their own privately matters from him to seek began, since for the state to provide they were not able, having feared lest by all he be deserted Indutiomarus ambassadors to Caesar sends:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But after some leaders from that state both by friendship of Cingetorix influenced and by the arrival of our army terrified to Caesar came and concerning their own privately matters from him to seek began, since for the state to provide they were not able, fearing lest by all he should be deserted Indutiomarus ambassadors to Caesar sends:
sentences.naturalTranslation: But after several leaders from that state, influenced by their friendship with Cingetorix and terrified by the arrival of our army, came to Caesar and began to make requests of him regarding their private affairs since they could not look out for the state, Indutiomarus, fearing he would be deserted by everyone, sent ambassadors to Caesar:

sentences.latin: sese idcirco ab suis discedere atque ad eum venire noluisse, quo facilius civitatem in officio contineret, ne omnis nobilitatis discessu plebs propter imprudentiam laberetur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: himself for that reason from his own to depart and to him to come to have been unwilling, so that more easily the state in duty he might keep, lest by all the nobility's departure the common people on account of ignorance might fall away:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: himself for that reason from his own to depart and to him to come to have been unwilling, by which more easily the state in duty he might keep, lest by all the nobility's departure the common people on account of ignorance should fall away:
sentences.naturalTranslation: He claimed that he had been unwilling to leave his people and come to Caesar for this reason: that he might more easily keep the state in its allegiance, lest the common people, through ignorance, should fall away if all the nobility departed.

sentences.latin: itaque esse civitatem in sua potestate, seseque, si Caesar permitteret, ad eum in castra venturum, suas civitatisque fortunas eius fidei permissurum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: therefore to be the state in his power, and himself, if Caesar should permit, to him into the camp about to come, his own and the state's fortunes to his protection about to entrust.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so to be the state in his power, and himself, if Caesar should permit, to him into the camp to be about to come, his own and the state's fortunes to his faith to be about to entrust.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he said, the state was in his power, and if Caesar permitted, he would come to him in his camp and entrust his own fortunes and those of the state to Caesar's protection.

sentences.latin: Caesar, etsi intellegebat qua de causa ea dicerentur quaeque eum res ab instituto consilio deterreret, tamen, ne aestatem in Treveris consumere cogeretur omnibus ad Britannicum bellum rebus comparatis, Indutiomarum ad se cum CC obsidibus venire iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, although he understood for what cause those things were being said and what matter him from his begun plan was deterring, nevertheless, lest the summer among the Treveri to spend he be compelled all for the British war things having been prepared, Indutiomarus to himself with 200 hostages to come ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, although he was understanding for what reason those things were being said and what thing him from the begun plan was deterring, nevertheless, lest the summer among the Treveri to spend he should be forced all for the British war things having been prepared, Indutiomarus to himself with 200 hostages to come ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar understood why these things were being said and what motive was deterring Indutiomarus from his intended plan, nevertheless, so that he would not be forced to spend the summer among the Treveri when everything was ready for the war in Britain, he ordered Indutiomarus to come to him with two hundred hostages.

sentences.latin: His adductis, in eis filio propinquisque eius omnibus, quos nominatim evocaverat, consolatus Indutiomarum hortatusque est uti in officio maneret;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been brought, among them the son and relatives of him all, whom by name he had called out, having consoled Indutiomarus and he exhorted that in duty he should remain;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been brought, among them the son and relatives of him all, whom by name he had called out, having comforted Indutiomarus he encouraged that in duty he should remain;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these were brought, including his son and all his relatives whom Caesar had summoned by name, he consoled Indutiomarus and exhorted him to remain loyal.

sentences.latin: nihilo tamen setius principibus Treverorum ad se convocatis hos singillatim Cingetorigi conciliavit, quod cum merito eius a se fieri intellegebat, tum magni interesse arbitrabatur eius auctoritatem inter suos quam plurimum valere, cuius tam egregiam in se voluntatem perspexisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: by nothing however less the leaders of the Treveri to himself having been called together these individually to Cingetorix he won over, because both by merit of him by himself to be done he understood, and also of great importance he was judging his authority among his own as much as possible to be strong, of whom such excellent toward himself goodwill he had seen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by nothing however less the leaders of the Treveri to himself having been called together these individually to Cingetorix he reconciled, because both by merit of him by himself to be done he was understanding, and of great to be important he was thinking his authority among his own as much as possible to be strong, of whom so excellent toward himself goodwill he had seen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, having summoned the leaders of the Treveri to him, he won them over individually to Cingetorix; he did this because he recognized it was deserved, and also because he thought it was of great importance that the authority of a man whose extraordinary goodwill toward him he had witnessed should be as strong as possible among his people.

sentences.latin: Id tulit factum graviter Indutiomarus, suam gratiam inter suos minui, et, qui iam ante inimico in nos animo fuisset, multo gravius hoc dolore exarsit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This deed bore heavily Indutiomarus, his own influence among his own to be diminished, and, who already before with a hostile toward us mind had been, by much more heavily by this pain he blazed up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This deed bore heavily Indutiomarus, his own influence among his own to be diminished, and, who already before with a hostile toward us mind had been, much more heavily by this pain he blazed up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Indutiomarus took this action hard, seeing his influence among his people diminished; and having already previously been hostile toward us, he was now much more violently inflamed by this grievance.

sentences.latin: His rebus constitutis Caesar ad portum Itium cum legionibus pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been settled Caesar to port Itius with the legions arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been settled Caesar to port Itius with the legions arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After settling these matters, Caesar arrived at Portus Itius with his legions.

sentences.latin: Ibi cognoscit LX naves, quae in Meldis factae erant, tempestate reiectas cursum tenere non potuisse atque eodem unde erant profectae revertisse; reliquas paratas ad navigandum atque omnibus rebus instructas invenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There he learns 60 ships, which among the Meldi had been made, by a storm driven back their course to hold not to have been able and to the same place from where they had set out to have returned; the remaining ones prepared for sailing and with all things equipped he found.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There he learns 60 ships, which among the Meldi had been made, by a storm driven back course to hold not to have been able and to the same place from where they had set out to have returned; the rest ready for sailing and with all things equipped he found.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There he learned that sixty ships, which had been built among the Meldi, had been driven back by a storm and were unable to hold their course, returning to the place from which they had started; the rest he found ready for sailing and fully equipped.

sentences.latin: Eodem equitatus totius Galliae convenit, numero milium quattuor, principesque ex omnibus civitatibus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the same place the cavalry of all Gaul assembled, in number of thousands four, and leaders from all states.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the same place the cavalry of all Gaul assembles, in number of thousands four, and the leaders from all states.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cavalry of all Gaul, numbering four thousand, assembled at the same place, along with the leaders from all the states.

sentences.latin: Ex quibus perpaucos, quorum in se fidem perspexerat, relinquere in Gallia, reliquos obsidum loco secum ducere decreverat, quod, cum ipse abesset, motum Galliae verebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From whom very few, of whom towards himself loyalty he had perceived, to leave in Gaul, the rest in of hostages place with himself to lead he had decided, because, when himself he would be away, a movement of Gaul he was fearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From whom very few, whose in himself loyalty he had perceived, to leave in Gaul, the rest in the place of hostages with himself to lead he had decided, because, when he himself was away, a movement of Gaul he was fearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He had decided to leave behind in Gaul only a few of them whose loyalty to him he had witnessed, and to take the rest with him as hostages, because he feared an uprising in Gaul while he was away.

sentences.latin: Erat una cum ceteris Dumnorix Aeduus, de quo ante ab nobis dictum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was together with the others Dumnorix the Aeduan, about whom before by us it has been said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was together with the others Dumnorix the Aeduan, about whom before by us it has been said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among the others was Dumnorix the Aeduan, whom we have mentioned previously.

sentences.latin: Hunc secum habere in primis constituerat, quod eum cupidum rerum novarum, cupidum imperi, magri animi, magnae inter Gallos auctoritatis cognoverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This one with himself to have especially he had resolved, because him desirous of things new, desirous of power, of great spirit, of great among the Gauls authority he had recognized.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This man with himself to have especially he had determined, because him desirous of new things, desirous of power, of great spirit, of great among the Gauls authority he had known.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar had resolved to keep this man with him especially, because he knew him to be eager for revolution, thirsty for power, high-spirited, and possessed of great influence among the Gauls.

sentences.latin: Accedebat huc quod in concilio Aeduorum Dumnorix dixerat sibi a Caesare regnum civitatis deferri; quod dictum Aedui graviter ferebant, neque recusandi aut deprecandi causa legatos ad Caesarem mittere audebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was added to this that in the council of the Aeduans Dumnorix had said to himself by Caesar the kingship of the state was being conferred; which saying the Aeduans heavily were bearing, nor of refusing or of entreating for the sake ambassadors to Caesar to send they were daring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was added to this that in the council of the Aedui Dumnorix had said to himself by Caesar the kingship of the state was being conferred; which saying the Aedui heavily were bearing, nor of refusing or of pleading for the sake ambassadors to Caesar to send they were daring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this was added the fact that Dumnorix had claimed in a council of the Aeduans that Caesar was offering him the kingship of the state; the Aeduans took this claim badly, yet they did not dare send ambassadors to Caesar to reject or protest the offer.

sentences.latin: Id factum ex suis hospitibus Caesar cognoverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This fact from his own guest-friends Caesar had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This fact from his own guest-friends Caesar had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar had learned of this fact from his own guest-friends.

sentences.latin: Ille omnibus primo precibus petere contendit ut in Gallia relinqueretur, partim quod insuetus navigandi mare timeret, partim quod religionibus impediri sese diceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That one with all at first prayers to seek he strove that in Gaul he might be left, partly because unaccustomed of sailing the sea he was fearing, partly because by religious scruples to be hindered himself he was saying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He with all at first prayers to seek strove that in Gaul he might be left, partly because unaccustomed of sailing the sea he was fearing, partly because by religious obligations to be hindered himself he was saying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first, he used every prayer to strive to be left in Gaul, partly because he was afraid of the sea as he was unaccustomed to sailing, and partly because he claimed to be hindered by religious obligations.

sentences.latin: Posteaquam id obstinate sibi negari vidit, omni spe impetrandi adempta principes Galliae sollicitare, sevocare singulos hortarique coepit uti in continenti remanerent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: After that it obstinately to himself to be denied he saw, all hope of obtaining having been taken away, the chiefs of Gaul to stir up, to call aside individuals and to exhort he began that on the continent they should remain;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After that this obstinately to himself to be denied he saw, all hope of obtaining having been taken away, the chiefs of Gaul to stir up, to call aside individuals and to exhort he began that on the continent they should remain;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he saw that his request was being stubbornly denied, and all hope of gaining it was lost, he began to agitate the Gallic chiefs, calling them aside individually and urging them to remain on the continent;

sentences.latin: metu territare: non sine causa fieri, ut Gallia omni nobilitate spoliaretur; id esse consilium Caesaris, ut quos in conspectu Galliae interficere vereretur, hos omnes in Britanniam traductos necaret;
sentences.referenceTranslation: with fear to terrify: not without cause it was happening, that Gaul of all nobility should be despoiled; that to be the plan of Caesar, that whom in the sight of Gaul to kill he was fearing, these all into Britain having been led across he might kill;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: with fear to terrify: not without cause it was happening, that Gaul of all nobility should be despoiled; that to be the plan of Caesar, that whom in the sight of Gaul to kill he was fearing, these all into Britain having been led across he might kill;
sentences.naturalTranslation: he terrified them with fear, claiming it was not without reason that Gaul was being stripped of all its nobility; that it was Caesar's plan to bring them all across to Britain and put them to death, since he was afraid to kill them in the sight of Gaul;

sentences.latin: fidem reliquis interponere, iusiurandum poscere, ut quod esse ex usu Galliae intellexissent communi consilio administrarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: faith to the rest to pledge, an oath to demand, that what to be from the use of Gaul they had understood by common counsel they should carry out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: faith to the rest to pledge, an oath to demand, that what to be from the use of Gaul they had understood by common counsel they should administer.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he pledged his word to the rest and demanded an oath that they would carry out by common counsel whatever they understood to be for the benefit of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Haec a compluribus ad Caesarem deferebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things by several to Caesar were being reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things by several to Caesar were being reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These matters were reported to Caesar by several people.

sentences.latin: Qua re cognita Caesar, quod tantum civitati Aeduae dignitatis tribuebat, coercendum atque deterrendum quibuscumque rebus posset Dumnorigem statuebat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been known Caesar, because so much of dignity to the state Aeduan he was attributing, to be restrained and to be deterred by whatever things he was able Dumnorix he was deciding;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been learned Caesar, because so much to the state Aeduan of dignity he was assigning, to be restrained and to be deterred by whatever things he could Dumnorix he was deciding;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned of this, Caesar, because he attributed so much importance to the Aeduan state, decided that Dumnorix must be restrained and deterred by whatever means possible;

sentences.latin: quod longius eius amentiam progredi videbat, prospiciendum, ne quid sibi ac rei publicae nocere posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because further his madness to proceed he was seeing, it must be provided for, lest anything to himself and to the republic to harm it might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because further his madness to proceed he was seeing, to be provided for, lest anything to himself and to the republic to harm he might be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because he saw his madness was proceeding further, he felt he must take precautions lest he be able to cause any harm to himself or the republic.

sentences.latin: Itaque dies circiter XXV in eo loco commoratus,
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so days about 25 in that place having delayed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so days about twenty-five in that place having delayed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: And so, having delayed in that place for about twenty-five days,

sentences.latin: quod Carus ventus navigationem impediebat, qui magnam partem omnis temporis in his locis flare consuevit, dabat operam ut in officio Dumnorigem contineret, nihilo tamen setius omnia eius consilia cognosceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because the Corus wind navigation was hindering, which a great part of all time in these places to blow was accustomed, he was giving effort that in duty Dumnorix he might keep, by nothing however less all his plans he might learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because the North-west wind the navigation was hindering, which a great part of all time in these places to blow is accustomed, he was giving effort that in duty Dumnorix he might keep, by nothing however less all his plans he might learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because the northwest wind, which is accustomed to blow in these parts for a great part of the year, was hindering navigation, he took pains to keep Dumnorix to his duty, while nonetheless keeping informed of all his plans.

sentences.latin: Tandem idoneam nactus tempestatem milites equitesque conscendere in naves iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Finally suitable having found weather the soldiers and horsemen to embark into the ships he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Finally suitable having found weather the soldiers and horsemen to embark into the ships he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Finally, having found suitable weather, he ordered the soldiers and cavalry to board the ships.

sentences.latin: At omnium impeditis animis Dumnorix cum equitibus Aeduorum a castris insciente Caesare domum discedere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But of all hindered the minds Dumnorix with the horsemen of the Aedui from the camp not knowing Caesar home to depart began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But of all occupied minds Dumnorix with the horsemen of the Aedui from the camp not knowing Caesar toward home to depart began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But while the minds of everyone were occupied, Dumnorix, with the Aeduan cavalry, began to depart from the camp for home without Caesar's knowledge.

sentences.latin: Qua re nuntiata Caesar intermissa profectione atque omnibus rebus postpositis magnam partem equitatus ad eum insequendum mittit retrahique imperat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been announced Caesar interrupted the departure and all things having been put after a great part of the cavalry to him following sends and to be dragged back he orders;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been announced Caesar having been interrupted the departure and all things having been put after a great part of the cavalry to him pursuing sends and to be brought back he commands;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported, Caesar, having paused the departure and set aside all other matters, sent a large part of the cavalry to pursue him and ordered him to be brought back;

sentences.latin: si vim faciat neque pareat, interfici iubet, nihil hunc se absente pro sano facturum arbitratus, qui praesentis imperium neglexisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if force he should make and not obey, to be killed he orders, nothing this one himself being absent for a sane man would do having thought, who of [him] present the command had neglected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if force he should make nor obey, to be killed he orders, nothing this man himself being absent for a sane would do having thought, who of present the command had neglected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he ordered him to be killed if he should use force or fail to obey, thinking that he would do nothing like a sane man in his absence, since he had disregarded his authority while he was present.

sentences.latin: Ille enim revocatus resistere ac se manu defendere suorumque fidem implorare coepit, saepe clamitans liberum se liberaeque esse civitatis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He for having been called back to resist and himself by hand to defend and of his own the faith to implore began, often shouting free himself and of a free to be state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He for having been called back to resist and himself by hand to defend and of his own the faith to implore began, often shouting free himself and of a free to be state.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he, when called back, began to resist and defend himself by force and to implore the loyalty of his men, repeatedly shouting that he was a free man and of a free state.

sentences.latin: Illi, ut erat imperatum, circumsistunt hominem atque interficiunt: at equites Aedui ad Caesarem omnes revertuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, as it had been commanded, surround the man and kill: but the horsemen Aeduan to Caesar all return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, as it had been commanded, surround the man and kill: but the horsemen Aeduan to Caesar all return.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They, as had been commanded, surrounded the man and killed him; but the Aeduan cavalry all returned to Caesar.

sentences.latin: His rebus gestis, Labieno in continente cum tribus legionibus et equitum milibus duobus relicto ut portus tueretur et rem frumentariam provideret quaeque in Gallia gererentur cognosceret consiliumque pro tempore et pro re caperet,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been done, Labienus on the continent with three legions and of horsemen thousands two having been left so that the ports he might guard and the matter grain-related he might provide for and what things in Gaul were being done he might learn and a plan according to the time and according to the matter he might take,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been done, Labienus in the continent with three legions and of horsemen thousands two having been left so that the ports he might protect and the matter grain-related provide for and what things in Gaul were being done he might learn and a plan according to the time and according to the matter he might take,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these arrangements were made, Labienus was left on the continent with three legions and two thousand cavalry to guard the ports, provide for the grain supply, keep track of events in Gaul, and make plans according to the time and circumstances.

sentences.latin: ipse cum quinque legionibus et pari numero equitum, quem in continenti reliquerat, ad solis occasum naves solvit et leni Africo provectus media circiter nocte vento intermisso cursum non tenuit, et longius delatus aestu orta luce sub sinistra Britanniam relictam conspexit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he himself with five legions and an equal number of horsemen, which on the continent he had left, at of the sun the setting the ships loosed and by a gentle Southwest wind carried forward at middle about night the wind having ceased the course not he held, and further carried away by the tide at risen light under the left Britain left behind he saw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he himself with five legions and an equal number of horsemen, which on the continent he had left, at the sun's setting the ships loosed and by a gentle Southwest wind carried forward middle around night the wind having ceased the course not he held, and further carried away by the tide light having arisen under the left Britain left behind he saw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself, with five legions and the same number of cavalry as he had left on the continent, set sail at sunset; carried forward by a gentle southwest wind, the wind died down around midnight and he failed to hold his course; having been carried too far by the tide, at daybreak he saw Britain left behind on his left.

sentences.latin: Tum rursus aestus commutationem secutus remis contendit ut eam partem insulae caperet, qua optimum esse egressum superiore aestate cognoverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then again of the tide the change having followed with oars he strove so that that part of the island he might reach, where best to be the landing in the previous summer he had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then again the tide's change having followed with oars he strove so that that part of the island he might reach, where best to be the landing in the previous summer he had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, following the turn of the tide, he strove with oars to reach that part of the island where he had learned the previous summer that the landing was best.

sentences.latin: Qua in re admodum fuit militum virtus laudanda, qui vectoriis gravibusque navigiis non intermisso remigandi labore longarum navium cursum adaequarunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which matter very much was of the soldiers the valor to be praised, who with transport and heavy vessels not interrupted of rowing the labor of the long ships the speed equaled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which matter very much was of the soldiers the valor to be praised, who with transport and heavy vessels not interrupted of rowing labor of the long ships the speed equaled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this matter, the valor of the soldiers was greatly to be praised, for in heavy transport vessels, with unremitting labor at rowing, they matched the speed of the warships.

sentences.latin: Accessum est ad Britanniam omnibus navibus meridiano fere tempore, neque in eo loco hostis est visus;
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was approached to Britain with all the ships at midday nearly time, and not in that place an enemy was seen;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was approached to Britain by all the ships at midday nearly time, nor in that place an enemy was seen;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Britain was reached with all the ships at about midday, and no enemy was seen in that place;

sentences.latin: sed, ut postea Caesar ex captivis cognovit, cum magnae manus eo convenissent, multitudine navium perterritae, quae cum annotinis privatisque quas sui quisque commodi fecerat amplius octingentae uno erant visae tempore, a litore discesserant ac se in superiora loca abdiderant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but, as afterwards Caesar from prisoners learned, although great bands there had assembled, by the multitude of ships terrified, which with last year's and private ones which for his own of advantage each had made more than eight hundred at one were seen time, from the shore they had departed and themselves in higher places had hidden.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but, as afterwards Caesar from captives learned, although great bands there had assembled, by the multitude of ships terrified, which with last year's and private ones which for his own each convenience had made more than eight hundred at one were seen time, from the shore they had departed and themselves in higher places had hidden.
sentences.naturalTranslation: but, as Caesar later learned from prisoners, although large bands had assembled there, they were terrified by the number of shipswhich, including those of the previous year and private vessels built for personal use, appeared as more than eight hundred at onceand had withdrawn from the shore to hide in the higher ground.

sentences.latin: Caesar exposito exercitu et loco castris idoneo capto, ubi ex captivis cognovit quo in loco hostium copiae consedissent, cohortibus decem ad mare relictis et equitibus trecentis, qui praesidio navibus essent, de tertia vigilia ad hostes contendit, eo minus veritus navibus, quod in litore molli atque aperto deligatas ad ancoram relinquebat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar the army having been set out and a place for the camp suitable having been taken, when from prisoners he learned in what place of the enemies the forces had settled, cohorts ten at the sea having been left and horsemen three hundred, who for a protection to the ships might be, during the third watch toward the enemies he hastened, by that less having feared for the ships, because on a shore soft and open fastened at anchor he was leaving [them],
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar the army having been set out and a place for the camp suitable having been taken, when from captives he learned in what place of the enemies the forces had settled, cohorts ten at the sea having been left and horsemen three hundred, who for a guard to the ships might be, during the third watch to the enemies he hastened, by that less fearing for the ships, because on a shore soft and open fastened at anchor he was leaving [them],
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having landed the army and chosen a suitable spot for the camp, learned from prisoners where the enemy forces had taken up their position; leaving ten cohorts and three hundred cavalry at the sea to serve as a guard for the ships, he marched toward the enemy during the third watch, feeling less anxiety for the ships because he was leaving them moored at anchor on a soft and open shore.

sentences.latin: et praesidio navibus Q. Atrium praefecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and for a protection to the ships Quintus Atrius he put in charge.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and for a guard to the ships Quintus Atrius he put in charge.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and he put Quintus Atrius in charge of the guard for the ships.

sentences.latin: Ipse noctu progressus milia passuum circiter XII hostium copias conspicatus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself by night having advanced thousands of paces about twelve of the enemies the forces caught sight of.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself by night having advanced thousands of paces about twelve of the enemies the forces caught sight of.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having advanced about twelve miles during the night, he caught sight of the enemy forces.

sentences.latin: Illi equitatu atque essedis ad flumen progressi ex loco superiore nostros prohibere et proelium committere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They with cavalry and war-chariots to the river having advanced from a place higher our [men] to keep back and battle to join began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They with cavalry and chariots to the river having advanced from a place higher our [men] to hinder and battle to join began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They, having advanced to the river with cavalry and chariots, began to check our men from the higher ground and engage in battle.

sentences.latin: Repulsi ab equitatu se in silvas abdiderunt, locum nacti egregie et natura et opere munitum, quem domestici belli, ut videbantur, causa iam ante praeparaverant;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Repulsed by the cavalry, themselves in the woods they hid, a place having found excellently both by nature and by work fortified, which for the sake of domestic war, as they seemed, already before they had prepared;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Driven back by the cavalry themselves in the woods they hid, a place having found excellently both by nature and by work fortified, which of a domestic war, as they seemed, for the sake already before they had prepared;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Driven back by the cavalry, they hid themselves in the woods, having found a place excellently fortified by both nature and manual labor, which they had already prepared beforehand, as it seemed, for the purpose of internal war.

sentences.latin: nam crebris arboribus succisis omnes introitus erant praeclusi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: for with many trees cut down all entrances had been blocked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: for with numerous trees felled all the entrances had been blocked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: for all the entrances had been blocked by felling numerous trees.

sentences.latin: Ipsi ex silvis rari propugnabant nostrosque intra munitiones ingredi prohibebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They themselves out of the woods scattered were fighting and our men within the fortifications to enter were prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They themselves from the woods scattered were fighting and our [men] inside the fortifications to enter were preventing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They themselves fought in scattered groups from the woods and prevented our men from entering the fortifications.

sentences.latin: At milites legionis septimae, testudine facta et aggere ad munitiones adiecto, locum ceperunt eosque ex silvis expulerunt paucis vulneribus acceptis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the soldiers of the legion seventh, a testudo having been made and a mound to the fortifications thrown up, the place took and them out of the woods drove out with few wounds received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the soldiers of the legion seventh, a testudo having been made and a mound to the fortifications thrown up, the place took and them from the woods drove out few wounds having been received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the soldiers of the seventh legion, having formed a testudo and thrown up a ramp against the fortifications, took the position and drove them out of the woods with only a few wounds sustained.

sentences.latin: Sed eos fugientes longius Caesar prosequi vetuit, et quod loci naturam ignorabat, et quod magna parte diei consumpta munitioni castrorum tempus relinqui volebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But them fleeing further Caesar to follow forbade, both because of the place the nature he was ignorant of, and because with a great part of the day consumed for the fortification of the camp time to be left he was wishing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But them fleeing further Caesar to follow forbade, both because of the place the nature he was ignorant of, and because a great part of the day having been spent for the fortification of the camp time to be left he was wishing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Caesar forbade pursuing them further as they fled, both because he was unfamiliar with the nature of the terrain and because, as a great part of the day was spent, he wanted time to be left for fortifying the camp.

sentences.latin: Postridie eius diei mane tripertito milites equitesque in expeditionem misit, ut eos qui fugerant persequerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the day after that day in the morning in three parts the soldiers and cavalry on an expedition he sent, so that those who had fled they might pursue.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the next day of that day in the morning in three parts the soldiers and horsemen on an expedition he sent, so that those who had fled they might pursue.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the morning of the following day, he sent the soldiers and cavalry on an expedition in three divisions to pursue those who had fled.

sentences.latin: His aliquantum itineris progressis, cum iam extremi essent in prospectu, equites a Quinto Atrio ad Caesarem venerunt, qui nuntiarent superiore nocte maxima coorta tempestate prope omnes naves adflictas atque in litore eiectas esse, quod neque ancorae funesque subsisterent, neque nautae gubernatoresque vim tempestatis pati possent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These some amount of the journey having advanced, when already the rear were in sight, horsemen from Quintus Atrius to Caesar came, who might report on the previous night a very great having arisen storm nearly all the ships damaged and on the shore cast up to have been, because neither anchors and ropes held, nor sailors and pilots the force of the storm to endure were able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These some [amount] of the journey having advanced, when already the rear were in sight, horsemen from Quintus Atrius to Caesar came, who might report on the previous night a very great having arisen storm nearly all the ships shattered and on the shore cast up to be, because neither anchors and ropes held, nor sailors and pilots the force of the storm to endure were able;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these had advanced some distance on their march, and the rear of the column was still in sight, horsemen came from Quintus Atrius to Caesar to report that a massive storm had arisen the previous night and nearly all the ships had been damaged and cast up on the shore, because neither anchors nor cables held, and the sailors and pilots could not withstand the force of the storm.

sentences.latin: itaque ex eo concursu navium magnum esse incommodum acceptum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and so from that collision of ships a great to be disadvantage received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so from that collision of ships a great to be disadvantage received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and so, from that collision of ships, a great disaster had been sustained.

sentences.latin: His rebus cognitis Caesar legiones equitatumque revocari atque in itinere resistere iubet, ipse ad naves revertitur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned Caesar the legions and cavalry to be called back and on the journey to halt orders, himself to the ships returns;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been learned Caesar the legions and cavalry to be called back and on the journey to halt orders, he himself to the ships returns;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning these facts, Caesar ordered the legions and cavalry to be recalled and to halt on their march, while he himself returned to the ships.

sentences.latin: eadem fere quae ex nuntiis litterisque cognoverat coram perspicit, sic ut amissis circiter XL navibus reliquae tamen refici posse magno negotio viderentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the same things almost which from the messengers and letters he had learned in person he sees, so that with lost about 40 ships the remaining however to be repaired to be able with great trouble seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the same things nearly which from messengers and letters he had learned in person he sees, so that having been lost about 40 ships the rest however to be repaired to be able with great trouble seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He saw for himself almost the same things he had learned from the messengers and letters, such that although about forty ships were lost, the remainder nevertheless seemed capable of being repaired, though with great difficulty.

sentences.latin: Itaque ex legionibus fabros deligit et ex continenti alios arcessi iubet;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore from the legions craftsmen he selects and from the continent others to be summoned he orders;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore from the legions craftsmen he selects and from the continent others to be summoned he orders;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he selected craftsmen from the legions and ordered others to be summoned from the continent;

sentences.latin: Labieno scribit, ut quam plurimas posset eis legionibus, quae sunt apud eum, naves instituat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To Labienus he writes, that as many as possible he could with those legions, which are with him, ships he should build.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To Labienus he writes, that as many as possible he could with those legions, which are with him, ships he should build.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He wrote to Labienus to build as many ships as possible with the legions he had with him.

sentences.latin: Ipse, etsi res erat multae operae ac laboris, tamen commodissimum esse statuit omnes naves subduci et cum castris una munitione coniungi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself, although the matter was of much work and labor, nevertheless most convenient to be he decided all ships to be drawn up and with the camp in one fortification to be joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself, although the matter was of much effort and labor, nevertheless most convenient to be he decided all ships to be hauled up and with the camp in one fortification to be joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although it was a task of great effort and labor, he nevertheless decided that the most convenient course was for all the ships to be beached and joined with the camp in a single fortification.

sentences.latin: In his rebus circiter dies X consumit ne nocturnis quidem temporibus ad laborem militum intermissis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In these things about days 10 he spends not even in nocturnal times for the labor of the soldiers having been interrupted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In these matters about days 10 he spends not even nocturnal times for the labor of the soldiers having been interrupted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He spent about ten days on these tasks, without the soldiers' labor being interrupted even during the night.

sentences.latin: Subductis navibus castrisque egregie munitis easdem copias, quas ante, praesidio navibus reliquit: ipse eodem unde redierat proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been drawn up the ships and the camp excellently fortified the same forces, which before, as a guard for the ships he left: he himself to the same place from where he had returned sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been hauled up the ships and the camp excellently fortified, the same forces, which before, for a guard for the ships he left: he himself to the same place from where he had returned sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After beaching the ships and excellently fortifying the camp, he left the same forces as before to guard the ships; he himself set out for the same place from which he had returned.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, maiores iam undique in eum locum copiae Britannorum convenerant summa imperi bellique administrandi communi consilio permissa Cassivellauno, cuius fines a maritimis civitatibus flumen dividit, quod appellatur Tamesis, a mari circiter milia passuum LXXX.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, greater already from all sides into that place forces of the Britons had assembled the supreme command and of the war of managing by common counsel having been entrusted to Cassivellaunus, whose territories from the maritime states a river divides, which is called Thames, from the sea about thousands of paces 80.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had come, greater now from all sides into that place forces of the Britons had assembled, the chief command and of the war to be managed by common counsel having been entrusted to Cassivellaunus, whose territories from the maritime states a river divides, which is called the Thames, from the sea about thousands of paces 80.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, larger forces of Britons had already assembled from all sides, the supreme command and management of the war having been entrusted by common consent to Cassivellaunus, whose territory is divided from the maritime states by a river called the Thames, about eighty miles from the sea.

sentences.latin: Huic superiore tempore cum reliquis civitatibus continentia bella intercesserant; sed nostro adventu permoti Britanni hunc toti bello imperioque praefeceraut.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this man in previous time with the remaining states continuous wars had occurred; but by our arrival moved the Britons this man over the whole war and command placed in charge.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this man in previous time with the remaining states continuous wars had occurred; but by our arrival moved the Britons this man over the whole war and command placed in charge.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Previously, continuous wars had occurred between him and the other states; but moved by our arrival, the Britons placed him in charge of the entire war and command.

sentences.latin: Britanniae pars interior ab eis incolitur quos natos in insula ipsi memoria proditum dicunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of Britain the part interior by those is inhabited whom born on the island they themselves by memory handed down say,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of Britain the part interior by those is inhabited whom born on the island they themselves by memory handed down say,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The interior part of Britain is inhabited by those who, according to their own oral tradition, were born on the island,

sentences.latin: maritima pars ab eis, qui praedae ac belli inferendi causa ex Belgio transierunt (qui omnes fere eis nominibus civitatum appellantur, quibus orti ex civitatibus eo pervenerunt) et bello illato ibi permanserunt atque agros colere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the maritime part by those, who for the sake of booty and of war of bringing from Belgium crossed over (who all almost by those names of states are called, from which having sprung from states there they arrived) and war having been brought there they remained and the fields to cultivate began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the maritime part by those, who for the sake of plunder and of war to be waged from Belgium crossed over (who all almost by those names of states are called, from which having originated from states there they arrived) and war having been brought there they remained and fields to cultivate began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: the maritime part is inhabited by those who crossed over from Belgium for the sake of plunder and waging war (almost all of whom are called by the names of the states from which they originated before arriving there) and, after waging war, remained there and began to cultivate the fields.

sentences.latin: Hominum est infinita multitudo creberrimaque aedificia fere Gallicis consimilia, pecorum magnus numerus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of men there is an infinite multitude and very frequent buildings almost to the Gallic very similar, of cattle a great number.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of men there is an infinite multitude and very frequent buildings almost to the Gallic ones very similar, of cattle a great number.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The population is immense and the buildings, very similar to those of the Gauls, are very numerous; there is also a great number of cattle.

sentences.latin: Vtuntur aut aere aut nummo aureo aut taleis ferreis ad certum pondus examinatis pro nummo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They use either bronze or coin golden or bars iron to a fixed weight weighed for money.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They use either bronze or a coin golden or bars iron to a certain weight weighed for a coin.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They use bronze, gold coins, or iron bars weighed to a fixed standard as currency.

sentences.latin: Nascitur ibi plumbum album in mediterraneis regionibus, in maritimis ferrum, sed eius exigua est copia; aere utuntur importato.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is produced there lead white in inland regions, in maritime iron, but of it small is supply; bronze they use imported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is produced there lead white in the inland regions, in the maritime ones iron, but of it small is the supply; bronze they use imported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Tin is produced there in the inland regions, and iron in the coastal areas, though the supply of the latter is small; the bronze they use is imported.

sentences.latin: Materia cuiusque generis ut in Gallia est, praeter fagum atque abietem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Timber of every kind as in Gaul is, except beech and fir.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Timber of every kind as in Gaul there is, except beech and fir.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There is timber of every kind, as in Gaul, except for beech and fir.

sentences.latin: Leporem et gallinam et anserem gustare fas non putant; haec tamen alunt animi voluptatisque causa.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hare and hen and goose to taste right not they think; these however they breed of mind and of pleasure for the sake.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hare and hen and goose to taste right not they think; these however they breed of the mind and of pleasure for the sake.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They consider it wrong to eat hare, chicken, or goose; however, they breed these animals for pastime and pleasure.

sentences.latin: Loca sunt temperatiora quam in Gallia, remissioribus frigoribus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Places are more temperate than in Gaul, with more relaxed colds.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The places are more temperate than in Gaul, with more relaxed colds.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The climate is more temperate than in Gaul, with less severe winters.

sentences.latin: Insula natura triquetra, cuius unum latus est contra Galliam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Island by nature triangular, of which one side is against Gaul.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The island by nature triangular, of which one side is against Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The island is triangular in shape, with one side facing Gaul.

sentences.latin: Huius lateris alter angulus, qui est ad Cantium, quo fere omnes ex Gallia naves appelluntur, ad orientem solem, inferior ad meridiem spectat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this side one corner, which is at Kent, where almost all from Gaul ships are driven, to the rising sun, the lower to the south looks.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this side one corner, which is at Kent, where almost all from Gaul ships are driven, to the rising sun, the lower to the south looks.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One corner of this side, which is by Kentwhere almost all ships from Gaul put infaces the east, while the lower corner faces south.

sentences.latin: Hoc pertinet circiter mila passuum quingenta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This extends about miles of paces five hundred.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This extends about thousands of paces five hundred.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This side extends for about five hundred miles.

sentences.latin: Alterum vergit ad Hispaniam atque occidentem solem; qua ex parte est Hibernia, dimidio minor, ut aestimatur, quam Britannia, sed pari spatio transmissus atque ex Gallia est in Britanniam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The other inclines toward Spain and the setting sun; on which side is Ireland, by half smaller, as it is estimated, than Britain, but with equal space of passage as from Gaul is into Britain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The other inclines toward Spain and the setting sun; on which side is Ireland, by a half smaller, as it is estimated, than Britain, but with an equal space the crossing as from Gaul is into Britain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The second side faces toward Spain and the west; in this direction lies Ireland, which is estimated to be half the size of Britain, but the sea crossing is the same distance as that from Gaul to Britain.

sentences.latin: In hoc medio cursu est insula, quae appellatur Mona: complures praeterea minores subiectae insulae existimantur, de quibus insulis nonnulli scripserunt dies continuos triginta sub bruma esse noctem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In this middle course is an island, which is called Mona: several besides smaller situated-near islands are thought, about which islands some have written days continuous thirty under winter-solstice to be night.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In this middle course is an island, which is called Mona: several besides smaller lying-near islands are thought, about which islands some have written days continuous thirty under the winter solstice to be night.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the middle of this channel is an island called Mona; furthermore, several smaller islands are thought to lie nearby, where some authors have written that there is continuous night for thirty days during the winter solstice.

sentences.latin: Nos nihil de eo percontationibus reperiebamus, nisi certis ex aqua mensuris breviores esse quam in continenti noctes videbamus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: We nothing about it by inquiries were finding, except by certain from water measurements shorter to be than on the continent the nights we were seeing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: We nothing about it by inquiries were finding, except by certain from water measurements shorter to be than on the continent the nights we were seeing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: We learned nothing about this through inquiries, except that we saw by accurate water-clock measurements that the nights are shorter than on the continent.

sentences.latin: Huius est longitudo lateris, ut fert illorum opinio, septingentorum milium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this is the length of the side, as carries of those the opinion, of seven hundred thousands.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this is the length of the side, as brings of those the opinion, of seven hundred miles.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The length of this side, according to their opinion, is seven hundred miles.

sentences.latin: Tertium est contra septentriones; cui parti nulla est obiecta terra, sed eius angulus lateris maxime ad Germaniam spectat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The third is against the north; to which part no is opposed land, but of it the angle of the side mostly toward Germany looks.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The third is against the north; to which part no is opposed land, but of it the angle of the side mostly toward Germany looks.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The third side faces north; no land lies opposite this part, but the corner of this side looks chiefly toward Germany.

sentences.latin: Hoc milia passuum octingenta in longitudinem esse existimatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thousands of paces eight hundred in length to be is estimated.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This thousands of paces eight hundred in length to be is estimated.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This side is estimated to be eight hundred miles in length.

sentences.latin: Ita omnis insula est in circuitu vicies centum milium passuum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus the whole island is in circuit twenty times a hundred thousands of paces.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus the whole island is in circuit twenty times a hundred thousands of paces.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus the whole island is two thousand miles in circumference.

sentences.latin: Ex his omnibus longe sunt humanissimi qui Cantium incolunt, quae regio est maritima omnis, neque multum a Gallica differunt consuetudine.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Out of these all by far are the most civilized who Kent inhabit, which region is maritime all, nor much from Gallic they differ custom.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From these all by far are the most civilized who Kent inhabit, which region is maritime all, nor much from Gallic they differ custom.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Of all these, the most civilized by far are those who inhabit Kent, which is an entirely maritime region, and they do not differ much from Gallic custom.

sentences.latin: Interiores plerique frumenta non serunt, sed lacte et carne vivunt pellibusque sunt vestiti.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The interior ones for the most part grains do not sow, but on milk and meat they live and in skins are clothed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The interior mostly grains not do sow, but on milk and meat they live and in skins they are clothed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Most of those in the interior do not sow grain, but live on milk and meat and are clothed in skins.

sentences.latin: Omnes vero se Britanni vitro inficiunt, quod caeruleum efficit colorem, atque hoc horridiores sunt in pugna aspectu;
sentences.referenceTranslation: All indeed themselves Britons with woad dye, which a blue produces color, and by this more horrific they are in battle in appearance;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All indeed themselves Britons with woad dye, which blue produces color, and by this more bristling they are in battle in appearance;
sentences.naturalTranslation: All the Britons, indeed, dye themselves with woad, which produces a blue color, and for this reason they are more terrifying in appearance in battle;

sentences.latin: capilloque sunt promisso atque omni parte corporis rasa praeter caput et labrum superius.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and with hair they are long and every part of the body shaven except the head and the lip upper.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and with hair they are long and every part of the body shaved except the head and the lip upper.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they wear their hair long and have every part of their body shaven except the head and the upper lip.

sentences.latin: Vxores habent deni duodenique inter se communes et maxime fratres cum fratribus parentesque cum liberis; sed qui sunt ex his nati, eorum habentur liberi, quo primum virgo quaeque deducta est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Wives they have by tens and by twelves among themselves common and especially brothers with brothers and parents with children; but who are from these born, of those they are held children, to whom first the virgin each was led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Wives they have by tens and by twelves among themselves common and especially brothers with brothers and parents with children; but who are from these born, of those they are held children, to whom first the virgin each was led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Groups of ten or twelve men have wives in common, especially brothers with brothers and parents with children; but the children born of these unions are considered to belong to the man to whom the woman was first led as a bride.

sentences.latin: Equites hostium essedariique acriter proelio cum equitatu nostro in itinere conflixerunt, tamen ut nostri omnibus partibus superiores fuerint atque eos in silvas collesque compulerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The cavalry of the enemies and the charioteers fiercely in battle with the cavalry our on the march clashed, yet so that our [men] in all parts superior were and them into the woods and hills drove.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The horsemen of the enemies and the charioteers sharply in battle with the cavalry our on the march clashed, yet so that our in all parts superior were and them into the woods and hills they drove.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy's cavalry and charioteers clashed fiercely in battle with our cavalry on the march, yet our men were superior in every respect and drove them into the woods and hills.

sentences.latin: Sed compluribus interfectis cupidius insecuti nonnullos ex suis amiserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But several having been killed, too eagerly having followed, some from their own they lost.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But with several killed too eagerly having followed some from their own they lost.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, after killing several of the enemy, our men pursued too eagerly and lost some of their own.

sentences.latin: At illi intermisso spatio imprudentibus nostris atque occupatis in munitione castrorum subito se ex statione pro castris collocati,
sentences.referenceTranslation: But they, an interval having been let pass, while unaware our [men] and occupied in the fortification of the camp, suddenly themselves from the station before the camp having been placed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But they with an interval having passed while unaware were our and occupied in the fortification of the camp suddenly themselves from the guard-post before the camp having stationed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: But after an interval, while our men were off guard and busy with the fortification of the camp, they suddenly appeared from the guard post where they had been stationed in front of the camp,

sentences.latin: acriter pugnaverunt, duabusque missis subsidio cohortibus a Caesare atque eis primis legionum duarum, cum hae perexiguo intermisso loci spatio inter se constitissent, novo genere pugnae perterritis nostris per medios audacissime perruperunt seque inde incolumes receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: fiercely they fought, and two having been sent as a relief cohorts by Caesar and those the first of legions two, when these a very small having been let pass of place space between themselves had stood, by the new kind of battle terrified our [men], through the middle most boldly they broke through and themselves from there unhurt withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: sharply they fought, and with two sent for a relief cohorts by Caesar and those the first of legions two, when these with a very small having been left of place space between themselves had stood, by the new kind of battle terrified our through the middle most boldly they broke through and themselves from there safe they withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and fought fiercely; and although Caesar sent two cohorts as reinforcementsspecifically the first cohorts of two legionsand these had taken their stand with only a very small space between them, the enemy, while our men were terrified by this new way of fighting, most boldly broke through the middle and withdrew from there safely.

sentences.latin: Eo die Quintus Laberius Durus, tribunus militum, interficitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that day Quintus Laberius Durus, tribune of the soldiers, is killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On that day Quintus Laberius Durus, tribune of the soldiers, is killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On that day, Quintus Laberius Durus, a military tribune, was killed.

sentences.latin: Illi pluribus submissis cohortibus repelluntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, more having been sent cohorts, are driven back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They with more sent cohorts are driven back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy were driven back when more cohorts were sent to the rescue.

sentences.latin: Toto hoc in genere pugnae, cum sub oculis omnium ac pro castris dimicaretur, intellectum est nostros propter gravitatem armorum, quod neque insequi cedentes possent neque ab signis discedere auderent, minus aptos esse ad huius generis hostem,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In all this in kind of battle, when under the eyes of all and before the camp it was being fought, it was understood that our [men] on account of the weight of arms, because neither to follow retreating [ones] they were able nor from the standards to depart they dared, less fit to be for this of kind enemy,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In all this in kind of battle, when under the eyes of all and before the camp it was being fought, it was understood our on account of the weight of arms, because neither to follow those yielding they were able nor from the standards to depart they dared, less fit to be for of this kind enemy,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Throughout this whole type of fighting, since the battle took place under everyone's eyes and in front of the camp, it was realized that our men, because of the weight of their armor, were less suited for an enemy of this kind, as they could neither pursue those who retreated nor dared to leave their standards.

sentences.latin: equites autem magno cum periculo proelio dimicare, propterea quod illi etiam consulto plerumque cederent et, cum paulum ab legionibus nostros removissent, ex essedis desilirent et pedibus dispari proelio contenderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the cavalry however with great with danger in battle fought, because that they even by design mostly would retreat and, when a little from the legions our [men] they had removed, from the chariots they would leap down and on feet in unequal battle would contend.
