sentences.originalMITTranslation: the horsemen however with great with danger in battle to fight, because those even by design mostly were yielding and, when a little from the legions our they had removed, from the chariots they would leap down and on feet in unequal battle they would contend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, the cavalry fought with great danger, because the enemy would often retreat even by design and, once they had drawn our men a little way from the legions, they would leap down from their chariots and fight on foot in an unequal contest.

sentences.latin: Equestris autem proeli ratio et cedentibus et insequentibus par atque idem periculum inferebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of cavalry however of battle the system both to retreating and to following equal and the same danger was bringing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of cavalry however of battle the nature both to those yielding and to those following equal and the same danger was bringing in.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Moreover, the nature of the cavalry engagement brought an equal and identical danger to both those retreating and those pursuing.

sentences.latin: Accedebat huc ut numquam conferti sed rari magnisque intervallis proeliarentur stationesque dispositas haberent, atque alios alii deinceps exciperent, integrique et recentes defetigatis succederent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was added to this that never crowded but scattered and with great intervals they would battle and stations arranged they would have, and some others in turn would relieve, and whole and fresh to the exhausted would succeed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was added to this that never crowded but scattered and with great intervals they would battle and guard-posts stationed they would have, and some others in turn would relieve, and the whole and fresh to the tired would succeed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this was added the fact that they never fought in close formation but scattered and at wide intervals, and they had outposts stationed so that they could relieve one another in turn, with fresh and rested men taking the place of the exhausted.

sentences.latin: Postero die procul a castris hostes in collibus constiterunt rarique se ostendere et lenius quam pridie nostros equites proelio lacessere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day far from the camp the enemies on the hills stood and scattered themselves to show and more gently than on the day before our cavalry in battle to provoke they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the following day far from the camp the enemies on the hills took a stand and scattered themselves to show and more gently than on the day before our horsemen in battle to provoke they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, the enemy took up positions on the hills far from the camp; appearing only in scattered groups, they began to harass our cavalry in skirmishes less vigorously than the day before.

sentences.latin: Sed meridie, cum Caesar pabulandi causa tres legiones atque omnem equitatum cum Gaio Trebonio legato misisset, repente ex omnibus partibus ad pabulatores advolaverunt, sic uti ab signis legionibusque non absisterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But at midday, when Caesar for the sake of foraging three legions and all the cavalry with Gaius Trebonius the legate had sent, suddenly from all parts toward the foragers they flew, so that from the standards and the legions they did not keep away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But at midday, when Caesar for the sake of foraging three legions and all the cavalry with Gaius Trebonius the lieutenant had sent, suddenly from all parts toward the foragers they flew, so that from the standards and the legions they did not keep away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But at noon, when Caesar had sent three legions and all the cavalry with the lieutenant Gaius Trebonius to forage, the enemy suddenly rushed the foragers from all sides, pressing so close that they did not hold back even from the standards and the legions.

sentences.latin: Nostri acriter in eos impetu facto reppulerunt neque finem sequendi fecerunt, quoad subsidio confisi equites, cum post se legiones viderent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our men sharply against them an attack having been made drove [them] back nor an end of following made, until in the support having trusted the cavalry, when behind themselves the legions they saw,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men sharply against them an attack having been made drove [them] back nor an end of following made, until in the support having trusted the horsemen, when behind themselves the legions they saw,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men made a sharp attack and drove them back, and did not stop the pursuit until the cavalry, relying on the support of the legions they saw behind them,

sentences.latin: praecipites hostes egerunt magnoque eorum numero interfecto neque sui colligendi neque consistendi aut ex essedis desiliendi facultatem dederunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: headlong the enemy drove and a great of them number having been killed neither of themselves collecting nor of standing or from chariots leaping down opportunity they gave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: headlong the enemy drove and a great of them number having been killed neither of themselves collecting nor of taking a stand or from the chariots leaping down the opportunity they gave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: drove the enemy headlong; having killed a great number of them, they gave them no chance to rally, to make a stand, or to leap down from their chariots.

sentences.latin: Ex hac fuga protinus, quae undique convenerant, auxilia discesserunt, neque post id tempus umquam summis nobiscum copiis hostes contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From this flight immediately, which from all sides had assembled, the auxiliaries departed, nor after that time ever with greatest with us forces the enemies contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From this flight immediately, which from all sides had assembled, the auxiliaries departed, nor after that time ever with greatest with us forces the enemies contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Immediately after this flight, the auxiliary forces that had assembled from all sides departed, and after that time the enemy never again engaged us with their full strength.

sentences.latin: Caesar cognito consilio eorum ad flumen Tamesim in fines Cassivellauni exercitum duxit; quod flumen uno omnino loco pedibus, atque hoc aegre, transiri potest.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar having been learned the plan of them to the river Thames into the territories of Cassivellaunus the army led; which river in one altogether place by feet, and this with difficulty, to be crossed is able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar having been learned the plan of them to the river Thames into the territories of Cassivellaunus the army led; which river in one altogether place by feet, and this with difficulty, to be crossed is able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having learned their plan, led his army to the river Thames into the territory of Cassivellaunus; this river can be crossed on foot in only one place, and even there with difficulty.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, animum advertit ad alteram fluminis ripam magnas esse copias hostium instructas;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, the mind he turned to the other of the river bank great to be forces of the enemy drawn up;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had come, the mind he turned to the other of the river bank great to be forces of the enemy drawn up;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, he noticed that large forces of the enemy were drawn up on the opposite bank of the river;

sentences.latin: ripa autem erat acutis sudibus praefixis munita, eiusdemque generis sub aqua defixae sudes flumine tegebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the bank however was with sharp stakes driven in front fortified, and of the same kind under the water driven down stakes by the river were covered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the bank however was with sharp stakes driven in front fortified, and of the same kind under the water driven down stakes by the river were covered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: moreover, the bank was fortified with sharp stakes driven into the edge, and stakes of the same kind driven into the riverbed were hidden beneath the water.

sentences.latin: His rebus cognitis a captivis perfugisque Caesar praemisso equitatu confestim legiones subsequi iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned from prisoners and deserters Caesar having been sent ahead the cavalry immediately the legions to follow closely ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been learned from prisoners and deserters Caesar having been sent ahead the cavalry immediately the legions to follow closely ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned these facts from prisoners and deserters, Caesar sent the cavalry ahead and immediately ordered the legions to follow close behind.

sentences.latin: Sed ea celeritate atque eo impetu milites ierunt, cum capite solo ex aqua exstarent, ut hostes impetum legionum atque equitum sustinere non possent ripasque dimitterent ac se fugae mandarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But with that speed and with that force the soldiers went, although with the head alone from the water they stood out, that the enemies the attack of the legions and of the cavalry to sustain not were able and the banks they abandoned and themselves to flight they committed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But with that speed and with that force the soldiers went, although with the head alone from the water they stood out, that the enemies the attack of the legions and of the horsemen to sustain not were able and the banks they abandoned and themselves to flight they committed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the soldiers advanced with such speed and such force, even though only their heads were above water, that the enemy could not withstand the charge of the legions and cavalry, but abandoned the banks and took to flight.

sentences.latin: Cassivellaunus, ut supra demonstravimus, omni deposita spe contentionis dimissis amplioribus copiis milibus circiter quattuor essedariorum relictis itinera nostra servabat paulumque ex via excedebat locisque impeditis ac silvestribus sese occultabat, atque eis regionibus quibus nos iter facturos cognoverat pecora atque homines ex agris in silvas compellebat et,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cassivellaunus, as above we have shown, all hope of struggle having been laid aside, larger forces having been dismissed, about four thousand of charioteers having been left, our routes was watching and a little from the road was withdrawing and in places entangled and wooded himself was hiding, and in those regions in which us to be about to make a journey he had learned, cattle and men from the fields into the woods he was driving and,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cassivellaunus, as above we have shown, all having been laid aside hope of struggle having been dismissed the larger forces thousands about four of charioteers having been left our routes was watching and a little from the road was departing and in places difficult and wooded himself was hiding, and in those regions in which us a journey about to make he had learned cattle and men from the fields into the woods he was driving and,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Cassivellaunus, as we have mentioned before, gave up all hope of a direct conflict and dismissed most of his forces, keeping only about four thousand charioteers. He tracked our line of march, staying slightly off the road and hiding in difficult, wooded terrain; in the areas where he knew we would travel, he drove the people and livestock from the fields into the woods.

sentences.latin: cum equitatus noster liberius praedandi vastandique causa se in agros eiecerat, omnibus viis semitisque essedarios ex silvis emittebat et magno cum periculo nostrorum equitum cum eis confligebat atque hoc metu latius vagari prohibebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: when our cavalry more freely for the sake of plundering and devastating itself into the fields had thrown, by all roads and paths charioteers from the woods he was sending out and with great danger of our cavalry with them he was contending and by this fear to wander more widely he was prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: when cavalry our more freely of plundering and of wasting for the sake itself into the fields had thrown, from all roads and paths the charioteers from the woods he was sending out and with great with danger of our horsemen with them he was clashing and by this fear more widely to wander he was prohibiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Whenever our cavalry ventured too far into the fields to plunder and devastate the land, he would send his charioteers out from the woods by every road and path to engage them, putting our horsemen in great danger. Through this threat, he prevented them from scouting over a wider area.

sentences.latin: Relinquebatur ut neque longius ab agmine legionum discedi Caesar pateretur, et tantum in agris vastandis incendiisque faciendis hostibus noceretur, quantum labore atque itinere legionarii milites efficere poterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was remaining that neither further from the column of the legions to be departed Caesar would allow, and only so much in fields devastating and fires making to the enemies it would be harmed, as much by labor and by march the legionary soldiers to effect were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was left that neither further from the line of the legions to be departed Caesar would allow, and so much in the fields wasting and fires making to the enemies it should be harmed, as much by labor and by march the legionary soldiers to effect were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The only option left was for Caesar to forbid the cavalry from wandering too far from the main body of the legions, and to limit the damage done to the enemy through burning and looting to what the legionary soldiers could achieve through their own difficult marching.

sentences.latin: Interim Trinobantes, prope firmissima earum regionum civitas, ex qua Mandubracius adulescens Caesaris fidem secutus ad eum in continentem Galliam venerat, cuius pater in ea civitate regnum obtinuerat interfectusque erat a Cassivellauno, ipse fuga mortem vitaverat, legatos ad Caesarem mittunt pollicenturque sese ei dedituros atque imperata facturos;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile the Trinobantes, nearly the strongest of those regions state, from which Mandubracius a young man Caesar's faith having followed to him into mainland Gaul had come, whose father in that state the kingdom had held and had been killed by Cassivellaunus, he himself by flight death had avoided, ambassadors to Caesar they send and promise themselves to him they will surrender and commands they will do;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile the Trinobantes, nearly the strongest of those regions state, from which Mandubracius a young man Caesar's protection having followed to him into the continent Gaul had come, whose father in that state the kingship had held and had been killed by Cassivellaunus, he himself by flight death had avoided, ambassadors to Caesar they send and they promise themselves to him to be about to surrender and commands to be about to do;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the Trinobantesperhaps the strongest state in those regionssent ambassadors to Caesar. From this tribe, the young Mandubracius had come to Caesar in mainland Gaul to seek his protection; his father had been king of the tribe but was killed by Cassivellaunus, though Mandubracius himself escaped death by fleeing. They promised to surrender to Caesar and obey his orders.

sentences.latin: petunt ut Mandubracium ab iniuria Cassivellauni defendat atque in civitatem mittat, qui praesit imperiumque obtineat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: they ask that Mandubracius from the injury of Cassivellaunus he defend and into the state he send, who may preside and the power may hold.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: they ask that Mandubracius from the injury of Cassivellaunus he defend and into the state he send, who may be in charge and the power may hold.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They requested that Caesar protect Mandubracius from Cassivellaunus's violence and send him back to the state to rule and hold sovereign power.

sentences.latin: His Caesar imperat obsides quadraginta frumentumque exercitui Mandubraciumque ad eos mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these Caesar commands hostages forty and grain for the army and Mandubracius to them he sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these Caesar commands hostages forty and grain for the army and Mandubracius to them he sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar demanded forty hostages and grain for his army from them, and he sent Mandubracius back to them.

sentences.latin: Illi imperata celeriter fecerunt, obsides ad numerum frumentumque miserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They the commands quickly did, hostages to the number and grain they sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They the commands quickly did, hostages to the number and grain they sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They quickly carried out his orders, sending the required number of hostages and the grain.

sentences.latin: Trinobantibus defensis atque ab omni militum iniuria prohibitis Cenimagni, Segontiaci, Ancalites, Bibroci, Cassi legationibus missis sese Caesari dedunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Trinobantes having been defended and from all injury of soldiers prohibited, the Cenimagni, Segontiaci, Ancalites, Bibroci, Cassi, embassies having been sent, themselves to Caesar surrender.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Trinobantes having been defended and from all of the soldiers injury protected the Cenimagni, Segontiaci, Ancalites, Bibroci, Cassi embassies having been sent themselves to Caesar they surrender.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With the Trinobantes protected and secured from any harassment by the soldiers, the Cenimagni, Segontiaci, Ancalites, Bibroci, and Cassi also sent embassies and surrendered to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Ab his cognoscit non longe ex eo loco oppidum Cassivellauni abesse silvis paludibusque munitum, quo satis magnus hominum pecorisque numerus convenerit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From these he learns not far from that place the town of Cassivellaunus to be away, by woods and marshes fortified, where a sufficiently large number of men and of cattle has gathered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From these he learns not far from that place the town of Cassivellaunus to be away by woods and marshes fortified, where a sufficiently large of men and of cattle number has assembled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From them, he learned that Cassivellaunus's stronghold was not far off, protected by woods and marshes, where a large number of men and cattle had gathered.

sentences.latin: Oppidum autem Britanni vocant, cum silvas impeditas vallo atque fossa munierunt, quo incursionis hostium vitandae causa convenire consuerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A town however the Britons call, when woods entangled with a rampart and a ditch they have fortified, where for the sake of an incursion of enemies avoiding to gather they have been accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A town moreover the Britons call, when woods entangled with a wall and a ditch they have fortified, where of an incursion of enemies of avoiding for the sake to assemble they are accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Britons call it a 'town' when they have fortified dense woods with a rampart and a ditch, where they usually gather to avoid enemy incursions.

sentences.latin: Eo proficiscitur cum legionibus: locum reperit egregie natura atque opere munitum; tamen hunc duabus ex partibus oppugnare contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thither he sets out with the legions: the place he finds excellently by nature and by work fortified; nevertheless this from two parts to attack he hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thither he sets out with the legions: a place he finds excellently by nature and by work fortified; however this from two parts to attack he hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He set out for that place with his legions and found it remarkably well-fortified by both nature and human effort; nevertheless, he prepared to attack it from two sides.

sentences.latin: Hostes paulisper morati militum nostrorum impetum non tulerunt seseque alia ex parte oppidi eiecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies for a little while having delayed of the soldiers our the attack not they bore and themselves from another part of the town they threw out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies having delayed a little while the attack of our soldiers not they bore and themselves from another part of the town they threw out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a brief delay, the enemy could not withstand the assault of our soldiers and fled from another part of the town.

sentences.latin: Magnus ibi numerus pecoris repertus, multique in fuga sunt comprehensi atque interfecti.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A large there number of cattle [was] found, and many in flight were caught and killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great there number of cattle was found, and many in flight were caught and killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A large number of cattle was found there, and many men were captured and killed during the flight.

sentences.latin: Dum haec in his locis geruntur, Cassivellaunus ad Cantium, quod esse ad mare supra demonstravimus, quibus regionibus quattuor reges praeerant, Cingetorix, Carvilius, Taximagulus, Segovax, nuntios mittit atque eis imperat uti coactis omnibus copiis castra navalia de improviso adoriantur atque oppugnent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things in these places are being done, Cassivellaunus to Kent, which to be at the sea above we have shown, over which regions four kings were in command, Cingetorix, Carvilius, Taximagulus, Segovax, messengers sends and to them commands that having been collected all forces the camp naval by surprise they should attack and assault.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things in these places are done, Cassivellaunus to Kent, which to be at the sea above we have shown, over which regions four kings were in command, Cingetorix, Carvilius, Taximagulus, Segovax, messengers sends and to them commands that, having collected all forces, the naval camps by surprise they should attack and assault.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these events were taking place in those areas, Cassivellaunus sent messengers to Kentwhich, as we have mentioned, is by the sea and was ruled by four kings: Cingetorix, Carvilius, Taximagulus, and Segovaxordering them to gather all their forces and launch a surprise attack on the naval camp.

sentences.latin: Ei cum ad castra venissent, nostri eruptione facta multis eorum interfectis, capto etiam nobili duce Lugotorige suos incolumes reduxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They when to the camp had come, our [men] a sally having been made many of them having been killed, having been captured also the noble leader Lugotorix their own [men] unharmed led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They when to the camp had come, our men a sally having been made, many of them having been killed, captured also the noble leader Lugotorix, their own men safe they led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they reached the camp, our men made a sally, killed many of them, captured the noble leader Lugotorix, and returned to their lines without loss.

sentences.latin: Cassivellaunus hoc proelio nuntiato tot detrimentis acceptis, vastatis finibus, maxime etiam permotus defectione civitatum legatos per Atrebatem Commium de deditione ad Caesarem mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cassivellaunus this battle having been reported so many losses having been received, having been devastated the territories, especially also moved by the desertion of the states ambassadors through the Atrebatian Commius about surrender to Caesar sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cassivellaunus this battle having been reported, so many losses having been received, devastated territories, greatly also moved by the defection of the states, ambassadors through the Atrebatian Commius about surrender to Caesar sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Cassivellaunus received news of this battle, having suffered so many losses, seen his lands devastated, and being especially troubled by the defection of the tribes, he sent envoys to Caesar through Commius the Atrebatian to discuss surrender.

sentences.latin: Caesar, cum constituisset hiemare in continenti propter repentinos Galliae motus, neque multum aestatis superesset, atque id facile extrahi posse intellegeret, obsides imperat et quid in annos singulos vectigalis populo Romano Britannia penderet constituit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, when he had decided to winter on the continent because of the sudden of Gaul movements, and not much of summer remained, and that easily to be dragged out to be able he understood, hostages commands and what in years each of tribute to the people Roman Britain should pay he established;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, when he had decided to winter on the continent because of sudden of Gaul movements, and not much of summer remained, and that easily to be dragged out could be he understood, hostages orders and what in years each of tribute to the people Roman Britain should pay he established;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having decided to winter on the continent due to sudden uprisings in Gaul, and since little of the summer remained and he realized the conflict could easily be prolonged, demanded hostages and determined the annual tribute Britain should pay to the Roman people.

sentences.latin: interdicit atque imperat Cassivellauno, ne Mandubracio neu Trinobantibus noceat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he forbids and commands Cassivellaunus, that not Mandubracius nor the Trinobantes he should harm.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he forbids and commands Cassivellaunus, lest Mandubracius nor the Trinobantes he harm.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He strictly forbade Cassivellaunus from harming Mandubracius or the Trinobantes.

sentences.latin: Obsidibus acceptis exercitum reducit ad mare, naves invenit refectas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hostages having been received the army he leads back to the sea, the ships he finds repaired.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hostages having been received, the army he leads back to the sea, ships he finds repaired.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After receiving the hostages, he led the army back to the sea, where he found the ships repaired.

sentences.latin: His deductis, quod et captivorum magnum numerum habebat, et nonnullae tempestate deperierant naves, duobus commeatibus exercitum reportare instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been launched, because both of captives a large number he had, and some by a storm had been lost ships, in two trips the army to carry back he decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been launched, because both of captives a great number he had, and some by storm had perished ships, in two trips the army to carry back he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these were launched, because he had a large number of prisoners and some ships had been lost in the storm, he decided to transport the army back in two trips.

sentences.latin: Ac sic accidit, uti ex tanto navium numero tot navigationibus neque hoc neque superiore anno ulla omnino navis,
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so it happened, that out of so great a number of ships in so many voyages neither in this nor in the previous year any ship at all,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so it happened, that from so great of ships number in so many voyages neither this nor the previous year any at all ship,
sentences.naturalTranslation: And so it happened that, despite such a large number of ships and so many voyages, not a single vessel was lost either this year or the year before,

sentences.latin: quae milites portaret, desideraretur; at ex eis, quae inanes ex continenti ad eum remitterentur et prioris commeatus expositis militibus et quas postea Labienus faciendas curaverat numero LX, perpaucae locum caperent, reliquae fere omnes reicerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which might carry soldiers, was missed; but out of those, which empty from the continent to him were being sent back both of the former convoy the soldiers having been set out and those which afterwards Labienus to be made had cared for in number 60, very few the place reached, the rest almost all were driven back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which soldiers carried, was missing; but from those, which empty from the continent to him were sent back both of the former trip having been set out the soldiers and which afterwards Labienus to be made had cared for in number 60, very few the place reached, the rest almost all were driven back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that was carrying soldiers; but of those which were being sent back to him empty from the continentboth those from the first convoy after the soldiers had been disembarked and the sixty others that Labienus had later seen to being builtvery few reached their destination, while almost all the rest were driven back.

sentences.latin: Quas cum aliquamdiu Caesar frustra exspectasset, ne anni tempore a navigatione excluderetur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when for some time Caesar in vain had waited for, lest by the time of year from sailing he might be excluded,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when for some time Caesar in vain had expected, lest by the year's time from navigation he be excluded,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After Caesar had waited for these in vain for some time, fearing he might be prevented from sailing by the season,

sentences.latin: quod aequinoctium suberat, necessario angustius milites collocavit ac summa tranquillitate consecuta, secunda inita cum solvisset vigilia, prima luce terram attigit omnesque incolumes naves perduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because the equinox was near, by necessity more closely the soldiers he stowed and the greatest tranquility having followed, the second having begun when he had set sail watch, at first light the land he reached and all safe the ships he brought through.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because the equinox was near, by necessity more closely the soldiers he packed and great tranquility having followed, the second having begun when he had set sail watch, at first light land he touched and all safe ships he brought through.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because the equinox was approaching, he was forced to pack the soldiers more closely together; then, a great calm following, he set sail at the beginning of the second watch, reached land at daybreak, and brought all the ships safely to port.

sentences.latin: Subductis navibus concilioque Gallorum Samarobrivae peracto, quod eo anno frumentum in Gallia propter siccitates angustius provenerat, coactus est aliter ac superioribus annis exercitum in hibernis collocare legionesque in plures civitates distribuere;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The ships having been drawn up and a council of the Gauls at Samarobriva having been completed, because in that year grain in Gaul on account of droughts more narrowly had come forth, he was compelled otherwise than in previous years the army in winter quarters to station and the legions into more states to distribute;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been beached the ships and the council of the Gauls at Samarobriva having been completed, because in that year grain in Gaul because of droughts more narrowly had come forth, he was forced otherwise than in previous years the army in winter quarters to place and the legions into more states to distribute;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the ships were hauled up and a council of the Gauls was held at Samarobriva, because the grain crop in Gaul had been thin that year due to droughts, he was forced to station his army in winter quarters differently than in previous years and to distribute the legions among more states.

sentences.latin: ex quibus unam in Morinos ducendam Gaio Fabio legato dedit, alteram in Nervios Quinto Ciceroni, tertiam in Esubios Lucio Roscio; quartam in Remis cum Tito Labieno in confinio Treverorum hiemare iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: out of which one into the Morini to be led to Gaius Fabius the legate he gave, another into the Nervii to Quintus Cicero, a third into the Esubii to Lucius Roscius; a fourth among the Remi with Titus Labienus in the border of the Treveri to winter he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from which one into the Morini to be led to Gaius Fabius the legate he gave, another into the Nervii to Quintus Cicero, a third into the Esubii to Lucius Roscius; a fourth in the Remi with Titus Labienus in the border of the Treveri to winter he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Of these, he gave one to the legate Gaius Fabius to be led into the territory of the Morini, a second to Quintus Cicero among the Nervii, and a third to Lucius Roscius among the Esubii; a fourth he ordered to winter among the Remi with Titus Labienus on the border of the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Tres in Belgis collocavit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Three among the Belgae he stationed:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Three in the Belgae he placed:
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stationed three among the Belgae:

sentences.latin: eis Marcum Crassum quaestorem et Lucium Munatium Plancum et Gaium Trebonium legatos praefecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: over them Marcus Crassus the quaestor and Lucius Munatius Plancus and Gaius Trebonius legates he put in charge.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: over them Marcus Crassus the quaestor and Lucius Munatius Plancus and Gaius Trebonius legates he put in charge.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he put the quaestor Marcus Crassus and the legates Lucius Munatius Plancus and Gaius Trebonius in command of them.

sentences.latin: Vnam legionem, quam proxime trans Padum conscripserat, et cohortes V in Eburones, quorum pars maxima est inter Mosam ac Rhenum, qui sub imperio Ambiorigis et Catuvolci erant, misit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One legion, which recently across the Po he had enrolled, and cohorts five into the Eburones, of whom the part greatest is between the Meuse and the Rhine, who under the command of Ambiorix and Catuvolcus were, he sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One legion, which recently across the Po he had enrolled, and cohorts 5 into the Eburones, of whom the part greatest is between the Meuse and the Rhine, who under the command of Ambiorix and Catuvolcus were, he sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent one legion, which he had recently recruited north of the Po, and five cohorts to the Eburones, the greatest part of whom live between the Meuse and the Rhine and were under the rule of Ambiorix and Catuvolcus.

sentences.latin: Eis militibus Quintum Titurium Sabinum et Lucium Aurunculeium Cottam legatos praeesse iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over those soldiers Quintus Titurius Sabinus and Lucius Aurunculeium Cotta legates to be in command he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Over those soldiers Quintus Titurius Sabinus and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta legates to be in command he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the legates Quintus Titurius Sabinus and Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta to take command of those soldiers.

sentences.latin: Ad hunc modum distributis legionibus facillime inopiae frumentariae sese mederi posse existimavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In this manner with the legions distributed, most easily for the lack of grain himself to be able to remedy he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In this manner with the legions distributed, most easily for the lack of grain himself to be able to remedy he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By distributing the legions in this way, he believed he could most easily remedy the grain shortage.

sentences.latin: Atque harum tamen omnium legionum hiberna praeter eam, quam Lucio Roscio im pacatissimam et quietissimam partem ducendam dederat, milibus passuum centum continebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And of these however all legions the winter quarters except that (one), which to Lucius Roscius into a most peaceful and most quiet part to be led he had given, within thousands of paces a hundred were contained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And however the winter quarters of all these legions, except that one which he had given to Lucius Roscius to be led into a most peaceful and quiet part, were contained within a hundred miles.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The winter quarters of all these legions, however, were contained within a range of one hundred miles, except for the one he had assigned to Lucius Roscius to be led into a very peaceful and quiet region.

sentences.latin: Ipse interea, quoad legiones collocatas munitaque hiberna cognovisset, in Gallia morari constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself meanwhile, until the legions stationed and the winter quarters fortified he had learned, in Gaul to delay decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself meanwhile, until the legions stationed and fortified winter quarters he had learned, in Gaul to delay decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself meanwhile decided to stay in Gaul until he had learned that the legions were stationed and the winter quarters were fortified.

sentences.latin: Erat in Carnutibus summo loco natus Tasgetius, cuius maiores in sua civitate regnum obtinuerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was among the Carnutes of the highest rank born Tasgetius, whose ancestors in their state the kingdom had held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was among the Carnutes in the highest place born Tasgetius, whose ancestors in their own state the kingdom had held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among the Carnutes was Tasgetius, a man of the highest rank, whose ancestors had held the sovereignty in their state.

sentences.latin: Huic Caesar pro eius virtute atque in se benevolentia, quod in omnibus bellis singulari eius onera fuerat usus, maiorum locum restituerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this man Caesar for his virtue and toward himself goodwill, because in all wars the singular of him service he had used, of his ancestors the place had restored.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this man Caesar for his virtue and toward himself goodwill, because in all wars the singular his service he had used, of his ancestors the place had restored.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this man Caesar had restored the position of his ancestors in recognition of his merit and goodwill toward him, because he had made use of his exceptional service in all his wars.

sentences.latin: Tertium iam hunc annum regnantem inimici, multis palam ex civitate eius auctoribus, eum interfecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The third now this year reigning enemies, many openly from the state of him instigators, him they killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The third now this year reigning enemies, many openly from the state his instigators, him they killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While he was now in his third year of reigning, his enemies killed him, with many from his state openly instigating the deed.

sentences.latin: Defertur ea res ad Caesarem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is reported this matter to Caesar.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is reported this matter to Caesar.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This matter was reported to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Ille veritus, quod ad plures pertinebat, ne civitas eorum impulsu deficeret, Lucium Plancum cum legione ex Belgio celeriter in Carnutes proficisci iubet ibique hiemare quorumque opera cognoverat Tasgetium interfectum, hos comprehensos ad se mittere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He having feared, because to many it pertained, lest the state by their impulse might revolt, Lucius Plancus with a legion from Belgium quickly into the Carnutes to set out orders and there to winter and of whom by the work he had learned Tasgetius (had been) killed, these having been seized to himself to send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He having feared, because to many it pertained, lest the state by their impulse might revolt, Lucius Plancus with a legion from Belgium quickly into the Carnutes to set out orders and there to winter and by whose work he had learned Tasgetius killed, these arrested to himself to send.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fearing that the state might revolt at their instigation, since many were involved, he ordered Lucius Plancus to set out quickly with a legion from Belgium to the Carnutes and winter there, and to arrest and send to him those by whose agency he learned Tasgetius had been killed.

sentences.latin: Interim ab omnibus legatis quaestoreque, quibus legiones tradiderat, certior factus est in hiberna perventum locumque hibernis esse munitum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile by all the lieutenants and the quaestor, to whom the legions he had handed over, more certain he was made into the winter quarters it had been arrived and the place for the winter quarters to be fortified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile by all the lieutenants and the quaestor, to whom the legions he had handed over, more certain he was made into winter quarters it had been arrived and the place for winter quarters to be fortified.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, he was informed by all the lieutenants and the quaestor to whom he had assigned the legions that they had arrived at their winter quarters and the sites had been fortified.

sentences.latin: Diebus circiter XV, quibus in hiberna ventum est, initium repentini tumultus ac defectionis ortum est ab Ambiorige et Catuvolco;
sentences.referenceTranslation: In days about fifteen, in which into the winter quarters it was come, the beginning of a sudden uprising and revolt arisen was from Ambiorix and Catuvolcus;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In days about fifteen, in which into winter quarters it was come, the beginning of a sudden uprising and revolt arose from Ambiorix and Catuvolcus;
sentences.naturalTranslation: About fifteen days after they had arrived at their winter quarters, a sudden uprising and revolt broke out, started by Ambiorix and Catuvolcus.

sentences.latin: qui, cum ad fines regni sui Sabino Cottaeque praesto fuissent frumentumque in hiberna comportavissent, Indutiomari Treveri nuntiis impulsi suos concitaverunt subitoque oppressis lignatoribus magna manu ad castra oppugnatum venerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who, when at the borders of their kingdom to Sabinus and Cotta they had been ready and grain into the winter quarters they had conveyed, by the messages of Indutiomarus the Treveran incited, their own [people] they stirred up and suddenly, having overwhelmed the wood-gatherers, with a large band to the camp to attack they came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who, when at the borders of kingdom their own to Sabinus and Cotta ready they had been and grain into winter quarters had brought, of Indutiomarus the Treveran by messages incited their own people they stirred up and suddenly having overwhelmed the wood-gatherers with a large band to the camp to attack they came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These leaders, after meeting Sabinus and Cotta at the borders of their kingdom and conveying grain to the winter quarters, were incited by messages from Indutiomarus of the Treveri; they stirred up their people, suddenly overwhelmed the wood-gatherers, and advanced in force to attack the camp.

sentences.latin: Cum celeriter nostri arma cepissent vallumque adscendissent atque una ex parte Hispanis equitibus emissis equestri proelio superiores fuissent, desperata re hostes suos ab oppugnatione reduxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When quickly our [men] arms had taken and the rampart had ascended and from one part Spanish horsemen having been sent out in a cavalry battle superior they had been, the matter having been despaired of, the enemies their own [men] from the siege led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When quickly our men arms had taken and the rampart had ascended and from one part Spanish horsemen having been sent out in a cavalry battle superior they had been, despaired the matter the enemies their own from the siege led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When our men quickly took up arms and mounted the rampart, and after Spanish cavalry were sent out from one side and proved superior in a cavalry engagement, the enemy despaired of success and withdrew their forces from the assault.

sentences.latin: Tum suo more conclamaverunt, uti aliqui ex nostris ad colloquium prodiret: habere sese, quae de re communi dicere vellent, quibus rebus controversias minui posse sperarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then by their custom they shouted out, that someone from our [men] to a conference should come forward: that they had [things], which about the matter common to speak they wished, by which things controversies to be diminished to be able they hoped.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then in their own custom they shouted out, that some from our men to a conference should come forward: to have themselves, which things about the matter common to say they wished, by which things controversies to be diminished to be able they hoped.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, according to their custom, they shouted for someone from our side to come forward for a conference, claiming they had matters of common interest to discuss, by which they hoped their disputes could be settled.

sentences.latin: Mittitur ad eos colloquendi causa Gaius Arpineius, eques Romanus, familiaris Quinti Tituri, et Quintus Iunius ex Hispania quidam, qui iam ante missu Caesaris ad Ambiorigem ventitare consuerat; apud quos Ambiorix ad hunc modum locutus est:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is sent to them for the sake of conferring Gaius Arpineius, a knight Roman, a friend of Quintus Titurius, and Quintus Iunius from Spain a certain [man], who already before by the sending of Caesar to Ambiorix to go often had been accustomed; among whom Ambiorix in this manner spoke:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is sent to them of conferring for the sake Gaius Arpineius, a knight Roman, a friend of Quintus Titurius, and Quintus Junius from Spain a certain one, who already before by the sending of Caesar to Ambiorix to visit frequently had been accustomed; among whom Ambiorix in this manner spoke:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaius Arpineius, a Roman knight and friend of Quintus Titurius, was sent to them to confer, along with a certain Quintus Iunius from Spain, who had previously been accustomed to visit Ambiorix on Caesar's missions. Before them, Ambiorix spoke in the following manner:

sentences.latin: sese pro Caesaris in se beneficiis plurimum ei confiteri debere, quod eius opera stipendio liberatus esset, quod Aduatucis, finitimis suis, pendere consuesset, quodque ei et filius et fratris filius ab Caesare remissi essent, quos Aduatuci obsidum numero missos apud se in servitute et catenis tenuissent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: [that] he for Caesar's toward himself benefits very much to him to owe to confess, because by his work from tribute he had been freed, which to the Aduatuci, neighbors his, to pay he had been accustomed, and because to him both a son and a brother's son by Caesar had been sent back, whom the Aduatuci in the number of hostages sent among themselves in slavery and chains had held;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: himself for of Caesar toward himself benefits very much to him to confess to owe, because by his work from tribute freed he had been, which to the Aduatuci, neighbors his own, to pay he had been accustomed, and because to him both son and of brother son by Caesar sent back had been, whom the Aduatuci in of hostages the number sent among themselves in slavery and chains had held;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He confessed that he owed a great deal to Caesar for the favors shown him: through Caesar's efforts, he had been freed from the tribute he used to pay to his neighbors, the Aduatuci, and Caesar had returned both his son and his nephew, whom the Aduatuci had held in slavery and chains after they were sent as hostages.

sentences.latin: neque id, quod fecerit de oppugnatione castrorum, aut iudicio aut voluntate sua fecisse, sed coactu civitatis, suaque esse eiusmodi imperia, ut non minus haberet iuris in se multitudo quam ipse in multitudinem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not that, which he did concerning the attack of the camp, either by judgment or by will his own to have done, but by the compulsion of the state, and his own to be of such a kind commands, that not less had of right over himself the multitude than he himself over the multitude.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor that, which he did concerning the attack of the camp, either by judgment or by will his own to have done, but by the compulsion of the state, and his own to be of such a kind powers, that not less had of right over himself the multitude than he himself over the multitude.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stated that his actions regarding the attack on the camp were not done of his own judgment or will, but by the compulsion of his state; his power was such that the people had no less authority over him than he had over the people.

sentences.latin: Civitati porro hanc fuisse belli causam, quod repentinae Gallorum coniurationi resistere non potuerit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the state furthermore this to have been of the war the cause, because a sudden of the Gauls conspiracy to resist it was not able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the state furthermore this to have been of the war the cause, because to the sudden of the Gauls conspiracy to resist it was not able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, the cause of the war for the state was that it could not resist the sudden conspiracy of the Gauls.

sentences.latin: Id se facile ex humilitate sua probare posse, quod non adeo sit imperitus rerum ut suis copiis populum Romanum superari posse confidat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This himself easily from humility his own to be able to prove, because not so much he is inexperienced of things that with his own forces the people Roman to be overcome to be able he trusts.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This himself easily from humility his own to prove to be able, because not so much he is unskilled of things that with his own forces the people Roman to be overcome to be able he trusts.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He could easily prove this from his own insignificance, as he was not so ignorant of affairs as to believe that the Roman people could be defeated by his own forces.

sentences.latin: Sed esse Galliae commune consilium: omnibus hibernis Caesaris oppugnandis hunc esse dictum diem, ne qua legio alterae legioni subsidio venire posset;
sentences.referenceTranslation: But to be of Gaul a common plan: for all the winter quarters of Caesar to be attacked this to be the appointed day, lest any legion to another legion for a help to come should be able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But to be of Gaul a common plan: for all winter quarters of Caesar to be attacked this to be the appointed day, lest any legion to another legion for help to come could;
sentences.naturalTranslation: But it was a general plan of Gaul: this day had been appointed for attacking all of Caesar's winter quarters, so that no legion could come to the aid of another.

sentences.latin: non facile Gallos Gallis negare potuisse, praesertim cum de recuperanda communi libertate consilium initum videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: not easily Gauls to Gauls to deny to have been able, especially when about recovering common liberty a plan entered upon seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not easily Gauls to Gauls to deny to have been able, especially when about recovering common liberty a plan entered upon seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was not easy for Gauls to refuse Gauls, especially when the plan seemed to be about recovering their common liberty.

sentences.latin: Quibus quoniam pro pietate satisfecerit, habere nunc se rationem offici pro beneficiis Caesaris: monere, orare Titurium pro hospitio, ut suae ac militum saluti consulat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To whom since for duty he has satisfied, to have now himself a calculation of duty for the benefits of Caesar: to warn, to pray Titurius for the sake of hospitality, that for his own and the soldiers' safety he might consult.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To whom since for loyalty he has satisfied, to have now himself a calculation of duty for the benefits of Caesar: to warn, to pray Titurius for the sake of hospitality, that for his own and the soldiers' safety he should consult.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since he had satisfied his duty to them, he now had to consider his obligation for Caesar's favors: he warned and begged Titurius, in the name of their hospitality, to look out for his own safety and that of his soldiers.

sentences.latin: Magnam manum Germanorum conductam Rhenum transisse; hanc adfore biduo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A large band of Germans having been hired the Rhine to have crossed; this to be present in two days.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A large band of Germans having been hired the Rhine to have crossed; this to be present in two days.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A large force of hired Germans had crossed the Rhine and would arrive within two days.

sentences.latin: Ipsorum esse consilium, velintne priusquam finitimi sentiant eductos ex hibernis milites aut ad Ciceronem aut ad Labienum deducere, quorum alter milia passuum circiter quinquaginta, alter paulo amplius ab eis absit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of themselves to be the plan, whether they wish before the neighbors perceive led out from winter quarters soldiers either to Cicero or to Labienus to lead, of whom the one thousands of paces about fifty, the other a little more from them is distant.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of themselves to be the plan, whether they wish before the neighbors perceive the led out from winter quarters soldiers either to Cicero or to Labienus to lead down, of whom the one miles of paces about fifty, the other a little more from them is distant.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was for them to decide whether they wished, before the neighbors noticed, to lead the soldiers out of winter quarters to either Cicero or Labienus, one of whom was about fifty miles away, the other a little further.

sentences.latin: Illud se polliceri et iureiurando confirmare tutum iter per fines daturum;
sentences.referenceTranslation: That thing himself to promise and by oath to confirm a safe journey through the borders he would give;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That thing himself to promise and by oath to confirm a safe journey through the borders he would give;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He promised and confirmed by oath that he would grant them safe passage through his territory.

sentences.latin: quod cum faciat, et civitati sese consulere, quod hibernis levetur, et Caesari pro eius meritis gratiam referre.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when he does, both for the state himself to consult, because from winter quarters it is relieved, and to Caesar for his merits thanks to return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when he does, both for the state himself to consult, because from winter quarters it is relieved, and to Caesar for his merits thanks to return.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By doing this, he was both acting in the interest of his state by relieving it of the winter quarters and showing gratitude to Caesar for his kindness.

sentences.latin: Hac oratione habita discedit Ambiorix.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This speech having been held departs Ambiorix.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This speech having been held departs Ambiorix.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having delivered this speech, Ambiorix departed.

sentences.latin: Arpineius et Iunius, quae audierunt, ad legatos deferunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Arpineius and Junius, what they heard, to the legates they report.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Arpineius and Junius, what things they heard, to the legates they report.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Arpineius and Junius reported what they had heard to the legates.

sentences.latin: Illi repentina re perturbati, etsi ab hoste ea dicebantur, tamen non neglegenda existimabant maximeque hac re permovebantur, quod civitatem ignobilem atque humilem Eburonum sua sponte populo Romano bellum facere ausam vix erat credendum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They by the sudden matter disturbed, although by an enemy those things were said, yet not to be neglected they were thinking and especially by this matter they were moved, because the state obscure and humble of the Eburones of its own accord against the Roman people war to make to have dared scarcely was to be believed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They by the sudden thing disturbed, although by an enemy those things were said, nevertheless not to be neglected they were thinking and especially by this thing they were moved, because the state obscure and humble of the Eburones of its own accord against the Roman people war to make to have dared scarcely was to be believed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Disturbed by the sudden news, they felt that even though it came from an enemy, it should not be ignored; they were particularly moved by the fact that it was hard to believe the obscure and humble Eburones would dare to make war on the Roman people on their own initiative.

sentences.latin: Itaque ad consilium rem deferunt magnaque inter eos exsistit controversia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so to a council the matter they bring and a great among them arises controversy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore to a council the matter they bring and a great among them arises controversy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, they brought the matter to a council, and a great controversy arose among them.

sentences.latin: Lucius Aurunculeius compluresque tribuni militum et primorum ordinum centuriones nihil temere agendum neque ex hibernis iniussu Caesaris discedendum existimabant: quantasvis [magnas] copias etiam Germanorum sustineri posse munitis hibernis docebant: rem esse testimonio, quod primum hostium impetum multis ultro vulneribus illatis fortissime sustinuerint: re frumentaria non premi; interea et ex proximis hibernis et a Caesare conventura subsidia: postremo quid esse levius aut turpius, quam auctore hoste de summis rebus capere consilium?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lucius Aurunculeius and several tribunes of soldiers and of the first ranks centurions nothing rashly to be done nor from winter quarters without the order of Caesar to be departed were thinking: however great forces even of Germans to be able to be sustained with fortified winter quarters they were showing: the matter to be for a testimony, because the first of the enemies attack many moreover wounds having been inflicted most bravely they sustained: by the grain matter not to be pressed; meanwhile both from the nearest winter quarters and from Caesar would come reinforcements: finally what to be more light or more shameful, than with an author enemy about the highest matters to take a plan?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Lucius Aurunculeius and several tribunes of soldiers and of the first ranks centurions nothing rashly to be done nor from winter quarters without the order of Caesar to be departed were thinking: however great forces even of Germans to be able to be sustained with fortified winter quarters they were showing: the thing to be for a testimony, because the first of the enemies attack many moreover wounds having been inflicted most bravely they sustained: by the grain matter not to be pressed; meanwhile both from the nearest winter quarters and from Caesar would come reinforcements: finally what to be more light or more shameful, than with an author an enemy about the highest things to take a plan?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Lucius Aurunculeius and several military tribunes and first-rank centurions thought that nothing should be done rashly and that they should not leave winter quarters without Caesar's order. They argued that even very large forces of Germans could be resisted if the winter quarters were fortified, citing as proof that they had bravely withstood the first enemy attack while inflicting many casualties. They were not short of grain, and in the meantime, reinforcements would arrive from the nearest winter quarters and from Caesar. Finally, what could be more irresponsible or shameful than to make decisions on matters of the highest importance on the advice of an enemy?

sentences.latin: Contra ea Titurius sero facturos clamitabat, cum maiores manus hostium adiunctis Germanis convenissent, aut cum aliquid calamitatis in proximis hibernis esset acceptum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Against these things Titurius too late to be going to act was shouting, when larger bands of enemies with Germans joined had come together, or when some of disaster in the nearest winter quarters had been received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Against those things Titurius that they would act too late was shouting, when larger bands of enemies with joined Germans had assembled, or when some of calamity in the nearest winter quarters had been received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In response to these arguments, Titurius kept shouting that they would be acting too late once larger bodies of the enemy, joined by Germans, had assembled, or if some disaster occurred in the nearest winter quarters.

sentences.latin: Brevem consulendi esse occasionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Short of deliberating to be the opportunity.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Short of deliberating to be the opportunity.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The opportunity for deliberation was short.

sentences.latin: Caesarem arbitrari profectum in Italiam;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar he thought to have set out into Italy;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar to think to have set out into Italy;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He believed that Caesar had already set out for Italy;

sentences.latin: neque aliter Carnutes interficiendi Tasgeti consilium fuisse capturos, neque Eburones, si ille adesset, tanta contemptione nostri ad castra venturos esse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not otherwise the Carnutes of killing Tasgetius the plan would have taken, nor the Eburones, if he were present, with such contempt of us to the camp would come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor otherwise the Carnutes of killing Tasgetius the plan would have taken, nor the Eburones, if he were present, with such contempt of us to the camp would come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: otherwise, the Carnutes would not have formed the plan to kill Tasgetius, nor would the Eburones, if Caesar were present, have come to our camp with such contempt for us.

sentences.latin: Non hostem auctorem, sed rem spectare: subesse Rhenum; magno esse Germanis dolori Ariovisti mortem et superiores nostras victorias;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not the enemy as author, but the fact he was looking at: to be near the Rhine; for great to be to the Germans pain Ariovistus' death and our previous victories;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not the enemy as author, but the matter to look at: to be near the Rhine; for a great to be to the Germans grief Ariovistus's death and our previous victories;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was not looking at the enemy as the source of advice, but at the facts: the Rhine was close by; the death of Ariovistus and our previous victories were a source of great grief to the Germans;

sentences.latin: ardere Galliam tot contumeliis acceptis sub populi Romani imperium redactam superiore gloria rei militaris exstincta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to burn Gaul so many insults having been received under the Roman people's power brought back, previous glory of military matter having been extinguished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to burn Gaul so many insults having been received under the Roman people's power brought back, previous glory of military matter extinguished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaul was incensed, having been brought under the sovereignty of the Roman people after suffering so many insults, and its former military glory having been extinguished.

sentences.latin: Postremo quis hoc sibi persuaderet, sine certa re Ambiorigem ad eiusmodi consilium descendisse?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Finally who this to himself would persuade, without a certain thing Ambiorix to of this kind a plan had descended?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Finally who this to himself would persuade, without a certain thing Ambiorix to this kind of plan to have descended?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Finally, who could convince himself that Ambiorix had resorted to such a plan without a certain reason?

sentences.latin: Suam sententiam in utramque partem esse tutam: si nihil esset durius, nullo cum periculo ad proximam legionem perventuros; si Gallia omnis cum Germanis consentiret, unam esse in celeritate positam salutem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: His own opinion in each part to be safe: if nothing were harder, with no danger to the nearest legion they would arrive; if Gaul all with the Germans should agree, one to be in speed placed safety.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: His own opinion in each part to be safe: if nothing were harder, with no danger to the nearest legion they would arrive; if Gaul all with the Germans should agree, one to be in speed placed safety.
sentences.naturalTranslation: His own proposal was safe in either case: if nothing more serious happened, they would reach the nearest legion with no danger; if all Gaul were in league with the Germans, their only safety lay in speed.

sentences.latin: Cottae quidem atque eorum, qui dissentirent, consilium quem habere exitum?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of Cotta indeed and of those, who were disagreeing, the plan what to have end?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of Cotta indeed and of those, who were dissenting, the plan what to have end?
sentences.naturalTranslation: What end, indeed, would the plan of Cotta and those who disagreed with him have?

sentences.latin: In quo si non praesens periculum, at certe longinqua obsidione fames esset timenda.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which if not present danger, but certainly by a long siege hunger would have to be feared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which if not present danger, but certainly by a long siege hunger would be to be feared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In their plan, if there were no immediate danger, there was certainly the threat of starvation from a long siege.

sentences.latin: Hac in utramque partem disputatione habita, cum a Cotta primisque ordinibus acriter resisteretur, " Vincite," inquit, " si ita vultis," Sabinus, et id clariore voce, ut magna pars militum exaudiret;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This in each part dispute having been held, when by Cotta and the first ranks sharply it was resisted, "Conquer," he said, "if so you wish," Sabinus, and that with a clearer voice, so that a large part of the soldiers might hear;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This in each part dispute having been held, when by Cotta and the first ranks sharply it was resisted, "Prevail," he said, "if so you wish," Sabinus, and that with a louder voice, so that a large part of the soldiers might hear;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this dispute had been held on both sides, since Cotta and the first-rank centurions were resisting sharply, Sabinus said, "Have your way, if you so wish," and he said this in a louder voice so that a large part of the soldiers could overhear;

sentences.latin: "neque is sum," inquit, "qui gravissime ex vobis mortis periculo terrear: hi sapient; si gravius quid acciderit, abs te rationem reposcent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: "nor he am I," he said, "who most seriously out of you by death's danger should be terrified: these men will be wise; if more serious anything shall have happened, from you an account they will demand back,"
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "nor he am I," he said, "who most seriously of you by death's danger may be terrified: these will know; if more serious anything shall have happened, from you an account they will demand,"
sentences.naturalTranslation: "I am not the one among you," he said, "who is most terrified by the danger of death: these men will understand; if anything more serious happens, they will demand an accounting from you,"

sentences.latin: qui, si per te liceat, perendino die cum proximis hibernis coniuncti communem cum reliquis belli casum sustineant, non reiecti et relegati longe ab ceteris aut ferro aut fame intereant."
sentences.referenceTranslation: "who, if through you it should be permitted, on the day after tomorrow with the nearest winter quarters joined together the common with the rest of war's chance they would sustain, not rejected and banished far from the others either by sword or by hunger perish."
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "who, if through you it should be permitted, on the day after tomorrow with the nearest winter quarters joined common with the rest of war's chance might sustain, not rejected and banished far from the others either by sword or by hunger perish."
sentences.naturalTranslation: "for if you would allow it, they would be joined with the nearest winter quarters by the day after tomorrow and share the common lot of war with the rest, rather than perishing by the sword or starvation, cast off and isolated far from the others."

sentences.latin: Consurgitur ex consilio; comprehendunt utrumque et orant, ne sua dissensione et pertinacia rem in summum periculum deducant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: It is risen from the council; they grasp each [man] and pray, lest by their own disagreement and stubbornness the matter into the highest danger they lead:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is risen from the council; they grasp each and pray, lest by their disagreement and stubbornness the matter into highest danger they lead:
sentences.naturalTranslation: The council rises; they grasp both leaders and beg them not to bring the situation into extreme danger through their disagreement and stubbornness:

sentences.latin: facilem esse rem, seu maneant, seu proficiscantur, si modo unum omnes sentiant ac probent; contra in dissensione nullam se salutem perspicere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: easy to be the matter, whether they remain, or they set out, if only one thing all feel and approve; on the contrary in disagreement no they safety perceive.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: easy to be the matter, whether they remain, or they set out, if only one thing all feel and approve; on the contrary in disagreement no they safety perceive.
sentences.naturalTranslation: the situation is easy, whether they stay or depart, if only everyone thinks and approves of one plan; on the other hand, they see no safety in disagreement.

sentences.latin: Res disputatione ad mediam noctem perducitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The matter by dispute to middle night is led through.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The matter by dispute to middle night is led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The matter is prolonged by dispute until midnight.

sentences.latin: Tandem dat Cotta permotus manus: superat sententia Sabini.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At last gives Cotta moved hands: prevails the opinion of Sabinus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At last gives Cotta moved hands: prevails the opinion of Sabinus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At last Cotta, deeply moved, gives in: the opinion of Sabinus prevails.

sentences.latin: Pronuntiatur prima luce ituros.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It is announced at first light they will go.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is announced at first light they will go.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It is announced that they will set out at dawn.

sentences.latin: Consumitur vigiliis reliqua pars noctis, cum sua quisque miles circumspiceret, quid secum portare posset, quid ex instrumento hibernorum relinquere cogeretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is consumed in wakefulness the remaining part of the night, when his own each soldier was looking around, what with himself to carry he was able, what from the equipment of the winter quarters to leave he was being forced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is consumed in watches the remaining part of the night, when his own each soldier was looking around, what with himself to carry he might be able, what from the equipment of the winter quarters to leave he was being forced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The rest of the night is spent in wakefulness, as each soldier looked over his belongings to see what he could carry with him and what part of his winter equipment he would be forced to leave behind.

sentences.latin: Omnia excogitantur, quare nec sine periculo maneatur, et languore militum et vigiliis periculum augeatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All things are thought out, why neither without danger it is stayed, and by the exhaustion of the soldiers and wakefulness the danger is increased.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All things are thought out, why neither without danger it might be stayed, and by the exhaustion of the soldiers and by watches the danger might be increased.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Every reason is imagined why it would be dangerous to stay and how the danger would be increased by the exhaustion and wakefulness of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Prima luce sic ex castris proficiscuntur, ut quibus esset persuasum non ab hoste, sed ab homine amicissimo Ambiorige consilium datum, longissimo agmine maximisque impedimentis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light thus from the camps they set out, as [those] to whom it had been persuaded [that] not by an enemy, but by a man most friendly Ambiorix the plan [had been] given, with a very long column and very great baggage.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light thus from the camps they set out, as those to whom it had been persuaded not by an enemy, but by a man most friendly Ambiorix the plan given, in a very long column and with very great baggage.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At dawn, they set out from the camp in a very long column with a massive amount of baggage, convinced that the advice had been given not by an enemy, but by Ambiorix, a most devoted friend.

sentences.latin: At hostes, posteaquam ex nocturno fremitu vigiliisque de profectione eorum senserunt, collocatis insidiis bipertito in silvis opportuno atque occulto loco a milibus passuum circiter duobus Romanorum adventum exspectabant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the enemies, after from the nocturnal noise and watches about the departure of them they perceived, with ambushes placed in two parts in the woods in a favorable and hidden place from thousands of paces about two the Romans' arrival were awaiting,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the enemies, after from the nocturnal noise and watches about the departure of them they perceived, having placed ambushes in two parts in the woods in a favorable and hidden place from thousands of paces about two of the Romans the arrival were awaiting,
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the enemy, having perceived their departure from the noise and the lack of sleep during the night, set an ambush in two divisions in a favorable and hidden spot in the woods about two miles away, where they awaited the Romans' arrival.

sentences.latin: et cum se maior pars agminis in magnam convallem demisisset, ex utraque parte eius vallis subito se ostenderunt novissimosque premere et primos prohibere ascensu atque iniquissimo nostris loco proelium committere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and when itself the greater part of the column into a great valley had descended, from each part of that valley suddenly themselves they showed and the last [men] to press and the first to prohibit from ascent and in a most unfavorable for our [men] place battle to join they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and when itself the greater part of the column into a great valley had sent down, from each part of that valley suddenly themselves they showed and the last to press and the first to prohibit from ascent and in a most unfavorable for our men place battle to join they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the greater part of the column had descended into a large valley, the enemy suddenly appeared on both sides of the valley and began to press the rear, block the vanguard from climbing out, and engage in battle in a place most disadvantageous to our men.

sentences.latin: Tum demum Titurius, qui nihil ante providisset, trepidare et concursare cohortesque disponere, haec tamen ipsa timide atque ut eum omnia deficere viderentur; quod plerumque eis accidere consuevit, qui in ipso negotio consilium capere coguntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then finally Titurius, who nothing before had foreseen, to tremble and to run about and the cohorts to arrange, these [things] however themselves timidly and as if him all [things] to fail seemed; which mostly to those to happen is accustomed, who in the business itself a plan to take are compelled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then at last Titurius, who nothing before had foreseen, to tremble and to run about and the cohorts to arrange, these however themselves timidly and so that him all things to fail seemed; which mostly to those to happen is accustomed, who in the business itself a plan to take are forced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then at last Titurius, who had foreseen nothing beforehand, began to panic, run about, and deploy his cohorts, yet he did even these things timidly and in a way that suggested all control was failing him; this usually happens to those who are forced to make a plan in the heat of the moment.

sentences.latin: At Cotta, qui cogitasset haec posse in itinere accidere atque ob eam causam profectionis auctor non fuisset, nulla in re communi saluti deerat et in appellandis cohortandisque militibus imperatoris et in pugna militis officia praestabat.
