sentences.referenceTranslation: But Cotta, who had thought these [things] to be able on the journey to happen and for that cause of the departure the author had not been, in no thing for the common safety was failing and in calling upon and encouraging the soldiers of a commander and in the fight of a soldier the duties he was performing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Cotta, who had thought these things to be able on the journey to happen and for that cause of the departure an author had not been, in no thing to the common safety was failing and in calling upon and encouraging the soldiers of a commander and in the fight of a soldier the duties he was performing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Cotta, who had anticipated that these things might happen on the march and for that reason had opposed the departure, did not fail the common safety in any respect; he performed the duties of a general in addressing and encouraging the troops, and those of a soldier in the thick of the fight.

sentences.latin: Cum propter longitudinem agminis minus facile omnia per se obire et, quid quoque loco faciendum esset, providere possent, iusserunt pronuntiare, ut impedimenta relinquerent atque in orbem consisterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Since on account of the length of the column less easily all [things] by themselves to attend to and, what in each place to be done was, to foresee they were able, they ordered to announce, that the baggage they should leave and into a circle they should stand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Since on account of the length of the column less easily all things by themselves to attend to and, what in each place to be done was, to foresee they were able, they ordered to announce, that the baggage they should leave and into a circle they should stand.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since, because of the length of the column, they could not easily attend to everything themselves or foresee what needed to be done in every location, they ordered the word to be passed for the men to abandon the baggage and form a circle.

sentences.latin: Quod consilium etsi in eiusmodi casu reprehendendum non est, tamen incommode accidit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which plan although in a case of such a kind to be blamed is not, however inconveniently it happened:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which plan although in such a kind of case to be blamed is not, however inconveniently it happened:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although this plan is not to be criticized in such an emergency, it nevertheless turned out unfortunately:

sentences.latin: nam et nostris militibus spem minuit et hostes ad pugnam alacriores effecit, quod non sine summo timore et desperatione id factum videbatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: for both for our soldiers hope it diminished and the enemies to the fight more eager it made, because not without the greatest fear and desperation that done seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: for both to our soldiers hope it diminished and the enemies to the fight more eager it made, because not without the highest fear and desperation it done seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: for it both diminished the hope of our soldiers and made the enemy more eager for the fight, because the action appeared to have been taken out of extreme fear and desperation.

sentences.latin: Praeterea accidit, quod fieri necesse erat, ut vulgo milites ab signis discederent, quae quisque eorum carissima haberet, ab impedimentis petere atque arripere properaret, clamore et fletu omnia complerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Besides it happened, which to happen necessary was, that commonly the soldiers from the standards should depart, [the things] which each of them most dear held, from the baggage to seek and to snatch up he should hasten, with shouting and weeping all [things] were filled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Besides it happened, which to happen necessary was, that commonly the soldiers from the standards should depart, which things each of them most dear held, from the baggage to seek and to snatch he should hasten, with shouting and weeping all things were being filled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, it happened, as was inevitable, that the soldiers generally left their standards and hurried to seek and snatch from the baggage whatever each held most dear, while the whole place was filled with shouting and weeping.

sentences.latin: At barbaris consilium non defuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But to the barbarians a plan was not lacking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But to the barbarians a plan was not lacking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the barbarians were not lacking a plan.

sentences.latin: Nam duces eorum tota acie pronuntiare iusserunt, ne quis ab loco discederet: illorum esse praedam atque illis reservari quaecumque Romani reliquissent: proinde omnia in victoria posita existimarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For the leaders of them in the whole battle-line to announce ordered, lest anyone from the place should depart: of those to be the booty and for those to be reserved whatever the Romans had left: therefore all things in victory placed they should think.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For the leaders of them in the whole battle-line to announce ordered, lest anyone from the place should depart: of them to be the booty and for them to be reserved whatever the Romans had left behind: therefore all things in victory placed they should think.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For their leaders ordered it to be announced along the whole line that no one should leave his post: that the booty was theirs and for them was reserved whatever the Romans left behind: therefore they should consider everything to depend on victory.

sentences.latin: Erant et virtute et studio pugnandi pares; nostri, tametsi ab duce et a fortuna deserebantur, tamen omnem spem salutis in virtute ponebant, et quotiens quaeque cohors procurrerat, ab ea parte magnus numerus hostium cadebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They were both in valor and in zeal of fighting equal; our men, although by the leader and by fortune they were being deserted, nevertheless all hope of safety in valor were placing, and as often as each cohort had run forward, from that part a great number of enemies was falling.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They were both in valor and in zeal of fighting equal; our men, although by the leader and by fortune they were being deserted, nevertheless all hope of safety in valor were placing, and as often as each cohort had run forward, from that part a great number of enemies was falling.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They were equal both in courage and in their desire for fighting; our men, although they were being deserted by their leader and by fortune, nevertheless placed all hope of safety in courage, and whenever any cohort charged forward, a great number of the enemy fell in that quarter.

sentences.latin: Qua re animadversa Ambiorix pronuntiari iubet, ut procul tela coniciant neu propius accedant et, quam in partem Romani impetum fecerint, cedant (levitate armorum et cotidiana exercitatione nihil eis noceri posse),
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been noticed Ambiorix to be announced orders, that from afar weapons they should hurl nor nearer should approach and, into which part the Romans an attack have made, they should yield (by the lightness of arms and daily exercise nothing to them to be able to be harmed),
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been noticed Ambiorix to be announced orders, that from afar weapons they should hurl nor nearer approach and, into which part the Romans an attack have made, they should yield (by the lightness of arms and daily exercise nothing to them to be able to be harmed),
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having noticed this, Ambiorix ordered it to be announced that they should hurl their weapons from a distance and not approach too closely, and that they should give way in whatever direction the Romans made an attack (stating that because of the lightness of their armor and their daily training, no harm could be done to them),

sentences.latin: rursus se ad signa recipientes insequantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: again themselves to the standards betaking they should pursue.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: again themselves to the standards betaking they should follow.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and should pursue them again as they retreated to their standards.

sentences.latin: Quo praecepto ab eis diligentissime observato, cum quaepiam cohors ex orbe excesserat atque impetum fecerat, hostes velocissime refugiebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which command by them most diligently having been observed, when any cohort from the circle had gone out and an attack had made, the enemies most swiftly were fleeing back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which command by them most diligently having been observed, when any cohort from the circle had gone out and an attack had made, the enemies most swiftly were fleeing back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This command being most diligently observed by them, whenever any cohort left the circle and made a charge, the enemy retreated with great speed.

sentences.latin: Interim eam partem nudari necesse erat et ab latere aperto tela recipi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile that part to be exposed necessary was and from the side open weapons to be received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile that part to be exposed necessary was and from the side open weapons to be received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the meantime, that part of the line was necessarily exposed, and weapons were received on their open flank.

sentences.latin: Rursus cum in eum locum unde erant egressi reverti coeperant, et ab eis qui cesserant et ab eis qui proximi steterant circumveniebantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Again when into that place from where they had gone out to return they had begun, both by those who had yielded and by those who nearest had stood they were being surrounded;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Again when into that place from where they had gone out to return they had begun, both by those who had yielded and by those who nearest had stood they were being surrounded;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they began to return again to the place from which they had advanced, they were surrounded both by those who had given way and by those who had stood nearest to them.

sentences.latin: sin autem locum tenere vellent, nec virtuti locus relinquebatur, neque ab tanta multitudine coniecta tela conferti vitare poterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if however the place to hold they wished, neither for valor a place was being left, nor by so great a multitude hurled weapons crowded together to avoid they were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if however the place to hold they wished, neither for valor a place was being left, nor by so great a multitude hurled weapons crowded together to avoid they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If, however, they wished to hold their ground, no opportunity was left for courage, nor could they, being crowded together, avoid the weapons hurled by so great a multitude.

sentences.latin: Tamen tot incommodis conflictati, multis vulneribus acceptis resistebant et magna parte diei consumpta, cum a prima luce ad horam octavam pugnaretur, nihil quod ipsis esset indignum committebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nevertheless by so many disasters distressed, many wounds having been received they were resisting and a great part of the day having been consumed, when from first light to the hour eighth it was being fought, nothing which for themselves was unworthy were they committing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nevertheless by so many disadvantages distressed, many wounds having been received they were resisting and a great part of the day having been consumed, when from first light to the hour eighth it was being fought, nothing which for themselves was unworthy they were committing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, though distressed by so many disadvantages and having received many wounds, they continued to resist; and after a great part of the day had been spent, although they had been fighting from dawn until the eighth hour, they did nothing unworthy of themselves.

sentences.latin: Tum Tito Balventio, qui superiore anno primum pilum duxerat, viro forti et magnae auctoritatis, utrumque femur tragula traicitur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then for Titus Balventius, who in the previous year the first century had led, a man brave and of great authority, each thigh by a javelin is pierced;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then for Titus Balventius, who in the previous year the first century had led, a man brave and of great authority, each thigh by a javelin is pierced;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then Titus Balventius, a brave man of great authority who the previous year had been chief centurion, had both his thighs pierced by a javelin.

sentences.latin: Quintus Lucanius, eiusdem ordinis, fortissime pugnans, dum circumvento filio subvenit, interficitur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quintus Lucanius, of the same rank, most bravely fighting, while to [his] surrounded son he comes to help, is killed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quintus Lucanius, of the same rank, most bravely fighting, while for the surrounded son he comes to help, is killed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Quintus Lucanius, a centurion of the same rank, was killed while fighting most bravely as he went to the aid of his surrounded son;

sentences.latin: Lucius Cotta legatus omnes cohortes ordinesque adhortans in adversum os funda vulneratur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lucius Cotta the legate all cohorts and ranks encouraging into the facing face by a sling is wounded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Lucius Cotta the legate all cohorts and ranks encouraging in the facing face by a sling is wounded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Lucius Cotta, the legate, while encouraging all the cohorts and ranks, was wounded directly in the face by a sling stone.

sentences.latin: His rebus permotus Quintus Titurius, cum procul Ambiorigem suos cohortantem conspexisset, interpretem suum Gnaeum Pompeium ad eum mittit rogatum ut sibi militibusque parcat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things moved Quintus Titurius, when from afar Ambiorix his own [men] encouraging he had caught sight of, his interpreter Gnaeus Pompeius to him sends to ask that to him and the soldiers he spare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things moved Quintus Titurius, when from afar Ambiorix his own men encouraging he had seen, his interpreter Gnaeus Pompeius to him sends to ask that for himself and the soldiers he spare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Deeply moved by these events, Quintus Titurius, having caught sight of Ambiorix in the distance encouraging his men, sent his interpreter Gnaeus Pompeius to him to ask that he spare him and his soldiers.

sentences.latin: Ille appellatus respondit: si velit secum colloqui, licere; sperare a multitudine impetrari posse, quod ad militum salutem pertineat; ipsi vero nihil nocitum iri, inque eam rem se suam fidem interponere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That [one] having been addressed replied: if he should wish with him to speak, it is permitted; he hoped from the multitude to be obtained it could, what to the soldiers' safety pertained; to himself indeed nothing harmed would be, and into that matter he his own pledge interposed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He having been addressed replied: if he should wish with him to speak, it to be permitted; to hope from the multitude to be able to be obtained, what to the soldiers' safety pertained; to himself indeed nothing to be about to be harmed, and into that matter he his own faith was pledging.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ambiorix replied to the appeal: if Sabinus wished to confer with him, it was permitted; he hoped that he could obtain from the multitude what pertained to the safety of the soldiers; as for Sabinus himself, no harm would be done to him, and he pledged his word to that effect.

sentences.latin: Ille cum Cotta saucio communicat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: He with Cotta wounded communicates,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He with Cotta wounded communicates,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Sabinus conferred with the wounded Cotta,

sentences.latin: si videatur, pugna ut excedant et cum Ambiorige una colloquantur: sperare ab eo de sua ac militum salute impetrari posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if it should seem [good], from the battle that they should withdraw and with Ambiorix together speak: he hoped from him about his own and the soldiers' safety to be obtained it could.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if it should seem [good], from the battle that they should depart and with Ambiorix together speak: to hope from him about their own and the soldiers' safety to be able to be obtained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: asking whether it seemed right for them to withdraw from the battle and confer with Ambiorix together; he hoped that he could obtain from him safety for themselves and the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Cotta se ad armatum hostem iturum negat atque in eo perseverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cotta himself to an armed enemy to be about to go denies and in that persists.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cotta himself to an armed enemy to be about to go denies and in that perseveres.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Cotta declared that he would not go to an armed enemy and persisted in that resolution.

sentences.latin: Sabinus quos in praesentia tribunos militum circum se habebat et primorum ordinum centuriones se sequi iubet et, cum propius Ambiorigem accessisset, iussus arma abicere imperatum facit suisque ut idem faciant imperat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Sabinus which in the presence tribunes of soldiers around himself he was having and of the first ranks centurions himself to follow orders and, when nearer to Ambiorix he had approached, ordered arms to throw away the command he does and to his [men] that the same they should do he commands.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Sabinus those whom in the present the tribunes of soldiers around himself he was having and of the first ranks the centurions himself to follow orders and, when nearer to Ambiorix he had approached, ordered arms to throw away the command he does and to his own that the same they should do he commands.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Sabinus ordered the military tribunes he had around him at the time and the centurions of the first rank to follow him; when he had come closer to Ambiorix, being ordered to throw down his arms, he obeyed the command and ordered his men to do the same.

sentences.latin: Interim, dum de condicionibus inter se agunt longiorque consulto ab Ambiorige instituitur sermo, paulatim circumventus interficitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile, while about conditions among themselves they act and a longer by design by Ambiorix is started conversation, gradually surrounded he is killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile, while about conditions among themselves they act and a longer by design by Ambiorix is started conversation, gradually surrounded he is killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, while they were discussing terms and a longer conversation was being deliberately started by Ambiorix, Sabinus was gradually surrounded and killed.

sentences.latin: Tum vero suo more victoriam conclamant atque ululatum tollunt impetuque in nostros facto ordines perturbant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then indeed by their custom victory they shout and a howl they raise and an attack on our [men] having been made the ranks they throw into confusion.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then indeed in their own custom victory they shout and a howl they raise and an attack on our men having been made the ranks they throw into confusion.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then indeed, according to their custom, they shouted victory and raised a howl; having made a charge against our men, they threw the ranks into confusion.

sentences.latin: Ibi Lucius Cotta pugnans interficitur cum maxima parte militum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There Lucius Cotta fighting is killed with the greatest part of the soldiers.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There Lucius Cotta fighting is killed with the greatest part of the soldiers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There Lucius Cotta was killed while fighting, along with the greater part of his soldiers.

sentences.latin: Reliqui se in castra recipiunt unde erant egressi;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The rest themselves into the camp retreat from where they had gone out;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The rest themselves into the camp withdraw from where they had gone out;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The survivors retreated to the camp from which they had set out;

sentences.latin: ex quibus Lucius Petrosidius aquilifer, cum magna multitudine hostium premeretur, aquilam intra vallum proiecit; ipse pro castris fortissime pugnans occiditur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from whom Lucius Petrosidius the eagle-bearer, when by a great multitude of enemies he was being pressed, the eagle inside the rampart threw; he himself before the camp most bravely fighting is killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from whom Lucius Petrosidius the eagle-bearer, when by a great multitude of enemies he was being pressed, the eagle inside the rampart threw; he himself before the camp most bravely fighting is killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among them, the standard-bearer Lucius Petrosidius, being hard-pressed by a great swarm of enemies, threw the eagle inside the rampart; he himself was killed fighting most bravely in front of the camp.

sentences.latin: Illi aegre ad noctem oppugnationem sustinent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: They with difficulty until night the attack sustain;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They with difficulty until night the attack sustain;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They held out against the attack with difficulty until nightfall;

sentences.latin: noctu ad unum omnes desperata salute se ipsi interficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at night to one all, despaired of safety, themselves they kill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at night to one all, safety having been despaired of, themselves they kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the night, despairing of safety, they all killed themselves to a man.

sentences.latin: Pauci ex proelio lapsi incertis itineribus per silvas ad Titum Labienum legatum in hiberna perveniunt atque eum de rebus gestis certiorem faciunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A few from the battle having escaped by uncertain paths through the woods to Titus Labienus the legate into winter quarters arrive and him about the things done more certain make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A few from the battle having escaped by uncertain routes through the forests to Titus Labienus the legate into winter quarters arrive and him about the things done more certain make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A few who escaped from the battle reached the legate Titus Labienus at his winter quarters by wandering paths through the woods and informed him of what had happened.

sentences.latin: Hac victoria sublatus Ambiorix statim cum equitatu in Aduatucos, qui erant eius regno finitimi, proficiscitur; neque noctem neque diem intermittit peditatumque se subsequi iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this victory elated Ambiorix immediately with the cavalry into the Aduatuci, who were to his kingdom neighboring, sets out; neither night nor day he lets pass and the infantry himself to follow he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By this victory elated Ambiorix immediately with the cavalry into the Aduatuci, who were to his kingdom neighboring, sets out; neither night nor day he lets pass and the infantry himself to follow he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Elated by this victory, Ambiorix immediately set out with his cavalry for the Aduatuci, who were neighbors of his kingdom; he paused neither night nor day and ordered the infantry to follow him.

sentences.latin: Re demonstrata Aduatucisque concitatis postero die in Nervios pervenit hortaturque, ne sui in perpetuum liberandi atque ulciscendi Romanos pro eis quas acceperint iniuriis occasionem dimittant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The matter having been explained and the Aduatuci having been incited, on the following day into the Nervii he arrives and exhorts, lest of themselves in perpetuity freeing and of avenging the Romans for those which they received injuries the opportunity they let slip:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The matter having been shown and the Aduatuci having been stirred up on the next day into the Nervii he arrives and exhorts, that not of themselves in perpetuity of liberating and of avenging the Romans for those which they received injuries the opportunity they let slip:
sentences.naturalTranslation: After explaining the situation and inciting the Aduatuci, he reached the Nervii the next day and urged them not to let slip the opportunity of liberating themselves forever and of taking vengeance on the Romans for the wrongs they had suffered:

sentences.latin: interfectos esse legatos duos magnamque partem exercitus interisse demonstrat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: to have been killed the legates two and a great part of the army to have perished he points out;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to have been killed the legates two and a great part of the army to have perished he shows;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He pointed out that two legates had been killed and a large part of the army had perished;

sentences.latin: nihil esse negoti subito oppressam legionem quae cum Cicerone hiemet interfici; se ad eam rem profitetur adiutorem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nothing to be of business suddenly overwhelmed the legion which with Cicero winters to be killed; himself for that matter he declares a helper.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nothing to be of trouble suddenly overwhelmed the legion which with Cicero winters to be killed; himself for that matter he declares an assistant.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He claimed it would be no trouble for the legion wintering with Cicero to be suddenly overwhelmed and destroyed; he offered himself as an ally for that purpose.

sentences.latin: Facile hac oratione Nerviis persuadet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Easily by this speech to the Nervii he persuades.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Easily by this speech the Nervii he persuades.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He easily persuaded the Nervii with this speech.

sentences.latin: Itaque confestim dimissis nuntiis ad Ceutrones, Grudios, Levacos, Pleumoxios, Geidumnos, qui omnes sub eorum imperio sunt, quam maximas manus possunt cogunt et de improviso ad Ciceronis hiberna advolant nondum ad eum fama de Tituri morte perlata.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so immediately with messengers having been sent to the Ceutrones, Grudii, Levaci, Pleumoxii, Geidumni, who all under their command are, as greatest bands as they can they collect and from un-foreseen to Cicero's winter quarters they fly not yet to him the report about Titurius' death having been carried.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so immediately having been sent messengers to the Ceutrones, Grudii, Levaci, Pleumoxii, Geidumni, who all under their power are, as great as possible bands they can they collect and from the unforeseen to Cicero's winter quarters they fly not yet to him the report about Titurius' death having been brought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having immediately dispatched messengers to the Ceutrones, Grudii, Levaci, Pleumoxii, and Geidumniall of whom were under their rulethey gathered as large a force as possible and rushed unexpectedly to Cicero's winter quarters before the news of Titurius' death had reached him.

sentences.latin: Huic quoque accidit, quod fuit necesse, ut nonnulli milites, qui lignationis munitionisque causa in silvas discessissent, repentino equitum adventu interciperentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this one also it happened, which was necessary, that some soldiers, who for the sake of wood-gathering and fortification into the woods had departed, by the sudden of the horsemen arrival were intercepted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one also it happened, which was necessary, that some soldiers, who for the sake of wood-gathering and fortification into the woods had departed, by the sudden of the horsemen arrival were intercepted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To him also it happened, as was inevitable, that several soldiers who had gone into the woods to gather timber and fortification materials were cut off by the sudden arrival of the enemy cavalry.

sentences.latin: His circumventis magna manu Eburones, Nervii, Aduatuci atque horum omnium socii et clientes legionem oppugnare incipiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been surrounded by a large band the Eburones, Nervii, Aduatuci and of these all the allies and clients the legion to attack begin.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been surrounded with a great band the Eburones, Nervii, Aduatuci and of these all the allies and clients the legion to attack begin.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these men were surrounded, the Eburones, Nervii, and Aduatuci, along with all their allies and dependents, began to attack the legion with a massive force.

sentences.latin: Nostri celeriter ad arma concurrunt, vallum conscendunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our men quickly to arms run together, the rampart they climb.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men quickly to arms run together, the rampart they climb.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men quickly rushed to arms and mounted the rampart.

sentences.latin: Aegre is dies sustentatur, quod omnem spem hostes in celeritate ponebant atque hanc adepti victoriam in perpetuum se fore victores confidebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With difficulty that day is sustained, because all hope the enemies in speed were placing and this having gained victory in perpetuity themselves would be victors they were confident.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With difficulty that day is sustained, because all hope the enemies in speed were placing and this having obtained victory in perpetuity themselves would be victors they were confident.
sentences.naturalTranslation: That day's attack was sustained with difficulty, because the enemy placed all their hope in speed and were confident that, if they gained this victory, they would be victorious forever.

sentences.latin: Mittuntur ad Caesarem confestim ab Cicerone litterae magnis propositis praemiis, si pertulissent: obsessis omnibus viis missi intercipiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Are sent to Caesar immediately by Cicero letters with great having been offered rewards, if they had carried through: with besieged all roads those sent are intercepted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Are sent to Caesar immediately by Cicero letters with great having been offered rewards, if they had carried through: having been blocked all ways the [messengers] sent are intercepted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Letters were immediately sent by Cicero to Caesar with offers of great rewards if the messengers delivered them; however, since all the roads were blocked, the messengers were intercepted.

sentences.latin: Noctu ex materia, quam munitionis causa comportaverant, turres admodum CXX excitantur incredibili celeritate; quae deesse operi videbantur, perficiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At night from the material, which for the sake of fortification they had collected, towers fully 120 are raised with incredible speed; the things which to be lacking to the work seemed, are completed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At night from the material, which for the sake of fortification they had brought together, towers fully 120 are raised with incredible speed; [the things] which to be lacking to the work seemed, are completed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During the night, using the timber they had collected for the fortifications, fully 120 towers were erected with incredible speed, and whatever seemed lacking in the defenses was completed.

sentences.latin: Hostes postero die multo maioribus coactis copiis castra oppugnant, fossam complent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies on the following day with much greater having been collected forces the camp attack, the ditch they fill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies on the next day with much greater having been collected forces the camp attack, the ditch they fill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, the enemy attacked the camp with much larger forces and filled in the ditch.

sentences.latin: Eadem ratione, qua pridie, ab nostris resistitur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the same method, as on the day before, by our men it is resisted:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the same method, as on the day before, by our men it is resisted:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Resistance was made by our men in the same manner as on the previous day.

sentences.latin: hoc idem reliquis deinceps fit diebus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: this same (thing) for the remaining in succession happens days.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This same thing on the remaining in succession happens days.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The same thing happened on each of the following days.

sentences.latin: Nulla pars nocturni temporis ad laborem intermittitur; non aegris, non vulneratis facultas quietis datur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: No part of nocturnal time for labor is interrupted; not to the sick, not to the wounded opportunity of rest is given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: No part of the nocturnal time for labor is interrupted; not to the sick, not to the wounded the opportunity of rest is given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Work continued through every part of the night; no opportunity for rest was granted even to the sick or the wounded.

sentences.latin: Quaecumque ad proximi diei oppugnationem opus sunt noctu comparantur; multae praeustae sudes, magnus muralium pilorum numerus instituitur; turres contabulantur, pinnae loricaeque ex cratibus attexuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whatever things for the next day's assault necessary are by night are prepared; many burned-at-the-tip stakes, a great of wall-pikes number is set up; towers are floored, battlements and breastworks from wickerwork are woven on.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whatever for the next day's assault necessary are by night are prepared; many burned-at-the-end stakes, a large of wall-pikes number is set up; towers are boarded up, battlements and breastworks from wickerwork are woven on.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Whatever was needed for the next day's defense was prepared during the night; many stakes with charred tips and a great number of heavy mural pikes were readied; towers were built up with stories, and battlements and breastworks were woven from wicker.

sentences.latin: Ipse Cicero, cum tenuissima valetudine esset, ne nocturnum quidem sibi tempus ad quietem relinquebat, ut ultro militum concursu ac vocibus sibi parcere cogeretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Himself Cicero, although in very thin health he was, not even nocturnal indeed for himself time for rest was leaving, so that actually by the soldiers' running together and voices to himself to spare he was compelled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Himself Cicero, although in very thin health he was, not even nocturnal indeed for himself time for rest he was leaving, so that actually by the soldiers' running together and voices to himself to spare he was compelled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Cicero himself, although he was in very poor health, did not leave even the night for his own rest, until he was actually forced to spare himself by the spontaneous gathering and pleas of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Tunc duces principesque Nerviorum qui aliquem sermonis aditum causamque amicitiae cum Cicerone habebant colloqui sese velle dicunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then the leaders and chiefs of the Nervii who some of speech access and cause of friendship with Cicero were having to confer themselves to wish they say.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then the leaders and chiefs of the Nervii who some of speech access and cause of friendship with Cicero were having to speak themselves to wish they say.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then the leaders and chieftains of the Nervii, who had some means of access for conversation and a pretext of friendship with Cicero, stated that they wished to confer with him.

sentences.latin: Facta potestate eadem quae Ambiorix cum Titurio egerat commemorant: omnem esse in armis Galliam;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Made the opportunity the same things which Ambiorix with Titurius had done they recount: all to be in arms Gaul;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been made the opportunity the same things which Ambiorix with Titurius had done they mention: all to be in arms Gaul;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the opportunity was granted, they recounted the same points that Ambiorix had discussed with Titurius: that all Gaul was in arms;

sentences.latin: Germanos Rhenum transisse; Caesaris reliquorumque hiberna oppugnari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the Germans the Rhine to have crossed; Caesar's and of the rest winter quarters to be attacked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Germans the Rhine to have crossed; Caesar's and of the rest the winter quarters to be attacked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the Germans had crossed the Rhine; and that the winter quarters of Caesar and the others were being attacked.

sentences.latin: Addunt etiam de Sabini morte: Ambiorigem ostentant fidei faciendae causa.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They add also about of Sabinus death: Ambiorix they point out of faith making for the sake.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They add also about Sabinus's death: Ambiorix they point to for the sake of faith making.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They also added news of Sabinus's death, pointing to Ambiorix to gain credibility.

sentences.latin: Errare eos dicunt, si quidquam ab his praesidi sperent, qui suis rebus diffidant; sese tamen hoc esse in Ciceronem populumque Romanum animo, ut nihil nisi hiberna recusent atque hanc inveterascere consuetudinem nolint:
sentences.referenceTranslation: To err them they say, if anything from these of protection they should hope, who in their own affairs distrust; themselves however this to be toward Cicero and the people Roman in mind, that nothing except winter quarters they refuse and this to grow old custom they do not wish:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To err them they say, if anything from these of protection they hope for, who in their own affairs distrust; themselves however of this to be toward Cicero and the people Roman mind, that nothing except winter quarters they refuse and this to become established custom they do not wish:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said that the Romans were mistaken if they hoped for any protection from those who despaired of their own situation; however, they claimed to be of such a mind toward Cicero and the Roman people that they objected to nothing except the winter quarters and did not wish this practice to become established:

sentences.latin: licere illis incolumibus per se ex hibernis discedere et quascumque in partes velint sine metu proficisci.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be permitted to them unharmed through them from winter quarters to depart and whatever into parts they wish without fear to set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to be permitted to them unharmed through them from the winter quarters to depart and whatever into parts they wish without fear to set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that it was permitted for them to depart from the winter quarters unharmed with their consent and to set out for whatever regions they wished without fear.

sentences.latin: Cicero ad haec unum modo respondit: non esse consuetudinem populi Romani accipere ab hoste armato condicionem:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cicero ad these things one only responded: not to be the custom of the people Roman to accept from an enemy armed a condition:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cicero to these things one only replied: not to be the custom of the people Roman to accept from an enemy armed a condition:
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this, Cicero made only one reply: that it was not the custom of the Roman people to accept terms from an armed enemy.

sentences.latin: si ab armis discedere velint, se adiutore utantur legatosque ad Caesarem mittant; sperare pro eius iustitia, quae petierint, impetraturos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if from arms to depart they should wish, him as helper they should use and ambassadors to Caesar they should send; to hope in accordance with his justice, what they have sought, they will obtain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if from arms to depart they wish, himself as helper they should use and ambassadors to Caesar they should send; to hope according to his justice, what they have asked, they will obtain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If they wished to lay down their arms, they should use him as an intermediary and send ambassadors to Caesar; he hoped that, given Caesar's sense of justice, they would obtain what they requested.

sentences.latin: Ab hac spe repulsi Nervii vallo pedum IX et fossa pedum XV hiberna cingunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From this hope driven back the Nervii with a wall of feet nine and a ditch of feet fifteen the winter-quarters surround.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From this hope driven back the Nervii with a wall of feet 9 and a ditch of feet 15 the winter quarters surround.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Driven back from this hope, the Nervii surrounded the winter quarters with a nine-foot rampart and a fifteen-foot trench.

sentences.latin: Haec et superiorum annorum consuetudine ab nobis cognoverant et, quosdam de exercitu habebant captivos, ab eis docebantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things both from of former years custom from us they had learned and, certain from the army they were holding prisoners, by them they were being taught;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things both of previous years from custom from us they had learned and, certain from the army they were having prisoners, by them they were being taught;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had learned these techniques from us through the practice of previous years, and they were also being taught by certain prisoners from the army whom they held.

sentences.latin: sed nulla ferramentorum copia quae esset ad hunc usum idonea, gladiis caespites circumcidere, manibus sagulisque terram exhaurire nitebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: but with no of iron-tools supply which was for this use suitable, with swords sods to cut around, with hands and small-cloaks earth to carry out they were striving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but with no of iron tools supply which was for this use suitable, with swords sods to cut around, with hands and small cloaks earth to take out they were striving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But having no supply of iron tools suitable for this purpose, they were forced to cut sods with their swords and carry out the earth with their hands and cloaks.

sentences.latin: Qua quidem ex re hominum multitudo cognosci potuit: nam minus horis tribus milium pedum XV in circuitu munitionem perfecerunt
sentences.referenceTranslation: From which indeed thing of men the multitude to be known was able: for in less than hours three of miles of feet fifteen in circuit a fortification they completed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From which indeed from thing of men the multitude to be known was able: for in less than hours three of miles of feet 15 in circuit the fortification they completed
sentences.naturalTranslation: From this circumstance, the vast number of men could be realized; for in less than three hours, they completed a fortification fifteen miles in circumference.

sentences.latin: reliquisque diebus turres ad altitudinem valli, falces testudinesque, quas idem captivi docuerant, parare ac facere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and on the remaining days towers to the height of the wall, hooks and tortoises, which the same prisoners had taught, to prepare and to make they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and on the remaining days towers to the height of the wall, hooks and tortoises, which the same prisoners had taught, to prepare and to make they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following days, they began to prepare and construct towers to the height of the rampart, as well as grappling hooks and sheds, which the same prisoners had taught them how to make.

sentences.latin: Septimo oppugnationis die maximo coorto vento ferventes fusili ex argilla glandes fundis et fervefacta iacula in casas, quae more Gallico stramentis erant tectae, iacere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the seventh of the siege day a very great having arisen wind glowing from molten clay bullets with slings and heated javelins into the huts, which in the manner Gallic with straw were covered, to throw they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the seventh of the assault day a very great having arisen wind hot from molten from clay bullets with slings and heated javelins into the huts, which in the manner Gallic with straw were covered, to throw they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the seventh day of the siege, a very strong wind having arisen, they began to discharge from slings red-hot bullets made of molten clay and heated javelins into the huts, which, in the Gallic fashion, were thatched with straw.

sentences.latin: Hae celeriter ignem comprehenderunt et venti magnitudine in omnem locum castrorum distulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These quickly fire caught and by the wind's greatness into every place of the camp they spread.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These quickly the fire caught and by the wind's greatness into every place of the camp they spread.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These quickly caught fire, and the wind's force spread the flames to every part of the camp.

sentences.latin: Hostes maximo clamore sicuti parta iam atque explorata victoria turres testudinesque agere et scalis vallum ascendere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies with the greatest shout just as if gained already and assured victory towers and tortoises to move and with ladders the wall to climb began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies with a very great shout just as if gained already and assured victory towers and tortoises to drive and with ladders the wall to climb began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With a massive shout, as if victory were already won and assured, the enemy began to move forward their towers and sheds and to scale the rampart with ladders.

sentences.latin: At tanta militum virtus atque ea praesentia animi fuit, ut, cum undique flamma torrerentur maximaque telorum multitudine premerentur suaque omnia impedimenta atque omnes fortunas conflagrare intellegerent, non modo demigrandi causa de vallo decederet nemo, sed paene ne respiceret quidem quisquam, ac tum omnes acerrime fortissimeque pugnarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But so great of the soldiers the valor and that presence of mind was, that, when from all sides by flame they were being scorched and by a very great of weapons multitude they were being pressed and their own all baggage and all fortunes to be burning they understood, not only for the sake of departing from the rampart departed no one, but almost not even looked back indeed anyone, and then all most keenly and most bravely were fighting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But so great of the soldiers the valor and that presence of mind was, that, when from all sides by flame they were being scorched and by the greatest of weapons multitude they were being pressed and their own all baggage and all fortunes to be burning they understood, not only for the sake of departing from the rampart departed no one, but almost not even looked back indeed anyone, and then all most fiercely and most bravely were fighting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But such was the soldiers' courage and presence of mind that, although they were scorched by fire on all sides, hard-pressed by a massive volley of weapons, and aware that all their baggage and possessions were burning, not a single man left the rampart to seek safety; in fact, hardly anyone even looked back, but instead they all continued to fight with the utmost ferocity and bravery.

sentences.latin: Hic dies nostris longe gravissimus fuit; sed tamen hunc habuit eventum, ut eo die maximus numerus hostium vulneraretur atque interficeretur, ut se sub ipso vallo constipaverant recessumque primis ultimi non dabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This day for our [men] by far most heavy was; but however this it had outcome, that on that day a very great number of the enemies was wounded and was killed, as themselves under the very rampart they had crowded and a retreat to the first the last [men] were not giving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This day for ours by far the most heavy was; but however this it had outcome, that on that day the greatest number of enemies was wounded and was killed, as themselves under the very rampart they had crowded and retreat to the first the last were not giving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was by far the most difficult day for our men; nevertheless, it had this result: a huge number of the enemy were wounded and killed, because they had crowded themselves right under the rampart, and those in the rear were not giving those in front any room to retreat.

sentences.latin: Paulum quidem intermissa flamma et quodam loco turri adacta et contingente vallum tertiae cohortis centuriones ex eo, quo stabant, loco recesserunt suosque omnes removerunt, nutu vocibusque hostes, si introire vellent, vocare coeperunt; quorum progredi ausus est nemo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A little indeed having been abated the flame and in a certain place a tower having been brought up and touching the rampart of the third cohort the centurions from that, in which they were standing, place withdrew and their own all [men] they moved back, by gesture and by voices the enemies, if to enter they wished, to call they began; of whom to step forward dared no one.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A little indeed having been abated the flame and in a certain place a tower having been moved up and touching the rampart, of the third cohort the centurions from that, in which they were standing, place withdrew and their own all removed, by nod and by voices the enemy, if to enter they wished, to call they began; of whom to go forward dared no one.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the fire had died down a little and a siege tower had been pushed up to touch the rampart at one point, the centurions of the third cohort withdrew from their position and pulled back all their men; then, by gestures and shouts, they began to challenge the enemy to enter if they wished, but not one of them dared to advance.

sentences.latin: Tum ex omni parte lapidibus coniectis deturbati, turrisque succensa est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then from every part stones having been thrown they [were] driven off, and the tower set on fire was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then from every part stones having been thrown they were driven off, and the tower set on fire was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, stones were hurled from every direction, the enemy were driven back, and their tower was set on fire.

sentences.latin: Erant in ea legione fortissimi viri, centuriones, qui primis ordinibus appropinquarent, Titus Pullo et Lucius Vorenus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There were in that legion most brave men, centurions, who to the first ranks were approaching, Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There were in that legion most brave men, centurions, who to the first ranks were approaching, Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In that legion, there were two very brave centurions, Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus, who were approaching the highest rank.

sentences.latin: Hi perpetuas inter se controversias habebant, quinam anteferretur, omnibusque annis de locis summis simultatibus contendebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These perpetual between themselves controversies were having, which one should be preferred, and in all years about positions with the highest rivalries they were contending.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These perpetual among themselves controversies were having, who should be preferred, and in all years about positions with the highest rivalries they were contending.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These two had continual disputes about which of them should be promoted ahead of the other, and every year they competed for high position with intense rivalry.

sentences.latin: Ex his Pullo, cum acerrime ad munitiones pugnaretur, "Quid dubitas," inquit, " Vorene? aut quem locum tuae probandae virtutis exspectas ?
sentences.referenceTranslation: From these Pullo, when most fiercely at the fortifications it was being fought, "Why do you hesitate," he said, "Vorenus? or what place of your to be proved valor do you wait for?"
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From these Pullo, when most fiercely at the fortifications it was being fought, "Why do you hesitate," he said, "Vorenus? or what place of your proving valor do you wait for?"
sentences.naturalTranslation: One of them, Pullo, while the fighting at the fortifications was at its peak, said, "Why hesitate, Vorenus? What better opportunity are you waiting for to prove your courage?"

sentences.latin: Hic dies de nostris controversiis iudicabit." Haec cum dixisset, procedit extra munitiones quaque pars hostium confertissma est visa irrumpit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: "This day about our controversies will judge." These [things] when he had said, he proceeds outside the fortifications and where the part of the enemies most dense was seen he breaks in.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "This day about our controversies will judge." These things when he had said, he proceeds outside the fortifications and where the part of the enemy most crowded was seen he breaks in.
sentences.naturalTranslation: "Today will decide our dispute." After saying this, he advanced beyond the fortifications and charged into the densest part of the enemy ranks.

sentences.latin: Ne Vorenus quidem tum sese vallo continet, sed omnium veritus existimationem subsequitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not even Vorenus then himself by the rampart contains, but of all having feared the opinion he follows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not even Vorenus then himself by the rampart contains, but of all having feared the opinion he follows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Not even Vorenus stayed behind the rampart then, but followed, fearing what everyone would think of him.

sentences.latin: Mediocri spatio relicto Pullo pilum in hostes immittit atque unum ex multitudine procurrentem traicit; quo percusso et exanimato hunc scutis protegunt, in hostem tela universi coniciunt neque dant regrediendi facultatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A moderate space having been left Pullo a javelin into the enemies sends and one from the multitude running forward he pierces; who having been struck and killed this [man] with shields they protect, against the enemy weapons all together they hurl and not they give of retreating the opportunity.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A moderate space having been left Pullo a javelin into the enemy sends and one from the multitude running forward pierces; whom struck and breathless this one with shields they protect, against the enemy weapons all together they hurl and not they give of retreating the opportunity.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After covering a short distance, Pullo threw his javelin at the enemy and pierced one who was running forward from the crowd. As the man fell struck and lifeless, the enemy covered him with their shields, and all together hurled their weapons at Pullo, giving him no chance to retreat.

sentences.latin: Transfigitur scutum Pulloni et verutum in balteo defigitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is pierced the shield for Pullo and a javelin in the belt is fixed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Pierced is the shield for Pullo and a javelin in the belt is fixed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pullo's shield was pierced through and a javelin was driven into his belt.

sentences.latin: Avertit hic casus vaginam et gladium educere conanti dextram moratur manum, impeditumque hostes circumsistunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Turns aside this event the scabbard and the sword to draw trying the right delays hand, and [him] hindered the enemies surround.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Turns aside this event the scabbard and the sword to draw trying the right it delays hand, and hindered the enemy surround.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This accident knocked his scabbard out of place and delayed his right hand as he tried to draw his sword; the enemy surrounded him in his hindered state.

sentences.latin: Succurrit inimicus illi Vorenus et laboranti subvenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Runs to help the rival to that one Vorenus and to [him] struggling comes to aid.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Runs to help his rival to him Vorenus and to the struggling one he brings aid.
sentences.naturalTranslation: His rival, Vorenus, ran to his aid and supported him in his struggle.

sentences.latin: Ad hunc se confestim a Pullone omnis multitudo convertit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this one themselves immediately from Pullo the whole multitude turns:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one themselves immediately from Pullo the whole multitude turns:
sentences.naturalTranslation: The entire crowd immediately turned away from Pullo toward Vorenus:

sentences.latin: illum veruto arbitrantur occisum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that one by a javelin they think killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that one by the javelin they think killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they thought that Pullo had been killed by the javelin.

sentences.latin: Gladio comminus rem gerit Vorenus atque uno interfecto reliquos paulum propellit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: With sword at close quarters the matter carries on Vorenus and one having been killed the rest a little he drives forward;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With sword at close quarters the thing carries on Vorenus and one having been killed the rest a little he drives back;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Vorenus carried on the fight at close quarters with his sword and, having killed one, drove the rest back a little;

sentences.latin: dum cupidius instat, in locum deiectus inferiorem concidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: while too eagerly he presses on, into a place having been thrown down lower he falls.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: while too eagerly he presses on, into a place thrown down lower he fell.
sentences.naturalTranslation: while pressing on too eagerly, he stumbled and fell into a depression in the ground.

sentences.latin: Huic rursus circumvento fert subsidium Pullo,
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this one again having been surrounded brings help Pullo,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one again surrounded brings help Pullo,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pullo in turn brought help to him as he was surrounded,

sentences.latin: atque ambo incolumes compluribus interfectis summa cum laude sese intra munitiones recipiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and both safe many having been killed with highest praise themselves within the fortifications they withdraw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and both unhurt several having been killed with the highest with praise themselves inside the fortifications they withdraw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and both, having killed many of the enemy, withdrew safely inside the fortifications with the highest praise.

sentences.latin: Sic fortuna in contentione et certamine utrumque versavit, ut alter alteri inimicus auxilio salutique esset, neque diiudicari posset, uter utri virtute anteferendus videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus fortune in the rivalry and contest each one turned, so that the one to the other rival for help and for safety was, nor to be decided it was able, which of the two to which of the two in valor to be preferred seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: So fortune in the contention and the struggle each one dealt with, that the one to the other rival for help and for safety was, and not to be decided it could, which to which in valor to be preferred seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this way, fortune dealt with both in their rivalry and conflict so that each rival was a source of help and safety to the other, and it could not be decided which of the two seemed preferable in valor.

sentences.latin: Quanto erat in dies gravior atque asperior oppugnatio, et maxime quod magna parte militum confecta vulneribus res ad paucitatem defensorum pervenerat, tanto crebriores litterae nuntiique ad Caesarem mittebantur; quorum pars deprehensa in conspectu nostrorum militum cum cruciatu necabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By how much was into days heavier and harsher the siege, and especially because with a large part of the soldiers exhausted by wounds the matter to a small number of defenders had arrived, by so much more frequent letters and messengers to Caesar were being sent; of whom a part caught in sight of our soldiers with torture were being killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By how much was into days heavier and harsher the siege, and especially because with a great part of the soldiers worn out by wounds the matter to a fewness of defenders had arrived, by so much more frequent letters and messengers to Caesar were being sent; of whom a part caught in sight of our soldiers with torture was being killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The more serious and fierce the siege became every dayespecially because, with a large portion of the soldiers exhausted by wounds, the defense had fallen to a small number of menthe more frequently letters and messengers were sent to Caesar. Some of these, when captured in sight of our soldiers, were tortured to death.

sentences.latin: Erat unus intus Nervius nomine Vertico, loco natus honesto, qui a prima obsidione ad Ciceronem perfugerat suamque ei fidem praestiterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was one inside a Nervian by name Vertico, from a place born honorable, who from the first siege to Cicero had fled and his own loyalty to him had proven.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was one inside a Nervian by name Vertico, from a place born honorable, who from the first siege to Cicero had fled and his own loyalty to him had shown.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Inside the camp was a Nervian named Vertico, born of high rank, who had fled to Cicero at the start of the siege and had proven his loyalty to him.

sentences.latin: Hic servo spe libertatis magnisque persuadet praemiis, ut litteras ad Caesarem deferat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man a slave with hope of freedom and with great persuades rewards, that letters to Caesar he might carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This man to a slave by hope of liberty and by great persuades rewards, that letters to Caesar he should carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He persuaded a slave, by promising him freedom and great rewards, to deliver a letter to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Has ille in iaculo illigatas effert et Gallus inter Gallos sine ulla suspicione versatus ad Caesarem pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These he on a javelin bound carries out and a Gaul among Gauls without any suspicion having moved about to Caesar arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These he in a javelin tied carries out and a Gaul among Gauls without any suspicion having moved about to Caesar arrives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The slave carried the letter out tied to a javelin, and moving among the Gauls without suspicion as a Gaul himself, he reached Caesar.

sentences.latin: Ab eo de periculis Ciceronis legionisque cognoscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From him about the dangers of Cicero and of the legion it is learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By him about the dangers of Cicero and of the legion it is learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From him, the facts about the danger facing Cicero and his legion were learned.

sentences.latin: Caesar acceptis litteris hora circiter XI diei statim nuntium in Bellovacos ad M. Crassum quaestorem mittit, cuius hiberna aberant ab eo milia passuum XXV;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar with the letters received at hour about the 11th of the day immediately a messenger into the Bellovaci to M. Crassus the quaestor sends, whose winter quarters were away from him thousands of paces 25;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar with the letters received at hour about the eleventh of the day immediately a messenger into the Bellovaci to M. Crassus the quaestor sends, whose winter quarters were away from him thousands of paces twenty-five;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon receiving the letter around the eleventh hour of the day, Caesar immediately sent a messenger to the quaestor Marcus Crassus in the territory of the Bellovaci, whose winter quarters were twenty-five miles away.

sentences.latin: iubet media nocte legionem proficisci celeriterque ad se venire.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he orders at middle night the legion to set out and quickly to him to come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he orders at middle night the legion to set out and quickly to him to come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered the legion to set out at midnight and come to him quickly.

sentences.latin: Exit cum nuntio Crassus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Goes out with the messenger Crassus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Goes out with the messenger Crassus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Crassus left as soon as he received the message.

sentences.latin: Alterum ad Gaium Fabium legatum mittit, ut in Atrebatium fines legionem adducat, qua sibi iter faciendum sciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Another to Gaius Fabius the legate he sends, that into of the Atrebates borders the legion he might lead, where for himself a journey to be made he was knowing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Another to Gaius Fabius the legate he sends, that into of the Atrebates borders the legion he should lead, where for himself a journey to be made he was knowing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent another messenger to the legate Gaius Fabius, ordering him to lead his legion into the territory of the Atrebates, through which he knew he would have to march.

sentences.latin: Scribit Labieno, si rei publicae commodo facere posset, cum legione ad fines Nerviorum veniat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He writes to Labienus, if for the republic's advantage to do he were able, with the legion to the borders of the Nervii he should come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He writes to Labienus, if with the republic's advantage to do he could, with the legion to the borders of the Nervii he should come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He wrote to Labienus that, if he could do so without detriment to the state, he should come with his legion to the borders of the Nervii.

sentences.latin: Reliquam partem exercitus, quod paulo aberat longius, non putat exspectandam; equites circiter quadringentos ex proximis hibernis colligit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The remaining part of the army, because it was away a little further, he does not think to be waited for; cavalry about four hundred from the nearest winter quarters he collects.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The remaining part of the army, because a little it was away further, not he thinks to be waited for; horsemen about four hundred from the nearest winter quarters he collects.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He decided not to wait for the rest of the army because it was a bit further away; instead, he gathered about four hundred cavalry from the nearest winter quarters.

sentences.latin: Hora circiter tertia ab antecursoribus de Crassi adventu certior factus eo die milia passuum XX procedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At hour about the third by the scouts about Crassus' arrival more certain having been made, on that day miles of paces twenty he proceeds.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At hour about the third by the scouts about of Crassus arrival informed made on that day thousands of paces twenty he proceeds.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Informed by scouts of Crassus' arrival around the third hour, he advanced twenty miles that day.

sentences.latin: Crassum Samarobrivae praeficit legionemque attribuit, quod ibi impedimenta exercitus, obsides civitatum, litteras publicas frumentumque omne quod eo tolerandae hiemis causa devexerat relinquebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Crassus over Samarobriva he puts in charge and a legion assigns, because there the baggage of the army, hostages of the states, letters public and grain all which there for the sake of enduring winter he had brought he was leaving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Crassus at Samarobriva he puts in charge and a legion assigns, because there the baggage of the army, hostages of the states, letters public and grain all which to there for the sake of enduring winter he had brought he was leaving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He put Crassus in charge of Samarobriva and assigned him a legion, because he was leaving there the army's baggage, the hostages of the states, the public records, and all the grain he had brought there to last through the winter.

sentences.latin: Fabius, ut imperatum erat, non ita multum moratus in itinere cum legione occurrit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Fabius, as it had been commanded, not so much having delayed, on the journey with the legion meets him.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Fabius, as commanded it had been, not so much having delayed on the journey with the legion meets.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As ordered, Fabius did not delay long and met him on the march with his legion.

sentences.latin: Labienus interitu Sabini et caede cohortium cognita, cum omnes ad eum Treverorum copiae venissent, veritus, si ex hibernis fugae similem profectionem fecisset, ut hostium impetum sustinere posset, praesertim quos recenti victoria efferri sciret, litteras Caesari remittit, quanto cum periculo legionem ex hibernis educturus esset; rem gestam in Eburonibus perscribit; docet omnes equitatus peditatusque copias Treverorum tria milia passuum longe ab suis castris consedisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus, the death of Sabinus and the slaughter of the cohorts having been learned, since all to him of the Treveri forces had come, fearing, if from winter quarters of flight similar a departure he had made, that of the enemies the attack to sustain he might be able, especially whom by recent victory to be elated he knew, letters to Caesar sends back, with how much danger the legion from winter quarters about to lead out he would be; the thing done among the Eburones he writes out; he informs all of cavalry and infantry forces of the Treveri three thousands of paces far from his camps to have settled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus with the death of Sabinus and the slaughter of the cohorts known, when all to him of the Treveri forces had come, having feared, if from winter quarters of flight similar a departure he had made, that of the enemies the attack to sustain he could, especially whom with recent victory to be elated he knew, letters to Caesar sends back, with how much with danger the legion from winter quarters about to lead out he would be; the matter done among the Eburones he writes out; he teaches all of cavalry and of infantry forces of the Treveri three thousands of paces far from his own camp to have settled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus, learning of Sabinus' death and the slaughter of the cohorts, and seeing that all the forces of the Treveri had come against him, feared that if he left winter quarters in a move resembling flight, he would be unable to withstand the enemy's attackespecially since he knew they were emboldened by their recent victory. He sent word back to Caesar, explaining the great danger of leading the legion out of winter quarters; he described what had happened among the Eburones and reported that all the Treveran cavalry and infantry had encamped three miles from his own camp.

sentences.latin: Caesar consilio eius probato, etsi opinione trium legionum deiectus ad duas redierat, tamen unum communis salutis auxilium in celeritate ponebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, his plan having been approved, although from the expectation of three legions disappointed to two he had returned, nevertheless one of common safety help in speed he was placing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar with the plan of him approved, although from the expectation of three legions disappointed to two he had returned, nevertheless one of common safety help in speed was placing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar approved of his plan, and although he was disappointed in his hope of having three legions and was reduced to two, he still believed that the only hope for their common safety lay in speed.

sentences.latin: Venit magnis itineribus in Nerviorum fines.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He comes by great marches into of the Nervii the borders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He comes by great journeys into of the Nervii borders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He arrived in the territory of the Nervii by forced marches.

sentences.latin: Ibi ex captivis cognoscit, quae apud Ciceronem gerantur, quantoque in periculo res sit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There from captives he learns, what things at Cicero's are being done, and in how much danger the matter is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There from captives he learns, what things at Cicero's are being done, and in how much in danger the matter is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There he learned from prisoners what was happening at Cicero's camp and how dangerous the situation was.

sentences.latin: Tum cuidam ex equitibus Gallis magnis praemiis persuadet uti ad Ciceronem epistolam deferat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then a certain one from the horsemen Gallic with great rewards he persuades that to Cicero a letter he should carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then to a certain one from the horsemen Gauls with great rewards he persuades that to Cicero a letter he should carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, by offering great rewards, he persuaded one of the Gallic cavalrymen to carry a letter to Cicero.

sentences.latin: Hanc Graecis conscriptam litteris mittit, ne intercepta epistola nostra ab hostibus consilia cognoscantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This in Greek written letters he sends, lest intercepted the letter our by the enemies plans be learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This in Greek written letters he sends, lest with intercepted letter our by the enemies plans be learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent this written in Greek characters so that, if the letter were intercepted, our plans would not be discovered by the enemy.

sentences.latin: Si adire non possit, monet ut tragulam cum epistola ad amentum deligata intra munitionem castrorum abiciat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If to approach not he should be able, he advises that a javelin with a letter to the thong tied within the fortification of the camp he throw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If to approach he is not able, he warns that a javelin with a letter to the thong tied within the fortification of the camp he should throw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he cannot get close, he instructs him to throw a javelin, with a letter tied to its strap, inside the camp's fortifications.

sentences.latin: In litteris scribit se cum legionibus profectum celeriter adfore; hortatur ut pristinam virtutem retineat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the letter he writes himself with the legions having set out quickly to be about to be present; he urges that his former courage he should retain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the letter he writes himself with the legions having set out quickly to be about to be present; he urges that his former valor he should retain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the letter he writes that he has set out with the legions and will arrive soon; he urges him to maintain his former courage.

sentences.latin: Gallus periculum veritus, ut erat praeceptum, tragulam mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Gaul the danger having feared, as it had been commanded, the javelin sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Gaul the danger having feared, as it had been commanded, the javelin sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fearing the danger, the Gaul threw the javelin as he had been instructed.

sentences.latin: Haec casu ad turrim adhaesit neque ab nostris biduo animadversa tertio die a quodam milite conspicitur, dempta ad Ciceronem defertur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This by chance to a tower stuck and not by our men for two days noticed on the third day by a certain soldier is seen, having been taken down to Cicero it is carried.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This by chance to a tower stuck and not by our men for two days noticed on the third day by a certain soldier is seen, having been taken down to Cicero it is carried.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By chance, this stuck to a tower and, not being noticed by our men for two days, was seen on the third day by a soldier, who took it down and brought it to Cicero.

sentences.latin: Ille perlectam in conventu militum recitat maximaque omnes laetitia adficit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He it having been read through in an assembly of the soldiers reads aloud and with the greatest all joy he affects.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He it having been read through in an assembly of soldiers reads aloud and with the greatest all joy affects.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After reading it through, he read it aloud in an assembly of the soldiers, filling everyone with the greatest joy.

sentences.latin: Tum fumi incendiorum procul videbantur; quae res omnem dubitationem adventus legionum expulit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then the smokes of fires from afar were seen; which thing all doubt of the arrival of the legions drove away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then the smokes of fires at a distance were seen; which thing all doubt of the arrival of the legions drove away.
