sentences.naturalTranslation: Then the smoke of fires was seen in the distance, an event which removed all doubt about the arrival of the legions.

sentences.latin: Galli re cognita per exploratores obsidionem relinquunt, ad Caesarem omnibus copiis contendunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Gauls the matter having been learned through scouts the siege leave, toward Caesar with all forces they hasten.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Gauls the matter having been learned through scouts the siege leave, toward Caesar with all forces they hasten.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the Gauls learned of this through their scouts, they abandoned the siege and marched toward Caesar with all their forces.

sentences.latin: Hae erant armata circiter milia LX.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These were armed about thousands sixty.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These were armed about thousands sixty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These numbered about sixty thousand armed men.

sentences.latin: Cicero data facultate Gallum ab eodem Verticone, quem supra demonstravimus, repetit, qui litteras ad Caesarem deferat; hunc admonet, iter caute diligenterque faciat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cicero given the opportunity a Gaul from the same Vertico, whom above we have mentioned, seeks again, who a letter to Caesar should carry; this man he warns, the journey cautiously and diligently he should make:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cicero the opportunity having been given a Gaul from the same Vertico, whom above we have shown, seeks again, who a letter to Caesar should carry; this man he warns, the journey cautiously and diligently he should make:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Cicero, having found the opportunity, requested another Gaul from the same Vertico mentioned above to carry a letter to Caesar; he warned him to make the journey cautiously and carefully.

sentences.latin: perscribit in litteris hostes ab se discessisse omnemque ad eum multitudinem convertisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He writes out in the letter the enemies from him to have departed and all to him the multitude to have turned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he writes out in the letter the enemies from himself to have departed and all to him the multitude to have turned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He wrote in the letter that the enemy had departed from him and had turned their entire multitude toward Caesar.

sentences.latin: Quibus litteris circiter media nocte Caesar adlatis suos facit certiores eosque ad dimicandum animo confirmat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which letters around middle night Caesar having been brought his (men) he makes more certain and them to fighting in mind he strengthens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which letter about middle of the night Caesar having been brought his men makes more certain and them to fighting in mind strengthens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After receiving this letter around midnight, Caesar informed his men and encouraged them for the coming battle.

sentences.latin: Postero die luce prima movet castra et circiter milia passuum quattuor progressus trans vallem et rivum multitudinem hostium conspicatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day at light first he moves camp and around thousands of paces four having advanced across a valley and a stream a multitude of the enemies he catches sight of.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the following day at light first he moves camp and about thousands of paces four having advanced across a valley and a stream the multitude of the enemies he catches sight of.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At dawn the next day, he moved camp and, after advancing about four miles, caught sight of a great number of the enemy across a valley and a stream.

sentences.latin: Erat magni periculi res tantulis copiis iniquo loco dimicare; tum, quoniam obsidione liberatum Ciceronem sciebat, aequo animo remittendum de celeritate existimabat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was of great danger a thing with so small forces in an unfavorable place to fight; then, since from siege freed Cicero he knew, with a calm mind that it must be relaxed concerning speed he was thinking:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was of great danger a thing with so small forces in an unfavorable place to fight; then, since from siege freed Cicero he knew, with a level mind to be relaxed about speed he was thinking:
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was a matter of great risk to fight in an unfavorable position with such small forces; furthermore, since he knew Cicero had been freed from the siege, he felt he could safely reduce his speed.

sentences.latin: consedit et quam aequissimo loco potest castra communit atque haec, etsi erant exigua per se vix hominum milium septem praesertim nullis cum impedimentis, tamen angustiis viarum quam maxime potest contrahit, eo consilio, ut in summam contemptionem hostibus veniat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he sat down and in as favorable a place as he can camp he fortifies and these, although they were small by themselves scarcely of men thousands seven especially with no baggage, nevertheless by narrowness of paths as much as he can he contracts, with that plan, that into the greatest contempt to the enemies he might come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he sat down and in as level a place as he is able the camp he fortifies and these, although they were small by themselves scarcely of men thousands seven especially none with baggage, nevertheless by narrowness of paths as much as most he is able he contracts, with that plan, that into the greatest contempt to the enemies he might come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He halted and fortified his camp in the most favorable position possible; although the camp was already small, holding barely seven thousand men and no baggage, he further contracted it by narrowing the passages as much as possible, intending to make the enemy hold him in utter contempt.

sentences.latin: Interim speculatoribus in omnes partes dimissis explorat quo commodissime itinere vallem transire possit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile scouts into all parts having been sent out he explores by what most convenient route the valley to cross he might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile scouts into all parts having been sent out he explores by what most conveniently route the valley to cross he is able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, having sent out scouts in all directions, he investigated the most convenient route to cross the valley.

sentences.latin: Eo die parvulis equestribus proeliis ad aquam factis utrique sese suo loco continent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that day small cavalry battles at the water having been made both themselves in their own place they contain:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On that day very small cavalry battles at the water having been made both themselves in their own place contain:
sentences.naturalTranslation: That day, after some minor cavalry skirmishes near the water, both sides kept to their own positions.

sentences.latin: Galli, quod ampliores copias,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Gauls, because larger forces,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Gauls, because larger forces,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Gauls did so because they were waiting for larger forces,

sentences.latin: quae nondum convenerant, exspectabant; Caesar, si forte timoris simulatione hostes in suum locum elicere posset, ut citra vallem pro castris proelio contenderet, si id efficere non posset,
sentences.referenceTranslation: which not yet had assembled, they were expecting; Caesar, if by chance by fear's simulation the enemies into his own place he might be able to entice, so that on this side of the valley before the camp in battle he might contend, if that to effect he was not able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which not yet had come together, were waiting for; Caesar, if by chance of fear by pretense the enemies into his own place he might be able to entice, so that on this side of the valley before the camp in battle he might contend, if that to effect he was not able,
sentences.naturalTranslation: which had not yet assembled; Caesar, meanwhile, hoped to entice the enemy onto his own ground by feigning fear, so that he might fight on his side of the valley in front of his camp; if he could not achieve this,

sentences.latin: ut exploratis itineribus minore cum periculo vallem rivumque transiret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so that the routes having been explored with less danger the valley and stream he might cross.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: so that the routes having been explored with smaller danger the valley and stream he might cross.
sentences.naturalTranslation: his plan was to cross the valley and stream with less risk after the routes had been scouted.

sentences.latin: Prima luce hostium equitatus ad castra accedit proeliumque cum nostris equitibus committit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light of the enemies the cavalry to the camp approaches and battle with our cavalry it joins.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light of the enemies the cavalry to the camp approaches and battle with our cavalry joins.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At dawn, the enemy's cavalry approached the camp and engaged in battle with our own horsemen.

sentences.latin: Caesar consulto equites cedere seque in castra recipere iubet, simul ex omnibus partibus castra altiore vallo muniri portasque obstrui atque in his administrandis rebus quam maxime concursari et cum simulatione agi timoris iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar by design the cavalry to withdraw and themselves into the camp to betake orders, at the same time from all parts the camp with a higher wall to be fortified and the gates to be blocked and in these things being managed as much as possible to be run about and with a pretense to be acted of fear he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar by design the cavalry to withdraw and themselves into the camp to retreat orders, at the same time from all parts the camp with a higher wall to be fortified and the gates to be blocked and in these things being managed as much as possible to be run about and with pretense to be acted of fear he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar deliberately ordered the cavalry to withdraw and retreat into the camp; at the same time, he ordered the camp to be fortified with a higher wall on all sides, the gates to be blocked up, and these tasks to be carried out with as much running about as possible and a pretense of fear.

sentences.latin: Quibus omnibus rebus hostes invitati copias traducunt aciemque iniquo loco constituunt, nostris vero etiam de vallo deductis propius accedunt et tela intra munitionem ex omnibus partibus coniciunt
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which all things the enemies invited their forces lead across and their line in an unfavorable place station, our men indeed even from the wall having been withdrawn nearer they approach and weapons inside the fortification from all parts they hurl.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which all things the enemies invited their forces lead across and their line in an unfavorable place they station, our men indeed even from the wall having been led down nearer they approach and weapons within the fortification from all parts they hurl
sentences.naturalTranslation: Enticed by all these actions, the enemy led their forces across and drew up their line on unfavorable ground; then, as our men had even been withdrawn from the wall, they approached closer and hurled weapons into the fortification from all sides.

sentences.latin: praeconibusque circummissis pronuntiari iubent, seu quis Gallus seu Romanus velit ante horam tertiam ad se transire, sine periculo licere; post id tempus non fore potestatem:
sentences.referenceTranslation: and heralds having been sent around to be announced they order, whether any Gaul or Roman wishes before the hour third to them to cross over, without danger it is permitted; after that time there would not be the opportunity:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and heralds having been sent around to be announced they order, if any Gaul or Roman should wish before the hour third to them to cross over, without danger it is permitted; after that time there would not be the power:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They sent heralds around and ordered it to be announced that if any Gaul or Roman wished to come over to them before the third hour, they might do so without danger; after that time, there would be no further opportunity.

sentences.latin: ac sic nostros contempserunt, ut obstructis in speciem portis singulis ordinibus caespitum, quod ea non posse introrumpere videbantur, alii vallum manu scindere, alii fossas complere inciperent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and so our men they despised, that having been blocked for appearance the gates with single rows of sods, because by that way not to be able to break in they seemed, some the wall by hand to tear down, others the ditches to fill up they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so our men they despised, that with blocked for appearance gates by single rows of sods, because by those not to be able to break in they seemed, some the wall by hand to tear down, others the ditches to fill up they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They held our men in such contempt that, since the gates appeared to be blocked by only single rows of sods and they thought they could not break in that way, some began to tear down the rampart by hand, while others began to fill in the ditches.

sentences.latin: Tum Caesar omnibus portis eruptione facta equitatuque emisso celeriter hostes in fugam dat, sic uti omnino pugnandi causa resisteret nemo, magnumque ex eis numerum occidit atque omnes armis exuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then Caesar from all gates a sally having been made and the cavalry having been sent out quickly the enemy into flight gives, so that altogether for the sake of fighting resisted no one, and a great from them number he killed and all of arms he stripped.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then Caesar from all gates a sally having been made and the cavalry having been sent out quickly the enemy into flight he gives, so that altogether for the sake of fighting should resist no one, and a great from them number he kills and all of arms he strips.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then Caesar, making a sally from all the gates and sending out the cavalry, quickly put the enemy to flight, so that not a single man stood his ground to fight; he killed a great number of them and stripped them all of their arms.

sentences.latin: Longius prosequi veritus, quod silvae paludesque intercedebant neque etiam parvulo detrimento illorum locum relinqui videbat, omnibus suis incolumibus copiis eodem die ad Ciceronem pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Further to pursue having feared, because woods and marshes were intervening nor even with a very small loss of them a place to be left he saw, with all his safe forces on the same day to Cicero he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Further to pursue having feared, because woods and marshes were intervening nor even with a very small loss of those the place to be left he saw, with all his safe forces on the same day to Cicero he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fearing to pursue them further because woods and marshes intervened and he saw no opportunity for even the slightest loss to be inflicted on them, he reached Cicero on the same day with all his forces safe.

sentences.latin: Institutas turres, testudines munitionesque hostium admiratur; legione producta cognoscit non decimum quemque esse reliquum militem sine vulnere:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The set up towers, mantlets and fortifications of the enemy he admires; the legion having been led out he learns not every tenth to be remaining soldier without a wound:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The set up towers, tortoises and fortifications of the enemies he admires; the legion having been led out he learns not every tenth to be remaining soldier without a wound:
sentences.naturalTranslation: He marveled at the towers, mantlets, and fortifications erected by the enemy; having paraded the legion, he found that not one soldier in ten had escaped without a wound.

sentences.latin: ex his omnibus iudicat rebus, quanto cum periculo et quanta cum virtute res sint administratae.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from these all he judges things, with how much danger and with how much courage the matters have been managed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from these all he judges things, with how much danger and with how much virtue the matters have been managed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From all these things, he judged with what great danger and with what great courage the defense had been conducted.

sentences.latin: Ciceronem pro eius merito legionemque collaudat; centuriones singillatim tribunosque militum appellat, quorum egregiam fuisse virtutem testimonio Ciceronis cognoverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cicero for his merit and the legion he praises; the centurions individually and the tribunes of the soldiers he calls by name, whose excellent to have been courage by the testimony of Cicero he had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cicero for his merit and the legion he praises; the centurions individually and the tribunes of the soldiers he calls by name, whose excellent to have been virtue by the testimony of Cicero he had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He praised Cicero and the legion as they deserved; he addressed the centurions and military tribunes individually by name, having learned of their exceptional courage from Cicero's testimony.

sentences.latin: De casu Sabini et Cottae certius ex captivis cognoscit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: About the fate of Sabinus and Cotta more certainly from prisoners he learns.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: About the misfortune of Sabinus and Cotta more certainly from captives he learns.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He learned more definite information about the fate of Sabinus and Cotta from the prisoners.

sentences.latin: Postero die contione habita rem gestam proponit, milites consolatur et confirmat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the following day, a meeting having been held, the thing done he sets forth, the soldiers he consoles and encourages:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the next day an assembly having been held the matter done he sets forth, the soldiers he consoles and encourages:
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, he held an assembly and explained what had happened, offering consolation and encouragement to the soldiers.

sentences.latin: quod detrimentum culpa et temeritate legati sit acceptum, hoc aequiore animo ferendum docet, quod beneficio deorum immortalium et virtute eorum expiato incommodo neque hostibus diutina laetatio neque ipsis longior dolor relinquatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because loss by the fault and rashness of the legate had been received, this with a more level mind to be borne he teaches, because by the benefit of the gods immortal and the valor of them, the inconvenience having been expiated, neither to the enemies long-lasting rejoicing nor to themselves longer grief is left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because the loss by the fault and rashness of the legate has been received, this with a more level mind to be borne he teaches, because by the benefit of the gods immortal and the virtue of them the inconvenience having been expiated neither to the enemies lasting joy nor to themselves longer grief is left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He explained that the loss suffered through the commander's fault and rashness should be borne with greater equanimity, because, thanks to the immortal gods and their own valor, the disaster had been redeemed, leaving the enemy no lasting joy and themselves no prolonged sorrow.

sentences.latin: Interim ad Labienum per Remos incredibili celeritate de victoria Caesaris fama perfertur, ut, cum ab hibernis Ciceronis milia passuum abesset circiter LX, eoque post horam nonam diei Caesar pervenisset, ante mediam noctem ad portas castrorum clamor oreretur, quo clamore significatio victoriae gratulatioque ab Remis Labieno fieret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile to Labienus through the Remi with incredible speed about the victory of Caesar a report is carried, so that, when from the winter quarters of Cicero thousands of paces he was distant about 60, and to that place after the ninth hour of the day Caesar had arrived, before middle night at the gates of the camp a shout arose, by which shout an indication of victory and congratulation by the Remi to Labienus was made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile to Labienus through the Remi with incredible speed about the victory of Caesar the report is carried, so that, when from the winter quarters of Cicero miles of paces he was away about 60, and there after the hour ninth of the day Caesar had arrived, before middle night at the gates of the camp a shout arose, by which shout an indication of victory and congratulation by the Remi to Labienus was made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, news of Caesars victory reached Labienus through the Remi with incredible speed; although he was about sixty miles from Ciceros winter quarters and Caesar had only arrived there after the ninth hour of the day, a shout arose at the gates of the camp before midnight, by which the Remi signaled the victory and offered their congratulations to Labienus.

sentences.latin: Hac fama ad Treveros perlata Indutiomarus, qui postero die castra Labieni oppugnare decreverat, noctu profugit copiasque omnes in Treveros reducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This report to the Treveri having been carried, Indutiomarus, who on the following day the camp of Labienus to attack had decided, by night fled and forces all into the Treveri leads back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This report to the Treveri having been carried Indutiomarus, who on the next day the camp of Labienus to attack had decided, by night fled and forces all into the Treveri leads back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this news reached the Treveri, Indutiomarus, who had decided to attack Labienus's camp the next day, fled during the night and led all his forces back to the territory of the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Caesar Fabium cum sua legione remittit in hiberna, ipse cum tribus legionibus circum Samarobrivam trinis hibernis hiemare constituit et, quod tanti motus Galliae exstiterant, totam hiemem ipse ad exercitum manere decrevit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar Fabius with his legion sends back into winter quarters, himself with three legions around Samarobriva in three winter quarters to winter decided and, because so great movements of Gaul had arisen, the whole winter himself at the army to remain he decreed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar Fabius with his legion sends back into winter quarters, himself with three legions around Samarobriva in three winter quarters to winter decided and, because so great movements of Gaul had arisen, the whole winter himself at the army to remain he decreed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar sent Fabius and his legion back to their winter quarters, while he himself decided to winter near Samarobriva with three legions in three separate camps; because such great uprisings had broken out in Gaul, he resolved to stay with the army himself throughout the winter.

sentences.latin: Nam illo incommodo de Sabini morte perlato omnes fere Galliae civitates de bello consultabant, nuntios legationesque in omnes partes dimittebant et quid reliqui consili caperent atque unde initium belli fieret explorabant nocturnaque in locis desertis concilia habebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For that disaster about the death of Sabinus having been reported, almost all of Gaul states about war were consulting, messengers and embassies into all parts were sending and what of remaining plan they should take and from where the beginning of war should be made they were exploring and nightly in places deserted councils they were holding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For that disaster about the of Sabinus death having been reported all almost of Gaul states about war were consulting, messengers and embassies into all parts they were sending and what of remaining plan they should take and from where the beginning of war should be made they were exploring and nocturnal in places deserted councils they were having.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For once the disaster of Sabinus's death was reported, almost all the states of Gaul began to deliberate on war, sending messengers and embassies in every direction to determine what plan they should adopt and where the war should begin, and they held secret councils at night in remote places.

sentences.latin: Neque ullum fere totius hiemis tempus sine sollicitudine Caesaris intercessit, quin aliquem de consiliis ac motu Gallorum nuntium acciperet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor any almost of the whole winter time without anxiety of Caesar passed, but that some about the plans and movement of the Gauls message he received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor any almost of the whole winter time without anxiety of Caesar passed, but that some about the plans and movement of the Gauls message he received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Hardly any time passed during the entire winter without Caesar feeling anxious or receiving some report concerning the plans and movements of the Gauls.

sentences.latin: In his ab Lucio Roscio, quem legioni tertiae decimae praefecerat, certior factus est magnas Gallorum copias earum civitatum, quae Armoricae appellantur, oppugnandi sui causa convenisse
sentences.referenceTranslation: Among these by Lucius Roscius, whom to the legion thirteenth he had put in command, more certain he was made that great of the Gauls forces of those states, which Armorican are called, for the sake of attacking him had assembled
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In these by Lucius Roscius, whom to the legion thirteenth he had put in command, more certain he was made great of the Gauls forces of those states, which Armorican are called, for the sake of attacking him had assembled
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among these reports, he was informed by Lucius Roscius, whom he had put in command of the Thirteenth Legion, that large Gallic forces from the states called Armorican had assembled for the purpose of attacking him.

sentences.latin: neque longius milia passuum octo ab hibernis suis afuisse, sed nuntio allato de victoria Caesaris discessisse, adeo ut fugae similis discessus videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not further thousands of paces eight from winter quarters his had been away, but the message having been brought about the victory of Caesar they had departed, so much that of flight similar the departure seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor further miles of paces eight from winter quarters his had been away, but a message having been brought about the victory of Caesar they had departed, so that to flight similar the departure seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had been no more than eight miles away from his winter quarters, but upon receiving news of Caesar's victory, they retreated so hastily that their departure looked like a flight.

sentences.latin: At Caesar principibus cuiusque civitatis ad se evocatis alias territando, cum se scire quae fierent denuntiaret, alias cohortando magnam partem Galliae in officio tenuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Caesar the leaders of each state to himself having been called, at times by terrifying, when himself to know what things were being done he announced, at times by encouraging, a great part of Gaul in duty held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Caesar the leaders of each state to himself having been called now by terrifying, when himself to know what were being done he announced, now by encouraging a great part of Gaul in duty held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Caesar, having summoned the leaders of each state to him, kept a large part of Gaul in their allegiance, partly by intimidating them with the declaration that he knew what was happening, and partly by encouragement.

sentences.latin: Tamen Senones, quae est civitas in primis firma et magnae inter Gallos auctoritatis, Cavarinum, quem Caesar apud eos regem constituerat, cuius frater Moritasgus adventu in Galliam Caesaris cuiusque maiores regnum obtinuerant, interficere publico consilio conati, cum ille praesensisset ac profugisset, usque ad fines insecuti
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nevertheless the Senones, which is a state especially strong and of great among the Gauls authority, Cavarinus, whom Caesar among them king had appointed, whose brother Moritasgus at the arrival into Gaul of Caesar and whose ancestors the kingdom had held, to kill by public counsel having attempted, when he had sensed beforehand and had fled, all the way to the borders having followed
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nevertheless the Senones, which is a state especially firm and of great among the Gauls authority, Cavarinus, whom Caesar among them king had appointed, whose brother Moritasgus at the arrival into Gaul of Caesar and whose ancestors the kingdom had held, to kill by public council having attempted, when he had perceived and had fled, all the way to the borders having followed
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, the Senonesa state particularly powerful and of great influence among the Gaulsattempted by public decree to kill Cavarinus, whom Caesar had appointed king over them, and whose brother Moritasgus and ancestors had previously held the throne; when he sensed the plot and fled, they pursued him all the way to the borders.

sentences.latin: regno domoque expulerunt et, missis ad Caesarem satisfaciendi causa legatis, cum is omnem ad se senatum venire iussisset, dicto audientes non fuerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from the kingdom and home they expelled [him] and, having been sent to Caesar for the sake of satisfying envoys, when he all to himself the senate to come had ordered, to the word hearing they were not.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from the kingdom and home they expelled and, having been sent to Caesar for the sake of satisfying envoys, when he all to himself the senate to come had ordered, to the word hearing they were not.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They drove him from his throne and home, and although they sent envoys to Caesar to offer an explanation, they refused to obey when he ordered their entire senate to appear before him.

sentences.latin: Ac tantum apud homines barbaros valuit esse aliquos repertos principes inferendi belli tantamque omnibus voluntatum commutationem attulit, ut praeter Aeduos et Remos, quos praecipuo semper honore Caesar habuit, alteros pro vetere ac perpetua erga populum Romanum fide, alteros pro recentibus Gallici belli officiis, nulla fere civitas fuerit non suspecta nobis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so much among men barbarian it availed to be some found leaders of bringing in war and so great to all of wills a change it brought, that except the Aedui and Remi, whom in special always honor Caesar held, the ones for old and perpetual toward the people Roman loyalty, the others for recent of the Gallic war services, no almost state was not suspicious to us.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so much among men barbarian it availed to be some found leaders of bringing war and so great to all of wills a change it brought, that except the Aedui and Remi, whom in special always honor Caesar held, the ones for old and perpetual toward the people Roman loyalty, the others for recent of the Gallic war services, no almost state was not suspected by us.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The fact that some leaders had been found to initiate war had such a powerful effect on these barbarians and caused such a complete change of heart in everyone that, with the exception of the Aedui and the Remiwhom Caesar always held in special honor, the former for their long-standing loyalty to Rome, the latter for their recent services in the Gallic Warthere was hardly a state that we did not view with suspicion.

sentences.latin: Idque adeo haud scio mirandumne sit, cum compluribus aliis de causis, tum maxime quod ei, qui virtute belli omnibus gentibus praeferebantur, tantum se eius opinionis deperdidisse ut a populo Romano imperia perferrent gravissime dolebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And that indeed not I know whether to be wondered at it is, since for several other from causes, then especially because they, who in virtue of war to all nations were preferred, so much themselves of that reputation to have lost that from the people Roman commands they should endure most heavily were grieving.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And that indeed I do not know whether to be wondered at it is, since for several other from causes, then especially because those, who in valor of war to all nations were preferred, so much themselves of that reputation to have lost that from the people Roman commands they should endure most heavily were grieving.
sentences.naturalTranslation: I am not sure if this is really to be wondered at, both for several other reasons and especially because those who were once considered superior to all nations in military prowess were deeply grieved to have lost so much of that reputation that they now had to endure the commands of the Roman people.

sentences.latin: Treveri vero atque Indutiomarus totius hiemis nullum tempus intermiserunt, quin trans Rhenum legatos mitterent, civitates sollicitarent, pecunias pollicerentur, magna parte exercitus nostri interfecta multo minorem superesse dicerent partem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Treveri indeed and Indutiomarus of the whole winter no time let pass, but that across the Rhine envoys they sent, states they stirred up, moneys they promised, a great part of army our having been killed a much smaller to remain they said part.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Treveri indeed and Indutiomarus of the whole winter no time let pass, but that across the Rhine envoys they sent, states they solicited, moneys they promised, a great part of army our having been killed a much smaller to remain they said part.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Treveri and Indutiomarus let no part of the winter pass without sending envoys across the Rhine to stir up the states, promise money, and claim that, since a large part of our army had been destroyed, only a much smaller force remained.

sentences.latin: Neque tamen ulli civitati Germanorum persuaderi potuit, ut Rhenum transiret, cum se bis expertos dicerent, Ariovisti bello et Tencterorum transitu: non esse amplius fortunam temptaturos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor however to any state of the Germans to be persuaded it was possible, that the Rhine it should cross, since themselves twice having tried they said, in Ariovistus's war and of the Tencteri by the crossing: not to be further fortune they would try.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor however to any state of the Germans to be persuaded it was able, that the Rhine it should cross, since themselves twice having tried they said, in Ariovistus's war and the Tencteri's crossing: not to be further fortune they would try.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, they could not persuade any German state to cross the Rhine, as the Germans replied that they had tried it twicein the war with Ariovistus and during the migration of the Tencteriand would not tempt fortune any further.

sentences.latin: Hac spe lapsus Indutiomarus nihilo minus copias cogere,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In this hope disappointed Indutiomarus by nothing less forces to collect,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From this hope fallen Indutiomarus by nothing less forces to collect,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Disappointed in this hope, Indutiomarus nevertheless began to raise forces,

sentences.latin: exercere, a finitimis equos parare, exules damnatosque tota Gallia magnis praemiis ad se allicere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to train [them], from neighbors horses to prepare, exiles and condemned [men] from whole Gaul with great rewards to himself to entice he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to train, from neighbors horses to prepare, exiles and condemned men from whole Gaul with great rewards to himself to entice he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: to train them, to procure horses from his neighbors, and to entice exiles and outlaws from all over Gaul to join him with promises of great rewards.

sentences.latin: Ac tantam sibi iam his rebus in Gallia auctoritatem comparaverat ut undique ad eum legationes concurrerent, gratiam atque amicitiam publice privatimque peterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so great for himself already by these things in Gaul authority he had prepared that from all sides to him embassies ran together, favor and friendship publicly and privately they sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so great for himself already by these things in Gaul authority he had acquired that from all sides to him embassies ran together, favor and friendship publicly and privately they sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He had already gained such great influence in Gaul through these actions that embassies flocked to him from every direction, seeking his favor and friendship both on behalf of their states and for themselves.

sentences.latin: Vbi intellexit ultro ad se veniri, altera ex parte Senones Carnutesque conscientia facinoris instigari, altera Nervios Aduatucosque bellum Romanis parare, neque sibi voluntariorum copias defore, si ex finibus suis progredi coepisset, armatum concilium indicit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When he understood of their own accord to him it was being come, on one from part the Senones and Carnutes by consciousness of crime to be spurred on, on the other the Nervii and Aduatuci war for the Romans to prepare, and not for himself of volunteers forces to be lacking, if from borders his to go forward he had begun, an armed council he proclaims.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When he understood voluntarily to him it was being come, on one from part the Senones and Carnutes by consciousness of crime to be spurred on, on the other the Nervii and Aduatuci war for the Romans to prepare, and not for himself of volunteers forces to be lacking, if from borders his to advance he had begun, an armed council he proclaims.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he realized that people were coming to him voluntarily, that on one side the Senones and Carnutes were driven by the guilt of their crime, and on the other the Nervii and Aduatuci were preparing for war against the Romans, and that he would not lack a force of volunteers once he began to advance from his territory, he called for an armed council.

sentences.latin: Hoc more Gallorum est initium belli,
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this custom of the Gauls is the beginning of war,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This by custom of the Gauls is the beginning of war,
sentences.naturalTranslation: According to the custom of the Gauls, this marks the beginning of a war,

sentences.latin: quo lege communi omnes puberes armati convenire consuerunt; qui ex eis novissimus convenit, in conspectu multitudinis omnibus cruciatibus affectus necatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at which by common law all youths armed to assemble have been accustomed; who out of them last arrives, in sight of the multitude with all tortures having been afflicted is killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at which by law common all youths armed to assemble are accustomed; who from them last arrives, in sight of the multitude with all tortures having been afflicted is killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: at which, by a general law, all adult males are accustomed to assemble in arms; whoever among them arrives last is put to death with every kind of torture in the sight of the assembled crowd.

sentences.latin: In eo concilio Cingetorigem, alterius principem factionis, generum suum, quem supra demonstravimus Caesaris secutum fidem ab eo non discessisse, hostem iudicat bonaque eius publicat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In that council Cingetorix, of the other the leader faction, son-in-law his own, whom above we have shown Caesar's having followed loyalty from him not to have departed, an enemy he judges and goods of him he confiscates.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that council Cingetorix, of the other the leader faction, son-in-law his, whom above we have shown Caesar's having followed loyalty from him not to have departed, an enemy he judges and goods his he confiscates.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In that council, he declared Cingetorixthe leader of the rival faction and his own son-in-law, who, as we have previously mentioned, had remained loyal to Caesar and had not deserted himto be a public enemy and confiscated his property.

sentences.latin: His rebus confectis, in concilio pronuntiat arcessitum se a Senonibus et Carnutibus aliisque compluribus Galliae civitatibus;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been finished, in the council he announces summoned himself by the Senones and Carnutes and other several of Gaul states;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been finished, in the council he announces summoned himself by the Senones and Carnutes and others several of Gaul states;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After completing these matters, he announced in the council that he had been summoned by the Senones, the Carnutes, and several other Gallic states;

sentences.latin: huc iturum per fines Remorum eorumque agros popula turum ac, priusquam id faciat, castra Labieni oppugnaturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: hither to be about to go through the borders of the Remi and of them the fields to be about to ravage and, before that he may do, the camp of Labienus to be about to attack.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to here he would go through the borders of the Remi and their fields would ravage and, before that he should do, the camp of Labienus would attack.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he stated that he would march there through the territory of the Remi, ravaging their lands, and that before doing so, he would attack Labienus's camp.

sentences.latin: Quae fieri velit praecipit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: What things to be done he wishes he instructs.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things to be done he wishes he instructs.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He gave instructions on what he wanted to be done.

sentences.latin: Labienus, cum et loci natura et manu munitissumis castris sese teneret, de suo ac legionis periculo nihil timebat; ne quam occasionem rei bene gerendae dimitteret, cogitabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus, since both by the place's nature and by hand in most fortified camp himself he was holding, about his own and the legion's danger nothing was fearing; lest any opportunity of the matter well to be conducted he might let slip, he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus, since both by the place's nature and by hand in a most fortified camp himself he was holding, about his own and the legion's danger nothing was fearing; lest any opportunity of the matter well being conducted he should let pass, he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus, since he was holding his position in a camp strongly fortified by both its natural location and manual labor, had no fears for his own safety or that of his legion; instead, he was considering how not to miss any opportunity for a successful action.

sentences.latin: Itaque a Cingetorige atque eius propinquis oratione Indutiomari cognita, quam in concilio habuerat, nuntios mittit ad finitimas civitates equitesque undique evocat: his certum diem conveniendi dicit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so from Cingetorix and his relatives the speech of Indutiomarus having been learned, which in the council he had held, messengers he sends to the neighboring states and cavalry from all sides he calls out: to these a certain day of assembling he appoints.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so from Cingetorix and his relatives the speech of Indutiomarus having been learned, which in the council he had held, messengers he sends to neighboring states and cavalry from all sides he calls out: to these a fixed day of assembling he appoints.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having learned from Cingetorix and his relatives about the speech Indutiomarus had delivered in the council, he sent messengers to the neighboring states and summoned cavalry from all quarters, appointing a specific day for them to assemble.

sentences.latin: Interim prope cotidie cum omni equitatu Indutiomarus sub castris eius vagabatur, alias ut situm castrorum cognosceret, alias colloquendi aut territandi causa: equites plerumque omnes tela intra vallum coniciebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile nearly daily with all the cavalry Indutiomarus near the camp of him was wandering, at one time so that the site of the camp he might learn, at another time of talking or of frightening for the sake: the horsemen for the most part all weapons inside the rampart were throwing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile almost daily with all cavalry Indutiomarus under the camp his was wandering, at times that the site of the camp he might learn, at other times of talking or of frightening for the sake: the horsemen mostly all weapons inside the rampart were throwing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Indutiomarus patrolled near the camp almost every day with all his cavalry, sometimes to learn the layout of the camp, at other times to seek a parley or to intimidate; the horsemen would generally all hurl weapons over the rampart.

sentences.latin: Labienus suos intra munitionem continebat timorisque opinionem, quibuscumque poterat rebus, augebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus his own men inside the fortification was keeping and of fear the impression, by whatever things he was able, was increasing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus his own men inside the fortification was keeping and of fear the impression, by whatever he was able things, was increasing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus kept his men within the fortifications and, by every means possible, sought to heighten the impression that he was afraid.

sentences.latin: Cum maiore in dies contemptione Indutiomarus ad castra accederet, nocte una intromissis equitibus omnium finitimarum civitatum quos arcessendos curaverat, tanta diligentia omnes suos custodiis intra castra continuit, ut nulla ratione ea res enuntiari aut ad Treveros perferri posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When with greater daily contempt Indutiomarus to the camp was approaching, on night one having been let in horsemen of all neighboring states whom to be summoned he had cared for, with such diligence all his own [men] by guards within the camp he kept, that by no means that matter to be reported or to the Treveri to be carried through was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When with greater daily contempt Indutiomarus to the camp was approaching, on night one having been let in the horsemen of all neighboring states whom to be summoned he had cared for, with such great diligence all his own men by guards within the camp he kept, that by no reason that matter to be announced or to the Treveri to be carried through could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As Indutiomarus approached the camp with increasing daily contempt, Labienus, having brought in cavalry from all the neighboring states during a single nightwhom he had arranged to be summonedkept all his men within the camp with such strict guarding that there was no way the matter could be reported or conveyed to the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Interim ex consuetudine cotidiana Indutiomarus ad castra accedit atque ibi magnam partem diei consumit; equites tela coniciunt et magna cum contumelia verborum nostros ad pugnam evocant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile from custom daily Indutiomarus to the camp approaches and there a great part of the day consumes; the horsemen weapons hurl and with great with insult of words our [men] to battle call out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile from custom daily Indutiomarus to the camp approaches and there a great part of the day consumes; the horsemen weapons throw and with great with insult of words our men to battle call out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, according to his daily custom, Indutiomarus approached the camp and spent a large part of the day there; his cavalry hurled missiles and challenged our men to battle with many insulting words.

sentences.latin: Nullo ab nostris dato responso, ubi visum est, sub vesperum dispersi ac dissipati discedunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With no by our [men] given response, when it seemed [fit], toward evening dispersed and scattered they depart.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: No by our men given response, when it seemed [fit], toward evening dispersed and scattered they depart.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When no response was given by our men, they departed toward evening, dispersed and scattered, whenever they saw fit.

sentences.latin: Subito Labienus duabus portis omnem equitatum emittit; praecipit atque interdicit, proterritis hostibus atque in fugam coniectis (quod fore, sicut accidit, videbat) unum omnes peterent Indutiomarum, neu quis quem prius vulneret, quam illum interfectum viderit, quod mora reliquorum spatium nactum illum effugere nolebat; magna proponit eis qui occiderint praemia;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Suddenly Labienus from two gates all the cavalry sends out; he instructs and forbids, the enemies having been terrified and into flight thrown (which to be about to happen, just as it happened, he was seeing) one [man] all should seek Indutiomarus, nor anyone anyone earlier should wound, than him killed he should have seen, because by delay of the rest space having been obtained him to escape he was not wishing; great he offers to those who shall have killed rewards;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Suddenly Labienus from two gates all the cavalry sends out; he commands and forbids, the enemies having been thoroughly terrified and into flight thrown (which to be about to happen, just as it happened, he was seeing) one all should seek Indutiomarus, nor anyone anyone sooner should wound, than him killed he should have seen, because by the delay of the rest space having been obtained him to escape he was not wishing; great he proposes to those who shall have killed rewards;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Suddenly Labienus sent out all the cavalry from two gates; he gave strict orders that, once the enemy were terrified and put to flight (which he foresaw would happen, as it did), everyone should seek out Indutiomarus alone, and no one should wound anyone else until they saw him killed, for he did not want Indutiomarus to gain time through the delay caused by the others and escape; he offered great rewards to those who should kill him.

sentences.latin: summittit cohortes equitibus subsidio.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he sends up cohorts to the horsemen for a reinforcement.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he sends up cohorts to the horsemen for a reinforcement.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent cohorts to support the cavalry.

sentences.latin: Comprobat hominis consilium fortuna, et cum unum omnes peterent, in ipso fluminis vado deprehensus Indutiomarus interficitur, caputque eius refertur in castra: redeuntes equites quos possunt consectantur atque occidunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Approves the man's plan fortune, and when one [man] all were seeking, in the very of the river ford caught Indutiomarus is killed, and the head of him is brought back into the camp: returning horsemen whom they are able they pursue and kill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Approves the man's plan fortune, and when one all were seeking, in the very of the river ford caught Indutiomarus is killed, and the head of him is brought back into the camp: returning horsemen whom they can they pursue and kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fortune approved the man's plan, and since everyone was seeking one man, Indutiomarus was caught and killed at the very ford of the river, and his head was brought back to the camp; on their return, the cavalry pursued and killed as many as they could.

sentences.latin: Hac re cognita omnes Eburonum et Nerviorum quae convenerant copiae discedunt, pauloque habuit post id factum Caesar quietiorem Galliam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing having been learned all of the Eburones and of the Nervii which had assembled forces depart, and a little had after that deed Caesar quieter Gaul.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This thing having been known all of the Eburones and of the Nervii which had assembled forces depart, and a little had after that deed Caesar a quieter Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was known, all the forces of the Eburones and Nervii that had assembled dispersed, and after this event, Caesar found Gaul somewhat more peaceful.

sentences.latin: Multis de causis Caesar maiorem Galliae motum exspectans per Marcum Silanum, Gaium Antistium Reginum, Titum Sextium legatos delectum habere instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For many from causes Caesar a greater of Gaul movement expecting through Marcus Silanus, Gaius Antistius Reginum, Titus Sextius legates a levy to have decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For many from causes Caesar a greater of Gaul movement expecting through Marcus Silanus, Gaius Antistius Reginus, Titus Sextius lieutenants a levy to have he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For many reasons, Caesar, expecting a greater uprising in Gaul, decided to hold a levy through his legates Marcus Silanus, Gaius Antistius Reginus, and Titus Sextius.

sentences.latin: Simul ab Gnaeo Pompeio proconsule petit, quoniam ipse ad urbem cum imperio rei publicae causa remaneret, quos ex Cisalpina Gallia consulis sacramento rogavisset,
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time from Gnaeus Pompey the proconsul he asks, since he himself at the city with command for the sake of the republic was remaining, [those] whom from Cisalpine Gaul by the consul's oath he had enlisted,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time from Gnaeus Pompey the proconsul he asks, since he himself at the city with command for the sake of the republic was remaining, whom from Cisalpine Gaul by the consul's oath he had asked,
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, he requested of the proconsul Gnaeus Pompey that, since Pompey himself was remaining near the city with military command for the sake of the state, he should order those whom he had enlisted from Cisalpine Gaul under a consul's oath...

sentences.latin: ad signa convenire et ad se proficisci iuberet, magni interesse etiam in reliquum tempus ad opinionem Galliae existimans tantas videri Italiae facultates ut, si quid esset in bello detrimenti acceptum, non modo id brevi tempore sarciri, sed etiam maioribus augeri copiis posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to the standards to assemble and to him to set out he should order, of great [importance] to be even for the remaining time for the opinion of Gaul thinking so great to be seen of Italy the resources that, if any there was in war of loss received, not only it in a short time to be repaired, but even with greater to be increased forces it was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to the standards to assemble and to him to set out he should order, of great to be of interest even for the remaining time to the opinion of Gaul thinking so great to be seen of Italy resources that, if anything there were in war of loss received, not only it in a short time to be repaired, but even with greater to be increased forces it could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: ...to assemble at their standards and set out to join him; he thought it of great importance, even for the future, regarding the opinion of Gaul, that the resources of Italy should appear so great that, if any loss were sustained in war, it could not only be repaired in a short time but even be replaced by larger forces.

sentences.latin: Quod cum Pompeius et rei publicae et amicitiae tribuisset, celeriter confecto per suos dilectu tribus ante exactam hiemem et constitutis et adductis legionibus duplicatoque earum cohortium numero, quas cum Quinto Titurio amiserat, et celeritate et copiis docuit, quid populi Romani disciplina atque opes possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when Pompey both to the republic and to friendship had granted, quickly having been completed through his own [men] a levy, three before the finished winter both having been organized and brought up legions and having been doubled of those cohorts the number, which with Quintus Titurius he had lost, both by speed and by forces he showed, what the of the Roman people discipline and resources were able [to do].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when Pompey both to the republic and to friendship had granted, quickly having been finished through his own men the levy three before the finished winter both established and brought legions and doubled of those cohorts the number, which with Quintus Titurius he had lost, both by speed and by forces he showed, what of the Roman people the discipline and resources could [do].
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since Pompey had granted this request out of consideration for both the state and their friendship, Caesar quickly completed a levy through his own officers; before the end of winter, three legions were organized and brought to him, doubling the number of cohorts he had lost with Quintus Titurius, and by this speed and these forces he demonstrated what the discipline and resources of the Roman people could achieve.

sentences.latin: Interfecto Indutiomaro, ut docuimus, ad eius propinquos a Treveris imperium defertur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been killed Indutiomarus, as we have shown, to his relatives by the Treveri the supreme command is conferred.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been killed Indutiomarus, as we have shown, to his relatives by the Treveri the command is transferred.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After Indutiomarus was killed, as we have mentioned, the Treveri conferred the supreme command upon his relatives.

sentences.latin: Illi finitimos Germanos sollicitare et pecuniam polliceri non desistunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They the neighboring Germans to stir up and money to promise do not cease.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They the neighboring Germans to stir up and money to promise do not cease.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did not cease to stir up the neighboring Germans and to promise them money.

sentences.latin: Cum ab proximis impetrare non possent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When from the nearest [they] to obtain [it] were not able,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When from the nearest to obtain [it] they could not,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they were unable to obtain their request from those nearest to them,

sentences.latin: ulteriores temptant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the more remote [they] try.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the further ones they try.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they tried those further away.

sentences.latin: Inventis nonnullis civitatibus iureiurando inter se confirmant obsidibusque de pecunia cavent: Ambiorigem sibi societate et foedere adiungunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been found some states, by an oath among themselves they confirm and by hostages for the money they give security: Ambiorix to themselves in alliance and treaty they join.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been found some states by an oath among themselves they confirm and by hostages concerning the money they take precaution: Ambiorix to themselves by an alliance and a treaty they join.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having found some states willing, they bound themselves by a mutual oath and provided hostages as security for the money; they also joined Ambiorix to their cause through an alliance and treaty.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus cognitis Caesar, cum undique bellum parari videret, Nervios, Aduatucos ac Menapios adiunctis Cisrhenanis omnibus Germanis esse in armis, Senones ad imperatum non venire et cum Carnutibus finitimisque civitatibus consilia communicare, a Treveris Germanos crebris legationibus sollicitari, maturius sibi de bello cogitandum putavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been learned Caesar, when from all sides war to be prepared he saw, the Nervii, Aduatuci and Menapii having been joined the Cisrhine all Germans to be in arms, the Senones to the command not to come and with the Carnutes and neighboring states plans to share, by the Treveri the Germans with frequent embassies to be stirred up, earlier for himself about war to be thought he considered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been known Caesar, when from all sides war to be prepared he saw, the Nervii, Aduatuci and Menapii having been joined Cisrhenane all Germans to be in arms, the Senones to the command not to come and with the Carnutes and neighboring states plans to communicate, by the Treveri the Germans by frequent embassies to be stirred up, more early for himself about war to be thought he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar learned of these developments and saw that war was being prepared on all sidesthat the Nervii, Aduatuci, and Menapii, joined by all the Germans on this side of the Rhine, were in arms; that the Senones were not obeying his commands and were sharing plans with the Carnutes and neighboring states; and that the Germans were being incited by frequent embassies from the Treverihe decided he must plan for war earlier than usual.

sentences.latin: Itaque nondum hieme confecta proximis quattuor coactis legionibus de improviso in fines Nerviorum contendit et,
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so not yet the winter having been finished, the nearest four having been collected legions, by surprise into the borders of the Nervii he hastened and,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so not yet winter finished the nearest four having been collected legions by surprise into the borders of the Nervii he hastens and,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, before the winter was even over, he concentrated the four nearest legions and made a surprise march into the territory of the Nervii.

sentences.latin: priusquam illi aut convenire aut profugere possent, magno pecoris atque hominum numero capto atque ea praeda militibus concessa vastatisque agris in deditionem venire atque obsides sibi dare coegit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: before they either to assemble or to flee were able, a great of cattle and of men number having been captured and that booty to the soldiers having been granted and having been ravaged the fields, into surrender to come and hostages to him to give he compelled [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: before they either to assemble or to flee could, a great of cattle and of men number having been captured and that booty to the soldiers granted and having been devastated the fields into surrender to come and hostages to him to give he compelled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Before they could either assemble or flee, he captured a great number of cattle and people, gave the booty to his soldiers, and, after laying waste to their fields, compelled them to surrender and give him hostages.

sentences.latin: Eo celeriter confecto negotio rursus in hiberna legiones reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That quickly having been finished business, again into winter quarters the legions he led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That quickly finished business again into winter quarters the legions he led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having quickly finished that business, he led the legions back into winter quarters.

sentences.latin: Concilio Galliae primo vere, ut instituerat, indicto, cum reliqui praeter Senones, Carnutes Treverosque venissent, initium belli ac defectionis hoc esse arbitratus, ut omnia postponere videretur, concilium Lutetiam Parisiorum transfert.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A council of Gaul in early spring, as he had established, having been proclaimed, when the rest except the Senones, Carnutes, and Treveri had come, thinking this to be the beginning of war and of revolt, so that he might seem to postpone all things, the council to Lutetia of the Parisii he transfers.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A council of Gaul in early spring, as he had established, having been proclaimed, when the rest except the Senones, Carnutes and Treveri had come, thinking this to be the beginning of war and revolt, so that he might seem to put aside all things, the council to Lutetia of the Parisii he transfers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having called a council of Gaul in early spring as was his custom, when everyone except the Senones, Carnutes, and Treveri arrived, Caesar considered this the start of a war and rebellion; to show that everything else was secondary, he moved the council to Lutetia, a town of the Parisii.

sentences.latin: Confines erant hi Senonibus civitatemque patrum memoria coniunxerant, sed ab hoc consilio afuisse existimabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Neighbors were these to the Senones and the state in the memory of fathers they had joined, but from this plan to have been absent they were thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Neighbors were these to the Senones and the state in the memory of fathers they had joined, but from this plan to have been absent they were thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These people were neighbors of the Senones and had united their state with them within living memory, but they were believed to have taken no part in the current plot.

sentences.latin: Hac re pro suggestu pronuntiata eodem die cum legionibus in Senones proficiscitur magnisque itineribus eo pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing from the platform having been announced, on the same day with the legions against the Senones he sets out and by great marches thither he arrives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This matter from the platform having been announced, on the same day with the legions against the Senones he sets out and by great marches there he arrives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After announcing this decision from the tribunal, he set out with his legions against the Senones that same day and reached their territory by forced marches.

sentences.latin: Cognito eius adventu Acco, qui princeps eius consili fuerat, iubet in oppida multitudinem convenire.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been known his arrival, Acco, who the leader of that plan had been, orders into the towns the multitude to assemble.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been known his arrival, Acco, who leader of that plan had been, orders into the towns the multitude to assemble.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning of Caesar's arrival, Acco, the mastermind of the plot, ordered the population to gather in the towns.

sentences.latin: Conantibus, priusquam id effici posset, adesse Romanos nuntiatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To [them] attempting, before that to be accomplished was able, to be present the Romans it is announced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To those trying, before that to be accomplished could be, to be present the Romans is announced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While they were attempting this, and before it could be completed, news arrived that the Romans were already there.

sentences.latin: Necessario sententia desistunt legatosque deprecandi causa ad Caesarem mittunt: adeunt per Aeduos, quorum antiquitus erat in fide civitas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By necessity from the plan they desist and ambassadors for the sake of pleading to Caesar they send: they approach through the Aedui, of whom from ancient times was in the protection the state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By necessity from the plan they desist and ambassadors for the sake of pleading to Caesar they send: they approach through the Aedui, of whom from ancient times was in the protection the state.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Forced to abandon their plan, they sent envoys to Caesar to plead for mercy; they made their approach through the Aedui, under whose protection their state had been since ancient times.

sentences.latin: Libenter Caesar petentibus Aeduis dat veniam excusationemque accipit, quod aestivum tempus instantis belli, non quaestionis esse arbitrabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Gladly Caesar to the requesting Aedui gives pardon and the excuse accepts, because the summer time of an imminent war, not of an investigation to be he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Willingly Caesar to the requesting Aedui gives pardon and the excuse accepts, because the summer time of the pressing war, not of an inquiry to be he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar readily granted them pardon at the request of the Aedui and accepted their excuse, as he believed the summer should be spent on the impending war rather than an investigation.

sentences.latin: Obsidibus imperatis centum hos Aeduis custodiendos tradit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hostages having been demanded a hundred, these to the Aedui to be guarded he hands over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hostages having been demanded a hundred, these to the Aedui to be guarded he hands over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After demanding a hundred hostages, he handed them over to the Aedui to be kept under guard.

sentences.latin: Eodem Carnutes legatos obsidesque mittunt usi deprecatoribus Remis, quorum erant in clientela: eadem ferunt responsa.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the same [place] the Carnutes ambassadors and hostages send, having used as intercessors the Remi, of whom they were in the clientship: the same they carry back responses.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the same place the Carnutes ambassadors and hostages send having used as intercessors the Remi, of whom they were in the clientship: the same they carry back responses.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Carnutes also sent envoys and hostages to the same place, using the Remiwhose dependents they wereas intercessors; they received the same reply.

sentences.latin: Peragit concilium Caesar equitesque imperat civitatibus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He finishes the council Caesar and horsemen he levies on the states.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Finishes the council Caesar and horsemen commands from the states.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar concluded the council and requisitioned cavalry from the states.

sentences.latin: Hac parte Galliae pacata totus et mente et animo in bellum Treverorum et Ambiorigis insistit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With this part of Gaul having been pacified, whole both in mind and in spirit on the war of the Treveri and of Ambiorix he presses.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This part of Gaul having been pacified, whole both in mind and in spirit on the war of the Treveri and of Ambiorix he applies himself.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having pacified this part of Gaul, he devoted himself entirely, heart and soul, to the war against the Treveri and Ambiorix.

sentences.latin: Cavarinum cum equitatu Senonum secum proficisci iubet, ne quis aut ex huius iracundia aut ex eo, quod meruerat, odio civitatis motus exsistat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cavarinus with the cavalry of the Senones with himself to set out he orders, lest any either from of this man's hot-temper or from that, which he had earned, hatred of the state disturbance should arise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cavarinus with the cavalry of the Senones with himself to set out he orders, lest any either from this man's hot-temper or from that, which he had earned, hatred of the state disturbance should arise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered Cavarinus to accompany him with the Senonian cavalry, to prevent any disturbance arising from the man's quick temper or from the hatred he had earned from his fellow citizens.

sentences.latin: His rebus constitutis, quod pro explorato habebat Ambiorigem proelio non esse concertaturum, reliqua eius consilia animo circumspiciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been established, because for certain he held Ambiorix in battle not to be about to fight, the remaining of him plans in mind he was surveying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been arranged, because for certain he was holding Ambiorix in battle not to be about to fight, the remaining his plans in mind he was surveying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these arrangements were made, since he considered it certain that Ambiorix would not engage in a pitched battle, he began to consider the rest of his plans.

sentences.latin: Erant Menapii propinqui Eburonum finibus, perpetuis paludibus silvisque muniti, qui uni ex Gallia de pace ad Caesarem legatos numquam miserant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There were the Menapii near to of the Eburones borders, by continuous marshes and woods protected, who alone from Gaul concerning peace to Caesar envoys never had sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Were the Menapii near to the of the Eburones borders, by continuous marshes and forests protected, who alone out of Gaul about peace to Caesar ambassadors never had sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Menapii, who lived near the borders of the Eburones and were protected by continuous marshes and forests, were the only people in Gaul who had never sent envoys to Caesar to ask for peace.

sentences.latin: Cum his esse hospitium Ambiorigi sciebat; item per Treveros venisse Germanis in amicitiam cognoverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these to be hospitality to Ambiorix he knew; likewise through the Treveri to have come to the Germans into friendship he had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these to be guest-friendship to Ambiorix he was knowing; likewise through the Treveri to have come to the Germans into friendship he had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He knew that Ambiorix had a guest-friendship with them; he had also learned that he had entered into an alliance with the Germans through the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Haec prius illi detrahenda auxilia existimabat quam ipsum bello lacesseret, ne desperata salute aut se in Menapios abderet aut cum Transrhenanis congredi cogeretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These first from him to be drawn away reinforcements he was thinking before himself in war he should provoke, lest having despaired of safety either himself among the Menapii he should hide or with the Transrhenanes to join he should be forced.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These first from him to be stripped away reinforcements he was thinking before himself by war he should provoke, lest having despaired of safety either himself among the Menapii he should hide or with the Transrhenanes to join he should be forced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He thought he should strip Ambiorix of these reinforcements before attacking him directly, fearing that if he despaired of safety, he might either hide among the Menapii or be forced to join the tribes across the Rhine.

sentences.latin: Hoc inito consilio totius exercitus impedimenta ad Labienum in Treveros mittit duasque legiones ad eum proficisci iubet; ipse cum legionibus expeditis quinque in Menapios proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This having been entered upon plan of the whole army the baggage to Labienus among the Treveri he sends and two legions to him to set out he orders; himself with legions light-armed five into the Menapii sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been entered plan, of the whole army the baggage to Labienus among the Treveri he sends and two legions to him to set out he orders; he himself with legions light-armed five against the Menapii sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having formed this plan, he sent the baggage of the entire army to Labienus in the territory of the Treveri and ordered two legions to march to him; he himself set out against the Menapii with five lightly equipped legions.

sentences.latin: Illi nulla coacta manu loci praesidio freti in silvas paludesque confugiunt suaque eodem conferunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They no having been collected band in of the place protection relying into the woods and marshes flee and their things to the same place they bring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, no having been collected band, in the of the place protection relying, into the forests and marshes flee and their things to the same place they carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They, having collected no organized force but relying on the protection of the terrain, fled into the forests and marshes, carrying their property with them.

sentences.latin: Caesar partitis copiis cum Gaio Fabio legato et Marco Crasso quaestore celeriterque effectis pontibus adit tripertito, aedificia vicosque incendit, magno pecoris atque hominum numero potitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar having been divided forces with Gaius Fabius the legate and Marcus Crassus the quaestor and quickly having been finished bridges approaches in three parts, buildings and villages he burns, of a great of cattle and of men number he gets possession.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar having been divided the forces with Gaius Fabius the lieutenant and Marcus Crassus the quaestor and quickly having been finished the bridges, he approaches in three parts, buildings and villages he burns, of a great of cattle and of men number he gets possession.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, having divided his forces with the legate Gaius Fabius and the quaestor Marcus Crassus, and having quickly constructed bridges, advanced in three divisions, burned buildings and villages, and captured a great number of cattle and people.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus coacti Menapii legatos ad eum pacis petendae causa mittunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which things having been compelled the Menapii envoys to him of peace to be sought for the sake they send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which things compelled the Menapii ambassadors to him of peace seeking for the sake send.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Compelled by these circumstances, the Menapii sent envoys to him to sue for peace.

sentences.latin: Ille obsidibus acceptis hostium se habiturum numero confirmat, si aut Ambiorigem aut eius legatos finibus suis recepissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He, hostages having been received, of enemies himself to be about to have in the number confirms, if either Ambiorix or his legates in borders their they had received.
