sentences.originalMITTranslation: He, hostages having been accepted, of enemies himself to be about to have in the number declares, if either Ambiorix or his legates within their borders they should have received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After receiving the hostages, he declared that he would treat them as enemies if they sheltered Ambiorix or his envoys within their borders.

sentences.latin: His confirmatis rebus Commium Atrebatem cum equitatu custodis loco in Menapiis relinquit; ipse in Treveros proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been confirmed, Commius the Atrebatian with the cavalry in the place of a guard among the Menapii he leaves; he himself toward the Treveri sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been confirmed, Commius the Atrebatian with cavalry in the place of a guard among the Menapii he leaves; himself toward the Treveri sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having settled these matters, he left Commius the Atrebatian with the cavalry to act as a guard among the Menapii; he himself set out against the Treveri.

sentences.latin: Dum haec a Caesare geruntur, Treveri magnis coactis peditatus equitatusque copiis Labienum cum una legione, quae in eorum finibus hiemaverat, adoriri parabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things by Caesar are being done, the Treveri great having been collected of infantry and of cavalry forces Labienus with one legion, which in their borders had wintered, to attack were preparing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things by Caesar are being done, the Treveri, great having been collected of infantry and of cavalry forces, Labienus with one legion, which in their borders had wintered, to attack were preparing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While Caesar was occupied with these matters, the Treveri collected large forces of infantry and cavalry and prepared to attack Labienus and the single legion that had wintered in their territory.

sentences.latin: Iamque ab eo non longius bidui via aberant, cum duas venisse legiones missu Caesaris cognoscunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And already from him not further of a two-day journey they were away, when two to have come legions by the sending of Caesar they learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And already from him not further of a two-day journey they were away, when two to have come legions by the sending of Caesar they learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They were already no more than a two-day march away from him when they learned that two legions had arrived, sent by Caesar.

sentences.latin: Positis castris a milibus passuum XV auxilia Germanorum exspectare constituunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having placed the camp at thousands of paces fifteen, reinforcements of the Germans to wait for they decide.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having placed camp at thousands of paces fifteen, the reinforcements of the Germans to wait for they decide.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pitching camp fifteen miles away, they decided to wait for German reinforcements.

sentences.latin: Labienus hostium cognito consilio sperans temeritate eorum fore aliquam dimicandi facultatem praesidio quinque cohortium impedimentis relicto cum viginti quinque cohortibus magnoque equitatu contra hostem proficiscitur et mille passuum intermisso spatio castra communit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus, the of the enemies having been known plan, hoping by the rashness of them there would be some of fighting opportunity, a guard of five cohorts for the baggage having been left, with twenty-five cohorts and a great cavalry against the enemy sets out and a mile having been put between space the camp fortifies.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus, the of the enemies having been known plan, hoping by the rashness of them there would be some of fighting opportunity, a guard of five cohorts for the baggage having been left, with twenty-five cohorts and a great cavalry against the enemy sets out and a mile having been put between space the camp fortifies.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus, learning of the enemy's plan and hoping their recklessness would offer an opportunity for battle, left a guard of five cohorts for the baggage and set out against the enemy with twenty-five cohorts and a large body of cavalry, fortifying a camp one mile away from them.

sentences.latin: Erat inter Labienum atque hostem difficili transitu flumen ripisque praeruptis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was between Labienus and the enemy of difficult crossing a river and with banks steep.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was between Labienus and the enemy with a difficult crossing a river and with banks steep.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Between Labienus and the enemy lay a river that was difficult to cross and had steep banks.

sentences.latin: Hoc neque ipse transire habebat in animo neque hostes transituros existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This neither he himself to cross was having in mind nor the enemies about to cross he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This neither himself to cross he was having in mind nor the enemies about to cross he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He did not intend to cross it himself, nor did he think the enemy would cross it.

sentences.latin: Augebatur auxiliorum cotidie spes.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Was being increased of reinforcements daily the hope.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Was being increased of reinforcements daily the hope.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Hope for reinforcements grew daily.

sentences.latin: Loquitur in concilio palam, quoniam Germani appropinquare dicantur, sese suas exercitusque fortunas in dubium non devocaturum et postero die prima luce castra moturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He speaks in council openly, since the Germans to approach are said, that he his own and of the army fortunes into doubt not would call and on the next day at first light the camp would move.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He speaks in council openly, since the Germans to approach are said, himself his own and of the army fortunes into doubt not to be about to call and on the following day at first light the camp to be about to move.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He openly declared in a council of war that, since the Germans were said to be approaching, he would not risk his own or the army's fortunes and would move camp at dawn the following day.

sentences.latin: Celeriter haec ad hostes deferuntur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly these things to the enemies are reported,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly these things to the enemies are reported,
sentences.naturalTranslation: These reports were quickly carried to the enemy,

sentences.latin: ut ex magno Gallorum equitum numero nonnullos Gallicis rebus favere natura cogebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: as from a large of Gallic horsemen number some to Gallic interests to favor nature was compelling.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: as from the great of Gallic horsemen number some Gallic interests to favor nature was compelling.
sentences.naturalTranslation: since nature compelled some out of the large number of Gallic cavalry to favor the Gallic cause.

sentences.latin: Labienus noctu tribunis militum primisque ordinibus convocatis, quid sui sit consili proponit et, quo facilius hostibus timoris det suspicionem, maiore strepitu et tumultu, quam populi Romani fert consuetudo castra moveri iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus by night the tribunes of soldiers and the first ranks having been called together, what of his is plan proposes and, by which more easily to the enemies of fear he might give suspicion, with greater noise and uproar, than of the people Roman carries custom the camp to be moved orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus by night the tribunes of soldiers and the first ranks having been called together, what of his is plan he proposes and, by which more easily to the enemies of fear he might give suspicion, with greater noise and uproar than of the people Roman carries custom the camp to be moved he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At night, Labienus called together the military tribunes and the first-rank centurions, explained his plan, and, in order to give the enemy a stronger impression of fear, ordered the camp to be moved with more noise and confusion than is usual for the Roman people.

sentences.latin: His rebus fugae similem profectionem effecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things of flight similar a departure he made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things of flight similar a departure he made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By these means, he made the departure look like a flight.

sentences.latin: Haec quoque per exploratores ante lucem in tanta propinquitate castrorum ad hostes deferuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things also through scouts before light in so great proximity of the camps to the enemies are reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things also through scouts before light in so great proximity of the camps to the enemies are reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These things were also reported to the enemy by scouts before dawn, because the camps were so close together.

sentences.latin: Vix agmen novissimum extra munitiones processerat, cum Galli cohortati inter se, ne speratam praedam ex manibus dimitterent--longum esse perterritis Romanis Germanorum auxilium exspectare, neque suam pati dignitatem ut tantis copiis tam exiguam manum praesertim fugientem atque impeditam adoriri non audeant--flumen transire et iniquo loco committere proelium non dubitant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Scarcely the column rear outside the fortifications had proceeded, when the Gauls having encouraged among themselves, lest the hoped-for booty from hands they should let go--long it was for the terrified Romans of the Germans help to wait for, nor their own to allow dignity that with so great forces so small a band especially fleeing and hindered to attack they should not dare--the river to cross and in an unfavorable place to join battle they do not hesitate.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Scarcely the line rear outside the fortifications had proceeded, when the Gauls, having encouraged among themselves, lest the hoped-for booty from hands they should let golong it to be for the terrified Romans of the Germans help to wait for, nor their own to allow dignity that with so great forces so small a band especially fleeing and encumbered to attack they should not darethe river to cross and in an unfavorable place to join battle they do not hesitate.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The rear of the column had scarcely moved beyond the fortifications when the Gauls, encouraging one another not to let the hoped-for booty slip from their handsarguing that it would take too long for the terrified Romans to wait for help from the Germans, and that their dignity would not allow them to shrink from attacking such a small force, especially one in flight and encumbered, with such large numbersdid not hesitate to cross the river and join battle on unfavorable ground.

sentences.latin: Quae fore suspicatus Labienus, ut omnes citra flumen eliceret, eadem usus simulatione itineris placide progrediebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things to be about to happen having suspected Labienus, so that all on this side of the river he might entice, the same having used pretense of a journey calmly was advancing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things to be about to be having suspected Labienus, so that all on this side of the river he might entice, the same having used pretense of a march calmly was advancing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus, suspecting that this would happen, continued to advance calmly, using the same pretense of a march in order to entice them all to his side of the river.

sentences.latin: Tum praemissis paulum impedimentis atque in tumulo quodam collocatis "Habetis," inquit, "milites, quam petistis facultatem: hostem impedito atque iniquo loco tenetis:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then having been sent ahead a little the baggage and on a hill certain having been placed "You have," he said, "soldiers, which you sought opportunity: the enemy in a hindered and unfavorable place you hold:"
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then having sent ahead a little the baggage and on a hill certain having been placed, "You have," he said, "soldiers, which you sought opportunity: the enemy in an encumbered and unfavorable place you hold:"
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, having sent the baggage ahead a short distance and placed it on a certain hill, he said, "Soldiers, you have the opportunity you sought: you have the enemy in a difficult and unfavorable position:"

sentences.latin: praestate eandem nobis ducibus virtutem, quam saepe numero imperatori praestitistis, atque illum adesse et haec coram cernere existimate."
sentences.referenceTranslation: show the same to us leaders valor, which often in number to the commander you have shown, and that he is present and these things face to face sees consider.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "show the same to us leaders valor, which often in number to the commander you have shown, and him to be present and these things face to face to see think."
sentences.naturalTranslation: show the same valor under our leadership that you have often shown to your commander, and imagine that he is present and watching these events in person.

sentences.latin: Simul signa ad hostem converti aciemque dirigi iubet, et paucis turmis praesidio ad impedimenta dimissis reliquos equites ad latera disponit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time the standards to the enemy to be turned and the line to be directed he orders, and with a few troops for a guard to the baggage having been sent away the remaining horsemen at the flanks he stations.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time the standards toward the enemy to be turned and the line to be directed he orders, and a few troops for a guard to the baggage having been sent away the remaining horsemen on the flanks he stations.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, he ordered the standards to be turned toward the enemy and the battle line to be formed; having sent a few squadrons to guard the baggage, he stationed the rest of the cavalry on the flanks.

sentences.latin: Celeriter nostri clamore sublato pila in hostes immittunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly our [men] a shout having been raised javelins into the enemies hurl.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly our [men] a shout having been raised javelins into the enemies hurl.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men quickly raised a shout and hurled their javelins at the enemy.

sentences.latin: Illi, ubi praeter spem quos fugere credebant infestis signis ad se ire viderunt, impetum modo ferre non potuerunt ac primo concursu in fugam coniecti proximas silvas petierunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They, when beyond hope [those] whom to flee they were believing with hostile standards toward themselves to go they saw, the attack even to bear not they were able and at the first encounter into flight having been cast the nearest woods they sought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They, when beyond hope [those] whom to flee they were believing with hostile standards toward themselves to go they saw, the attack even to bear not they were able and at the first clash into flight having been cast the nearest woods they sought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the enemy saw those whom they believed were fleeing advancing toward them with hostile intent, contrary to their expectations, they could not even withstand the initial charge; they were put to flight at the first encounter and sought refuge in the nearest woods.

sentences.latin: Quos Labienus equitatu consectatus, magno numero interfecto, compluribus captis, paucis post diebus civitatem recepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom Labienus with cavalry having pursued, a great number having been killed, several having been captured, a few after days the state he recovered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom Labienus with cavalry having pursued, a great number having been killed, several having been captured, a few after days the state he recovered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Labienus pursued them with his cavalry, and after killing a great number and capturing many others, he received the submission of the state a few days later.

sentences.latin: Nam Germani qui auxilio veniebant percepta Treverorum fuga sese domum receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For the Germans who for aid were coming, having been perceived the of the Treveri flight, themselves home they withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For the Germans who for aid were coming, having been perceived the Treveri's flight, themselves home they withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the Germans who were coming to their aid, having learned of the flight of the Treveri, returned to their homes.

sentences.latin: Cum his propinqui Indutiomari, qui defectionis auctores fuerant, comitati eos ex civitate excesserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these the relatives of Indutiomarus, who of the revolt authors had been, having accompanied them out of the state departed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these the relatives of Indutiomarus, who of the revolt authors had been, having accompanied them out of the state departed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The relatives of Indutiomarus, who had been the instigators of the revolt, accompanied them and fled the state.

sentences.latin: Cingetorigi, quem ab initio permansisse in officio demonstravimus, principatus atque imperium est traditum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To Cingetorix, whom from the beginning to have remained in duty we have shown, the leadership and supreme power was handed over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To Cingetorix, whom from the beginning to have remained in duty we have shown, the leadership and supreme power was handed over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The leadership and supreme power were handed over to Cingetorix, who, as we have shown, remained loyal from the beginning.

sentences.latin: Caesar, postquam ex Menapiis in Treveros venit, duabus de causis Rhenum transire constituit; quarum una erat, quod auxilia contra se Treveris miserant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, after from the Menapii into the Treveri he came, for two from causes the Rhine to cross he decided; of which one was, because reinforcements against himself to the Treveri they had sent,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, after from the Menapii into the Treveri he came, for two from reasons the Rhine to cross decided; of which one was, because reinforcements against himself to the Treveri they had sent,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After Caesar arrived among the Treveri from the Menapii, he decided to cross the Rhine for two reasons: one was that they had sent reinforcements to the Treveri against him;

sentences.latin: altera, ne ad eos Ambiorix receptum haberet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the other, lest to them Ambiorix a retreat might have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the other, lest to them Ambiorix a retreat might have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: the other was to prevent Ambiorix from having a place of retreat among them.

sentences.latin: His constitutis rebus paulum supra eum locum quo ante exercitum traduxerat facere pontem instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been decided things a little above that place where before the army he had led across to make a bridge he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been decided things a little above that place where before the army he had led across to make a bridge he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having made these decisions, he began to build a bridge a little above the place where he had previously led his army across.

sentences.latin: Nota atque instituta ratione magno militum studio paucis diebus opus efficitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the known and established method with great of the soldiers zeal in a few days the work is completed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the known and established method with great of the soldiers zeal in a few days the work is completed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Using the method already known and established, the work was completed in a few days through the great enthusiasm of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Firmo in Treveris ad pontem praesidio relicto, ne quis ab his subito motus oreretur, reliquas copias equitatumque traducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A strong in the Treveri at the bridge guard having been left, lest any by these suddenly movement should arise, the remaining forces and cavalry he leads across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A firm in the Treveri at the bridge guard having been left, lest any from them suddenly movement might arise, the remaining forces and cavalry he leads across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Leaving a strong guard among the Treveri at the bridge to prevent any sudden uprising from them, he led the rest of his forces and the cavalry across.

sentences.latin: Vbii, qui ante obsides dederant atque in deditionem venerant, purgandi sui causa ad eum legatos mittunt, qui doceant neque auxilia ex sua civitate in Treveros missa neque ab se fidem laesam:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Ubii, who before hostages had given and into surrender had come, of clearing themselves for the sake to him ambassadors send, who might show neither reinforcements from their state into the Treveri sent nor by themselves faith injured:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Ubii, who before hostages had given and into surrender had come, of clearing themselves for the sake to him ambassadors send, who might show neither reinforcements from their state into the Treveri [to have been] sent nor by themselves faith [to have been] broken:
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Ubii, who had previously given hostages and surrendered, sent ambassadors to him to clear themselves, explaining that reinforcements had not been sent from their state to the Treveri, nor had they broken their word.

sentences.latin: petunt atque orant ut sibi parcat, ne communi odio Germanorum innocentes pro nocentibus poenas pendant; si amplius obsidum vellet, dare pollicentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: they seek and pray that to them he might spare, lest in the common hatred of the Germans the innocent for the guilty penalties they might pay; if more of hostages he should wish, to give they promise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: they seek and pray that to them he might spare, lest in the common hatred of the Germans the innocent for the guilty penalties they might pay; if more of hostages he should wish, to give they promise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They begged and pleaded with him to spare them, so that the innocent would not suffer for the guilty due to a general hatred of Germans; they promised to give more hostages if he wished.

sentences.latin: Cognita Caesar causa reperit ab Suebis auxilia missa esse; Vbiorum satisfactionem accipit, aditus viasque in Suebos perquirit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been learned Caesar the cause finds out by the Suebi reinforcements sent to have been; of the Ubii the excuse he accepts, approaches and ways into the Suebi he searches out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been investigated Caesar the cause found by the Suebi reinforcements to have been sent; of the Ubii the excuse he accepts, the approaches and ways into the Suebi he searches out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After investigating the matter, Caesar found that the reinforcements had been sent by the Suebi; he accepted the Ubii's explanation and searched for routes and approaches into the territory of the Suebi.

sentences.latin: Interim paucis post diebus fit ab Vbiis certior Suebos omnes in unum locum copias cogere atque eis nationibus quae sub eorum sint imperio denuntiare, ut auxilia peditatus equitatusque mittant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile a few after days he is made by the Ubii more certain the Suebi all into one place forces to collect and to those nations which under their are power to command, that reinforcements of infantry and of cavalry they should send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile a few after days he is made by the Ubii more certain the Suebi all into one place forces to collect and to those nations which under their are power to command, that reinforcements of infantry and of cavalry they should send.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A few days later, he was informed by the Ubii that all the Suebi were concentrating their forces in one place and ordering the nations under their rule to send reinforcements of infantry and cavalry.

sentences.latin: His cognitis rebus rem frumentariam providet, castris idoneum locum deligit; Vbiis imperat ut pecora deducant suaque omnia ex agris in oppida conferant, sperans barbaros atque imperitos homines inopia cibariorum adductos ad iniquam pugnandi condicionem posse deduci;
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been learned things the matter grain-related he provides for, for a camp a suitable place he chooses; to the Ubii he commands that cattle they lead away and their all from the fields into the towns they bring together, hoping the barbarian and unskilled men by lack of provisions influenced to an unfair of fighting condition to be able to be led;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been known things the matter grain-related he provides for, for the camp a suitable place he chooses; to the Ubii he commands that cattle they should lead away and their all [things] from the fields into the towns they should bring together, hoping barbarian and unskilled men by lack of provisions influenced to an unfavorable of fighting condition to be able to be led;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning this, he arranged for grain supplies and chose a suitable site for a camp; he ordered the Ubii to remove their cattle and bring all their property from the fields into the towns, hoping that these uncivilized and inexperienced men, driven by a lack of provisions, could be forced into an unfavorable position for fighting.

sentences.latin: mandat, ut crebros exploratores in Suebos mittant quaeque apud eos gerantur cognoscant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he mandates, that frequent scouts into the Suebi they should send and what things among them are being done they should learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he mandates, that frequent scouts into the Suebi they should send and what among them are being done they should find out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He instructed them to send frequent scouts among the Suebi to find out what was happening there.

sentences.latin: Illi imperata faciunt et paucis diebus intermissis referunt: Suebos omnes, posteaquam certiores nuntii de exercitu Romanorum venerint, cum omnibus suis sociorumque copiis, quas coegissent, penitus ad extremos fines se recepisse:
sentences.referenceTranslation: They the commanded things do and a few days having intervened they report: the Suebi all, after more certain messengers about the army of the Romans had come, with all their and of the allies forces, which they had collected, deep to the furthest borders themselves to have withdrawn:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They the commanded [things] do and a few days having intervened they report: the Suebi all, after more certain news about the army of the Romans had come, with all their own and of the allies forces, which they had collected, far to the furthest borders themselves to have withdrawn:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They carried out his orders and, after a few days, reported back: all the Suebi, once they received reliable news of the Roman army's approach, had retreated deep into their furthest territories with all their own forces and those of their allies which they had gathered.

sentences.latin: silvam esse ibi infinita magnitudine, quae appellatur Bacenis; hanc longe introrsus pertinere et pro nativo muro obiectam Cheruscos ab Suebis Suebosque ab Cheruscis iniuriis incursionibusque prohibere: ad eius initium silvae Suebos adventum Romanorum exspectare constituisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: a forest to be there of infinite magnitude, which is called Bacenis; this far inward to extend and as a natural wall placed against the Cherusci from the Suebi and the Suebi from the Cherusci from injuries and incursions to prohibit: at its beginning of the forest the Suebi the arrival of the Romans to wait for to have decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a forest to be there of infinite magnitude, which is called Bacenis; this far inward to extend and as a natural wall placed against the Cherusci from the Suebi and the Suebi from the Cherusci from injuries and incursions to prohibit: at its beginning of the forest the Suebi the arrival of the Romans to wait for to have decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They reported that there was a forest of immense size there called Bacenis; it extended far into the interior and, serving as a natural barrier, protected the Cherusci from the Suebi and the Suebi from the Cherusci, preventing mutual injuries and raids. At the edge of this forest, the Suebi had decided to await the arrival of the Romans.

sentences.latin: Quoniam ad hunc locum perventum est, non alienum esse videtur de Galliae Germaniaeque moribus et quo differant hae nationes inter sese proponere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Since to this place it has been come, not foreign to be it seems about of Gaul and of Germany the customs and in what they differ these nations among themselves to set forth.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Since to this place it has been come, not foreign to be it seems about of Gaul and of Germany the customs and in what they differ these nations among themselves to set forth.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since we have reached this point, it seems appropriate to describe the customs of Gaul and Germany and the differences between these nations.

sentences.latin: In Gallia non solum in omnibus civitatibus atque in omnibus pagis partibusque, sed paene etiam in singulis domibus factiones sunt, earumque factionum principes sunt
sentences.referenceTranslation: In Gaul not only in all states and in all cantons and parts, but almost even in individual houses factions are, and of those factions the leaders are
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In Gaul not only in all states and in all cantons and parts, but almost even in individual houses factions are, and of those factions leaders are
sentences.naturalTranslation: In Gaul, there are factions not only in every state and in every canton and district, but almost even in every household, and there are leaders of these factions.

sentences.latin: qui summam auctoritatem eorum iudicio habere existimantur, quorum ad arbitrium iudiciumque summa omnium rerum consiliorumque redeat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who the highest authority in their judgment to have are thought, to whose decision and judgment the sum of all things and plans should return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who highest authority by their judgment to have are thought, to whose decision and judgment the sum of all things and plans returns.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These leaders are thought, in the judgment of the Gauls, to possess the highest authority, and to their decision and judgment the final word on all matters and plans is referred.

sentences.latin: Itaque eius rei causa antiquitus institutum videtur, ne quis ex plebe contra potentiorem auxili egeret: suos enim quisque opprimi et circumveniri non patitur, neque, aliter si faciat, ullam inter suos habet auctoritatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore of this thing for the sake from ancient times established it seems, lest anyone from the plebs against a more powerful [man] of help should be in need: his own [people] for each [leader] to be oppressed and circumvented does not allow, nor, otherwise if he should do, any among his own has he authority.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore of this thing for the sake from ancient times established it seems, lest anyone from the common people against a more powerful [man] of help should lack: his own [people] for each to be oppressed and circumvented does not allow, nor, otherwise if he should do, any among his own has he authority.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, this system seems to have been established in ancient times for this reason: so that no one of the common people should lack help against a more powerful man; for each leader does not allow his own followers to be oppressed or cheated, and if he were to act otherwise, he would have no authority among his own people.

sentences.latin: Haec eadem ratio est in summa totius Galliae: namque omnes civitates in partes divisae sunt duas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This same system is in the sum of all Gaul: for all states into parts divided are two.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This same system is in the sum of whole Gaul: for all states into parts divided are two.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This same principle exists in Gaul as a whole, for all states are divided into two factions.

sentences.latin: Cum Caesar in Galliam venit, alterius factionis principes erant Aedui, alterius Sequani.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When Caesar into Gaul came, of the one faction leaders were the Aedui, of the other the Sequani.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When Caesar into Gaul came, of the one faction leaders were the Aedui, of the other the Sequani.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar arrived in Gaul, the Aedui were the leaders of one faction, and the Sequani of the other.

sentences.latin: Hi cum per se minus valerent, quod summa auctoritas antiquitus erat in Aeduis magnaeque eorum erant clientelae, Germanos atque Ariovistum sibi adiunxerant eosque ad se magnis iacturis pollicitationibusque perduxerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These since through themselves less they were strong, because the highest authority from ancient times was in the Aedui and great of them were the clienteles, the Germans and Ariovistus to themselves they had joined and them to themselves by great sacrifices and promises they had led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These since by themselves less they were strong, because highest authority from ancient times was in the Aedui and great of them were clienteles, the Germans and Ariovistus to themselves they had joined and those to themselves by great sacrifices and promises they had led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the Sequani were less powerful on their ownbecause the highest authority had anciently belonged to the Aedui and their dependencies were extensivethey had allied themselves with the Germans and Ariovistus, winning them over with great sacrifices and promises.

sentences.latin: Proeliis vero compluribus factis secundis atque omni nobilitate Aeduorum interfecta tantum potentia antecesserant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Battles indeed several having been made successful and all the nobility of the Aedui having been killed, so much in power they had surpassed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Battles indeed several having been made successful and all the nobility of the Aedui killed so much in power they had advanced,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Indeed, after several successful battles were fought and all the Aeduan nobility was killed, they had advanced so far in power,

sentences.latin: ut magnam partem clientium ab Aeduis ad se traducerent obsidesque ab eis principum filios acciperent et publice iurare cogerent nihil se contra Sequanos consili inituros et partem finitimi agri per vim occupatam possiderent Galliaeque totius principatum obtinerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that a great part of the clients from the Aedui to themselves they transferred and hostages from them the sons of the leaders they received and publicly to swear they compelled that nothing against the Sequani of a plan they would enter and a part of the neighboring territory through force occupied they possessed and of all Gaul the leadership they obtained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that a great part of clients from the Aedui to themselves they transferred and hostages from them the of leaders sons they received and publicly to swear they compelled nothing themselves against the Sequani of plan would enter and a part of neighboring land through force occupied they possessed and of Gaul whole the leadership they held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that they transferred a large part of the Aeduan dependents to themselves, took the sons of their leaders as hostages, and compelled them to swear publicly that they would take no counsel against the Sequani; they also held a part of the neighboring territory seized by force and maintained leadership over all of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Qua necessitate adductus Diviciacus auxili petendi causa Romam ad senatum profectus infecta re redierat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which necessity led Diviciacus of help seeking for the sake to Rome to the senate having set out, the matter unfinished, had returned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which necessity led Diviciacus of help seeking for the sake to Rome to the senate having set out the thing unfinished had returned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Driven by this necessity, Diviciacus had set out for Rome to the Senate to seek help, but had returned without achieving his purpose.

sentences.latin: Adventu Caesaris facta commutatione rerum, obsidibus Aeduis redditis, veteribus clientelis restitutis, novis per Caesarem comparatis, quod hi, qui se ad eorum amicitiam adgregaverant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the arrival of Caesar having been made a change of things, hostages to the Aedui having been returned, old clienteles having been restored, new ones through Caesar having been obtained, because these, who themselves to their friendship had joined,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the arrival of Caesar made a change of things, hostages to the Aedui returned, old clienteles restored, new through Caesar obtained, because these, who themselves to their friendship had joined,
sentences.naturalTranslation: With Caesar's arrival, a change in the state of affairs occurred: the Aeduan hostages were returned, their former dependencies were restored, and new ones were acquired through Caesar, because those who had joined themselves to their alliance,

sentences.latin: meliore condicione atque aequiore imperio se uti videbant, reliquis rebus eorum gratia dignitateque amplificata Sequani principatum dimiserant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: better condition and more fair command themselves to use they saw, other things their influence and dignity having been increased the Sequani the leadership had lost.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: better condition and fairer rule themselves to use they saw, in other things their influence and dignity having been increased the Sequani the leadership had lost.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Seeing that they were now in a better condition and under a fairer rule, and since their influence and dignity had increased in other respects, the Sequani had lost their leadership.

sentences.latin: In eorum locum Remi successerant: quos quod adaequare apud Caesarem gratia intellegebatur, ei, qui propter veteres inimicitias nullo modo cum Aeduis coniungi poterant, se Remis in clientelam dicabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In their place the Remi had succeeded: whom because to equal with Caesar in influence it was understood, those, who on account of old enmities in no way with the Aedui to be joined were able, themselves to the Remi into clientship were dedicating.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Into their place the Remi had succeeded: whom because to equal with Caesar in influence it was understood, those, who on account of old enmities in no way with the Aedui to be joined were able, themselves to the Remi into clientship they devoted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Remi had taken their place; because it was understood that they were equal in influence with Caesar, those who, due to old feuds, could in no way be allied with the Aedui, committed themselves to the protection of the Remi.

sentences.latin: Hos illi diligenter tuebantur: ita et novam et repente collectam auctoritatem tenebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These those diligently were protecting: thus both new and suddenly collected authority they were holding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These those [the Remi] diligently protected: thus both new and suddenly collected authority they held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Remi protected them diligently; in this way, they maintained an authority that was both new and rapidly acquired.

sentences.latin: Eo tum statu res erat, ut longe principes haberentur Aedui, secundum locum dignitatis Remi obtinerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In that then state the matter was, that by far the leaders were held the Aedui, the second place of dignity the Remi were obtaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In that then state the matter was, that by far leaders were held the Aedui, second place of dignity the Remi held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At that time, the situation was such that the Aedui were considered the undisputed leaders, while the Remi held the second rank of honor.

sentences.latin: In omni Gallia eorum hominum, qui aliquo sunt numero atque honore, genera sunt duo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In all Gaul of those men, who in some number and honor are, classes are two.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In all Gaul of those men, who in some number and honor are, kinds are two.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Throughout all of Gaul, there are two classes of men who are of any account or honor.

sentences.latin: Nam plebes paene servorum habetur loco, quae nihil audet per se, nullo adhibetur consilio.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For the common people almost of slaves is held in the place, which nothing dares by itself, to no council is admitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For the common people almost of slaves is held in the place, which nothing dares by itself, to no council is admitted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the common people are treated almost as slaves; they dare nothing on their own and are never invited to any council.

sentences.latin: Plerique, cum aut aere alieno aut magnitudine tributorum aut iniuria potentiorum premuntur, sese in servitutem dicant nobilibus: in hos eadem omnia sunt iura, quae dominis in servos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Most, when either by debt or by magnitude of tributes or by injury of the more powerful they are pressed, themselves into slavery dedicate to the nobles: in hos same all are the rights, which to masters over slaves.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Most, when either by debt or magnitude of taxes or injury of the more powerful they are pressed, themselves into slavery devote to the nobles: in these the same all are rights, which to masters over slaves.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Most of them, when oppressed by debt, the weight of taxes, or the injustice of the powerful, surrender themselves into slavery to the nobles, who possess the same rights over them as masters have over slaves.

sentences.latin: Sed de his duobus generibus alterum est druidum, alterum equitum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But of these two classes one is of the Druids, the other of the knights.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But of these two kinds one is of the Druids, the other of the knights.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Of these two classes, one consists of the Druids, the other of the knights.

sentences.latin: Illi rebus divinis intersunt, sacrificia publica ac privata procurant, religiones interpretantur: ad hos magnus adulescentium numerus disciplinae causa concurrit, magnoque hi sunt apud eos honore.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Those in things divine are present, sacrifices public and private they manage, religious matters they interpret: to these a great of young men number for the sake of instruction flock, and in great these are among them honor.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Those in things divine are present, sacrifices public and private they manage, religious matters they interpret: to these a great of young men number for the sake of instruction flock, and in great these are among them honor.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Druids are concerned with divine matters, manage public and private sacrifices, and interpret religious questions; a great number of young men flock to them for instruction, and they are held in high honor among the people.

sentences.latin: Nam fere de omnibus controversiis publicis privatisque constituunt, et, si quod est admissum facinus, si caedes facta, si de hereditate, de finibus controversia est, idem decernunt, praemia poenasque constituunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For almost about all controversies public and private they decide, and, if any is committed crime, if murder done, if about inheritance, about boundaries controversy is, the same decide, rewards and punishments they establish;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For almost about all controversies public and private they decide, and, if any is committed crime, if murder made, if about inheritance, about boundaries controversy is, the same [men] decide, rewards and punishments they establish;
sentences.naturalTranslation: For they decide almost all public and private disputes; if any crime has been committed, if a murder has occurred, or if there is a dispute over an inheritance or boundaries, they are the ones who decide and establish the rewards and punishments.

sentences.latin: si qui aut privatus aut populus eorum decreto non stetit, sacrificiis interdicunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if anyone either private or people of them by decree not has stood, from sacrifices they forbid.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if anyone either private or a people by their decree has not stood, from sacrifices they forbid.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If any individual or tribe does not abide by their decision, they ban them from sacrifices.

sentences.latin: Haec poena apud eos est gravissima.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This penalty among them is most heavy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This penalty among them is most heavy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among them, this is the most severe punishment.

sentences.latin: Quibus ita est interdictum, hi numero impiorum ac sceleratorum habentur, his omnes decedunt, aditum sermonemque defugiunt, ne quid ex contagione incommodi accipiant, neque his petentibus ius redditur neque honos ullus communicatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To whom thus it has been forbidden, these in the number of the impious and of the wicked are held, from these all depart, approach and conversation they flee, lest anything from contact of harm they receive, nor to these seeking justice is returned nor honor any shared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To whom thus it has been forbidden, these in the number of the impious and wicked are held, from these all depart, approach and conversation they flee, lest anything of harm from contact they receive, nor to these seeking is justice returned nor honor any shared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who are thus banned are reckoned among the impious and the criminal; everyone avoids them, fleeing their approach and conversation to avoid any harm from contact; justice is not rendered to them when they seek it, nor is any honor shared with them.

sentences.latin: His autem omnibus druidibus praeest unus, qui summam inter eos habet auctoritatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over these however all Druids is in charge one, who highest among them has authority.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Over these however all Druids presides one, who the highest among them has authority.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One man, however, presides over all these Druids and possesses the highest authority among them.

sentences.latin: Hoc mortuo aut si qui ex reliquis excellit dignitate succedit, aut, si sunt plures pares, suffragio druidum, nonnumquam etiam armis de principatu contendunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This one having died either if anyone from the remaining excels in dignity he succeeds, or, if there are more equals, by vote of the Druids, sometimes even by arms for the leadership they contend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This [one] having died either if anyone from the remaining excels in dignity he succeeds, or, if there are many equals, by the vote of the Druids, sometimes even by arms for the leadership they contend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon his death, if anyone among the rest excels in rank, he succeeds him; but if there are several equals, they compete for the leadership by a vote of the Druids, and sometimes even by force of arms.

sentences.latin: hi certo anni tempore in finibus Carnutum, quae regio totius Galliae media habetur, considunt in loco consecrato.
sentences.referenceTranslation: these at a certain of the year time in the borders of the Carnutes, which region of all Gaul middle is held, sit down in a place consecrated.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: these at a certain of the year time in the borders of the Carnutes, which region of all Gaul middle is held, sit down in a place consecrated.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At a certain time of year, they hold a session in a consecrated place within the territory of the Carnutes, a region which is considered the center of all Gaul.

sentences.latin: Huc omnes undique, qui controversias habent, conveniunt eorumque decretis iudiciisque parent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To here all from everywhere, who controversies have, assemble and of them the decrees and judgments they obey.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hither all from everywhere, who controversies have, come together and their decrees and judgments obey.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All people from every side who have disputes assemble here and submit to their decrees and judgments.

sentences.latin: Disciplina in Britannia reperta atque inde in Galliam translata esse existimatur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The discipline in Britain discovered and from there into Gaul transferred to have been is thought,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The system in Britain discovered and from there into Gaul transferred to have been is thought,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their system of training is thought to have been discovered in Britain and transferred from there into Gaul,

sentences.latin: et nunc, qui diligentius eam rem cognoscere volunt, plerumque illo discendi causa proficiscuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and now, who more diligently that matter to learn want, generally to that place of learning for the sake they set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and now, [those] who more diligently that matter to learn wish, generally thither for the sake of learning set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and even now, those who wish to study the matter more deeply generally travel there for the purpose of learning.

sentences.latin: Druides a bello abesse consuerunt neque tributa una cum reliquis pendunt; militiae vacationem omniumque rerum habent immunitatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Druids from war to be absent are accustomed nor taxes together with the rest pay; of military service exemption of all and things they have immunity.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Druids from war to be absent are accustomed nor taxes together with the rest pay; of military service exemption and of all things they have immunity.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Druids are accustomed to be exempt from war and do not pay taxes along with the rest; they have exemption from military service and immunity from all burdens.

sentences.latin: Tantis excitati praemiis et sua sponte multi in disciplinam conveniunt et a parentibus propinquisque mittuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By so great excited rewards and by their own accord many into the discipline come together and by parents relatives-and are sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By such great excited rewards both of their own accord many into the discipline come together and by parents and relatives are sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Excited by such great rewards, many join this training of their own accord, while others are sent by their parents and relatives.

sentences.latin: Magnum ibi numerum versuum ediscere dicuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A great there number of verses to learn by heart they are said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great there number of verses to learn by heart they are said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They are said to learn a great number of verses there by heart.

sentences.latin: Itaque annos nonnulli vicenos in disciplina permanent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so years some twenty in the discipline they remain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so years some twenty in the discipline they remain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, some remain in training for twenty years.

sentences.latin: Neque fas esse existimant ea litteris mandare, cum in reliquis fere rebus, publicis privatisque rationibus Graecis litteris utantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor right to be they think those things to letters to entrust, although in the remaining almost things, public private-and accounts Greek letters they use.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor right to be they think those things to letters to commit, although in the remaining almost matters, public and private accounts Greek letters they use.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They do not think it right to commit these teachings to writing, although in almost all other matters, both public and private accounts, they use Greek characters.

sentences.latin: Id mihi duabus de causis instituisse videntur, quod neque in vulgum disciplinam efferri velint neque eos, qui discunt, litteris confisos minus memoriae studere: quod fere plerisque accidit, ut praesidio litterarum diligentiam in perdiscendo ac memoriam remittant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This to me for two from causes to have established they seem, because neither into the common people the discipline to be carried out they wish nor those, who learn, in letters having relied less to memory to pay attention: which generally to most happens, that by the protection of letters diligence in learning thoroughly and memory they relax.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This to me for two from reasons to have established they seem, because neither into the common people the discipline to be carried out they wish nor those, who learn, on letters having relied less to memory to pay attention: which generally to most happens, that by the protection of letters diligence in learning thoroughly and memory they relax.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They seem to me to have established this for two reasons: because they do not want their teaching to be spread among the common people, nor do they want those who learn to rely on writing and pay less attention to memory; for it commonly happens to most people that, by relying on writing, they relax their diligence in learning and their use of memory.

sentences.latin: In primis hoc volunt persuadere, non interire animas, sed ab aliis post mortem transire ad alios, atque hoc maxime ad virtutem excitari putant metu mortis neglecto.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In first this they wish to persuade, not to perish souls, but from some after death to cross over to others, and by this especially to virtue to be excited they think the fear of death having been neglected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the first [place] this they wish to persuade, not to perish souls, but from some after death to pass to others, and by this most greatly to virtue to be excited they think the fear of death having been neglected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Above all, they wish to persuade people of this: that souls do not perish, but pass after death from one person to another; they think that this especially rouses men to courage, as the fear of death is disregarded.

sentences.latin: Multa praeterea de sideribus atque eorum motu, de mundi ac terrarum magnitudine, de rerum natura, de deorum immortalium vi ac potestate disputant et iuventuti tradunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Many things besides about the stars and of them the motion, about of the world and of the lands the size, about of things the nature, about of the gods immortal the force and power they discuss and to the youth they hand down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Many things besides about the stars and their motion, about of the world and of the lands the magnitude, about of things the nature, about of the gods immortal the force and power they discuss and to the youth hand down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They also hold many discussions about the stars and their motion, the size of the universe and the earth, the nature of things, and the strength and power of the immortal gods, and they hand this knowledge down to the youth.

sentences.latin: Alterum genus est equitum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The other kind is of knights.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The other kind is of knights.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The other class is that of the knights.

sentences.latin: Hi, cum est usus atque aliquod bellum incidit (quod fere ante Caesaris adventum quotannis accidere solebat, uti aut ipsi iniurias inferrent aut illatas propulsarent), omnes in bello versantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These, when there is need and some war happens (which generally before of Caesar the arrival yearly to happen was accustomed, so that either themselves injuries they might inflict or [those] inflicted they might repel), all in war are engaged,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These, when there is need and some war happens (which generally before Caesar's arrival every year to happen was accustomed, so that either themselves injuries they inflicted or [those] inflicted they repelled), all in war are engaged,
sentences.naturalTranslation: These, whenever there is need and some war occurs (which before Caesar's arrival used to happen almost every year, so that they were either inflicting injuries themselves or repelling those inflicted on them), are all engaged in war.

sentences.latin: atque eorum ut quisque est genere copiisque amplissimus, ita plurimos circum se ambactos clientesque habet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and of them as each is in birth and in resources most distinguished, so most around himself vassals and clients he has.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and of them as each is in birth and resources most distinguished, so most around himself vassals and clients he has.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And the more distinguished each of them is by birth and resources, the more vassals and clients he has around him.

sentences.latin: Hanc unam gratiam potentiamque noverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This one influence and power they have known.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This one influence and power they have known.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This is the only form of influence and power they recognize.

sentences.latin: Natio est omnis Gallorum admodum dedita religionibus,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The nation is all of the Gauls very much devoted to religious rites,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The nation is all of the Gauls very much devoted to religious rites,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The whole nation of the Gauls is greatly devoted to religious observances,

sentences.latin: atque ob eam causam, qui sunt adfecti gravioribus morbis quique in proeliis periculisque versantur, aut pro victimis homines immolant aut se immolaturos vovent administrisque ad ea sacrificia druidibus utuntur, quod, pro vita hominis nisi hominis vita reddatur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: and for that cause, [those] who are affected by more serious diseases and who in battles and dangers are engaged, either for victims men they sacrifice or themselves to be about to sacrifice they vow and as assistants for those sacrifices druids they use, because, for the life of a man unless the life of a man be returned,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and for that cause, those who are affected by more serious diseases and those who in battles and dangers are engaged, either for victims men they sacrifice or themselves to be about to sacrifice they vow and as assistants for those sacrifices druids they use, because, for the life of a man unless the life of a man be returned,
sentences.naturalTranslation: and for this reason, those who are afflicted by serious illnesses or who are engaged in battles and dangers either sacrifice human beings as victims or vow that they will do so, employing the Druids as ministers for these sacrifices, because they believe that unless a man's life is offered for a man's life,

sentences.latin: non posse deorum immortalium numen placari arbitrantur, publiceque eiusdem generis habent instituta sacrificia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: not to be able the divine power of the gods immortal to be appeased they think, and publicly of the same kind they have established sacrifices.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not to be able the divine power of the immortal gods to be appeased they think, and publicly of the same kind they have established sacrifices.
sentences.naturalTranslation: the divine power of the immortal gods cannot be appeased; and they have sacrifices of the same kind established for public purposes.

sentences.latin: Alii immani magnitudine simulacra habent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Others of immense size figures have,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Others of immense size figures have,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Others have figures of immense size,

sentences.latin: quorum contexta viminibus membra vivis hominibus complent; quibus succensis circumventi flamma exanimantur homines.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of which the woven with twigs limbs with living men they fill; which having been set on fire surrounded by flame are killed the men.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of which the woven with twigs limbs with living men they fill; which having been set on fire surrounded by flame are killed the men.
sentences.naturalTranslation: whose limbs, woven from wicker, they fill with living men; when these are set on fire, the men perish, enveloped in flames.

sentences.latin: Supplicia eorum qui in furto aut in latrocinio aut aliqua noxia sint comprehensi gratiora dis immortalibus esse arbitrantur; sed, cum eius generis copia defecit, etiam ad innocentium supplicia descendunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The executions of those who in theft or in robbery or some offense have been caught more pleasing to the gods immortal to be they think; but, when of that kind the supply has failed, even to of the innocent executions they descend.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The punishments of those who in theft or in robbery or some offense have been caught more pleasing to the gods immortal to be they think; but, when of that kind the supply has failed, even to of the innocent punishments they descend.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They believe that the execution of those caught in theft, robbery, or any other offense is more pleasing to the immortal gods; but when the supply of that kind runs out, they even resort to the execution of the innocent.

sentences.latin: Deum maxime Mercurium colunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the gods especially Mercury they worship.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the gods especially Mercury they worship.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among the gods, they worship Mercury most of all.

sentences.latin: Huius sunt plurima simulacra: hunc omnium inventorem artium ferunt, hunc viarum atque itinerum ducem, hunc ad quaestus pecuniae mercaturasque habere vim maximam arbitrantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this [one] are very many statues: this [one] of all the inventor of arts they report, this [one] of roads and of journeys the guide, this [one] for the gains of money and trades to have power greatest they think.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this one are very many images: this one of all the inventor of arts they say, this one of roads and of journeys the guide, this one for the gains of money and trades to have power greatest they think.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There are many statues of him: they call him the inventor of all arts, the guide of roads and journeys, and they believe he has the greatest power over the acquisition of money and over trade.

sentences.latin: Post hunc Apollinem et Martem et Iovem et Minervam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After this [one] Apollo and Mars and Jupiter and Minerva.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After this one Apollo and Mars and Jupiter and Minerva.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After him, they worship Apollo, Mars, Jupiter, and Minerva.

sentences.latin: De his eandem fere, quam reliquae gentes, habent opinionem: Apollinem morbos depellere, Minervam operum atque artificiorum initia tradere, Iovem imperium caelestium tenere, Martem bella regere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Concerning these [gods] the same almost, as the remaining nations, they have opinion: Apollo diseases to drive away, Minerva of works and of crafts the beginnings to hand down, Jupiter the power of the celestials to hold, Mars wars to rule.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Concerning these the same almost, as the remaining nations, they have opinion: Apollo diseases to drive away, Minerva of works and of crafts the beginnings to hand down, Jupiter the power of the celestials to hold, Mars wars to rule.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Regarding these gods, they hold nearly the same opinion as other nations: that Apollo drives away diseases, Minerva introduces the principles of works and crafts, Jupiter holds sovereignty over the heavens, and Mars governs wars.

sentences.latin: Huic, cum proelio dimicare constituerunt, ea quae bello ceperint plerumque devovent: cum superaverunt, animalia capta immolant reliquasque res in unum locum conferunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To this [Mars], when in battle to fight they have decided, those things which in war they shall have captured for the most part they vow: when they have overcome, animals captured they sacrifice and the remaining things into one place they bring together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To this one, when in battle to fight they have decided, those things which in war they have captured for the most part they devote: when they have conquered, the animals captured they sacrifice and the remaining things into one place they bring together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To Mars, when they have decided to engage in battle, they usually vow whatever they might capture in the war; when they are victorious, they sacrifice the captured animals and gather the rest of the spoils into a single location.

sentences.latin: Multis in civitatibus harum rerum exstructos tumulos locis consecratis conspicari licet;
sentences.referenceTranslation: In many in states of these things piled up mounds in places consecrated to be seen it is permitted;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In many in states of these things built up mounds in places consecrated to be seen it is permitted;
sentences.naturalTranslation: In many states, one can see mounds of these things piled up in consecrated places;

sentences.latin: neque saepe accidit, ut neglecta quispiam religione aut capta apud se occultare aut posita tollere auderet, gravissimumque ei rei supplicium cum cruciatu constitutum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not often it happens, that neglected religion anyone either captured things at his own [house] to hide or placed things to take away would dare, and most heavy for that thing punishment with torture established is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not often it happens, that having been neglected by anyone religion either things captured at his house to hide or things placed to take away he would dare, and the most severe for that thing punishment with torture established is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and it rarely happens that anyone, disregarding religious awe, would dare either to hide captured goods at home or to remove what has been deposited; for such an offense, a most severe punishment involving torture has been established.

sentences.latin: Galli se omnes ab Dite patre prognatos praedicant idque ab druidibus proditum dicunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Gauls themselves all from Dis father descended proclaim and that by the druids handed down they say.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Gauls themselves all from Dis father descended proclaim and that by the druids handed down they say.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Gauls all claim to be descended from Father Dis, and they say that this tradition has been handed down by the druids.

sentences.latin: Ob eam causam spatia omnis temporis non numero dierum sed noctium finiunt; dies natales et mensum et annorum initia sic observant ut noctem dies subsequatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For that cause the spaces of all time not by the number of days but of nights they limit; birthdays and of months and of years the beginnings thus they observe that the night the day follows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For that cause the spaces of all time not by the number of days but of nights they limit; birthdays and of months and of years the beginnings so they observe that the night the day follows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this reason, they measure all periods of time not by the number of days but by nights; they observe birthdays and the beginnings of months and years in such a way that the day follows the night.

sentences.latin: In reliquis vitae institutis hoc fere ab reliquis differunt, quod suos liberos, nisi cum adoleverunt, ut munus militiae sustinere possint, palam ad se adire non patiuntur filiumque puerili aetate in publico in conspectu patris adsistere turpe ducunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the remaining of life customs in this almost from the rest they differ, because their own children, unless when they have grown up, so that the duty of military service to sustain they are able, openly to themselves to approach not they allow and a son in boyish age in public in the sight of the father to stand disgraceful they consider.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the remaining of life customs in this almost from the rest they differ, because their own children, unless when they have grown up, so that the duty of military service to sustain they are able, openly to them to approach not they allow and a son in boyish age in public in the sight of the father to stand shameful they consider.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In other customs of life, they differ from almost all other people in this: they do not allow their children to approach them openly until they have grown up enough to perform military service, and they consider it disgraceful for a son of boyish age to stand in public in his father's sight.

sentences.latin: Viri, quantas pecunias ab uxoribus dotis nomine acceperunt, tantas ex suis bonis aestimatione facta cum dotibus communicant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Men, how much money from wives in of dowry name they have received, so much from their own goods an estimation having been made with the dowries they communicate.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Men, how much money from wives in the name of dowry they have received, so much from their own goods an estimation having been made with the dowries they join.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Whatever amount of money men receive from their wives as a dowry, they contribute an equal amount from their own property after an appraisal has been made.

sentences.latin: Huius omnis pecuniae coniunctim ratio habetur fructusque servantur: uter eorum vita superarit, ad eum pars utriusque cum fructibus superiorum temporum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this all money jointly an account is held and the profits are saved: which of them in life shall have survived, to him the part of both with the profits of the previous times comes.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this all money jointly an account is held and the profits are saved: which of them in life shall have survived, to him the part of both with the profits of the previous times comes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A joint account is kept of all this money and the profits are saved; whichever of them survives the other, the share of both, along with the profits of previous years, goes to that person.

sentences.latin: Viri in uxores, sicuti in liberos, vitae necisque habent potestatem; et cum paterfamiliae illustriore loco natus decessit, eius propinqui conveniunt et, de morte si res in suspicionem venit, de uxoribus in servilem modum quaestionem habent et, si compertum est, igni atque omnibus tormentis excruciatas interficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Men over wives, just as over children, of life and of death have power; and when a father of a family in a more illustrious place born has died, his relatives assemble and, concerning the death if the matter into suspicion comes, concerning the wives in a slave-like manner an inquiry they hold and, if it has been discovered, by fire and all tortures having been tortured they kill [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Men over wives, just as over children, of life and of death have power; and when the father of the family in a more distinguished place born has died, his relatives assemble and, concerning the death if the matter into suspicion comes, concerning the wives in a slave-like manner an inquiry they hold and, if it has been discovered, by fire and all tortures having been tortured they kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Husbands have the power of life and death over their wives, just as they do over their children; and when a father of a family born of noble rank dies, his relatives assemble, and if the circumstances of his death are suspicious, they conduct an inquiry into the wives in the manner of slaves; if guilt is discovered, they put them to death, tortured by fire and every kind of torment.

sentences.latin: Funera sunt pro cultu Gallorum magnifica et sumptuosa; omniaque quae vivis cordi fuisse arbitrantur in ignem inferunt, etiam animalia, ac paulo supra hanc memoriam servi et clientes, quos ab eis dilectos esse constabat, iustis funeribus confectis una cremabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Funerals are for the culture of the Gauls magnificent and sumptuous; and all things which to the living to the heart to have been they think into the fire they carry, even animals, and a little before this memory slaves and clients, whom by them loved to have been it was established, just funeral rites having been completed together were burned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Funerals are for the culture of the Gauls magnificent and sumptuous; and all things which to the living to the heart to have been they think into the fire they bring, even animals, and a little before this memory slaves and clients, whom by them loved to have been it was established, just funerals having been finished together were burned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gallic funerals are magnificent and costly considering their culture; they cast into the fire everything they believe was dear to the living, including animals, and until recently, slaves and dependents known to have been loved by them were burned together with them once the proper funeral rites were completed.

sentences.latin: Quae civitates commodius suam rem publicam administrare existimantur, habent legibus sanctum, si quis quid de re publica a finitimis rumore aut fama acceperit, uti ad magistratum deferat neve cum quo alio communicet,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which states more advantageously their own republic to administer are thought, have by laws ordained, if anyone anything about the republic from neighbors by rumor or report shall have received, that to the magistrate he report nor with anyone else communicate,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which states more conveniently their own public matter to administer are thought, have by laws ordained, if anyone anything about the public matter from neighbors by rumor or report has received, that to the magistrate he report and not with any other communicate,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those states which are considered to manage their public affairs more efficiently have a legal ordinance that if anyone hears any news concerning the state from neighbors by rumor or report, he must report it to a magistrate and not share it with anyone else.

sentences.latin: quod saepe homines temerarios atque imperitos falsis rumoribus terreri et ad facinus impelli et de summis rebus consilium capere cognitum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because often men rash and inexperienced by false rumors to be terrified and to crime to be impelled and about highest matters a plan to take it has been learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because often men reckless and inexperienced by false rumors to be terrified and to a crime to be driven and about highest matters a plan to take it has been learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because it is well known that rash and inexperienced men are often terrified by false rumors, driven to crime, and make decisions on matters of the highest importance.

sentences.latin: Magistratus quae visa sunt occultant quaeque esse ex usu iudicaverunt multitudini produnt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The magistrates what things seen have been they hide and what things to be of use they have judged to the multitude they reveal.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The magistrates what things seen are hide and what things to be of use they have judged to the multitude they bring forth.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The magistrates conceal what they see fit and reveal to the common people what they judge to be useful.

sentences.latin: De re publica nisi per concilium loqui non conceditur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: About the republic except through a council to speak not it is permitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: About the public matter except through a council to speak not it is permitted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It is not permitted to speak about public affairs except through a formal assembly.

sentences.latin: Germani multum ab hac consuetudine differunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Germans much from this custom differ.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Germans much from this custom differ.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Germans differ greatly from this custom.

sentences.latin: Nam neque druides habent, qui rebus divinis praesint, neque sacrificiis student.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For neither druids they have, who over things divine may preside, nor to sacrifices they are devoted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For neither druids they have, who over matters divine preside, nor to sacrifices they are devoted.
