sentences.naturalTranslation: For they have no druids to preside over divine matters, nor do they practice sacrifices.

sentences.latin: Deorum numero eos solos ducunt, quos cernunt et quorum aperte opibus iuvantur, Solem et Vulcanum et Lunam, reliquos ne fama quidem acceperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the gods' number those alone they lead, whom they see and by whose openly powers they are helped, the Sun and Vulcan and the Moon, the rest not even by report they have received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In of the gods number those alone they lead, whom they perceive and by whose openly powers they are helped, the Sun and Vulcan and the Moon, the rest not even by report they have received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They rank as gods only those whom they can see and by whose power they are clearly aidedthe Sun, Vulcan, and the Moon; they have not even heard of the others by report.

sentences.latin: Vita omnis in venationibus atque in studiis rei militaris consistit: ab parvulis labori ac duritiae student.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Life all in huntings and in pursuits of thing military consists: from little ones to labor and to hardship they are devoted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Life all in huntings and in studies of matter military consists: from small ones to labor and hardship they are devoted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their whole life consists of hunting and military pursuits; from childhood, they devote themselves to labor and hardship.

sentences.latin: Qui diutissime impuberes permanserunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who longest chaste have remained,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who longest immature have remained,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who have remained chaste for the longest time,

sentences.latin: maximam inter suos ferunt laudem: hoc ali staturam, ali vires nervosque confirmari putant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Greatest among their own they bear praise: by this to be nourished stature, to be nourished strengths and sinews to be strengthened they think.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: greatest among their own they bring praise: by this to be nourished stature, by this strengths and sinews to be strengthened they think.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They receive the highest praise among their people for this: they believe that by this practice their stature is increased, and their strength and muscles are toughened.

sentences.latin: Intra annum vero vicesimum feminae notitiam habuisse in turpissimis habent rebus; cuius rei nulla est occultatio, quod et promiscue in fluminibus perluuntur et pellibus aut parvis renonum tegimentis utuntur magna corporis parte nuda.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Within year indeed twentieth of woman knowledge to have had among most shameful they hold things; of which thing no is concealment, because both promiscuously in rivers they are washed and skins or small of reindeer-skins coverings they use great of body part naked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Within year indeed twentieth of a woman knowledge to have had in most shameful they have matters; of which matter no is concealment, because both promiscuously in rivers they are washed and in skins or small of reindeer-skins coverings they use great of body part naked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Indeed, they consider it a most disgraceful matter to have had knowledge of a woman before the twentieth year; there is no concealment of this fact, because they bathe together in the rivers and use skins or small coverings of reindeer-hide, leaving a large part of the body bare.

sentences.latin: Agriculturae non student, maiorque pars eorum victus in lacte, caseo, carne consistit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To agriculture not they are eager, and greater part of their food in milk, cheese, meat consists.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To agriculture not they are devoted, and greater part of their food in milk, cheese, meat consists.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They do not devote themselves to agriculture, and the greater part of their diet consists of milk, cheese, and meat.

sentences.latin: Neque quisquam agri modum certum aut fines habet proprios; sed magistratus ac principes in annos singulos gentibus cognationibusque hominum, qui una coierunt, quantum et quo loco visum est agri attribuunt atque anno post alio transire cogunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor anyone of land measure fixed or boundaries has own; but magistrates and chiefs for years single to tribes and kinships of men, who together have come, how much and in what place it has seemed of land they assign and year after to another to cross they compel.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor anyone of land measure certain or boundaries has own; but magistrates and leaders into years single to tribes and kinships of men, who together have come, how much and in what place seen is of land they assign and a year after to another to cross they compel.
sentences.naturalTranslation: No one possesses a fixed amount of land or private boundaries; instead, the magistrates and leading men assign to the tribes and families of men who have joined together as much land as they see fit and in whatever location, and a year later they compel them to move elsewhere.

sentences.latin: Eius rei multas adferunt causas: ne adsidua consuetudine capti studium belli gerendi agricultura commutent; ne latos fines parare studeant, potentioresque humiliores possessionibus expellant; ne accuratius ad frigora atque aestus vitandos aedificent; ne qua oriatur pecuniae cupiditas, qua ex re factiones dissensionesque nascuntur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this thing many they bring forward causes: lest by constant habit captured zeal of war waging with agriculture they exchange; lest broad boundaries to acquire they be eager, and more powerful more humble from possessions expel; lest more carefully to colds and heats avoiding they build; lest any may arise of money desire, from which thing factions and dissensions are born;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this matter many they bring causes: lest by persistent custom captured study of war waging by agriculture they exchange; lest wide boundaries to prepare they study, and more powerful the humbler from possessions expel; lest more accurately to colds and heats avoiding they build; lest any should arise of money desire, from which matter factions and dissensions are born;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They offer many reasons for this practice: so that they are not captivated by long-standing habit and exchange their zeal for waging war for agriculture; so that they do not strive to acquire broad territories and the more powerful drive the humbler from their possessions; so that they do not build too carefully to avoid cold and heat; so that no desire for money arises, from which factions and dissensions are born;

sentences.latin: ut animi aequitate plebem contineant, cum suas quisque opes cum potentissimis aequari videat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that by of mind equality common people they may restrain, when his own each wealth with most powerful to be equaled he sees.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that in mind equity the common people they contain, when his own each resources with the most powerful to be equaled he sees.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and so that they may keep the common people in check by contentment of mind, since each man sees his own wealth equal to that of the most powerful.

sentences.latin: Civitatibus maxima laus est quam latissime circum se vastatis finibus solitudines habere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To states greatest praise is as most widely around themselves devastated boundaries solitudes to have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To states greatest praise is as widest around themselves devastated boundaries solitudes to have.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the states, the greatest glory is to have the widest possible wilderness around them, with their borders laid waste.

sentences.latin: Hoc proprium virtutis existimant, expulsos agris finitimos cedere, neque quemquam prope audere consistere:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This characteristic of virtue they think, expelled from lands neighbors to withdraw, nor anyone near to dare to halt:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This proper of virtue they think, driven out from lands neighbors to yield, nor anyone near to dare to stand:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They consider it a mark of valor that their neighbors, driven from their lands, withdraw, and that no one dares to settle near them.

sentences.latin: simul hoc se fore tutiores arbitrantur repentinae incursionis timore sublato.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at the same time by this themselves to be about to be safer they judge of sudden incursion fear having been removed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at the same time by this themselves to be will be safer they think of sudden incursion fear having been removed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, they believe they will be safer because the fear of a sudden invasion has been removed.

sentences.latin: Cum bellum civitas aut inlatum defendit aut infert, magistratus, qui ei bello praesint, ut vitae necisque habeant potestatem, deliguntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When war state either brought against it defends or brings against, magistrates, who over that war may be in charge, so that of life and of death they may have power, are chosen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When war a state either brought in defends or brings in, magistrates, who over that war preside, so that of life and of death they have power, are chosen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When a state either wards off a war waged against it or launches one, magistrates are chosen to preside over that war with the power of life and death.

sentences.latin: In pace nullus est communis magistratus, sed principes regionum atque pagorum inter suos ius dicunt controversiasque minuunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In peace no is common magistrate, but leaders of regions and of districts among their own law say and controversies diminish.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In peace no is common magistrate, but leaders of regions and of districts among their own [people] law say and controversies diminish.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In times of peace, there is no central magistrate; instead, the leading men of the regions and districts administer justice and settle disputes among their own people.

sentences.latin: Latrocinia nullam habent infamiam, quae extra fines cuiusque civitatis fiunt, atque ea iuventutis exercendae ac desidiae minuendae causa fieri praedicant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Robberies no have infamy, which outside borders of each state happen, and those of youth exercising and of idleness diminishing for the sake to happen they declare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Robberies no have infamy, which outside borders of each state happen, and those of youth exercising and of idleness diminishing for the sake to happen they declare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Acts of robbery committed outside the borders of each state carry no disgrace; they claim that these are done to train the youth and reduce idleness.

sentences.latin: Atque ubi quis ex principibus in concilio dixit se ducem fore, qui sequi velint, profiteantur, consurgunt ei qui et causam et hominem probant suumque auxilium pollicentur atque ab multitudine collaudantur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: And when anyone from the leaders in council has said himself leader will be, who to follow wish, let them declare, rise up those who both the cause and the man approve and their own help promise and by the multitude are praised:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And when anyone from the leaders in council has said himself leader will be, who to follow wish, let them declare, rise up those who both cause and man approve and their own help promise and by the multitude are praised:
sentences.naturalTranslation: And when any of the leaders has declared in council that he will be a leader and calls for volunteers, those who approve of both the cause and the man stand up, promise their assistance, and are cheered by the crowd:

sentences.latin: qui ex his secuti non sunt, in desertorum ac proditorum numero ducuntur, omniumque his rerum postea fides derogatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who from these followed not have, in of deserters and of traitors number are led, and of all to these things afterwards trust is withdrawn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who from these followed not have, in of deserters and of traitors number are led, and of all to these things afterwards trust is withdrawn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those among them who do not follow are considered deserters and traitors, and thereafter all trust is withdrawn from them in all matters.

sentences.latin: Hospitem violare fas non putant; qui quacumque de causa ad eos venerunt, ab iniuria prohibent, sanctos habent, hisque omnium domus patent victusque communicatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A guest to violate right not they think; who for whatever from cause to them have come, from injury they prohibit, sacred they hold, and to these of all the houses lie open and food is shared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Guest to violate right not they think; who for whatever from cause to them have come, from injury they prohibit, sacred they hold, and to these of all houses lie open and food is shared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They consider it a crime to harm a guest; whoever comes to them for any reason, they protect from injury and regard as sacred, and the homes of all are open to them and food is shared.

sentences.latin: Ac fuit antea tempus, cum Germanos Galli virtute superarent, ultro bella inferrent, propter hominum multitudinem agrique inopiam trans Rhenum colonias mitterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And there was before a time, when Germans Gauls in valor surpassed, voluntarily wars brought in, on account of of men multitude and of land scarcity across the Rhine colonies sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And there was before a time, when Germans Gauls in valor surpassed, voluntarily wars brought in, on account of of men multitude and of land scarcity across Rhine colonies sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was once a time when the Gauls surpassed the Germans in valor, waged war on them of their own accord, and sent colonies across the Rhine because of their large population and lack of land.

sentences.latin: Itaque ea quae fertilissima Germaniae sunt loca circum Hercyniam silvam, quam Eratostheni et quibusdam Graecis fama notam esse video, quam illi Orcyniam appellant, Volcae Tectosages occupaverunt atque ibi consederunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so those which most fertile of Germany are places around the Hercynian forest, which to Eratosthenes and certain Greeks by report known to be I see, which those Orcynia call, the Volcae Tectosages occupied and there settled;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore those which most fertile of Germany are places around Hercynian forest, which to Eratosthenes and certain Greeks by report known to be I see, which those Orcynia call, Volcae Tectosages occupied and there settled;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, the Volcae Tectosages seized and settled in those parts of Germany which are most fertile, near the Hercynian forestwhich I see was known by report to Eratosthenes and certain other Greeks, who called it Orcynia.

sentences.latin: quae gens ad hoc tempus his sedibus sese continet summamque habet iustitiae et bellicae laudis opinionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which nation to this time in these seats itself contains and highest has of justice and of warlike praise reputation.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which nation to this time in these seats itself contains and highest has of justice and of warlike praise reputation.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This nation remains in these settlements to this day and enjoys a very high reputation for justice and military fame.

sentences.latin: Nunc quod in eadem inopia, egestate, patientia qua Germani permanent, eodem victu et cultu corporis utuntur; Gallis autem provinciarum propinquitas et transmarinarum rerum notitia multa ad copiam atque usus largitur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Now because in the same scarcity, poverty, endurance in which Germans remain, the same food and care of body they use; to the Gauls however of provinces proximity and of overseas things knowledge many to abundance and uses supplies,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Now because in same scarcity, poverty, endurance in which Germans remain, same food and culture of body they use; to Gauls however of provinces proximity and of overseas things knowledge many [things] to abundance and uses supplies,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Now, because they persist in the same state of scarcity, poverty, and endurance as the Germans, they use the same food and dress; however, for the Gauls, the proximity of the provinces and knowledge of overseas commodities provides many things for luxury and daily use.

sentences.latin: paulatim adsuefacti superari multisque victi proeliis ne se quidem ipsi cum illis virtute comparant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: gradually accustomed to be surpassed and by many conquered battles not themselves even they with them in valor compare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: gradually accustomed to be overcome and by many conquered battles not themselves even they with those in valor compare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having gradually become accustomed to being defeated and having been conquered in many battles, they do not even compare themselves with the Germans in valor.

sentences.latin: Huius Hercyniae silvae, quae supra demonstrata est, latitudo novem dierum iter expedito patet: non enim aliter finiri potest, neque mensuras itinerum noverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this Hercynian forest, which above has been shown, the width of nine days' journey for an unencumbered traveler extends: not for otherwise to be bounded it is able, nor measurements of journeys they have known.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this Hercynian forest, which above shown has been, width of nine days journey for an unencumbered [traveler] extends: not for otherwise to be bounded it can, nor measures of journeys they have known.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The width of this Hercynian forest, which was mentioned above, extends for a nine-day journey for an unencumbered traveler; for it cannot be measured in any other way, and the inhabitants do not know the standard measurements of journeys.

sentences.latin: Oritur ab Helvetiorum et Nemetum et Rauracorum finibus rectaque fluminis Danubi regione pertinet ad fines Dacorum et Anartium;
sentences.referenceTranslation: It rises from of the Helvetii and Nemetes and Rauraci territories and in a straight of the river Danube direction it reaches to the territories of the Daci and Anartes;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It rises from of Helvetii and of Nemetes and of Rauraci borders and in straight of river Danube region reaches to borders of Daci and of Anartes;
sentences.naturalTranslation: It begins at the borders of the Helvetii, Nemetes, and Rauraci, and runs in a straight line along the Danube to the territories of the Dacians and Anartes;

sentences.latin: hinc se flectit sinistrorsus diversis ab flumine regionibus multarumque gentium fines propter magnitudinem adtingit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: from here itself it turns leftwards in different from the river directions and of many nations the borders on account of its size it touches;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from here itself it turns leftwards in different from river regions and of many nations borders on account of size it touches;
sentences.naturalTranslation: from there it turns leftward away from the river and, because of its vast size, touches the borders of many nations;

sentences.latin: neque quisquam est huius Germaniae, qui se aut adisse ad initium eius silvae dicat, cum dierum iter LX processerit, aut, quo ex loco oriatur, acceperit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor anyone is of this Germany, who himself either to have approached to the beginning of that forest says, although of days journey 60 he has proceeded, or, from what place it rises, has heard.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor anyone is of this Germany, who himself either to have gone to beginning of that forest says, when of days journey 60 he has proceeded, or, from what place it rises, has heard.
sentences.naturalTranslation: there is no one in this part of Germany who can claim to have reached the beginning of that forest, even after traveling for sixty days, or who has heard where it begins.

sentences.latin: Multaque in ea genera ferarum nasci constat, quae reliquis in locis visa non sint; ex quibus quae maxime differant ab ceteris et memoriae prodenda videantur haec sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And many in it kinds of wild beasts to be born it is agreed, which in remaining places seen not have been; from which those which most differ from the others and to memory to be handed down seem these are.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And many in it kinds of wild beasts to be born it is certain, which in remaining in places seen not have been; from which those which most differ from others and to memory to be handed down seem these are.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It is well known that many kinds of wild animals live there which are not seen in other places; of these, the ones that differ most from others and seem worthy of record are as follows.

sentences.latin: Est bos cervi figura, cuius a media fronte inter aures unum cornu exsistit excelsius magisque directum his, quae nobis nota sunt, cornibus: ab eius summo sicut palmae ramique late diffunduntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There is an ox of a stag's shape, of which from the middle forehead between the ears one horn stands out taller and more straight than these, which to us known are, horns: from its top just as palms and branches widely are spread out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There is an ox of a stag shape, of which from middle forehead between ears one horn stands out taller and more straight than these, which to us known are, horns: from its top just as palms and branches widely are spread.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There is an ox shaped like a stag, from the middle of whose forehead between the ears a single horn grows, taller and straighter than the horns known to us; from its top, branches spread out like the palms of hands.

sentences.latin: Eadem est feminae marisque natura, eadem forma magnitudoque cornuum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The same is of the female and of the male the nature, the same the shape and the size of the horns.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Same is of female and of male nature, same form and size of horns.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The nature of the female and the male is the same, as are the shape and size of their horns.

sentences.latin: Sunt item, quae appellantur alces.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There are likewise, those which are called elks.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There are likewise, which are called elks.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There are also animals called elks.

sentences.latin: Harum est consimilis capris figura et varietas pellium, sed magnitudine paulo antecedunt mutilaeque sunt cornibus et crura sine nodis articulisque habent
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of these is very similar to goats the shape and the variety of skins, but in size a little they surpass and mutilated they are in horns and legs without knots and joints they have
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these is very like to goats shape and variety of skins, but in size a little they go before and mutilated are in horns and legs without knots and joints they have
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their shape and dappled skins are very similar to goats, but they are slightly larger, have blunt horns, and their legs are without knots or joints.

sentences.latin: neque quietis causa procumbunt neque, si quo adflictae casu conciderunt, erigere sese aut sublevare possunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: neither for the sake of rest they lie down nor, if by any chance afflicted they have fallen down, to raise themselves or to lift up they are able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor of rest for the sake they lie down nor, if by any afflicted chance they have fallen, to raise themselves or to lift up they are able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They do not lie down to rest, and if they happen to fall by some accident, they are unable to stand up or lift themselves.

sentences.latin: His sunt arbores pro cubilibus: ad eas se applicant atque ita paulum modo reclinatae quietem capiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these are trees for beds: to them themselves they apply and so a little only reclined rest they take.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these there are trees for beds: to them themselves they apply and thus a little only reclined rest they take.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These trees serve as their beds; they lean against them and, reclining only slightly, take their rest.

sentences.latin: Quarum ex vestigiis cum est animadversum a venatoribus, quo se recipere consuerint, omnes eo loco aut ab radicibus subruunt aut accidunt arbores, tantum ut summa species earum stantium relinquatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which from tracks when it has been noticed by hunters, where themselves to withdraw they have been accustomed, all in that place either from roots they undermine or cut into trees, only so that the top appearance of them standing is left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of which from the tracks when it has been noticed by hunters, where themselves to betake they have been accustomed, all in that place either from the roots they undermine or cut into the trees, so much that the highest appearance of them standing is left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When hunters have discovered from their tracks where they are accustomed to retreat, they either undermine all the trees at the roots in that place or cut into them, just enough so that the appearance of them standing is maintained.

sentences.latin: Huc cum se consuetudine reclinaverunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hither when themselves by custom they have reclined,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hither when themselves by custom they have reclined,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they have leaned against these according to their habit,

sentences.latin: infirmas arbores pondere adfligunt atque una ipsae concidunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the weak trees by weight they knock down and together themselves they fall down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the weak trees by weight they knock down and together themselves they fall down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they knock down the weakened trees with their weight and fall down along with them.

sentences.latin: Tertium est genus eorum, qui uri appellantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Third is the kind of those, who urus are called.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Third is the kind of those, who aurochs are called.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There is a third kind of animal, which are called urus.

sentences.latin: Hi sunt magnitudine paulo infra elephantos, specie et colore et figura tauri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These are in size a little below elephants, in appearance and color and shape of a bull.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These are in size a little below elephants, in appearance and color and shape of a bull.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These are slightly smaller than elephants in size, but have the appearance, color, and shape of a bull.

sentences.latin: Magna vis eorum est et magna velocitas, neque homini neque ferae quam conspexerunt parcunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Great force of them is and great speed, neither man nor wild beast which they have caught sight of do they spare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Great strength of them is and great speed, nor to man nor to wild beast which they have caught sight of do they spare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their strength and speed are great, and they spare neither man nor beast that they have sighted.

sentences.latin: Hos studiose foveis captos interficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These eagerly in pits captured they kill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These eagerly in pits captured they kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The locals zealously kill these after catching them in pits.

sentences.latin: Hoc se labore durant adulescentes atque hoc genere venationis exercent, et qui plurimos ex his interfecerunt, relatis in publicum cornibus, quae sint testimonio, magnam ferunt laudem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this labor themselves they harden young men and by this kind of hunting they exercise, and who most from these have killed, brought back into public horns, which are for a testimony, great they carry praise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By this labor themselves they harden the young men and in this kind of hunting they exercise, and who the most from these have killed, brought back into public the horns, which may be for a testimony, great they bring praise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The young men harden themselves with this labor and train in this kind of hunting; those who have killed the most, having brought the horns into public view to serve as evidence, receive great praise.

sentences.latin: Sed adsuescere ad homines et mansuefieri ne parvuli quidem excepti possunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But to be accustomed to men and to be tamed not even very small taken they are able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But to become accustomed to men and to be tamed not even very small having been taken they are able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But they cannot be accustomed to men or tamed, even if caught when very young.

sentences.latin: Amplitudo cornuum et figura et species multum a nostrorum boum cornibus differt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The size of the horns and the shape and appearance much from of our oxen the horns differs.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The size of the horns and the shape and the appearance much from of our oxen the horns differs.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The size, shape, and appearance of their horns differ greatly from those of our oxen.

sentences.latin: Haec studiose conquisita ab labris argento circumcludunt atque in amplissimis epulis pro poculis utuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These eagerly sought after at the rims with silver they encircle and in most splendid feasts for cups they use.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These eagerly sought out at the lips with silver they encircle and in most magnificent banquets for cups they use.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They eagerly seek these out, encircle the rims with silver, and use them as drinking cups at their most magnificent feasts.

sentences.latin: Caesar, postquam per Vbios exploratores comperit Suebos sese in silvas recepisse, inopiam frumenti veritus, quod, ut supra demonstravimus, minime omnes Germani agriculturae student, constituit non progredi longius; sed,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, after through the Ubii scouts he found out the Suebi themselves into the woods had withdrawn, a lack of grain having feared, because, as above we have shown, very little all Germans to agriculture are devoted, decided not to proceed further; but,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, after through the Ubii scouts he found out the Suebi themselves into the forests had retreated, the lack of grain having feared, because, as above we have shown, very little all Germans to agriculture are devoted, decided not to proceed further; but,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After Caesar learned through Ubian scouts that the Suebi had retreated into the forests, fearing a shortage of grain becauseas we have previously mentionedthe Germans pay very little attention to agriculture, he decided not to advance any further; however,

sentences.latin: ne omnino metum reditus sui barbaris tolleret atque ut eorum auxilia tardaret, reducto exercitu partem ultimam pontis,
sentences.referenceTranslation: lest entirely the fear of return his from the barbarians he might take away and so that their reinforcements he might delay, having led back the army the part final of the bridge,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: lest altogether the fear of return of his own from the barbarians he might take away and so that their reinforcements he might delay, having led back the army the part last of the bridge,
sentences.naturalTranslation: so as not to entirely remove the fear of his return from the barbarians and to delay their reinforcements, he led back his army and ordered the far end of the bridge,

sentences.latin: quae ripas Vbiorum contingebat, in longitudinem pedum ducentorum rescindit atque in extremo ponte turrim tabulatorum quattuor constituit praesidiumque cohortium duodecim pontis tuendi causa ponit magnisque eum locum munitionibus firmat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which the banks of the Ubii was touching, for a length of feet two hundred he cuts down and on the end of the bridge a tower of stories four he established and a garrison of cohorts twelve of the bridge of guarding for the sake he places and with great that place fortifications he strengthens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which the banks of the Ubii was touching, into a length of feet two hundred he cuts down and on the end of the bridge a tower of stories four he established and a garrison of cohorts twelve of the bridge of protecting for the sake he places and with great that place fortifications he strengthens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: which touched the banks of the Ubii, to be broken down for a length of two hundred feet; at the end of the bridge, he built a four-story tower, stationed a garrison of twelve cohorts to protect the bridge, and strengthened the position with extensive fortifications.

sentences.latin: Ei loco praesidioque Gaium Volcatium Tullum adulescentem praefecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over that place and garrison Gaius Volcatius Tullus the young man he put in command.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Over that place and garrison Gaius Volcatius Tullus the young man he put in charge.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He placed the young Gaius Volcatius Tullus in command of that post and garrison.

sentences.latin: Ipse, cum maturescere frumenta inciperent, ad bellum Ambiorigis profectus per Arduennam silvam, quae est totius Galliae maxima atque ab ripis Rheni finibusque Treverorum ad Nervios pertinet milibusque amplius quingentis in longitudinem patet, Lucium Minucium Basilum cum omni equitatu praemittit, si quid celeritate itineris atque opportunitate temporis proficere possit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself, when to ripen the grain began, to the war of Ambiorix having set out through the Ardennes forest, which is of all Gaul the largest and from the banks of the Rhine and the borders of the Treveri to the Nervii extends and by miles more than five hundred in length lies open, Lucius Minucius Basilus with all the cavalry he sends ahead, if anything by speed of the march and by favorableness of the time he might be able to accomplish;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself, when to ripen the grain began, to the war of Ambiorix having set out through the Ardennes forest, which is of all Gaul the largest and from the banks of the Rhine and the borders of the Treveri to the Nervii extends and in miles more than five hundred in length lies open, Lucius Minucius Basilus with all the cavalry he sends ahead, if anything by speed of the journey and by opportunity of time he might be able to accomplish;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the grain began to ripen, he himself set out for the war against Ambiorix through the Ardennes forestwhich is the largest in all Gaul, extending from the banks of the Rhine and the borders of the Treveri to the Nervii, and stretching more than five hundred miles in lengthand sent Lucius Minucius Basilus ahead with all the cavalry to see if he could gain any advantage through a rapid march and a timely opportunity.

sentences.latin: monet, ut ignes in castris fieri prohibeat, ne qua eius adventus procul significatio fiat: sese confestim subsequi dicit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he warns, that fires in the camp to be made he should forbid, lest any of his arrival from afar a sign be made: himself immediately to follow he says.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he warns, that fires in the camp to be made he should forbid, lest any of his arrival from afar a sign be made: himself immediately to follow he says.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He warned him to forbid the lighting of fires in the camp, so that no sign of his arrival might be seen from a distance, and said that he himself would follow immediately.

sentences.latin: Basilus, ut imperatum est, facit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Basilus, as it was commanded, does.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Basilus, as it was commanded, does.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Basilus did as he was ordered.

sentences.latin: Celeriter contraque omnium opinionem confecto itinere multos in agris inopinantes deprehendit: eorum indicio ad ipsum Ambiorigem contendit, quo in loco cum paucis equitibus esse dicebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly and against of all the expectation having completed the march many in the fields unaware he catches: by their information to himself Ambiorix he hastens, in which place with a few horsemen to be he was said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly and against of all the expectation having completed the journey many in the fields unaware he catches: by their information to himself Ambiorix he hastens, in which place with a few horsemen to be he was said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having completed the march quickly and contrary to everyone's expectation, he surprised many people in the fields who were caught off guard; following their information, he hastened toward Ambiorix himself, to the place where he was reported to be with a few horsemen.

sentences.latin: Multum cum in omnibus rebus tum in re militari potest fortuna.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Much both in all things and then in matter military is able fortune.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Much both in all things and then in matter military is able fortune.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fortune has great power both in all affairs and especially in military matters.

sentences.latin: Namsicutmagno accidit casu ut in ipsum incautum etiam atque imparatum incideret, priusque eius adventus ab omnibus videretur, quam fama ac nuntius adferretur: sic magnae fuit fortunae omni militari instrumento, quod circum se habebat, erepto, raedis equisque comprehensis ipsum effugere mortem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For just as by great chance it happened that upon him unaware even and unprepared it fell, and sooner his arrival by all was seen, than rumor and messenger was brought: so of great it was fortune all military equipment, which around himself he was having, having been snatched away, carriages and horses having been seized, himself to escape death.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For just as it happened by great chance that upon him unaware even and unprepared he fell, and earlier his arrival by all was seen, than rumor and messenger was brought: so of great was fortune all military equipment, which around himself he had, having been snatched away, wagons and horses having been seized, himself to escape death.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For just as it happened by a great stroke of luck that he fell upon him while he was unaware and unprepared, and his arrival was seen by everyone before any rumor or messenger arrived, so it was a matter of great fortune that, although all his military equipment which he had with him was snatched away and his carriages and horses seized, he himself escaped death.

sentences.latin: Sed hoc quoque factum est,
sentences.referenceTranslation: But this also was done,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But this also was done,
sentences.naturalTranslation: But this also happened,

sentences.latin: quod aedificio circumdato silva, ut sunt fere domicilia Gallorum, qui vitandi aestus causa plerumque silvarum atque fluminum petunt propinquitates, comites familiaresque eius angusto in loco paulisper equitum nostrorum vim sustinuerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because the building having been surrounded by woods, as are generally the dwellings of the Gauls, who for the sake of avoiding heat mostly of woods and of rivers seek the proximities, the companions and friends of him in a narrow in place for a little while of our horsemen the force sustained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because the building having been surrounded by woods, as are generally dwellings of Gauls, who for the sake of avoiding heat mostly of woods and of rivers seek proximities, companions and friends of him in a narrow in place for a little while of our horsemen the force sustained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because the building was surrounded by woodsas are most dwellings of the Gauls, who generally seek the vicinity of woods and rivers to avoid the heathis companions and friends held off the attack of our cavalry for a short time in a narrow spot.

sentences.latin: His pugnantibus illum in equum quidam ex suis intulit: fugientem silvae texerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These fighting, him onto a horse someone from his own put: fleeing the woods covered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These fighting, him onto a horse a certain one from his own put: fleeing the woods covered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While they were fighting, one of his men placed him on a horse; the woods covered him as he fled.

sentences.latin: Sic et ad subeundum periculum et ad vitandum multum fortuna valuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus both for undergoing danger and for avoiding much fortune was strong.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus both for undergoing danger and for avoiding much fortune was strong.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus fortune played a major role both in his encountering the danger and in his escaping it.

sentences.latin: Ambiorix copias suas iudicione non conduxerit, quod proelio dimicandum non existimarit, an tempore exclusus et repentino equitum adventu prohibitus, cum reliquum exercitum subsequi crederet, dubium est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Ambiorix forces his whether by judgment not he brought together, because in battle it must be fought not he thought, or by time shut out and by the sudden of horsemen arrival prevented, when the rest of the army to follow he believed, doubtful it is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Ambiorix forces his whether by judgment not he brought together, because in battle it must be fought not he thought, or by time shut out and by sudden of horsemen arrival prohibited, when the rest of the army to follow he believed, doubtful is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It is doubtful whether Ambiorix did not assemble his forces by design, because he did not think he should fight a pitched battle, or whether he was prevented by lack of time and the sudden arrival of the cavalry, believing that the rest of the army was following close behind.

sentences.latin: Sed certe dimissis per agros nuntiis sibi quemque consulere iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But certainly having been sent through the fields messengers for himself each one to look out he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But certainly having been sent through the fields messengers for himself each one to look out he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But certainly, having sent messengers through the countryside, he ordered everyone to look out for themselves.

sentences.latin: Quorum pars in Arduennam silvam, pars in continentes paludes profugit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom a part into the Ardennes forest, a part into continuous marshes fled;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom a part into the Ardennes forest, a part into continuous marshes fled;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some of them fled into the Ardennes forest, others into the vast marshes;

sentences.latin: qui proximi Oceano fuerunt, his insulis sese occultaverunt, quas aestus efficere consuerunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: who nearest to the Ocean were, in those islands themselves they hid, which the tides to make are accustomed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who nearest to the Ocean were, in these islands themselves they hid, which the tides to make are accustomed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: those who were nearest to the Ocean hid themselves in the islands which the tides are accustomed to create;

sentences.latin: multi ex suis finibus egressi se suaque omnia alienissimis crediderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: many from their borders having departed themselves and their all to most complete strangers entrusted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: many from their own borders having departed themselves and their things all to complete strangers entrusted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Many, having left their own territories, entrusted themselves and all their possessions to total strangers.

sentences.latin: Catuvolcus, rex dimidiae partis Eburonum, qui una cum Ambiorige consilium inierat, aetate iam confectus, cum laborem aut belli aut fugae ferre non posset, omnibus precibus detestatus Ambiorigem, qui eius consilii auctor fuisset, taxo, cuius magna in Gallia Germaniaque copia est, se exanimavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Catuvolcus, king of a half part of the Eburones, who together with Ambiorix a plan had entered, by age now worn out, since the labor either of war or of flight bear he was not able, with all prayers having cursed Ambiorix, who of that plan the author had been, with yew, of which a great in Gaul and Germany supply is, himself he killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Catuvolcus, king of half part of the Eburones, who together with Ambiorix the plan had entered, by age now exhausted, since the labor either of war or of flight to bear not he was able, with all prayers having cursed Ambiorix, who of that plan the author had been, with yew, of which great in Gaul and Germany the supply is, himself he killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Catuvolcus, king of half the Eburones, who had entered into the conspiracy with Ambiorix, being now worn out by age and unable to endure the hardships of war or flight, cursed Ambiorix with every possible imprecation for being the instigator of the plot, and killed himself with yew, a tree which is very common in Gaul and Germany.

sentences.latin: Segni Condrusique, ex gente et numero Germanorum, qui sunt inter Eburones Treverosque, legatos ad Caesarem miserunt oratum, ne se in hostium numero duceret neve omnium Germanorum, qui essent citra Rhenum, unam esse causam iudicaret: nihil se de bello cogitavisse, nulla Ambiorigi auxilia misisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Segni and Condrusi, from the race and number of the Germans, who are between the Eburones and Treveri, ambassadors to Caesar sent to plead, that not themselves in the enemies' number he should lead nor of all Germans, who were on this side of the Rhine, one to be the cause he should judge: nothing themselves about war to have thought, no to Ambiorix reinforcements to have sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Segni and Condrusi, from the race and number of Germans, who are between the Eburones and Treveri, ambassadors to Caesar sent to plead, that not them in of enemies the number he should lead nor of all Germans, who were on this side of the Rhine, one to be the cause he should judge: nothing they about war had thought, no to Ambiorix reinforcements had sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Segni and Condrusi, of German stock and nation, who live between the Eburones and the Treveri, sent ambassadors to Caesar to plead that he should not count them as enemies nor judge the cause of all Germans on this side of the Rhine to be the same; they claimed they had not thought of war and had sent no reinforcements to Ambiorix.

sentences.latin: Caesar explorata re quaestione captivorum, si qui ad eos Eburones ex fuga convenissent, ad se ut reducerentur, imperavit; si ita fecissent, fines eorum se violaturum negavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar having investigated the matter by questioning of captives, if any to them Eburones from flight had come together, to himself that they should be brought back, he commanded; if so they had done, the borders of them himself to be about to violate he denied.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar having been explored the matter by questioning of captives, if any to them Eburones from flight had come, to himself that they be led back, he ordered; if so they had done, the borders of them he to violate denied.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After investigating the matter by questioning the prisoners, Caesar ordered that if any Eburones had fled to them, they should be brought back to him; if they did so, he promised not to violate their territory.

sentences.latin: Tum copiis in tres partes distributis impedimenta omnium legionum Aduatucam contulit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then the forces into three parts having been divided the baggage of all the legions to Aduatuca he brought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then the forces into three parts having been distributed the baggage of all legions to Aduatuca he brought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, having divided his forces into three parts, he brought the baggage of all the legions to Aduatuca.

sentences.latin: Id castelli nomen est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That of a fort the name is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That of a fort the name is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: That is the name of a fort.

sentences.latin: Hoc fere est in mediis Eburonum finibus, ubi Titurius atque Aurunculeius hiemandi causa consederant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This almost is in the middle of the Eburones' borders, ubi Titurius and Aurunculeius for the sake of wintering had settled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This almost is in the middle of the Eburones borders, where Titurius and Aurunculeius of wintering for the sake had settled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This is situated almost in the center of the Eburones' territory, where Titurius and Aurunculeius had established their winter quarters.

sentences.latin: Hunc cum reliquis rebus locum probabat, tum quod superioris anni munitiones integrae manebant, ut militum laborem sublevaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This since for other reasons the place he approved, then because of the previous year the fortifications intact remained, so that the soldiers' labor he might lighten.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This both for other things place he was approving, and then because of the previous year the fortifications intact were remaining, so that of the soldiers the labor he might lighten.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He approved of this location both for other reasons and because the fortifications of the previous year remained intact, which would lighten the labor of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Praesidio impedimentis legionem quartamdecimam reliquit, unam ex eis tribus, quas proxime conscriptas ex Italia traduxerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As a guard for the baggage the legion fourteenth he left, one from those three, which recently having been enrolled from Italy he had brought across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As a guard for the baggage the legion fourteenth he left, one from those three, which recently having been enrolled from Italy he had brought across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He left the fourteenth legion as a guard for the baggage, one of the three which he had recently enrolled and brought over from Italy.

sentences.latin: Ei legioni castrisque Quintum Tullium Ciceronem praeficit ducentosque equites attribuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Over that legion and camp Quintus Tullius Cicero he puts in command and two hundred horsemen he assigned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Over that legion and camp Quintus Tullius Cicero he puts in charge and two hundred horsemen he assigned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He placed Quintus Tullius Cicero in command of that legion and the camp, and assigned him two hundred cavalry.

sentences.latin: Partito exercitu Titum Labienum cum legionibus tribus ad Oceanum versus in eas partes quae Menapios attingunt proficisci iubet;
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the army having been divided, Titus Labienus with legions three toward the Ocean into those parts which the Menapii touch to set out he orders;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The army having been divided, Titus Labienus with legions three toward the Ocean into those parts which the Menapii touch to set out he orders;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having divided the army, he orders Titus Labienus to set out with three legions toward the Ocean, into the regions bordering the Menapii.

sentences.latin: Gaium Trebonium cum pari legionum numero ad eam regionem quae ad Aduatucos adiacet depopulandam mittit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Gaius Trebonius with an equal of legions number to that region which to the Aduatuci lies adjacent for the purpose of plundering he sends;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Gaius Trebonius with an equal of legions number to that region which to the Aduatuci lies near for the purpose of plundering he sends;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sends Gaius Trebonius with an equal number of legions to plunder the region adjacent to the Aduatuci.

sentences.latin: ipse cum reliquis tribus ad flumen Scaldem, quod influit in Mosam, extremasque Arduennae partis ire constituit, quo cum paucis equitibus profectum Ambiorigem audiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he himself with the remaining three to the river Scheldt, which flows into the Meuse, and the furthest of the Ardennes parts to go decided, whither with a few horsemen set out Ambiorix he was hearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he himself with the remaining three to the river Scheldt, which flows into the Meuse, and the furthest of the Ardennes parts to go decided, where with a few horsemen set out Ambiorix he was hearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself decided to go with the remaining three legions to the river Scheldt, which flows into the Meuse, and to the furthest reaches of the Ardennes, where he heard Ambiorix had gone with a few horsemen.

sentences.latin: Discedens post diem septimum sese reversurum confirmat; quam ad diem ei legioni quae in praesidio relinquebatur deberi frumentum sciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Departing after the day seventh himself about to return he confirms; by which day to that legion which in protection was being left to be owed grain he was knowing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Departing after the day seventh himself about to return he confirms; by which day to that legion which in protection was being left to be owed grain he was knowing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon departing, he promised to return after seven days; he knew that grain was due on that day to the legion left behind as a garrison.

sentences.latin: Labienum Treboniumque hortatur, si rei publicae commodo facere possint, ad eum diem revertantur, ut rursus communicato consilio exploratisque hostium rationibus aliud initium belli capere possint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus and Trebonius he exhorts, if for the republic's advantage to do they are able, by that day they should return, so that again with the plan shared and explored the enemies' methods another beginning of war to take they might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienum and Trebonius he encourages, if with the republic's advantage to do they are able, by that day they should return, so that again with the plan shared and having been explored the enemy's methods another beginning of war to take they might be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He urges Labienus and Trebonius to return by that day if they can do so without detriment to the state, so that after consulting together and investigating the enemy's tactics, they might begin a new phase of the war.

sentences.latin: Erat, ut supra demonstravimus, manus certa nulla, non oppidum, non praesidium, quod se armis defenderet, sed in omnes partes dispersa multitudo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was, as above we have shown, band fixed none, not a town, not a garrison, which itself with arms might defend, but into all parts a dispersed multitude.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was, as above we have shown, band certain none, not a town, not a garrison, which itself with arms might defend, but into all parts a dispersed multitude.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As we have shown above, there was no fixed force, no town, and no garrison to defend itself with arms, but a population scattered in every direction.

sentences.latin: Vbi cuique aut valles abdita aut locus silvestris aut palus impedita spem praesidi aut salutis aliquam offerebat, consederat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Where to each either a valley hidden or a place wooded or a swamp hindered hope of protection or of safety some was offering, he had settled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Where to each either a valley hidden or a place wooded or a marsh hindered hope of protection or safety some was offering, he had settled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Wherever a hidden valley, a wooded spot, or a difficult marsh offered anyone some hope of protection or safety, there he had taken refuge.

sentences.latin: Haec loca vicinitatibus erant nota, magnamque res diligentiam requirebat non in summa exercitus tuenda (nullum enim poterat universisaperterritis ac dispersis periculum accidere), sed in singulis militibus conservandis; quae tamen ex parte res ad salutem exercitus pertinebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These places to the neighborhoods were known, and a great the matter diligence was requiring not in the whole of the army to be protected (no for was able to the whole terrified and dispersed danger to happen), but in individual soldiers to be preserved; which however from a part matter to the safety of the army was pertaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These places to the neighborhoods were known, and a great care the matter was requiring not in the whole of the army to be protected (for no could to the whole terrified and dispersed danger happen), but in individual soldiers to be preserved; which however from a part matter to the safety of the army was pertaining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These places were known to the local inhabitants, and the situation required great care, not in protecting the army as a whole (for no danger could happen to the entire force while the enemy was terrified and scattered), but in keeping individual soldiers safe; yet this concern, in part, affected the safety of the entire army.

sentences.latin: Nam et praedae cupiditas multos longius evocabat, et silvae incertis occultisque itineribus confertos adire prohibebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For both of booty desire many further was calling out, and the woods with uncertain and hidden paths in a mass to go were prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For both of booty desire many further was calling out, and the woods with uncertain and hidden paths in a mass to go prohibited.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the desire for plunder lured many quite far, and the woods, with their uncertain and hidden paths, prevented them from advancing in a compact body.

sentences.latin: Si negotium confici stirpemque hominum sceleratorum interfici vellet, dimittendae plures manus diducendique erant milites;
sentences.referenceTranslation: If the business to be finished and the race of men wicked to be killed he was wishing, to be sent out more bands and to be drawn apart were the soldiers;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If the business to be finished and the race of men wicked to be killed he was wishing, to be sent out more bands and to be led apart were the soldiers;
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he wished the business to be finished and the race of these wicked men to be exterminated, more bands of men had to be sent out and the soldiers had to be separated.

sentences.latin: si continere ad signa manipulos vellet, ut instituta ratio et consuetudo exercitus Romani postulabat, locus ipse erat praesidio barbaris, neque ex occulto insidiandi et dispersos circumveniendi singulis deerat audacia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If to keep at the standards the maniples he wished, as the established method and custom of the army Roman was demanding, the place itself was for a protection to the barbarians, nor from hidden [places] of ambushing and the scattered of surrounding to individuals was lacking boldness.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if to keep at the standards the maniples he was wishing, as the established method and custom of the army Roman was demanding, the place itself was for a protection to the barbarians, nor from hidden of ambushing and the dispersed of surrounding to individuals was lacking boldness.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he wished to keep the maniples at their standards, as the established method and custom of the Roman army required, the terrain itself protected the barbarians, and individuals did not lack the boldness to ambush from cover and surround scattered soldiers.

sentences.latin: Vt in eiusmodi difficultatibus, quantum diligentia provideri poterat providebatur, ut potius in nocendo aliquid praetermitteretur, etsi omnium animi ad ulciscendum ardebant, quam cum aliquo militum detrimento noceretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: As in of this kind difficulties, as much as by diligence to be provided for it was able it was provided for, so that rather in harming something might be passed over, although of all the minds for avenging were burning, than with some of the soldiers loss it might be harmed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As in of this kind difficulties, as much as by care to be provided for was able it was being provided for, so that rather in harming something might be passed over, although of all the minds for avenging were burning, than with some of soldiers loss it might be harmed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Considering the difficulties, as much care as possible was taken so that an opportunity to inflict damage might be passed overeven though everyone was eager for revengerather than harming the enemy at the cost of losing soldiers.

sentences.latin: Dimittit ad finitimas civitates nuntios Caesar: omnes ad se vocat spe praedae ad diripiendos Eburones, ut potius in silvis Gallorum vita quam legionarius miles periclitetur, simul ut magna multitudine circumfusa pro tali facinore stirps ac nomen civitatis tollatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He sends out to the neighboring states messengers Caesar: all to himself he calls by hope of booty for the purpose of plundering the Eburones, so that rather in the woods of the Gauls the life than the legionary soldier might be endangered, at the same time so that by a great multitude poured around for such a crime the stock and name of the state might be destroyed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He sends out to the neighboring states messengers Caesar: all to himself he calls by hope of booty for plundering the Eburones, so that rather in the woods of Gauls the life than the legionary soldier might be endangered, at the same time so that by a great multitude poured around for such a crime the race and name of the state might be destroyed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar sent messengers to the neighboring states, inviting everyone to join him in plundering the Eburones with the hope of booty. His goal was to risk the lives of Gauls in the woods rather than his legionary soldiers, and simultaneously to wipe out the race and name of that state for such a crime by surrounding them with a vast multitude.

sentences.latin: Magnus undique numerus celeriter convenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A large from all sides number quickly assembles.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great from all sides number quickly assembles.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A large number quickly assembled from all sides.

sentences.latin: Haec in omnibus Eburonum partibus gerebantur, diesque appetebat septimus, quem ad diem Caesar ad impedimenta legionemque reverti constituerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things in all of the Eburones parts were being done, and the day was approaching seventh, which to day Caesar to the baggage and the legion to return had decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things in all of the Eburones parts were being carried on, and the day was approaching seventh, by which day Caesar to the baggage and the legion to return had decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These operations were being carried out in all parts of the Eburones' territory, and the seventh day was approaching, the day on which Caesar had decided to return to the baggage and the legion.

sentences.latin: Hic quantum in bello fortuna possit et quantos adferat casus cognosci potuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Here how much in war fortune is able and how great it brings chances to be known it was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Here how much in war fortune is able and how great she brings chances to be known was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Here it could be seen how much power fortune has in war and what great accidents it brings about.

sentences.latin: Dissipatis ac perterritis hostibus, ut demonstravimus, manus erat nulla quae parvam modo causam timoris adferret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been scattered and terrified the enemies, as we have shown, a band was none which a small only cause of fear might bring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been scattered and terrified the enemies, as we have shown, band there was none which a small only cause of fear might bring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the enemy were scattered and terrified, as we have shown, there was no organized body that could cause even a slight reason for fear.

sentences.latin: Trans Rhenum ad Germanos pervenit fama, diripi Eburones atque ultro omnes ad praedam evocari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Across the Rhine to the Germans reached the rumor, to be plundered the Eburones and furthermore all to the booty to be called out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Across the Rhine to the Germans reached the rumor, to be plundered the Eburones and furthermore all to the booty to be called out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Across the Rhine, word reached the Germans that the Eburones were being plundered and that everyone was being invited to share in the booty.

sentences.latin: Cogunt equitum duo milia Sugambri, qui sunt proximi Rheno, a quibus receptos ex fuga Tencteros atque Vsipetes supra docuimus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They collect of horsemen two thousand the Sugambri, who are nearest to the Rhine, by whom received from flight the Tencteri and Usipetes above we have taught.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They collect of horsemen two thousand the Sugambri, who are nearest to the Rhine, by whom received from flight the Tencteri and Usipetes above we have taught.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Sugambri, who live nearest to the Rhine and who, as we mentioned above, received the Tencteri and Usipetes after their flight, collected two thousand horsemen.

sentences.latin: Transeunt Rhenum navibus ratibusque triginta milibus passuum infra eum locum, ubi pons erat perfectus praesidiumque ab Caesare relictum: primos Eburonum fines adeunt; multos ex fuga dispersos excipiunt, magno pecoris numero, cuius sunt cupidissimi barbari, potiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They cross the Rhine by ships and rafts thirty thousands of paces below that place, where the bridge had been completed and a guard by Caesar left: first of the Eburones borders they approach; many from flight scattered they pick up, a large of cattle number, of which are most desirous the barbarians, they get possession of.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They cross the Rhine by ships and rafts thirty of thousands of paces below that place, where the bridge had been completed and a garrison by Caesar left: first the Eburones' borders they approach; many from flight dispersed they catch, a great of cattle number, of which are most desirous the barbarians, they get possession of.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They crossed the Rhine in ships and rafts thirty miles below the place where the bridge had been built and a guard left by Caesar. They entered the borders of the Eburones first, captured many people scattered in flight, and took possession of a large number of cattle, for which barbarians are most greedy.

sentences.latin: Invitati praeda longius procedunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Invited by booty farther they proceed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Invited by booty farther they proceed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Lured by the prospect of plunder, they advanced further.

sentences.latin: Non hos palus in bello latrociniisque natos, non silvae morantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not these [men] a marsh in war and robberies born, not forests delay.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not these a marsh in war and robberies born, not forests delay.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Neither marshes nor forests delayed these men, who were born to war and banditry.

sentences.latin: Quibus in locis sit Caesar ex captivis quaerunt; profectum longius reperiunt omnemque exercitum discessisse cognoscunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which places might be Caesar from prisoners they ask; set out farther they find and all the army to have departed they learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which places might be Caesar from prisoners they ask; set out farther they find and all the army to have departed they learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They asked the prisoners where Caesar was; they discovered he had set out further away and learned that the entire army had departed.

sentences.latin: Atque unus ex captivis "Quid vos," inquit, "hanc miseram ac tenuem sectamini praedam, quibus licet iam esse fortunatissimos?
sentences.referenceTranslation: And one from the prisoners 'Why you,' he said, 'this wretched and thin follow booty, for whom it is permitted now to be most fortunate?'
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And one from the prisoners "Why you," he said, "this wretched and thin follow booty, for whom it is permitted now to be most fortunate?"
sentences.naturalTranslation: And one of the prisoners said, 'Why do you pursue such wretched and meager booty, when you now have the chance to be most wealthy?'

sentences.latin: Tribus horis Aduatucam venire potestis: huc omnes suas fortunas exercitus Romanorum contulit: praesidi tantum est, ut ne murus quidem cingi possit, neque quisquam egredi extra munitiones audeat."
sentences.referenceTranslation: In three hours to Aduatuca to come you are able: hither all their fortunes the army of the Romans brought: of guard so much there is, that not even the wall indeed to be manned is able, nor anyone to go out outside the fortifications dares.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In three hours to Aduatuca to come you are able: to here all their fortunes the army of the Romans brought: of protection so much there is, that not even the wall to be manned is able, nor anyone to go out outside the fortifications dares.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In three hours you can reach Aduatuca; here the Roman army has brought all its wealth. There is so little of a garrison that the wall cannot even be manned, and no one dares to step outside the fortifications.

sentences.latin: Oblata spe Germani quam nacti erant praedam in occulto relinquunt; ipsi Aduatucam contendunt usi eodem duce, cuius haec indicio cognoverant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Offered hope the Germans which they had obtained booty in a hidden [place] leave; themselves to Aduatuca they hasten having used the same guide, by whose information these [things] they had learned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Offered hope the Germans which they had obtained booty in secret leave; themselves to Aduatuca hasten having used the same leader, by whose information these things they had learned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With this hope offered, the Germans hid the booty they had already seized and hastened to Aduatuca, using the same guide whose information had provided these facts.

sentences.latin: Cicero, qui omnes superiores dies praeceptis Caesaris cum summa diligentia milites in castris continuisset ac ne calonem quidem quemquam extra munitionem egredi passus esset, septimo die diffidens de numero dierum Caesarem fidem servaturum, quod longius progressum audiebat, neque ulla de reditu eius fama adferebatur, simul eorum permotus vocibus,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cicero, who all previous days by instructions of Caesar with highest diligence the soldiers in camp had kept and not even a camp-servant indeed anyone outside the fortification to go out had allowed, on the seventh day distrusting about the number of days Caesar his word would keep, because farther advanced he was hearing, nor any about return of him report was brought, at the same time moved by their voices,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cicero, who all previous days by the instructions of Caesar with highest diligence the soldiers in camp had kept and not even a camp-follower indeed any outside the fortification to go out had allowed, on the seventh day distrusting concerning the number of days Caesar his word would keep, because farther advanced he was hearing, nor any concerning the return of him rumor was brought, at the same time of them moved by the voices,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Cicero, who for all the preceding days had kept his soldiers in camp with the greatest care according to Caesar's instructions and had not allowed even a single camp-servant to step outside the fortifications, began to doubt on the seventh day whether Caesar would keep his word regarding the number of days, as he heard he had advanced further and no news of his return was arriving; at the same time, he was influenced by the remarks of his men,

sentences.latin: qui illius patientiam paene obsessionem appellabant, siquidem ex castris egredi non liceret, nullum eiusmodi casum exspectans, quo novem oppositis legionibus maximoque equitatu dispersis ac paene deletis hostibus in milibus passuum tribus offendi posset, quinque cohortes frumentatum in proximas segetes mittit, quas inter et castra unus omnino collis intererat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who his patience almost a siege were calling, if indeed from camp to go out it was not permitted, no of this kind accident expecting, by which nine opposed legions and greatest cavalry scattered and almost destroyed enemies in miles of paces three to be harmed it could, five cohorts to forage into the nearest grain-fields he sends, which between and the camp one altogether hill was between.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who his patience almost a siege were calling, if indeed from the camp to go out it was not permitted, no of this kind accident expecting, by which nine opposed legions and greatest cavalry dispersed and almost destroyed enemies in miles of paces three to be harmed it could, five cohorts to forage into the nearest grain-fields he sends, which between and the camp one altogether hill was between.
sentences.naturalTranslation: who called his patience almost a siege since they were not allowed to leave the camp. Expecting no such accident by which he could be harmed within three miles while nine legions and a massive cavalry force were opposed to a scattered and nearly destroyed enemy, he sent five cohorts to forage in the nearest grain fields, between which and the camp only a single hill intervened.

sentences.latin: Complures erant ex legionibus aegri relicti;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several were from the legions sick left behind;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Several were from the legions sick left behind;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Several men from the legions had been left behind sick;

sentences.latin: ex quibus qui hoc spatio dierum convaluerant, circiter CCC, sub vexillo una mittuntur; magna praeterea multitudo calonum, magna vis iumentorum, quae in castris subsederant, facta potestate sequitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from whom those who in this space of days had recovered, about 300, under a banner together are sent; a great besides multitude of camp-servants, a great force of pack-animals, which in camp had remained, having been made permission follows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from whom who in this space of days had recovered, about 300, under a banner together are sent; a large besides multitude of camp-followers, a large force of pack-animals, which in the camp had remained, made the opportunity follows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: of these, about three hundred who had recovered during this time were sent out together under a separate banner; in addition, a large number of camp-servants and a great many pack-animals that had remained in the camp followed once permission was granted.

sentences.latin: Hoc ipso tempore et casu Germani equites interveniunt protinusque eodem illo, quo venerant, cursu ab decumana porta in castra irrumpere conantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: At this very time and by chance German horsemen intervene and immediately by that same, in which they had come, speed from the decuman gate into the camp to break in they attempt,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At this very time and chance German horsemen arrive and immediately by that same, in which they had come, speed from the decuman gate into the camp to burst in they try,
sentences.naturalTranslation: At this very moment, by chance, German cavalry arrived and immediately attempted to break into the camp through the rear gate at the same speed with which they had come.

sentences.latin: nec prius sunt visi obiectis ab ea parte silvis, quam castris appropinquarent, usque eo ut qui sub vallo tenderent mercatores recipiendi sui facultatem non haberent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor sooner were they seen, with woods having been placed in the way from that part, than to the camp they were approaching, even to that point that those who under the rampart were stretching traders of recovering themselves the opportunity did not have.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor before they were seen placed in the way from that part by woods, than to the camp they were approaching, even to that point that who under the rampart were staying traders of recovering themselves the opportunity not they had.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because the woods blocked the view from that direction, they were not seen until they were close to the camp; indeed, the traders who were camped under the rampart had no opportunity to retreat inside.

sentences.latin: Inopinantes nostri re nova perturbantur, ac vix primum impetum cohors in statione sustinet.
