sentences.referenceTranslation: Unaware our men by the new thing are disturbed, and scarcely the first attack the cohort on guard sustains.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not expecting our men by the new thing are disturbed, and scarcely the first attack the cohort on guard sustains.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Taken by surprise, our men were thrown into confusion by the unexpected event, and the cohort on guard duty could barely withstand the first charge.

sentences.latin: Circumfunduntur ex reliquis hostes partibus, si quem aditum reperire possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They are poured around from the remaining parts the enemies, if any entrance to find they might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They are poured around from the remaining the enemies parts, if any approach to find they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy swarmed around the other sides to see if they could find any way in.

sentences.latin: Aegre portas nostri tuentur, reliquos aditus locus ipse per se munitioque defendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With difficulty the gates our men protect, the remaining entrances the place itself by itself and the fortification defends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With difficulty the gates our men defend, the remaining approaches the place itself by itself and the fortification defends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men defended the gates with difficulty, while the terrain itself and the fortifications protected the other points of entry.

sentences.latin: Totis trepidatur castris, atque alius ex alio causam tumultus quaerit; neque quo signa ferantur neque quam in partem quisque conveniat provident.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the whole it is trembled camp, and one from another the cause of the tumult asks; neither where the standards should be carried nor into which part each one should assemble do they foresee.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the whole it is trembled camp, and one from another the cause of the tumult asks; neither where the standards should be carried nor into which part each should assemble they foresee.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Panic spread throughout the camp, and men asked one another the cause of the uproar; they did not know where to advance the standards or where each man should assemble.

sentences.latin: Alius iam castra capta pronuntiat, alius deleto exercitu atque imperatore victores barbaros venisse contendit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: One now the camp captured announces, another with the army destroyed and the commander the victorious barbarians to have come maintains;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One now the camp captured announces, another the army destroyed and the commander the victorious barbarians to have come maintains;
sentences.naturalTranslation: One man declared that the camp had already been captured; another maintained that the army and commander had been destroyed and the victorious barbarians had arrived.

sentences.latin: plerique novas sibi ex loco religiones fingunt Cottaeque et Tituri calamitatem, qui in eodem occiderint castello, ante oculos ponunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: most new for themselves from the place superstitions imagine and of Cotta and Titurius the disaster, who in the same had fallen fort, before their eyes they place.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: most new for themselves from the place religious fears imagine and of Cotta and Titurius the disaster, who in the same had fallen fort, before their eyes they place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Most of them, influenced by the location, imagined new superstitious fears and called to mind the disaster of Cotta and Titurius, who had fallen in that same fort.

sentences.latin: Tali timore omnibus perterritis confirmatur opinio barbaris, ut ex captivo audierant, nullum esse intus praesidium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By such fear all having been terrified, is confirmed the opinion for the barbarians, as from a captive they had heard, that no was inside garrison.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By such fear all thoroughly terrified is confirmed the opinion for the barbarians, as from the prisoner they had heard, no to be inside garrison.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since everyone was terrified by such fear, the barbarians were convinced of the report they had heard from a prisoner: that there was no garrison inside.

sentences.latin: perrumpere nituntur seque ipsi adhortantur, ne tantam fortunam ex manibus dimittant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to break through they strive and themselves they themselves encourage, lest so great fortune from hands they let go.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to break through they strive and themselves they themselves encourage, lest so great a fortune from their hands they let go.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They strove to break through and encouraged one another not to let such a great opportunity slip through their hands.

sentences.latin: Erat aeger cum praesidio relictus Publius Sextius Baculus, qui primum pilum ad Caesarem duxerat, cuius mentionem superioribus proeliis fecimus, ac diem iam quintum cibo caruerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was sick with the garrison left Publius Sextius Baculus, who the first rank under Caesar had led, of whom mention in previous battles we made, and for the day now fifth from food had lacked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was sick with the guard left Publius Sextius Baculus, who the first century to Caesar had led, of whom mention in previous battles we made, and day now fifth from food had lacked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Publius Sextius Baculus, who had served as a chief centurion under Caesar and whom we have mentioned in previous battles, had been left behind sick with the garrison and had now gone five days without food.

sentences.latin: Hic diffisus suae atque omnium saluti inermis ex tabernaculo prodit: videt imminere hostes atque in summo esse rem discrimine: capit arma a proximis atque in porta consistit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man, despairing of his own and of all safety, unarmed from the tent comes forth: he sees to be imminent the enemies and in the highest to be the matter crisis: he takes arms from the nearest [men] and in the gate stands:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This man, despairing of his own and of all safety, unarmed from the tent comes forth: he sees to be imminent the enemies and in the highest to be the matter crisis: he takes arms from the nearest and in the gate stands:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Despairing of his own safety and that of everyone else, he emerged unarmed from his tent. Seeing that the enemy were close at hand and the situation was in the utmost peril, he seized weapons from those nearby and took his stand in the gateway.

sentences.latin: consequuntur hunc centuriones eius cohortis quae in statione erat: paulisper una proelium sustinent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: follow him the centurions of that cohort which on guard was: for a little while together the battle they sustain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: follow him the centurions of that cohort which on guard was: for a little while together the battle they sustain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The centurions of the cohort on guard duty followed him, and together they held off the attack for a short time.

sentences.latin: Relinquit animus Sextium gravibus acceptis vulneribus: aegre per manus tractus servatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Leaves the spirit Sextius, heavy having been received wounds: with difficulty by hands dragged he is saved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Leaves consciousness Sextius, heavy having been received wounds: with difficulty by hands dragged he is saved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Sextius fainted after receiving severe wounds; he was saved only by being dragged away by hand with great difficulty.

sentences.latin: Hoc spatio interposito reliqui sese confirmant tantum, ut in munitionibus consistere audeant speciemque defensorum praebeant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This space having been put between, the rest themselves encourage so much, that in the fortifications to stand they dare and the appearance of defenders they show.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This space having been interposed, the rest themselves encourage so much, that in the fortifications to stand they dare and the appearance of defenders they show.
sentences.naturalTranslation: During this interval, the rest of the men recovered their spirits enough to dare to take their stand on the fortifications and present the appearance of a defending force.

sentences.latin: Interim confecta frumentatione milites nostri clamorem exaudiunt: praecurrunt equites; quanto res sit in periculo cognoscunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile, finished the foraging, soldiers our the shouting hear: run ahead the horsemen; in how much the matter is in danger they learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile, finished the foraging, soldiers our the shout hear: run ahead the horsemen; in how much the matter is in danger they learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, having finished their foraging, our soldiers heard the shouting. The cavalry rode ahead and discovered how dangerous the situation was.

sentences.latin: Hic vero nulla munitio est quae perterritos recipiat: modo conscripti atque usus militaris imperiti ad tribunum militum centurionesque ora convertunt; quid ab his praecipiatur exspectant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Here indeed no fortification is which the terrified [men] might receive: lately enrolled and of use military unskilled to the tribune of soldiers and centurions [their] faces they turn; what by these is commanded they wait for.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Here indeed no fortification is which the terrified might receive: lately enrolled and of use military unskilled to the tribune of soldiers and centurions faces they turn; what by these is commanded they wait for.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Here, however, there was no fortification to receive the terrified men. Being raw recruits and unskilled in military practice, they turned their faces toward the military tribune and the centurions, waiting for orders.

sentences.latin: Nemo est tam fortis quin rei novitate perturbetur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: No one is so brave but that by the matter's novelty he is disturbed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: No one is so brave but that by the matter's novelty he is disturbed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: No one is so brave that he is not unsettled by the unexpectedness of the situation.

sentences.latin: Barbari signa procul conspicati oppugnatione desistunt:
sentences.referenceTranslation: The barbarians the standards from afar having caught sight of, from the assault desist:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The barbarians the standards far off having caught sight of from the attack desist:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Catching sight of the standards in the distance, the barbarians abandoned the assault.

sentences.latin: redisse primo legiones credunt, quas longius discessisse ex captivis cognoverant; postea despecta paucitate ex omnibus partibus impetum faciunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to have returned at first the legions they believe, which further to have departed from prisoners they had learned; afterwards, despised the small number, from all parts an attack they make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to have returned at first the legions they believe, which further to have departed from captives they had learned; afterwards, despised the small number, from all parts an attack they make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first they believed the legions had returned, which they had learned from prisoners had gone further away; later, despising the small number of our men, they launched an attack from all sides.

sentences.latin: Calones in proximum tumulum procurrunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The camp-servants onto the nearest hill run forward.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The camp-servants onto the nearest hill run forward.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The camp servants ran forward to the nearest hill.

sentences.latin: Hinc celeriter deiecti se in signa manipulosque coniciunt: eo magis timidos perterrent milites.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From here quickly driven down themselves into the standards and maniples they throw: by this more the fearful they terrify soldiers.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From here quickly driven down, themselves into the standards and maniples they throw: by that more the timid they frighten soldiers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Quickly driven from there, they threw themselves into the standards and maniples; this terrified the already fearful soldiers even more.

sentences.latin: Alii cuneo facto ut celeriter perrumpant censent, quoniam tam propinqua sint castra, et si pars aliqua circumventa ceciderit, at reliquos servari posse confidunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Some, a wedge having been made, that quickly they might break through think, since so near are the camps, and if part some surrounded should fall, yet the rest to be saved to be able they trust;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Some, a wedge having been made, that quickly they break through propose, since so near are the camps, and if part some surrounded shall have fallen, yet the rest to be saved to be able they trust;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some thought that by forming a wedge they could quickly break through, since the camp was so near; they were confident that even if some were surrounded and fell, the rest could still be saved.

sentences.latin: alii, ut in iugo consistant atque eundem omnes ferant casum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: others, that on the ridge they should stand and the same all should bear fate.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: others, that on the ridge they stand and the same all bear chance.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Others thought they should take a stand on the ridge and all share the same fate.

sentences.latin: Hoc veteres non probant milites, quos sub vexillo una profectos docuimus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This the veteran not approve soldiers, whom under the banner together having set out we have shown.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This the veteran not approve soldiers, whom under the banner together having set out we have shown.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The veteran soldiers, who we mentioned had set out together under their own banner, did not approve of this.

sentences.latin: Itaque inter se cohortati duce Gaio Trebonio, equite Romano, qui eis erat praepositus, per medios hostes perrumpunt incolumesque ad unum omnes in castra perveniunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so among themselves having encouraged, with leader Gaius Trebonius, a knight Roman, who over them had been placed, through the middle of the enemies they break through and safe to a man all into the camp they arrive.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so among themselves having encouraged, leader Gaius Trebonius, knight Roman, who over them had been put in charge, through the middle of the enemies they break through and safe to one all into the camp they arrive.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And so, after encouraging one another, led by Gaius Trebonius, a Roman knight who had been placed in command of them, they broke through the middle of the enemy and all arrived safely in camp to a man.

sentences.latin: Hos subsecuti calones equitesque eodem impetu militum virtute servantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having followed, the camp-servants and horsemen by the same onset by the soldiers' valor are saved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having followed, the camp-servants and horsemen by the same charge by the soldiers' valor are saved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The camp servants and cavalry followed them and were saved by the same charge and the courage of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: At ei qui in iugo constiterant, nullo etiam nunc usu rei militaris percepto neque in eo quod probaverant consilio permanere, ut se loco superiore defenderent, neque eam quam prodesse aliis vim celeritatemque viderant imitari potuerunt, sed se in castra recipere conati iniquum in locum demiserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But those who on the ridge had stood, with no even now experience of thing military gained, neither in that which they had approved plan to remain, that themselves in place higher they might defend, nor that which to be of use to others force and speed they had seen to imitate were able, but themselves into camp to retreat having tried, into an unfavorable into place they descended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But those who on the ridge had stood, no even now experience of matter military having been gained, neither in that which they had approved plan to remain, that themselves in place higher they might defend, nor that which to be of use to others force and speed they had seen to imitate were able, but themselves into the camp to retreat having tried, into an unfavorable into place they descended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But those who had taken a stand on the ridge, still having gained no military experience, were neither able to stick to the plan they had decided onto defend themselves from the higher groundnor could they imitate the force and speed they had seen benefit the others; instead, in an attempt to retreat to the camp, they descended into unfavorable ground.

sentences.latin: Centuriones, quorum nonnulli ex inferioribus ordinibus reliquarum legionum virtutis causa in superiores erant ordines huius legionis traducti, ne ante partam rei militaris laudem amitterent, fortissime pugnantes conciderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The centurions, of whom some from lower ranks of the remaining legions for sake of valor into higher had been ranks of this legion transferred, lest before-acquired of thing military glory they should lose, most bravely fighting fell.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The centurions, of whom some from lower ranks of the remaining legions for valor's sake into higher had been ranks of this legion transferred, lest before-won of matter military glory they might lose, most bravely fighting fell.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The centurions, some of whom had been promoted from the lower ranks of other legions to higher ranks in this legion because of their courage, fought most bravely and fell, so as not to lose the military glory they had previously earned.

sentences.latin: Militum pars horum virtute summotis hostibus praeter spem incolumis in castra pervenit, pars a barbaris circumventa periit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the soldiers a part, by these men's valor having been driven back the enemies, beyond hope safe into camp arrived, a part by the barbarians surrounded perished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the soldiers a part, by these men's valor driven back the enemies, beyond hope safe into the camp arrived, a part by the barbarians surrounded perished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some of the soldiers, the enemy having been driven back by the courage of these men, reached the camp safely against all hope; the rest were surrounded by the barbarians and killed.

sentences.latin: Germani desperata expugnatione castrorum, quod nostros iam constitisse in munitionibus videbant, cum ea praeda quam in silvis deposuerant trans Rhenum sese receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Germans, the storming of the camp having been despaired of, because they were seeing our [men] now to have taken a stand in the fortifications, with that booty which in the woods they had deposited, across the Rhine themselves they betook.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Germans, the storming of the camp having been despaired of, because they saw our men already to have taken a stand in the fortifications, with that booty which in the woods they had deposited, across the Rhine themselves withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Despairing of storming the camp because they saw that our men had already taken their positions on the fortifications, the Germans retreated across the Rhine with the booty they had hidden in the woods.

sentences.latin: Ac tantus fuit etiam post discessum hostium terror ut ea nocte, cum Gaius Volusenus missus cum equitatu ad castra venisset, fidem non faceret adesse cum incolumi Caesarem exercitu.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so great was even after the departure of the enemies the terror that on that night, when Gaius Volusenus having been sent with the cavalry to the camp had come, he did not make belief to be present with an unharmed Caesar army.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so great was even after the departure of the enemies the terror that on that night, when Gaius Volusenus having been sent with the cavalry to the camp had come, he did not make faith that to be present with a safe Caesar army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Even after the enemy's departure, the terror was so great that when Gaius Volusenus arrived at the camp with the cavalry that night, he could not convince them that Caesar was approaching with his army intact.

sentences.latin: Sic omnino animos timor praeoccupaverat ut paene alienata mente deletis omnibus copiis equitatum se ex fuga recepisse dicerent neque incolumi exercitu Germanos castra oppugnaturos fuisse contenderent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus entirely their minds fear had preoccupied that almost with an alienated mind, all forces having been destroyed, the cavalry themselves from flight to have recovered they were saying, nor with an unharmed army the Germans the camp to have been about to attack they were contending.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus entirely their minds fear had preoccupied that almost with an alienated mind, all forces having been destroyed, the cavalry themselves from flight to have recovered they said, nor with a safe army the Germans the camp to have been about to attack they contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Fear had so completely seized their minds that, almost out of their wits, they claimed that the cavalry had escaped from a total slaughter of the forces and maintained that the Germans would never have attacked the camp if the army were safe.

sentences.latin: Quem timorem Caesaris adventus sustulit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which fear Caesar's arrival removed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which fear Caesar's arrival removed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar's arrival dispelled this fear.

sentences.latin: Reversus ille eventus belli non ignorans unum, quod cohortes ex statione et praesidio essent emissae, questus ne minimo quidem casu locum relinqui debuisse, multum fortunam in repentino hostium adventu potuisse iudicavit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having returned, he, the events of the war not being ignorant of, one thing, because the cohorts from their station and guard had been sent out, having complained that not even for the smallest chance a place to be left ought to have been, much fortune in the sudden of the enemies arrival to have been able he judged,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having returned, he, the events of the war not being ignorant of, one thing, that the cohorts from their post and guard had been sent out, having complained that not even for the smallest chance a place to be left ought to have been, much fortune in the sudden of the enemies arrival to have been able he judged,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon his return, being well aware of the turns of war, Caesar complained of only one thing: that the cohorts had been sent away from their posts and guard duty, noting that not even the slightest opening should have been left to chance; he judged that fortune had played a major role in the enemy's sudden arrival,

sentences.latin: multo etiam amplius, quod paene ab ipso vallo portisque castrorum barbaros avertisset. quarum omnium rerum maxime admirandum videbatur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: by much even more, because almost from the very rampart and gates of the camp the barbarians it had turned away. Of which all things most to be wondered at it was seeming,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by much even more, because almost from the very rampart and gates of the camp the barbarians it had turned away. Of which all things most to be wondered at it seemed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: and even more so because it had turned the barbarians back from the very rampart and gates of the camp. Of all these events, the most remarkable seemed to be

sentences.latin: quod Germani, qui eo consilio Rhenum transierant, ut Ambiorigis fines depopularentur, ad castra Romanorum delati optatissimum Ambiorigi beneficium obtulerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that the Germans, who with that plan the Rhine had crossed, so that Ambiorix's territories they might plunder, to the camp of the Romans having been brought, a most desired to Ambiorix benefit they offered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that the Germans, who with that plan the Rhine had crossed, so that Ambiorix's borders they might plunder, to the camp of the Romans having been brought, a most desired to Ambiorix benefit offered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the Germans, who had crossed the Rhine with the intention of plundering the territory of Ambiorix, were instead drawn to the Roman camp and thus rendered Ambiorix a most welcome service.

sentences.latin: Caesar rursus ad vexandos hostes profectus magno coacto numero ex finitimis civitatibus in omnes partes dimittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar again to harassing the enemies having set out, a large having been collected number from the neighboring states, into all parts he sends [them] out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar again to harassing the enemies having set out, a large having been collected number from the neighboring states into all parts he sends out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, setting out once more to harass the enemy, collected a large number of men from the neighboring states and dispatched them in every direction.

sentences.latin: Omnes vici atque omnia aedificia quae quisque conspexerat incendebantur; praeda ex omnibus locis agebatur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: All villages and all buildings which each one had caught sight of were being burned; booty from all places was being driven;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All villages and all buildings which each one had seen were being burned; booty from all places was being driven;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Every village and every building that anyone caught sight of was set on fire; plunder was driven off from every quarter.

sentences.latin: frumenta non solum tanta multitudine iumentorum atque hominum consumebantur, sed etiam anni tempore atque imbribus procubuerant ut, si qui etiam in praesentia se occultassent, tamen his deducto exercitu rerum omnium inopia pereundum videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the grain not only by so great a multitude of beasts and of men was being consumed, but also by the time of year and by rains had been beaten down so that, if any even in the present themselves had hidden, yet for these, the army having been withdrawn, by of all things a lack to be perished it was seeming.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the grain not only by so great a multitude of pack animals and men was being consumed, but also by the time of year and by rains had fallen down so that, if any even for the present themselves had hidden, yet for these, the army having been led away, by of all things want to be perished it seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The grain was not only being consumed by such a vast number of pack animals and men, but it had also been beaten down by the season and the rains, so that even if any of the enemy had hidden themselves for the time being, it seemed they would surely perish from a total lack of supplies once the army was withdrawn.

sentences.latin: Ac saepe in eum locum ventum est tanto in omnes partes diviso equitatu, ut modo visum ab se Ambiorigem in fuga circumspicerent captivi nec plane etiam abisse ex conspectu contenderent, ut spe consequendi illata atque infinito labore suscepto,
sentences.referenceTranslation: And often into that place it was come with so great into all parts divided cavalry, that just now seen by themselves Ambiorix in flight would look around for the captives nor clearly even to have gone away from sight would they maintain, so that with hope of overtaking brought in and infinite labor undertaken,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And often into that place it was come, with so great into all parts divided cavalry, that just now seen by themselves Ambiorix in flight looked around the captives, nor clearly even to have gone away from sight they contended, so that with hope of overtaking brought in and infinite labor undertaken,
sentences.naturalTranslation: And they often reached a point where, with the cavalry spread so widely in all directions, the captives would look around and claim they had just seen Ambiorix in flight, insisting he had not yet quite vanished from sight; thus, with the hope of catching him inspired and immense effort expended,

sentences.latin: qui se summam ab Caesare gratiam inituros putarent, paene naturam studio vincerent, semperque paulum ad summam felicitatem defuisse videretur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: who themselves highest from Caesar favor to be about to enter thought, almost nature by zeal they conquered, and always a little to the highest success to have been lacking it seemed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who themselves the highest from Caesar gratitude to enter upon thought, almost nature by zeal they conquered, and always a little to the highest success to have been lacking it seemed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: those who thought they would gain the highest favor from Caesar almost surpassed human nature in their zeal, and it always seemed that they fell just a little short of complete success,

sentences.latin: atque ille latebris aut saltibus se eriperet et noctu occultatus alias regiones partesque peteret non maiore equitum praesidio quam quattuor, quibus solis vitam suam committere audebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and he by hiding-places or glades himself snatched away and by night hidden other regions and parts sought not with greater of horsemen escort than four, to whom alone life his own to commit he was daring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and he by hiding places or glades himself snatched away and by night hidden other regions and parts sought with no greater of horsemen guard than four, to whom alone his life to commit he dared.
sentences.naturalTranslation: while he escaped into hiding places or thickets and, concealed by night, sought other regions and districts with an escort of no more than four horsemen, to whom alone he dared entrust his life.

sentences.latin: Tali modo vastatis regionibus exercitum Caesar duarum cohortium damno Durocortorum Remorum reducit concilioque in eum locum Galliae indicto de coniuratione Senonum et Carnutum quaestionem habere instituit et de Accone, qui princeps eius consili fuerat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In such manner devastated the regions the army Caesar of two cohorts with loss to Durocortorum of the Remi leads back and a council into that place of Gaul having been appointed concerning the conspiracy of the Senones and Carnutes an inquiry to have he decided and concerning Acco, who leader of that plan had been,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In such a manner the regions having been devastated, the army Caesar with of two cohorts loss to Durocortorum of the Remi leads back, and a council into that place of Gaul having been called, concerning the conspiracy of the Senones and Carnutes an inquiry to have he decided, and concerning Acco, who the leader of that plan had been,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having devastated the regions in this manner, Caesar led the army back to Durocortorum of the Remi with the loss of two cohorts; having appointed a council of Gaul at that place, he decided to hold an inquiry into the conspiracy of the Senones and Carnutes and regarding Acco, who had been the leader of that plot.

sentences.latin: graviore sententia pronuntiata more maiorum supplicium sumpsit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: a more heavy sentence having been pronounced by the custom of the ancestors punishment he took.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a more severe sentence having been pronounced, in the manner of the ancestors punishment he took.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After a severe sentence was pronounced, he executed him according to the custom of their ancestors.

sentences.latin: Non nulli iudicium veriti profugerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not some the judgment having feared fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not some the judgment having feared fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some, fearing the judgment, fled.

sentences.latin: Quibus cum aqua atque igni interdixisset, duas legiones ad fines Treverorum, duas in Lingonibus, sex reliquas in Senonum finibus Agedinci in hibernis collocavit frumentoque exercitui proviso, ut instituerat, in Italiam ad conventus agendos profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From whom when from water and fire he had forbidden, two legions at the borders of the Treveri, two among the Lingones, six remaining in of the Senones borders at Agedincum in winter quarters he placed and grain for the army provided, as he had established, into Italy to the assemblies to be held he set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To whom when from water and fire he had forbidden, two legions at the borders of the Treveri, two among the Lingones, six remaining in the Senones' borders at Agedincum in winter quarters he placed, and grain for the army having been provided, as he had established, into Italy to the assemblies to be held he set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had banned these from fire and water, he stationed two legions at the borders of the Treveri, two among the Lingones, and the remaining six at Agedincum in the territory of the Senones for winter quarters; then, having provided grain for the army, he set out for Italy to hold the assemblies, as he had planned.

sentences.latin: Quieta Gallia Caesar, ut constituerat, in Italiam ad conventus agendos proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quiet Gaul Caesar, as he had decided, into Italy to the assemblies to be held sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Gaul being quiet, Caesar, as he had decided, into Italy to the assemblies to be held sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaul being quiet, Caesar set out for Italy to hold the assemblies, as he had intended.

sentences.latin: Ibi cognoscit de Clodii caede [de] senatusque consulto certior factus, ut omnes iuniores Italiae coniurarent, delectum tota provincia habere instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There he learns about of Clodius the murder and of the senate's decree more certain made, that all younger men of Italy should take the oath, a levy in the whole province to have he decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There he learns about Clodius's murder, and of the senate's decree having been made more certain, that all the younger men of Italy should take the oath, a levy in the whole province to have he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There he learned of the murder of Clodius, and having been informed of the senate's decree that all the youth of Italy should take the military oath, he decided to hold a levy throughout the whole province.

sentences.latin: Eae res in Galliam Transalpinam celeriter perferuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things into Gaul Transalpine quickly are carried.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things into Transalpine Gaul quickly are carried.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These events were quickly reported in Transalpine Gaul.

sentences.latin: Addunt ipsi et adfingunt rumoribus Galli, quod res poscere videbatur, retineri urbano motu Caesarem neque in tantis dissensionibus ad exercitum venire posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They add themselves and invent to rumors the Gauls, because the matter to demand was seeming, to be held back by the city disturbance Caesar and not in so great dissensions to the army to come to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They add themselves and invent to the rumors, the Gauls, because the matter to demand seemed, to be held back by the city disturbance Caesar and not in such great dissensions to the army to come to be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Gauls themselves added to and invented rumors, as the situation seemed to require, that Caesar was being detained by the disturbances in the city and could not reach his army amidst such great dissensions.

sentences.latin: Hac impulsi occasione, qui iam ante se populi Romani imperio subiectos dolerent liberius atque audacius de bello consilia inire incipiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this impelled opportunity, who already before themselves to the Roman people's power subjected were grieving, more freely and more boldly about war plans to enter they begin.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By this driven opportunity, who already before themselves to the Roman people's power subjected grieved, more freely and more boldly about war plans to enter they begin.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Impelled by this opportunity, those who already previously grieved that they were subjected to the rule of the Roman people began to form plans for war more freely and more boldly.

sentences.latin: Indictis inter se principes Galliae conciliis silvestribus ac remotis locis queruntur de Acconis morte;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been proclaimed among themselves the leaders of Gaul councils in wooded and remote places they complain about Acco's death;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been proclaimed among themselves the leaders of Gaul councils in wooded and remote places they complain about Acco's death;
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the leaders of Gaul had appointed councils among themselves in wooded and remote places, they complained about the death of Acco;

sentences.latin: posse hunc casum ad ipsos recidere demonstrant: miserantur communem Galliae fortunam: omnibus pollicitationibus ac praemiis deposcunt qui belli initium faciant et sui capitis periculo Galliam in libertatem vindicent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be able this misfortune to themselves to fall back they show: they pity the common of Gaul fortune: with all promises and rewards they demand those who of war a beginning should make and of their own head with danger Gaul into liberty should claim.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to be able this misfortune to themselves to fall back they point out: they pity the common of Gaul fortune: with all promises and rewards they demand those who of war beginning should make and of their own head with danger Gaul into liberty should claim.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they pointed out that this misfortune could fall back on themselves; they pitied the common fortune of Gaul; and with all sorts of promises and rewards, they called for those who would make a beginning of the war and restore Gaul to liberty at the risk of their own lives.

sentences.latin: In primis rationem esse habendam dicunt, priusquam eorum clandestina consilia efferantur, ut Caesar ab exercitu intercludatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the first things a plan to be to be had they say, before their secret plans are brought out, that Caesar from the army should be cut off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In first things a plan to be to be had they say, before their secret plans are brought out, so that Caesar from the army may be cut off.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said that, above all, a plan must be formed to cut Caesar off from his army before their secret designs were revealed.

sentences.latin: Id esse facile,
sentences.referenceTranslation: That to be easy,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That to be easy,
sentences.naturalTranslation: This would be easy,

sentences.latin: quod neque legiones audeant absente imperatore ex hibernis egredi, neque imperator sine praesidio ad legiones pervenire possit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: because neither the legions would dare being absent the commander from winter quarters to go out, nor the commander without a guard to the legions to arrive would be able;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because neither the legions would dare being absent the general from winter quarters to go out, nor the general without a guard to the legions to arrive would be able;
sentences.naturalTranslation: because the legions would not dare to leave their winter quarters in the absence of their commander, nor could the commander reach the legions without an escort;

sentences.latin: postremo in acie praestare interfici quam non veterem belli gloriam libertatemque quam a maioribus acceperint recuperare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: finally in battle line to be better to be killed than not the old of war glory and liberty which from ancestors they received to recover.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: finally in battle line to be better to be killed than not the old of war glory and liberty which from ancestors they received to recover.
sentences.naturalTranslation: finally, that it was better to be killed in battle than not to recover their ancient glory in war and the liberty which they had received from their ancestors.

sentences.latin: His rebus agitatis profitentur Carnutes se nullum periculum communis salutis causa recusare principesque ex omnibus bellum facturos pollicentur et,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been discussed declare the Carnutes themselves no danger of common safety for the sake of to refuse and leaders from all war to be about to make they promise and,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been discussed declare the Carnutes themselves no danger of common safety for the sake of to refuse and the first from all war to be about to make they promise and,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these matters were discussed, the Carnutes declared that they would refuse no danger for the sake of the common safety, and they promised that they would be the first of all to make war; and,

sentences.latin: quoniam in praesentia obsidibus cavere inter se non possint ne res efferatur, ut iureiurando ac fide sanciatur, petunt, collatis militaribus signis, quo more eorum gravissima caerimonia continetur, ne facto initio belli ab reliquis deserantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: since in the present with hostages to take precaution among themselves not they are able lest the matter be brought out, that by oath and faith it be sanctioned, they ask, having been brought together military standards, by which custom of them the most solemn ceremony is contained, lest having been made the beginning of war by the rest they be deserted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: since in the present by hostages to provide security among themselves they are not able lest the matter be brought out, that by oath and faith it be sanctioned, they ask, having been brought together military standards, by which custom of them the most serious ceremony is contained, lest having been made the beginning of war by the rest they be deserted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: since they could not at present exchange hostages with one another for fear the matter should be revealed, they requested that it be ratified by an oath and a pledge, bringing together their military standards (which is their most solemn ceremony), so that they would not be deserted by the rest once the war had begun.

sentences.latin: Tum collaudatis Carnutibus, dato iureiurando ab omnibus qui aderant, tempore eius rei constituto ab concilio disceditur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then the Carnutes having been praised, an oath having been given by all who were present, the time of this matter having been established, from the council it is departed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then having been praised the Carnutes, having been given an oath by all who were present, the time of this matter having been decided from the council it is departed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, after praising the Carnutes and taking an oath from all present, they set a date for the action and adjourned the council.

sentences.latin: Vbi ea dies venit, Carnutes Cotuato et Conconnetodumno ducibus, desperatis hominibus, Cenabum signo dato concurrunt civesque Romanos, qui negotiandi causa ibi constiterant, in his Gaium Fufium Citam, honestum equitem Romanum, qui rei frumentariae iussu Caesaris praeerat, interficiunt bonaque eorum diripiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When that day came, the Carnutes, Cotuatus and Conconnetodumnus [being] leaders, desperate men, to Cenabum the signal having been given they rush together and the citizens Roman, who for the sake of trading there had settled, among these Gaius Fufius Cita, an honorable knight Roman, who over the matter grain-related by order of Caesar was in charge, they kill and the goods of them they plunder.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When that day came, the Carnutes with Cotuatus and Conconnetodumnus as leaders, desperate men, to Cenabum the signal having been given they rush and the citizens Roman, who for the sake of trading there had settled, among these Gaius Fufius Cita, an honorable knight Roman, who to the matter of grain by order of Caesar was in charge, they kill and the goods of them they plunder.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the day arrived, the Carnutes, led by Cotuatus and Conconnetodumnusmen of desperate characterrushed into Cenabum at a given signal. They slaughtered the Roman citizens who had settled there for trade, including Gaius Fufius Cita, a distinguished Roman knight who was in charge of the grain supply by Caesar's order, and plundered their property.

sentences.latin: Celeriter ad omnes Galliae civitates fama perfertur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly to all of Gaul states the report is carried.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly to all of Gaul states the report is carried.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The news spread quickly to all the states of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Nam ubicumque maior atque illustrior incidit res, clamore per agros regionesque significant; hunc alii deinceps excipiunt et proximis tradunt, ut tum accidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For wherever a greater and more notable happens matter, by a shout through the fields and regions they signify; this shout others in turn take up and to the nearest hand over, as then happened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For wherever a greater and more notable happens matter, by a shout through the fields and regions they signify; this others in succession take up and to the nearest hand over, as then happened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For whenever a particularly significant or remarkable event occurs, they spread the news by shouting across the fields and districts; others take up the cry in succession and pass it to their neighbors, as happened on this occasion.

sentences.latin: Nam quae Cenabi oriente sole gesta essent, ante primam confectam vigiliam in finibus Arvernorum audita sunt, quod spatium est milium passuum circiter centum LX.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For [the things] which at Cenabum the sun rising had been done, before the first finished watch in the borders of the Arverni were heard, which distance is of thousands of paces about a hundred and 60.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For what things at Cenabum rising the sun had been done, before the first finished watch in the borders of the Arverni were heard, which distance is of thousands of paces about one hundred sixty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Indeed, what had happened at Cenabum at sunrise was heard in the territory of the Arverni before the end of the first watch, a distance of about one hundred and sixty miles.

sentences.latin: Simili ratione ibi Vercingetorix, Celtilli filius, Arvernus, summae potentiae adulescens, cuius pater principatum Galliae totius obtinuerat et ob eam causam, quod regnum appetebat, ab civitate erat interfectus, convocatis suis clientibus facile incendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By a similar reason there Vercingetorix, of Celtillus the son, an Arvernian, of highest power a young man, whose father the leadership of Gaul whole had held and for that cause, because a kingdom he was seeking, by the state had been killed, having called together his clients easily he inflamed [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By a similar reason there Vercingetorix, of Celtillus the son, an Arvernian, of highest power a young man, whose father the leadership of Gaul whole had held and for that cause, because a kingdom he was seeking, by the state had been killed, having been called together his clients easily he inflamed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In a similar way, Vercingetorix, the son of Celtillus, an Arvernian youth of great influencewhose father had held the leadership of all Gaul and had been put to death by the state for seeking royal powercalled his dependents together and easily incited them to revolt.

sentences.latin: Cognito eius consilio ad arma concurritur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been known his plan, to arms it is rushed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been known his plan to arms it is rushed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When his plan became known, there was a general rush to arms.

sentences.latin: Prohibetur ab Gobannitione, patruo suo, reliquisque principibus, qui hanc temptandam fortunam non existimabant; expellitur ex oppido Gergovia;
sentences.referenceTranslation: He is prohibited by Gobannitio, his uncle, and the rest of the leaders, who this to-be-tried fortune not were thinking; he is expelled from the town Gergovia;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He is prohibited by Gobannitio, his uncle, and the rest of the leaders, who this to be tried fortune did not think; he is expelled from the town Gergovia;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was opposed by his uncle Gobannitio and the other leaders, who did not think this risk should be taken; consequently, he was driven out of the town of Gergovia.

sentences.latin: non destitit tamen atque in agris habet dilectum egentium ac perditorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: not he ceased however and in the fields he holds a levy of the needy and of the ruined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he did not stop however and in the fields he has a levy of the needy and the ruined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, he did not give up, but held a levy of the destitute and desperate in the countryside.

sentences.latin: Hac coacta manu, quoscumque adit ex civitate ad suam sententiam perducit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This having been collected band, whomever he goes to from the state to his own opinion he leads;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been collected band, whomever he goes to from the state to his own opinion he leads;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having raised this force, he won over to his cause everyone from the state whom he approached.

sentences.latin: hortatur ut communis libertatis causa arma capiant, magnisque coactis copiis adversarios suos a quibus paulo ante erat eiectus expellit ex civitate.
sentences.referenceTranslation: he exhorts that for the sake of common liberty arms they take, and great having been collected forces his adversaries by whom a little before he had been ejected he expels from the state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Having collected such a body of troops, he brings over to his sentiments such of his fellow-citizens as he has access to: he exhorts them to take up arms in behalf of the general freedom, and having assembled great forces he drives from the state his opponents, by whom he had been expelled a short time previously.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He urged them to take up arms for the sake of their common freedom, and having gathered a large force, he drove from the state the opponents who had expelled him shortly before.

sentences.latin: Rex ab suis appellatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: King by his [people] he is called.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He is saluted king by his partisans; he sends embassadors in every direction, he conjures them to adhere firmly to their promise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He was proclaimed king by his followers.

sentences.latin: Dimittit quoque versus legationes; obtestatur ut in fide maneant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He sends out in every direction embassies; he implores that in loyalty they remain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He is saluted king by his partisans; he sends embassadors in every direction, he conjures them to adhere firmly to their promise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent embassies in every direction, imploring them to remain loyal.

sentences.latin: Celeriter sibi Senones, Parisios, Pictones, Cadurcos, Turonos, Aulercos, Lemovices, Andos reliquosque omnes qui Oceanum attingunt adiungit: omnium consensu ad eum defertur imperium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly to himself the Senones, Parisii, Pictones, Cadurci, Turoni, Aulerci, Lemovices, Andi and remaining all who the Ocean touch he joins: by all's consent to him is conferred the supreme command.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He quickly attaches to his interests the Senones, Parisii, Pictones, Cadurci, Turones, Aulerci, Lemovice, and all the others who border on the ocean; the supreme command is conferred on him by unanimous consent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He quickly won over the Senones, Parisii, Pictones, Cadurci, Turoni, Aulerci, Lemovices, Andi, and all the others who border the Ocean; by universal consent, the supreme command was conferred upon him.

sentences.latin: Qua oblata potestate omnibus his civitatibus obsides imperat, certum numerum militum ad se celeriter adduci iubet,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which having been offered power from all these states hostages he demands, a certain number of soldiers to himself quickly to be led he orders,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] He quickly attaches to his interests the Senones, Parisii, Pictones, Cadurci, Turones, Aulerci, Lemovice, and all the others who border on the ocean; the supreme command is conferred on him by unanimous consent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having been granted this power, he demanded hostages from all these states and ordered a specific number of soldiers to be brought to him quickly.

sentences.latin: armorum quantum quaeque civitas domi quodque ante tempus efficiat constituit; in primis equitatui studet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of arms how much each state at home and before what time it should produce he established; in first things to the cavalry he gives attention.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On obtaining this authority, he demands hostages from all these states, he orders a fixed number of soldiers to be sent to him immediately; he determines what quantity of arms each state shall prepare at home, and before what time; he pays particular attention to the cavalry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He determined how many weapons each state should produce at home and by what time; above all, he focused on the cavalry.

sentences.latin: Summae diligentiae summam imperi severitatem addit; magnitudine supplici dubitantes cogit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the greatest diligence the greatest of command severity he adds; by the magnitude of punishment the wavering he compels.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] On obtaining this authority, he demands hostages from all these states, he orders a fixed number of soldiers to be sent to him immediately; he determines what quantity of arms each state shall prepare at home, and before what time; he pays particular attention to the cavalry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To extreme diligence he added extreme severity of command; he compelled those who wavered through the severity of his punishments.

sentences.latin: nam maiore commisso delicto igni atque omnibus tormentis necat, leviore de causa auribus desectis aut singulis effossis oculis domum remittit, ut sint reliquis documento et magnitudine poenae perterreant alios.
sentences.referenceTranslation: for a greater having been committed crime by fire and all tortures he kills, for a lighter for cause ears having been cut off or single having been gouged out eyes home he sends back, so that they may be to the rest for a warning and by the magnitude of the penalty they may terrify others.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the utmost vigilance he adds the utmost rigor of authority; and by the severity of his punishments brings over the wavering: for on the commission of a greater crime he puts the perpetrators to death by fire and every sort of tortures; for a slighter cause, he sends home the offenders with their ears cut off, or one of their eyes put out, that they may be an example to the rest, and frighten others by the severity of their punishment.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For a more serious crime, he put the offender to death with fire and every kind of torture; for a lesser offense, he sent the person home with their ears cut off or one eye gouged out, to serve as a warning to the rest and to terrify others by the severity of the punishment.

sentences.latin: His suppliciis celeriter coacto exercitu Lucterium Cadurcum, summae hominem audaciae, cum parte copiarum in Rutenos mittit; ipse in Bituriges proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these punishments quickly having been collected an army Lucterius the Cadurcan, a man of greatest audacity, with part of the forces into the Ruteni he sends; himself into the Bituriges he sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Having quickly collected an army by their punishments, he sends Lucterius, one of the Cadurci, a man the utmost daring, with part of his forces, into the territory of the Ruteni; and marches in person into the country of the Bituriges.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having quickly raised an army through these punishments, he sent Lucterius the Cadurcan, a man of extreme daring, with part of the forces to the Ruteni; he himself set out for the Bituriges.

sentences.latin: Eius adventu Bituriges ad Aeduos,
sentences.referenceTranslation: At his arrival the Bituriges to the Aedui,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Having quickly collected an army by their punishments, he sends Lucterius, one of the Cadurci, a man the utmost daring, with part of his forces, into the territory of the Ruteni; and marches in person into the country of the Bituriges.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon his arrival, the Bituriges sent ambassadors to the Aedui,

sentences.latin: quorum erant in fide, legatos mittunt subsidium rogatum, quo facilius hostium copias sustinere possint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom they were in the protection, ambassadors they send help to ask, by which more easily of the enemies the forces to sustain they might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On his arrival, the Bituriges send embassadors to the Aedui, under whose protection they were, to solicit aid in order that they might more easily resist the forces of the enemy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since they were under their protection, they sent envoys to ask for help, so that they might more easily withstand the enemy forces.

sentences.latin: Aedui de consilio legatorum, quos Caesar ad exercitum reliquerat, copias equitatus peditatusque subsidio Biturigibus mittunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Aedui from the advice of the legates, whom Caesar at the army had left, forces of cavalry and of infantry as a help to the Bituriges they send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Aedui, by the advice of the lieutenants whom Caesar had left with the army, send supplies of horse and foot to succor the Bituriges.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the advice of the legates whom Caesar had left with the army, the Aedui sent cavalry and infantry forces to assist the Bituriges.

sentences.latin: Qui cum ad flumen Ligerim venissent, quod Bituriges ab Aeduis dividit, paucos dies ibi morati neque flumen transire
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who when to the river Loire they had come, which the Bituriges from the Aedui divides, a few days there having delayed nor the river to cross
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When they came to the river Loire, which separates the Bituriges from the Aedui, they delayed a few days there, and, not daring to pass the river, return home, and send back word to the lieutenants that they had returned through fear of the treachery of the Bituriges, who, they ascertained, had formed this design, that if the Aedui should cross the river, the Bituriges on the one side, and the Arverni on the other, should surround them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these had reached the Loire river, which separates the Bituriges from the Aedui, they delayed there for a few days, and not daring to cross the river,

sentences.latin: ausi domum revertuntur legatisque nostris renuntiant se Biturigum perfidiam veritos revertisse, quibus id consili fuisse cognoverint, ut, si flumen transissent, una ex parte ipsi, altera Arverni se circumsisterent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: having dared home they return and to our legates they report themselves of the Bituriges the treachery having feared to have returned, to whom that of plan to have been they learned, that, if the river they had crossed, from one part themselves, from the other the Arverni them would surround.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When they came to the river Loire, which separates the Bituriges from the Aedui, they delayed a few days there, and, not daring to pass the river, return home, and send back word to the lieutenants that they had returned through fear of the treachery of the Bituriges, who, they ascertained, had formed this design, that if the Aedui should cross the river, the Bituriges on the one side, and the Arverni on the other, should surround them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they returned home and reported to our legates that they had returned because they feared the treachery of the Bituriges, who they learned had planned that if they crossed the river, they themselves would surround them on one side and the Arverni on the other.

sentences.latin: Id eane de causa, quam legatis pronuntiarunt, an perfidia adducti fecerint, quod nihil nobis constat, non videtur pro certo esse proponendum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That whether for that cause, which to the legates they declared, or by treachery led they did, because nothing to us is certain, not it seems for certain to be set forth.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whether they did this for the reason which they alleged to the lieutenants, or influenced by treachery, we think that we ought not to state as certain, because we have no proof.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Whether they did this for the reason they gave the legates or were led by treachery, since we have no certain evidence, it does not seem right to state it as a fact.

sentences.latin: Bituriges eorum discessu statim cum Arvernis iunguntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Bituriges by their departure immediately with the Arverni are joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On their departure, the Bituriges immediately unite themselves to the Arverni.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon their departure, the Bituriges immediately joined forces with the Arverni.

sentences.latin: His rebus in Italiam Caesari nuntiatis, cum iam ille urbanas res virtute Cn.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things into Italy to Caesar having been announced, when already he the city affairs by the virtue of Gnaeus
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] These affairs being announced to Caesar in Italy, at the time when he understood that matters in the city had been reduced to a more tranquil state by the energy of Cneius Pompey, he set out for Transalpine Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these events were reported to Caesar in Italy, and when he understood that affairs in the city, through the merit of Gnaeus

sentences.latin: Pompei commodiorem in statum pervenisse intellegeret, in Transalpinam Galliam profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Pompey into a more favorable state to have arrived he understood, into Transalpine Gaul he set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] These affairs being announced to Caesar in Italy, at the time when he understood that matters in the city had been reduced to a more tranquil state by the energy of Cneius Pompey, he set out for Transalpine Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pompey, had reached a more favorable state, he set out for Transalpine Gaul.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, magna difficultate adficiebatur, qua ratione ad exercitum pervenire posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, by great difficulty he was affected, by what means to the army to arrive he might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] After he had arrived there, he was greatly at a loss to know by what means he could reach his army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had arrived there, he was faced with the great difficulty of how he could reach his army.

sentences.latin: Nam si legiones in provinciam arcesseret, se absente in itinere proelio dimicaturas intellegebat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: For if the legions into the province he should summon, himself being absent on the journey in battle they would fight he understood;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] After he had arrived there, he was greatly at a loss to know by what means he could reach his army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he realized that if he summoned the legions into the province, they would have to fight a battle on the march in his absence;

sentences.latin: si ipse ad exercitum contenderet, ne eis quidem eo tempore qui quieti viderentur suam salutem recte committi videbat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if he himself to the army should hasten, not even to those at that time who quiet seemed his own safety rightly to be entrusted he saw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if he himself to the army should hasten, not even to those at that time who quiet seemed his own safety rightly to be entrusted he saw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He saw that if he himself should hasten to the army, his safety could not rightly be entrusted even to those who seemed peaceful at that time.

sentences.latin: Interim Lucterius Cadurcus in Rutenos missus eam civitatem Arvernis conciliat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile Lucterius the Cadurcan into the Ruteni sent that state to the Arverni wins over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile Lucterius the Cadurcan into the Ruteni sent that state to the Arverni wins over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Lucterius the Cadurcan, having been sent to the Ruteni, won over that state to the Arverni.

sentences.latin: Progressus in Nitiobriges et Gabalos ab utrisque obsides accipit et magna coacta manu in provinciam Narbonem versus eruptionem facere contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having advanced into the Nitiobriges and Gabali from both hostages he receives and a large having been collected band into the province Narbo toward an eruption to make he hastens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having advanced into the Nitiobriges and Gabali from both hostages he receives and a large having been collected band into the province toward Narbo an eruption to make he hastens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Advancing into the territories of the Nitiobriges and Gabali, he received hostages from both and, having collected a large force, hastened to make an incursion into the Province toward Narbo.

sentences.latin: Qua re nuntiata Caesar omnibus consiliis antevertendum existimavit, ut Narbonem proficisceretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been announced Caesar all plans to be preceded thought, that to Narbo he should set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been announced Caesar all plans to be anticipated he thought, so that to Narbo he might set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported, Caesar thought that he should prioritize this over all other plans and set out for Narbo.

sentences.latin: Eo cum venisset, timentes confirmat, praesidia in Rutenis provincialibus, Volcis Arecomicis, Tolosatibus circumque Narbonem, quae loca hostibus erant finitima, constituit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had come, the fearing ones he encourages, garrisons among the provincial Ruteni, Volcae Arecomici, Tolosates and around Narbo, which places to the enemies were neighboring, he established;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had come, the fearing [ones] he encourages, garrisons in the Ruteni provincial, Volcae Arecomici, Tolosates and around Narbo, which places to the enemies were neighboring, he established;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, he encouraged those who were afraid and established garrisons among the provincial Ruteni, the Volcae Arecomici, the Tolosates, and around Narbo, locations which were bordering the enemy.

sentences.latin: partem copiarum ex provincia supplementumque, quod ex Italia adduxerat, in Helvios, qui fines Arvernorum contingunt, convenire iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: part of the forces from the province and the reinforcement, which from Italy he had brought, among the Helvii, who the borders of the Arverni touch, to assemble he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: part of the forces from the province and the reinforcement, which from Italy he had brought, into the Helvii, who the borders of the Arverni touch, to assemble he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered part of the forces from the Province and the reinforcements he had brought from Italy to assemble in the territory of the Helvii, who border the territory of the Arverni.

sentences.latin: His rebus comparatis, represso iam Lucterio et remoto, quod intrare intra praesidia periculosum putabat, in Helvios proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been prepared, checked now Lucterius and removed, because to enter within the garrisons dangerous he thought, into the Helvii he sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been prepared, checked already Lucterius and removed, because to enter within the garrisons dangerous he thought, into the Helvii he sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these preparations were made, and Lucterius was checked and driven backsince he thought it dangerous to enter within the line of garrisonsCaesar set out for the Helvii.

sentences.latin: Etsi mons Cevenna, qui Arvernos ab Helviis discludit, durissimo tempore anni altissima nive iter impediebat, tamen discussa nive sex in altitudinem pedum atque ita viis patefactis summo militum sudore ad fines Arvernorum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Although the mountain Cevenna, which the Arverni from the Helvii separates, in the hardest time of the year with very deep snow the journey was impeding, nevertheless cleared away the snow six in depth feet and thus the ways having been opened with the greatest of the soldiers sweat to the borders of the Arverni he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Although the mountain Cevenna, which the Arverni from the Helvii separates, in the hardest time of the year by very deep snow the journey was impeding, nevertheless cleared away the snow six in depth feet and thus the ways having been opened with the greatest of the soldiers sweat to the borders of the Arverni he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the Cevennes mountains, which separate the Arverni from the Helvii, were blocking the way with very deep snow at the harshest time of the year, he nevertheless cleared away snow six feet deep and, having thus opened the roads through the extreme exertion of his soldiers, reached the borders of the Arverni.

sentences.latin: Quibus oppressis inopinantibus, quod se Cevenna ut muro munitos existimabant, ac ne singulari quidem umquam homini eo tempore anni semitae patuerant, equitibus imperat, ut quam latissime possint vagentur et quam maximum hostibus terrorem inferant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who having been crushed unaware, because themselves by the Cevenna as by a wall fortified they were thinking, and not even to a single ever man at that time of the year the paths had been open, to the horsemen he commands, that as widely as they can they wander and as great as possible to the enemies terror they bring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who having been crushed unaware, because themselves by the Cevenna as by a wall fortified they were thinking, and not even to a single indeed ever man at that time of year the paths had been open, to the horsemen he commands, that as widely as they can they wander and as great as possible to the enemies terror they bring.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having surprised them while they were off their guardbecause they thought they were protected by the Cevennes as if by a wall, and at that time of year the paths had never been open even to a single travelerhe ordered his cavalry to range as widely as possible and strike as much terror as they could into the enemy.

sentences.latin: Celeriter haec fama ac nuntiis ad Vercingetorigem perferuntur; quem perterriti omnes Arverni circumsistunt atque obsecrant, ut suis fortunis consulat, neve ab hostibus diripiantur, praesertim cum videat omne ad se bellum translatum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly these things by rumor and by messengers to Vercingetorix are carried; whom terrified all the Arverni surround and beseech, that for their fortunes he should consult, nor by the enemies they should be plundered, especially since he sees all to themselves the war transferred.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly these things by rumor and by messengers to Vercingetorix are carried; whom terrified all the Arverni surround and beseech, that for their fortunes he should consult, and not by the enemies they be plundered, especially since he sees all to themselves the war transferred.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This news was quickly carried to Vercingetorix by rumor and messengers; the terrified Arverni all crowded around him and begged him to look after their interests and not let them be plundered by the enemy, especially since he saw that the whole war had been shifted into their territory.

sentences.latin: Quorum ille precibus permotus castra ex Biturigibus movet in Arvernos versus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom he by the prayers moved camp from the Bituriges moves toward the Arverni.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom he by the prayers moved the camp from the Bituriges moves into the Arverni toward.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Moved by their prayers, he shifted camp from the territory of the Bituriges toward the Arverni.

sentences.latin: At Caesar biduum in his locis moratus, quod haec de Vercingetorige usu ventura opinione praeceperat, per causam supplementi equitatusque cogendi ab exercitu discedit; Brutum adulescentem his copiis praeficit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Caesar for two days in these places having delayed, because these things about Vercingetorix would come to pass by experience in opinion he had anticipated, through the pretext of reinforcements and of cavalry collecting from the army departs; Brutus the young man over these forces he puts in charge;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Caesar for two days in these places having delayed, because these things about Vercingetorix by experience about to come by anticipation he had foreseen, through the pretext of reinforcement and of cavalry to be collected from the army he departs; Brutus the young man over these forces he puts in charge;
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Caesar, having delayed in these parts for two days because he had anticipated that these events concerning Vercingetorix would actually happen, left the army under the pretext of collecting reinforcements and cavalry; he put the young Brutus in command of these forces.

sentences.latin: hunc monet, ut in omnes partes equites quam latissime pervagentur: daturum se operam, ne longius triduo ab castris absit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: him he warns, that into all parts the horsemen as widely as possible should range: that give he would effort, lest longer than three days from the camp he be away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: him he warns, that into all parts the horsemen as widely as possible should range: about to give he [himself] effort, lest longer than three days from the camp he be away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He instructed him to have the cavalry range as widely as possible in all directions, promising that he would make every effort not to be absent from the camp for more than three days.

sentences.latin: His constitutis rebus suis inopinantibus quam maximis potest itineribus Viennam pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been arranged, his [men] not expecting, by as great as he is able marches to Vienna he arrives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been arranged things his [men] unaware by as great as he can journeys to Vienna he arrives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having made these arrangements, while his own men were unaware of his plans, he reached Vienna by the longest possible marches.

sentences.latin: Ibi nactus recentem equitatum, quem multis ante diebus eo praemiserat, neque diurno neque nocturno itinere intermisso per fines Aeduorum in Lingones contendit, ubi duae legiones hiemabant, ut, si quid etiam de sua salute ab Aeduis iniretur consili, celeritate praecurreret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There having found fresh cavalry, which many before days there he had sent ahead, neither by day nor by night march interrupted through the borders of the Aedui into the Lingones he hastens, where two legions were wintering, so that, if anything even concerning his own safety by the Aedui was entered of plan, by speed he might forestall [it].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There having found fresh cavalry, which many before days there he had sent ahead, neither by day nor by night journey interrupted through the borders of the Aedui into the Lingones he hastens, where two legions were wintering, so that, if anything even concerning his own safety by the Aedui was being entered of a plan, by speed he might forestall [it].
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, picking up fresh cavalry which he had sent ahead many days before, he pushed on through the territory of the Aedui into that of the Lingones, where two legions were wintering; he did this without stopping his march by day or night, so that he might forestall by speed any plot the Aedui might form against his safety.

sentences.latin: Eo cum pervenisset, ad reliquas legiones mittit priusque omnes in unum locum cogit quam de eius adventu Arvernis nuntiari posset.
