sentences.referenceTranslation: There when he had arrived, to the remaining legions he sends and earlier all into one place he collects than about his arrival to the Arverni to be announced it was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when he had arrived, to the remaining legions he sends and sooner all into one place he collects than about his arrival to the Arverni to be announced it could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, he sent word to the remaining legions and concentrated them all in one place before news of his arrival could reach the Arverni.

sentences.latin: Hac re cognita Vercingetorix rursus in Bituriges exercitum reducit atque inde profectus Gorgobinam, Boiorum oppidum, quos ibi Helvetico proelio victos Caesar collocaverat Aeduisque attribuerat, oppugnare instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing having been learned Vercingetorix back into the Bituriges the army leads back and from there having set out Gorgobina, of the Boii the town, whom there in the Helvetian battle conquered Caesar had placed and to the Aedui had assigned, to besiege he decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This thing having been learned Vercingetorix back into the Bituriges the army leads back and from there having set out Gorgobina, of the Boii the town, whom there in the Helvetian battle conquered Caesar had placed and to the Aedui had assigned, to besiege he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning this, Vercingetorix led his army back into the territory of the Bituriges, and from there he set out to besiege Gorgobina, a town of the Boii, whom Caesar had settled there after their defeat in the battle against the Helvetii and had made subjects of the Aedui.

sentences.latin: Magnam haec res Caesari difficultatem ad consilium capiendum adferebat, si reliquam partem hiemis uno loco legiones contineret, ne stipendiariis Aeduorum expugnatis cuncta Gallia deficeret, quod nullum amicis in eo praesidium videretur positum esse; si maturius ex hibernis educeret, ne ab re frumentaria duris subvectionibus laboraret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Great this thing to Caesar difficulty for a plan forming was bringing, if the remaining part of winter in one place the legions he should keep, lest the tributaries of the Aedui having been taken by storm all Gaul should revolt, because no for friends in him protection seemed to have been placed; if earlier from winter quarters he should lead out, lest from the grain matter by difficult transportations he should suffer.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Great this thing to Caesar difficulty to a plan to be taken was bringing, if the remaining part of winter in one place the legions he should keep, lest the tributaries of the Aedui having been taken by storm all Gaul should revolt, because no to friends in him protection seemed to have been placed; if earlier from winter quarters he should lead out, lest from the grain matter by difficult transportations he should suffer.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This situation caused Caesar great difficulty in forming a plan: if he kept the legions in one place for the rest of the winter, he feared that if the dependents of the Aedui were conquered, all Gaul would revolt because it would seem that no protection was offered to his friends; if he led them out of winter quarters too early, he feared he might suffer from a lack of supplies due to the difficulty of transport.

sentences.latin: Praestare visum est tamen omnis difficultates perpeti, quam tanta contumelia accepta omnium suorum voluntates alienare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To be better it seemed however all difficulties to endure, than so great an insult having been received of all his own [allies] the wills to alienate.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To be better it seemed nevertheless all difficulties to endure, than so great an insult having been received of all his [allies] the wills to alienate.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, it seemed better to endure every hardship than to alienate the loyalty of all his allies by accepting such a great disgrace.

sentences.latin: Itaque cohortatus Aeduos de supportando commeatu praemittit ad Boios qui de suo adventu doceant hortenturque ut in fide maneant atque hostium impetum magno animo sustineant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so having encouraged the Aedui concerning bringing up supplies he sends ahead to the Boii [those] who about his arrival should inform and should encourage that in loyalty they remain and of the enemies the attack with great spirit they should sustain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so having encouraged the Aedui about bringing up supplies he sends ahead to the Boii [those] who about his arrival should inform and should encourage that in loyalty they remain and the enemies' attack with great spirit they sustain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, after encouraging the Aedui to bring up supplies, he sent messengers ahead to the Boii to inform them of his arrival and to urge them to remain loyal and withstand the enemy's attack with great courage.

sentences.latin: Duabus Agedinci legionibus atque impedimentis totius exercitus relictis ad Boios proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Two at Agedincum legions and baggage of the whole army having been left, to the Boii he sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With two at Agedincum legions and the baggage of the whole army having been left behind, toward the Boii he sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Leaving two legions and the baggage of the entire army at Agedincum, he set out for the Boii.

sentences.latin: Altero die cum ad oppidum Senonum Vellaunodunum venisset, ne quem post se hostem relinqueret, quo expeditiore re frumentaria uteretur, oppugnare instituit idque biduo circumvallavit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the second day when to the town of the Senones Vellaunodunum he had come, lest any behind himself enemy he might leave, so that with more unimpeded grain supply he might use, to attack he decided and it in two days he surrounded with a wall;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the second day when to the town of the Senones Vellaunodunum he had come, lest any behind himself enemy he might leave, by which more unencumbered a grain supply he might use, to besiege he decided and it in two days he surrounded with a wall;
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following day, when he had arrived at Vellaunodunum, a town of the Senones, he decided to attack it to avoid leaving any enemy behind him and to ensure a more efficient grain supply; he completed the circumvallation in two days.

sentences.latin: tertio die missis ex oppido legatis de deditione arma conferri, iumenta produci, sescentos obsides dari iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: on the third day having been sent from the town envoys about surrender, arms to be collected, pack animals to be brought forth, six hundred hostages to be given he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: on the third day having been sent from the town envoys concerning surrender, arms to be collected, pack animals to be brought forward, six hundred hostages to be given he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the third day, after envoys were sent from the town to discuss surrender, he ordered the arms to be collected, the pack animals brought out, and six hundred hostages to be given.

sentences.latin: Ea qui conficeret, C. Trebonium legatum relinquit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things who might complete, Gaius Trebonius the lieutenant he leaves.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things who might complete, Gaius Trebonius the legate he leaves.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He left his lieutenant, Gaius Trebonius, to complete these arrangements.

sentences.latin: Ipse, ut quam primum iter faceret, Cenabum Carnutum proficiscitur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself, so that as as soon as possible the journey he might make, to Cenabum of the Carnutes sets out;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself, so that as as soon as possible a march he might make, to Cenabum of the Carnutes sets out;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself set out for Cenabum, a town of the Carnutes, in order to complete the march as quickly as possible.

sentences.latin: qui tum primum allato nuntio de oppugnatione Vellaunoduni, cum longius eam rem ductum iri existimarent, praesidium Cenabi tuendi causa, quod eo mitterent, comparabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who then first having been brought news about the siege of Vellaunodunum, since longer that matter to be drawn out they were thinking, a garrison for the sake of Cenabum defending, which there they might send, were preparing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who then first having been brought news about the siege of Vellaunodunum, since longer that matter to be drawn out they were thinking, a garrison for the sake of Cenabum being protected, which there they might send, were preparing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had only just received news of the siege of Vellaunodunum; thinking that the operation would take longer, they were preparing a garrison to send for the defense of Cenabum.

sentences.latin: Huc biduo pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To here in two days he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To here in two days he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He arrived there in two days.

sentences.latin: Castris ante oppidum positis diei tempore exclusus in posterum oppugnationem differt quaeque ad eam rem usui sint militibus imperat
sentences.referenceTranslation: The camp before the town having been placed, by the time of day shut out, until the next day the attack he puts off and what things for that matter for a use might be to the soldiers he commands
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the camp before the town having been placed, by the time of day shut out, until the next day the siege he puts off and what things for that matter for a use might be to the soldiers he commands
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having pitched camp before the town, he was prevented by the time of day from attacking and postponed it until the next day, ordering the soldiers to prepare whatever was necessary for the assault.

sentences.latin: et, quod oppidum Cenabum pons fluminis Ligeris contingebat, veritus ne noctu ex oppido profugerent, duas legiones in armis excubare iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and, because the town Cenabum a bridge of the river Loire was touching, fearing lest by night from the town they might flee, two legions in arms to keep watch he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and, because the town Cenabum a bridge of the river Loire was touching, fearing lest by night from the town they might flee, two legions in arms to keep watch he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since a bridge over the Loire River reached the town of Cenabum, he feared they might escape under cover of night and ordered two legions to keep watch under arms.

sentences.latin: Cenabenses paulo ante mediam noctem silentio ex oppido egressi flumen transire coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The people of Cenabum a little before middle night in silence from the town having gone out the river to cross began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The people of Cenabum a little before middle night in silence from the town having gone out the river to cross began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A little before midnight, the inhabitants of Cenabum silently left the town and began to cross the river.

sentences.latin: Qua re per exploratores nuntiata Caesar legiones
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing through scouts having been announced Caesar the legions
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing through scouts having been reported, Caesar the legions
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this news was reported by the scouts, Caesar led the legions

sentences.latin: quas expeditas esse iusserat portis incensis intromittit atque oppido potitur, perpaucis ex hostium numero desideratis quin cuncti caperentur, quod pontis atque itinerum angustiae multitudinis fugam intercluserant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which light-armed to be he had ordered the gates having been set on fire he sends in and of the town gets possession, very few from of the enemies the number being missed but that all were captured, because of the bridge and of the roads the narrowness of the multitude the flight had shut off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which ready to be he had ordered, with the gates set on fire, he sends in and of the town gets possession, very few from the of the enemies number being missing but that all were captured, because of the bridge and of the paths the narrowness of the multitude the flight had blocked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: which he had ordered to be ready for action, through the burning gates; he seized the town with only a few of the enemy's number escaping capture, because the narrowness of the bridge and the roads had blocked the flight of the crowd.

sentences.latin: Oppidum diripit atque incendit, praedam militibus donat, exercitum Ligerem traducit atque in Biturigum fines pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The town he plunders and burns, the booty to the soldiers he gives, the army the Loire across he leads and into of the Bituriges the territories arrives.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The town he plunders and burns, the booty to the soldiers he gives, the army the Loire he leads across and into of the Bituriges the borders arrives.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He plundered and burned the town, gave the booty to the soldiers, led his army across the Loire, and reached the territory of the Bituriges.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix, ubi de Caesaris adventu cognovit, oppugnatione destitit atque obviam Caesari proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix, when about of Caesar the arrival he learned, from the siege desisted and to meet Caesar sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix, when about of Caesar the arrival he learned, from the siege ceased and to meet Caesar sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Vercingetorix learned of Caesar's arrival, he abandoned the siege and set out to meet him.

sentences.latin: Ille oppidum Biturigum positum in via Noviodunum oppugnare instituerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He a town of the Bituriges placed on the way Noviodunum to besiege had begun.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He a town of the Bituriges placed on the way Noviodunum to besiege had decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar had begun to besiege Noviodunum, a town of the Bituriges situated on his route.

sentences.latin: Quo ex oppido cum legati ad eum venissent oratum ut sibi ignosceret suaeque vitae consuleret, ut celeritate reliquas res conficeret, qua pleraque erat consecutus, arma conferri, equos produci, obsides dari iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From which town when envoys to him had come to beg that to them he might grant pardon and for their life might provide, so that with speed the remaining things he might finish, by which most things he had achieved, arms to be collected, horses to be brought out, hostages to be given he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From which town when envoys to him had come to plead that to them he might be lenient and for their life might provide, so that with speed the remaining things he might finish, by which most things he had attained, arms to be collected, horses to be brought forward, hostages to be given he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When envoys came to him from this town to beg for pardon and for their lives to be spared, he ordered arms to be collected, horses brought out, and hostages given, so that he might finish the remaining business with the same speed by which he had achieved most of his successes.

sentences.latin: Parte iam obsidum tradita, cum reliqua administrarentur, centurionibus et paucis militibus intromissis, qui arma iumentaque conquirerent, equitatus hostium procul visus est, qui agmen Vercingetorigis antecesserat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Part already of the hostages having been handed over, when the remaining things were being managed, centurions and a few soldiers having been sent in, who arms and pack-animals might search for, the cavalry of the enemies at a distance was seen, which the column of Vercingetorix had preceded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With a part already of the hostages handed over, when the remaining things were being managed, with centurions and a few soldiers sent in, who arms and pack animals might search for, the cavalry of the enemies at a distance was seen, which the column of Vercingetorix had preceded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A portion of the hostages had already been handed over and the remaining arrangements were being carried out; centurions and a few soldiers had been sent in to search for arms and pack-animals, when the enemy's cavalry, which had preceded Vercingetorix's main column, was seen in the distance.

sentences.latin: Quem simul atque oppidani conspexerunt atque in spem auxili venerunt, clamore sublato arma capere, portas claudere, murum complere coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which as soon as the townsmen caught sight of and into hope of help they came, a shout having been raised arms to take, gates to close, the wall to fill they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which as soon as the townspeople caught sight of and into hope of help they came, a shout having been raised, arms to take, gates to close, the wall to fill they began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As soon as the townsmen caught sight of them and regained hope of relief, they raised a shout and began to take up arms, shut the gates, and man the walls.

sentences.latin: Centuriones in oppido,
sentences.referenceTranslation: The centurions in the town,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The centurions in the town,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The centurions inside the town,

sentences.latin: cum ex significatione Gallorum novi aliquid ab eis iniri consili intellexissent, gladiis destrictis portas occupaverunt suosque omnes incolumes receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: when from the behavior of the Gauls new something by them to be entered upon of a plan they had understood, swords having been drawn the gates they seized and their own all safe they recovered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: when from the behavior of the Gauls new something by them to be entered upon of a plan they had understood, with swords drawn the gates they seized and their own men all safe they recovered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: realizing from the behavior of the Gauls that some new plan was being formed by them, drew their swords, seized the gates, and brought all their men back safely.

sentences.latin: Caesar ex castris equitatum educi iubet, proelium equestre committit: laborantibus iam suis Germanos equites circiter CCCC summittit, quos ab initio habere secum instituerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar from the camp the cavalry to be led out orders, a battle cavalry joins: for the laboring already his own German horsemen about 400 he sends to help, whom from the beginning to have with himself he had established.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar from the camp the cavalry to be led out orders, a cavalry battle joins: to those now struggling of his own the German horsemen about 400 he sends, whom from the beginning to have with himself he had resolved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar ordered the cavalry to be led out of the camp and joined a cavalry engagement. When his men began to struggle, he sent about four hundred German horsemen to their aid, whom he had made a practice of keeping with him from the start.

sentences.latin: Eorum impetum Galli sustinere non potuerunt atque in fugam coniecti multis amissis se ad agmen receperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of them the attack the Gauls to sustain were not able and into flight thrown many having been lost themselves to the main body withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Their attack the Gauls to sustain were not able and into flight cast many having been lost themselves to the column they retreated.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Gauls could not withstand their attack and, being put to flight with many losses, retreated to their main column.

sentences.latin: Quibus profligatis rursus oppidani perterriti comprehensos eos, quorum opera plebem concitatam existimabant, ad Caesarem perduxerunt seseque ei dediderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who having been routed again the townsmen terrified having been seized those, by whose agency the common people stirred up they were thinking, to Caesar led and themselves to him surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been routed again the townspeople terrified those seized, of whom by the work the common people incited they thought, to Caesar they led and themselves to him they surrendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After these were routed, the terrified townsmen again seized those by whose influence they believed the common people had been incited, brought them to Caesar, and surrendered themselves to him.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus confectis, Caesar ad oppidum Avaricum, quod erat maximum munitissimumque in finibus Biturigum atque agri fertilissima regione, profectus est, quod eo oppido recepto civitatem Biturigum se in potestatem redacturum confidebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been finished, Caesar to the town Avaricum, which was the largest and most fortified in the borders of the Bituriges and of the land in the most fertile region, set out, because that town having been recovered the state of the Bituriges himself into power would reduce he was confident.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been finished, Caesar to the town Avaricum, which was the largest and most fortified in the borders of the Bituriges and in the most fertile region of the land, set out, because that town having been received the state of the Bituriges himself into power to be reduced he was confident.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these matters were settled, Caesar set out for the town of Avaricum, the largest and best-fortified in the territory of the Bituriges and situated in a very fertile region; he was confident that by capturing this town, he would bring the entire state of the Bituriges under his control.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix tot continuis incommodis Vellaunoduni, Cenabi, Novioduni acceptis suos ad concilium convocat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix so many continuous setbacks at Vellaunodunum, Cenabum, Noviodunum having been received his own to a council calls together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix so many continuous setbacks at Vellaunodunum, Cenabum, Noviodunum having been received his own to a council calls together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After suffering so many successive setbacks at Vellaunodunum, Cenabum, and Noviodunum, Vercingetorix summoned his followers to a council.

sentences.latin: Docet longe alia ratione esse bellum gerendum atque antea gestum sit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He teaches by a far other method to be the war must be waged than before it has been waged.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He teaches by a far other method to be war waged than before it has been waged.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He explained that the war must be conducted on a far different plan than it had been previously.

sentences.latin: Omnibus modis huic rei studendum, ut pabulatione et commeatu Romani prohibeantur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: In all ways for this thing it must be striven, so that from foraging and provisions the Romans may be kept away:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In all ways for this thing it must be striven, that from foraging and supplies the Romans be prohibited:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Every effort must be made to prevent the Romans from obtaining forage and supplies.

sentences.latin: id esse facile, quod equitatu ipsi abundent et quod anni tempore subleventur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: that to be easy, because in cavalry they themselves abound and because by the time of year they are assisted;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that to be easy, because in cavalry themselves they abound and because by the time of year they are assisted;
sentences.naturalTranslation: This would be easy because they themselves were superior in cavalry and were aided by the time of year.

sentences.latin: pabulum secari non posse; necessario dispersos hostes ex aedificiis petere: hos omnes cotidie ab equitibus deligi posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: forage to be cut not to be able; by necessity dispersed the enemies from buildings to seek: these all daily by the horsemen to be picked off to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: fodder to be cut not to be able; of necessity scattered the enemies from buildings to seek: these all daily by the horsemen to be picked off can.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Forage could not be cut; the enemy would necessarily scatter to seek it from buildings, and all of these could be picked off daily by the cavalry.

sentences.latin: Praeterea salutis causa rei familiaris commoda neglegenda: vicos atque aedificia incendi oportere hoc spatio ab via quoque versus, quo pabulandi causa adire posse videantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Furthermore for the sake of safety of private property the advantages must be neglected: villages and buildings to be burned it behooves in this space from the road also in every direction, to which for the sake of foraging to go to to be able they seem.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Furthermore for the sake of safety of private property the advantages to be neglected: villages and buildings to be burned it behoves in this space from the road also in every direction, to where for the sake of foraging to approach to be able they may seem.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, for the sake of their common safety, private interests must be set aside: villages and buildings should be burned in every direction from the line of march as far as the enemy might seem able to go for the purpose of foraging.

sentences.latin: Harum ipsis rerum copiam suppetere,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of these things for themselves an abundance to be at hand,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these things to themselves an abundance to be at hand,
sentences.naturalTranslation: They had an abundance of these supplies,

sentences.latin: quod, quorum in finibus bellum geratur, eorum opibus subleventur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: because, in whose territories the war is being waged, by their resources they are supported:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because, in whose borders the war is waged, by their resources they are assisted:
sentences.naturalTranslation: because they were supported by the resources of those in whose territory the war was being fought.

sentences.latin: Romanos aut inopiam non laturos aut magno periculo longius ab castris processuros;
sentences.referenceTranslation: the Romans either the scarcity not would endure or with great danger further from the camps would proceed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the Romans either the scarcity not will endure or with great danger further from the camp will proceed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: the Romans would either be unable to endure the scarcity or would have to advance further from their camp at great risk;

sentences.latin: neque interesse, ipsosne interficiant, impedimentisne exuant, quibus amissis bellum geri non possit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not to make a difference, whether themselves they kill, or of baggage they strip, which having been lost war to be waged not is able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor to matter, whether themselves they kill, or of baggage they strip, which having been lost war to be waged not can.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and it made no difference whether they killed the Romans themselves or stripped them of their baggage, since if it were lost, war could not be carried on.

sentences.latin: Praeterea oppida incendi oportere, quae non munitione et loci natura ab omni sint periculo tuta, neu suis sint ad detractandam militiam receptacula neu Romanis proposita ad copiam commeatus praedamque tollendam.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Furthermore towns to be burned it behooved, which not by fortification and of place nature from all are danger safe, nor for their own people they be for avoiding military service shelters nor for Romans set forth for abundance of provisions and booty to be carried off.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Furthermore towns to be burned it behoves, which not by fortification and nature of the place from all danger are safe, lest to their own they be for declining military service refuges nor to the Romans set forth for an abundance of supplies and booty to be taken.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, it was necessary to burn those towns which were not safe from all danger by fortification or natural position, so that they might not serve as refuges for their own men to avoid service, nor be available to the Romans for obtaining an abundance of provisions and booty.

sentences.latin: haec si gravia aut acerba videantur, multo illa gravius aestimare, liberos, coniuges in servitutem abstrahi, ipsos interfici; quae sit necesse accidere victis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: these things if heavy or bitter they should seem, by much those things more heavily to estimate, children, wives into slavery to be dragged away, themselves to be killed; which it is necessary to happen to the conquered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: these if heavy or bitter they seem, by much those things more heavily to estimate, children, wives into slavery to be dragged away, themselves to be killed; which to be necessary to happen to the conquered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: if these measures seemed harsh or bitter, they should consider it much harsher that their children and wives were being dragged into slavery and they themselves were being killedthings which necessarily happen to the conquered.

sentences.latin: Omnium consensu hac sententia probata uno die amplius XX urbes Biturigum incenduntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of all by consensus this opinion having been approved in one day more than 20 cities of the Bituriges are burned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the consensus of all this opinion having been approved in one day more than 20 cities of the Bituriges are burned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This proposal being approved by general consensus, more than twenty cities of the Bituriges were burned in a single day.

sentences.latin: Hoc idem fit in reliquis civitatibus: in omnibus partibus incendia conspiciuntur; quae etsi magno cum dolore omnes ferebant, tamen hoc sibi solati proponebant, quod se prope explorata victoria celeriter amissa reciperaturos confidebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This same thing happens in the remaining states: in all parts fires are seen; which although with great grief all were bearing, yet this for themselves of solace they were setting forth, because themselves nearly certain victory quickly the lost things to recover they were trusting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This same thing happens in the remaining states: in all parts fires are seen; which although with great grief all were bearing, nevertheless this to themselves as solace they were proposing, because they were confident themselves, victory nearly explored, quickly the lost things to be about to recover.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The same thing happened in the other states: fires were seen in every direction; and although everyone bore this with great grief, they yet consoled themselves with the thought that, since victory was almost certain, they were confident they would quickly recover what they had lost.

sentences.latin: Deliberatur de Avarico in communi concilio, incendi placeret an defendi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It is deliberated concerning Avaricum in a common council, to be burned it should please or to be defended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is deliberated about Avaricum in a common council, to be burned it should please or to be defended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A deliberation was held in a general council concerning Avaricum, whether it was better for it to be burned or defended.

sentences.latin: Procumbunt omnibus Gallis ad pedes Bituriges, ne pulcherrimam prope totius Galliae urbem, quae praesidio et ornamento sit civitati, suis manibus succendere cogerentur:
sentences.referenceTranslation: They fall down of all the Gauls at the feet the Bituriges, lest the most beautiful nearly of all Gaul city, which for protection and for ornament is to the state, with their own hands to set fire to they should be compelled:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Fall down to all the Gauls at the feet the Bituriges, lest the most beautiful nearly of all Gaul city, which for a protection and ornament is to the state, with their own hands to set fire to they be forced.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Bituriges fell at the feet of all the Gauls, begging that they might not be compelled to set fire with their own hands to what was almost the most beautiful city in all Gaul, which was both a protection and an ornament to their state.

sentences.latin: facile se loci natura defensuros dicunt, quod prope ex omnibus partibus flumine et palude circumdata unum habeat et perangustum aditum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Easily themselves by the nature of the place they would defend they say, because nearly from all parts by river and marsh surrounded one it has and very narrow approach.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: easily themselves by the nature of the place they would defend they say, because nearly from all parts by a river and a marsh surrounded one it has and very narrow approach.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said they could easily defend themselves by the nature of the terrain, because, being surrounded on almost all sides by a river and a marsh, it had only one very narrow approach.

sentences.latin: Datur petentibus venia dissuadente primo Vercingetorige, post concedente et precibus ipsorum et misericordia vulgi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is given to the seeking ones permission, with Vercingetorix dissuading at first, afterwards conceding both to the prayers of them and the pity of the common people.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is given to those seeking permission with Vercingetorix dissuading at first, afterwards conceding both to the prayers of them and to the pity of the common people.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their request was granted, with Vercingetorix at first opposing it, but later yielding both to their pleas and to the compassion of the common people.

sentences.latin: Defensores oppido idonei deliguntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Defenders for the town suitable are chosen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Defenders for the town suitable are chosen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Suitable defenders were chosen for the town.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix minoribus Caesarem itineribus subsequitur et locum castris deligit paludibus silvisque munitum ab Avarico longe milia passuum XVI.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix by smaller marches Caesar follows and a place for the camp chooses by marshes and woods protected from Avaricum distant miles of paces 16.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix by smaller marches Caesar follows and a place for a camp chooses by marshes and woods fortified from Avaricum far thousands of paces sixteen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Vercingetorix followed Caesar by shorter marches and chose a spot for his camp protected by marshes and forests, sixteen miles away from Avaricum.

sentences.latin: Ibi per certos exploratores in singula diei tempora quae ad Avaricum agerentur cognoscebat et quid fieri vellet imperabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There through certain scouts into individual of the day times what at Avaricum were being done he was learning and what to be done he wished he was ordering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There through certain scouts at individual of the day times what at Avaricum were being done he was learning and what to be done he wished he was ordering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, through reliable scouts, he learned at every hour of the day what was happening at Avaricum and issued orders for what he wanted done.

sentences.latin: Omnis nostras pabulationes frumentationesque observabat dispersosque, cum longius necessario procederent, adoriebatur magnoque incommodo adficiebat, etsi, quantum ratione provideri poterat, ab nostris occurrebatur, ut incertis temporibus diversisque itineribus iretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All our foraging and grain-gathering parties he was watching and the dispersed ones, when further by necessity they were proceeding, he was attacking and with great disadvantage was affecting, although, as much as by reason to be foreseen it was able, by ours it was met, so that at uncertain times and by diverse routes it was gone.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All our foraging and grain-gathering expeditions he was watching and the dispersed [men], when further by necessity they were proceeding, he was attacking and with great disadvantage was affecting, although, as much as by reason to be foreseen it was possible, by our [men] it was met, so that at uncertain times and by diverse routes it was gone.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He watched all our foraging and grain-gathering parties and attacked our men when they were scattered and forced to go further afield, inflicting great loss on them, even though our men took every possible precaution to go at irregular times and by different routes.

sentences.latin: Castris ad eam partem oppidi positis Caesar, quae intermissa [a] flumine et a paludibus aditum, ut supra diximus, angustum habebat, aggerem apparare, vineas agere, turres duas constituere coepit: nam circumvallare loci natura prohibebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the camp at that part of the town placed Caesar, which interrupted by the river and by marshes an approach, as above we said, narrow was having, a rampart to prepare, vineae to move forward, towers two to set up began: for to surround with a wall the nature of the place was prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the camp at that part of the town placed Caesar, which left open by the river and by the marshes an approach, as above we said, narrow had, a rampart to prepare, vineae to move forward, towers two to set up began: for to surround with a wall the nature of the place was prohibiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having pitched his camp at that part of the town which, where the river and marshes did not intervene, had a narrow approach as we mentioned above, Caesar began to prepare a rampart, move up mantlets, and erect two towers; for the nature of the ground prevented him from completely encircling it with a wall.

sentences.latin: De re frumentaria Boios atque Aeduos adhortari non destitit; quorum alteri, quod nullo studio agebant, non multum adiuvabant, alteri non magnis facultatibus, quod civitas erat exigua et infirma, celeriter quod habuerunt consumpserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: About the grain matter the Boii and the Aedui to exhort he did not cease; of whom the ones, because with no zeal they were acting, not much were helping, the others with not great resources, because the state was small and weak, quickly what they had they consumed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Concerning the grain matter the Boii and the Aedui to exhort he did not cease; of whom the ones, because with no zeal they were acting, not much were helping, the others not with great resources, because the state was small and weak, quickly what they had they consumed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He did not cease to urge the Boii and the Aedui regarding the grain supply; of these, the latter, acting with no enthusiasm, were not of much help, while the former, having limited resources because their state was small and weak, quickly consumed what they had.

sentences.latin: Summa difficultate rei frumentariae adfecto exercitu tenuitate Boiorum, indiligentia Aeduorum, incendiis aedificiorum, usque eo ut complures dies frumento milites caruerint et pecore ex longinquioribus vicis adacto extremam famem sustentarent, nulla tamen vox est ab eis audita populi Romani maiestate et superioribus victoriis indigna.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the greatest difficulty of the grain matter affected the army by the poverty of the Boii, the negligence of the Aedui, the burnings of buildings, up to that point that for several days of grain the soldiers lacked and with cattle from more distant villages driven to them extreme hunger they were sustaining, no however voice was from them heard of the Roman people's majesty and previous victories unworthy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the highest difficulty of the grain matter having affected the army by the poverty of the Boii, the negligence of the Aedui, the burnings of buildings, even to that point that for several days of grain the soldiers lacked and with cattle from more distant villages driven in extreme hunger they were sustaining, no however voice was from them heard of the people Roman majesty and previous victories unworthy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The army was affected by the greatest difficulty regarding grain due to the poverty of the Boii, the negligence of the Aedui, and the burning of buildings, to such an extent that for several days the soldiers were without grain and warded off extreme hunger with cattle driven from more distant villages; yet no word was heard from them unworthy of the majesty of the Roman people and their previous victories.

sentences.latin: Quin etiam Caesar cum in opere singulas legiones appellaret et, si acerbius inopiam ferrent, se dimissurum oppugnationem diceret, universi ab eo, ne id faceret, petebant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nay even Caesar when in the work individual legions he was addressing and, if too bitterly the scarcity they were bearing, himself would abandon the siege he was saying, all from him, that not that he should do, were begging:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nay even Caesar when in the work individual legions he was addressing and, if too bitterly the scarcity they were bearing, himself would abandon the siege he was saying, all from him, that not that he should do, were begging:
sentences.naturalTranslation: In fact, when Caesar addressed the individual legions at their work and said he would abandon the siege if they found the scarcity too hard to bear, they all begged him not to do so.

sentences.latin: sic se complures annos illo imperante meruisse, ut nullam ignominiam acciperent, nusquam infecta re discederent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: thus themselves several years him commanding to have served, that no disgrace they received, nowhere unfinished thing they departed:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: thus themselves for several years with him commanding to have served, that no disgrace they received, nowhere with the matter unfinished they departed:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said that they had served for several years under his command in such a way that they never suffered disgrace or retreated without achieving their objective.

sentences.latin: hoc se ignominiae laturos loco, si inceptam oppugnationem reliquissent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: this themselves of disgrace they would bear in place, if the begun siege they had abandoned:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: this themselves of disgrace would bear in the place, if the begun siege they had abandoned:
sentences.naturalTranslation: They would consider it a mark of disgrace if they abandoned the siege they had begun.

sentences.latin: praestare omnes perferre acerbitates, quam non civibus Romanis, qui Cenabi perfidia Gallorum interissent, parentarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be better all to endure hardships, than not for the citizens Roman, who at Cenabum by treachery of the Gauls had perished, they should perform funeral rites.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to be better all to endure hardships, than not for the citizens Roman, who at Cenabum by the treachery of the Gauls had perished, they should perform funeral rites.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was better to endure every hardship than to fail to avenge the Roman citizens who had perished at Cenabum through the treachery of the Gauls.

sentences.latin: Haec eadem centurionibus tribunisque militum mandabant, ut per eos ad Caesarem deferrentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These same things to the centurions and to the tribunes of the soldiers they were entrusting, so that through them to Caesar they might be reported.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These same things to the centurions and to the tribunes of the soldiers they were entrusting, so that through them to Caesar they might be reported.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They entrusted these same messages to the centurions and military tribunes to be reported to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Cum iam muro turres appropinquassent, ex captivis Caesar cognovit Vercingetorigem consumpto pabulo castra movisse propius Avaricum atque ipsum cum equitatu expeditisque, qui inter equites proeliari consuessent, insidiarum causa eo profectum, quo nostros postero die pabulatum venturos arbitraretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When already to the wall the towers had approached, from captives Caesar learned Vercingetorix, consumed fodder, the camp to have moved nearer Avaricum and himself with the cavalry and light-armed, who among the cavalry to fight were accustomed, for the sake of ambush to that place to have set out, where our [men] on the following day to forage to come he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When already to the wall the towers had approached, from captives Caesar learned Vercingetorix with the forage consumed the camp to have moved nearer Avaricum and himself with the cavalry and light-armed [troops], who among the cavalry to battle were accustomed, for the sake of an ambush to that place to have set out, where our [men] on the following day to forage would come he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the siege towers had already approached the wall, Caesar learned from captives that Vercingetorix, having used up the fodder, had moved his camp closer to Avaricum, and that he himself had set out with the cavalry and light-armed troops who usually fought among the horsemen to lay an ambush where he expected our men to come for forage the next day.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus cognitis media nocte silentio profectus ad hostium castra mane pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been learned, in the middle of the night in silence having set out, to of the enemies the camp in the morning he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been learned in the middle of the night in silence having set out to the of the enemies camp in the morning he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned these facts, he set out in silence at midnight and arrived at the enemy's camp in the morning.

sentences.latin: Illi celeriter per exploratores adventu Caesaris cognito carros impedimentaque sua in artiores silvas abdiderunt, copias omnes in loco edito atque aperto instruxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They quickly through scouts the arrival of Caesar having been known, the wagons and baggage their own into thicker woods hid, the forces all in a place elevated and open drew up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They quickly through scouts the arrival of Caesar having been learned the wagons and baggage their own in thicker woods hid, the forces all in a place elevated and open they drew up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy, quickly learning of Caesar's arrival through scouts, hid their wagons and baggage in the denser parts of the woods and drew up all their forces on high, open ground.

sentences.latin: Qua re nuntiata Caesar celeriter sarcinas conferri, arma expediri iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been reported, Caesar quickly the packs to be collected, the arms to be made ready ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been reported Caesar quickly the packs to be collected, the arms to be made ready ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was reported, Caesar quickly ordered the packs to be piled together and the weapons to be readied.

sentences.latin: Collis erat leniter ab infimo acclivis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A hill there was gently from the bottom sloping upward.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A hill there was gently from the bottom sloping upwards.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a hill with a gentle slope rising from the bottom.

sentences.latin: Hunc ex omnibus fere partibus palus difficilis atque impedita cingebat non latior pedibus quinquaginta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This from all almost parts a marsh difficult and obstructed was surrounding not wider than feet fifty.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This from all almost parts a marsh difficult and obstructed was surrounding not wider than feet fifty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A difficult and obstructive marsh, no more than fifty feet wide, surrounded this hill on almost every side.

sentences.latin: Hoc se colle interruptis pontibus Galli fiducia loci continebant generatimque distributi in civitates omnia vada ac saltus eius paludis obtinebant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: On this hill themselves with broken bridges the Gauls by confidence of the place were keeping and by tribes distributed into states all fords and thickets of that marsh were holding,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On this hill themselves, the bridges having been broken, the Gauls by confidence of the place were keeping, and by tribes distributed into states, all fords and glades of that marsh they were holding,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Gauls remained on this hill, having broken the bridges and relying on the strength of their position; distributed by tribe into their respective states, they held all the fords and passes of that marsh,

sentences.latin: sic animo parati, ut, si eam paludem Romani perrumpere conarentur, haesitantes premerent ex loco superiore; ut qui propinquitatem loci videret paratos prope aequo Marte ad dimicandum existimaret, qui iniquitatem condicionis perspiceret inani simulatione sese ostentare cognosceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so in mind prepared, that, if that marsh the Romans to break through should try, struggling they might press from a place higher; so that he who the proximity of the place should see prepared nearly with equal Mars for fighting would think, [but] he who the inequality of the condition should perceive in an empty pretense themselves to show would recognize.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: thus in mind prepared, that, if that marsh the Romans to break through should try, struggling they might press from a higher place; so that he who the proximity of the place saw, prepared nearly with equal Mars for fighting would think [them], [but] he who the inequality of the condition perceived, in an empty pretense themselves to show would recognize.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they were so prepared in spirit that, if the Romans tried to cross that marsh, they would attack them from the higher ground while they were struggling; so that anyone who saw the proximity of the positions would think them ready to fight on nearly equal terms, but anyone who perceived the unfairness of the situation would realize they were making an empty show of defiance.

sentences.latin: Indignantes milites Gaesar, quod conspectum suum hostes perferre possent tantulo spatio interiecto, et signum proeli exposcentes edocet, quanto detrimento et quot virorum fortium morte necesse sit constare victoriam; quos cum sic animo paratos videat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Indignant the soldiers Caesar, because the sight of them the enemies to endure were able with so small a space thrown between, and the signal of battle demanding he informs, by how much loss and by how many of men brave death necessary it is to cost victory; whom when so in mind prepared he sees,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The indignant soldiers Caesar, because his sight the enemy to endure were able with so small a space cast between, and the signal of battle demanding, informs, with how much loss and how many of brave men death it is necessary to cost victory; whom when thus in mind prepared he sees,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar informed his soldierswho were indignant that the enemy could endure the sight of them with so small a distance between and were demanding the signal for battleat what great loss and at the cost of how many brave men's lives victory must necessarily be won; seeing them so ready in spirit,

sentences.latin: ut nullum pro sua laude periculum recusent, summae se iniquitatis condemnari debere, nisi eorum vitam sua salute habeat cariorem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that no for their own praise danger they refuse, of highest injustice himself to be condemned to owe, unless their life than his own safety he should hold dearer.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that no for their own praise danger they refuse, of the highest injustice himself to be condemned to owe, unless their life than his own safety he holds dearer.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that they refused no danger for his glory, he said that he ought to be condemned for the greatest injustice if he did not hold their lives dearer than his own safety.

sentences.latin: Sic milites consolatus eodem die reducit in castra reliquaque quae ad oppugnationem pertinebant oppidi administrare instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus the soldiers having consoled on the same day he leads back into the camp and the remaining things which to the siege were pertaining of the town to arrange he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus the soldiers having consoled, on the same day he leads back into the camp and the remaining things which to the siege were pertaining of the town to arrange he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having thus consoled the soldiers, he led them back to camp on the same day and began to arrange the remaining things necessary for the siege of the town.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix, cum ad suos redisset, proditionis insimulatus, quod castra propius Romanos movisset, quod cum omni equitatu discessisset, quod sine imperio tantas copias reliquisset, quod eius discessu Romani tanta opportunitate et celeritate venissent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix, when to his own [people] he had returned, of treason accused, because the camp nearer the Romans he had moved, because with all the cavalry he had departed, because without command so great forces he had left, because by his departure the Romans with such opportunity and speed had come:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix, when to his own [people] he had returned, of treason accused, because the camp nearer the Romans he had moved, because with all the cavalry he had departed, because without command so great forces he had left, because by his departure the Romans with such opportunity and speed had come:
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Vercingetorix returned to his people, he was accused of treason because he had moved the camp closer to the Romans, because he had departed with all the cavalry, because he had left such large forces without a commander, and because the Romans had arrived with such opportunity and speed during his absence:

sentences.latin: non haec omnia fortuito aut sine consilio accidere potuisse; regnum illum Galliae malle Caesaris concessu quam ipsorum habere beneficio
sentences.referenceTranslation: not these all things by chance or without a plan to happen were able; the kingdom that [man] of Gaul to prefer by Caesar's grant than of themselves to have by the benefit
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not these all things by chance or without a plan to happen were able; the kingship that [man] of Gaul to prefer by Caesar's grant than by their own benefit to have
sentences.naturalTranslation: they claimed that all these things could not have happened by chance or without a plan; that he preferred to hold the kingship of Gaul by Caesar's grant rather than by their own favor.

sentences.latin: --tali modo accusatus ad haec respondit: Quod castra movisset, factum inopia pabuli etiam ipsis hortantibus; quod propius Romanos accessisset, persuasum loci opportunitate, qui se ipsum munitione defenderet:
sentences.referenceTranslation: --in such a way accused to these things he responded: That the camp he had moved, done by lack of fodder even themselves urging; that nearer the Romans he had approached, persuaded by the opportunity of the place, which itself by fortification would defend:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: in such a way accused to these things he responded: That the camp he had moved, [it was] done by lack of forage even they themselves urging; that nearer the Romans he had approached, [he was] persuaded by the opportunity of the place, which itself by fortification would defend:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having been accused in such a manner, he responded to these charges: that he had moved the camp because of a lack of fodder, at their own urging; that he had approached closer to the Romans because he was convinced by the advantage of the position, which would defend itself by its own natural fortification;

sentences.latin: equitum vero operam neque in loco palustri desiderari debuisse et illic fuisse utilem, quo sint profecti.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of the cavalry indeed the service neither in a marshy place to be missed to have owed and there to have been useful, where they have set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of the cavalry indeed the service neither in a marshy place to be missed ought and there to have been useful, where they have set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: that the service of the cavalry should not have been missed in a marshy place, and that they had been useful in the place to which they had gone.

sentences.latin: Summam imperi se consulto nulli discedentem tradidisse, ne is multitudinis studio ad dimicandum impelleretur; cui rei propter animi mollitiem studere omnes videret, quod diutius laborem ferre non possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The supreme [command] of power himself by design to no one departing to have handed over, lest he by the crowd's eagerness to fighting might be driven; which thing on account of the mind's softness to be eager for all he saw, because longer labor to bear they were not able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The supreme [command] of power he by design to no one departing had handed over, lest he by the crowd's zeal to fighting be driven; which thing on account of the mind's softness to desire all he saw, because longer labor to bear they were not able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said that he had deliberately handed over the supreme command to no one upon his departure, lest that person be driven to fight by the eagerness of the multitude; for he saw that everyone was eager for battle because of their weakness of spirit, as they could no longer endure the hardship.

sentences.latin: Romani si casu intervenerint, fortunae, si alicuius indicio vocati, huic habendam gratiam, quod et paucitatem eorum ex loco superiore cognoscere et virtutem despicere potuerint, qui dimicare non ausi turpiter se in castra receperint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Romans if by chance they intervened, to fortune, if by someone's information called, to this one thanks must be had, because both the smallness of them from a higher place to learn and their courage to despise they were able, who to fight not having dared basely themselves into the camp withdrew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Romans if by chance they intervened, to fortune, if by someone's information called, to this [person] to be had thanks, because both the small number of them from a higher place to learn and [their] courage to despise they were able, who to fight not having dared shamefully themselves into the camp withdrew.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If the Romans arrived by chance, they should thank fortune; if they were summoned by an informer, they should thank him, because from their higher position they could see how few the enemy were and despise the cowardice of those who, not daring to fight, retreated shamefully to their camp.

sentences.latin: Imperium se ab Caesare per proditionem nullum desiderare, quod habere victoria posset, quae iam esset sibi atque omnibus Gallis explorata: quin etiam ipsis remittere, si sibi magis honorem tribuere, quam ab se salutem accipere videantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Command himself from Caesar through betrayal none to desire, which to have by victory he was able, which already was to him and to all Gauls certain: nay even to them to give back, if to him more honor to bestow, than from him safety to receive they seem.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Power he from Caesar through treason none to desire, which to have by victory he was able, which already was to him and to all Gauls certain: nay even to them to give back, if to him more honor to grant, than from him safety to receive they seem.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said he desired no position of command from Caesar through treachery, since he could obtain it by a victory which was already certain for him and all the Gauls; indeed, he would even resign his command to them, if they seemed to be conferring an honor upon him rather than receiving their safety from him.

sentences.latin: "Haec ut intellegatis," inquit, "a me sincere pronuntiari, audite Romanos milites." Producit servos,
sentences.referenceTranslation: "These things so that you may understand," he says, "by me sincerely to be declared, hear the Roman soldiers." He brings forward slaves,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "These things so that you may understand," he said, "by me sincerely to be pronounced, hear the Roman soldiers." He brings forward slaves,
sentences.naturalTranslation: "To understand that these things are declared by me with sincerity," he said, "listen to the Roman soldiers." He then brought forward some slaves,

sentences.latin: quos in pabulatione paucis ante diebus exceperat et fame vinculisque excruciaverat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: whom in foraging a few before days he had captured and by hunger and chains had tortured.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: whom in foraging a few before days he had intercepted and by hunger and chains had tortured.
sentences.naturalTranslation: whom he had captured while they were foraging a few days earlier and had tortured with hunger and chains.

sentences.latin: Hi iam ante edocti quae interrogati pronuntiarent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These already before having been taught what having been questioned they should declare,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These already before taught what having been questioned they should pronounce,
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men, having already been coached on what to say when questioned,

sentences.latin: milites se esse legionarios dicunt; fame et inopia adductos clam ex castris exisse, si quid frumenti aut pecoris in agris reperire possent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: soldiers themselves to be legionary they say; by hunger and want driven secretly from the camp to have gone out, if any of grain or of cattle in the fields to find they were able:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: soldiers themselves to be legionary they say; by hunger and want driven secretly from the camp to have gone out, if any of grain or of cattle in the fields to find they were able:
sentences.naturalTranslation: stated that they were legionary soldiers; that, driven by hunger and want, they had secretly left the camp to see if they could find any grain or cattle in the fields.

sentences.latin: simili omnem exercitum inopia premi, nec iam vires sufficere cuiusquam nec ferre operis laborem posse: itaque statuisse imperatorem, si nihil in oppugnatione oppidi profecissent, triduo exercitum deducere. "Haec," inquit, "a me," Vercingetorix, "beneficia habetis,
sentences.referenceTranslation: by similar all the army want to be pressed, nor now strengths to suffice of anyone nor to bear of the work the labor to be able: therefore to have decided the commander, if nothing in the siege of the town they had gained, in three days the army to lead away. "These," he says, "from me," Vercingetorix, "benefits you have,"
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by a similar all the army want to be pressed, nor now the strengths to suffice of anyone nor to bear of the work the labor to be able: and so to have decided the commander, if nothing in the siege of the town they had gained, in three days the army to lead away. "These," he said, "from me," Vercingetorix, "benefits you have,"
sentences.naturalTranslation: They added that the whole army was suffering from a similar scarcity, that no one's strength was sufficient anymore to endure the labor of the siege works, and therefore the commander had decided to withdraw the army in three days if they made no progress in the siege of the town. "These are the benefits," said Vercingetorix, "that you have from me,"

sentences.latin: quem proditionis insimulatis; cuius opera sine vestro sanguine tantum exercitum victorem fame consumptum videtis; quem turpiter se ex fuga recipientem ne qua civitas suis finibus recipiat a me provisum est."
sentences.referenceTranslation: whom of betrayal you accuse; by whose effort without your blood so great an army victorious by hunger consumed you see; whom shamefully himself from flight recovering lest any state in its borders should receive by me it has been provided."
sentences.originalMITTranslation: whom of treason you accuse; by whose work without your blood so great an army victorious by hunger consumed you see; which shamefully itself from flight recovering lest any state in its borders receive by me it has been provided."
sentences.naturalTranslation: "whom you accuse of betrayal; by whose efforts you see this great and victorious army consumed by hunger without the shedding of your blood; and I have ensured that no state will receive him into its borders as he retreats shamefully in flight."

sentences.latin: Conclamat omnis multitudo et suo more armis concrepat, quod facere in eo consuerunt cuius orationem approbant: summum esse Vercingetorigem ducem, nec de eius fide dubitandum, nec maiore ratione bellum administrari posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Shouts out all the multitude and in their custom with arms they clash, which to do in that case they are accustomed of whom the speech they approve: greatest to be Vercingetorix the leader, nor about his loyalty to be doubted, nor with greater reason the war to be managed to be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Shouts out all the multitude and in their own custom with arms they clash, which to do in that [case] they are accustomed whose speech they approve: supreme to be Vercingetorix the leader, nor about his faith to be doubted, nor by a greater reason the war to be managed to be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The whole multitude shouted and clashed their arms in their customary manner, as they do for a leader whose speech they approve: they declared that Vercingetorix was a supreme leader, that his loyalty was not to be doubted, and that the war could not be conducted with greater skill.

sentences.latin: Statuunt, ut X milia hominum delecta ex omnibus copiis in oppidum mittantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: They decide, that ten thousands of men chosen from all the forces into the town should be sent,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They decide, that ten thousands of men chosen from all the forces into the town be sent,
sentences.naturalTranslation: They decided that ten thousand men, chosen from the entire force, should be sent into the town,

sentences.latin: nec solis Biturigibus communem salutem committendam censent, quod paene in eo, si id oppidum retinuissent, summam victoriae constare intellegebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not to the Bituriges alone the common safety to be committed they think, because almost in this, if that town they had retained, the sum of victory to consist they understood.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor to the Bituriges alone the common safety to be committed they think, because almost in that, if that town they had retained, the sum of victory to consist they understood.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did not think the common safety should be entrusted to the Bituriges alone, because they realized that the final victory almost depended on whether they held that town.

sentences.latin: Singulari militum nostrorum virtuti consilia cuiusque modi Gallorum occurrebant, ut est summae genus sollertiae atque ad omnia imitanda et efficienda, quae ab quoque traduntur, aptissimum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To the singular of our soldiers valor plans of every kind of the Gauls were meeting, as it is of highest kind of cleverness and to all things to be imitated and to be effected, which by each are handed down, most fit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To the singular of our soldiers valor plans of every kind of the Gauls were meeting, as it is of the highest a kind of cleverness and to all things to be imitated and to be effected, which by anyone are handed down, most fit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The extraordinary valor of our soldiers was met by devices of every sort from the Gauls, who are a race of great ingenuity and very well adapted to imitating and carrying out everything they are taught.

sentences.latin: Nam et laqueis falces avertebant, quas, cum destinaverant, tormentis introrsus reducebant, et aggerem cuniculis subtrahebant, eo scientius quod apud eos magnae sunt ferrariae atque omne genus cuniculorum notum atque usitatum est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For both with nooses the hooks they were turning aside, which, when they had fixed, with engines inward they were drawing back, and the mound by mines they were withdrawing, by that more skillfully because among them great are iron-mines and every kind of mines known and practiced is.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For both with nooses hooks they were turning away, which, when they had fixed, with engines inward they were drawing back, and the mound with mines they were withdrawing, by that more skillfully because among them great are iron-mines and every kind of mines known and practiced is.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For they used nooses to turn aside the wall-hooks, which, once secured, they pulled inward with windlasses; they also undermined the siege-mound, doing so with great skill because they have extensive iron mines and every type of mining is well known and practiced among them.

sentences.latin: Totum autem murum ex omni parte turribus contabulaverant atque has coriis intexerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The whole moreover wall from every part with towers they had boarded over and these with hides they had covered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The whole moreover wall from every part with towers they had floored over and these with hides they had covered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Furthermore, they had covered the entire wall on every side with wooden towers and protected these with hides.

sentences.latin: Tum crebris diurnis nocturnisque eruptionibus aut aggeri ignem inferebant aut milites occupatos in opere adoriebantur, et nostrarum turrium altitudinem, quantum has cotidianus agger expresserat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then by frequent daily and nightly sallies either to the mound fire they were bringing or the soldiers occupied in the work they were attacking, and of our towers the height, as much as these the daily mound had raised,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then with frequent daily and nightly sallies either to the mound fire they were bringing or the soldiers occupied in the work they were attacking, and of our towers the height, as much as these the daily mound had raised up,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, by frequent sorties day and night, they either set fire to the mound or attacked the soldiers busy with the work; and as the daily increase of the mound raised the height of our towers,

sentences.latin: commissis suarum turrium malis adaequabant, et apertos cuniculos praeusta et praeacuta materia et pice fervefacta et maximi ponderis saxis morabantur moenibusque appropinquare prohibebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: by joined of their own towers uprights they were equaling, and the opened mines with burnt and sharpened timber and with pitch boiled and of greatest weight stones they were delaying and from the walls to approach they were prohibiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by joined of their own towers uprights they were equaling, and the opened mines with burnt and sharpened timber and with pitch boiled and of greatest weight stones they were delaying and to the walls to approach they were prohibiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: they matched this by adding stories to the uprights of their own towers, and they blocked our open mines with charred and sharpened stakes, boiling pitch, and very heavy stones, preventing us from approaching the walls.

sentences.latin: Muri autem omnes Gallici hac fere forma sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Walls moreover all Gallic of this almost form are.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Walls moreover all Gallic in this almost form are.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Now, almost all Gallic walls are of the following design.

sentences.latin: Trabes derectae perpetuae in longitudinem paribus intervallis, distantes inter se binos pedes, in solo collocantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Beams straight continuous in length at equal intervals, distant between themselves two feet each, on the ground are placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Beams straight continuous in length at equal intervals, distant between themselves two feet, on the ground are placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Straight beams are placed on the ground at equal intervals, two feet apart, along the entire length of the wall.

sentences.latin: Hae revinciuntur introrsus et multo aggere vestiuntur: ea autem, quae diximus, intervalla grandibus in fronte saxis effarciuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These are fastened together inward and with much earth are covered: those moreover, which we said, intervals with large in front stones are filled up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These are fastened together inward and with much earth are clothed: those moreover, which we said, intervals with large in the front stones are stuffed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These are fastened together on the inside and covered with a large amount of earth, while the intervals we mentioned are filled in at the front with large stones.

sentences.latin: His collocatis et coagmentatis alius insuper ordo additur, ut idem illud intervallum servetur neque inter se contingant trabes, sed paribus intermissae spatiis singulae singulis saxis interiectis arte contineantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been placed and joined another on top order is added, so that the same that interval is preserved nor between themselves touch the beams, but by equal having been left spaces single by single stones having been cast between closely they are held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These having been placed and joined another on top order is added, so that the same that interval is preserved nor between themselves touch the beams, but by equal left spaces single by single stones having been placed between closely they are held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When these have been laid and joined, another layer is added on top, maintaining the same interval so that the beams do not touch each other; instead, they are kept at equal distances, each held firmly in place by the stones inserted between them.

sentences.latin: Sic deinceps omne opus contexitur, dum iusta muri altitudo expleatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus in succession the whole work is woven together, until the proper height of the wall is completed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus in succession the whole work is woven together, until the proper of the wall height is completed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this way, the entire structure is built up in layers until the wall reaches its required height.

sentences.latin: Hoc cum in speciem varietatemque opus deforme non est alternis trabibus ac saxis, quae rectis lineis suos ordines servant, tum ad utilitatem et defensionem urbium summam habet opportunitatem, quod et ab incendio lapis et ab ariete materia defendit, quae perpetuis trabibus pedes quadragenos plerumque introrsus revincta neque perrumpi neque distrahi potest.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This work, while in appearance and variety it is not unsightly with alternating beams and stones, which in straight lines keep their rows, then for utility and defense of cities it has the highest advantage, because both from fire the stone and from the ram the timber defends, which with continuous beams forty feet for the most part inward bound together neither can be broken through nor pulled apart.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This while in appearance and variety the work ugly is not with alternating beams and stones, which in straight lines their orders keep, then to the utility and defense of cities the highest it has advantage, because both from fire the stone and from the ram the timber defends, which with continuous beams feet forty for the most part inward fastened neither to be broken through nor to be pulled apart is able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While this design is not unpleasing to the eye with its alternating layers of timber and stone arranged in straight rows, it is also highly effective for the defense of cities. The stone protects it from fire and the timber from the battering ram; since the beams are forty feet long and fastened together on the inside, the structure can neither be breached nor pulled apart.

sentences.latin: His tot rebus impedita oppugnatione milites, cum toto tempore frigore et assiduis imbribus tardarentur, tamen continenti labore omnia haec superaverunt et diebus XXV aggerem latum pedes CCCXXX, altum pedes LXXX exstruxerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these so many things the siege having been hindered, the soldiers, although during the whole time by cold and constant rains they were delayed, nevertheless by continuous labor all these things overcame and in twenty-five days a mound wide 330 feet, high 80 feet they built.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these so many things hindered the siege the soldiers, although in all the time by cold and constant rains they were delayed, nevertheless by continuous labor all these things they overcame and in days 25 a mound wide feet 330, high feet 80 they built.
