sentences.naturalTranslation: Despite the siege being hindered by so many obstacles, and although the soldiers were delayed the entire time by cold and constant rain, they overcame all these difficulties through unremitting labor. In twenty-five days, they constructed a siege ramp 330 feet wide and 80 feet high.

sentences.latin: Cum is murum hostium paene contingeret, et Caesar ad opus consuetudine excubaret militesque hortaretur, ne quod omnino tempus ab opere intermitteretur, paulo ante tertiam vigiliam est animadversum fumare aggerem, quem cuniculo hostes succenderant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When it the wall of the enemies almost was touching, and Caesar at the work by custom was keeping watch and the soldiers was encouraging, lest any time at all from the work be interrupted, a little before the third watch it was noticed to smoke the mound, which by a tunnel the enemies had set on fire,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When it the wall of the enemies almost was touching, and Caesar at the work by custom was keeping watch and the soldiers was encouraging, lest any at all time from the work should be interrupted, a little before the third watch it was noticed to smoke the mound, which by a mine the enemies had set on fire,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the ramp almost touched the enemy's wall, Caesar, who was keeping watch at the works as was his custom and encouraging the soldiers not to lose a single moment, noticed just before the third watch that the ramp was smoking; the enemy had set it on fire from a tunnel.

sentences.latin: eodemque tempore toto muro clamore sublato duabus portis ab utroque latere turrium eruptio fiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and at the same time on the whole wall a shout having been raised from two gates from each side of the towers a sally was being made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and at the same time on the whole wall a shout having been raised from two gates from each side of the towers a sally was being made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same moment, a shout went up along the entire wall, and the enemy made a sally from two gates on either side of the towers.

sentences.latin: Alii faces atque aridam materiem de muro in aggerem eminus iaciebant, picem reliquasque res, quibus ignis excitari potest, fundebant, ut quo primum curreretur aut cui rei ferretur auxilium vix ratio iniri posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Others torches and dry material from the wall onto the mound from a distance were throwing, pitch and remaining things, by which fire can be excited, they were pouring, so that to where first it should be run or to which thing help should be brought scarcely a plan could be formed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Others torches and dry material from the wall onto the mound from a distance were throwing, pitch and remaining things, by which fire to be stirred up is able, they were pouring, so that to where first it should be run or to which thing should be brought help scarcely a plan to be entered upon was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Others were throwing torches and dry wood from the wall onto the ramp or pouring down pitch and other combustibles, so that it was difficult to decide where to run first or what part of the works to defend.

sentences.latin: Tamen, quod instituto Caesaris semper duae legiones pro castris excubabant pluresque partitis temporibus erant in opere, celeriter factum est, ut alii eruptionibus resisterent, alii turres reducerent aggeremque interscinderent, omnis vero ex castris multitudo ad restinguendum concurreret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nevertheless, because by the regulation of Caesar always two legions before the camp were keeping watch and more with divided times were on the work, quickly it was done, that some the sallies should resist, others the towers should draw back and the mound should cut through, all indeed from the camp the multitude to extinguishing should run together.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nevertheless, because by the regulation of Caesar always two legions before the camp were keeping watch and more with divided times were in the work, quickly it was done, that some the sallies should resist, others the towers should draw back and the mound should cut through, all indeed from the camp the multitude to extinguishing should run together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, because Caesar always kept two legions on guard in front of the camp and had others working in shifts, they were able to respond quickly. Some resisted the sallies, others pulled back the towers and cut through the ramp to stop the fire, while the entire force from the camp rushed out to extinguish the flames.

sentences.latin: Cum in omnibus locis consumpta iam reliqua parte noctis pugnaretur, semperque hostibus spes victoriae redintegraretur, eo magis, quod deustos pluteos turrium videbant nec facile adire apertos ad auxiliandum animadvertebant, semperque ipsi recentes defessis succederent omnemque Galliae salutem in illo vestigio temporis positam arbitrarentur, accidit inspectantibus nobis quod dignum memoria visum praetereundum non existimavimus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When in all places, the remaining part of the night now having been consumed, it was being fought, and always for the enemies the hope of victory was being renewed, the more so because they were seeing the burned-up breastworks of the towers and were noticing that [our men] being exposed did not easily approach to bring help, and they themselves fresh were always succeeding the tired and were thinking the whole safety of Gaul was placed in that moment of time, there happened with us watching something which, having seemed worthy of memory, we did not think should be passed over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When in all places consumed now the remaining part of the night it was being fought, and always to the enemies the hope of victory was being renewed, by that more, because the burned screens of the towers they were seeing nor easily to go to the exposed to helping they were noticing, and always themselves fresh to the tired were succeeding and all of Gaul safety in that point of time placed they were thinking, it happened with watching us what worthy of memory having seemed to be passed over not we thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The fighting continued everywhere even as the night drew to a close. The enemy's hope of victory was constantly renewed, especially since they saw the breastworks of our towers had burned away and noticed our soldiers could not easily move up to help while exposed. Fresh troops constantly replaced their exhausted ones, as they believed the entire fate of Gaul hung on that moment. Then, before our very eyes, an event occurred so memorable that I felt it should not be overlooked.

sentences.latin: Quidam ante portam oppidi Gallus per manus sebi ac picis traditas glebas in ignem e regione turris proiciebat: scorpione ab latere dextro traiectus exanimatusque concidit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A certain Gaul before the gate of the town through hands lumps of tallow and of pitch passed into the fire from the region of the tower was throwing: by a scorpion from the side right pierced and killed he fell.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A certain before the gate of the town Gaul through hands of tallow and of pitch handed lumps into the fire from the region of the tower was throwing: by a scorpion from the side right pierced and killed he fell.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A certain Gaul in front of the town gate was taking lumps of tallow and pitch passed to him by hand and throwing them into the fire opposite one of our towers. He was pierced through his right side by a bolt from a scorpion and fell dead.

sentences.latin: Hunc ex proximis unus iacentem transgressus eodem illo munere fungebatur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man from the nearest ones one having stepped over him lying the same that duty was performing;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This man from the nearest one lying having stepped over the same that duty was performing;
sentences.naturalTranslation: One of those standing nearest stepped over his prostrate body and took up the same task;

sentences.latin: eadem ratione ictu scorpionis exanimato alteri successit tertius et tertio quartus, nec prius ille est a propugnatoribus vacuus relictus locus quam restincto aggere atque omni ex parte summotis hostibus finis est pugnandi factus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the same reason, one having been killed by a blow of a scorpion, to the second succeeded a third and to the third a fourth, nor sooner was that place left empty of defenders than, the mound having been extinguished and from every part the enemies having been moved away, an end of fighting was made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the same reason, one having been killed by a strike of a scorpion, a third succeeded to the second and a fourth to the third, nor was that place left empty by the defenders before, the mound having been extinguished and the enemies having been moved away from every part, an end of fighting was made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the same way, when one man was killed by a bolt from a scorpion, a third took the place of the second, and a fourth the place of the third; nor was that spot ever left without defenders until the fire on the mound was put out, the enemy driven back on all sides, and the fighting finally ended.

sentences.latin: Omnia experti Galli, quod res nulla successerat, postero die consilium ceperunt ex oppido profugere hortante et iubente Vercingetorige.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having tried all things, the Gauls, because no thing had succeeded, on the following day took the plan to flee from the town, Vercingetorix encouraging and ordering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having tried all things, the Gauls, because no thing had succeeded, on the following day took a plan to flee from the town, Vercingetorix encouraging and ordering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having tried everything and finding that nothing worked, the Gauls decided the next day to flee from the town, at the encouragement and command of Vercingetorix.

sentences.latin: Id silentio noctis conati non magna iactura suorum sese effecturos sperabant, propterea quod neque longe ab oppido castra Vercingetorigis aberant, et palus, quae perpetua intercedebat, Romanos ad insequendum tardabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This in the silence of night having attempted, with not a great loss of their own they hoped that they would accomplish, because neither far from the town the camps of Vercingetorix were away, and a marsh, which continuous lay between, was slowing the Romans for pursuing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having attempted this in the silence of night, they were hoping that they would effect it not with a great loss of their own men, because neither far from the town the camps of Vercingetorix were away, and the marsh, which continuously lay between, was slowing the Romans for following.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Attempting this in the silence of the night, they hoped to achieve it without great loss to their own men, because Vercingetorixs camp was not far from the town and a continuous marsh lying between them would hinder the Romans in their pursuit.

sentences.latin: Iamque hoc facere noctu apparabant, cum matres familiae repente in publicum procurrerunt flentesque proiectae ad pedes suorum omnibus precibus petierunt, ne se et communes liberos hostibus ad supplicium dederent, quos ad capiendam fugam naturae et virium infirmitas impediret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And already this to do at night they were preparing, when the mothers of families suddenly into public ran forward and weeping, thrown at the feet of their own, with all prayers begged, that not themselves and their common children to the enemies for punishment they should surrender, whom for taking flight weakness of nature and of strengths was hindering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And already they were preparing to do this by night, when the mothers of families suddenly ran out into the public view and weeping, having thrown themselves at the feet of their own men, with all prayers begged, that they not surrender themselves and their common children to the enemies for punishment, whom for taking flight the weakness of nature and of strengths was hindering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They were already preparing to do this at night when the matrons suddenly rushed out into the streets; weeping and throwing themselves at the feet of their husbands, they begged them not to abandon them and their common children to the enemy for punishment, since their natural weakness and lack of strength prevented them from joining the flight.

sentences.latin: Vbi eos in sententia perstare viderunt, quod plerumque in summo periculo timor misericordiam non recipit, conclamare et significare de fuga Romanis coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When them in their opinion to persist they saw, because mostly in the highest danger fear mercy does not receive, to shout and to signal about the flight to the Romans they began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When they saw them to persist in the opinion, because mostly in the greatest danger fear does not receive pity, they began to shout and to signal about the flight to the Romans.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they saw that the men were persisting in their plansince in extreme danger fear usually leaves no room for pitythe women began to shout and signal to the Romans about the escape.

sentences.latin: Quo timore perterriti Galli, ne ab equitatu Romanorum viae praeoccuparentur, consilio destiterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which fear thoroughly terrified, the Gauls, lest by the cavalry of the Romans the roads should be preoccupied, from the plan desisted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Terrified by which fear, the Gauls, lest the roads be preoccupied by the cavalry of the Romans, desisted from the plan.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by this fear that the Roman cavalry might seize the roads ahead of them, the Gauls abandoned their plan.

sentences.latin: Postero die Caesar promota turri perfectisque operibus quae facere instituerat, magno coorto imbre non inutilem hanc ad capiendum consilium tempestatem arbitratus est, quod paulo incautius custodias in muro dispositas videbat, suosque languidius in opere versari iussit et quid fieri vellet ostendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the following day Caesar, the tower having been moved forward and the works having been finished which to make he had determined, a great rain having arisen, not useless this for taking a plan weather he judged, because a little more carelessly the guards on the wall distributed he saw, and his own more slowly in the work to be occupied he ordered and what he wished to be done he showed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the following day, Caesar, the tower having been moved forward and the works having been finished which he had determined to make, a great rain having arisen, thought this storm not useless for taking a plan, because he was seeing the guards on the wall disposed a little more incautiously, and he ordered his own men to be engaged in the work more languidly and showed what he wanted to be done.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, after the siege tower had been moved forward and the works he had planned were completed, a heavy rain began to fall. Caesar thought this a favorable time to carry out his plan, as he noticed the guards on the wall were stationed somewhat carelessly; he ordered his men to go about their work more slowly and explained his intentions.

sentences.latin: Legionibusque intra vineas in occulto expeditis, cohortatus ut aliquando pro tantis laboribus fructum victoriae perciperent, eis qui primi murum ascendissent praemia proposuit militibusque signum dedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And the legions within the sheds in secret having been readied, having encouraged that at last for such great labors the fruit of victory they should receive, to those who first the wall had ascended rewards he offered and to the soldiers the signal he gave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And the legions having been readied in secret within the sheds, having encouraged them that they might at last receive the fruit of victory for such great labors, he proposed rewards for those who first had ascended the wall and gave the signal to the soldiers.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having readied the legions in secret behind the mantlets, he encouraged them to finally reap the fruits of victory in exchange for such great hardships; he offered rewards to those who were first to scale the wall and gave the signal to the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Illi subito ex omnibus partibus evolaverunt murumque celeriter compleverunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They suddenly from all parts flew out and the wall quickly filled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They suddenly from all parts flew out and quickly filled the wall.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They suddenly dashed forward from all sides and quickly manned the wall.

sentences.latin: Hostes re nova perterriti muro turribusque deiecti in foro ac locis patentioribus cuneatim constiterunt, hoc animo ut si qua ex parte obviam contra veniretur acie instructa depugnarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies by the new thing terrified, from the wall and towers cast down, in the forum and places more open in a wedge-formation stood, with this mind that if from any part against them it was come, with a line drawn up they would fight it out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies, terrified by the new thing, having been cast down from the wall and towers, stood in a wedge-formation in the forum and more open places, with this mind that if from any part it was come against them in the way, they would fight it out with a line having been drawn up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by this sudden turn of events and driven from the wall and towers, the enemy formed into wedges in the forum and more open areas, determined to fight in battle formation if an attack was made from any direction.

sentences.latin: Vbi neminem in aequum locum sese demittere, sed toto undique muro circumfundi viderunt, veriti ne omnino spes fugae tolleretur, abiectis armis ultimas oppidi partes continenti impetu petiverunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When no one into level place themselves to descend, but on the whole on all sides wall to be poured around they saw, having feared lest altogether hope of flight might be taken away, with thrown away arms the furthest of the town parts with continuous rush they sought,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When they saw no one to let himself down into the level place, but to be poured around on the whole wall from all sides, having feared lest the hope of flight be taken away entirely, their arms having been thrown away, they sought the furthest parts of the town with a continuous rush,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they saw that no one was descending to level ground, but that the enemy were spreading around the entire wall on all sides, fearing that all hope of escape might be lost, they threw down their arms and rushed in a continuous stream toward the furthest parts of the town.

sentences.latin: parsque ibi, cum angusto exitu portarum se ipsi premerent, a militibus, pars iam egressa portis ab equitibus est interfecta;
sentences.referenceTranslation: and a part there, when in the narrow exit of the gates themselves they were pressing, by the soldiers, a part already having gone out from the gates by the horsemen was killed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and a part there, since they themselves were pressing themselves in the narrow exit of the gates, by the soldiers, a part already having gone out from the gates by the cavalry was killed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some were killed there by the infantry as they crowded one another in the narrow passage of the gates, while others, who had already made it out of the gates, were cut down by the cavalry.

sentences.latin: nec fuit quisquam, qui praedae studeret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor was there anyone, who for booty might be eager.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor was there anyone, who was eager for booty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And there was no one who gave any thought to plunder.

sentences.latin: Sic et Cenabi caede et labore operis incitati non aetate confectis, non mulieribus, non infantibus pepercerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus both by Cenabum's slaughter and by the labor of the work incited, not those by age worn out, not women, not infants they spared.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus incited both by the slaughter of Cenabum and by the labor of the work, they did not spare those finished by age, not women, not infants.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Incensed by the massacre at Cenabum and the toil of the siege, they spared neither the elderly, nor women, nor children.

sentences.latin: Denique ex omni numero, qui fuit circiter milium XL, vix DCCC, qui primo clamore audito se ex oppido eiecerunt, incolumes ad Vercingetorigem pervenerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Finally out of the whole number, which was about of thousands 40, scarcely 800, who the first shout having been heard themselves out of the town threw, safe to Vercingetorix arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Finally out of the whole number, which was about 40 of thousands, scarcely 800, who the first shout having been heard threw themselves out of the town, reached Vercingetorix safe.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Ultimately, out of a total population of about 40,000, barely 800 peoplethose who had fled the town at the first sound of the alarmreached Vercingetorix safely.

sentences.latin: Quos ille multa iam nocte silentio ex fuga excepit, veritus ne qua in castris ex eorum concursu et misericordia vulgi seditio oreretur, ut procul in via dispositis familiaribus suis principibusque civitatum disparandos deducendosque ad suos curaret, quae cuique civitati pars castrorum ab initio obvenerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom he late now at night in silence from the flight received, having feared lest any in the camp from their gathering and the pity of the common people a sedition might arise, so that far off on the road having been stationed his own friends and the leaders of the states to be separated and to be led to their own [people] he took care, which to each state part of the camp from the beginning had fallen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom he late now at night in silence from the flight received, having feared lest any sedition might arise in the camps from their running together and the pity of the common people, so that, his own friends and the leaders of the states having been stationed far off on the road, he took care for them to be separated and led away to their own people, which part of the camps had fallen to each state from the beginning.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He received these fugitives in silence late at night, fearing that their arrival and the common soldiers' pity for them might cause a riot in the camp; he therefore stationed his own friends and the tribal leaders along the road at a distance to ensure they were separated and escorted to the specific sections of the camp that had been assigned to each tribe from the start.

sentences.latin: Postero die concilio convocato consolatus cohortatusque est ne se admodum animo demitterent, ne perturbarentur incommodo;
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the following day a council having been called together he consoled and encouraged [them] that not themselves too much in mind they should cast down, nor they should be disturbed by the setback;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the following day, a council having been called together, he consoled and encouraged them that they not let themselves down in mind very much, nor be disturbed by the inconvenience;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, having summoned a council, he consoled and encouraged them not to be overly discouraged or distressed by the disaster.

sentences.latin: non virtute neque in acie vicisse Romanos, sed artificio quodam et scientia oppugnationis, cuius rei fuerint ipsi imperiti;
sentences.referenceTranslation: not by valor nor in battle-line to have conquered the Romans, but by a certain craft and knowledge of siege-work, of which thing they had been themselves unskilled;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: not by virtue nor in battle line had the Romans conquered, but by a certain artifice and knowledge of siege-craft, of which thing they themselves had been unskilled;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He argued that the Romans had not won through superior courage or in a fair fight, but through a particular skill and knowledge of siegecraft, an art in which the Gauls themselves were inexperienced.

sentences.latin: errare, si qui in bello omnes secundos rerum proventus exspectent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to err, if any in war all favorable of things outcomes should expect.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to err, if any in war expect all favorable outcomes of things.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said they were mistaken if anyone expected only favorable outcomes in war.

sentences.latin: Sibi numquam placuisse Avaricum defendi, cuius rei testes ipsos haberet; sed factum imprudentia Biturigum et nimia obsequentia reliquorum uti hoc incommodum acciperetur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To him never to have pleased Avaricum to be defended, of which thing witnesses themselves he had; but it was done by the imprudence of the Bituriges and the excessive compliance of the rest that this setback was received;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To him never had it pleased Avaricum to be defended, of which thing he was having themselves as witnesses; but it was done by the imprudence of the Bituriges and the too much compliance of the rest that this inconvenience was received;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He reminded them that he had never been in favor of defending Avaricum, a fact to which they themselves could bear witness; rather, it was the lack of foresight on the part of the Bituriges and the over-compliance of the others that had led to this misfortune.

sentences.latin: id tamen se celeriter maioribus commodis sanaturum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: that however he quickly with greater advantages would repair.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: that however he quickly with greater advantages would heal.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He promised, however, that he would quickly repair this loss by gaining even greater advantages.

sentences.latin: Nam quae ab reliquis Gallis civitates dissentirent, has sua diligentia adiuncturum atque unum consilium totius Galliae effecturum, cuius consensui ne orbis quidem terrarum possit obsistere; idque se prope iam effectum habere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For which from the remaining Gauls states were disagreeing, these by his diligence he would join and one council of all Gaul he would effect, to whose consensus not even the circle of lands could resist; and that he nearly now effected had.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For which states from the remaining Gauls were dissenting, these by his diligence he would join and one council of all Gaul he would effect, to whose consensus not even the circle of lands could resist; and that he nearly now had effected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he said he would bring over by his own efforts those states that were still holding aloof from the rest of the Gauls, and would establish a single policy for all Gaul, whose united front not even the whole world could withstand; and he added that he had already nearly accomplished this.

sentences.latin: Interea aequum esse ab eis communis salutis causa impetrari ut castra munire instituerent, quo facilius repentinos hostium impetus sustinerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile fair to be from them of common safety for the sake to be obtained that the camp to fortify they should begin, by which more easily sudden of the enemies attacks they might sustain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile it was fair to be obtained from them for the sake of common safety that they should begin to fortify the camp, by which more easily sudden attacks of the enemies they might sustain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In the meantime, he argued it was only fair to obtain from them, for the sake of their common safety, a commitment to begin fortifying their camp, so that they might more easily withstand sudden attacks from the enemy.

sentences.latin: Fuit haec oratio non ingrata Gallis, et maxime, quod ipse animo non defecerat tanto accepto incommodo neque se in occultum abdiderat et conspectum multitudinis fugerat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Was this speech not unpleasing to the Gauls, and especially, because he himself in spirit had not failed so great having been received setback nor himself in secret had hidden and the sight of the multitude had fled;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This speech was not unpleasing to the Gauls, and especially, because he himself in mind had not failed so great a disadvantage having been received nor himself into secret had hidden and the sight of the multitude had fled;
sentences.naturalTranslation: This speech was not unwelcome to the Gauls, especially because he himself had not lost heart after such a great setback, nor had he gone into hiding or avoided the sight of the people;

sentences.latin: plusque animo providere et praesentire existimabatur, quod re integra primo incendendum Avaricum, post deserendum censuerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and more in mind to foresee and to perceive he was thought, because the matter being whole first to be burned Avaricum, afterwards to be abandoned he had judged.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and more in mind to foresee and to perceive beforehand he was thought, because the matter being whole first to be burned Avaricum, afterwards to be abandoned he had judged.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and he was thought to possess greater foresight and intuition because, while the situation was still undecided, he had first advised that Avaricum should be burned, and later that it should be abandoned.

sentences.latin: Itaque ut reliquorum imperatorum res adversae auctoritatem minuunt, sic huius ex contrario dignitas incommodo accepto in dies augebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore as of other commanders things adverse authority diminish, so of this one on the contrary dignity a setback having been received in days was increased.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so as of other commanders adverse things authority diminish, so of this one on the contrary dignity the disadvantage having been received in days was increased.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, while failure usually diminishes the authority of other commanders, his prestige, on the contrary, increased daily despite the setback.

sentences.latin: Simul in spem veniebant eius adfirmatione de reliquis adiungendis civitatibus; primumque eo tempore Galli castra munire instituerunt et sic sunt animo confirmati, homines insueti laboris, ut omnia quae imperarentur sibi patienda existimarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time into hope they were coming by his affirmation about the remaining to be joined states; and first at that time the Gauls the camp to fortify began and so they were in spirit strengthened, men unaccustomed to labor, that all things which were ordered by them to be endured they thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time into hope they were coming by his affirmation about the remaining to be joined states; and first at that time the Gauls to fortify the camp began and thus they were in mind strengthened, men unaccustomed of labor, that all things which were ordered to themselves to be endured they thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, they were beginning to feel hopeful because of his assurance about bringing in the remaining states; and for the first time, the Gauls began to fortify their camp and were so strengthened in spirit that, although they were men unaccustomed to hard labor, they believed they must endure whatever was commanded of them.

sentences.latin: Nec minus quam est pollicitus Vercingetorix animo laborabat ut reliquas civitates adiungeret, atque eas donis pollicitationibusque alliciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nor less than he promised Vercingetorix in mind was working that the remaining states he might join, and them with gifts and promises he was enticing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nor less than he promised Vercingetorix in mind was working that the remaining states he might join, and them with gifts and promises he was enticing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Vercingetorix worked no less hard than he had promised to bring in the remaining states, and he tried to win them over with gifts and promises.

sentences.latin: Huic rei idoneos homines deligebat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: For this matter suitable men he was choosing,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For this thing suitable men he was choosing,
sentences.naturalTranslation: He selected men suitable for this task,

sentences.latin: quorum quisque aut oratione subdola aut amicitia facillime capere posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom each one either by speech crafty or by friendship most easily to capture might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom each either by speech crafty or by friendship most easily to capture might be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: each of whom was capable of winning others over most easily, either through crafty speech or through personal friendship.

sentences.latin: Qui Avarico expugnato refugerant,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who Avaricum having been stormed had fled back,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who Avaricum having been stormed had fled,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Those who had fled after the storming of Avaricum,

sentences.latin: armandos vestiendosque curat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: to be armed and to be clothed he takes care;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to be armed and to be clothed he cares for;
sentences.naturalTranslation: he saw to it that they were provided with arms and clothing;

sentences.latin: simul, ut deminutae copiae redintegrarentur, imperat certum numerum militum civitatibus, quem et quam ante diem in castra adduci velit, sagittariosque omnes, quorum erat permagnus numerus in Gallia, conquiri et ad se mitti iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: at the same time, so that the diminished forces might be restored, he commands a certain number of soldiers from the states, which and before what day into the camp he wishes to be led, and archers all, of whom there was a very great number in Gaul, to be sought out and to himself to be sent he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: at the same time, so that the diminished forces might be renewed, he commands a certain number of soldiers from the states, which and before what day into the camp to be led he wishes, and archers all, of whom there was a very great number in Gaul, to be sought out and to himself to be sent he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, to replenish his diminished forces, he requisitioned a specific number of soldiers from the states, specifying how many and by what date he wanted them brought to camp; he also ordered that all archers, of whom there was a vast number in Gaul, be rounded up and sent to him.

sentences.latin: His rebus celeriter id quod Avarici deperierat expletur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By these things quickly that which at Avaricum had been lost is filled up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By these things quickly that which at Avaricum had perished is filled up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By these measures, the losses sustained at Avaricum were quickly replaced.

sentences.latin: Interim Teutomatus, Olloviconis filius, rex Nitiobrigum, cuius pater ab senatu nostro amicus erat appellatus, cum magno equitum suorum numero et quos ex Aquitania conduxerat ad eum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile Teutomatus, of Ollovico the son, king of the Nitiobriges, whose father by senate our friend had been called, with a great number of cavalry his own and [those] whom from Aquitania he had hired to him arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile Teutomatus, of Ollovico the son, king of the Nitiobriges, whose father by the senate our friend had been called, with a great number of cavalry his own and those whom from Aquitania he had hired to him arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile Teutomatus, son of Ollovico and king of the Nitiobriges, whose father had been named a friend by our senate, joined him with a large body of his own cavalry and others he had recruited from Aquitania.

sentences.latin: Caesar Avarici complures dies commoratus summamque ibi copiam frumenti et reliqui commeatus nactus exercitum ex labore atque inopia refecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar at Avaricum several days having delayed and a very great supply there of grain and of remaining provision having found the army from labor and want refreshed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar at Avaricum several days having delayed and the greatest supply there of grain and of remaining provision having found the army from labor and want refreshed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar stayed at Avaricum for several days, and having found there a vast supply of grain and other provisions, he allowed his army to recover from their toil and privation.

sentences.latin: Iam prope hieme confecta cum ipso anni tempore ad gerendum bellum vocaretur et ad hostem proficisci constituisset, sive eum ex paludibus silvisque elicere sive obsidione premere posset, legati ad eum principes Aeduorum veniunt oratum ut maxime necessario tempore civitati subveniat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Now nearly winter having been finished when by the very time of year to waging war he was called and to the enemy to set out he had decided, whether him from the marshes and forests to lure out or by siege to press he might be able, ambassadors to him the leading men of the Aedui come to entreat that at a most necessary time the state he help:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Now nearly winter having been finished when by the very time of year to waging war he was called and to the enemy to set out he had decided, whether him from the marshes and forests to lure out or by siege to press he might be able, ambassadors to him the chiefs of the Aedui come to pray that at a most necessary time to the state he might come to help:
sentences.naturalTranslation: With winter now almost over, Caesar was being called to action by the season itself and had decided to march against the enemy, hoping either to lure them out of the marshes and forests or to reduce them by siege; at this point, leading men of the Aedui came to him as ambassadors to beg for his help for their state at a most critical moment.

sentences.latin: summo esse in periculo rem, quod, cum singuli magistratus antiquitus creari atque regiam potestatem annum obtinere consuessent, duo magistratum gerant et se uterque eorum legibus creatum esse dicat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: in highest to be in danger the matter, because, whereas single magistrates from ancient times to be created and royal power for a year to hold they had been accustomed, two the magistracy hold and himself each of them by laws to have been created says.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: in the highest to be in danger the matter, because, when single magistrates from ancient times to be created and royal power for a year to hold they had been accustomed, two the magistracy hold and himself each of them by laws to have been created says.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They explained that their situation was extremely perilous because, while it was their ancient custom to elect a single magistrate who held royal power for one year, two men were now holding office, each claiming to have been legally elected.

sentences.latin: Horum esse alterum Convictolitavem, florentem et illustrem adulescentem, alterum Cotum, antiquissima familia natum atque ipsum hominem summae potentiae et magnae cognationis, cuius frater Valetiacus proximo anno eundem magistratum gesserit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of these to be one Convictolitavis, a flourishing and illustrious youth, the other Cotus, from a very ancient family born and himself a man of highest power and of great kinship, whose brother Valetiacus in the previous year the same magistracy held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of these to be one Convictolitavis, a flourishing and illustrious youth, the other Cotus, from a very ancient family born and himself a man of highest power and of great kinship, whose brother Valetiacus in the nearest year the same magistracy had held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: One of these was Convictolitavis, a distinguished and influential young man; the other was Cotus, born of a very ancient family and himself a man of great power and extensive connections, whose brother Valetiacus had held the same office the previous year.

sentences.latin: Civitatem esse omnem in armis; divisum senatum, divisum populum, suas cuiusque eorum clientelas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The state to be all in arms; divided the senate, divided the people, his own of each of them the client-groups.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The state to be all in arms; divided the senate, divided the people, their own of each of them clienteles.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The entire state was in arms, with the senate divided, the people divided, and each candidate having his own body of followers.

sentences.latin: Quod si diutius alatur controversia, fore uti pars cum parte civitatis confligat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Because if longer is nourished the controversy, it would be that part with part of the state would clash.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Because if longer should be nourished the controversy, it would be that part with part of the state would clash.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For if the dispute were kept up any longer, it was inevitable that one faction of the state would come into conflict with the other.

sentences.latin: Id ne accidat, positum in eius diligentia atque auctoritate.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That this not happen, [it was] placed in his diligence and authority.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That this not happen, [it was] placed in his diligence and authority.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said it depended on his care and influence to prevent this from happening.

sentences.latin: Caesar, etsi a bello atque hoste discedere detrimentosum esse existimabat, tamen non ignorans quanta ex dissensionibus incommoda oriri consuessent, ne tanta et tam coniuncta populo Romano civitas, quam ipse semper aluisset omnibusque rebus ornasset, ad vim atque arma descenderet, atque ea pars quae minus sibi confideret auxilia a Vercingetorige arcesseret,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, although from the war and the enemy to depart detrimental to be he was thinking, nevertheless not being ignorant how great from dissensions inconveniences to arise were accustomed, lest so great and so joined to the Roman people a state, which he himself always had nourished and with all things had adorned, to violence and arms should descend, and that part which less in itself was trusting reinforcements from Vercingetorix should summon,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, although from the war and the enemy to depart detrimental to be he was thinking, nevertheless not being ignorant how great from dissensions inconveniences to arise were accustomed, lest so great and so joined to the Roman people a state, which he himself always had nourished and with all things had adorned, to violence and arms should descend, and that part which less in itself was trusting reinforcements from Vercingetorix should summon,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar thought it detrimental to turn away from the war and the enemy, he was well aware of the great disasters that usually arise from internal strife. He wanted to prevent such a powerful state, so closely allied to Romeone he had always supported and honored in every wayfrom resorting to violence and arms, and to stop the weaker faction from calling on Vercingetorix for help.

sentences.latin: huic rei praevertendum existimavit et, quod legibus Aeduorum eis, qui summum magistratum obtinerent, excedere ex finibus non liceret, ne quid de iure aut de legibus eorum deminuisse videretur, ipse in Aeduos proficisci statuit senatumque omnem et quos inter controversia esset ad se Decetiam evocavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to this matter to be anticipated he thought and, because by the laws of the Aedui for those, who the highest magistracy were holding, to depart from the borders not it was permitted, lest anything from the right or from the laws of them to have diminished he might seem, he himself into the Aedui to set out decided and the senate all and those among whom the controversy was to himself to Decetia he called.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to this matter to be anticipated he thought and, because by the laws of the Aedui for those, who the highest magistracy were holding, to go out from the borders not it was permitted, lest anything from the right or from the laws of them to have diminished he might seem, he himself into the Aedui to set out decided and the senate all and those between whom the controversy was to himself to Decetia he called.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He decided he must attend to this matter first. Since Aeduan law forbade those holding the highest office from leaving their territory, Caesarto avoid appearing to infringe upon their rights or lawsresolved to go to the Aedui himself. He summoned their entire senate and the disputing parties to meet him at Decetia.

sentences.latin: Cum prope omnis civitas eo convenisset, docereturque paucis clam convocatis alio loco, alio tempore atque oportuerit fratrem a fratre renuntiatum, cum leges duo ex una familia vivo utroque non solum magistratus creari vetarent, sed etiam in senatu esse prohiberent, Cotum imperium deponere coegit, Convictolitavem,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When nearly all the state there had come together, and it was shown a few secretly having been called together in another place, at another time than it was proper a brother by a brother [had been] declared [elected], since the laws two from one family while living both not only magistrates to be created were forbidding, but even in the senate to be they were prohibiting, Cotus the power to lay down he compelled, Convictolitavis,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When nearly all the state there had come together, and it was shown a few secretly having been called together in another place, at another time than it was proper a brother by a brother [had been] declared [elected], since the laws two from one family while both living not only magistrates to be created were forbidding, but even in the senate to be they were prohibiting, Cotus the power to lay down he compelled, Convictolitavis,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When almost the entire state had assembled there, it was proved that a small group had been secretly convened at an improper time and place, and that one brother had been declared elected by the other. Since their laws forbade two members of the same family from both holding office or even sitting in the senate while both were alive, Caesar compelled Cotus to resign his power.

sentences.latin: qui per sacerdotes more civitatis intermissis magistratibus esset creatus, potestatem obtinere iussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who through the priests by the custom of the state the magistrates having been interrupted had been created, the power to hold he ordered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who through the priests by the custom of the state the magistrates having been interrupted had been created, the power to hold he ordered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered Convictolitavis, who had been appointed by the priests according to the state's custom when the magistracy was vacant, to hold the office.

sentences.latin: Hoc decreto interposito cohortatus Aeduos, ut controversiarum ac dissensionis obliviscerentur atque omnibus omissis his rebus huic bello servirent eaque quae meruissent praemia ab se devicta Gallia exspectarent equitatumque omnem et peditum milia decem sibi celeriter mitterent, quae in praesidiis rei frumentariae causa disponeret, exercitum in duas partes divisit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: This decree having been interposed having encouraged the Aedui, that of controversies and of dissension they should forget and all having been set aside these things this war they should serve and those which they had deserved rewards from him having been conquered Gaul they should expect and the cavalry all and of infantry thousands ten to him quickly they should send, which in garrisons for the sake of the grain supply he might distribute, the army into two parts he divided:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This decree having been interposed having encouraged the Aedui, that of controversies and of dissension they should forget and all having been set aside these things this war they should serve and those which they had earned rewards from him having been conquered Gaul they should expect and the cavalry all and of infantry thousands ten to him quickly they should send, which in garrisons for the sake of the grain supply he might distribute, the army into two parts he divided:
sentences.naturalTranslation: After issuing this decree, he urged the Aedui to forget their disputes and dissensions and, putting aside all such matters, to devote themselves to the present war. He told them to expect the rewards they deserved from him once Gaul was conquered, and asked them to send him all their cavalry and ten thousand infantry quickly, so he could station them in garrisons to protect the grain supply. He then divided his army into two parts.

sentences.latin: quattuor legiones in Senones Parisiosque Labieno ducendas dedit, sex ipse in Arvernos ad oppidum Gergoviam secundum flumen Elaver duxit; equitatus partem illi attribuit, partem sibi reliquit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: four legions into the Senones and Parisii to Labienus to be led he gave, six he himself into the Arverni to the town Gergovia along the river Allier led; of the cavalry a part to him he assigned, a part for himself he left.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: four legions into the Senones and Parisii to Labienus to be led he gave, six he himself into the Arverni to the town Gergovia along the river Allier led; of the cavalry a part to him he assigned, a part for himself he left.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He gave four legions to Labienus to lead against the Senones and Parisii, while he himself led six into the territory of the Arverni toward the town of Gergovia, following the river Allier. He assigned part of the cavalry to Labienus and kept the rest for himself.

sentences.latin: Qua re cognita Vercingetorix omnibus interruptis eius fluminis pontibus ab altera fluminis parte iter facere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been learned Vercingetorix all having been broken down of that river bridges from the other of the river part a journey to make began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been known Vercingetorix all having been broken down of this river bridges from the other of the river part a journey to make began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Vercingetorix learned of this, he broke down all the bridges on that river and began to march along the opposite bank.

sentences.latin: Cum uterque utrimque exisset exercitus, in conspectu fereque e regione castris castra ponebant dispositis exploratoribus, necubi effecto ponte Romani copias traducerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When each on both sides had gone out army, in sight and almost from the opposite region with camps camps they were placing having been distributed scouts, lest anywhere a bridge having been made the Romans the forces should lead across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When each on both sides had gone out army, in sight and almost from the region with camp camp they were placing having been distributed scouts, lest anywhere a bridge having been made the Romans the forces should lead across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When both armies had set out, they marched in sight of each other, pitching their camps almost directly opposite one another. Vercingetorix posted scouts to ensure the Romans did not build a bridge anywhere and lead their forces across.

sentences.latin: Erat in magnis Caesaris difficultatibus res, ne maiorem aestatis partem flumine impediretur, quod non fere ante autumnum Elaver vado transiri solet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was in great of Caesar difficulties the matter, lest the greater of summer part by the river he might be hindered, because not generally before autumn the Allier by a ford to be crossed is accustomed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was in great of Caesar difficulties the matter, lest the greater of summer part by the river he should be hindered, because not generally before autumn the Allier by a ford to be crossed is accustomed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar's situation was one of great difficulty, as he feared being blocked by the river for the greater part of the summer, since the Allier is generally not crossable by ford before autumn.

sentences.latin: Itaque, ne id accideret, silvestri loco castris positis e regione unius eorum pontium, quos Vercingetorix rescindendos curaverat, postero die cum duabus legionibus in occulto restitit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore, lest that should happen, in a wooded place the camp having been placed from the region of one of those bridges, which Vercingetorix to be broken down had cared for, on the following day with two legions in secret he remained;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so, lest that should happen, in a wooded place the camp having been placed from the region of one of those bridges, which Vercingetorix to be cut down had cared for, on the following day with two legions in secret he remained;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, to prevent this, he pitched camp in a wooded area opposite one of the bridges that Vercingetorix had ordered destroyed, and remained there in hiding the next day with two legions.

sentences.latin: reliquas copias cum omnibus impedimentis, ut consueverat, misit, apertis quibusdam cohortibus, uti numerus legionum constare videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the remaining forces with all the baggage, as he had been accustomed, he sent, having been opened certain cohorts, so that the number of legions to be complete might seem.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the remaining forces with all the baggage, as he had been accustomed, he sent, having been opened certain cohorts, so that the number of legions to be complete might seem.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent the rest of the forces on with all the baggage as usual, but spaced out certain cohorts so that the full number of legions would appear to be present.

sentences.latin: His quam longissime possent egredi iussis, cum iam ex diei tempore coniecturam ceperat in castra perventum, isdem sublicis, quarum pars inferior integra remanebat, pontem reficere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These as furthest as they could to march out having been ordered, when already from the day's time a conjecture he had taken into camp it had been arrived, with the same piles, of which the part lower whole remained, the bridge to rebuild he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These as furthest they could to go out having been ordered, when already from of the day time a conjecture he had taken into camp it had been arrived, with the same piles, of which the part lower whole was remaining, the bridge to rebuild he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having ordered these troops to march as far as possible, and judging by the time of day that they had reached camp, he began to rebuild the bridge using the same piles, the lower parts of which were still intact.

sentences.latin: Celeriter effecto opere legionibusque traductis et loco castris idoneo delecto reliquas copias revocavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly having been finished the work and the legions having been led across and a place for the camp suitable having been chosen the remaining forces he called back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly having been completed the work and the legions having been led across and a place for the camp suitable having been chosen the remaining forces he called back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the work was quickly finished and the legions led across, he chose a suitable site for a camp and recalled the rest of his forces.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix re cognita, ne contra suam voluntatem dimicare cogeretur, magnis itineribus antecessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix the thing having been known, lest against his own will to fight he might be forced, by great marches went ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix the thing having been known, lest against his will to fight he should be compelled, by great marches went ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Vercingetorix learned of this, he moved ahead by forced marches to avoid being forced into a battle against his will.

sentences.latin: Caesar ex eo loco quintis castris Gergoviam pervenit equestrique eo die proelio levi facto perspecto urbis situ, quae posita in altissimo monte omnes aditus difficiles habebat, de expugnatione desperavit, de obsessione non prius agendum constituit, quam rem frumentariam expedisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar from that place on the fifth camp Gergovia reached and a cavalry on that day battle light having been made having been examined the city's site, which placed on a very high mountain all approaches difficult had, about storming he despaired, about a siege not before to be acted he decided, than the grain supply he had secured.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar from that place on the fifth camp to Gergovia arrived and a cavalry on that day battle light having been made having been examined of the city the site, which placed on a very high mountain all approaches difficult was having, about the storming he despaired, about a siege not before to be acted he decided, than the grain supply he had set in order.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar reached Gergovia on the fifth day's march from that spot; after a minor cavalry skirmish on the same day and an examination of the city's positionwhich, being situated on a very high mountain, had difficult approaches on all sideshe gave up hope of taking it by storm and decided not to begin a siege until he had secured his grain supply.

sentences.latin: At Vercingetorix castris, prope oppidum positis, mediocribus circum se intervallis separatim singularum civitatium copias collocaverat atque omnibus eius iugi collibus occupatis, qua despici poterat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Vercingetorix the camp, near the town having been placed, with moderate around himself intervals separately of the individual states the forces he had placed and all of that ridge the hills having been occupied, where it could be looked down upon,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Vercingetorix with the camp, near the town placed, with moderate around himself intervals separately of the individual states the forces he had placed and all of that ridge hills having been occupied, where it could be looked down,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Vercingetorix, meanwhile, had pitched camp near the town and stationed the forces of the individual states separately at short intervals around him; having occupied all the hills of that ridge from which one could look down on the plain,

sentences.latin: horribilem speciem praebebat; principesque earum civitatium, quos sibi ad consilium capiendum delegerat, prima luce cotidie ad se convenire iubebat, seu quid communicandum, seu quid administrandum videretur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: a terrifying sight he was presenting; and the chiefs of those states, whom for himself for a plan to be taken he had chosen, at first light daily to himself to come together he was ordering, whether anything to be communicated, or anything to be administered it seemed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: a horrible sight he was offering; and the chiefs of those states, whom for himself for a plan to be taken he had chosen, at first light daily to himself to come together he was ordering, whether anything to be communicated, or anything to be administered it seemed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: he presented a formidable appearance. He ordered the chiefs of the states, whom he had selected to form his council, to assemble before him every day at dawn to discuss any information or necessary actions.

sentences.latin: neque ullum fere diem intermittebat quin equestri proelio interiectis sagittariis, quid in quoque esset animi ac virtutis suorum perspiceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not any almost day he was letting pass but that by a cavalry battle having been interspersed archers, what in each was of spirit and of courage of his own men he might perceive.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor any almost day he was letting pass but that in a cavalry battle having been interspersed archers, what in each was of spirit and of courage of his own he might see.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Almost every day he would engage in a cavalry skirmish, with archers interspersed among the horsemen, to test the spirit and courage of each of his men.

sentences.latin: Erat e regione oppidi collis sub ipsis radicibus montis, egregie munitus atque ex omni parte circumcisus; quem si tenerent nostri, et aquae magna parte et pabulatione libera prohibituri hostes videbantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was from the region of the town a hill under the very roots of the mountain, excellently fortified and from every part cut off; which if our men should hold, both from a great part of water and from free foraging to prohibit the enemies they seemed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was from the region of the town a hill under the very roots of the mountain, excellently fortified and from every part cut off; which if our men should hold, both from a great part of water and from free foraging to prohibit the enemies they seemed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Opposite the town, at the very foot of the mountain, was a hill, strongly fortified and steep on all sides. It seemed that if our men could take it, they would cut the enemy off from most of their water supply and free foraging.

sentences.latin: sed is locus praesidio ab his non nimis firmo tenebatur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: but that place by a garrison by them not too firm was being held;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: but that place by a garrison by them not too strong was held;
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, the place was held by them with a garrison that was not particularly strong.

sentences.latin: tamen silentio noctis Caesar ex castris egressus, priusquam subsidio ex oppido veniri posset, deiecto praesidio potitus loco duas ibi legiones collocavit fossamque duplicem duodenum pedum a maioribus castris ad minora perduxit, ut tuto ab repentino hostium incursu etiam singuli commeare possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nevertheless in the silence of night Caesar from the camp having gone out, before for help from the town it could be come, the garrison having been dislodged having gained the place two there legions he stationed and a ditch double of twelve feet from the larger camp to the smaller he led, so that safely from a sudden of the enemies attack even individuals to go back and forth could.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nevertheless in the silence of the night Caesar from the camps having gone out, before for help from the town it could be come, the garrison having been dislodged having gained the place two there legions he stationed and a ditch double of twelve feet from the larger camps to the smaller he led through, so that safely from a sudden of the enemies attack even individuals to go back and forth could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, Caesar set out from camp in the dead of night, and before reinforcements could arrive from the town, he dislodged the garrison and seized the position. He stationed two legions there and dug a double ditch twelve feet wide from the larger camp to the smaller one, so that even individual soldiers could move back and forth safely from any sudden enemy attack.

sentences.latin: Dum haec ad Gergoviam geruntur, Convictolitavis Aeduus, cui magistratum adiudicatum a Caesare demonstravimus, sollicitatus ab Arvernis pecunia cum quibusdam adulescentibus colloquitur; quorum erat princeps Litaviccus atque eius fratres, amplissima familia nati adulescentes.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things at Gergovia are being done, Convictolitavis the Aeduan, to whom the magistracy adjudged by Caesar we have shown, solicited by the Arverni by money with certain young men speaks; of whom was the leader Litaviccus and his brothers, from a most distinguished family born young men.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things at Gergovia are carried on, Convictolitavis the Aeduan, to whom the magistracy adjudged by Caesar we have shown, solicited by the Arverni by money with certain young men speaks; of whom was the leader Litaviccus and his brothers, from a most distinguished family born young men.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these events were unfolding at Gergovia, Convictolitavis the Aeduanwhose claim to the magistracy, as we have mentioned, Caesar had upheldwas bribed by the Arverni and entered into talks with certain young men. Their leader was Litaviccus and his brothers, youths born of a most noble family.

sentences.latin: Cum his praemium communicat hortaturque, ut se liberos et imperio natos meminerint.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With these the reward he shares and exhorts, that themselves free and for command born they should remember.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With these the reward he shares and exhorts, that themselves free and for command born they should remember.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He shared the bribe with them and urged them to remember that they were free and born for sovereignty.

sentences.latin: Vnam esse Aeduorum civitatem, quae certissimam Galliae victoriam detineat; eius auctoritate reliquas contineri; qua traducta locum consistendi Romanis in Gallia non fore.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One to be of the Aedui the state, which the most certain of Gaul victory holds back; by its authority the rest are held together; which having been brought over a place of standing for the Romans in Gaul not would be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One to be of the Aedui the state, which the most certain of Gaul victory holds back; by its authority the rest to be held together; which having been brought over a place of standing for the Romans in Gaul not to be going to be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He argued that the Aedui were the only state holding back a certain victory for Gaul; that the other tribes were kept in check by their influence; and that if they were won over, the Romans would have no foothold left in Gaul.

sentences.latin: Esse nonnullo se Caesaris beneficio adfectum, sic tamen, ut iustissimam apud eum causam obtinuerit; sed plus communi libertati tribuere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To be by some of Caesar benefit himself affected, so however, that a most just before him cause he obtained; but more to common liberty he assigns.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To be by some himself of Caesar benefit affected, so however, that a most just before him cause he obtained; but more to common liberty to bestow.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He admitted that he had received some favor from Caesar, though only in so far as he had won a most just case before him; but he insisted that he owed more to the common liberty of his people.

sentences.latin: Cur enim potius Aedui de suo iure et de legibus ad Caesarem disceptatorem, quam Romani ad Aeduos veniant?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Why for rather the Aedui about their own right and about laws to Caesar as arbitrator, than the Romans to the Aedui should come?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Why for rather the Aedui about their own right and about laws to Caesar as arbiter, than the Romans to the Aedui should come?
sentences.naturalTranslation: For why should the Aedui come to Caesar to arbitrate their rights and laws, rather than the Romans coming to the Aedui?

sentences.latin: Celeriter adulescentibus et oratione magistratus et praemio deductis, cum se vel principes eius consili fore profiterentur, ratio perficiendi quaerebatur, quod civitatem temere ad suscipiendum bellum adduci posse non confidebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Quickly the young men both by the speech of the magistrate and by the reward having been led away, when themselves even leaders of that plan to be they professed, a method of accomplishing was being sought, because the state blindly to undertaking war to be led could not they were confident.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Quickly the young men both by the speech of the magistrate and by the reward having been led away, when themselves even leaders of that plan to be going to be they professed, a method of accomplishing was sought, because the state blindly to undertaking war to be led to be able they did not trust.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The young men were quickly won over by the magistrate's speech and the bribe. When they declared they would even lead the plot, they began looking for a way to carry it out, as they were not confident that the state could be easily induced to take up war.

sentences.latin: Placuit ut Litaviccus decem illis milibus, quae Caesari ad bellum mitterentur, praeficeretur atque ea ducenda curaret, fratresque eius ad Caesarem praecurrerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It pleased that Litaviccus over those ten thousands, which to Caesar for the war were being sent, should be put in command and those to be led should care for, and the brothers of him to Caesar should run ahead.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It pleased that Litaviccus over those ten thousands, which to Caesar for the war were being sent, should be put in command and them to be led should care for, and the brothers of him to Caesar should run ahead.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was decided that Litaviccus should be put in command of the ten thousand men being sent to Caesar for the war and should see to their march, while his brothers should hasten ahead to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Reliqua qua ratione agi placeat constituunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The remaining things in what manner to be done it pleases they decide.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The remaining things by what method to be done it pleases they determine.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They decided how the remaining matters should be handled.

sentences.latin: Litaviccus accepto exercitu, cum milia passuum circiter XXX ab Gergovia abesset, convocatis subito militibus lacrimans, "Quo proficiscimur," inquit, "milites?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Litaviccus the army having been received, when thousands of paces about 30 from Gergovia he was away, having been called together suddenly the soldiers weeping, 'Whither do we set out,' he said, 'soldiers?'
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Litaviccus the army having been received, when thousands of paces about 30 from Gergovia he was away, having been called together suddenly the soldiers weeping, "Whither do we set out," he said, "soldiers?"
sentences.naturalTranslation: After taking command of the army, when Litaviccus was about thirty miles from Gergovia, he suddenly called the soldiers together and said, weeping, 'Where are we going, soldiers?'

sentences.latin: Omnis noster equitatus, omnis nobilitas interiit; principes civitatis, Eporedorix et Viridomarus, insimulati proditionis ab Romanis indicta causa interfecti sunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All our cavalry, all the nobility has perished; the leaders of the state, Eporedorix and Viridomarus, accused of treason by the Romans with the cause unpleaded were killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All our cavalry, all the nobility has perished; the leaders of the state, Eporedorix and Viridomarus, accused of treason by the Romans, the cause unpleaded, have been killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All our cavalry and all our nobility have perished; the leaders of our state, Eporedorix and Viridomarus, having been accused of treason by the Romans, were put to death without a trial.

sentences.latin: Haec ab ipsis cognoscite, qui ex ipsa caede fugerunt: nam ego fratribus atque omnibus meis propinquis interfectis dolore prohibeor,
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things from themselves learn, who from the slaughter itself fled: for I my brothers and all my relatives having been killed by grief am prevented,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things from themselves learn, who from the very slaughter fled: for I, my brothers and all my kinsmen having been killed, by grief am prevented,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Learn these facts from those who fled from the slaughter itself; for I, since my brothers and all my relatives have been killed, am prevented by grief,

sentences.latin: quae gesta sunt, pronuntiare." Producuntur hi quos ille edocuerat quae dici vellet, atque eadem, quae Litaviccus pronuntiaverat, multitudini exponunt: multos equites Aeduorum interfectos,
sentences.referenceTranslation: what things were done, to announce. Are brought forward these whom he had instructed what things he wished to be said, and the same things, which Litaviccus had announced, to the multitude they set forth: many horsemen of the Aedui having been killed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "what things were done, to announce." Are brought forward these whom he had instructed what things to be said he wished, and the same things, which Litaviccus had announced, to the multitude they set forth: many horsemen of the Aedui to have been killed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: from reporting what happened. Those whom he had instructed in what he wanted said were brought forward, and they related the same story to the crowd that Litaviccus had told: that many Aeduan horsemen had been killed,

sentences.latin: quod collocuti cum Arvernis dicerentur; ipsos se inter multitudinem militum occultasse atque ex media caede fugisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: because having spoken with the Arverni they were said; themselves they among the multitude of soldiers had hidden and from the middle of the slaughter had fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: because having spoken with the Arverni they were said; themselves they among the multitude of soldiers to have hidden and from the middle of the slaughter to have fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: because they were said to have conferred with the Arverni; and that they themselves had hidden among the mass of soldiers and fled from the midst of the slaughter.

sentences.latin: Conclamant Aedui et Litaviccum obsecrant ut sibi consulat. "Quasi vero," inquit ille, "consili sit res, ac non necesse sit nobis Gergoviam contendere et cum Arvernis nosmet coniungere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cry out the Aedui and Litaviccus they implore that for them he might take counsel. 'As if indeed,' said he, 'of deliberation be the matter, and not necessary it be for us to Gergovia to hasten and with the Arverni ourselves to join.'
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cry out the Aedui and Litaviccus they beseech that for them he should consult. "Quasi vero," said he, "of deliberation should be the matter, and not necessary it should be for us to Gergovia to hasten and with the Arverni ourselves to join."
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Aedui cried out and implored Litaviccus to look out for them. 'As if indeed,' he replied, 'this were a matter for deliberation, and it were not necessary for us to march to Gergovia and join ourselves with the Arverni.'

sentences.latin: An dubitamus quin nefario facinore admisso Romani iam ad nos interficiendos concurrant?
sentences.referenceTranslation: Or do we doubt but that a wicked crime having been committed the Romans already to us to be killed are rushing together?
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Or do we doubt but that, a wicked crime having been committed, the Romans already to us to be killed are running together?
sentences.naturalTranslation: Or do we doubt that, having committed such a heinous crime, the Romans are already rushing here to kill us?

sentences.latin: Proinde, si quid in nobis animi est,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore, if any of spirit in us is,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore, if any of spirit is in us,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, if there is any spirit in us,

sentences.latin: persequamur eorum mortem qui indignissime interierunt, atque hos latrones interficiamus." Ostendit cives Romanos, qui eius praesidi fiducia una erant:
sentences.referenceTranslation: let us avenge of them the death who most unworthily perished, and these robbers let us kill. He pointed out citizens Roman, who of his protection in reliance together were:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: let us avenge of those the death who most unworthily perished, and these robbers let us kill." He points out citizens Roman, who of his protection in reliance together were:
sentences.naturalTranslation: let us avenge the death of those who perished so shamefully and kill these robbers. He then pointed out the Roman citizens who were with him, relying on his protection:

sentences.latin: magnum numerum frumenti commeatusque diripit, ipsos crudeliter excruciatos interficit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: a large number of grain and of supplies he plunders, themselves cruelly tortured he kills.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great number of grain and of provisions he plunders, themselves cruelly tortured he kills.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He plundered a large quantity of grain and supplies, and after cruelly torturing the men, he put them to death.

sentences.latin: nuntios tota civitate Aeduorum dimittit, eodem mendacio de caede equitum et principum permovet; hortatur ut simili ratione atque ipse fecerit suas iniurias persequantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: messengers through the whole state of the Aedui he sends out, by the same lie about the slaughter of the horsemen and of the leaders he agitates; he exhorts that in a similar manner as he himself has done their own injuries they should pursue.
