sentences.originalMITTranslation: Messengers through the whole state of the Aedui he sends out, by the same lie about the slaughter of the horsemen and of the leaders he agitates; he urges that in a similar manner as he himself has done their own injuries they should pursue.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent messengers throughout the entire Aeduan state, agitating the people with the same lie about the slaughter of the cavalry and leaders; he urged them to avenge their wrongs in the same way he had done.

sentences.latin: Eporedorix Aeduus, summo loco natus adulescens et summae domi potentiae, et una Viridomarus, pari aetate et gratia, sed genere dispari, quem Caesar ab Diviciaco sibi traditum ex humili loco ad summam dignitatem perduxerat, in equitum numero convenerant nominatim ab eo evocati.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Eporedorix the Aeduan, from a very high place born a young man and of the highest at home power, and together Viridomarus, of equal age and influence, but of birth unequal, whom Caesar from Diviciacus to himself handed over from a humble place to the highest dignity had led, in the of horsemen number had assembled by name by him summoned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Eporedorix the Aeduan, in the highest place born a young man and of the highest at home power, and together Viridomarus, of equal age and influence, but of birth unequal, whom Caesar from Diviciacus to himself handed over from a humble place to the highest dignity had led, in the of the horsemen number had come together by name by him summoned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Eporedorix the Aeduan, a young man of noble birth and great influence at home, and with him Viridomarus, of equal age and popularity but of lower birthwhom Caesar, having received him from Diviciacus, had raised from a humble position to the highest rankhad joined the cavalry, having been personally summoned by Caesar.

sentences.latin: His erat inter se de principatu contentio, et in illa magistratuum controversia alter pro Convictolitavi, alter pro Coto summis opibus pugnaverant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these there was among themselves concerning the leadership a struggle, and in that of the magistrates controversy the one for Convictolitavis, the other for Cotus with the greatest resources had fought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these there was among themselves about the leadership a struggle, and in that of the magistrates controversy the one for Convictolitavis, the other for Cotus with the greatest resources had fought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a rivalry for leadership between these two, and in the recent dispute over the magistracy, one had fought for Convictolitavis and the other for Cotus with all their resources.

sentences.latin: Ex eis Eporedorix cognito Litavicci consilio media fere nocte rem ad Caesarem defert; orat ne patiatur civitatem pravis adulescentium consiliis ab amicitia populi Romani deficere; quod futurum provideat, si se tot hominum milia cum hostibus coniunxerint, quorum salutem neque propinqui neglegere, neque civitas levi momento aestimare posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From them Eporedorix, having learned Litaviccus's plan, at middle almost night the matter to Caesar reports; he prays that not he allow the state by the depraved of young men plans from the friendship of the people Roman to revolt; which to happen he foresees, if themselves so many of men thousands with the enemies shall have joined, whose safety neither relatives to neglect, nor the state of light importance to value would be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From them Eporedorix having been learned Litaviccus's plan at middle almost night the matter to Caesar reports; he prays that he not allow the state by the depraved of young men plans from the friendship of the people Roman to revolt; which would happen he foresees, if themselves so many of men thousands with the enemies should join, whose safety neither relatives to neglect, nor the state of light importance to estimate would be able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Of these, Eporedorix, having learned of Litaviccuss plan, reported the matter to Caesar around midnight; he begged him not to allow the state to abandon its friendship with the Roman people because of the reckless schemes of young men. He foresaw that this would happen if so many thousands of men joined the enemy, for their relatives could not ignore their safety, nor could the state regard it as a trivial matter.

sentences.latin: Magna adfectus sollicitudine hoc nuntio Caesar, quod semper Aeduorum civitati praecipue indulserat, nulla interposita dubitatione legiones expeditas quattuor equitatumque omnem ex castris educit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: By great affected anxiety by this news Caesar, because always to the of the Aedui state especially he had been indulgent, no interposed doubt with, legions light-armed four and cavalry all from the camp he leads out;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By great affected anxiety by this news Caesar, because always to the Aedui's state especially he had been indulgent, no having been interposed hesitation legions light-armed four and cavalry all from the camp leads out;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Greatly disturbed by this news, because he had always shown special favor to the Aeduan state, Caesar led four light-armed legions and all the cavalry out of the camp without any hesitation.

sentences.latin: nec fuit spatium tali tempore ad contrahenda castra, quod res posita in celeritate videbatur; Gaium Fabium legatum cum legionibus duabus castris praesidio relinquit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor was there space at such a time for to be contracted the camp, because the matter placed in speed seemed; Gaius Fabius the legate with legions two for the camp as a guard he leaves.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: nor was there space at such a time for contracting the camp, because the matter placed in speed seemed; Gaius Fabius the legate with legions two for the camp as a guard he leaves.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was no time at such a moment to reduce the size of the camp, since the situation seemed to depend on speed; he left the legate Gaius Fabius with two legions to guard the camp.

sentences.latin: Fratres Litavicci cum comprehendi iussisset, paulo ante reperit ad hostes fugisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The brothers of Litaviccus when to be arrested he had ordered, a little before he found to the enemies to have fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The brothers of Litaviccus when to be arrested he had ordered, a little before he found to the enemies to have fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he ordered Litaviccus's brothers to be arrested, he discovered that they had fled to the enemy shortly before.

sentences.latin: Adhortatus milites, ne necessario tempore itineris labore permoveantur, cupidissimis omnibus progressus milia passuum XXV agmen Aeduorum conspicatus immisso equitatu iter eorum moratur atque impedit interdicitque omnibus ne quemquam interficiant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having exhorted the soldiers, lest at a critical time by the of the march labor they be disturbed, very eager all with, having advanced miles twenty-five, the column of the Aedui having sighted, sent in the cavalry, the march of them he delays and hinders and forbids to all that not anyone they kill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having encouraged the soldiers, that not at a necessary time by the journey's labor they be disturbed, very eager all having advanced miles of paces 25 the column of the Aedui having sighted having been sent in the cavalry the journey of them he delays and hinders and forbids to all that not anyone they kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After encouraging his soldiers not to be discouraged by the labor of the march at such a critical time, and with everyone being very eager, he advanced twenty-five miles. Sighting the Aeduan column, he sent in the cavalry to delay and hinder their march, and he strictly forbade everyone from killing anyone.

sentences.latin: Eporedorigem et Viridomarum,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Eporedorix and Viridomarus,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Eporedorix and Viridomarus,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Eporedorix and Viridomarus,

sentences.latin: quos illi interfectos existimabant, inter equites versari suosque appellare iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: whom those [men] killed were thinking, among the horsemen to move about and their own [people] to call out to he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: whom they killed were thinking, among the horsemen to move about and their own people to call upon he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered those whom they believed to have been killed to move among the cavalry and call out to their own people.

sentences.latin: His cognitis et Litavicci fraude perspecta Aedui manus tendere, deditionem significare et proiectis armis mortem deprecari incipiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned and Litaviccus's fraud having been seen through, the Aedui hands to stretch out, surrender to signal, and, arms having been thrown down, death to beg off they begin.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been recognized and Litaviccus's fraud having been seen through the Aedui hands to stretch out, surrender to signify and having been thrown down arms death to beg off they begin.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once these facts were known and Litaviccus's treachery was revealed, the Aedui began to stretch out their hands, signal surrender, and, throwing down their arms, beg for their lives.

sentences.latin: Litaviccus cum suis clientibus, quibus more Gallorum nefas est etiam in extrema fortuna deserere patronos, Gergoviam profugit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Litaviccus with his own clients, for whom by the custom of the Gauls a crime it is even in extreme fortune to desert patrons, to Gergovia fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Litaviccus with his clients, for whom by the custom of the Gauls a crime it is even in extreme fortune to desert patrons, to Gergovia fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Litaviccus fled to Gergovia with his retainers, for whom, according to Gallic custom, it is a crime to desert their patrons even in the most desperate circumstances.

sentences.latin: Caesar nuntiis ad civitatem Aeduorum missis, qui suo beneficio conservatos docerent quos iure belli interficere potuisset, tribusque horis noctis exercitui ad quietem datis castra ad Gergoviam movit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, messengers to the state of the Aedui having been sent, who by his kindness [that they were] preserved should show whom by the law of war to kill he could have, and three hours of the night to the army for rest having been given, the camp toward Gergovia moved.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar messengers to the state of the Aedui having been sent, who by his own kindness preserved should show those whom by the law of war to kill he could have, and three hours of the night to the army for rest having been given the camp toward Gergovia moved.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar sent messengers to the Aeduan state to inform them that those whom he could have rightfully executed by the laws of war had been spared by his mercy; then, after giving the army three hours of the night for rest, he moved camp toward Gergovia.

sentences.latin: Medio fere itinere equites a Fabio missi, quanto res in periculo fuerit, exponunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the middle almost of the journey, horsemen by Fabius sent, in how much danger the matter had been, explain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the middle almost of the journey horsemen by Fabius sent, in how much the matter in danger had been, they explain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he was about halfway there, horsemen sent by Fabius arrived and explained how dangerous the situation had been.

sentences.latin: Summis copiis castra oppugnata demonstrant, cum crebro integri defessis succederent nostrosque assiduo labore defatigarent, quibus propter magnitudinem castrorum perpetuo esset isdem in vallo permanendum;
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the greatest forces the camp attacked they show, since frequently fresh [men] to the tired were succeeding and our [men] with constant labor were wearing out, for whom on account of the size of the camp constantly it was for the same [men] on the rampart to be remaining;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With the greatest forces the camp attacked they show, since frequently fresh men to the tired were succeeding and our men by constant labor were wearing out, for whom on account of the size of the camp constantly it was for the same ones on the rampart to be remaining;
sentences.naturalTranslation: They reported that the camp had been attacked by massive forces, as fresh troops frequently relieved the exhausted ones, wearing our men out with unceasing effort, since the size of the camp required the same men to remain on the rampart indefinitely.

sentences.latin: multitudine sagittarum atque omnis generis telorum multos vulneratos; ad haec sustinenda magno usui fuisse tormenta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: by a multitude of arrows and of every kind of missiles many [men] wounded; for these things to be sustained of great use had been the engines.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: by a multitude of arrows and of every kind of missiles many wounded; for these things to be sustained of great use to have been the engines.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They added that many were wounded by a multitude of arrows and missiles of every kind, and that the artillery had been of great use in withstanding these attacks.

sentences.latin: Fabium discessu eorum duabus relictis portis obstruere ceteras pluteosque vallo addere et se in posterum diem similemque casum apparare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Fabius at the departure of them, two having been left gates, to be blocking the others and breastworks to the rampart to be adding and himself for the following day and a similar event to be preparing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Fabius at the departure of them two having been left gates to block up the others and breastworks to the rampart to add and himself for the following day and a similar event to prepare.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They said that Fabius, upon their departure, was blocking all but two of the gates, adding breastworks to the rampart, and preparing himself for the following day and a similar emergency.

sentences.latin: His rebus cognitis Caesar summo studio militum ante ortum solis in castra pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been learned, Caesar with the greatest zeal of the soldiers before the rising of the sun into the camp arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been learned Caesar with the greatest zeal of the soldiers before the rising of the sun into the camp arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned of these events, Caesar reached the camp before sunrise, thanks to the extreme devotion of his soldiers.

sentences.latin: Dum haec ad Gergoviam geruntur, Aedui primis nuntiis ab Litavicco acceptis nullum sibi ad cognoscendum spatium relinquunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things at Gergovia are being done, the Aedui, the first messages from Litaviccus having been received, no for themselves for investigating space leave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things at Gergovia are being done, the Aedui the first messages from Litaviccus having been received no for themselves for investigating space they leave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these events were taking place at Gergovia, the Aedui, upon receiving the first messages from Litaviccus, left themselves no time to investigate the truth.

sentences.latin: Impellit alios avaritia, alios iracundia et temeritas, quae maxime illi hominum generi est innata, ut levem auditionem habeant pro re comperta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Drives some greed, others anger and rashness, which especially to that of men race is innate, so that light hearsay they hold for a thing discovered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Drives some greed, others anger and rashness, which especially to that of men race is innate, so that a light rumor they hold for a thing discovered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Greed drives some, while anger and rashnesstraits deeply ingrained in that race of mendrive others to treat mere hearsay as established fact.

sentences.latin: Bona civium Romanorum diripiunt, caedes faciunt, in servitutem abstrahunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Goods of citizens Roman they plunder, slaughters they make, into slavery they drag away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Goods of citizens Roman they plunder, slaughters they make, into slavery they drag away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They plundered the property of Roman citizens, committed murders, and dragged others away into slavery.

sentences.latin: Adiuvat rem proclinatam Convictolitavis plebemque ad furorem impellit, ut facinore admisso ad sanitatem reverti pudeat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Helps the matter leaning forward Convictolitavis and the common people to madness drives, so that with a crime committed to sanity to return it may shame [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Helps the matter leaning forward Convictolitavis and the common people to madness he drives, so that a crime having been committed to sanity to return it may shame [them].
sentences.naturalTranslation: Convictolitavis encouraged the downward trend and incited the common people to such madness that, once a crime had been committed, they would be too ashamed to return to their senses.

sentences.latin: Marcum Aristium, tribunum militum, iter ad legionem facientem fide data ex oppido Cabillono educunt: idem facere cogunt eos, qui negotiandi causa ibi constiterant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Marcus Aristius, a tribune of soldiers, a journey to the legion making, with faith given from the town Cabillonum they lead out: the same to do they compel those, who for the sake of trading there had settled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Marcus Aristius, a tribune of soldiers, a journey to the legion making, faith having been given, from the town Cabillonum they lead out: the same to do they compel those, who for the sake of trading there had halted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They lured Marcus Aristius, a military tribune traveling to his legion, out of the town of Cabillonum by giving him a pledge of safety; they forced those who had settled there for trade to do the same.

sentences.latin: Hos continuo (in) itinere adorti omnibus impedimentis exuunt; repugnantes diem noctemque obsident; multis utrimque interfectis maiorem multitudinem armatorum concitant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These immediately on the journey having attacked of all baggage they strip; resisting [them] day and night they besiege; many on both sides having been killed a greater multitude of armed men they stir up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These immediately on the journey having attacked of all baggage they strip; resisting [them] day and night they besiege; many on both sides having been killed a greater multitude of armed men they stir up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They immediately attacked them on the road and stripped them of all their baggage; they besieged those who resisted day and night; and after many were killed on both sides, they called up an even larger force of armed men.

sentences.latin: Interim nuntio allato omnes eorum milites in potestate Caesaris teneri, concurrunt ad Aristium, nihil publico factum consilio demonstrant; quaestionem de bonis direptis decernunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile with a message brought all of their soldiers in the power of Caesar to be held, they run together to Aristius, nothing by public plan to have been done they show; an inquiry concerning the goods plundered they decree,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile a message having been brought all of their soldiers in the power of Caesar to be held, they run together to Aristius, nothing by public having been done council they point out; an inquiry about the goods plundered they decree,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, when news arrived that all their soldiers were being held in Caesar's power, they rushed to Aristius and protested that nothing had been done by official decree; they then ordered an inquiry into the plundered property.

sentences.latin: Litavicci fatrumque bona publicant, legatos ad Caesarem sui purgandi gratia mittunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of Litaviccus and of [his] brothers the goods they confiscate, ambassadors to Caesar of themselves clearing for the sake they send.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of Litaviccus and of [his] brothers the goods they confiscate, ambassadors to Caesar of themselves clearing for the sake they send.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They confiscated the property of Litaviccus and his brothers and sent envoys to Caesar to clear themselves of blame.

sentences.latin: Haec faciunt reciperandorum suorum causa; sed contaminati facinore et capti compendio ex direptis bonis, quod ea res ad multos pertinebat, timore poenae exterriti consilia clam de bello inire incipiunt civitatesque reliquas legationibus sollicitant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These [things] they do of recovering their own for the sake; but contaminated by the crime and captured by the gain from the plundered goods, because that matter to many pertained, by fear of punishment terrified plans secretly concerning war to enter they begin and states remaining by embassies they solicit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things they do of recovering their own for the sake; but contaminated by the crime and captured by the gain from the plundered goods, because that matter to many pertained, by fear of punishment terrified plans secretly about war to enter they begin and states remaining by embassies they solicit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did this to recover their own people; however, being tainted by crime and captivated by the profit from the plundered goodsan involvement that extended to manyand terrified by the fear of punishment, they began to make secret plans for war and stirred up the other states with embassies.

sentences.latin: Quae tametsi Caesar intellegebat, tamen quam mitissime potest legatos appellat: nihil se propter inscientiam levitatemque vulgi gravius de civitate iudicare neque de sua in Aeduos benevolentia deminuere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things although Caesar understood, nevertheless as mildly as he can the ambassadors he addresses: nothing himself on account of the ignorance and fickleness of the common people more severely concerning the state to judge nor from his toward the Aedui goodwill to diminish.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things although Caesar understood, yet as mildly as he can the ambassadors he addresses: nothing himself on account of the ignorance and fickleness of the common people more severely about the state to judge nor from his toward the Aedui goodwill to diminish.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar was aware of these developments, he addressed the envoys as mildly as possible, stating that he did not judge the state too severely because of the ignorance and fickleness of the common people, nor was his goodwill toward the Aedui diminished.

sentences.latin: Ipse maiorem Galliae motum exspectans, ne ab omnibus civitatibus circumsisteretur, consilia inibat quemadmodum ab Gergovia discederet ac rursus omnem exercitum contraheret,
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself a greater of Gaul movement expecting, lest by all states he be surrounded, plans was entering in what way from Gergovia he might depart and again all the army he might draw together,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself a greater of Gaul movement expecting, lest by all states he be surrounded, plans was entering in what way from Gergovia he might depart and again all the army he might draw together,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Expecting a greater uprising in Gaul, and fearing he might be surrounded by all the states, he began to consider how he might withdraw from Gergovia and once again concentrate his entire army.

sentences.latin: ne profectio nata ab timore defectionis similis fugae videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: lest the departure born from fear of defection similar to flight might seem.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: lest the departure born from fear of the revolt similar to a flight might seem.
sentences.naturalTranslation: ...lest a departure prompted by fear of revolt should look like a flight.

sentences.latin: Haec cogitanti accidere visa est facultas bene rei gerendae.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To [him] thinking these [things] to happen seemed an opportunity of well the matter carrying out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To [him] these things thinking to happen seemed an opportunity well of the matter conducting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While he was considering these matters, an opportunity for a successful action seemed to present itself.

sentences.latin: Nam cum in minora castra operis perspiciendi causa venisset, animadvertit collem, qui ab hostibus tenebatur, nudatum hominibus, qui superioribus diebus vix prae multitudine cerni poterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For when into the smaller camp for the sake of the work inspecting he had come, he noticed a hill, which by the enemies was being held, stripped of men, which on previous days scarcely because of the multitude to be seen was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For when into the smaller camp of the work inspecting for the sake he had come, he noticed a hill, which by the enemies was being held, stripped of men, which on previous days scarcely because of the multitude to be seen was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For when he had come to the smaller camp to inspect the works, he noticed that a hill which the enemy had previously held was stripped of men, though on previous days it could hardly be seen because of the crowd.

sentences.latin: Admiratus quaerit ex perfugis causam, quorum magnus ad eum cotidie numerus confluebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having wondered he asks from the deserters the cause, of whom a great to him daily number was flocking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having wondered he asks from the deserters the cause, of whom a great to him daily number was flowing together.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Surprised, he asked the reason from the deserters, a great number of whom were flocking to him daily.

sentences.latin: Constabat inter omnes, quod iam ipse Caesar per exploratores cognoverat, dorsum esse eius iugi prope aequum, sed hunc silvestrem et angustum, qua esset aditus ad alteram partem oppidi; huic loco vehementer illos timere nec iam aliter sentire, uno colle ab Romanis occupato, si alterum amisissent, quin paene circumvallati atque omni exitu et pabulatione interclusi viderentur: ad hunc muniendum omnes a Vercingetorige evocatos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was agreed among all, which already himself Caesar through scouts had learned, the ridge to be of that height nearly level, but this [part] wooded and narrow, where there was an approach to the other part of the town; for this place strongly those [men] to fear nor now otherwise to feel, one hill by the Romans occupied, if the other they should have lost, but that almost surrounded and from every exit and foraging shut off they would seem: for this [place] to be fortified all by Vercingetorix [had been] called out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was agreed among all, which already himself Caesar through scouts had learned, the ridge to be of that height nearly level, but this [part] wooded and narrow, where there was an approach to the other part of the town; for this place vehemently those to fear nor now otherwise to feel, one hill by the Romans occupied, if the other they had lost, but that almost surrounded and from all exit and foraging shut off they would seem: to this [place] fortifying all by Vercingetorix [had been] called out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was common knowledge, as Caesar himself had already learned from scouts, that the ridge of that crest was almost level, but that this part was wooded and narrow where there was access to the other side of the town; they feared greatly for this place and felt that, with one hill already occupied by the Romans, if they lost the other, they would be almost surrounded and cut off from all exit and foraging: Vercingetorix had summoned everyone to fortify this spot.

sentences.latin: Hac re cognita Caesar mittit complures equitum turmas; eis de media nocte imperat, ut paulo tumultuosius omnibus locis vagarentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This thing having been learned Caesar sends several of horsemen troops; to them about middle of the night he commands, that a little more riotously in all places they should wander.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This thing having been learned Caesar sends several of horsemen troops; to them about middle of night he commands, that a little more riotously in all places they should wander.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned this, Caesar sent several troops of cavalry; he ordered them to range about in every direction after midnight with a bit more noise than usual.

sentences.latin: Prima luce magnum numerum impedimentorum ex castris mulorumque produci deque his stramenta detrahi mulionesque cum cassidibus equitum specie ac simulatione collibus circumvehi iubet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At first light a great number of pack animals from the camp and of mules to be led out and from these the packs to be pulled off and the muleteers with helmets in the appearance and pretense of horsemen the hills to ride around he orders.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At first light a great number of baggage animals from the camp and of mules to be led out and from these the packs to be pulled off and the muleteers with helmets in of horsemen appearance and pretense the hills to ride around he orders.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At daybreak, he ordered a large number of pack animals and mules to be led out of the camp, their packs removed, and the muleteers, wearing helmets to look like cavalry, to ride around the hills.

sentences.latin: His paucos addit equites qui latius ostentationis causa vagarentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To these a few he adds horsemen who more widely for the sake of show should wander.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these a few he adds horsemen who more widely of display for the sake should wander.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To these he added a few cavalrymen to range more widely for the sake of a demonstration.

sentences.latin: Longo circuitu easdem omnes iubet petere regiones.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By a long circuit the same all he orders to seek regions.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By a long circuit the same all he orders to seek regions.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered them all to head for the same regions by a long detour.

sentences.latin: Haec procul ex oppido videbantur, ut erat a Gergovia despectus in castra, neque tanto spatio certi quid esset explorari poterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things from afar from the town were seen, as there was from Gergovia a view down into the camp, nor at such a distance of certain what it was to be discovered was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things from afar from the town were seen, as there was from Gergovia a view down into the camp, nor at such a distance of certain what it was to be discovered was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These movements were visible from the town, as there was a view from Gergovia down into the camp, but at such a distance it was impossible to discover for certain what was happening.

sentences.latin: Legionem unam eodem iugo mittit et paulum progressam inferiore constituit loco silvisque occultat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: One legion on the same ridge he sends and having advanced a little in a lower he stationed place and with woods hides.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: One legion on the same ridge he sends and having advanced a little in a lower place he stationed and by woods hides.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent one legion along the same ridge and, after it had advanced a short distance, stationed it in a lower position and concealed it in the woods.

sentences.latin: Augetur Gallis suspicio, atque omnes illo ad munitionem copiae traducuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is increased for the Gauls the suspicion, and all thither to the fortification the forces are led across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is increased for the Gauls the suspicion, and all to that place to the fortification the forces are led across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The suspicion of the Gauls was increased, and all their forces were transferred to that fortification.

sentences.latin: Vacua castra hostium Caesar conspicatus tectis insignibus suorum occultatisque signis militaribus raros milites, ne ex oppido animadverterentur, ex maioribus castris in minora traducit legatisque, quos singulis legionibus praefecerat, quid fieri velit ostendit:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Empty the camps of the enemy Caesar having observed, with covered insignia of his men and hidden standards military, scattered soldiers, lest from the town they be noticed, from the larger camp into the smaller he leads across and to the legates, whom over individual legions he had placed in command, what to be done he wishes he shows:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The empty camp of the enemy Caesar having observed, with the insignia of his own [men] covered and the military standards hidden, scattered soldiers, lest from the town they be noticed, from the larger camp into the smaller he leads across and to the legates, whom over individual legions he had placed in command, what he wants to be done he shows:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having observed that the enemy's camp was empty, Caesar covered the insignia of his men and hid their military standards, then moved soldiers in small groups from the larger camp to the smaller one so they would not be noticed from the town; he then explained his plan to the legates he had placed in command of each legion:

sentences.latin: in primis monet ut contineant milites, ne studio pugnandi aut spe praedae longius progrediantur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: among the first things he warns that they should restrain the soldiers, lest by eagerness of fighting or by hope of booty too far they should advance;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: among the first [things] he warns that they should restrain the soldiers, lest by eagerness of fighting or by hope of booty too far they advance;
sentences.naturalTranslation: he warned them first and foremost to keep the soldiers under control, so that they would not advance too far out of an eagerness to fight or hope for plunder;

sentences.latin: quid iniquitas loci habeat incommodi proponit: hoc una celeritate posse mutari; occasionis esse rem, non proeli.
sentences.referenceTranslation: what the inequality of the place has of disadvantage he sets forth: this by speed alone to be able to be changed; of opportunity to be the matter, not of battle.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: what the inequality of the place has of disadvantage he sets forth: this by speed alone to be able to be changed; of opportunity to be the matter, not of battle.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he pointed out the disadvantage caused by the unfavorable terrain, stating that this could only be overcome by speed, and that the situation required a surprise attack rather than a pitched battle.

sentences.latin: His rebus expositis signum dat et ab dextra parte alio ascensu eodem tempore Aeduos mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things having been explained the signal he gives and from the right part by another ascent at the same time the Aedui he sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things having been explained the signal he gives and from the right part by another ascent at the same time the Aedui he sends.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After explaining these points, he gave the signal and at the same time sent the Aedui by another path up the hill on the right.

sentences.latin: Oppidi murus ab planitie atque initio ascensus recta regione, si nullus anfractus intercederet, MCC passus aberat:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of the town the wall from the plain and the beginning of the ascent in a straight line, if no winding intervened, 1200 paces was distant:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of the town the wall from the plain and the beginning of the ascent in a straight line, if no winding intervened, 1200 paces was distant:
sentences.naturalTranslation: In a straight line, if there were no curves in the path, the wall of the town was 1,200 paces from the plain and the start of the ascent.

sentences.latin: quidquid huc circuitus ad molliendum clivum accesserat, id spatium itineris augebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: whatever to this of circuit to softening the slope had been added, that the space of the journey was increasing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: whatever to this of circuit to soften the slope had been added, that the space of the journey was increasing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Whatever distance was added by the winding path to ease the slope increased the length of the journey.

sentences.latin: A medio fere colle in longitudinem, ut natura montis ferebat, ex grandibus saxis sex pedum murum qui nostrorum impetum tardaret praeduxerant Galli, atque inferiore omni spatio vacuo relicto superiorem partem collis usque ad murum oppidi densissimis castris compleverant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From the middle almost of the hill in length, as the nature of the mountain allowed, from large stones a six-foot wall which of our men the attack might slow down had extended the Gauls, and the lower all space empty having been left the upper part of the hill all the way to the wall of the town with very dense camps they had filled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From the middle almost of the hill in length, as the nature of the mountain was allowing, from large stones a six-foot wall which of our [men] the attack might slow down had extended the Gauls, and the lower all space empty having been left the upper part of the hill all the way to the wall of the town with very dense camps they had filled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: About halfway up the hill, the Gauls had built a six-foot wall of large stones running lengthwise as the terrain permitted to slow down our attack; leaving the entire lower space empty, they had filled the upper part of the hill right up to the town wall with very crowded camps.

sentences.latin: Milites dato signo celeriter ad munitionem perveniunt eamque transgressi trinis castris potiuntur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: The soldiers the signal having been given quickly to the fortification arrive and it having crossed three camps they gain possession of;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The soldiers the signal having been given quickly to the fortification arrive and it having crossed three camps they take possession of;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the signal was given, the soldiers quickly reached the fortification, crossed it, and captured three separate camps.

sentences.latin: ac tanta fuit in castris capiendis celeritas, ut Teutomatus, rex Nitiobrigum, subito in tabernaculo oppressus, ut meridie conquieverat, superiore corporis parte nudata vulnerato equo vix se ex manibus praedantium militum eriperet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and so great was in the camps being captured the speed, that Teutomatus, king of the Nitiobriges, suddenly in his tent surprised, as at midday he had rested, with the upper part of his body bare with a wounded horse scarcely himself from the hands of the plundering soldiers snatched away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and so great was in the camps being captured the speed, that Teutomatus, king of the Nitiobriges, suddenly in his tent surprised, as at midday he had rested, with the upper of his body part bare with a wounded horse scarcely himself from the hands of the plundering soldiers he rescued.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The speed in capturing the camp was so great that Teutomatus, king of the Nitiobriges, who had been resting at midday and was surprised in his tent, barely escaped the hands of the looting soldiers with his upper body bare and his horse wounded.

sentences.latin: Consecutus id quod animo proposuerat, Caesar receptui cani iussit legionique decimae, quacum erat, continuo signa constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having followed that which in mind he had proposed, Caesar for a retreat to be sounded ordered and for the legion tenth, with which he was, immediately the standards he halted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having attained that which in mind he had proposed, Caesar for a retreat to be sounded ordered and for the legion tenth, with which he was, immediately the standards he halted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having achieved what he had intended, Caesar ordered the retreat to be sounded and immediately halted the standards of the tenth legion, which was with him.

sentences.latin: Ac reliquarum legionum milites non exaudito sono tubae, quod satis magna valles intercedebat, tamen ab tribunis militum legatisque, ut erat a Caesare praeceptum, retinebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And of the remaining legions the soldiers not having heard the sound of the trumpet, because a sufficiently large valley lay between, nevertheless by the tribunes of the soldiers and the legates, as had been by Caesar commanded, were being held back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And of the remaining legions the soldiers not having heard the sound of the trumpet, because a sufficiently large valley was intervening, nevertheless by the tribunes of the soldiers and the legates, as had been by Caesar commanded, were being held back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the soldiers of the other legions did not hear the trumpet blast because of the wide valley between them, they were nevertheless held back by the military tribunes and legates, as Caesar had commanded.

sentences.latin: Sed elati spe celeris victoriae et hostium fuga et superiorum temporum secundis proeliis nihil adeo arduum sibi esse existimaverunt quod non virtute consequi possent, neque finem prius sequendi fecerunt quam muro oppidi portisque appropinquarunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But elated by the hope of a swift victory and by the flight of the enemies and by of previous times successful battles nothing so difficult for themselves to be they thought which not by valor they could achieve, nor an end sooner of following they made than to the wall of the town and the gates they approached.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But elated by the hope of a swift victory and the of the enemy flight and of previous times successful battles nothing so arduous for themselves to be they thought which not by valor they could attain, nor an end before of following they made than to the wall of the town and the gates they approached.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But elated by the hope of a quick victory, the flight of the enemy, and their past successes in battle, they believed nothing was too difficult for them to achieve through valor; they did not stop their pursuit until they reached the town walls and gates.

sentences.latin: Tum vero ex omnibus urbis partibus orto clamore,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then indeed from all of the city parts having arisen a shout,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then indeed from all of the city parts having arisen a shout,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then, when a shout arose from every part of the city,

sentences.latin: qui longius aberant repentino tumultu perterriti, cum hostem intra portas esse existimarent, sese ex oppido eiecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: those who further away were by the sudden tumult terrified, since the enemy within the gates to be they thought, themselves from the town they threw out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: those who further away were by the sudden tumult terrified, since the enemy within the gates to be they thought, themselves from the town they threw out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: those who were further away, terrified by the sudden uproar and believing the enemy was already inside the gates, rushed out of the town.

sentences.latin: Matres familiae de muro vestem argentumque iactabant et pectore nudo prominentes passis manibus obtestabantur Romanos, ut sibi parcerent neu, sicut Avarici fecissent, ne a mulieribus quidem atque infantibus abstinerent:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Mothers of families from the wall clothing and silver were throwing and with breast bare leaning forward with outstretched hands were imploring the Romans, that themselves they might spare nor, just as at Avaricum they had done, not from women even and infants they should refrain:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The mothers of families from the wall clothing and silver were throwing and with breast bare leaning forward with outstretched hands were imploring the Romans, that themselves they should spare nor, just as at Avaricum they had done, not from the women even and the infants they should refrain:
sentences.naturalTranslation: Matrons began throwing clothing and silver from the wall and, leaning forward with bare breasts and outstretched hands, implored the Romans to spare them and not to slaughter even women and children, as they had done at Avaricum.

sentences.latin: nonnullae de muris per manus demissae sese militibus tradebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: some from the walls by hands let down themselves to the soldiers were handing over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: some from the walls by hands let down themselves to the soldiers were surrendering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Some women, lowered from the walls by hand, surrendered themselves to the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Lucius Fabius, centurio legionis VIII, quem inter suos eo die dixisse constabat excitari se Avaricensibus praemiis neque commissurum, ut prius quisquam murum ascenderet, tres suos nactus manipulares atque ab eis sublevatus murum ascendit: hos ipse rursus singulos exceptans in murum extulit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lucius Fabius, a centurion of the legion eighth, whom among his own on that day to have said it was known to be excited himself by the Avaricum rewards nor would he permit, that sooner anyone the wall should climb, three his own having found fellow-soldiers and by them lifted up the wall he climbed: these he himself in turn one by one taking up onto the wall he pulled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Lucius Fabius, a centurion of legion VIII, whom among his own [men] on that day to have said it was well known to be excited himself by the Avarican rewards nor would he allow, that before anyone the wall should ascend, three of his own having found maniple-mates and by them lifted up the wall he ascended: these he himself in turn one by one taking up onto the wall he raised.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Lucius Fabius, a centurion of the Eighth Legion, who was known to have told his men that day that he was inspired by the rewards offered at Avaricum and would not let anyone scale the wall before him, found three soldiers of his company, was lifted up by them, and climbed the wall; he then reached down and pulled each of them up after him.

sentences.latin: Interim ei qui ad alteram partem oppidi, ut supra demonstravimus, munitionis causa convenerant, primo exaudito clamore, inde etiam crebris nuntiis incitati, oppidum a Romanis teneri, praemissis equitibus magno concursu eo contenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile those who at the other part of the town, as above we have shown, for the sake of fortification had gathered, first having heard the shout, then also by frequent messages incited, the town by the Romans to be held, having sent ahead the cavalry with a great rush there they hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile those who to the other part of the town, as above we have shown, for the sake of fortification had gathered, first having heard the shout, then also by frequent messages incited, the town by the Romans to be held, having sent ahead the cavalry with a great rush to that place they hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, those who had gathered at the other side of the town for the purpose of fortification, as mentioned above, first heard the shouting and were then further incited by frequent reports that the town was being held by the Romans; sending their cavalry ahead, they rushed there in a great mass.

sentences.latin: Eorum ut quisque primus venerat, sub muro consistebat suorumque pugnantium numerum augebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of them as each first had come, under the wall he was standing and of his own fighting [men] the number he was increasing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of them as each first had come, under the wall he was taking a stand and of his own fighting the number he was increasing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As each of them arrived first, he took his stand under the wall and increased the number of his comrades who were fighting.

sentences.latin: Quorum cum magna multitudo convenisset, matres familiae, quae paulo ante Romanis de muro manus tendebant, suos obtestari et more Gallico passum capillum ostentare liberosque in conspectum proferre coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom when a great multitude had assembled, the mothers of families, who a little before to the Romans from the wall hands were stretching, their own [men] to implore and in the Gallic custom disheveled hair to show and children into sight to bring forward began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom when a great multitude had assembled, the mothers of families, who a little before to the Romans from the wall hands were stretching, their own men to implore and in the Gallic custom disheveled hair to show and children into sight to bring forward began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When a great crowd of them had gathered, the matrons, who shortly before were stretching out their hands from the wall to the Romans, began to implore their men, showing their disheveled hair according to Gallic custom and bringing their children forward into view.

sentences.latin: Erat Romanis nec loco nec numero aequa contentio; simul et cursu et spatio pugnae defatigati non facile recentes atque integros sustinebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was to the Romans neither in place nor in number an equal struggle; at the same time both by running and by the duration of the battle exhausted, not easily fresh and whole [men] they were withstanding.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was for the Romans neither in place nor in number an equal struggle; at the same time both by running and by the duration of the fight exhausted, not easily fresh and whole men they were sustaining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the Romans, the struggle was equal neither in position nor in numbers; at the same time, exhausted by running and the duration of the fight, they could not easily withstand fresh and unwearied troops.

sentences.latin: Caesar, cum iniquo loco pugnari hostiumque augeri copias videret, praemetuens suis ad Titum Sextium legatum, quem minoribus castris praesidio reliquerat, misit, ut cohortes ex castris celeriter educeret et sub infimo colle ab dextro latere hostium constitueret,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, when in an unfavorable place to be fought and of the enemies to be increased the forces he saw, fearing for his own [men], to Titus Sextius the legate, whom in the smaller camp for a protection he had left, sent, that the cohorts from the camp quickly he should lead out and under the bottom of the hill from the right side of the enemies he should station,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, when in an unfavorable place to be fought and of the enemies to be increased the forces he saw, fearing for his own men, to Titus Sextius the legate, whom in the smaller camp for a protection he had left, sent, that cohorts from the camp quickly he should lead out and under the lowest hill from the right side of the enemies he should station,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, seeing that the battle was being fought on unfavorable ground and that the enemy's forces were increasing, and fearing for his men, sent word to Titus Sextius, the legate whom he had left in charge of the smaller camp, to lead the cohorts out of the camp quickly and station them at the foot of the hill on the enemy's right flank,

sentences.latin: ut, si nostros loco depulsos vidisset, quo minus libere hostes insequerentur terreret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: so that, if our [men] from the place driven off he had seen, by which less freely the enemies might pursue he might terrify [them].
sentences.originalMITTranslation: so that, if our men from the place driven off he had seen, by which the less freely the enemies might follow he might terrify.
sentences.naturalTranslation: so that, if he saw our men driven from their position, he might deter the enemy from pursuing too freely.

sentences.latin: Ipse paulum ex eo loco cum legione progressus, ubi constiterat, eventum pugnae exspectabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself a little from that place with the legion having advanced, where he had taken a stand, the outcome of the battle was awaiting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself a little from that place with the legion having advanced, where he had taken a stand, the outcome of the fight was awaiting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself, having advanced a little from the spot where he had halted with the legion, awaited the outcome of the battle.

sentences.latin: Cum acerrime comminus pugnaretur, hostes loco et numero, nostri virtute confiderent, subito sunt Aedui visi ab latere nostris aperto, quos Caesar ab dextra parte alio ascensu manus distinendae causa miserat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When most fiercely hand to hand it was being fought, the enemies in place and number, our [men] in valor were trusting, suddenly were the Aedui seen from the side to our [men] exposed, whom Caesar from the right part by another ascent of the hand to be divided for the sake [of] had sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When most fiercely hand-to-hand it was being fought, the enemies in place and number, our men in courage were trusting, suddenly were the Aedui seen from the side for our men open, whom Caesar from the right part by another ascent of the hand to be distracted for the sake of had sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While the battle was being fought most fiercely at close quarters, with the enemy relying on their position and numbers and our men on their valor, the Aedui suddenly appeared on our exposed flank, whom Caesar had sent by another ascent on the right to distract the enemy's forces.

sentences.latin: Hi similitudine armorum vehementer nostros perterruerunt, ac tametsi dextris humeris exsertis animadvertebantur, quod insigne pactum esse consuerat, tamen id ipsum sui fallendi causa milites ab hostibus factum existimabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These by the similarity of arms violently our [men] terrified, and although with right shoulders bared they were noticed, which a sign agreed upon to be had been accustomed, nevertheless that itself of themselves deceiving for the sake the soldiers by the enemies done were thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These by the similarity of arms violently our men terrified, and although with right shoulders bared they were noticed, which a sign agreed upon to be was accustomed, yet that itself of themselves deceiving for the sake of the soldiers by the enemies done were thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These men, because of the similarity of their armor, greatly terrified our troops; and although they were observed with their right shoulders barewhich was the agreed-upon signalthe soldiers nevertheless thought that very thing had been done by the enemy to deceive them.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore Lucius Fabius centurio quique una murum ascenderant circumventi atque interfecti muro praecipitabantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time Lucius Fabius the centurion and [those] who together the wall had climbed, surrounded and killed, from the wall were being thrown down.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time Lucius Fabius the centurion and those who together the wall had climbed, surrounded and killed, from the wall were being thrown down.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, the centurion Lucius Fabius and those who had climbed the wall with him were surrounded, killed, and thrown down from the wall.

sentences.latin: Marcus Petronius, eiusdem legionis centurio, cum portam excidere conatus esset, a multitudine oppressus ac sibi desperans multis iam vulneribus acceptis manipularibus suis, qui illum secuti erant, "Quoniam," inquit, "me una vobiscum servare non possum, vestrae quidem certe vitae prospiciam, quos cupiditate gloriae adductus in periculum deduxi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Marcus Petronius, of the same legion a centurion, when the gate to cut down he had tried, by the multitude overwhelmed and for himself despairing, many now wounds having been received, to his own maniples [men], who him had followed, "Since," he said, "myself together with you to save I am not able, for your indeed certainly lives I will provide, whom by desire of glory led on into danger I led."
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Marcus Petronius, of the same legion a centurion, when the gate to cut down he had tried, by the multitude overwhelmed and for himself despairing, many now wounds having been received, to his fellow-soldiers, who him had followed, "Since," he said, "myself together with you to save I am not able, for your indeed certainly lives I will provide, whom by desire of glory led I into danger have led."
sentences.naturalTranslation: Marcus Petronius, a centurion of the same legion, having attempted to cut down the gate, was overwhelmed by the crowd; despairing for his own life and having already received many wounds, he said to the men of his maniple who had followed him: "Since I cannot save myself along with you, I will at least provide for your lives, whom I have led into danger, driven by a desire for glory."

sentences.latin: Vos data facultate vobis consulite." Simul in medios hostes irrupit duobusque interfectis reliquos a porta paulum summovit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: "You, an opportunity having been given, for yourselves look out." At the same time into the middle of the enemies he burst and, two having been killed, the rest from the gate a little he moved back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "You, an opportunity having been given, for yourselves look out." At the same time into the middle of the enemies he burst and two having been killed, the rest from the gate a little he moved away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: "Take care of yourselves now that you have the chance." At the same time, he charged into the midst of the enemy, and after killing two of them, he drove the rest back a short distance from the gate.

sentences.latin: Conantibus auxiliari suis "Frustra," inquit, "meae vitae subvenire conamini, quem iam sanguis viresque deficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To those trying to help, his own [men], "In vain," he said, "to my life to come to the aid you try, whom already blood and strength fail."
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To those trying to help of his own men, "In vain," he said, "to my life to come to help you try, whom now blood and strengths fail."
sentences.naturalTranslation: To his men who were trying to help him, he said, "In vain do you try to save my life, for blood and strength are already failing me."

sentences.latin: Proinde abite, dum est facultas, vosque ad legionem recipite." Ita pugnans post paulum concidit ac suis saluti fuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: "Therefore go away, while there is opportunity, and yourselves to the legion betake." Thus fighting after a little he fell and to his own [men] for a safety he was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: "Therefore go away, while there is opportunity, and yourselves to the legion take back." Thus fighting after a little he fell and for his own men for a safety he was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: "Therefore, leave while you have the chance and retreat to the legion." Thus fighting, he fell a moment later and saved his men.

sentences.latin: Nostri, cum undique premerentur, XLVI centurionibus amissis deiecti sunt loco.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our [men], when from all sides they were being pressed, 46 centurions having been lost, were driven from the place.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men, when from all sides they were being pressed, 46 centurions having been lost, were driven down from the place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men, being hard-pressed on all sides and having lost forty-six centurions, were driven from their position.

sentences.latin: Sed intolerantius Gallos insequentes legio decima tardavit, quae pro subsidio paulo aequiore loco constiterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But too immoderately the Gauls pursuing the tenth legion delayed, which as a reserve in a little more level place had taken a stand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But too immoderately the Gauls pursuing the tenth legion slowed, which for a reserve in a little more level place had taken a stand.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the Tenth Legion, which had taken up a position on slightly more level ground as a reserve, checked the Gauls as they pursued too recklessly.

sentences.latin: Hanc rursus XIII legionis cohortes exceperunt, quae ex castris minoribus eductae cum Tito Sextio legato ceperant locum superiorem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This [legion] in turn the 13th legion's cohorts took up, which from the smaller camps led out with Titus Sextius the legate had taken a higher place.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This legion in turn of the 13th legion cohorts took up, which from the smaller camp led out with Titus Sextius the legate had taken a higher place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In turn, cohorts of the Thirteenth Legion, which had been led out of the smaller camp with the legate Titus Sextius, covered the Tenth and occupied higher ground.

sentences.latin: Legiones, ubi primum planitiem attigerunt, infestis contra hostes signis constiterunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The legions, when first the plain they reached, with hostile against the enemies standards they stood.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The legions, as soon as the plain they reached, with hostile against the enemies standards they stood.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As soon as the legions reached the plain, they halted and faced the enemy with standards advanced.

sentences.latin: Vercingetorix ab radicibus collis suos intra munitiones reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Vercingetorix from the roots of the hill his own [men] inside the fortifications led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Vercingetorix from the roots of the hill his own men within the fortifications led back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Vercingetorix led his men back from the foot of the hill inside the fortifications.

sentences.latin: Eo die milites sunt paulo minus septingenti desiderati.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On that day soldiers were a little less [than] seven hundred missed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On that day soldiers were a little less than seven hundred missed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On that day, slightly fewer than seven hundred soldiers were reported missing.

sentences.latin: Postero die Caesar contione advocata temeritatem cupiditatemque militum reprehendit, quod sibi ipsi iudicavissent quo procedendum aut quid agendum videretur, neque signo recipiendi dato constitissent neque ab tribunis militum legatisque retineri potuissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the next day Caesar, an assembly having been called, the rashness and greed of the soldiers blamed, because for themselves they had judged to where it must be proceeded or what must be done seemed [fit], and not a signal of retreating having been given they had stopped nor by the tribunes of the soldiers and the legates to be held back they had been able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the next day Caesar, an assembly having been called, the rashness and greed of the soldiers rebuked, because for themselves they had judged where to be advanced or what to be done seemed best, and not a signal of retreating having been given had they stopped nor by the tribunes of soldiers and legates to be held back had they been able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The next day, Caesar called an assembly and reprimanded the soldiers for their rashness and eagerness, because they had decided for themselves how far to advance and what should be done, failing to halt when the signal for retreat was given and refusing to be restrained by the military tribunes and legates.

sentences.latin: Exposuit quid iniquitas loci posset, quid ipse ad Avaricum sensisset, cum sine duce et sine equitatu deprehensis hostibus exploratam victoriam dimisisset, ne parvum modo detrimentum in contentione propter iniquitatem loci accideret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He explained what the inequality of the place could [do], what he himself at Avaricum had felt, when without a leader and without cavalry with the enemies caught he had dismissed a certain victory, lest even a small loss in the struggle on account of the inequality of the place should happen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He set forth what the inequality of the place could do, what he himself at Avaricum had felt, when without a leader and without cavalry the enemies having been caught he had let go a certain victory, lest even a small loss in the struggle on account of the inequality of the place should happen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He explained the disadvantage of the terrain and reminded them of his own decision at Avaricum, where, having caught the enemy without their leader or cavalry, he had foregone a certain victory to avoid even a slight loss in battle due to the unfavorable ground.

sentences.latin: Quanto opere eorum animi magnitudinem admiraretur, quos non castrorum munitiones, non altitudo montis, non murus oppidi tardare potuisset, tanto opere licentiam arrogantiamque reprehendere, quod plus se quam imperatorem de victoria atque exitu rerum sentire existimarent;
sentences.referenceTranslation: By how much work he admired the greatness of their mind, whom not the fortifications of the camp, not the height of the mountain, not the wall of the town had been able to slow down, by so much work he blamed [their] license and arrogance, because they thought themselves to judge more than the commander about victory and the outcome of things;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By how much work he was admiring the greatness of their mind, whom not the fortifications of the camp, not the height of the mountain, not the wall of the town had been able to slow down, by so much work he was blaming their license and arrogance, because they were thinking that they felt more than the commander concerning the victory and the outcome of things;
sentences.naturalTranslation: He stated that as much as he admired their great courage, which neither camp fortifications, nor mountain heights, nor town walls could slow down, he equally condemned their lack of discipline and their arrogance in thinking they knew more than their commander about victory and the outcome of the campaign.

sentences.latin: nec minus se ab milite modestiam et continentiam quam virtutem atque animi magnitudinem desiderare.
sentences.referenceTranslation: nor less did he from the soldier modesty and self-restraint than courage and greatness of mind desire.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not less did he from the soldier desire modesty and self-restraint than valor and greatness of mind.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He added that he expected modesty and self-restraint from a soldier no less than courage and high spirit.

sentences.latin: Hac habita contione et ad extremam orationem confirmatis militibus, ne ob hanc causam animo permoverentur neu quod iniquitas loci attulisset id virtuti hostium tribuerent, eadem de profectione cogitans quae ante senserat legiones ex castris eduxit aciemque idoneo loco constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This assembly having been held and at the end of the speech the soldiers having been encouraged, lest on account of this cause they be moved in mind nor what the inequality of the place had brought that to the courage of the enemies they should attribute, thinking the same things about the departure which before he had felt, he led the legions out from the camp and the battle line in a suitable place he established.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This assembly having been held and at the end of the speech the soldiers having been encouraged, lest on account of this cause they be moved in mind or what the inequality of the place had brought that they should attribute to the valor of the enemies, thinking the same things concerning the departure which he had felt before, he led the legions out from the camp and drew up the battle line in a suitable place.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After holding this assembly and encouraging the soldiers at the end of his speechtelling them not to be discouraged by this setback nor to attribute to the enemy's courage what the unfavorable terrain had causedhe maintained his original plan for departure, led the legions out of camp, and formed a battle line in a suitable position.

sentences.latin: Cum Vercingetorix nihil magis in aequum locum descenderet, levi facto equestri proelio atque secundo in castra exercitum reduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When Vercingetorix nothing more into a level place descended, a light cavalry battle having been made and successful, into the camp the army he led back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When Vercingetorix by nothing more was descending into a level place, a light cavalry battle having been made and successful, he led back the army into the camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Vercingetorix still refused to descend to level ground, Caesar engaged in a minor but successful cavalry skirmish and then led his army back to camp.

sentences.latin: Cum hoc idem postero die fecisset, satis ad Gallicam ostentationem minuendam militumque animos confirmandos factum existimans in Aeduos movit castra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When this same thing on the following day he had done, thinking enough for the Gallic display to be diminished and the minds of the soldiers to be encouraged had been done, into the Aedui he moved the camp.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When he had done this same thing on the following day, thinking enough had been done for the Gallic display to be diminished and the minds of the soldiers to be encouraged, he moved the camp into the Aedui.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having done the same thing the next day, and judging that enough had been done to deflate Gallic pride and reassure his own soldiers, he moved his camp toward the Aedui.

sentences.latin: Ne tum quidem insecutis hostibus tertio die ad flumen Elaver venit; pontem refecit exercitumque traduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not even then the enemies having followed, on the third day to the river Allier he came; the bridge he repaired and the army he led across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not even then the enemies having followed, on the third day he came to the river Allier; he repaired the bridge and led across the army.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the enemy did not follow even then, he reached the river Allier on the third day, repaired the bridge, and led his army across.

sentences.latin: Ibi a Viridomaro atque Eporedorige Aeduis appellatus discit cum omni equitatu Litaviccum ad sollicitandos Aeduos profectum: opus esse ipsos antecedere ad confirmandam civitatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There by Viridomarus and Eporedorix Aeduans having been addressed, he learns with all the cavalry Litaviccus for the purpose of stirring up the Aedui had set out: that there was need for themselves to go ahead for the purpose of strengthening the state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There by Viridomarus and Eporedorix Aeduans having been addressed he learns with all the cavalry Litaviccus to the Aeduans to be stirred up had set out: that it was necessary for themselves to go before to the state to be strengthened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, approached by the Aeduans Viridomarus and Eporedorix, he learned that Litaviccus had set out with all the cavalry to incite the Aedui to revolt; they claimed it was necessary for them to go ahead to keep the state loyal.

sentences.latin: Etsi multis iam rebus perfidiam Aeduorum perspectam habebat atque horum discessu admaturari defectionem civitatis existimabat, tamen eos retinendos non constituit, ne aut inferre iniuriam videretur aut dare timoris aliquam suspicionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Although by many things already the treachery of the Aedui he held perceived and by the departure of these the revolt of the state to be ripened he thought, nevertheless them to be retained he did not decide, lest either to inflict an injury he might seem or to give of fear some suspicion.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Although by many things already he was having the treachery of the Aeduans perceived and by the departure of these he was thinking the defection of the state to be ripened, nevertheless he did not decide they were to be held back, lest either he might seem to bring an injury or give some suspicion of fear.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although he already had clear evidence of Aeduan treachery from many incidents and believed their departure would hasten the state's revolt, he decided not to detain them, so as not to appear to be doing them an injustice or to give any impression of fear.

sentences.latin: Discedentibus his breviter sua in Aeduos merita exposuit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: To them departing briefly his own toward the Aedui services he set forth,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To these departing briefly his own services toward the Aeduans he set forth,
sentences.naturalTranslation: As they were leaving, he briefly reviewed his services to the Aedui,

sentences.latin: quos et quam humiles accepisset, compulsos in oppida, multatos agris omnibus ereptis copiis, imposito stipendio, obsidibus summa cum contumelia extortis,
sentences.referenceTranslation: whom and how humble he had received, driven into towns, punished in lands, all having been snatched away resources, imposed a tribute, hostages with greatest with insult extorted,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: whom and how humble he had received, driven into towns, punished with all fields snatched away, all resources snatched away, a tribute imposed, hostages with the greatest insult extorted,
sentences.naturalTranslation: [He reminded them] whom and how humble he had received them: driven into towns, deprived of their lands, stripped of all resources, burdened with tribute, and their hostages extorted with the greatest insult,

sentences.latin: et quam in fortunam quamque in amplitudinem deduxisset, ut non solum in pristinum statum redissent, sed omnium temporum dignitatem et gratiam antecessisse viderentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and into what fortune and into what greatness he had led [them], so that not only into former state they had returned, but of all times dignity and influence to have surpassed they seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and into what fortune and into what greatness he had led them, so that not only into their former status they had returned, but of all times the dignity and influence to have surpassed they seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: and to what fortune and greatness he had raised them, so that they not only returned to their former state, but seemed to have surpassed the prestige and influence of all previous times.

sentences.latin: His datis mandatis eos ab se dimisit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These having been given instructions them from himself he dismissed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These mandates having been given he dismissed them from himself.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having given these instructions, he dismissed them from his presence.

sentences.latin: Noviodunum erat oppidum Aeduorum ad ripas Ligeris opportuno loco positum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Noviodunum was a town of the Aedui at the banks of the Loire in a convenient place situated.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Noviodunum was a town of the Aeduans at the banks of the Loire in a convenient place positioned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Noviodunum was a town of the Aedui, situated in a convenient position on the banks of the Loire.

sentences.latin: Huc Caesar omnes obsides Galliae, frumentum, pecuniam publicam, suorum atque exercitus impedimentorum magnam partem contulerat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To here Caesar all hostages of Gaul, grain, money public, of his own and of the army baggage a great part had brought;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To here Caesar all the hostages of Gaul, the grain, the public money, of his own and of the army's baggage a great part had brought together;
sentences.naturalTranslation: To this place Caesar had brought all the hostages of Gaul, the grain, the public money, and a large part of his own and the army's baggage;

sentences.latin: huc magnum numerum equorum huius belli causa in Italia atque Hispania coemptum miserat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: to here a great number of horses of this war for the sake in Italy and Spain bought up he had sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to here a great number of horses for the sake of this war in Italy and Spain bought up he had sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: here he had also sent a great number of horses purchased in Italy and Spain for the purpose of this war.

sentences.latin: Eo cum Eporedorix Viridomarusque venissent et de statu civitatis cognovissent, Litaviccum Bibracti ab Aeduis receptum, quod est oppidum apud eos maximae auctoritatis, Convictolitavim magistratum magnamque partem senatus ad eum convenisse, legatos ad Vercingetorigem de pace et amicitia concilianda publice missos, non praetermittendum tantum commodum existimaverunt.
