sentences.referenceTranslation: To there when Eporedorix and Viridomarus had come and about the state of the community had learned, Litaviccus at Bibracte by the Aedui received, which is a town among them of greatest authority, Convictolitavis the magistrate and a great part of the senate to him to have come together, ambassadors to Vercingetorix about peace and friendship to be established publicly sent, not to be overlooked so great an advantage they thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To there when Eporedorix and Viridomarus had come and about the state of the state had learned, Litaviccus at Bibracte by the Aeduans received, which is a town among them of the greatest authority, Convictolitavis the magistrate and a great part of the senate to him to have come together, ambassadors to Vercingetorix concerning peace and friendship to be established publicly sent, they did not think so great an advantage to be overlooked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Eporedorix and Viridomarus arrived there and learned of the state of their communitythat Litaviccus had been received by the Aedui at Bibracte (their most influential town), that Convictolitavis the magistrate and a large part of the senate had joined him, and that ambassadors had been publicly sent to Vercingetorix to establish peace and friendshipthey thought that such a great advantage should not be overlooked.

sentences.latin: Itaque interfectis Novioduni custodibus quique eo negotiandi causa convenerant pecuniam atque equos inter se partiti sunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore having been killed of Noviodunum the guards and who there for the sake of trading had gathered the money and horses among themselves they divided;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore the guards of Noviodunum having been killed and those who to there for the sake of trading had come together the money and the horses among themselves they divided;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having killed the guards at Noviodunum and those who had gathered there for trade, they divided the money and horses among themselves;

sentences.latin: obsides civitatum Bibracte ad magistratum deducendos curaverunt; oppidum,
sentences.referenceTranslation: the hostages of the states to Bibracte to the magistrate to be led they cared for; the town,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the hostages of the states to Bibracte to the magistrate to be led they cared for; the town,
sentences.naturalTranslation: they arranged for the hostages of the various states to be brought to the magistrate at Bibracte; as for the town,

sentences.latin: quod a se teneri non posse iudicabant, ne cui esset usui Romanis, incenderunt;
sentences.referenceTranslation: which by themselves to be held not to be able they were judging, lest to anyone it might be for a use to the Romans, they burned;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which by themselves to be held not to be able they were judging, lest to anyone it be for a use for the Romans, they burned;
sentences.naturalTranslation: because they judged it could not be held by them, they burned it, so that it would be of no use to the Romans.

sentences.latin: frumenti quod subito potuerunt navibus avexerunt, reliquum flumine atque incendio corruperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of grain what suddenly they were able by ships they carried away, the rest by river and by fire they destroyed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of grain what suddenly they were able by ships they carried away, the rest by river and by fire they destroyed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They carried away by ship as much grain as they could on short notice and destroyed the rest by throwing it into the river or burning it.

sentences.latin: Ipsi ex finitimis regionibus copias cogere, praesidia custodiasque ad ripas Ligeris disponere equitatumque omnibus locis iniciendi timoris causa ostentare coeperunt, si ab re frumentaria Romanos excludere aut adductos inopia in provinciam expellere possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Themselves from neighboring regions forces to collect, garrisons and guards at the banks of the Loire to station and cavalry in all places of injecting fear for the sake to display they began, if from the grain supply the Romans to exclude or led by want into the province to drive out they were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They themselves from neighboring regions forces to collect, garrisons and guards at the banks of the Loire to station and cavalry in all places for the sake of inspiring fear to show off began, if from the grain supply the Romans to exclude or led by want into the province to drive out they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They began to gather forces from the neighboring regions, station garrisons and guards along the banks of the Loire, and display their cavalry everywhere to strike fear, hoping they might cut the Romans off from supplies or drive them into the Province through starvation.

sentences.latin: quam ad spem multum eos adiuvabat, quod Liger ex nivibus creverat, ut omnino vado non posse transiri videretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which toward hope much them it was helping, because the Loire from snows had grown, so that altogether by a ford not to be able to be crossed it seemed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which toward hope much them it was helping, because the Loire from snows had grown, so that altogether by a ford not to be able to be crossed it seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this hope they were greatly aided by the fact that the Loire had risen from melting snow, so that it seemed impossible to cross it by fording.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus cognitis Caesar maturandum sibi censuit, si esset in perficiendis pontibus periclitandum, ut prius quam essent maiores eo coactae copiae dimicaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been learned Caesar to be hastened by himself he thought, if it was in completing the bridges to be risked, so that before than were greater there collected forces he might fight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been learned Caesar that it must be hurried by him thought, if it had to be risked in completing the bridges, so that before than were greater there collected forces he might fight.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning this, Caesar decided he must make haste, even if he had to risk the danger of building bridges, so that he could engage in battle before larger forces were gathered there.

sentences.latin: Nam ut commutato consilio iter in provinciam converteret, id ne metu quidem necessario faciendum existimabat; cum infamia atque indignitas rei et oppositus mons Cevenna viarumque difficultas impediebat, tum maxime quod abiuncto Labieno atque eis legionibus quas una miserat vehementer timebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For that with changed plan his march into the province he should turn, that not even by fear necessary to be done he was thinking; since the disgrace and indignity of the matter and the opposed mountain Cevennes and of the roads the difficulty was hindering, then especially because with separated Labienus and those legions which together he had sent vehemently he was fearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For that with changed plan his march into the province he should turn, this not even by fear necessary to be done he was thinking; since the disgrace and unworthiness of the thing and the opposing mountain Cevennes and of the roads the difficulty was hindering, then especially because with Labienus separated and those legions which together he had sent he was vehemently fearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he did not think he should change his plan and turn toward the Province, even under the pressure of fear; not only did the disgrace and indignity of the situation, the barrier of the Cevennes, and the difficulty of the roads prevent it, but he was also deeply concerned about Labienus being separated from him with the legions he had sent.

sentences.latin: Itaque admodum magnis diurnis nocturnisque itineribus confectis contra omnium opinionem ad Ligerem venit
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so very great by day and by night marches having been completed against of all the opinion to the Loire he came.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so very great by day and by night marches having been completed against of all the opinion to the Loire he came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, after completing very long marches by day and night, he reached the Loire, contrary to everyone's expectation.

sentences.latin: vadoque per equites invento pro rei necessitate opportuno, ut brachia modo atque humeri ad sustinenda arma liberi ab aqua esse possent, disposito equitatu qui vim fluminis refringeret, atque hostibus primo aspectu perturbatis,
sentences.referenceTranslation: and a ford through the horsemen having been found for the of the matter necessity suitable, so that arms only and shoulders for sustaining weapons free from water to be were able, with stationed cavalry who the force of the river might break, and the enemies at the first sight having been thrown into confusion,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and a ford through the horsemen having been found for of the matter the necessity suitable, so that arms only and shoulders for sustaining weapons free from water to be were able, with the cavalry stationed who the force of the river might break, and the enemies at the first sight having been thrown into confusion,
sentences.naturalTranslation: A ford was found by the cavalry that was suitable for the emergency, allowing the men's arms and shoulders to remain above water to carry their weapons; the cavalry was stationed to break the force of the current, and the enemy was thrown into confusion at the first sight of them.

sentences.latin: incolumem exercitum traduxit frumentumque in agris et pecoris copiam nactus repleto his rebus exercitu iter in Senones facere instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: safe the army he led across and grain in the fields and of cattle an abundance having found with filled by these things the army a march into the Senones to make he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: safe the army he led across and grain in the fields and of cattle an abundance having found with filled by these things the army a march into the Senones to make he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He led the army across safely, and having found grain in the fields and an abundance of cattle, he provisioned the army and began his march toward the Senones.

sentences.latin: Dum haec apud Caesarem geruntur, Labienus eo supplemento, quod nuper ex Italia venerat, relicto Agedinci, ut esset impedimentis praesidio, cum quattuor legionibus Lutetiam proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: While these things among Caesar are being done, Labienus with that reinforcement, which recently from Italy had come, left at Agedincum, so that it might be for the baggage a protection, with four legions for Lutetia sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: While these things among Caesar are being done, Labienus with that reinforcement, which recently from Italy had come, left at Agedincum, so that it might be for the baggage a guard, with four legions for Lutetia sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While these events were taking place with Caesar, Labienus left the reinforcements that had recently arrived from Italy at Agedincum to guard the baggage, and set out for Lutetia with four legions.

sentences.latin: Id est oppidum Parisiorum, quod positum est in insula fluminis Sequanae.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That is a town of the Parisii, which placed is on an island of the river Seine.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That is a town of the Parisii, which placed is on an island of the river Seine.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This is a town of the Parisii, situated on an island in the river Seine.

sentences.latin: Cuius adventu ab hostibus cognito magnae ex finitimis civitatibus copiae convenerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom the arrival by the enemies having been known, large from the neighboring states forces gathered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whose arrival by the enemies having been known great from neighboring states forces assembled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the enemy learned of his arrival, large forces from the neighboring states assembled.

sentences.latin: Summa imperi traditur Camulogeno Aulerco, qui prope confectus aetate tamen propter singularem scientiam rei militaris ad eum est honorem evocatus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The highest of command is handed over to Camulogenus the Aulercan, who nearly worn out by age nevertheless on account of singular knowledge of military matter to that honor was called out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The sum of command is handed over to Camulogenus the Aulercan, who nearly worn out by age nevertheless on account of singular knowledge of matter military to that honor was called out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Supreme command was given to Camulogenus the Aulercan, who, although nearly exhausted by old age, was nevertheless called to that honor because of his extraordinary knowledge of military affairs.

sentences.latin: Is cum animadvertisset perpetuam esse paludem, quae influeret in Sequanam atque illum omnem locum magnopere impediret, hic consedit nostrosque transitu prohibere instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He when he had noticed continuous to be a marsh, which flowed into the Seine and that whole place greatly obstructed, here he settled and our [men] from crossing to prevent he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He when he had noticed continuous to be a marsh, which flowed into the Seine and that whole place greatly was hindering, here he settled and our men from the crossing to prohibit he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he noticed that there was a continuous marsh which flowed into the Seine and greatly obstructed the whole area, he took up a position there and determined to prevent our men from crossing.

sentences.latin: Labienus primo vineas agere, cratibus atque aggere paludem explere atque iter munire conabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus at first sheds to move forward, with hurdles and a mound the marsh to fill up and a path to build was trying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus at first mantlets to move, with hurdles and a mound the marsh to fill and a way to build was trying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At first, Labienus tried to move forward mantlets, fill up the marsh with hurdles and earth, and construct a roadway.

sentences.latin: Postquam id difficilius confieri animadvertit, silentio e castris tertia vigilia egressus eodem quo venerat itinere Metiosedum pervenit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: After that more difficult to be accomplished he noticed, in silence from the camp in the third watch having set out by the same by which he had come route to Metiosedum he arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: After that it more difficult to be accomplished he noticed, in silence from the camp at the third watch having gone out by the same by which he had come route to Metiosedum he arrived.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After he noticed that this was too difficult to accomplish, he set out from the camp in silence during the third watch and reached Metiosedum by the same route he had come.

sentences.latin: Id est oppidum Senonum in insula Sequanae positum, ut paulo ante de Lutetia diximus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That is a town of the Senones on an island of the Seine placed, as a little before about Lutetia we said.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That is a town of the Senones on an island of the Seine placed, as a little before about Lutetia we said.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This is a town of the Senones, situated on an island in the Seine, just as we said a little earlier regarding Lutetia.

sentences.latin: Deprensis navibus circiter quinquaginta celeriterque coniunctis atque eo militibus iniectis et rei novitate perterritis oppidanis, quorum magna pars erat ad bellum evocata, sine contentione oppido potitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been seized ships about fifty and quickly joined together and there soldiers thrown in and by the novelty of the thing terrified the townsmen, of whom a large part had been to war called out, without a struggle of the town he gains possession.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having seized ships about fifty and quickly joined and there soldiers having been thrown in and by the of the thing novelty terrified townspeople, of whom a great part had been to war called out, without a struggle of the town he gets possession.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having seized about fifty ships and quickly joined them together, he put soldiers on board; the townsmen, many of whom had been called away to the war, were terrified by the novelty of the situation, and he took possession of the town without a struggle.

sentences.latin: Refecto ponte, quem superioribus diebus hostes resciderant, exercitum traducit et secundo flumine ad Lutetiam iter facere coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been repaired the bridge, which in previous days the enemies had cut down, the army he leads across and with the following river toward Lutetia a march to make he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having repaired the bridge, which in previous days the enemies had cut down, the army he leads across and following the river toward Lutetia a march to make he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After repairing the bridge which the enemy had broken down in previous days, he led his army across and began to march toward Lutetia downstream.

sentences.latin: Hostes re cognita ab eis, qui Metiosedo fugerant, Lutetiam incendi pontesque eius oppidi rescindi iubent; ipsi profecti a palude ad ripas Sequanae e regione Lutetiae contra Labieni castra considunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies the thing having been known from those, who from Metiosedum had fled, Lutetia to be set on fire and the bridges of that town to be cut down they order; themselves having set out from the marsh to the banks of the Seine from the region of Lutetia opposite Labienus's camp they settle.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemies the thing having been known from those, who from Metiosedum had fled, Lutetia to be burned and the bridges of that town to be cut down they order; they themselves having set out from the marsh to the banks of the Seine from the region of Lutetia opposite Labienus's camp they settle.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the enemy learned what had happened from those who had fled from Metiosedum, they ordered Lutetia to be set on fire and its bridges to be destroyed; they themselves set out from the marsh and encamped on the banks of the Seine opposite Lutetia, facing Labienus's camp.

sentences.latin: Iam Caesar a Gergovia discessisse audiebatur, iam de Aeduorum defectione et secundo Galliae motu rumores adferebantur, Gallique in colloquiis interclusum itinere et Ligeri Caesarem inopia frumenti coactum in provinciam contendisse confirmabant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Now Caesar from Gergovia to have departed was heard, now about of the Aedui the revolt and the successful of Gaul movement rumors were being brought, and the Gauls in conversations cut off from the route and the Loire Caesar by lack of grain forced into the province to have hastened were asserting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Now Caesar from Gergovia to have departed was being heard, now about of the Aedui the revolt and a second of Gaul uprising rumors were being brought, and the Gauls in conversations shut off from the route and the Loire Caesar by lack of grain forced into the province to have hastened were asserting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By now it was being heard that Caesar had retreated from Gergovia, and rumors were spreading about the revolt of the Aedui and the successful uprising in Gaul; the Gauls, in their parleys, were asserting that Caesar, cut off from his route and the Loire and forced by a lack of grain, had hurried toward the Province.

sentences.latin: Bellovaci autem defectione Aeduorum cognita, qui ante erant per se infideles, manus cogere atque aperte bellum parare coeperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Bellovaci however, the revolt of the Aedui having been known, who before were by themselves unfaithful, bands to collect and openly war to prepare began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Bellovaci however, the revolt of the Aedui having been learned, who before were by themselves unfaithful, bands to collect and openly war to prepare began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, the Bellovaci, upon learning of the revolt of the Aeduiwho even before this had been untrustworthy on their own accountbegan to collect forces and openly prepare for war.

sentences.latin: Tum Labienus tanta rerum commutatione longe aliud sibi capiendum consilium atque antea senserat intellegebat,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then Labienus by so great of things change, far another by him to be taken plan than before he had felt, understood,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then Labienus, by so great a change of things, far another plan by him to be taken than before he had felt, understood,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Then Labienus, seeing such a great change in circumstances, realized that he had to adopt a far different plan than he had previously intended,

sentences.latin: neque iam, ut aliquid adquireret proelioque hostes lacesseret, sed ut incolumem exercitum Agedincum reduceret, cogitabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not now, that something he might gain and in battle the enemy he might provoke, but that safe the army to Agedincum he might lead back, he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and no longer, that something he might acquire and in battle the enemy provoke, but that safe the army to Agedincum he might lead back, he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: he was no longer thinking of making gains or provoking the enemy to battle, but of how to lead his army back safely to Agedincum.

sentences.latin: Namque altera ex parte Bellovaci, quae civitas in Gallia maximam habet opinionem virtutis, instabant, alteram Camulogenus parato atque instructo exercitu tenebat; tum legiones a praesidio atque impedimentis interclusas maximum flumen distinebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For on one from part the Bellovaci, which state in Gaul the greatest has reputation of valor, were pressing on, the other Camulogenus with a prepared and drawn up army was holding; then the legions from the garrison and the baggage cut off a very great river was keeping apart.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For on one part the Bellovaci, which state in Gaul the greatest has reputation of valor, were pressing on, the other Camulogenus with a prepared and drawn up army was holding; then the legions from the garrison and baggage cut off a very great river was keeping away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For on one side the Bellovaci, a state with the highest reputation for valor in Gaul, were pressing on; on the other, Camulogenus held the position with a prepared and well-equipped army; meanwhile, a massive river separated the legions, cut off from their garrison and baggage.

sentences.latin: Tantis subito difficultatibus obiectis ab animi virtute auxilium petendum videbat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: So great suddenly difficulties having been thrown in the way, from of the mind valor help to be sought he saw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: So great suddenly difficulties having been thrown in the way, from the mind's valor help to be sought he saw.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Faced with such sudden and immense difficulties, he saw that he must seek help from his own courage.

sentences.latin: Omni Gallia devicta Caesar cum a superiore aestate nullum bellandi tempus intermisisset militesque hibernorum quiete reficere a tantis laboribus vellet, complures eodem tempore civitates renovare belli consilia nuntiabantur coniurationesque facere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: All Gaul having been subdued, Caesar since from the previous summer no of warring time he had let pass and the soldiers with of winter-quarters rest to refresh from so great labors he wished, several at the same time states to renew of war plans were reported and conspiracies to make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All Gaul having been conquered, Caesar, since from the previous summer no time of warring he had let pass and the soldiers with the rest of winter quarters to refresh from so great labors he wished, several at the same time states to renew plans of war were reported and conspiracies to make.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After all Gaul had been subdued, Caesar, although he had not paused from campaigning since the previous summer and wished to let his soldiers recover from their great labors in the quiet of winter quarters, received reports that several states were simultaneously renewing their plans for war and forming conspiracies.

sentences.latin: Cuius rei verisimilis causa adferebatur, quod Gallis omnibus cognitum esset neque ulla multitudine in unum locum coacta resisti posse Romanis, nec, si diversa bella complures eodem tempore intulissent civitates, satis auxili aut spati aut copiarum habiturum exercitum populi Romani ad omnia persequenda; non esse autem alicui civitati sortem incommodi recusandam, si tali mora reliquae possent se vindicare in libertatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which thing a likely cause was being brought forward, because to Gauls all known it was neither by any multitude into one place collected to be resisted was possible to the Romans, nor, if diverse wars several at the same time had brought on states, enough of help or of time or of forces would have the army of the people Roman for all things to be pursued; not to be however for any state the lot of misfortune to be refused, if by such delay the rest could themselves restore into liberty.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of which thing a likely cause was brought forward, because to Gauls all known it was that neither by any multitude into one place collected could it be resisted to the Romans, nor, if different wars several at the same time had brought states, enough of help or of time or of troops would have the army of the Roman people for all things to be pursued; that not to be however for any state the lot of trouble to be refused, if by such delay the rest could themselves restore into liberty.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A plausible reason for this was offered: all the Gauls realized that they could not resist the Romans with any force concentrated in one place, but if several states launched separate wars simultaneously, the Roman army would lack the reinforcements, time, and resources to deal with them all; furthermore, no state should refuse its share of hardship if such a delay allowed the rest to regain their freedom.

sentences.latin: Quae ne opinio Gallorum confirmaretur, Caesar Marcum Antonium quaestorem suis praefecit hibernis; ipse equitum praesidio pridie Kal.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which lest opinion of the Gauls should be confirmed, Caesar Marcus Antonius the quaestor over his winter quarters placed; he himself with of horsemen a guard on the day before the Kalends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which lest opinion of the Gauls should be confirmed, Caesar Marcus Antonius the quaestor over his winter quarters placed; he himself with a guard of cavalry on the day before the Kalends
sentences.naturalTranslation: To prevent this belief of the Gauls from being confirmed, Caesar placed Marcus Antonius the quaestor in charge of his winter quarters; he himself, with a cavalry escort, on the day before the Kalends...

sentences.latin: Ianuarias ab oppido Bibracte proficiscitur ad legionem XIII, quam non longe a finibus Aeduorum collocaverat in finibus Biturigum, eique adiungit legionem XI, quae proxima fuerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of January from the town Bibracte sets out to the legion XIII, which not far from the borders of the Aedui he had stationed in the borders of the Bituriges, and to it joins the legion XI, which nearest had been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of January from the town Bibracte sets out to the 13th legion, which not far from the borders of the Aedui he had stationed in the borders of the Bituriges, and to it joins the 11th legion, which nearest had been.
sentences.naturalTranslation: ...of January, set out from the town of Bibracte to the Thirteenth Legion, which he had stationed in the territory of the Bituriges not far from the borders of the Aedui, and joined to it the Eleventh Legion, which was the nearest.

sentences.latin: Binis cohortibus ad impedimenta tuenda relictis reliquum exercitum in copiosissimos agros Biturigum inducit, qui, cum latos fines et complura oppida haberent, unius legionis hibernis non potuerint contineri quin bellum pararent coniurationesque facerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Two each cohorts for the baggage to be protected having been left, the remaining army into the most fertile fields of the Bituriges he leads, who, since broad borders and several towns they had, of one legion by the winter quarters not they could be contained but that war they would prepare and conspiracies make.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Two cohorts each for the baggage to be protected having been left, the rest of the army into the most fertile fields of the Bituriges he leads, who, since wide borders and several towns they had, by one legion's winter quarters not were able to be contained but that war they prepared and conspiracies made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Leaving two cohorts from each legion to guard the baggage, he led the rest of the army into the highly productive lands of the Bituriges; because they possessed extensive territory and many towns, they could not be kept in check by the winter quarters of a single legion, but were preparing for war and forming conspiracies.

sentences.latin: Repentino adventu Caesaris accidit, quod imparatis disiectisque accidere fuit necesse, ut sine timore ullo rura colentes prius ab equitatu opprimerentur quam confugere in oppida possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By the sudden arrival of Caesar it happened, which to the unprepared and scattered to happen was necessary, that without fear any the fields cultivating sooner by the cavalry they were overwhelmed than to flee into towns they were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By the sudden arrival of Caesar it happened, which to the unprepared and scattered to happen was necessary, that without fear any the fields tilling sooner by the cavalry were overwhelmed than to flee into towns they were able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because of Caesar's sudden arrival, it happenedas was inevitable for people caught unprepared and scatteredthat those working the fields without any fear were overwhelmed by the cavalry before they could flee into the towns.

sentences.latin: Namque etiam illud vulgare incursionis hostium signum, quod incendiis aedificiorum intellegi consuevit, Caesaris erat interdicto sublatum, ne aut copia pabuli frumentique, si longius progredi vellet, deficeretur, aut hostes incendiis terrerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For also that common of an incursion of enemies sign, which by the burnings of buildings to be understood was accustomed, by Caesar's prohibition had been removed, lest either the supply of fodder and grain, if further to proceed he should wish, should fail, or the enemies by the fires should be terrified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For even that common of an incursion of enemies sign, which by the burnings of buildings to be understood was accustomed, by Caesar's prohibition had been removed, lest either the supply of fodder and grain, if further to proceed he wished, should be lacking, or the enemies by the fires should be frightened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For even that common sign of an enemy raid, which is usually recognized by the burning of buildings, had been forbidden by Caesar's order, so that he would not run short of fodder and grain if he wished to advance further, and so the enemy would not be alerted by the fires.

sentences.latin: Multis hominum milibus captis perterriti Bituriges; qui primum adventum potuerant effugere Romanorum, in finitimas civitates aut privatis hospitiis confisi aut societate consiliorum confugerant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Many of men thousands having been captured, terrified [were] the Bituriges; [those] who the first arrival had been able to escape of the Romans, into neighboring states either in private hospitalities trusting or in the alliance of plans had fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Many of men thousands having been captured, terrified were the Bituriges; who the first arrival had been able to escape of the Romans, into neighboring states either in private hospitalities trusting or in the alliance of plans had fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: With many thousands of people captured, the Bituriges were terrified; those who had been able to escape the Romans' first arrival had fled into neighboring states, relying either on private guest-friendships or shared political interests.

sentences.latin: Frustra: nam Caesar magnis itineribus omnibus locis occurrit nec dat ulli civitati spatium de aliena potius quam de domestica salute cogitandi; qua celeritate et fideles amicos retinebat et dubitantes terrore ad condiciones pacis adducebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In vain: for Caesar by great marches in all places meets [them] nor gives to any state space concerning another's rather than concerning domestic safety of thinking; by which speed both faithful friends he was retaining and the wavering by terror to conditions of peace he was leading.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In vain: for Caesar by great marches in all places meets them nor gives to any state space concerning another's rather than concerning domestic safety of thinking; by which speed both faithful friends he was retaining and the wavering by terror to conditions of peace he was bringing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was in vain: for Caesar, by forced marches, met them everywhere and gave no state the opportunity to think of anyone's safety but their own; by this speed, he both kept his friends loyal and drove the wavering to accept peace terms through fear.

sentences.latin: Tali condicione proposita Bituriges, cum sibi viderent clementia Caesaris reditum patere in eius amicitiam finitimasque civitates sine ulla poena dedisse obsides atque in fidem receptas esse, idem fecerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Such a condition having been proposed, the Bituriges, when for themselves they saw by the clemency of Caesar a return to lie open into his friendship and neighboring states without any penalty to have given hostages and into protection to have been received, the same did.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Such a condition having been proposed, the Bituriges, when for themselves they saw by the clemency of Caesar a return to lie open into his friendship and neighboring states without any penalty had given hostages and into protection received had been, the same did.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When such terms were offered, the Bituriges, seeing that Caesar's clemency left a path open for a return to his friendship and that neighboring states had given hostages and been taken under his protection without penalty, did the same.

sentences.latin: Caesar militibus pro tanto labore ac patientia, qui brumalibus diebus itineribus difficillimis, frigoribus intolerandis studiosissime permanserant in labore, ducenos sestertios, centurionibus tot milia nummum praedae nomine condonanda pollicetur legionibusque in hiberna remissis ipse se recipit die XXXX Bibracte.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar to the soldiers for so great labor and patience, who in winter days by marches most difficult, in colds intolerable most zealously had remained in labor, two hundred sesterces, to the centurions so many thousands of coins in the name of booty to be granted promises and the legions into winter quarters having been sent back he himself betakes himself on day 40 to Bibracte.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar to the soldiers for so great labor and patience, who in winter days by marches most difficult, in colds intolerable most zealously had remained in labor, two hundred sesterces, to the centurions so many thousands of coins in the name of booty to be granted promises and the legions into winter quarters having been sent back he himself betakes on the 40th day to Bibracte.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As a reward for such great labor and endurancefor they had most zealously persevered in their work during winter days, through very difficult marches and intolerable coldCaesar promised two hundred sesterces to each soldier and several thousand to each centurion as prize money; then, having sent the legions back to winter quarters, he returned to Bibracte on the fortieth day.

sentences.latin: Ibi cum ius diceret, Bituriges ad eum legatos mittunt auxilium petitum contra Carnutes, quos intulisse bellum sibi querebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There while law he was administering, the Bituriges to him ambassadors send help to seek against the Carnutes, whom to have brought war upon themselves they were complaining.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There while law he was administering, the Bituriges to him ambassadors send help to seek against the Carnutes, whom to have brought war on themselves they were complaining.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While he was administering justice there, the Bituriges sent ambassadors to him to seek help against the Carnutes, who they complained had made war upon them.

sentences.latin: Qua re cognita, cum dies non amplius decem et octo in hibernis esset moratus, legiones XIIII et VI ex hibernis ab Arare educit, quas ibi collocatas explicandae rei frumentariae causa superiore commentario demonstratum est: ita cum duabus legionibus ad persequendos Carnutes proficiscitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been learned, when days not more [than] eighteen in winter quarters he had delayed, legions 14 and 6 from winter quarters from the Arar he leads out, which there placed for the sake of arranging the grain supply in the previous commentary it was shown: thus with two legions to pursuing the Carnutes he sets out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been learned, when days not more than eighteen in winter quarters he had delayed, the 14th and 6th legions from winter quarters from the Sane he leads out, which there stationed for the sake of arranging the grain supply in the previous commentary was shown: thus with two legions to pursuing the Carnutes he sets out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning this, although he had stayed in winter quarters for no more than eighteen days, he led the 14th and 6th legions from their quarters on the Arar, where it was mentioned in the previous book they had been stationed to manage the grain supply; thus, with two legions, he set out to pursue the Carnutes.

sentences.latin: Cum fama exercitus ad hostes esset perlata, calamitate ceterorum ducti Carnutes desertis vicis oppidisque, quae tolerandae hiemis causa constitutis repente exiguis ad necessitatem aedificiis incolebant (nuper enim devicti complura oppida dimiserant), dispersi profugiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When the report of the army to the enemies had been carried, by the calamity of the others led, the Carnutes, having deserted villages and towns, which for the sake of enduring winter in established suddenly small for necessity buildings they were inhabiting (for recently having been conquered several towns they had lost), scattered they flee.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When the report of the army to the enemies had been carried, by the calamity of the others led the Carnutes, having deserted villages and towns, which for the sake of enduring winter in established suddenly small for necessity buildings they were inhabiting (for recently conquered several towns they had lost), dispersed they flee.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When news of the army reached the enemy, the Carnutes, moved by the disaster of the others, abandoned their villages and townswhere they were living in small, hastily built shelters to endure the winter (for having been recently defeated, they had lost many of their towns)and fled in all directions.

sentences.latin: Caesar erumpentes eo maxime tempore acerrimas tempestates cum subire milites nollet, in oppido Carnutum Cenabo castra ponit atque in tecta partim Gallorum, partim quae coniectis celeriter stramentis tentoriorum integendorum gratia erant inaedificata, milites compegit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar breaking out at that especially time most sharp storms since to undergo the soldiers he was unwilling, in the town of the Carnutes Cenabum camp places and into the roofs partly of the Gauls, partly which by thrown together quickly straw for the sake of tents covering had been built in, the soldiers he crowded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, breaking out at that time especially most sharp storms since to undergo the soldiers he was unwilling, in the town of the Carnutes, Cenabum, camp places and into the roofs partly of the Gauls, partly which by thrown together quickly straw of tents covering for the sake of had been built in, the soldiers he packed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since Caesar was unwilling for his soldiers to endure the very severe storms breaking out at that particular time, he pitched camp in the Carnutian town of Cenabum and quartered his soldiers partly in the houses of the Gauls and partly in shelters hastily constructed with thatch to cover the tents.

sentences.latin: Equites tamen et auxiliarios pedites in omnes partes mittit quascumque petisse dicebantur hostes; nec frustra:
sentences.referenceTranslation: Cavalry however and auxiliary infantry into all parts he sends whichever to have sought were said the enemies; nor in vain:
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Cavalry however and auxiliary infantry into all parts he sends whichever to have sought were said the enemies; nor in vain:
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, he sent the cavalry and auxiliary infantry in every direction the enemy were said to have headed; and not in vain:

sentences.latin: nam plerumque magna praeda potiti nostri revertuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: for mostly with great booty having gained possession our men return.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: for for the most part with great booty having gained possession of our [men] return.
sentences.naturalTranslation: for our men usually returned having gained possession of a great amount of booty.

sentences.latin: Oppressi Carnutes hiemis difficultate, terrore periculi, cum tectis expulsi nullo loco diutius consistere auderent nec silvarum praesidio tempestatibus durissimis tegi possent, dispersi magna parte amissa suorum dissipantur in finitimas civitates.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Oppressed the Carnutes by the winter's difficulty, by terror of danger, since from roofs expelled in no place longer to halt they dared nor by the woods' protection in storms most harsh to be covered they were able, dispersed a great part having been lost of their own people they are scattered into neighboring states.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Oppressed the Carnutes by the winter's difficulty, by terror of danger, when from roofs expelled in no place longer to halt they dared nor by the woods' protection from storms most harsh to be covered they were able, dispersed a great part having been lost of their own [men] they are scattered into neighboring states.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Overwhelmed by the hardships of winter and the fear of danger, the Carnutesdriven from their homes and daring to stay nowhere for long, nor able to find shelter in the woods during the harshest stormswere scattered into neighboring states after losing a large portion of their people.

sentences.latin: Caesar tempore anni difficillimo, cum satis haberet convenientes manus dissipare, ne quod initium belli nasceretur, quantumque in ratione esset, exploratum haberet sub tempus aestivorum nullum summum bellum posse conflari, Gaium Trebonium cum duabus legionibus, quas secum habebat, in hibernis Cenabi collocavit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar at a time of year most difficult, since enough he held the assembling bands to scatter, lest any beginning of war should be born, and as much as in reason was, explored he held toward the time of summer quarters no supreme war to be able to be kindled, Gaius Trebonium with two legions, which with himself he had, in winter quarters at Cenabum he placed;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar at a time of year most difficult, since enough he held the assembling bands to dissipate, lest any beginning of war should be born, and as much as in reason was, explored he held toward the time of summer quarters no supreme war to be able to be kindled, Gaius Trebonius with two legions, which with himself he had, in winter quarters at Cenabum he placed;
sentences.naturalTranslation: At this most difficult time of year, Caesarconsidering it sufficient to disperse the assembling bands to prevent any new outbreak of war, and being convinced, as far as could be reasoned, that no major war could be ignited before the summer campaignstationed Gaius Trebonius with two legions at Cenabum.

sentences.latin: ipse, cum crebris legationibus Remorum certior fieret Bellovacos, qui belli gloria Gallos omnes Belgasque praestabant, finitimasque his civitates duce Correo Bellovaco et Commio Atrebate exercitus comparare atque in unum locum cogere, ut omni multitudine in fines Suessionum, qui Remis erant attributi, facerent impressionem, pertinere autem non tantum ad dignitatem sed etiam ad salutem suam iudicaret nullam calamitatem socios optime de re publica meritos accipere,
sentences.referenceTranslation: he himself, since by frequent embassies of the Remi more certain he was made the Bellovaci, who in war's glory Gauls all and Belgians surpassed, and neighboring to these states with leader Correus the Bellovacian and Commius the Atrebatian armies to prepare and into one place to collect, so that with all the multitude into the borders of the Suessiones, who to the Remi had been assigned, they might make an attack, and to pertain however not only to dignity but also to safety his own he judged no calamity allies best of the republic having deserved to receive,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he himself, when by frequent embassies of the Remi more certain he was made the Bellovaci, who in war's glory Gauls all and Belgians surpassed, and neighboring to these states with leader Correus the Bellovacan and Commius the Atrebatian armies to be preparing and into one place to be collecting, so that with all the multitude into the borders of the Suessiones, who to the Remi had been assigned, they might make an attack, and to pertain however not only to dignity but also to safety his own he judged no calamity the allies very well of the republic deserving to receive,
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself, being informed by frequent embassies from the Remi that the Bellovaci (who surpassed all the Gauls and Belgians in military glory) and their neighbors were raising armies under the leadership of Correus the Bellovacian and Commius the Atrebatian, and were concentrating their forces to launch a full-scale invasion of the Suessiones (who were dependents of the Remi), judged it a matter not only of his own prestige but also of his safety that allies who had served the state so well should suffer no disaster.

sentences.latin: legionem ex hibernis evocat rursus undecimam; litteras autem ad Gaium Fabium mittit, ut in fines Suessionum legiones duas quas habebat adduceret, alteramque ex duabus ab Labieno arcessit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the legion from winter quarters he calls out again the eleventh; letters however to Gaius Fabius he sends, that into the borders of the Suessiones the legions two which he had he should lead, and another from the two from Labienus he summons.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the legion from winter quarters he calls out again the eleventh; letters however to Gaius Fabius he sends, that into the borders of the Suessiones the legions two which he had he should lead, and another from the two from Labienus he summons.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He recalled the eleventh legion from its winter quarters; he also sent instructions to Gaius Fabius to lead his two legions into the territory of the Suessiones, and he summoned one of the two legions from Labienus.

sentences.latin: Ita, quantum hibernorum opportunitas bellique ratio postulabat, perpetuo suo labore in vicem legionibus expeditionum onus iniungebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus, as much as the winter quarters' convenience and the war's reason demanded, by constant his labor in turn on the legions of expeditions the burden he was imposing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus, as much as the winter quarters' convenience and the war's plan demanded, by perpetual his labor in turn on the legions of expeditions the burden he was imposing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, as far as the situation of the winter quarters and the requirements of the war allowed, he shared the burden of the expeditions among the legions in turn through his own constant effort.

sentences.latin: His copiis coactis ad Bellovacos proficiscitur castrisque in eorum finibus positis equitum turmas dimittit in omnes partes ad aliquos excipiendos ex quibus hostium consilia cognosceret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These forces having been collected toward the Bellovaci he sets out and a camp in their borders having been placed of cavalry troops he sends out into all parts for some men to be intercepted from whom the enemy's plans he might learn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These forces having been collected to the Bellovaci he sets out and camp in their borders having been placed of cavalry troops he sends out into all parts for some [people] to be intercepted from whom the enemies' plans he might learn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having assembled these forces, he marched against the Bellovaci and, after pitching camp in their territory, sent out troops of cavalry in all directions to capture prisoners from whom he might learn the enemy's plans.

sentences.latin: Equites officio functi renuntiant paucos in aedificiis esse inventos, atque hos, non qui agrorum colendorum causa remansissent (namque esse undique diligenter demigratum), sed qui speculandi causa essent remissi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The cavalry the duty having performed report few in buildings to have been found, and these, not who of fields to be tilled for the sake had remained (for to have been from everywhere diligently migrated), but who of spying for the sake had been sent back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The cavalry the duty having performed report few in buildings to have been found, and these, not who of fields to be tilled for the sake had remained (for to have been from everywhere diligently moved away), but who of spying for the sake had been sent back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cavalry, having performed their duty, reported that few people were found in the buildings, and that these were not people who had stayed behind to farm (for the whole area had been thoroughly evacuated), but were scouts sent back for the purpose of spying.

sentences.latin: A quibus cum quaereret Caesar quo loco multitudo esset Bellovacorum quodve esset consilium eorum, inveniebat Bellovacos omnes qui arma ferre possent in unum locum convenisse,
sentences.referenceTranslation: From whom when was asking Caesar in what place the multitude was of the Bellovaci or what was the plan of them, he was finding the Bellovaci all who arms to bear were able into one place to have come together,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From whom when was asking Caesar in what place the multitude was of the Bellovaci or what was the plan of them, he was finding the Bellovaci all who arms to bear were able into one place to have come together,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar asked them where the main body of the Bellovaci was and what their plan was, he discovered that all the Bellovaci capable of bearing arms had assembled in a single location.

sentences.latin: itemque Ambianos, Aulercos, Caletos, Veliocasses, Atrebatas; locum castris excelsum in silva circumdata palude delegisse, impedimenta omnia in ulteriores silvas contulisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and likewise the Ambiani, Aulerci, Caleti, Veliocasses, Atrebates; a place for a camp high in a forest surrounded by a marsh they had chosen, baggage all into further forests they had conveyed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and likewise the Ambiani, Aulerci, Caleti, Veliocasses, Atrebates; a place for camp high in a wood surrounded by a marsh to have chosen, baggage all into further woods to have conveyed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Ambiani, Aulerci, Caleti, Veliocasses, and Atrebates had also joined; they had chosen a high spot for their camp in a forest surrounded by a marsh and had moved all their baggage into more distant woods.

sentences.latin: Complures esse principes belli auctores, sed multitudinem maxime Correo obtemperare, quod ei summo esse odio nomen populi Romani intellexissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several to be leaders authors of the war, but the multitude especially Correus to obey, because to him in the highest to be hatred the name of the people Roman they had understood.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Several to be leaders of the war authors, but the multitude especially Correus to obey, because to him in the highest to be hatred the name of the people Roman they had understood.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Several leaders were instigators of the war, but the common people obeyed Correus most of all, because they understood that the name of the Roman people was held by him in the greatest hatred.

sentences.latin: Paucis ante diebus ex his castris Atrebatem Commium discessisse ad auxilia Germanorum adducenda; quorum et vicinitas propinqua et multitudo esset infinita.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A few before days from these camps the Atrebatian Commius to have departed for reinforcements of Germans to be brought; of whom both the proximity was near and the multitude was infinite.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A few before days from this camp the Atrebatian Commius to have departed for reinforcements of Germans to be brought; of whom both the proximity [was] near and the multitude was infinite.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A few days earlier, Commius the Atrebatian had left this camp to bring German reinforcements, whose proximity was close and whose numbers were vast.

sentences.latin: Constituisse autem Bellovacos omnium principum consensu, summa plebis cupiditate, si, ut diceretur, Caesar cum tribus legionibus veniret, offerre se ad dimicandum, ne miseriore ac duriore postea condicione cum toto exercitu decertare cogerentur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To have decided however the Bellovaci by all the leaders' consensus, with the greatest of the common people desire, if, as it was said, Caesar with three legions should come, to offer themselves for fighting, lest in a more miserable and harder later condition with the whole army to fight they should be compelled;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To have decided however the Bellovaci of all the leaders by consensus, with the highest of the common people desire, if, as it was said, Caesar with three legions should come, to offer themselves for fighting, lest by a more miserable and harder later condition with the whole army to fight it out they should be forced;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The Bellovaci, however, had decided by the consensus of all the leaders and with the greatest enthusiasm of the common people, that if Caesar came with only three legions, as was reported, they would offer battle, so that they would not be forced to fight later under more miserable and difficult conditions against his entire army.

sentences.latin: si maiores copias adduceret, in eo loco permanere quem delegissent, pabulatione autem, quae propter anni tempus cum exigua tum disiecta esset, et frumentatione et reliquo commeatu ex insidiis prohibere Romanos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: if greater forces he should bring, in that place to remain which they had chosen, from foraging however, which on account of the year's time both scanty and scattered was, and from grain-gathering and remaining supplies by ambushes to prohibit the Romans.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: if larger forces he should lead, in that place to remain which they had chosen, from foraging however, which on account of the year's time both meager and scattered was, and grain-gathering and remaining supplies from ambushes to prohibit the Romans.
sentences.naturalTranslation: If he brought larger forces, they would remain in the position they had chosen and use ambushes to prevent the Romans from foragingwhich was difficult and scattered due to the seasonas well as from gathering grain and other supplies.

sentences.latin: Quae Caesar consentientibus pluribus cum cognosset atque ea quae proponerentur consilia plena prudentiae longeque a temeritate barbarorum remota esse iudicaret, omnibus rebus inserviendum statuit, quo celerius hostis contempta sua paucitate prodiret in aciem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things Caesar with many agreeing when he had learned and those which were proposed plans full of prudence and far from the rashness of barbarians to be removed he judged, for all things to be provided for he decided, so that more quickly the enemy having despised his fewness might come forth into battle line.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which [things] Caesar with agreeing many when he had learned and those which were proposed plans full of prudence and far from the rashness of barbarians removed to be he judged, to all things to be devoted he decided, so that more quickly the enemy having despised his small number might come forward into battle line.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar learned these facts from several consistent reports and judged that the proposed plans were full of prudence and far removed from the usual rashness of barbarians, he decided to take every precaution so that the enemy, despising his small numbers, might more quickly come out to battle.

sentences.latin: Singularis enim virtutis veterrimas legiones VII, VIII, VIIII habebat, summae spei delectaeque iuventutis XI, quae octavo iam stipendio tamen in collatione reliquarum nondum eandem vetustatis ac virtutis ceperat opinionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of singular for valor oldest legions 7th, 8th, 9th he had, of highest hope and of chosen youth the 11th, which in its eighth already campaign however in comparison of the rest not yet the same of age and of valor had gained reputation.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of singular for valor oldest legions 7, 8, 9 he had, of highest hope and of chosen youth the 11th, which in the eighth already campaign however in comparison of the remaining not yet the same of age and of valor had gained reputation.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he had the 7th, 8th, and 9th legions, veteran units of singular valor, and the 11th, composed of chosen youths of the highest promise, which, though already in its eighth year of service, had not yet gained the same reputation for experience and bravery when compared to the others.

sentences.latin: Itaque consilio advocato, rebus eis quae ad se essent delatae omnibus expositis animos multitudinis confirmat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so a council having been called, matters those which to him had been reported all having been set forth the minds of the multitude he strengthens.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so a council having been called, things those which to him had been reported all having been set forth the minds of the multitude he strengthens.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, having called a council and explained all the reports that had been brought to him, he encouraged the spirits of the soldiers.

sentences.latin: Si forte hostes trium legionum numero posset elicere ad dimicandum, agminis ordinem ita constituit, ut legio septima, octava, nona ante omnia irent impedimenta, deinde omnium impedimentorum agmen, quod tamen erat mediocre, ut in expeditionibus esse consuevit, cogeret undecima, ne maioris multitudinis species accidere hostibus posset quam ipsi depoposcissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: If by chance the enemy by three legions' number he could lure to fighting, the column's order thus he arranged, that legion seventh, eighth, ninth before all should go baggage, then of all the baggage the train, which however was moderate, as in expeditions to be it was accustomed, should bring up the rear the eleventh, lest of a greater multitude an appearance to happen to the enemy could than they themselves had demanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: If by chance the enemies by three legions' number he could lure to fighting, the column's order thus he established, so that legion seventh, eighth, ninth before all should go the baggage, then of all the baggage the train, which however was moderate, as on expeditions to be it was accustomed, should bring up the rear the eleventh, lest of a larger multitude the appearance to happen to the enemies could than they themselves had demanded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In case he could lure the enemy to fight by the appearance of having only three legions, he arranged the order of the column so that the 7th, 8th, and 9th legions marched in front of all the baggage; then the 11th legion followed, bringing up the rear of the entire baggage trainwhich was modest, as is usual on such expeditionsso that the enemy would not see a larger force than they had expected to engage.

sentences.latin: Hac ratione paene quadrato agmine instructo in conspectum hostium celerius opinione eorum exercitum adducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By this method almost in a square column drawn up into the sight of the enemy more quickly than the opinion of them the army he leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By this method almost in a square column drawn up into the sight of the enemies more quickly than the opinion of them the army he leads.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having formed the army in this way, almost in a hollow square, he led it into the enemy's view more quickly than they had expected.

sentences.latin: Cum repente instructas velut in acie certo gradu legiones accedere Galli viderent, quorum erant ad Caesarem plena fiduciae consilia perlata, sive certaminis periculo sive subito adventu sive exspectatione nostri consili copias instruunt pro castris nec loco superiore decedunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When suddenly drawn up as if in battle line with a steady step the legions to approach the Gauls saw, of whom had been to Caesar full of confidence plans reported, whether by the danger of a contest or by the sudden arrival or by the expectation of our plan their forces they draw up before the camp nor from the higher ground do they withdraw.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When suddenly drawn up as if in battle line with a steady step the legions to approach the Gauls saw, of whom had been to Caesar full of confidence plans reported, either by the danger of a contest or by the sudden arrival or by the expectation of our plan their forces they draw up before the camp nor from the higher ground do they depart.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the Gauls suddenly saw the legions approaching, drawn up as if for battle and marching with a steady stepthough the reports they had previously sent to Caesar were full of confidencethey drew up their forces in front of their camp and refused to leave the higher ground, whether due to the danger of a battle, the suddenness of the arrival, or curiosity about our plan.

sentences.latin: Caesar, etsi dimicare optaverat, tamen admiratus tantam multitudinem hostium valle intermissa magis in altitudinem depressa quam late patente castra castris hostium confert.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, although to fight he had desired, nevertheless having wondered at so great a multitude of the enemy, a valley having been put between more in depth sunk than widely extending, his camp to the camp of the enemy he brings near.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, although to fight he had desired, nevertheless having wondered at so great a multitude of the enemies, a valley having been put between more in depth depressed than widely extending, his camp to the camp of the enemies he brings near.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar had hoped to fight, he was surprised by the great number of the enemy; therefore, since a valley intervened that was deep rather than wide, he established his camp opposite that of the enemy.

sentences.latin: Haec imperat vallo pedum XII muniri, loriculam pro [hac] ratione eius altitudinis inaedificari; fossam duplicem pedum denum quinum lateribus deprimi directis; turres excitari crebras in altitudinem trium tabulatorum, pontibus traiectis constratisque coniungi, quorum frontes viminea loricula munirentur; ut ab hostibus duplici fossa, duplici propugnatorum ordine defenderentur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: This he orders with a rampart of feet 12 to be fortified, a breastwork in proportion to this height to be built on; a ditch double of feet ten five each with sides to be sunk straight; towers to be raised numerous to a height of three stories, by bridges thrown across and floored to be joined, of which the fronts with a wicker breastwork might be protected; so that from the enemy by a double ditch, by a double of defenders rank they might be defended,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These he orders with a rampart of feet 12 to be fortified, a breastwork in proportion to this measure of its height to be built on; a ditch double of feet ten five each with sides to be sunk straight; towers to be raised frequent to a height of three stories, by bridges thrown across and floored to be joined, of which the fronts with a wicker breastwork might be fortified; so that by the enemy by a double ditch, by a double of defenders rank they might be defended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He ordered this camp to be fortified with a twelve-foot rampart and a breastwork built on top in proportion to that height. He also ordered a double ditch, fifteen feet wide with vertical sides, to be dug, and numerous three-story towers to be erected and connected by floored bridges, the fronts of which were protected by wickerwork; thus, they would be defended from the enemy by a double ditch and a double line of defenders,

sentences.latin: quorum alter ex pontibus, quo tutior altitudine esset, hoc audacius longiusque permitteret tela, alter, qui propior hostem in ipso vallo collocatus esset, ponte ab incidentibus telis tegeretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom the one from the bridges, by which safer by height he might be, by this more boldly and further might hurl weapons, the other, who nearer the enemy on the rampart itself had been placed, by the bridge from falling weapons might be covered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of which the one from the bridges, by which safer by height it might be, by this more boldly and further might hurl weapons, the other, who nearer the enemy on the rampart itself had been placed, by the bridge from falling weapons might be covered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: one of these ranks, stationed on the bridges, could hurl weapons more boldly and to a greater distance because of the safety provided by the height, while the other, placed on the rampart itself closer to the enemy, would be shielded from falling missiles by the bridge above.

sentences.latin: Portis fores altioresque turres imposuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the gates doors and higher towers he placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the gates doors and higher towers he placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He fitted the gates with doors and erected taller towers over them.

sentences.latin: Huius munitionis duplex erat consilium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of this fortification double was the purpose.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of this fortification double was the purpose.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There was a twofold purpose for this fortification.

sentences.latin: Namque et operum magnitudinem et timorem suum sperabat fiduciam barbaris allaturum, et cum pabulatum frumentatumque longius esset proficiscendum, parvis copiis castra munitione ipsa videbat posse defendi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For both the magnitude of the works and his own fear he was hoping confidence to the barbarians would bring, and when to forage and to gather grain further it was necessary to set out, with small forces the camp by the fortification itself he saw to be able to be defended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For both the magnitude of the works and his own fear he was hoping confidence to the barbarians would bring, and when to forage and to grain-gather further it had to be set out, with small forces the camp by the fortification itself he saw to be able to be defended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he hoped that both the scale of the works and the appearance of fear on his part would give the barbarians confidence, and he also saw that when it became necessary to go further afield for fodder and grain, the camp could be defended by a small force thanks to the fortification itself.

sentences.latin: Interim crebro paucis utrimque procurrentibus inter bina castra palude interiecta contendebatur; quam tamen paludem nonnumquam aut nostra auxilia Gallorum Germanorumque transibant acriusque hostes insequebantur, aut vicissim hostes eadem transgressi nostros longius summovebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile frequently with a few from both sides running forward between the two camps a marsh having been cast between it was contended; which however marsh sometimes either our auxiliaries of Gauls and Germans were crossing and more fiercely the enemy were pursuing, or in turn the enemy the same having crossed our men further were driving back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile frequently with a few from both sides running forward between the two camps a marsh having been cast between it was contended; which however marsh sometimes either our auxiliaries of Gauls and Germans were crossing and more fiercely the enemies were pursuing, or in turn the enemies the same having crossed our men further were driving back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, frequent skirmishes took place between the two camps, which were separated by a marsh, as small parties from both sides rushed forward. Sometimes our Gallic and German auxiliaries would cross this marsh and pursue the enemy vigorously, and at other times the enemy would cross it in turn and drive our men back a considerable distance.

sentences.latin: Accidebat autem cotidianis pabulationibus (id quod accidere erat necesse, cum raris disiectisque ex aedificiis pabulum conquireretur), ut impeditis locis dispersi pabulatores circumvenirentur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: It was happening moreover in daily foragings (that which to happen was necessary, when from scattered and dispersed from buildings fodder was being sought), that in difficult places dispersed foragers were being surrounded;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It was happening moreover in daily foragings (that which to happen was necessary, when from scattered and dispersed from buildings fodder was being sought), that in hindered places dispersed foragers were being surrounded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Moreover, during the daily foraging expeditions, it inevitably happenedsince fodder was being sought from scattered and isolated buildingsthat foragers became dispersed in difficult terrain and were surrounded.

sentences.latin: quae res, etsi mediocre detrimentum iumentorum ac servorum nostris adferebat, tamen stultas cogitationes incitabat barbarorum, atque eo magis, quod Commius, quem profectum ad auxilia Germanorum arcessenda docui, cum equitibus venerat; qui, tametsi numero non amplius erant quingenti, tamen Germanorum adventu barbari nitebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: which thing, although a moderate loss of pack animals and of slaves to our men it was bringing, nevertheless foolish thoughts was inciting of the barbarians, and by this more, because Commius, whom having set out for auxiliaries of Germans to be summoned I have shown, with cavalry had come; who, although in number not more were five hundred, nevertheless by the Germans' arrival the barbarians were relying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: which thing, although a moderate loss of pack animals and of slaves to our men it was bringing, nevertheless foolish thoughts was inciting of the barbarians, and by this more, because Commius, whom having set out to the auxiliaries of Germans to be summoned I have shown, with horsemen had come; who, although in number not more were five hundred, nevertheless by the Germans' arrival the barbarians were relying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although this caused only a moderate loss of pack animals and slaves to our men, it encouraged foolish ideas among the barbarians, all the more so because Commiuswho, as I have mentioned, had gone to summon German reinforcementshad arrived with cavalry. Although these numbered no more than five hundred, the barbarians were emboldened by the arrival of the Germans.

sentences.latin: Caesar, cum animadverteret hostem complures dies castris palude et loci natura munitis se tenere neque oppugnari castra eorum sine dimicatione perniciosa nec locum munitionibus claudi nisi a maiore exercitu posse, litteras ad Trebonium mittit, ut quam celerrime posset legionem XIII, quae cum T. Sextio legato in Biturigibus hiemabat, arcesseret atque ita cum tribus legionibus magnis itineribus ad se veniret;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, when he observed the enemy for several days themselves to hold in a camp by a marsh and the nature of the place fortified, and that not to be attacked the camp of them without a destructive struggle nor the place by fortifications to be enclosed unless by a larger army to be able, letters to Trebonius sends, that as quickly as he could the legion XIII, which with T. Sextius the legate among the Bituriges was wintering, he should summon and thus with three legions by great marches to him should come;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, when he noticed the enemy for several days in camp by a marsh and the nature of the place fortified themselves to hold and not to be attacked the camp of them without a struggle ruinous nor the place by fortifications to be enclosed unless by a larger army to be able, letters to Trebonius sends, that as most quickly he could the legion 13th, which with T. Sextius the legate among the Bituriges was wintering, he should summon and so with three legions by great marches to him he should come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar observed that the enemy had remained for several days in a camp fortified by a marsh and the natural terrain, and that their camp could not be attacked without a disastrous struggle nor the position blockaded except by a larger army, he sent a dispatch to Trebonius, ordering him to summon the Thirteenth Legion, which was wintering with the legate T. Sextius among the Bituriges, as quickly as possible and to join him with three legions by forced marches.

sentences.latin: ipse equites in vicem Remorum ac Lingonum reliquarumque civitatum, quorum magnum numerum evocaverat, praesidio pabulationibus mittit, qui subitas hostium incursiones sustinerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself the horsemen in turn of the Remi and Lingones and of the remaining states, of whom a great number he had called out, as a protection for the foraging parties sends, who sudden of the enemy incursions might withstand.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: he himself horsemen in turn of the Remi and Lingones and of the remaining states, of whom a great number he had called out, for a protection for foragings sends, who sudden of the enemies incursions might sustain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself sent the cavalry of the Remi, Lingones, and other statesof whom he had called up a great numberto protect the foraging parties and withstand any sudden enemy raids.

sentences.latin: Quod cum cotidie fieret ac iam consuetudine diligentia minueretur, quod plerumque accidit diuturnitate, Bellovaci delecta manu peditum cognitis stationibus cotidianis equitum nostrorum
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when daily it happened and now by habit diligence was being diminished, which mostly happens by long duration, the Bellovaci with a chosen band of infantry, having learned the daily stations of our horsemen
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when daily it was happening and now by custom diligence was being diminished, which mostly happens by length of time, the Bellovaci with a chosen band of infantry having learned the stations daily of our horsemen
sentences.naturalTranslation: As this happened daily and diligence was now being diminished by routineas usually happens over timethe Bellovaci, having observed the daily positions of our cavalry, selected a picked body of infantry.

sentences.latin: silvestribus locis insidias disponunt eodemque equites postero die mittunt, qui primum elicerent nostros, deinde circumventos aggrederentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: in wooded places ambushes they arrange and to the same place horsemen on the following day they send, who first might lure out our men, then the surrounded ones might attack.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: in wooded places ambushes they arrange and to the same place horsemen on the following day they send, who first might lure out our men, then surrounded might attack.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They set an ambush in the woods and sent cavalry to the same spot the next day, first to lure our men out and then to attack them once they were surrounded.

sentences.latin: Cuius mali sors incidit Remis, quibus ille dies fungendi muneris obvenerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of which evil the lot fell to the Remi, to whom that day of performing the duty had fallen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of which evil the lot fell to the Remi, to whom that day of performing the duty had fallen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The misfortune of this disaster fell upon the Remi, whose turn it was that day to perform the duty.

sentences.latin: Namque hi, cum repente hostium equites animadvertissent ac numero superiores paucitatem contempsissent, cupidius insecuti peditibus undique sunt circumdati.
