sentences.referenceTranslation: For these, when suddenly of the enemy the horsemen they had noticed and in number superior the small number they had despised, too eagerly having followed, by the infantry on all sides were surrounded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For these, when suddenly the enemies' horsemen they had noticed and in number superior the small number they had despised, too eagerly having followed by infantry from all sides were surrounded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For when they suddenly noticed the enemy cavalry and, being superior in number, looked down on their small force, they pursued too eagerly and were surrounded on all sides by the infantry.

sentences.latin: Quo facto perturbati celerius quam consuetudo fert equestris proeli se receperunt amisso Vertisco, principe civitatis, praefecto equitum;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which having been done, thrown into confusion, more quickly than custom brings of a cavalry battle themselves they withdrew, having lost Vertiscus, a chief of the state, the commander of the horsemen;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been done thrown into confusion more quickly than custom brings of a cavalry battle themselves they withdrew having lost Vertiscus, the chief of the state, the commander of the horsemen;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thrown into confusion by this, they retreated more quickly than is usual in a cavalry engagement, having lost Vertiscus, a leading man of his state and commander of the cavalry.

sentences.latin: qui cum vix equo propter aetatem posset uti, tamen consuetudine Gallorum neque aetatis excusatione in suscipienda praefectura usus erat neque dimicari sine se voluerat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: who when hardly a horse on account of age he was able to use, yet by the custom of the Gauls neither of age the excuse in undertaking the command had used nor to be fought without himself had wished.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: who since scarcely a horse on account of age he was able to use, nevertheless by the custom of the Gauls neither of age the excuse in undertaking the command had used nor to be fought without himself he had wished.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although he could hardly sit a horse because of his age, he had nevertheless followed Gallic custom by refusing to use his age as an excuse to avoid the command, nor had he wished the battle to be fought without him.

sentences.latin: Inflantur atque incitantur hostium animi secundo proelio, principe et praefecto Remorum interfecto,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Are puffed up and are incited of the enemy the minds by the successful battle, the chief and commander of the Remi having been killed,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Are puffed up and are incited the enemies' minds by the successful battle, the chief and commander of the Remi having been killed,
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy's spirits were inflated and emboldened by the successful engagement and the death of the Remian chief and commander.

sentences.latin: nostrique detrimento admonentur diligentius exploratis locis stationes disponere ac moderatius cedentem insequi hostem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and our men by the loss are warned, more carefully having explored the places, stations to arrange and more moderately the retreating to follow enemy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and our men by the loss are warned more diligently having explored the places stations to arrange and more moderately the retreating to follow enemy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men, cautioned by this loss, learned to scout the terrain more carefully before setting their outposts and to be more restrained when pursuing a retreating enemy.

sentences.latin: Non intermittunt interim cotidiana proelia in conspectu utrorumque castrorum, quae ad vada transitusque fiebant paludis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Not they leave off meanwhile daily battles in sight of both camps, which at the fords and crossings were happening of the marsh.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Not they leave off meanwhile daily battles in sight of each of the two camps, which at the fords and crossings were happening of the marsh.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, daily battles continued in full view of both camps, occurring at the fords and crossing points of the marsh.

sentences.latin: Qua contentione Germani, quos propterea Caesar traduxerat Rhenum ut equitibus interpositi proeliarentur, cum constantius universi paludem transissent paucisque resistentibus interfectis pertinacius reliquam multitudinem essent insecuti, perterriti non solum ei qui aut comminus opprimebantur aut eminus vulnerabantur, sed etiam qui longius subsidiari consuerant, turpiter refugerunt,
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which struggle the Germans, whom for this reason Caesar had led across the Rhine so that among the cavalry placed they might fight, when more firmly all together the marsh they had crossed and a few resisting having been killed more persistently the remaining multitude they had followed, terrified not only those who either at close quarters were being overwhelmed or from a distance were being wounded, but even those who further off to be in reserve had been accustomed, shamefully fled back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which struggle the Germans, whom for that reason Caesar had led across the Rhine so that among the cavalry placed they might fight, when more firmly all together the marsh they had crossed and a few resisting having been killed more persistently the remaining multitude they had followed, terrified not only those who either at close quarters were being overwhelmed or from a distance were being wounded, but also those who further off to be in reserve had been accustomed, shamefully fled back,
sentences.naturalTranslation: During this struggle, the Germanswhom Caesar had brought across the Rhine specifically to fight interspersed with the cavalrycrossed the marsh in a body with greater determination. After killing a few who resisted and pursuing the rest of the crowd more relentlessly, they struck such terror that not only those being overwhelmed at close quarters or wounded from afar, but even those stationed further back in reserve, fled in a shameful rout.

sentences.latin: nec prius finem fugae fecerunt saepe amissis superioribus locis quam se aut in castra suorum reciperent, aut nonnulli pudore coacti longius profugerent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and not sooner an end of flight they made, often having been lost the higher places, than themselves either into the camps of their own they betook, or some by shame compelled further fled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and not sooner an end of flight they made, often having lost higher places, than themselves either into the camps of their own they betook, or some by shame compelled further fled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They did not stop their flight, often abandoning higher ground, until they had either reached their own camp or, in some cases, driven by shame, fled even further away.

sentences.latin: Quorum periculo sic omnes copiae sunt perturbatae ut vix iudicari posset, utrum secundis minimisque rebus insolentiores an adverso mediocri casu timidiores essent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whose danger so all the forces were disturbed that scarcely to be judged it was able, whether in favorable and very small things more arrogant or in an adverse moderate misfortune more fearful they were.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By whose danger thus all the forces were thrown into confusion that scarcely it could be judged, whether in favorable and very small matters more insolent or in an adverse moderate misfortune more timid they were.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The entire army was so unsettled by their danger that it was hard to tell whether they were more arrogant in the slightest success or more cowardly in a moderate setback.

sentences.latin: Compluribus diebus isdem in castris consumptis, cum propius accessisse legiones et Gaium Trebonium legatum cognossent, duces Bellovacorum veriti similem obsessionem Alesiae noctu dimittunt eos quos aut aetate aut viribus inferiores aut inermes habebant, unaque reliqua impedimenta.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Several days in the same camps having been spent, when nearer to have approached the legions and Gaius Trebonius the legate they had learned, the leaders of the Bellovaci fearing a similar siege of Alesia by night send away those whom either by age or by strength inferior or unarmed they were holding, and together the remaining baggage.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Several days in the same camps having been spent, when nearer to have approached the legions and Gaius Trebonius the legate they had learned, the leaders of the Bellovaci having feared a similar siege of Alesia by night they send away those whom either by age or by strength inferior or unarmed they had, and together the remaining baggage.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After spending several days in the same camp, the leaders of the Bellovaci learned that the legions and the legate Gaius Trebonius were approaching. Fearing a siege like the one at Alesia, they sent away by night those who were unfit for battle due to age or weakness, or who were unarmed, along with the rest of the baggage train.

sentences.latin: Quorum perturbatum et confusum dum explicant agmen (magna enim multitudo carrorum etiam expeditos sequi Gallos consuevit), oppressi luce copias armatorum pro suis instruunt castris, ne prius Romani persequi se inciperent quam longius agmen impedimentorum suorum processisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom the disturbed and confused while they unfold the column (for a great multitude of carts even light-armed to follow the Gauls was accustomed), overtaken by light the forces of armed men in front of their camps they draw up, lest sooner the Romans to pursue them should begin than further the column of baggage of their own had proceeded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom the disturbed and confused while they set in order the column (for a great multitude of wagons even unencumbered to follow the Gauls was accustomed), overtaken by light the forces of armed men before their camps they draw up, lest sooner the Romans to pursue them should begin than further the column of baggage of their own had proceeded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While they were organizing this disordered and confused columnfor a vast number of wagons usually follows the Gauls even when they are lightly equippeddaylight caught them. They drew up their armed forces in front of their camp to prevent the Romans from beginning a pursuit before their baggage train had advanced a sufficient distance.

sentences.latin: At Caesar neque resistentes adgrediendos tanto collis ascensu iudicabat, neque non usque eo legiones admovendas ut discedere ex eo loco sine periculo barbari militibus instantibus non possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Caesar neither those resisting to be attacked with so great of a hill ascent was judging, nor not up to that point the legions to be moved forward so that to depart from that place without danger the barbarians with the soldiers pressing on were not able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Caesar neither those resisting to be attacked with so great of a hill ascent was judging, nor not up to that point the legions to be moved forward so that to depart from that place without danger the barbarians with the soldiers pressing on not could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, however, judged that he should not attack them while they resisted on such a steep ascent, but he also felt that he must move his legions forward far enough so that the barbarians could not retreat from that position without danger while his soldiers pressed them.

sentences.latin: Ita, cum palude impedita a castris castra dividi videret, quae transeundi difficultas celeritatem insequendi tardare posset, atque id iugum quod trans paludem paene ad hostium castra pertineret mediocri valle a castris eorum intercisum animum adverteret, pontibus palude constrata legiones traducit celeriterque in summam planitiem iugi pervenit, quae declivi fastigio duobus ab lateribus muniebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus, when by a marsh hindered from the camps the camps to be divided he saw, which difficulty of crossing the speed of following was able to slow, and that ridge which across the marsh almost to the of the enemies camp extended by a moderate valley from the camps of them cut off he noticed, with bridges the marsh having been covered the legions he leads across and quickly onto the highest level of the ridge he arrives, which with a sloping side from two sides was protected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus, when by a marsh hindered from the camps the camps to be divided he saw, which difficulty of crossing the speed of following could delay, and that ridge which across the marsh almost to the of the enemies camp extended by a moderate valley from the camps of them cut off he noticed, with bridges the marsh having been covered the legions he leads across and quickly onto the highest level of the ridge he arrives, which with a sloping side from two sides was protected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, seeing that the camps were separated by a difficult marsh which could hinder the speed of pursuit, and noticing that the ridge extending across the marsh almost to the enemy's camp was separated from it only by a small valley, he bridged the marsh, led his legions across, and quickly reached the level summit of the ridge, which was protected on two sides by steep slopes.

sentences.latin: Ibi legionibus instructis ad ultimum iugum pervenit aciemque eo loco constituit unde tormento missa tela in hostium cuneos conici possent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There the legions having been drawn up to the furthest ridge he arrived and the line in that place he established from where by an engine sent missiles into the of the enemies wedges to be thrown were able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There the legions having been drawn up to the furthest ridge he arrived and the battle line in that place he established from where by an engine sent missiles into the of the enemies columns to be thrown could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having drawn up his legions there, he reached the end of the ridge and formed his line of battle in a position from which missiles launched by engines could be hurled into the enemy's ranks.

sentences.latin: Barbari confisi loci natura, cum dimicare non recusarent, si forte Romani subire collem conarentur, paulatim copias distributas dimittere non possent, ne dispersi perturbarentur, in acie permanserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The barbarians trusting in the nature of the place, since to fight they were not refusing, if by chance the Romans to go up the hill should try, little by little the forces distributed to send away they were not able, lest dispersed they should be disturbed, in line of battle they remained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The barbarians having trusted in the nature of the place, although to fight not they were refusing, if by chance the Romans to go up the hill should try, little by little the forces distributed to send away not they could, lest dispersed they be thrown into confusion, in battle line they remained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The barbarians, trusting in the nature of the ground, did not refuse to fight if the Romans should attempt to climb the hill; however, they could not withdraw their forces in small detachments for fear of being thrown into confusion while scattered, so they remained in battle formation.

sentences.latin: Quorum pertinacia cognita Caesar XX cohortibus instructis castrisque eo loco metatis muniri iubet castra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom the persistence having been known, Caesar, twenty cohorts having been drawn up and a camp in that place having been measured out, orders the camp to be fortified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom the persistence having been learned Caesar with 20 cohorts drawn up and the camp in that place having been measured out to be fortified he orders the camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having recognized their persistence, Caesar drew up twenty cohorts, surveyed a site for a camp, and ordered it to be fortified.

sentences.latin: Absolutis operibus pro vallo legiones instructas collocat, equites frenatis equis in statione disponit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The works having been completed, before the rampart the legions drawn up he places, the horsemen, horses having been bridled, in station he disposes.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been finished the works before the rampart the legions drawn up he places, the horsemen with bridled horses in station he disposes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Once the fortifications were finished, he stationed the legions in battle formation in front of the rampart and posted the cavalry, with their horses bridled, at their stations.

sentences.latin: Bellovaci, cum Romanos ad insequendum paratos viderent neque pernoctare aut diutius permanere sine periculo eodem loco possent, tale consilium sui recipiendi ceperunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The Bellovaci, when the Romans for pursuing prepared they saw nor to pass the night or longer to remain without danger in the same place they were able, such a plan of themselves withdrawing they took.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The Bellovaci, when the Romans for following ready they saw and neither to pass the night or longer to remain without danger in the same place they could, such a plan of themselves withdrawing they took.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the Bellovaci saw that the Romans were ready to pursue them and realized they could not stay the night or remain in the same spot any longer without danger, they formed a plan for their retreat.

sentences.latin: Fasces, ubi consederant (namque in acie sedere Gallos consuesse superioribus commentariis Caesaris declaratum est), per manus stramentorum ac virgultorum, quorum summa erat in castris copia, inter se traditos ante aciem collocarunt extremoque tempore diei signo pronuntiato uno tempore incenderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Bundles, where they had sat (for in battle line to sit the Gauls to have been accustomed in previous commentaries of Caesar it has been declared), through hands of straw and of brushwood, of which the greatest was in the camp abundance, among themselves handed over before the line they placed and at the final time of the day, the signal having been announced, at one time they set on fire.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Bundles, where they had sat (for in battle line to sit the Gauls to have been accustomed in previous commentaries of Caesar it has been declared), through hands of straw and of brushwood, of which the greatest was in the camps supply, among themselves handed over before the battle line they placed and at the last time of the day a signal having been announced at one time they set on fire.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They passed from hand to hand bundles of straw and brushwood, which were in great supply in the camp, and placed them in front of their line where they had been sitting (for it has been noted in Caesar's earlier commentaries that the Gauls are accustomed to sit in formation); then, at the end of the day, upon a given signal, they set them all on fire at once.

sentences.latin: Ita continens flamma copias omnes repente a conspectu texit Romanorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus a continuous flame the forces all suddenly from the sight covered of the Romans.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus a continuous flame the forces all suddenly from the sight covered of the Romans.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this way, a continuous wall of fire suddenly hid all their forces from the sight of the Romans.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi accidit, barbari vehementissimo cursu refugerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when it happened, the barbarians with a most violent running fled back.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when it happened, the barbarians with a most violent running fled back.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this happened, the barbarians retreated at a very rapid pace.

sentences.latin: Caesar, etsi discessum hostium animadvertere non poterat incendiis oppositis, tamen id consilium cum fugae causa initum suspicaretur, legiones promovet, turmas mittit ad insequendum; ipse veritus insidias, ne forte in eodem loco subsistere hostis atque elicere nostros in locum conaretur iniquum, tardius procedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, although the departure of the enemies to notice he was not able, fires having been placed in the way, nevertheless that plan since for the sake of flight begun he suspected, the legions he moves forward, the troops he sends for pursuing; himself having feared ambushes, lest by chance in the same place to halt the enemy and to lure our men into a place unfavorable he might try, more slowly proceeds.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, although the departure of the enemies to notice not he was able with fires placed in the way, yet that plan since for the sake of flight begun he was suspecting, the legions moves forward, the troops he sends for following; himself having feared ambushes, lest by chance in the same place to halt the enemy and to lure our men into a place he might try unfavorable, more slowly proceeds.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Caesar could not see the enemy's departure because of the intervening fires, he suspected the plan had been made for the purpose of flight; he moved the legions forward and sent the cavalry to pursue them. Fearing an ambush, however, lest the enemy might be halting in the same spot to lure our men into unfavorable ground, he himself advanced more slowly.

sentences.latin: Equites cum intrare fumum et flammam densissimam timerent ac, si qui cupidius intraverant, vix suorum ipsi priores partes animadverterent equorum, insidias veriti liberam facultatem sui recipiendi Bellovacis dederunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The horsemen when to enter the smoke and flame most dense they feared and, if any more eagerly had entered, scarcely of their own themselves the front parts they noticed of the horses, ambushes having feared, a free opportunity of themselves withdrawing to the Bellovaci they gave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The horsemen when to enter the smoke and flame most dense they were fearing and, if any more eagerly had entered, scarcely of their own they themselves the front parts were noticing of the horses, ambushes having feared a free opportunity of themselves withdrawing to the Bellovaci they gave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since the cavalry were afraid to enter the smoke and thick flamesand those who had entered too eagerly could hardly see the heads of their own horsesthey feared an ambush and gave the Bellovaci a clear opportunity to retreat.

sentences.latin: Ita fuga timoris simul calliditatisque plena sine ullo detrimento milia non amplius decem progressi hostes loco munitissimo castra posuerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus by a flight of fear at the same time and of cleverness full, without any loss, miles not more than ten having advanced, the enemies in a place most fortified a camp placed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus a flight of fear at the same time and of cleverness full without any loss miles not more than ten having advanced the enemies in a place most fortified a camp placed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, after a retreat characterized by both fear and cunning, the enemy advanced no more than ten miles without any loss and pitched camp in a very strong position.

sentences.latin: Inde cum saepe in insidiis equites peditesque disponerent, magna detrimenta Romanis in pabulationibus inferebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From there when often in ambushes horsemen and foot-soldiers they disposed, great losses to the Romans in foraging they were bringing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From there when often in ambushes horsemen and footmen they were disposing, great losses to the Romans in foraging they were bringing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From that position, by frequently placing cavalry and infantry in ambush, they began to inflict heavy losses on the Romans during their foraging expeditions.

sentences.latin: Quod cum crebrius accideret, ex captivo quodam comperit Caesar Correum, Bellovacorum ducem, fortissimorum milia sex peditum delegisse equitesque ex omni numero mille, quos in insidiis eo loco collocaret, quem in locum propter copiam frumenti ac pabuli Romanos missuros suspicaretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when more frequently it happened, from a captive certain found out Caesar Correus, of the Bellovaci leader, of most brave thousands six of infantry to have chosen and horsemen from all number a thousand, whom in ambush in that place he might station, which into place on account of abundance of grain and fodder the Romans to be about to send he suspected.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when more frequently it happened, from a certain captive learned Caesar that Correus, of the Bellovaci leader, of most brave thousands six of footmen had chosen and horsemen from every number a thousand, whom in ambush in that place he might place, which into place on account of abundance of grain and fodder the Romans to be about to send he suspected.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this began to happen more frequently, Caesar learned from a certain prisoner that Correus, the leader of the Bellovaci, had selected six thousand of his bravest infantry and a thousand cavalry from the whole number to station in ambush in a place where he suspected the Romans would send for grain and fodder.

sentences.latin: Quo cognito consilio legiones plures quam solebat educit equitatumque, qua consuetudine pabulatoribus mittere praesidio consuerat, praemittit: huic interponit auxilia levis armaturae; ipse cum legionibus quam potest maxime appropinquat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which known plan legions more than he was accustomed he leads out and cavalry, by which custom to the foragers to send for a protection he had been accustomed, he sends ahead: to this he interposes auxiliaries of light armor; himself with the legions as he is able most greatly approaches.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which known plan the legions more than he was accustomed he leads out and the cavalry, by which custom to the foragers to send for a protection he had been accustomed, he sends ahead: to this he interposes auxiliaries of light armor; himself with the legions as much as he is able most closely approaches.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned of this plan, Caesar led out more legions than usual and sent the cavalry ahead, as was his custom to provide protection for the foragers; among these he interspersed light-armed auxiliaries, while he himself followed as closely as possible with the legions.

sentences.latin: Hostes in insidiis dispositi, cum sibi delegissent campum ad rem gerendam non amplius patentem in omnes partes passibus mille, silvis undique aut impeditissimo flumine munitum, velut indagine hunc insidiis circumdederunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The enemies in ambush disposed, when for themselves they had chosen a field for the thing to be done not more extending in all parts by paces a thousand, by woods on all sides or by a most obstructed river fortified, as if with a snare this with ambushes they surrounded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The enemy in ambush disposed, when for themselves they had chosen a field for the thing to be done not more extending in all parts by paces a thousand, by woods on all sides or by a most obstructed river fortified, as if by a snare this with an ambush they surrounded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy, stationed in ambush, had chosen a field for the action that extended no more than a thousand paces in any direction and was protected on all sides by woods or a very difficult river; they surrounded this area with their traps as if with a net.

sentences.latin: Explorato hostium consilio nostri ad proeliandum animo atque armis parati, cum subsequentibus legionibus nullam dimicationem recusarent, turmatim in eum locum devenerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been explored the enemy's plan our men for fighting in spirit and with arms prepared, since with following legions no struggle they would refuse, by troops into that place they arrived.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been explored the of the enemy plan our men for fighting in mind and with arms prepared, since with following legions no struggle they refused, by troops into that place they came.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having discovered the enemy's plan, our men, prepared in spirit and arms for battle and knowing the legions were following so they need not refuse any engagement, arrived at the spot troop by troop.

sentences.latin: Quorum adventu cum sibi Correus oblatam occasionem rei gerendae existimaret, primum cum paucis se ostendit atque in proximas turmas impetum fecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom by the arrival when for himself Correus offered an opportunity of the thing to be done he thought, first with a few himself he showed and into the nearest troops an attack he made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom by the arrival when to himself Correus offered an opportunity of the thing to be done he thought, first with a few himself he showed and into the nearest troops an attack he made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon their arrival, Correus, thinking that an opportunity for action had been offered to him, first showed himself with a few men and made an attack on the nearest troops.

sentences.latin: Nostri constanter incursum sustinent insidiatorum neque plures in unum locum conveniunt; quod plerumque equestribus proeliis cum propter aliquem timorem accidit, tum multitudine ipsorum detrimentum accipitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Our men firmly the attack sustain of the ambushers nor more into one place they come together; which mostly in cavalry battles when on account of some fear it happens, then by the multitude of themselves a loss is received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our men steadily the attack sustain of the ambushers nor more into one place they come together; which mostly in cavalry battles when on account of some fear it happens, then by the multitude of themselves a loss is received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our men firmly withstood the attack of the ambushers and avoided clustering together in one spot; in cavalry battles, when this happens due to fear, the very density of the crowd usually leads to heavy losses.

sentences.latin: Cum dispositis turmis in vicem rari proeliarentur neque ab lateribus circumveniri suos paterentur, erumpunt ceteri Correo proeliante ex silvis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When with disposed troops in turn scattered they were fighting nor from the sides to be surrounded their own they allowed, burst out the rest with Correus fighting from the woods.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When with disposed troops in turn scattered they were fighting nor from the sides to be surrounded their own they permitted, break out the rest while Correus is fighting from the woods.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While our troops, arranged in units, fought in turns and in small groups, refusing to let their flanks be turned, the rest of the enemy burst out of the woods while Correus was still engaged.

sentences.latin: Fit magna contentione diversum proelium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There happens with great struggle a scattered battle.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It becomes with great contention a diverse battle.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A confused battle ensued, fought with great intensity.

sentences.latin: Quod cum diutius pari Marte iniretur, paulatim ex silvis instructa multitudo procedit peditum, quae nostros coegit cedere equites.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when for a longer time with equal Mars it was entered upon, gradually from the woods drawn up a multitude proceeds of infantry, which our forced to yield horsemen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when for a longer time with equal Mars it was entered upon, gradually from the woods drawn up a multitude proceeds of footmen, which our men forced to yield horsemen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the battle had continued for some time with equal success on both sides, a body of infantry gradually emerged from the woods in formation, forcing our cavalry to give ground.

sentences.latin: Quibus celeriter subveniunt levis armaturae pedites, quos ante legiones missos docui, turmisque nostrorum interpositi constanter proeliantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To whom quickly come to help of light armor infantry, whom before the legions sent I showed, and with the troops of our men interposed firmly they fight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To whom quickly help the of light armor footmen, whom before the legions sent I have shown, and with the troops of our men interposed steadily they fight.
sentences.naturalTranslation: These were quickly reinforced by the light-armed infantry, who I mentioned had been sent ahead of the legions; taking their places among our cavalry units, they fought on with determination.

sentences.latin: Pugnatur aliquamdiu pari contentione; deinde, ut ratio postulabat proeli, qui sustinuerant primos impetus insidiarum hoc ipso fiunt superiores, quod nullum ab insidiantibus imprudentes acceperant detrimentum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: It is fought for some time with equal exertion; then, as the nature of the battle was demanding, those who had sustained the first attacks of the ambush by this very thing become superior, because no damage from the ambushers they unaware had received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: It is fought for some time with equal contention; then, as the reason demanded of the battle, who had sustained the first attacks of the ambush by this very thing they become superior, because no from the ambushers unaware they had received loss.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The battle raged for some time with equal intensity; then, as the nature of the engagement required, those who had withstood the initial ambush gained the upper hand for the very reason that they, though caught off guard, had suffered no loss from the attackers.

sentences.latin: Accedunt propius interim legiones, crebrique eodem tempore et nostris et hostibus nuntii adferuntur, imperatorem instructis copiis adesse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Approach nearer meanwhile the legions, and frequent at the same time both to our men and to the enemy messages are brought, the general with drawn up forces to be present.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They approach nearer meanwhile the legions, and frequent at the same time both to our men and to the enemy messengers are brought, the commander with drawn up forces to be present.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the legions drew closer, and at the same time, frequent reports reached both our men and the enemy that the commander was approaching with his troops in battle formation.

sentences.latin: Qua re cognita praesidio cohortium confisi nostri acerrime proeliantur, ne, si tardius rem gessissent, victoriae gloriam communicasse cum legionibus viderentur;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been known, in the protection of the cohorts having trusted, our men most fiercely fight, lest, if more slowly the thing they had conducted, the glory of the victory to have shared with the legions they might seem;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing known in the protection of the cohorts trusting our men most fiercely fight, lest, if more slowly the thing they had done, of the victory the glory to have shared with the legions they might seem;
sentences.naturalTranslation: Upon learning this, our men, trusting in the support of the cohorts, fought with the utmost ferocity, fearing that if they acted too slowly, they might appear to be sharing the glory of the victory with the incoming legions.

sentences.latin: hostes concidunt animis atque itineribus diversis fugam quaerunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: the enemy fall in spirits and by ways diverse flight seek.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: the enemy fall in minds and by routes diverse flight they seek.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy's spirits collapsed, and they sought escape by various routes.

sentences.latin: Nequiquam: nam quibus difficultatibus locorum Romanos claudere voluerant, eis ipsi tenebantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In vain: for by which difficulties of places the Romans to shut in they had wished, by those themselves they were being held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In vain: for by which difficulties of places the Romans to shut in they had wished, by those themselves they were held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: It was in vain: for they were now trapped by the same difficult terrain in which they had intended to hem in the Romans.

sentences.latin: Victi tamen perculsique maiore parte amissa consternati profugiunt partim silvis petitis, partim flumine (qui tamen in fuga a nostris acriter insequentibus conficiuntur),
sentences.referenceTranslation: Conquered however and struck down, with the greater part lost, dismayed they flee, partly the woods having been sought, partly the river (who however in flight by our men sharply pursuing are finished off),
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Conquered however and struck down with the greater part lost dismayed they flee partly the woods having been sought, partly the river (who however in flight by our men sharply following are finished),
sentences.naturalTranslation: Defeated, demoralized, and having lost most of their number, they fled in panic, some seeking the woods and others the river (where, however, they were cut down by our men in hot pursuit).

sentences.latin: cum interim nulla calamitate victus Correus excedere proelio silvasque petere aut invitantibus nostris ad deditionem potuit adduci, quin fortissime proeliando compluresque vulnerando cogeret elatos iracundia victores in se tela conicere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: while meanwhile by no calamity conquered Correus to withdraw from the battle and the woods to seek or, with our men inviting, to surrender could be led, but that by most bravely fighting and several wounding he forced carried away by anger the victors against himself weapons to hurl.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: when meanwhile by no calamity conquered Correus to depart from the battle and the woods to seek or by inviting our men to surrender could be led, but most bravely by fighting and many by wounding he forced the carried away by anger victors against himself weapons to hurl.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Correus, unbroken by any disaster, could not be persuaded to leave the field, seek the woods, or accept our invitation to surrender; instead, by fighting most bravely and wounding many, he forced the victors, incensed by his resistance, to hurl their weapons at him.

sentences.latin: Tali modo re gesta recentibus proeli vestigiis ingressus Caesar, cum victos tanta calamitate existimaret hostes nuntio accepto locum castrorum relicturos, quae non longius ab ea caede abesse plus minus octo milibus dicebantur, tametsi flumine impeditum transitum videbat, tamen exercitu traducto progreditur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In such a manner the thing having been done, on the fresh of the battle tracks having entered Caesar, since conquered by so great a calamity he was thinking the enemy, the message having been received, the place of the camps would leave, which not further from that slaughter to be distant more or less eight miles were said, although by the river hindered the passage he was seeing, nevertheless the army having been led across he advances.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In such a way the thing having been done on the fresh of the battle tracks having entered Caesar, since conquered by so great a calamity he thought the enemy the news having been received the place of the camps would leave, which not further from that slaughter to be away more or less eight thousands were said, although by the river hindered the passage he saw, yet the army having been led across he proceeds.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the affair was concluded in this way, Caesar, following the fresh tracks of the battle, believed that the enemy, crushed by such a disaster, would abandon their camp (which was said to be about eight miles from the scene of the slaughter) upon hearing the news; therefore, although he saw the crossing was obstructed by the river, he nevertheless led his army across and advanced.

sentences.latin: At Bellovaci reliquaeque civitates repente ex fuga paucis atque his vulneratis receptis, qui silvarum beneficio casum evitaverant, omnibus adversis, cognita calamitate, interfecto Correo, amisso equitatu et fortissimis peditibus, cum adventare Romanos existimarent, concilio repente cantu tubarum convocato conclamant, legati obsidesque ad Caesarem mittantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But the Bellovaci and the remaining states suddenly from flight a few and these wounded having been received, who by the benefit of the woods the fall had avoided, all things being adverse, the calamity having been known, Correus having been killed, the cavalry lost and the bravest infantry, since to approach the Romans they were thinking, a council suddenly by the sound of trumpets having been called they cry out, ambassadors and hostages to Caesar should be sent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But the Bellovaci and the remaining states suddenly from flight a few and these wounded having been received, who by the of the woods benefit the fall had avoided, with all things adverse, known the calamity, killed Correus, lost the cavalry and the most brave footmen, when to approach the Romans they thought, a council suddenly by the sound of trumpets called together they cry out, ambassadors and hostages to Caesar should be sent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But the Bellovaci and the other tribes, having taken in a few fugitives (and those wounded) who had escaped disaster thanks to the woods, found everything against them; with the disaster known, Correus killed, and their cavalry and finest infantry lost, and believing the Romans were approaching, they suddenly summoned a council by trumpet-call and cried out that ambassadors and hostages should be sent to Caesar.

sentences.latin: Hoc omnibus probato consilio Commius Atrebas ad eos confugit Germanos, a quibus ad id bellum auxilia mutuatus erat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This by all approved plan, Commius the Atrebatian to those fled Germans, from whom for that war auxiliaries borrowed he had.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This by all approved plan Commius the Atrebatian to those Germans fled, from whom for that war auxiliaries borrowed he had.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This plan being approved by all, Commius the Atrebatian fled to those Germans from whom he had borrowed auxiliary troops for that war.

sentences.latin: Ceteri e vestigio mittunt ad Caesarem legatos petuntque, ut ea poena sit contentus hostium, quam si sine dimicatione inferre integris posset, pro sua clementia atque humanitate numquam profecto esset illaturus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The others from the track send to Caesar ambassadors and seek, that with that punishment he be content of the enemies, which if without a struggle to inflict on the unhurt he were able, for his own mercy and humanity never certainly he would have been about to inflict.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The others from the track send to Caesar ambassadors and ask, that with that punishment he be content of the enemies, which if without a struggle to inflict on [them] untouched he were able, in accordance with his clemency and humanity never certainly he would have been about to inflict.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The rest immediately sent ambassadors to Caesar, requesting that he be satisfied with a punishment for the enemy which, out of his own mercy and humanity, he certainly would never have inflicted had he been able to do so without a battle while their forces were still intact.

sentences.latin: Adflictas opes equestri proelio Bellovacorum esse; delectorum peditum multa milia interisse, vix refugisse nuntios caedis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Afflicted the resources in a cavalry battle of the Bellovaci to be; of chosen infantry many thousands to have perished, scarcely to have fled back messengers of the slaughter.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Shattered the resources in a cavalry battle of the Bellovaci to be; of chosen infantry many thousands to have perished, scarcely to have escaped messengers of the slaughter.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They stated that the power of the Bellovaci had been broken in the cavalry engagement; many thousands of picked infantry had perished, and hardly any messengers of the slaughter had escaped.

sentences.latin: Tamen magnum ut in tanta calamitate Bellovacos eo proelio commodum esse consecutos, quod Correus, auctor belli, concitator multitudinis, esset interfectus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nevertheless a great as in so great a calamity the Bellovaci by that battle an advantage to have obtained, because Correus, the author of the war, the stirrer up of the multitude, had been killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nevertheless a great as in so great a calamity the Bellovaci in that battle advantage to have obtained, because Correus, author of the war, stirrer up of the multitude, had been killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nevertheless, they claimed that the Bellovaci had gained a great advantage in the midst of such a disaster, because Correus, the instigator of the war and the agitator of the common people, had been killed.

sentences.latin: Numquam enim senatum tantum in civitate illo vivo quantum imperitam plebem potuisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Never for the senate so much in the state he being alive as much as the unskilled common people to have been able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Never for the senate so much in the state he living as much as the ignorant common people to have been able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For while he was alive, the senate had never possessed as much power in the state as the ignorant masses.

sentences.latin: Haec orantibus legatis commemorat Caesar: Eodem tempore superiore anno Bellovacos ceterasque Galliae civitates suscepisse bellum: pertinacissime hos ex omnibus in sententia permansisse neque ad sanitatem reliquorum deditione esse perductos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These things to the praying ambassadors mentions Caesar: At the same time in the previous year the Bellovaci and the other of Gaul states to have undertaken war: most stubbornly these out of all in their opinion to have remained nor to sanity of the rest by surrender to have been led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These things to the praying ambassadors mentions Caesar: At the same time in the previous year the Bellovaci and the other of Gaul states to have undertaken war: most stubbornly these out of all in their opinion to have remained and not to sanity of the rest by surrender to have been led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To the ambassadors making these pleas, Caesar replied: At the same time the previous year, the Bellovaci and the other Gallic states had begun the war; of all of them, the Bellovaci had most stubbornly persisted in their purpose and had not been brought to their senses by the surrender of the others.

sentences.latin: Scire atque intellegere se causam peccati facillime mortuis delegari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To know and to understand himself the cause of the sin most easily to the dead to be assigned.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To know and to understand himself the cause of the sin most easily to the dead to be assigned.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He said he knew and understood that the blame for a fault is very easily shifted onto the dead.

sentences.latin: Neminem vero tantum pollere, ut invitis principibus, resistente senatu, omnibus bonis repugnantibus infirma manu plebis bellum concitare et gerere posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: No one indeed so much to be powerful, that the leaders being unwilling, the senate resisting, all good men fighting back, with a weak hand of the common people war to stir up and to wage he could.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: No one truly so much to be powerful, that with unwilling leaders, with resisting senate, with all good [men] fighting back with a weak hand of the common people war to stir up and to wage he could.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, no individual was so powerful that he could stir up and wage war with a weak following of commoners if the leaders were unwilling, the senate resisted, and all patriotic citizens opposed him.

sentences.latin: Sed tamen se contentum fore ea poena quam sibi ipsi contraxissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But nevertheless himself content to be about to be with that punishment which for themselves they themselves had contracted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But nevertheless himself content to be about to be with that punishment which for themselves they themselves had contracted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But nevertheless, he would be satisfied with the punishment they had brought upon themselves.

sentences.latin: Nocte insequenti legati responsa ad suos referunt, obsides conficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In the night following the ambassadors the responses to their own people carry back, the hostages they prepare.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: On the night following the ambassadors the responses to their own [people] carry back, hostages they make ready.
sentences.naturalTranslation: On the following night, the ambassadors carried the answers back to their people and prepared the hostages.

sentences.latin: Concurrunt reliquarum civitatium legati, quae Bellovacorum speculabantur eventum;
sentences.referenceTranslation: There run together of the remaining states the ambassadors, which of the Bellovaci were watching the outcome;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Run together of the remaining states the ambassadors, which of the Bellovaci were watching the outcome;
sentences.naturalTranslation: The ambassadors of the other states, who had been watching the outcome of the Bellovaci's situation, flocked together.

sentences.latin: obsides dant, imperata faciunt excepto Commio, quem timor prohibebat cuiusquam fidei suam committere salutem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Hostages they give, commands they do except Commius, whom fear was preventing to anyone's faith his own to commit safety.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Hostages they give, the things commanded they do except for Commius, whom fear was preventing to anyone's faith his own to commit safety.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They gave hostages and obeyed his commands, with the exception of Commius, whose fear prevented him from entrusting his safety to anyone's word.

sentences.latin: Nam superiore anno Titus Labienus, Caesare in Gallia citeriore ius dicente, cum Commium comperisset sollicitare civitates et coniurationem contra Caesarem facere, infidelitatem eius sine ulla perfidia iudicavit comprimi posse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For in the previous year Titus Labienus, Caesar in Hither Gaul law speaking, when Commius he had found to solicit states and a conspiracy against Caesar to make, the infidelity of him without any treachery he judged to be able to be suppressed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For in the previous year Titus Labienus, with Caesar in Gaul hither law saying, when Commius he had discovered to solicit states and a conspiracy against Caesar to make, the infidelity of him without any treachery he judged to be able to be suppressed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For in the previous year, while Caesar was administering justice in Hither Gaul, Titus Labienus discovered that Commius was inciting the tribes and forming a conspiracy against Caesar; he judged that his infidelity could be suppressed without any breach of faith.

sentences.latin: Quem quia non arbitrabatur vocatum in castra venturum, ne temptando cautiorem faceret, Gaium Volusenum Quadratum misit, qui eum per simulationem colloqui curaret interficiendum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whom because he was not thinking called into the camp would come, lest by attempting more cautious he might make, Gaius Volusenus Quadratus he sent, who him through a pretense of a conference should care for to be killed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whom because not he was thinking called into the camp to be about to come, lest by trying more cautious he might make [him], Gaius Volusenus Quadratus he sent, who him through the pretense of a conference should take care to be killed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Because he did not think Commius would come to the camp if summoned, and not wishing to make him more cautious by the attempt, he sent Gaius Volusenus Quadratus to arrange for his assassination under the pretense of a conference.

sentences.latin: Ad eam rem delectos idoneos ei tradit centuriones.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For that thing chosen suitable to him he hands over centurions.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For that thing chosen suitable to him he hands over centurions.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this purpose, he assigned him chosen and suitable centurions.

sentences.latin: Cum in colloquium ventum esset, et, ut convenerat, manum Commi Volusenus arripuisset, centurio vel insueta re permotus vel celeriter a familiaribus prohibitus Commi conficere hominem non potuit; graviter tamen primo ictu gladio caput percussit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When into the conference it had been come, and, as it had been agreed, the hand of Commius Volusenus had seized, a centurion either by the unusual thing moved or quickly by the friends of Commius prevented to finish the man was not able; heavily however with the first blow with a sword the head he struck.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When into the conference it had been come, and, as it had been agreed, the hand of Commius Volusenus had seized, a centurion either by the unusual thing moved or quickly by the friends of Commius prevented to finish the man not he was able; heavily however with the first blow with a sword the head he struck.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When they had come to the conference and Volusenus had seized Commius' hand as agreed, the centurioneither unsettled by the unusual task or quickly prevented by Commius' friendswas unable to finish the man off; however, he struck him a heavy blow on the head with his sword at the first stroke.

sentences.latin: Cum utrimque gladii destricti essent, non tam pugnandi quam diffugiendi fuit utrorumque consilium: nostrorum, quod mortifero vulnere Commium credebant adfectum; Gallorum, quod insidiis cognitis plura quam videbant extimescebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When on both sides swords drawn had been, not so much of fighting as of fleeing was of both the plan: of ours, because with a deadly wound Commius they were believing affected; of the Gauls, because the ambush having been recognized more things than they were seeing they were fearing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When on both sides swords drawn had been, not so much of fighting as of fleeing was of both the plan: of ours, because with a deadly wound Commius they were believing affected; of the Gauls, because the ambush having been recognized more things than they were seeing they were fearing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When swords were drawn on both sides, the intention of both parties was not so much to fight as to escape: our men believed Commius had been dealt a mortal wound, while the Gauls, realizing an ambush had been set, feared there were more dangers than they could see.

sentences.latin: Quo facto statuisse Commius dicebatur numquam in conspectum cuiusquam Romani venire.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing done to have decided Commius was said never into the sight of any Roman to come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing done to have decided Commius was said never into the sight of any Roman to come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this event, Commius was said to have resolved never again to come into the sight of any Roman.

sentences.latin: Bellicosissimis gentibus devictis Caesar, cum videret nullam iam esse civitatem quae bellum pararet quo sibi resisteret, sed nonnullos ex oppidis demigrare, ex agris diffugere ad praesens imperium evitandum, plures in partes exercitum dimittere constituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The most warlike tribes having been conquered Caesar, when he saw no now to be state which war was preparing by which to him it might resist, but some from the towns to move away, from the fields to flee for the present rule avoiding, into more parts the army to send away he decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The most warlike tribes having been conquered Caesar, when he saw no now to be state which war was preparing by which to himself it might resist, but some from the towns to be moving away, from the fields to be fleeing for the present command avoiding, into more parts the army to send away he decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having conquered the most warlike tribes, Caesar, seeing that no state was now preparing for war to resist him, but that some were moving out of the towns and fleeing from the fields to avoid his current rule, decided to divide his army into several parts.

sentences.latin: M. Antonium quaestorem cum legione duodecima sibi coniungit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Marcus Antonius the quaestor with the legion twelfth to himself he joins.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Marcus Antonius the quaestor with the legion twelfth to himself he joins.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He joined Marcus Antonius the quaestor and the twelfth legion to himself.

sentences.latin: C. Fabium legatum cum cohortibus XXV mittit in diversissimam partem Galliae, quod ibi quasdam civitates in armis esse audiebat neque C. Caninium Rebilum legatum, qui in illis regionibus erat, satis firmas duas legiones habere existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Gaius Fabius the legate with cohorts twenty-five he sends into a very different part of Gaul, because there certain states in arms to be he was hearing nor Gaius Caninius Rebilus the legate, who in those regions was, sufficiently strong two legions to have he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Gaius Fabius the legate with cohorts twenty-five he sends into a most diverse part of Gaul, because there certain states in arms to be he was hearing and not Gaius Caninius Rebilus the legate, who in those regions was, sufficiently firm two legions to have he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He sent Gaius Fabius the legate with twenty-five cohorts into a very distant part of Gaul, because he heard that certain tribes there were in arms, and he did not think that Gaius Caninius Rebilus the legate, who was in those regions, had two sufficiently strong legions.

sentences.latin: Titum Labienum ad se evocat; legionem autem XV, quae cum eo fuerat in hibernis, in togatam Galliam mittit ad colonias civium Romanorum tuendas, ne quod simile incommodum accideret decursione barbarorum ac superiore aestate Tergestinis acciderat, qui repentino latrocinio atque impetu illorum erant oppressi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Titus Labienus to himself he summons; the legion however 15th, which with him had been in winter quarters, into togated Gaul he sends for the colonies of citizens Roman to be protected, lest any similar misfortune should happen by the incursion of barbarians as in the previous summer to the Tergestini had happened, who by the sudden robbery and attack of those had been overwhelmed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Titus Labienus to himself he summons; the legion however 15th, which with him had been in winter quarters, into togated Gaul he sends for the colonies of citizens Roman to be protected, lest any similar inconvenience should happen by the incursion of barbarians as in the previous summer to the Tergestini had happened, who by a sudden robbery and attack of those had been overwhelmed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He summoned Titus Labienus to join him; however, he sent the 15th legion, which had been with Labienus in winter quarters, into Cisalpine Gaul to protect the colonies of Roman citizens, so that no similar disaster might occur from a barbarian incursion as had happened the previous summer to the people of Tergeste, who had been overwhelmed by their sudden raids and attacks.

sentences.latin: Ipse ad vastandos depopulandosque fines Ambiorigis proficiscitur; quem perterritum ac fugientem cum redigi posse in suam potestatem desperasset, proximum suae dignitatis esse ducebat, adeo fines eius vastare civibus, aedificiis, pecore, ut odio suorum Ambiorix, si quos fortuna reliquos fecisset, nullum reditum propter tantas calamitates haberet in civitatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself to the wasting and plundering the territories of Ambiorix sets out; whom terrified and fleeing when to be reduced to be able into his power he had despaired, the next thing to his dignity to be he was considering, to such an extent the territories of him to waste of citizens, buildings, cattle, that by the hatred of his own [people] Ambiorix, if any fortune remaining had made, no return on account of such great calamities would have into the state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself for the wasting and depopulating the territories of Ambiorix sets out; whom terrified and fleeing when to be reduced to be able into his power he had despaired, the next thing to his dignity to be he was thinking, to such an extent the territories of him to waste of citizens, buildings, cattle, that by the hatred of his own Ambiorix, if any fortune remaining had made, no return on account of such great calamities would have into the state.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself set out to devastate and pillage the territory of Ambiorix; since he despaired of being able to bring the terrified fugitive under his power, he considered it the next best thing for his prestige to strip his lands of people, buildings, and cattle to such an extent that Ambiorix would be so hated by his own peopleshould any survivethat he would have no hope of returning to his state after such great calamities.

sentences.latin: Cum in omnes partes finium Ambiorigis aut legiones aut auxilia dimisisset atque omnia caedibus, incendiis, rapinis vastasset, magno numero hominum interfecto aut capto Labienum cum duabus legionibus in Treveros mittit,
sentences.referenceTranslation: When into all parts of the territories of Ambiorix either legions or auxiliaries he had sent out and all things with slaughters, fires, robberies he had wasted, a great number of men having been killed or captured, Labienus with two legions into the Treveri he sends,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When into all parts of the territories of Ambiorix either legions or auxiliaries he had sent out and all things with slaughters, fires, robberies he had wasted, a great number of men having been killed or captured, Labienus with two legions into the Treveri he sends,
sentences.naturalTranslation: After he had dispatched either legions or auxiliary troops into every part of Ambiorix's territory and devastated everything with slaughter, fire, and pillage, killing or capturing a great number of people, he sent Labienus with two legions against the Treveri.

sentences.latin: quorum civitas propter Germaniae vicinitatem cotidianis exercitata bellis cultu et feritate non multum a Germanis differebat neque imperata umquam nisi exercitu coacta faciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: of whom the state on account of Germany's proximity by daily trained wars in culture and ferocity not much from the Germans was differing nor commands ever unless by an army compelled was it doing.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: of whom the state on account of Germany's proximity by daily trained wars in culture and ferocity not much from the Germans was differing nor commands ever unless by an army compelled was it doing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Their state, because of its proximity to Germany, was practiced in daily warfare and did not differ much from the Germans in their way of life and ferocity; they never obeyed orders unless compelled by an army.

sentences.latin: Interim Gaius Caninius legatus, cum magnam multitudinem convenisse hostium in fines Pictonum litteris nuntiisque Durati cognosceret, qui perpetuo in amicitia manserat Romanorum, cum pars quaedam civitatis eius defecisset, ad oppidum Lemonum contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Meanwhile Gaius Caninius the legate, when a great multitude to have assembled of the enemy into the borders of the Pictones by letters and messengers of Duratius he learned, who constantly in friendship had remained of the Romans, although a part certain of the state of him had revolted, to the town Lemonum he hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Meanwhile Gaius Caninius the legate, when a great multitude to have assembled of the enemy into the territories of the Pictones by letters and messengers of Duratius he was learning, who constantly in friendship had remained of the Romans, although a part certain of the state of him had revolted, to the town of Lemonum he hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, the legate Gaius Caninius, learning from the letters and messengers of Duratiuswho had remained a constant friend to the Romans even though a part of his state had revoltedthat a large force of the enemy had gathered in the territory of the Pictones, hastened toward the town of Lemonum.

sentences.latin: Quo cum adventaret atque ex captivis certius cognosceret multis hominum milibus a Dumnaco, duce Andium, Duratium clausum Lemoni oppugnari neque infirmas legiones hostibus committere auderet, castra posuit loco munito.
sentences.referenceTranslation: To which place when he was approaching and from prisoners more certainly he was learning by many of men thousands by Dumnacus, leader of the Andes, Duratius shut up at Lemonum to be besieged nor weak legions to the enemy to entrust he was daring, camp he placed in a place fortified.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: To which when he was approaching and from captives more certainly he was learning by many thousands of men by Dumnacus, leader of the Andes, Duratius shut up at Lemonum to be besieged nor weak legions to the enemy to commit he was daring, camp he placed in a place fortified.
sentences.naturalTranslation: As he approached the place and learned more definitely from prisoners that Duratius was shut up and besieged in Lemonum by many thousands of men under Dumnacus, leader of the Andes, he did not dare to risk his weak legions against the enemy and instead pitched camp in a fortified position.

sentences.latin: Dumnacus, cum appropinquare Caninium cognosset, copiis omnibus ad legiones conversis castra Romanorum oppugnare instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Dumnacus, when to approach Caninius he had known, with forces all toward the legions turned the camp of the Romans to attack he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Dumnacus, when to approach Caninius he had known, with forces all toward the legions turned the camp of the Romans to attack he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Dumnacus learned that Caninius was approaching, he turned all his forces against the legions and began to attack the Roman camp.

sentences.latin: Cum complures dies in oppugnatione consumpsisset et magno suorum detrimento nullam partem munitionum convellere potuisset, rursus ad obsidendum Lemonum redit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When several days in the attack he had spent and with great of his own [men] loss no part of the fortifications to tear away he had been able, again to the besieging Lemonum he returns.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When several days in the attack he had spent and with great of his own loss no part of the fortifications to tear away he had been able, again to the besieging Lemonum he returns.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After spending several days on the assault and being unable to break through any part of the fortifications despite heavy losses among his own men, he returned once more to the siege of Lemonum.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore C. Fabius legatus complures civitates in fidem recipit, obsidibus firmat litterisque Gai Canini Rebili fit certior quae in Pictonibus gerantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time C. Fabius the legate several states into faith receives, by hostages he strengthens and by letters of Gaius Caninius Rebilus he becomes more certain what in the Pictones are being done.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time C. Fabius the legate several states into faith receives, by hostages he strengthens and by letters of Gaius Caninius Rebilus he becomes more certain what in the Pictones are being done.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, the legate Gaius Fabius received several states into submission, securing them with hostages, and was informed by letters from Gaius Caninius Rebilus of what was happening among the Pictones.

sentences.latin: Quibus rebus cognitis proficiscitur ad auxilium Duratio ferendum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which things having been known he sets out to help to Duratius to be brought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which things having been known he sets out for help to Duratius to be brought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned of these matters, he set out to bring assistance to Duratius.

sentences.latin: At Dumnacus adventu Fabi cognito desperata salute, si tempore eodem coactus esset et Romanum externum sustinere hostem et respicere ac timere oppidanos, repente ex eo loco cum copiis recedit nec se satis tutum fore arbitratur, nisi flumine Ligeri, quod erat ponte propter magnitudinem transeundum, copias traduxisset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Dumnacus, the arrival of Fabius having been known, safety having been despaired of, if at the same time he should have been forced both the Roman external enemy to sustain and to look back at and fear the townsmen, suddenly from that place with his forces withdraws nor himself sufficiently safe to be he thinks, unless across the river Loire, which was by a bridge on account of its size to be crossed, his forces he had led across.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Dumnacus the arrival of Fabius having been known having despaired of safety, if at time the same he had been compelled both a Roman external to sustain enemy and to look back at and to fear the townsmen, suddenly from that place with forces he withdraws nor himself sufficiently safe to be he thinks, unless by the river Loire, which was by a bridge on account of its size to be crossed, his forces he had led across.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Dumnacus, learning of Fabius' arrival and despairing of his safety if forced to simultaneously withstand the external Roman enemy and watch the townsmen in fear, suddenly withdrew from that position with his troops. He believed he would not be safe until he had moved his forces across the Loire, which, due to its size, had to be crossed by a bridge.

sentences.latin: Fabius, etsi nondum in conspectum venerat hostibus neque se Caninio coniunxerat, tamen doctus ab eis qui locorum noverant naturam potissimum credidit hostes perterritos eum locum, quem petebant, petituros.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Fabius, although not yet into sight he had come to the enemies nor himself with Caninius he had joined, nevertheless informed by those who of the places knew the nature, especially believed the enemies terrified that place, which they were seeking, would seek.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Fabius, although not yet into sight he had come to the enemy nor himself with Caninius he had joined, nevertheless taught by those who of the places had known the nature especially believed the enemy terrified that place, which they were seeking, would seek.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although Fabius had not yet come into the enemy's sight or joined up with Caninius, he was informed by those familiar with the terrain and believed that the terrified enemy would head for the very destination they were already seeking.

sentences.latin: Itaque cum copiis ad eundem pontem contendit equitatumque tantum procedere ante agmen imperat legionum, quantum cum processisset, sine defatigatione equorum in eadem se reciperet castra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so with his forces to the same bridge he hastens and the cavalry so much to proceed before the line of march he orders of the legions, as much as when it had proceeded, without exhaustion of the horses into the same themselves they might recover camp.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so with forces to the same bridge he hastens and the cavalry so much to proceed before the line he orders of the legions, as much as when it had proceeded, without exhaustion of the horses into the same themselves they might recover camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, he hurried with his troops toward the same bridge and ordered the cavalry to advance ahead of the legions' line of march, but only so far that they could return to the same camp without exhausting their horses.

sentences.latin: Consecuntur equites nostri, ut erat praeceptum, invaduntque Dumnaci agmen et fugientes perterritosque sub sarcinis in itinere adgressi magna praeda multis interfectis potiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Follow our cavalry, as had been commanded, and they invade Dumnacus' column and the fleeing and terrified men under their packs on the march having attacked, great booty, many having been killed, they gain.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Follow our horsemen, as had been commanded, and they invade of Dumnacus the line and fleeing and terrified under packs on the march having attacked great booty many having been killed they gain.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our cavalry followed as ordered and attacked Dumnacus' column; falling upon the terrified men as they fled on the march burdened by their packs, they killed many and captured a great deal of booty.

sentences.latin: Ita re bene gesta se recipiunt in castra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus the thing well having been done, themselves they recover into camp.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus the matter well having been done themselves they recover into camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having successfully completed the operation, they returned to camp.

sentences.latin: Insequenti nocte Fabius equites praemittit sic paratos ut confligerent atque omne agmen morarentur, dum consequeretur ipse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: On the following night Fabius the cavalry sends ahead so prepared that they might engage and the whole column they might delay, until should follow he himself.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In the following night Fabius the cavalry sends ahead so prepared that they might clash and the whole line they might delay, until should follow he himself.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The following night, Fabius sent the cavalry ahead, prepared to engage and delay the entire column until he himself could catch up.

sentences.latin: Cuius praeceptis ut res gereretur, Quintus Atius Varus, praefectus equitum, singularis et animi et prudentiae vir, suos hortatur agmenque hostium consecutus turmas partim idoneis locis disponit, parte equitum proelium committit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By whose instructions so that the matter might be conducted, Quintus Atius Varus, prefect of the cavalry, of singular both courage and prudence a man, his own men encourages and the column of the enemies having followed, the troops partly in suitable places he stations, with part of the cavalry battle he joins.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By whose instructions so that the matter might be conducted, Quintus Atius Varus, prefect of the cavalry, of singular both of mind and of prudence a man, his own he encourages and the line of the enemy having followed the troops partly in suitable places he disposes, with a part of the cavalry battle he joins.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To carry out these instructions, Quintus Atius Varus, the cavalry commandera man of exceptional courage and judgmentencouraged his men, overtook the enemy column, stationed some of his troops in advantageous positions, and engaged in battle with the rest of his cavalry.

sentences.latin: Confligit audacius equitatus hostium succedentibus sibi peditibus, qui toto agmine subsistentes equitibus suis contra nostros ferunt auxilium.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Engages more boldly the cavalry of the enemies, coming up to them the infantry, who in the whole column halting to their cavalry against ours they bring help.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Clashes more boldly the cavalry of the enemy with coming up to themselves the infantry, who in the whole line halting to the cavalry their own against ours they bring help.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The enemy cavalry fought more boldly as their infantry came up to support them; the infantry, halting along the entire line, brought aid to their cavalry against our forces.

sentences.latin: Fit proelium acri certamine.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Becomes a battle with sharp contest.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Becomes a battle with sharp contest.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A battle ensued with fierce fighting.

sentences.latin: Namque nostri contemptis pridie superatis hostibus, cum subsequi legiones meminissent, et pudore cedendi et cupiditate per se conficiendi proeli fortissime contra pedites proeliantur,
sentences.referenceTranslation: For our men, the yesterday overcome enemies having been despised, since to follow the legions they remembered, both by the shame of yielding and by the desire through themselves of finishing the battle most bravely against the infantry they fight,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For our men having been despised the day before overcome enemies, when to follow the legions they had remembered, both by shame of yielding and by desire through themselves of finishing the battle most bravely against the infantry they fight,
sentences.naturalTranslation: For our men, despising the enemy they had defeated the day before and remembering that the legions were following close behind, fought most bravely against the infantry, driven both by the shame of retreating and the desire to finish the battle on their own.

sentences.latin: hostesque nihil amplius copiarum accessurum credentes, ut pridie cognoverant, delendi equitatus nostri nacti occasionem videbantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and the enemies nothing more of troops to be about to approach believing, as on the day before they had learned, of destroying the cavalry of ours having found an opportunity they seemed.
