sentences.originalMITTranslation: And the enemies, believing nothing more of forces would approach, as on the day before they had learned, having obtained an opportunity of destroying our cavalry, seemed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Believing that no more reinforcements would arrive, as they had learned the day before, the enemy seemed to have found an opportunity to destroy our cavalry.

sentences.latin: Cum aliquamdiu summa contentione dimicaretur, Dumnacus instruit aciem quae suis esset equitibus in vicem praesidio, cum repente confertae legiones in conspectum hostium veniunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When for some time with the greatest struggle it was being fought, Dumnacus draws up a battle line which for his own horsemen in turn might be for a protection, when suddenly the packed legions into the sight of the enemies come.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When for some time with the greatest exertion it was fought, Dumnacus draws up a battle line which for his own cavalry in turn might be for a protection, when suddenly the packed legions into the sight of the enemies come.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the battle had raged with great intensity for some time, Dumnacus drew up a line of infantry to support his cavalry in turn, when suddenly the legions appeared in close formation in full view of the enemy.

sentences.latin: Quibus visis perculsae barbarorum turmae ac perterritae acies hostium, perturbato impedimentorum agmine, magno clamore discursuque passim fugae se mandant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which having been seen, the struck-down troops of the barbarians and the terrified lines of the enemies, with the column of baggage thrown into confusion, with a great shout and running about everywhere to flight themselves they commit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been seen, the struck squadrons of the barbarians and the terrified lines of the enemies, the column of baggage having been thrown into confusion, with a great shout and running about everywhere to flight themselves they commit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the sight of them, the barbarian cavalry was shaken and the enemy's lines terrified; with their baggage train thrown into disorder, they fled in all directions with loud shouting and confusion.

sentences.latin: At nostri equites, qui paulo ante cum resistentibus fortissime conflixerant, laetitia victoriae elati magno undique clamore sublato cedentibus circumfusi, quantum equorum vires ad persequendum dextraeque ad caedendum valent, tantum eo proelio interficiunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But our horsemen, who a little before with those resisting most bravely had clashed, by the joy of victory elated, a great from all sides shout having been raised, around those yielding having been poured, as much as the horses' strengths for pursuing and the right hands for killing are strong, so many in that battle they kill.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But our cavalry, who a little before with those resisting most bravely had clashed, by the joy of victory elated, a great shout from all sides having been raised, to those yielding having been poured around, as much as the strengths of the horses for pursuing and the right hands for killing are strong, so much in that battle they kill.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But our cavalry, who shortly before had fought most bravely against those resisting, were elated by the joy of victory; raising a great shout on all sides, they surrounded the retreating foe and killed as many in that battle as the strength of their horses for pursuit and their own right hands for slaughter allowed.

sentences.latin: Itaque amplius milibus XII aut armatorum aut eorum qui eo timore arma proiecerant interfectis omnis multitudo capitur impedimentorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so more than thousands twelve either of armed men or of those who from that fear arms had thrown away having been killed, the whole multitude is captured of the baggage.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so more than thousands twelve either of armed men or of those who from that fear arms had thrown away having been killed, the whole multitude is captured of the baggage.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, with more than twelve thousand killedeither armed men or those who had thrown away their weapons out of fearthe entire baggage train was captured.

sentences.latin: Qua ex fuga cum constaret Drappetem Senonem, qui, ut primum defecerat Gallia, collectis undique perditis hominibus, servis ad libertatem vocatis, exulibus omnium civitatum adscitis, receptis latronibus impedimenta et commeatus Romanorum interceperat, non amplius hominum duobus milibus ex fuga collectis provinciam petere unaque consilium cum eo Lucterium Cadurcum cepisse, quem superiore commentario prima defectione Galliae facere in provinciam voluisse impetum cognitum est,
sentences.referenceTranslation: From which flight when it was evident that Drappes the Senonian, who, as first had revolted Gaul, having collected from everywhere desperate men, with slaves to liberty called, with exiles of all states admitted, having received brigands, the baggage and supplies of the Romans had intercepted, not more of men than two thousands from the flight having been collected, the province was seeking and together a plan with him Lucterius the Cadurcan had taken, whom in the former commentary at the first revolt of Gaul to make into the province to have wished an attack it was known,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From which flight when it was evident that Drappes the Senonian, who, as first had revolted Gaul, having collected from all sides desperate men, slaves to liberty having been called, exiles of all states having been admitted, having received robbers, the baggage and supplies of the Romans had intercepted, not more of men than two thousands from the flight having been collected, the province was seeking and together a plan with him Lucterius the Cadurcan had taken, whom in the previous commentary at the first revolt of Gaul to make into the province to have wished an attack it was known,
sentences.naturalTranslation: When it became clear from this flight that Drappes the Senonianwho at the first revolt of Gaul had gathered desperate men from everywhere, called slaves to freedom, admitted exiles from all states, and received brigands to intercept Roman baggage and supplieswas heading for the Province with no more than two thousand men collected from the flight, and that Lucterius the Cadurcan (who, as noted in the previous book, had wanted to attack the Province at the start of the Gallic revolt) had joined him in this plan,

sentences.latin: Caninius legatus cum legionibus duabus ad eos persequendos contendit, ne detrimento aut timore provinciae magna infamia perditorum hominum latrociniis caperetur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caninius the legate with legions two to them to be pursued hastened, lest by loss or fear of the province a great disgrace by the robberies of desperate men might be received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caninius the legate with legions two to them to be pursued hastened, lest by loss or fear of the province a great disgrace of desperate men by the robberies might be received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The legate Caninius hastened with two legions to pursue them, so that the Province might not suffer great disgrace from the damage or fear caused by the raids of these desperate men.

sentences.latin: Gaius Fabius cum reliquo exercitu in Carnutes ceterasque proficiscitur civitates, quarum eo proelio, quod cum Dumnaco fecerat, copias esse accisas sciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Gaius Fabius with the remaining army into the Carnutes and the other sets out states, of which in that battle, which with Dumnacus he had made, the forces to have been cut down he knew.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Gaius Fabius with the remaining army into the Carnutes and the other sets out states, of which in that battle, which with Dumnacus he had made, the forces to be cut down he was knowing.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaius Fabius set out with the rest of the army for the territory of the Carnutes and other states whose forces he knew had been shattered in the battle he had fought against Dumnacus.

sentences.latin: Non enim dubitabat quin recenti calamitate summissiores essent futurae, dato vero spatio ac tempore eodem instigante Dumnaco possent concitari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For not he was doubting but that by the recent calamity more submissive they would be, given however space and time, with the same Dumnacus instigating, they could be stirred up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For not he was doubting but that by the recent calamity more submissive they would be, but space and time having been given, the same Dumnacus instigating, they might be stirred up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he did not doubt that they would be more submissive due to their recent disaster, but that if given time and opportunity, they might be stirred up again by the instigation of Dumnacus.

sentences.latin: Qua in re summa felicitas celeritasque in recipiendis civitatibus Fabium consequitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In which matter the highest good fortune and speed in recovering the states Fabius follows.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In which matter the highest good fortune and speed in recovering the states Fabius follows.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In this business, Fabius was attended by the greatest good fortune and speed in recovering the states.

sentences.latin: Nam Carnutes, qui saepe vexati numquam pacis fecerant mentionem, datis obsidibus veniunt in deditionem, ceteraeque civitates positae in ultimis Galliae finibus Oceano coniunctae, quae Armoricae appellantur, auctoritate adductae Carnutum adventu Fabi legionumque imperata sine mora faciunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For the Carnutes, who often harassed never of peace had made mention, given hostages come into surrender, and the other states placed in the furthest of Gaul borders to the Ocean joined, which Armorican are called, by the authority influenced of the Carnutes by the arrival of Fabius and of the legions commands without delay do.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For the Carnutes, who often harassed never of peace had made mention, hostages having been given come into surrender, and the other states placed in the furthest borders of Gaul to the Ocean joined, which Armorican are called, by authority having been led of the Carnutes, by the arrival of Fabius and of the legions the things ordered without delay they do.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the Carnutes, who despite frequent harassment had never mentioned peace, gave hostages and surrendered; the other states located on the remote borders of Gaul near the Ocean, known as the Armorican states, followed the Carnutes' lead and, upon the arrival of Fabius and his legions, obeyed his orders without delay.

sentences.latin: Dumnacus suis finibus expulsus errans latitansque solus extremas Galliae regiones petere est coactus.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Dumnacus from his own borders driven out wandering and hiding alone the furthest Gaul regions to seek was compelled.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Dumnacus from his own borders expelled, wandering and hiding alone, the furthest regions of Gaul to seek was compelled.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Driven from his own territory, Dumnacus was forced to wander and hide alone, seeking refuge in the most remote regions of Gaul.

sentences.latin: At Drappes unaque Lucterius, cum legiones Caniniumque adesse cognoscerent nec se sine certa pernicie persequente exercitu putarent provinciae fines intrare posse nec iam libere vagandi latrociniorumque faciendorum facultatem haberent, in finibus consistunt Cadurcorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But Drappes together and Lucterius, when the legions and Caninius to be present they learned nor themselves without certain destruction with the pursuing army they thought of the province the borders to enter to be able nor now of freely wandering and of robberies making the opportunity they had, in the borders they halt of the Cadurci.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Drappes and together Lucterius, when the legions and Caninius to be present they were knowing nor themselves without certain destruction the army pursuing to be able to enter the borders of the province they were thinking nor now of freely wandering and of robberies making the opportunity they were having, in the borders they halt of the Cadurci.
sentences.naturalTranslation: But Drappes and Lucterius, learning that Caninius and his legions were nearby, realized they could not enter the borders of the Province without certain destruction while the army pursued them; no longer having the opportunity to roam freely and carry out raids, they halted within the territory of the Cadurci.

sentences.latin: Ibi cum Lucterius apud suos cives quondam integris rebus multum potuisset, semperque auctor novorum consiliorum magnam apud barbaros auctoritatem haberet, oppidum Vxellodunum, quod in clientela fuerat eius, egregie natura loci munitum, occupat suis et Drappetis copiis oppidanosque sibi coniungit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There since Lucterius among his own citizens formerly with intact affairs much had been able, and always an author of new plans great among the barbarians authority he had, the town Uxellodunum, which in the clientship had been of him, excellently by the nature of the place fortified, he occupies with his own and Drappes' forces and the townsmen to himself he joins.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There when Lucterius among his own citizens formerly in sound affairs much had been able, and always an author of new plans a great authority among the barbarians he was having, the town Uxellodunum, which in the clientship had been of him, excellently by the nature of the place fortified, he occupies with his own and Drappes' forces and the townsmen to himself he joins.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since Lucterius had formerly possessed great influence among his fellow citizens when their affairs were prosperous, and as a constant proponent of new schemes always held great authority among the barbarians, he occupied the town of Uxellodunum with his and Drappes' forcesa place once under his patronage and remarkably well-fortified by its natural locationand won over the townspeople to his cause.

sentences.latin: Quo cum confestim Gaius Caninius venisset animadverteretque omnes oppidi partes praeruptissimis saxis esse munitas, quo defendente nullo tamen armatis ascendere esset difficile, magna autem impedimenta oppidanorum videret, quae si clandestina fuga subtrahere conarentur, effugere non modo equitatum, sed ne legiones quidem possent, tripertito cohortibus divisis trina excelsissimo loco castra fecit;
sentences.referenceTranslation: To which when immediately Gaius Caninius had come and he noticed all of the town parts with very steep rocks to be fortified, where with defending no one nevertheless for armed men to climb it would be difficult, great however the baggage of the townsmen he saw, which if by secret flight to withdraw they tried, to escape not only the cavalry, but not even the legions indeed they would be able, in three parts the cohorts having been divided three in a very high place camps he made;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whither when immediately Gaius Caninius had come and he was noticing all parts of the town with very steep rocks to be fortified, which defending no one however for armed men to ascend it would be difficult, great however baggage of the townsmen he was seeing, which if by secret flight to withdraw they should try, to escape not only the cavalry, but not the legions indeed they would be able, in three parts the cohorts having been divided, three in a very high place camps he made;
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Gaius Caninius arrived there immediately and observed that every part of the town was fortified by sheer cliffswhich would be difficult for armed men to scale even if undefendedand saw the townspeople's massive amount of baggage, which they could not move in a secret flight without being overtaken by the cavalry and even the legions, he divided his cohorts into three parts and established three camps on very high ground.

sentences.latin: a quibus paulatim, quantum copiae patiebantur, vallum in oppidi circuitum ducere instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: from which gradually, as much as the forces allowed, a rampart in the town's circuit to lead he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: from which gradually, as much as the forces were allowing, a rampart into the town's circuit to lead he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: From these camps, he began to construct a rampart around the town's perimeter, progressing as quickly as his forces permitted.

sentences.latin: Quod cum animadverterent oppidani miserrimaque Alesiae memoria solliciti similem casum obsessionis vererentur, maximeque ex omnibus Lucterius, qui fortunae illius periculum fecerat, moneret frumenti rationem esse habendam, constituunt omnium consensu parte ibi relicta copiarum ipsi cum expeditis ad importandum frumentum proficisci.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when they noticed the townsmen and by the very miserable of Alesia memory anxious a similar fate of a siege they feared, and especially out of all Lucterius, who of that fortune the danger had made, warned of grain an account to be had, they decide by all's consent with a part there left of the forces themselves with light-armed men for importing grain to set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when they noticed the townsmen and by the most wretched memory of Alesia anxious a similar case of siege they were fearing, and especially out of all Lucterius, who of that fortune a trial had made, was warning a grain account must be had, they decide by all's consent, a part there having been left of the forces, themselves with light-armed men for importing grain to set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the townspeople noticed this, haunted by the wretched memory of Alesia and fearing a similar fate in a siegeand especially since Lucterius, who had experienced that disaster, warned that they must account for the grain supplythey decided by unanimous consent to leave part of their forces behind while they themselves set out with light-armed troops to bring in grain.

sentences.latin: Eo consilio probato proxima nocte duobus milibus armatorum relictis reliquos ex oppido Drappes et Lucterius educunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: That plan having been approved on the next night with two thousand of armed men left the rest out of the town Drappes and Lucterius lead out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: That plan having been approved, on the next night, two thousands of armed men having been left, the rest from the town Drappes and Lucterius lead out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This plan being approved, Drappes and Lucterius left two thousand armed men behind and led the rest out of the town the following night.

sentences.latin: Hi paucos dies morati ex finibus Cadurcorum, qui partim re frumentaria sublevare eos cupiebant, partim prohibere quo minus sumerent non poterant, magnum numerum frumenti comparant, nonnumquam autem expeditionibus nocturnis castella nostrorum adoriuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: These for a few days having delayed from the borders of the Cadurci, who partly in the matter of grain to assist them were desiring, partly to prohibit lest they take they were not able, a great number of grain they collect, sometimes however by expeditions nocturnal the forts of ours they attack.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: These for a few days having delayed from the borders of the Cadurci, who partly in the grain matter to help them were desiring, partly to prevent from taking they were not able, a great number of grain they prepare, sometimes however by expeditions nocturnal the forts of ours they attack.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After delaying for a few days in the territory of the Cadurciwho were partly eager to help them with grain and partly unable to prevent them from taking itthey collected a large quantity of supplies and occasionally attacked our forts in night raids.

sentences.latin: Quam ob causam Gaius Caninius toto oppido munitiones circumdare moratur, ne aut opus effectum tueri non possit aut plurimis in locis infirma disponat praesidia.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For which reason Gaius Caninius for the whole town fortifications to surround delays, lest either the work completed to protect he might not be able or in very many places weak he might distribute garrisons.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For which cause Gaius Caninius around the whole town fortifications to surround delays, lest either the work completed to protect he might not be able or in very many places weak he might distribute garrisons.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this reason, Gaius Caninius hesitated to completely surround the town with fortifications, fearing that he might either be unable to protect the completed works or be forced to station weak garrisons in too many locations.

sentences.latin: Magna copia frumenti comparata considunt Drappes et Lucterius non longius ab oppido X milibus, unde paulatim frumentum in oppidum supportarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A great supply of grain having been prepared, Drappes and Lucterius settle not further from the town than 10 miles, from where gradually grain into the town they might carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great supply of grain having been prepared, Drappes and Lucterius settle not farther from the town than 10 miles, from where gradually grain into the town they might carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having gathered a large supply of grain, Drappes and Lucterius encamped no more than ten miles from the town, so that they could gradually bring the grain into it.

sentences.latin: Ipsi inter se provincias partiuntur: Drappes castris praesidio cum parte copiarum restitit; Lucterius agmen iumentorum ad oppidum ducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They themselves among themselves the duties divide: Drappes at the camp for a protection with a part of the forces stayed; Lucterius a train of pack-animals to the town leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They themselves among themselves the duties divide: Drappes at the camp for a guard with a part of the forces remained; Lucterius a line of pack animals to the town leads.
sentences.naturalTranslation: They divided the duties between them: Drappes remained at the camp with part of the forces to guard it, while Lucterius led a pack-train toward the town.

sentences.latin: Dispositis ibi praesidiis hora noctis circiter decima silvestribus angustisque itineribus frumentum importare in oppidum instituit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Having been stationed there guards, at the hour of the night about the tenth, by woody and narrow paths grain to carry into the town he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having been distributed there guards, at the hour of the night about the tenth, by wooded and narrow paths grain to bring into the town he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After stationing guards there, he began to bring grain into the town through narrow, wooded paths at about the tenth hour of the night.

sentences.latin: Quorum strepitum vigiles castrorum cum sensissent, exploratoresque missi quae gererentur renuntiassent, Caninius celeriter cum cohortibus armatis ex proximis castellis in frumentarios sub ipsam lucem impetum fecit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom the noise the sentinels of the camp when they had perceived, and scouts sent what things were being done had reported, Caninius quickly with cohorts armed from the nearest forts against the grain-gatherers just before the light itself an attack made.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom the noise the sentinels of the camp when they had perceived, and scouts sent what things were being done had reported, Caninius quickly with cohorts armed from the nearest forts upon the grain-gatherers just before the light itself an attack made.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When the camp sentries heard their noise and the scouts who had been sent out reported what was happening, Caninius quickly led armed cohorts from the nearest forts and attacked the grain-gatherers just before dawn.

sentences.latin: Ei repentino malo perterriti diffugiunt ad sua praesidia; quae nostri ut viderunt, acrius contra armatos incitati neminem ex eo numero vivum capi patiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They by the sudden evil terrified flee to their own guards; which things our men as they saw, more fiercely against the armed men incited, no one from that number alive to be captured they allow.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: They by the sudden evil terrified flee in different directions to their guards; which things our men as they saw, more fiercely against the armed men incited, no one from that number alive to be taken they allow.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by this sudden disaster, they fled toward their guards; when our men saw this, they were spurred on even more fiercely against the armed Gauls and allowed no one from that group to be taken alive.

sentences.latin: Profugit inde cum paucis Lucterius nec se recipit in eastra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Fled from there with a few Lucterius nor himself he betakes into the camp.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Flees away from there with a few Lucterius nor himself he betakes into the camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Lucterius fled from the scene with a few followers and did not return to the camp.

sentences.latin: Re bene gesta Caninius ex captivis comperit partem copiarum cum Drappete esse in castris a milibus longe non amplius XII.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The matter well having been conducted, Caninius from the captives finds out a part of the forces with Drappes to be in the camp from miles away not more than 12.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The matter well having been conducted, Caninius from the captives finds out a part of the forces with Drappes to be in the camp from miles away not more than 12.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After this successful action, Caninius learned from the prisoners that part of the forces remained with Drappes in a camp no more than twelve miles away.

sentences.latin: Qua re ex compluribus cognita, cum intellegeret fugato duce altero perterritos reliquos facile opprimi posse, magnae felicitatis esse arbitrabatur neminem ex caede refugisse in castra qui de accepta calamitate nuntium Drappeti perferret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing from several having been learned, since he understood, having been put to flight the leader the other, the terrified remaining ones easily to be crushed to be able, of great luck to be he thought no one from the slaughter to have fled back into the camp who about the received disaster news to Drappes might carry.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing from several having been learned, since he understood, having been put to flight the leader one, the terrified remaining easily to be crushed to be able, of great good fortune to be he was thinking no one from the slaughter to have fled back into the camp who about the received disaster news to Drappes might carry.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having confirmed this from several sources, and realizing that with one leader in flight the remaining terrified troops could easily be crushed, he considered it a stroke of great luck that no one had escaped the slaughter to bring news of the disaster to Drappes.

sentences.latin: Sed in experiendo cum periculum nullum videret, equitatum omnem Germanosque pedites, summae velocitatis homines, ad castra hostium praemittit; ipse legionem unam in trina castra distribuit, alteram secum expeditam ducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: But in the trying since danger none he saw, the cavalry all and the German infantry, of the highest speed men, to the camp of the enemies he sends ahead; he himself legion one into the three camps distributed, the other with himself light-armed he leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But in trying since danger none he saw, the cavalry all and the German infantry, of the highest speed men, to the camp of the enemies he sends ahead; he himself legion one into the three camps distributed, the other with himself light-armed he leads.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Seeing no danger in making the attempt, he sent all the cavalry and the German infantrymen of extreme speedahead to the enemy's camp; he distributed one legion among the three camps and led the other, unencumbered, with him.

sentences.latin: Cum propius hostes accessisset, ab exploratoribus quos praemiserat cognoscit castra eorum, ut barbarorum fere consuetudo est, relictis locis superioribus ad ripas fluminis esse demissa; at Germanos equitesque imprudentibus omnibus de improviso advolasse proeliumque commisisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When nearer the enemies he had approached, from the scouts whom he had sent ahead he learns the camp of them, as of the barbarians generally the custom is, having been abandoned the places higher, to the banks of the river to have been moved down; but the Germans and the cavalry, they being unaware all, from the unforeseen to have flown at and battle to have joined.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When nearer the enemies he had approached, from the scouts whom he had sent ahead he learns the camp of them, as of the barbarians generally the custom is, having been abandoned the places higher, at the banks of the river to have been moved down; but the Germans and the cavalry, they being unaware all, from the unforeseen to have flown at and battle to have joined.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he had come closer to the enemy, he learned from the scouts he had sent ahead that their camp, as is generally the custom of barbarians, had been moved from the high ground down to the riverbanks; meanwhile, the Germans and the cavalry had swooped down unexpectedly while the enemy were off their guard and had joined battle.

sentences.latin: Qua re cognita legionem armatam instructamque adducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been known, the legion armed and drawn up he leads forward.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which thing having been known, the legion armed and drawn up he brings forward.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Having learned of this, he led forward the legion, armed and in battle formation.

sentences.latin: Ita repente omnibus ex partibus signo dato loca superiora capiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus suddenly from all parts the signal having been given the higher places are seized.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus suddenly from all parts the signal having been given the places higher are taken.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, the signal being suddenly given from all sides, the higher ground was seized.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi accidit, Germani equitesque signis legionis visis vehementissime proeliantur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when it happened, the Germans and the horsemen the standards of the legion having been seen most violently fight.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which when it happened, the Germans and the cavalry, the standards of the legion having been seen, most violently fight.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this happened, the Germans and the cavalry, seeing the legion's standards, fought with the greatest intensity.

sentences.latin: Confestim cohortes undique impetum faciunt omnibusque aut interfectis aut captis magna praeda potiuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Immediately the cohorts from all sides an attack make and all either killed or captured great booty they gain possession of.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Immediately the cohorts from all sides an attack make and all either having been killed or captured great booty they gain possession of.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The cohorts immediately attacked from all sides, and having either killed or captured everyone, they secured a great amount of plunder.

sentences.latin: Capitur ipse eo proelio Drappes.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is captured himself in that battle Drappes.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is captured himself in that battle Drappes.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Drappes himself was captured in that battle.

sentences.latin: Caninius felicissime re gesta sine ullo paene militis vulnere ad obsidendos oppidanos revertitur
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caninius most successfully the matter having been conducted without any almost of a soldier wound to the to-be-besieged townspeople returns.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caninius most successfully the matter having been conducted without any almost of a soldier wound to the townspeople to be besieged returns.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caninius, having conducted the affair most successfully without almost a single soldier being wounded, returned to continue the siege of the townspeople.

sentences.latin: externoque hoste deleto, cuius timore antea dividere praesidia et munitione oppidanos circumdare prohibitus erat, opera undique imperat administrari.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and the external enemy having been destroyed, by whose fear before to divide the garrisons and with a fortification the townspeople to surround he had been prohibited, the works on all sides he orders to be managed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and the external enemy having been destroyed, by whose fear before to divide the guards and with a fortification the townspeople to surround he had been prohibited, the works on all sides he orders to be managed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Now that the external enemy was destroyedfear of whom had previously prevented him from dividing his forces and surrounding the townspeople with fortificationshe ordered the siege works to be carried out on all sides.

sentences.latin: Venit eodem cum suis copiis postero die Gaius Fabius partemque oppidi sumit ad obsidendum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Comes to the same place with his forces on the following day Gaius Fabius and a part of the town takes for the purpose of besieging.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Comes to the same place with his forces on the following day Gaius Fabius and a part of the town takes for besieging.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaius Fabius arrived at the same place with his troops the next day and took over a section of the town for the siege.

sentences.latin: Caesar interim M. Antonium quaestorem cum cohortibus XV in Bellovacis relinquit, ne qua rursus novorum consiliorum capiendorum Belgis facultas daretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar meanwhile Marcus Antonius the quaestor with cohorts fifteen among the Bellovaci leaves, lest any again of new plans to-be-formed to the Belgae opportunity might be given.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar meanwhile Marcus Antonius the quaestor with cohorts 15 among the Bellovaci leaves, lest any again of new plans to be formed to the Belgae opportunity might be given.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Caesar left Marcus Antonius the quaestor with fifteen cohorts among the Bellovaci, so that the Belgae would not have any further opportunity to form new plots.

sentences.latin: Ipse reliquas civitates adit, obsides plures imperat, timentes omnium animos consolatione sanat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself the remaining states visits, hostages more commands, the fearing of all minds with consolation heals.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself the remaining states visits, hostages more he demands, the fearing of all minds with consolation he heals.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself visited the remaining states, demanded more hostages, and reassured the anxious minds of everyone with words of comfort.

sentences.latin: Cum in Carnutes venisset, quorum in civitate superiore commentario Caesar exposuit initium belli esse ortum, quod praecipue eos propter conscientiam facti timere animadvertebat, quo celerius civitatem timore liberaret, principem sceleris illius et concitatorem belli, Gutruatum, ad supplicium depoposcit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When into the Carnutes he had come, of whom in the previous commentary Caesar explained the beginning of the war to have arisen, because especially them on account of the consciousness of the deed to fear he was noticing, in order that more quickly the state from fear he might free, the leader of that crime and the inciter of the war, Gutruatus, for punishment he demanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When into the Carnutes he had come, of whom in a previous commentary Caesar explained the beginning of the war to have arisen, because especially them on account of consciousness of the deed to fear he was noticing, so that more quickly the state from fear he might free, the leader of that crime and the inciter of the war, Gutruatus, for punishment he demanded.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived among the Carnutes, in whose state Caesar explained in the previous book that the war had first broken out, noticing that they were particularly fearful due to their awareness of their actions, he demanded that Gutruatus, the leader of that crime and the instigator of the war, be handed over for punishment to more quickly free the state from fear.

sentences.latin: Qui etsi ne civibus quidem suis se committebat, tamen celeriter omnium cura quaesitus in castra perducitur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Who although not even to citizens indeed his own himself he was committing, nevertheless quickly by the care of all having been sought into the camp he is led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Who although not even to citizens indeed his own himself he was committing, nevertheless quickly by the care of all having been sought into the camp he is led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although he would not even trust himself to his own fellow citizens, he was quickly tracked down by the efforts of everyone and brought into the camp.

sentences.latin: Cogitur in eius supplicium Caesar contra suam naturam concursu maximo militum, qui ei omnia pericula et detrimenta belli accepta referebant, adeo ut verberibus exanimatum corpus securi feriretur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He is compelled to his punishment Caesar against his own nature by a gathering very great of soldiers, who to him all dangers and losses of the war as received were attributing, to such an extent that by lashes the lifeless body with an axe was struck.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He is compelled to his punishment Caesar against his own nature by a gathering very great of soldiers, who to him all dangers and losses of the war accepted were bringing back, to such an extent that by lashes an exhausted body with an ax was struck.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar was forced to execute him, contrary to his own nature, by a massive outcry of the soldiers, who blamed him for all the dangers and losses of the war; consequently, his body was beaten until lifeless and then beheaded with an axe.

sentences.latin: Ibi crebris litteris Canini fit certior quae de Drappete et Lucterio gesta essent, quoque in consilio permanerent oppidani.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There by frequent letters of Caninius he is made more certain what concerning Drappes and Lucterius had been done, and in what plan were remaining the townsmen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There by frequent letters of Caninius he becomes more certain what concerning Drappes and Lucterius had been done, and in what plan were remaining the townsmen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, through frequent letters from Caninius, he was informed of what had been done regarding Drappes and Lucterius, and what plan the townspeople were persisting in.

sentences.latin: Quorum etsi paucitatem contemnebat, tamen pertinaciam magna poena esse adficiendam iudicabat, ne universa Gallia non sibi vires defuisse ad resistendum Romanis, sed constantiam putaret, neve hoc exemplo ceterae civitates locorum opportunitate fretae se vindicarent in libertatem,
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom although the small number he was despising, nevertheless the stubbornness with a great punishment to be afflicted he was judging, lest all Gaul not to itself strengths to have been lacking for resisting the Romans, but constancy should think, nor by this example other states on the advantage of places relying themselves should claim into liberty,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom although the small number he was despising, nevertheless the persistence with a great penalty to be affected he was judging, lest all Gaul not to itself forces to have been lacking for resisting the Romans, but constancy might think, nor by this example the other states on the advantage of places relying themselves might claim into liberty,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although he despised their small numbers, he judged that their stubbornness should be met with a severe punishment, so that all of Gaul would not think that it was a lack of resolve rather than a lack of strength that prevented resistance to the Romans, and so that other states, relying on the natural strength of their positions, would not follow this example and attempt to assert their independence.

sentences.latin: cum omnibus Gallis notum esse sciret reliquam esse unam aestatem suae provinciae, quam si sustinere potuissent, nullum ultra periculum vererentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: since to all Gauls known to be he was knowing to remain to be one summer of his province, which if to endure they had been able, no further danger they would fear.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: since to all Gauls known to be he was knowing to remain to be one summer of his province, which if to sustain they had been able, no further danger they would fear.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he knew it was common knowledge among the Gauls that only one summer remained of his term of office, and if they could hold out through it, they would have no further danger to fear.

sentences.latin: Itaque Q. Calenum legatum cum legionibus reliquit qui iustis itineribus subsequeretur; ipse cum omni equitatu quam potest celerrime ad Caninium contendit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Therefore Quintus Calenus the legate with the legions he left who by regular marches should follow; he himself with all the cavalry as he is able most quickly to Caninius hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore Q. Calenus the legate with the legions he left who by regular marches might follow; he himself with all the cavalry as he is able most quickly to Caninius hastened.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he left his legate Quintus Calenus with the legions to follow by regular marches, while he himself hastened to Caninius with all the cavalry as quickly as possible.

sentences.latin: Cum contra exspectationem omnium Caesar Vxellodunum venisset oppidumque operibus clausum animadverteret neque ab oppugnatione recedi videret ulla condicione posse, magna autem copia frumenti abundare oppidanos ex perfugis cognosset, aqua prohibere hostem temptare coepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When against the expectation of all Caesar to Uxellodunum had come and the town by works closed he was noticing nor from the siege to be withdrawn he was seeing by any condition to be able, great however with a supply of grain to abound the townsmen from deserters he had learned, from water to prohibit the enemy to try he began.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When against the expectation of all Caesar to Uxellodunum had come and the town by works closed he was noticing nor from the siege to be withdrawn he was seeing by any condition to be possible, great moreover supply of grain to abound the townsmen from deserters he had learned, from water to prohibit the enemy to try he began.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar arrived at Uxellodunum contrary to everyone's expectation and saw that the town was enclosed by siege works and that the siege could not be abandoned under any circumstances, and having learned from deserters that the townspeople had an abundant supply of grain, he began to try to cut the enemy off from their water supply.

sentences.latin: Flumen infimam vallem dividebat, quae totum paene montem cingebat, in quo positum erat praeruptum undique oppidum Vxellodunum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A river the lowest valley was dividing, which the whole almost mountain was surrounding, on which placed was steep on all sides the town Uxellodunum.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A river the lowest valley was dividing, which the whole almost mountain was encircling, in which placed was steep on all sides the town Uxellodunum.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A river ran through the bottom of the valley, which almost entirely surrounded the mountain on which the town of Uxellodunum was situated, steep on all sides.

sentences.latin: Hoc avertere loci natura prohibebat: in infimis enim sic radicibus montis ferebatur, ut nullam in partem depressis fossis derivari posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This to divert the nature of the place was prohibiting: in the lowest for thus roots of the mountain it was being carried, that into no part by sunk ditches to be diverted it was able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This to turn away the nature of the place was prohibiting: in the lowest indeed so roots of the mountain it was being carried, that into no part by sunk ditches to be diverted it was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The nature of the terrain made it impossible to divert this river, for it flowed so close to the base of the mountain that it could not be channeled in any direction by digging ditches.

sentences.latin: Erat autem oppidanis difficilis et praeruptus eo descensus, ut prohibentibus nostris sine vulneribus ac periculo vitae neque adire flumen neque arduo se recipere possent ascensu.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There was however for the townsmen a difficult and steep thither descent, so that with our men prohibiting without wounds and danger of life neither to approach the river nor by the steep to betake themselves they were able ascent.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There was moreover to the townsmen difficult and steep to it the descent, so that with prohibiting our men without wounds and danger of life neither to approach the river nor by the steep to betake themselves they were able by ascent.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, the descent to the river was so difficult and steep for the townspeople that, with our men blocking them, they could neither reach the water nor retreat back up the steep slope without suffering casualties and risking their lives.

sentences.latin: Qua difficultate eorum cognita Caesar sagittariis funditoribusque dispositis, tormentis etiam quibusdam locis contra facillimos descensus collocatis aqua fluminis prohibebat oppidanos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which difficulty of theirs having been recognized Caesar with archers and slingers having been stationed, with engines also in certain places against the easiest descents having been placed from the water of the river was prohibiting the townsmen.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which difficulty of them having been learned Caesar with archers and slingers having been stationed, engines also in certain places against the easiest descents having been placed from the water of the river was prohibiting the townsmen.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Recognizing their difficulty, Caesar stationed archers and slingers and placed siege engines at certain points opposite the easiest paths of descent to keep the townspeople away from the river water.

sentences.latin: Quorum omnis postea multitudo aquatorum unum in locum conveniebat sub ipsius oppidi murum, ubi magnus fons aquae prorumpebat ab ea parte, quae fere pedum CCC intervallo fluminis circuitu vacabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Of whom all afterwards the multitude of water-seekers into one place was convening under the of the town itself wall, where a great spring of water was bursting forth from that part, which by almost of feet 300 an interval from the river's circuit was vacant.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Of whom all afterwards the multitude of water-carriers into one place was coming together under of the itself town the wall, where a great spring of water was breaking out from that part, which almost of feet 300 by an interval of the river by the circuit was lacking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Afterwards, the entire crowd of those seeking water gathered in a single spot beneath the town wall itself, where a large spring gushed out on the side that was left open by a gap of about three hundred feet in the river's loop.

sentences.latin: Hoc fonte prohiberi posse oppidanos cum optarent reliqui, Caesar unus videret, e regione eius vineas agere adversus montem et aggerem instruere coepit magno cum labore et continua dimicatione.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From this spring to be able to be prohibited the townsmen while the rest were wishing, Caesar alone might see, from the region of it sheds to drive against the mountain and a mound to construct he began with great with labor and continuous fighting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From this spring to be prohibited to be able the townsmen while were wishing the rest, Caesar alone was seeing, from the region of it mantlets to drive against the mountain and a ramp to build he began with great with labor and continuous fighting.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While the others merely hoped the townspeople could be cut off from this spring, Caesar alone saw how it could be done; he began to advance mantlets toward the spring against the hillside and to construct a ramp with great effort and constant fighting.

sentences.latin: Oppidani enim loco superiore decurrunt et eminus sine periculo proeliantur multosque pertinaciter succedentes vulnerant; non deterrentur tamen milites nostri vineas proferre et labore atque operibus locorum vincere difficultates.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The townsmen for from the place higher run down and from a distance without danger fight and many stubbornly advancing they wound; not are deterred however soldiers our sheds to bring forward and by labor and by works of the places to overcome the difficulties.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The townsmen for from the place higher run down and from a distance without danger they fight and many persistently coming up they wound; not are deterred however soldiers our mantlets to bring forward and by labor and by works of the places to overcome the difficulties.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For the townspeople ran down from the higher ground and fought from a distance without risk, wounding many who stubbornly advanced; nevertheless, our soldiers were not deterred from moving the mantlets forward and overcoming the difficulties of the terrain through hard work and engineering.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore cuniculos tectos ab vineis agunt ad caput fontis; quod genus operis sine ullo periculo, sine suspicione hostium facere licebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time tunnels covered from the sheds they drive to the head of the spring; which kind of work without any danger, without suspicion of the enemies to do it was permitted.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time tunnels covered from the mantlets they drive to the head of the spring; which kind of work without any danger, without suspicion of the enemies to do it was permitted.
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, they dug covered tunnels from the mantlets to the source of the spring; this type of work could be performed without any danger or suspicion from the enemy.

sentences.latin: Exstruitur agger in altitudinem pedum sexaginta, collocatur in eo turris decem tabulatorum, non quidem quae moenibus aequaret (id enim nullis operibus effici poterat), sed quae superare fontis fastigium posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Is built a mound to a height of feet sixty, is placed on it a tower of ten stories, not indeed which to the walls might equal (that for by no works to be effected was able), but which to overtop the spring's elevation might be able.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Is built a ramp into a height of feet sixty, is placed on it a tower of ten stories, not indeed which the walls might equal (that for by no works to be done was able), but which to surpass the spring's height was able.
sentences.naturalTranslation: A ramp sixty feet high was constructed, and a ten-story tower was placed upon itnot to match the height of the walls (which no siege-work could achieve), but to overtop the elevation of the spring.

sentences.latin: Ex ea cum tela tormentis iacerentur ad fontis aditum, nec sine periculo possent aquari oppidani, non tantum pecora atque iumenta, sed etiam magna hostium multitudo siti consumebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: From it when missiles by engines were being thrown to the spring's approach, nor without danger were able to get water the townsmen, not only cattle and beasts of burden, but also a great of the enemies multitude by thirst was being consumed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: From it when missiles by engines were being thrown to of the spring the approach, nor without danger were able to get water the townsmen, not only cattle and beasts of burden, but also a great of enemies multitude by thirst was being consumed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When missiles were discharged from the tower by engines toward the approach to the spring, and the townspeople could no longer fetch water without danger, not only the cattle and pack animals but also a great number of the enemy began to perish from thirst.

sentences.latin: Quo malo perterriti oppidani cupas sebo, pice, scandulis complent; eas ardentes in opera provolvunt eodemque tempore acerrime proeliantur, ut ab incendio restinguendo dimicationis periculo deterreant Romanos.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which evil terrified the townsmen casks with tallow, with pitch, with shingles fill; these burning into the works they roll forward and at the same time most fiercely they fight, so that from the fire extinguishing by the of the fighting danger they might deter the Romans.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which evil thoroughly terrified the townsmen casks with tallow, pitch, shingles fill; these burning into the works they roll forward and at the same time most fiercely they fight, so that from the fire extinguishing by of the fighting the danger they might deter the Romans.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by this disaster, the townspeople filled casks with tallow, pitch, and shingles; they rolled these down flaming onto the siege works and at the same time fought most fiercely to prevent the Romans from extinguishing the fire by the danger of the combat.

sentences.latin: Magna repente in ipsis operibus flamma exstitit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: A great suddenly in the works themselves flame arose.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great suddenly in the themselves works flame stood forth.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Suddenly, a great fire broke out right in the middle of the siege works.

sentences.latin: Quaecumque enim per locum praecipitem missa erant, ea vineis et aggere suppressa comprehendebant id ipsum quod morabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whatever indeed through place steep sent had been, those by vineae and rampart checked they were catching that very thing which was delaying.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whatever things for through the place steep sent had been, those by the mantlets and rampart suppressed were catching that very thing which was delaying.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For whatever was thrown down the steep slope was checked by the sheds and the rampart, catching the very objects that were slowing them down.

sentences.latin: Milites contra nostri, quamquam periculoso genere proeli locoque iniquo premebantur, tamen omnia fortissimo sustinebant animo.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Soldiers on the other hand our, although by dangerous kind of battle and place unfavorable they were being pressed, nevertheless all things with bravest they were sustaining spirit.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Soldiers on the other hand our, although by a dangerous kind of battle and by a place unfavorable they were being pressed, nevertheless all things with a very brave they were sustaining spirit.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Our soldiers, on the other hand, although they were hard-pressed by the dangerous nature of the fighting and the unfavorable terrain, nevertheless endured everything with the greatest courage.

sentences.latin: Res enim gerebatur et excelso loco et in conspectu exercitus nostri, magnusque utrimque clamor oriebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: The matter indeed was being carried on both in high place and in sight of army our, and great on both sides shout was arising.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: The matter for was being carried on both in a high place and in the sight of the army our, and a great on both sides shout was arising.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The action was taking place on high ground and in full view of our army, and a great shout arose from both sides.

sentences.latin: Ita quam quisque poterat maxime insignis, quo notior testatiorque virtus esset eius, telis hostium flammaeque se offerebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus as each one was able most distinguished, so that more known and more witnessed courage might be of him, to weapons of enemies and to flame himself he was offering.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus as each one was able most conspicuous, so that more known and more witnessed the valor might be of him, to the weapons of the enemies and to the flame himself he was offering.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, each man, striving to be as conspicuous as possible so that his courage might be better known and witnessed, exposed himself to the enemy's weapons and the flames.

sentences.latin: Caesar cum complures suos vulnerari videret, ex omnibus oppidi partibus cohortes montem ascendere et simulatione moenium occupandorum clamorem undique iubet tollere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar when several his own to be wounded he saw, from all of town parts cohorts mountain to climb and with pretense of walls to be seized shout from all sides he orders to raise.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar when several of his own to be wounded he saw, from all of the town parts cohorts the mountain to climb and with a pretense of the walls to be seized a shout from all sides he orders to raise.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar saw that many of his men were being wounded, he ordered cohorts from all sides of the town to climb the mountain and raise a shout everywhere, feigning an attempt to seize the walls.

sentences.latin: Quo facto perterriti oppidani, cum quid ageretur in locis reliquis essent suspensi, revocant ab impugnandis operibus armatos murisque disponunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been done terrified townsmen, since what was being done in places remaining they were in suspense, they call back from to be attacked works armed men and on walls they station.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been done terrified the townsmen, since what was being done in places remaining they were in suspense, they call back from the works to be attacked the armed men and on the walls they station.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Terrified by this action, and uncertain of what was happening elsewhere, the townsmen recalled their armed men from attacking the siege works and stationed them on the walls.

sentences.latin: Ita nostri fine proeli facto celeriter opera flamma comprehensa partim restinguunt, partim interscindunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus our men end of battle made quickly works by flame caught partly they extinguish, partly they cut away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus our men an end of the battle having been made quickly the works by flame caught partly extinguish, partly cut away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Thus, the fighting having ended, our men quickly extinguished the parts of the works caught by fire and cut away the rest.

sentences.latin: Cum pertinaciter resisterent oppidani, magna etiam parte amissa siti suorum in sententia permanerent, ad postremum cuniculis venae fontis intercisae sunt atque aversae.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Since stubbornly they were resisting townsmen, great even part lost by thirst of their own in purpose they were remaining, at last by mines veins of spring cut were and turned away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Since stubbornly were resisting the townsmen, a great even part having been lost by thirst of their own in their purpose they were remaining, at last by mines the veins of the spring cut were and turned away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although the townsmen resisted stubbornly and remained firm in their purpose even after many of their people were lost to thirst, the veins of the spring were finally cut and diverted by mines.

sentences.latin: Quo facto repente perennis exaruit fons tantamque attulit oppidanis salutis desperationem, ut id non hominum consilio, sed deorum voluntate factum putarent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which thing having been done suddenly perennial dried up spring and so great brought to townsmen of safety despair, that it not of men by counsel, but of gods by will done they thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Which having been done suddenly the perennial dried up spring and so great it brought to the townsmen of safety despair, that it not by of men counsel, but by of the gods will done they thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When this was done, the perennial spring suddenly dried up, which brought such despair of safety to the townsmen that they believed it had happened not by human planning, but by the will of the gods.

sentences.latin: Itaque se necessitate coacti tradiderunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so themselves by necessity compelled they surrendered.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so themselves by necessity compelled they surrendered.
sentences.naturalTranslation: And so, compelled by necessity, they surrendered.

sentences.latin: Caesar, cum suam lenitatem cognitam omnibus sciret neque vereretur ne quid crudelitate naturae videretur asperius fecisse, neque exitum consiliorum suorum animadverteret, si tali ratione diversis in locis plures consilia inissent, exemplo supplici deterrendos reliquos existimavit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar, since his own leniency known to all he knew nor was fearing lest anything by cruelty of nature he might seem more harshly to have done, nor an end of his plans he was perceiving, if in such a manner in different in places more [people] plans had entered into, by an example of punishment to be deterred the rest he thought.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, since his own leniency known to all he knew and not was fearing lest anything by cruelty of nature he might seem more harshly to have done, and not the end of his plans he was perceiving, if in such a manner in different places more people plans had entered into, by an example of punishment to be deterred the remaining he thought.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, knowing that his leniency was well known to all and not fearing that he might seem to have acted too harshly out of natural cruelty, yet seeing no end to his designs if more people adopted such plans in various places, decided that the rest must be deterred by an exemplary punishment.

sentences.latin: Itaque omnibus qui arma tulerant manus praecidit vitamque concessit, quo testatior esset poena improborum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so for all who arms had carried the hands he cut off and life he granted, so that more witnessed might be the punishment of the wicked.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: And so for all who arms had carried the hands he cut off and life he granted, so that more witnessed might be the punishment of the wicked.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, he cut off the hands of all who had borne arms but granted them their lives, so that the punishment of these criminals might be more visible.

sentences.latin: Drappes, quem captum esse a Caninio docui, sive indignitate et dolore vinculorum sive timore gravioris supplici paucis diebus cibo se abstinuit atque ita interiit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Drappes, whom to have been captured by Caninius I showed, whether by the indignity and pain of chains or by fear of a more serious punishment in a few days from food himself he abstained and thus died.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Drappes, whom to have been captured by Caninius I showed, whether by the indignity and pain of the chains or by fear of a more serious punishment in a few days from food himself he abstained and thus he died.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Drappes, who I mentioned had been captured by Caninius, either from the indignity and pain of his chains or from fear of a more severe punishment, abstained from food for a few days and so perished.

sentences.latin: Eodem tempore Lacterius, quem profugisse ex proelio scripsi, cum in potestatem venisset Epasnacti Arverni
sentences.referenceTranslation: At the same time Lacterius, whom to have fled from the battle I wrote, when into the power he had come of Epasnactus the Arvernian
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At the same time Lacterius, whom to have fled from the battle I wrote, when into the power he had come of Epasnactus the Arvernian
sentences.naturalTranslation: At the same time, Lacterius, who I wrote had fled from the battle, when he had come into the power of Epasnactus the Arvernian

sentences.latin: (crebro enim mutandis locis multorum fidei se committebat, quod nusquam diutius sine periculo commoraturus videbatur, cum sibi conscius esset, quam inimicum deberet Caesarem habere),
sentences.referenceTranslation: (frequently for by changing places of many to the faith himself he was committing, because nowhere longer without danger about to stay he was seeming, since to himself conscious he was, how an enemy he ought Caesar to have),
sentences.originalMITTranslation: (frequently for by changing places of many to the faith himself he was committing, because nowhere longer without danger about to stay he was seeming, since to himself conscious he was, how an enemy he ought Caesar to have),
sentences.naturalTranslation: (for by frequently changing locations he entrusted himself to the loyalty of many, because he felt he could stay nowhere for long without danger, being conscious of how great an enemy he must have in Caesar),

sentences.latin: hunc Epasnactus Arvernus, amicissimus populi Romani, sine dubitatione ulla vinctum ad Caesarem deduxit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: this [man] Epasnactus the Arvernian, most friendly of the people Roman, without hesitation any bound to Caesar led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: this man Epasnactus the Arvernian, most friendly of the people Roman, without hesitation any bound to Caesar led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Epasnactus the Arvernian, a great friend of the Roman people, delivered him in chains to Caesar without any hesitation.

sentences.latin: Labienus interim in Treveris equestre proelium facit secundum compluribusque Treveris interfectis et Germanis, qui nullis adversus Romanos auxilia denegabant, principes eorum vivos redigit in suam potestatem
sentences.referenceTranslation: Labienus meanwhile in the Treveri a cavalry battle makes successful and several Treveri having been killed and Germans, who to none against the Romans reinforcements were denying, the leaders of them alive he brings back into his power
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Labienus meanwhile in the Treveri a cavalry battle makes successful and several Treveri having been killed and Germans, who to none against the Romans reinforcements were denying, the leaders of them alive he brings back into his own power
sentences.naturalTranslation: Meanwhile, Labienus fought a successful cavalry engagement among the Treveri, and after killing several of the Treveri and Germanswho never refused reinforcements to those fighting the Romanshe brought their leaders back alive into his power.

sentences.latin: atque in his Surum Aeduum, qui et virtutis et generis summam nobilitatem habebat solusque ex Aeduis ad id tempus permanserat in armis.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and among these Surus the Aeduan, who both of courage and of birth the highest nobility was having and alone from the Aedui to that time had remained in arms.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and among these Surus the Aeduan, who both of valor and of birth the highest nobility was having and alone from the Aedui to that time had remained in arms.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Among these was Surus the Aeduan, a man of the highest nobility in both character and birth, and the only Aeduan who had remained in arms up to that time.

sentences.latin: Ibi cognoscit Commium Atrebatem proelio cum equitatu suo contendisse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There he learns Commius the Atrebatian in battle with cavalry his own to have contended.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There he learns Commius the Atrebatian in battle with cavalry his own to have contended.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There he learned that Commius the Atrebatian had engaged in a cavalry battle.

sentences.latin: Nam cum Antonius in hiberna venisset, civitasque Atrebatum in officio esset, Commius, qui post illam vulnerationem, quam supra commemoravi, semper ad omnes motus paratus suis civibus esse consuesset, ne consilia belli quaerentibus auctor armorum duxque deesset,
sentences.referenceTranslation: For when Antonius into winter quarters had come, and the state of the Atrebates in duty was, Commius, who after that wounding, which above I mentioned, always for all movements ready for his citizens to be had been accustomed, lest to those plans of war seeking an author of arms and a leader he might be missing,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For when Antonius into winter quarters had come, and the state of the Atrebates in duty was, Commius, who after that wounding, which above I mentioned, always for all movements prepared for his own citizens to be had been accustomed, lest for those plans of war seeking an advisor of arms and a leader he should be missing,
sentences.naturalTranslation: For when Antonius had arrived in winter quarters and the state of the Atrebates remained loyal, Commiuswho since that wound I mentioned above had always been ready to support his fellow citizens in any uprisingacted so that those seeking plans for war would not lack a leader and an instigator of arms.

sentences.latin: parente Romanis civitate cum suis equitibus latrociniis se suosque alebat infestisque itineribus commeatus complures, qui comportabantur in hiberna Romanorum, intercipiebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the state obeying the Romans, with his own horsemen by robberies himself and his own men he was feeding and on infested routes supplies several, which were being carried into the winter quarters of the Romans, he was intercepting.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For when Antonius had gone into winter quarters, and the state of the Atrebates continued in their allegiance, Comius, who, after that wound which I before mentioned, was always ready to join his countrymen upon every commotion, that they might not want a person to advise and head them in the management of the war, when his state submitted to the Romans, supported himself and his adherents on plunder by means of his cavalry, infested the roads, and intercepted several convoys which were bringing provisions to the Roman quarters.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Since his state was submissive to the Romans, he supported himself and his followers through banditry, and by making the roads dangerous, he intercepted several supply convoys that were being transported to the Roman winter quarters.

sentences.latin: Erat attributus Antonio praefectus equitum C. Volusenus Quadratus qui cum eo hibernaret.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There had been assigned to Antonius a commander of horsemen Gaius Volusenus Quadratus who with him might winter.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Caius Volusenus Quadratus was appointed commander of the horse under Antonius, to winter with him: Antonius sent him in pursuit of the enemy's cavalry; now Volusenus added to that valor which was pre-eminent in him, a great aversion to Comius, on which account he executed the more willingly the orders which he received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Gaius Volusenus Quadratus, a commander of cavalry, had been assigned to Antonius to spend the winter with him.

sentences.latin: Hunc Antonius ad persequendum equitatum hostium mittit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man Antonius for the purpose of pursuing the cavalry of the enemies sends.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] Caius Volusenus Quadratus was appointed commander of the horse under Antonius, to winter with him: Antonius sent him in pursuit of the enemy's cavalry; now Volusenus added to that valor which was pre-eminent in him, a great aversion to Comius, on which account he executed the more willingly the orders which he received.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Antonius sent him to pursue the enemy cavalry.

sentences.latin: Volusenus ad eam virtutem, quae singularis erat in eo, magnum odium Commi adiungebat, quo libentius id faceret quod imperabatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Volusenus to that valor, which remarkable was in him, great hatred of Commius was adding, by which more gladly that he might do which was being commanded.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Having, therefore, laid ambuscades, he had several encounters with his cavalry and came off successful.
sentences.naturalTranslation: To the remarkable valor he possessed, Volusenus added a great hatred for Commius, which made him all the more willing to carry out his orders.

sentences.latin: Itaque dispositis insidiis saepius equites eius adgressus secunda proelia faciebat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And so with ambushes having been arranged more often the horsemen of him having attacked successful battles he was making.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: At last, when a violent contest ensued, and Volusenus, through eagerness to intercept Comius, had obstinately pursued him with a small party; and Comius had, by the rapidity of his flight, drawn Volusenus to a considerable distance from his troops, he, on a sudden, appealed to the honor of all about him for assistance not to suffer the wound, which he had perfidiously received, to go without vengeance; and, wheeling his horse about, rode unguardedly before the rest up to the commander.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Consequently, by setting ambushes, he frequently attacked Commius's cavalry and won successful engagements.

sentences.latin: Novissime, cum vehementius contenderetur, ac Volusenus ipsius intercipiendi Commi cupiditate pertinacius eum cum paucis insecutus esset, ille autem fuga vehementi Volusenum produxisset longius, inimicus homini suorum invocat fidem atque auxilium, ne sua vulnera per fidem imposita paterentur impunita, conversoque equo se a ceteris incautius permittit in praefectum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Most recently, when more violently it was being fought, and Volusenus of himself intercepting Commius by a desire more stubbornly him with a few had followed, he however by flight violent Volusenus had led on further, the enemy to the man of his own men invokes the faith and help, lest his own wounds through faith imposed they should allow unpunished, and with the horse turned himself from the others more incautiously he lets go against the commander.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: All his horse following his example, made a few of our men turn their backs and pursued them.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Finally, during a particularly fierce skirmish, Volusenus, driven by a stubborn desire to capture Commius personally, pursued him with only a few men. Commius, however, led Volusenus further away by a headlong flight, then, hating the man, called upon the loyalty and help of his followers not to let the wounds he had received under a pledge of faith go unpunished; turning his horse, he recklessly charged ahead of the others at the commander.

sentences.latin: Faciunt hoc idem omnes eius equites paucosque nostros convertunt atque insequuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: They do this same thing all of his horsemen and few of our men they turn and follow.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Comius, clapping spurs to his horse, rode up to Volusenus, and, pointing his lance, pierced him in the thigh with great force.
sentences.naturalTranslation: All his cavalry did the same, turning our few men back and pursuing them.

sentences.latin: Commius incensum calcaribus equum coniungit equo Quadrati lanceaque infesta magnis viribus medium femur traicit Voluseni.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Commius the incited by spurs horse joins to the horse of Quadratus and with a lance hostile with great strengths the middle thigh he pierces of Volusenus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When their commander was wounded, our men no longer hesitated to make resistance, and, facing about, beat back the enemy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Commius, spurring his horse to a gallop, pulled alongside Quadratus's horse and, with his lance leveled, pierced Volusenus through the middle of the thigh with great force.

sentences.latin: Praefecto vulnerato non dubitant nostri resistere et conversis equis hostem pellere.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With the commander wounded not do doubt our men to resist and with turned horses the enemy to drive away.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When this occurred, several of the enemy, repulsed by the great impetuosity of our men, were wounded, and some were trampled to death in striving to escape, and some were made prisoners.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When their commander was wounded, our men did not hesitate to make a stand, and turning their horses, they drove back the enemy.

sentences.latin: Quod ubi accidit, complures hostium magno nostrorum impetu perculsi vulnerantur ac partim in fuga proteruntur, partim intercipiuntur; quod malum dux equi velocitate evitavit: graviter adeo vulneratus praefectus, ut vitae periculum aditurus videretur, refertur in castra.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Which when it happened, several of the enemies by the great of our men attack struck are wounded and partly in flight are trampled, partly are intercepted; which evil the leader by the horse's speed avoided: heavily so wounded the commander, that of life danger about to undergo he seemed, is carried back into the camp.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When this occurred, several of the enemy, repulsed by the great impetuosity of our men, were wounded, and some were trampled to death in striving to escape, and some were made prisoners.
