sentences.naturalTranslation: When this happened, many of the enemy were struck down by the great force of our charge and wounded; some were trampled in flight, others cut off. Their leader escaped this fate through the speed of his horse, but the commander, so severely wounded that he seemed to be in danger of his life, was carried back to camp.

sentences.latin: Commius autem sive expiato suo dolore sive magna parte amissa suorum legatos ad Antonium mittit seque et ibi futurum, ubi praescripserit, et ea facturum, quae imperarit, obsidibus firmat;
sentences.referenceTranslation: Commius however whether having-atoned-for his-own grief or a great part having-been-lost of-his-own [men] envoys to Antony sends and himself both there to-be-about-to-be, where he-shall-have-prescribed, and those-things to-be-about-to-do, which he-shall-have-commanded, with-hostages he-confirms;
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Their general escaped this misfortune by the swiftness of his horse.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Commius, however, whether because his resentment had been satisfied or because he had lost a large part of his followers, sent envoys to Antony and guaranteed with hostages that he would remain where directed and perform what was commanded.

sentences.latin: unum illud orat, ut timori suo concedatur, ne in conspectum veniat cuiusquam Romani.
sentences.referenceTranslation: one that-thing he-prays, that to-fear his-own it-may-be-conceded, lest into sight he-may-come of-any Roman.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Our commander, being severely wounded, so much so that he appeared to run the risk of losing his life, was carried back to the camp.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He made one request: that a concession be made to his fear, so that he would not have to come into the presence of any Roman.

sentences.latin: Cuius postulationem Antonius cum iudicaret ab iusto nasci timore, veniam petenti dedit, obsides accepit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whose demand Antony when he-judged from just to-be-born fear, pardon to-the-one-seeking he-gave, hostages he-received.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But Comius, having either gratified his resentment, or, because he had lost the greatest part of his followers, sent embassadors to Antonius, and assured him that he would give hostages as a security that he would go wherever Antonius should prescribe, and would comply with his orders, and only entreated that this concession should be made to his fears, that he should not be obliged to go into the presence of any Roman.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Antony, judging that this request arose from a justified fear, granted pardon to the petitioner and accepted the hostages.

sentences.latin: Scio Caesarem singulorum annorum singulos commentarios confecisse; quod ego non existimavi mihi esse faciendum, propterea quod insequens annus, L. Paulo C. Marcello consulibus, nullas habet magnopere Galliae res gestas.
sentences.referenceTranslation: I-know Caesar of-each years individual commentaries to-have-completed; which I not thought to-me to-be to-be-done, because that the-following year, Lucius Paulus [and] Gaius Marcellus being-consuls, no has greatly of-Gaul things done.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: As Antonius judged that his request originated in a just apprehension, he indulged him in it and accepted his hostages.Caesar, I know, has made a separate commentary of each year's transactions, which I have not thought it necessary for me to do, because the following year, in which Lucius Paulus and Caius Marcellus were consuls, produced no remarkable occurrences in Gaul.
sentences.naturalTranslation: I know that Caesar completed individual commentaries for each year; I did not think I should do this, because the following year, during the consulship of Lucius Paulus and Gaius Marcellus, contains no major achievements in Gaul.

sentences.latin: Ne quis tamen ignoraret, quibus in locis Caesar exercitusque eo tempore fuissent, pauca esse scribenda coniungendaque huic commentario statui.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Lest anyone however should-be-ignorant, in-which in places Caesar and-the-army at-that time had-been, a-few-things to-be to-be-written and-to-be-joined to-this commentary I-decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: But that no person may be left in ignorance of the place where Caesar and his army were at that time, have thought proper to write a few words in addition to this commentary.
sentences.naturalTranslation: However, so that no one would be ignorant of where Caesar and the army were at that time, I decided that a few things should be written and added to this commentary.

sentences.latin: Caesar in Belgio cum hiemaret, unum illud propositum habebat, continere in amicitia civitates, nulli spem aut causam dare armorum.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar in Belgium when he-was-wintering, one that-thing set-forth he-was-having, to-keep in friendship the-states, to-none hope or cause to-give of-arms.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar, while in winter quarters in the country of the Belgae, made it his only business to keep the states in amity with him, and to give none either hopes of, or pretext for a revolt.
sentences.naturalTranslation: While Caesar was wintering in Belgium, he had one objective: to keep the states in friendship and to give no one a hope or reason for war.

sentences.latin: Nihil enim minus volebat quam sub decessu suo necessitatem sibi aliquam imponi belli gerendi, ne, cum exercitum deducturus esset, bellum aliquod relinqueretur quod omnis Gallia libenter sine praesenti periculo susciperet.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nothing for less he-was-willing than under departure his-own necessity on-himself some to-be-imposed of-war to-be-waged, lest, when the-army about-to-lead-away he-was, war some should-be-left which all Gaul gladly without present danger would-undertake.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For nothing was further from his wishes than to be under the necessity of engaging in another war at his departure; lest, when he was drawing his army out of the country, any war should be left unfinished, which the Gauls would cheerfully undertake, when there was no immediate danger.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he wanted nothing less than to have some necessity for waging war imposed on him at the time of his departure, lest, when he was about to withdraw the army, some war be left behind which all Gaul would gladly undertake without immediate danger.

sentences.latin: Itaque honorifice civitates appellando, principes maximis praemiis adficiendo, nulla onera iniungendo defessam tot adversis proeliis Galliam condicione parendi meliore facile in pace continuit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: And-so honorably the-states by-addressing, the-leaders with-greatest rewards by-affecting, no burdens by-imposing, exhausted by-so-many adverse battles Gaul in-condition of-obeying better easily in peace he-kept.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Therefore, by treating the states with respect, making rich presents to the leading men, imposing no new burdens, and making the terms of their subjection lighter, he easily kept Gaul (already exhausted by so many unsuccessful battles) in obedience.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Therefore, by addressing the states honorably, bestowing great rewards on their leaders, and imposing no new burdens, he easily kept Gaulexhausted by so many unsuccessful battlesat peace under better conditions of obedience.

sentences.latin: Ipse hibernis peractis contra consuetudinem in Italiam quam maximis itineribus est profectus, ut municipia et colonias appellaret, quibus M. Antoni quaestoris sui, commendaverat sacerdoti petitionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He-himself winter-quarters having-been-completed against custom into Italy by-as-great-as-possible marches set out, so-that the-towns and colonies he-might-address, to-which of-Marcus Antonius quaestor his-own, he-had-commended of-priesthood the-candidacy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When the winter quarters were broken up he himself, contrary to his usual practice, proceeded to Italy, by the longest possible stages, in order to visit the free towns and colonies, that he might recommend to them the petition of Marcus Antonius, his treasurer, for the priesthood.
sentences.naturalTranslation: After the winter quarters were broken up, he himself set out for Italy by the longest possible marches, contrary to his usual custom, in order to address the municipalities and colonies to which he had recommended the candidacy of his quaestor, Marcus Antonius, for a priesthood.

sentences.latin: Contendebat enim gratia cum libenter pro homine sibi coniunctissimo, quem paulo ante praemiserat ad petitionem, tum acriter contra factionem et potentiam paucorum, qui M. Antoni repulsa Caesaris decedentis gratiam convellere cupiebant.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He-was-striving for with-influence both gladly for a-man to-himself most-closely-joined, whom a-little before he-had-sent-ahead to the-candidacy, and-also fiercely against the-faction and power of-the-few, who by-Marcus Antonius's rejection of-Caesar departing the-influence to-shatter were-desiring.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: [SHARED 2x] When the winter quarters were broken up he himself, contrary to his usual practice, proceeded to Italy, by the longest possible stages, in order to visit the free towns and colonies, that he might recommend to them the petition of Marcus Antonius, his treasurer, for the priesthood.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he was exerting his influence both gladly on behalf of a man very closely linked to him, whom he had sent ahead a little earlier to campaign, and also fiercely against the faction and power of a few men who, by the defeat of Marcus Antonius, desired to shatter the influence of the departing Caesar.

sentences.latin: Hunc etsi augurem prius factum quam Italiam attingeret in itinere audierat, tamen non minus iustam sibi causam municipia et colonias adeundi existimavit, ut eis gratias ageret, quod frequentiam atque officium suum Antonio praestitissent,
sentences.referenceTranslation: This man although an augur made before than Italy he reached on the journey he had heard, nevertheless not less just for himself a cause the municipalities and colonies of visiting he thought, so that to them thanks he might give, because their attendance and service to Antony they had shown,
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This [man] although an augur made before than Italy he reached on the journey he had heard, nevertheless not less just for himself a cause the municipalities and colonies of visiting he thought, so that to them thanks he might give, because their attendance and service to Antony they had shown,
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although he had heard while on his journey that Antony had been made augur before he reached Italy, he nevertheless thought he had an equally valid reason to visit the municipalities and colonies to thank them for showing such attendance and devotion to Antony,

sentences.latin: simulque se et honorem suum sequentis anni commendaret, propterea quod insolenter adversarii sui gloriarentur L. Lentulum et C. Marcellum consules creatos qui omnem honorem et dignitatem Caesaris spoliarent, ereptum Ser.
sentences.referenceTranslation: and at the same time himself and his own honor of the following year he might commend, for the reason that insolently his adversaries were boasting Lucius Lentulus and Gaius Marcellus as consuls created who all honor and dignity of Caesar might strip, snatched away from Servius
sentences.originalMITTranslation: and at the same time himself and his own honor of the following year he might commend, for the reason that insolently his adversaries were boasting Lucius Lentulus and Gaius Marcellus as consuls created who all honor and dignity of Caesar might strip, snatched away from Servius
sentences.naturalTranslation: and at the same time, he wished to recommend himself and his candidacy for the following year, because his enemies were insolently boasting that Lucius Lentulus and Gaius Marcellus had been elected consuls to strip Caesar of all honor and dignity, and that the consulship had been snatched from Servius

sentences.latin: Galbae consulatum, cum is multo plus gratia suffragiisque valuisset, quod sibi coniunctus et familiaritate et consuetudine legationis esset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Galba, although he by much more in influence and votes had been strong, because to him joined both by friendship and by the habit of lieutenancy he was.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Galba the consulship, although he by much more in influence and votes had prevailed, because to him joined both by friendship and by the habit of the lieutenancy he was.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Galba, even though the latter had been much stronger in influence and votes, simply because he was closely connected to Caesar by both personal friendship and their shared service during his lieutenancy.

sentences.latin: Exceptus est Caesaris adventus ab omnibus municipiis et coloniis incredibili honore atque amore.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Received was Caesar's arrival by all municipalities and colonies with incredible honor and love.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Received was Caesar's arrival by all municipalities and colonies with incredible honor and love.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar's arrival was welcomed by all the municipalities and colonies with incredible honor and affection.

sentences.latin: Tum primum enim veniebat ab illo universae Galliae bello.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Then first indeed he was coming from that of all Gaul war.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Then for the first time for he was coming from that of all Gaul war.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For this was the first time he was returning from the war against all of Gaul.

sentences.latin: Nihil relinquebatur quod ad ornatum portarum, itinerum, locorum omnium qua Caesar iturus erat excogitari poterat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Nothing was left which for the decoration of gates, of routes, of places all where Caesar about to go was could be devised.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Nothing was left which for the decoration of gates, of routes, of places all where Caesar about to go was could be thought of.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Nothing was left undone that could be devised for the decoration of the gates, the roads, and all the places through which Caesar was to pass.

sentences.latin: Cum liberis omnis multitudo obviam procedebat, hostiae omnibus locis immolabantur, tricliniis stratis fora templaque occupabantur, ut vel exspectatissimi triumphi laetitia praecipi posset.
sentences.referenceTranslation: With children the whole multitude meeting was proceeding, victims in all places were being sacrificed, with couches spread the forums and temples were being occupied, so that even of a most awaited triumph the joy anticipated could be.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: With children all the multitude meeting was proceeding, victims in all places were being sacrificed, with couches spread forums and temples were being occupied, so that even of a most awaited triumph the joy anticipated could be.
sentences.naturalTranslation: The whole population, including children, came out to meet him, victims were sacrificed everywhere, and with dining couches laid out, the forums and temples were filled, so that the joy of even the most long-awaited triumph might be anticipated.

sentences.latin: Tanta erat magnificentia apud opulentiores, cupiditas apud humiliores.
sentences.referenceTranslation: So great was the magnificence among the wealthier, the eagerness among the humbler.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: So great was the magnificence among the wealthier, the eagerness among the humbler.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Such was the magnificence displayed by the wealthy and the enthusiasm shown by the common people.

sentences.latin: Cum omnes regiones Galliae togatae Caesar percucurrisset, summa celeritate ad exercitum Nemetocennam rediit legionibusque ex omnibus hibernis ad fines Treverorum evocatis eo profectus est ibique exercitum lustravit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: When all regions of Gaul Togata Caesar had traversed, with the greatest speed to the army at Nemetocenna he returned and with the legions from all winter quarters to the borders of the Treveri called out to there he set out and there the army he reviewed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: When all regions of Gaul Togata Caesar had traversed, with highest speed to the army at Nemetocenna he returned and with the legions from all winter quarters to the borders of the Treveri called out to there he set out and there the army he reviewed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When Caesar had traversed all the regions of Cisalpine Gaul, he returned with the greatest speed to the army at Nemetocenna; having summoned the legions from all their winter quarters to the territory of the Treveri, he marched there and reviewed the army.

sentences.latin: T. Labienum Galliae togatae praefecit, quo maiore commendatione conciliaretur ad consulatus petitionem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Titus Labienus over Gaul Togata he placed in charge, so that with greater recommendation he might be won over for the of the consulship candidacy.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Titus Labienus over Gaul Togata he placed, so that with greater recommendation he might be won over for of the consulship the candidacy.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He placed Titus Labienus in charge of Cisalpine Gaul, so that he might be more strongly recommended for his candidacy for the consulship.

sentences.latin: Ipse tantum itinerum faciebat, quantum satis esse ad mutationem locorum propter salubritatem existimabat.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself so much of marches was making, as much as enough to be for change of places on account of healthiness he was thinking.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself so much of journeys was making, as much enough to be for the change of places on account of health he was thinking.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself made only as many marches as he thought sufficient for a change of location for the sake of health.

sentences.latin: Ibi quamquam crebro audiebat Labienum ab inimicis suis sollicitari certiorque fiebat id agi paucorum consiliis, ut interposita senatus auctoritate aliqua parte exercitus spoliaretur, tamen neque de Labieno credidit quidquam neque contra senatus auctoritatem ut aliquid faceret potuit adduci.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There although frequently he was hearing Labienus by enemies his to be solicited and more certain was being made that to be done by of a few plans, so that having been interposed the senate's authority of some part of the army he might be despoiled, nevertheless neither about Labienus did he believe anything nor against the senate's authority that anything he should do could he be led.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There although frequently he was hearing Labienus by enemies his to be solicited and more certain was becoming that done by of a few the plans, so that with interposed of the senate the authority of some part of the army he might be stripped, nevertheless neither about Labienus did he believe anything nor against of the senate the authority so that anything he might do could he be led.
sentences.naturalTranslation: There, although he frequently heard that Labienus was being solicited by his enemies and was informed that a plot was being hatched by a few men to strip him of part of his army through the senate's authority, he nevertheless believed nothing against Labienus, nor could he be induced to act against the authority of the senate.

sentences.latin: Iudicabat enim liberis sententiis patrum conscriptorum causam suam facile obtineri.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He was judging for by free opinions of the fathers enrolled cause his easily to be maintained.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He was judging for by the free opinions of the fathers enrolled the cause his easily to be maintained.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he judged that his cause would easily be maintained by the free votes of the senators.

sentences.latin: Nam C. Curio, tribunus plebis, cum Caesaris causam dignitatemque defendendam suscepisset, saepe erat senatui pollicitus, si quem timor armorum Caesaris laederet, et quoniam Pompei dominatio atque arma non minimum terrorem foro inferrent, discederet uterque ab armis exercitusque dimitteret: fore eo facto liberam et sui iuris civitatem.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For C. Curio, tribune of the plebs, when Caesar's cause and dignity to be defended he had undertaken, often had to the senate promised, if anyone fear of arms of Caesar was hurting, and since Pompey's domination and arms not minimum terror to the forum were bringing, should depart each from arms and armies should dismiss: would be by that deed free and of its own right the state.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For Gaius Curio, tribune of the plebs, when Caesar's cause and dignity to be defended he had undertaken, often had to the senate promised, if anyone the fear of the arms of Caesar was hurting, and since Pompey's domination and arms not the least terror to the forum were bringing, should depart each from arms and the armies should dismiss: would be by that deed free and of its own right the state.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For Gaius Curio, a tribune of the plebs, having undertaken to defend Caesar's cause and dignity, had often promised the senate that if anyone was troubled by fear of Caesar's armsand since Pompey's domination and arms brought no small terror to the forumboth should lay down their arms and disband their armies; he claimed that by this act, the state would be free and independent.

sentences.latin: Neque hoc tantum pollicitus est, sed etiam per se discessionem facere coepit; quod ne fieret consules amicique Pompei iusserunt atque ita rem morando discusserunt.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Neither this only he promised, but even by himself a division to make he began; which lest it should happen the consuls and friends of Pompey ordered and thus the matter by delaying they broke up.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Neither this only he promised, but even by himself a division to make he began; which lest it should happen the consuls and friends of Pompey ordered and thus the matter by delaying they broke up.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He did not only promise this, but even attempted to force a division of the house on his own; the consuls and Pompey's friends forbade this, and thus frustrated the matter by delay.

sentences.latin: Magnum hoc testimonium senatus erat universi conveniensque superiori facto.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Great this testimony of the senate was of the whole and consistent with the previous deed.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: A great this testimony of the senate was of the whole and consistent with the previous deed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: This was a great testimony from the entire senate and consistent with their previous action.

sentences.latin: Nam Marcellus proximo anno, cum impugnaret Caesaris dignitatem, contra legem Pompei et Crassi rettulerat ante tempus ad senatum de Caesaris provinciis, sententiisque dictis discessionem faciente Marcello, qui sibi omnem dignitatem ex Caesaris invidia quaerebat, senatus frequens in alia omnia transiit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For Marcellus in the nearest year, when he was attacking Caesar's dignity, against the law of Pompey and Crassus had referred before time to the senate about Caesar's provinces, and opinions having been spoken a division making Marcellus, who for himself all dignity from Caesar's envy was seeking, the senate in crowds into other all things went over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For Marcellus in the previous year, when he was attacking Caesar's dignity, against the law of Pompey and Crassus had referred before the time to the senate about Caesar's provinces, and with opinions spoken a division making Marcellus, who for himself all dignity from Caesar's envy was seeking, the senate in a crowd into all other things passed.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For in the previous year, when Marcellus was attacking Caesar's dignity, he had brought a motion before the senate regarding Caesar's provinces ahead of time and against the law of Pompey and Crassus; when the votes were cast and Marcelluswho sought to gain prestige for himself by inciting hatred against Caesarcalled for a division, a crowded senate voted against him.

sentences.latin: Quibus non frangebantur animi inimicorum Caesaris, sed admonebantur quo maiores pararent necessitates, quibus cogi posset senatus id probare, quod ipsi constituissent.
sentences.referenceTranslation: By which not were broken the minds of the enemies of Caesar, but they were warned so that greater they might prepare necessities, by which to be forced could the senate that to approve, which they themselves had decided.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: By which not were broken the spirits of the enemies of Caesar, but they were warned so that greater they might prepare necessities, by which to be forced could the senate that to approve, which they themselves had decided.
sentences.naturalTranslation: By these events, the spirits of Caesar's enemies were not broken, but they were warned to prepare more powerful means of compulsion, by which the senate might be forced to approve what they themselves had determined.

sentences.latin: Fit deinde senatus consultum, ut ad bellum Parthicum legio una a Cn.
sentences.referenceTranslation: There is made then a decree of the senate, that to the war Parthian legion one by Gnaeus [Pompey]...
sentences.originalMITTranslation: There is made then a decree of the senate, that for the war Parthian legion one by Gnaeus
sentences.naturalTranslation: A decree of the senate was then passed that one legion should be sent by Gnaeus Pompey for the Parthian war...

sentences.latin: Pompeio, altera a C. Caesare mitteretur; neque obscure duae legiones uni detrahuntur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Pompey, the other by C. Caesar should be sent; nor obscurely two legions from one are being withdrawn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Pompey, the other by Gaius Caesar should be sent; and not obscurely two legions from one are taken away.
sentences.naturalTranslation: ...and another by Gaius Caesar; it was quite clear that both legions were being taken from one man.

sentences.latin: Nam Cn.
sentences.referenceTranslation: For Gnaeus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: For Gnaeus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For Gnaeus.

sentences.latin: Pompeius legionem primam, quam ad Caesarem miserat, confectam ex delectu provinciae Caesaris, eam tamquam ex suo numero dedit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Pompey the legion first, which to Caesar he had sent, made up from the levy of the province of Caesar, it as if from his own number he gave.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Pompey the first legion, which to Caesar he had sent, made up from the levy of the province of Caesar, it as if from his own number gave.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pompey gave the first legion, which he had sent to Caesar and which had been raised from Caesar's own province, as if it were from his own quota.

sentences.latin: Caesar tamen, cum de voluntate minime dubium esset adversariorum suorum, Pompeio legionem remisit et suo nomine quintam decimam, quam in Gallia citeriore habuerat, ex senatus consulto iubet tradi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Caesar however, since about the intention least doubtful it was of his adversaries, to Pompey the legion sent back and in his own name the fifteenth, which in Gaul hither he had had, according to the senate's decree he orders to be handed over.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Caesar however, since about the will least doubtful it was of his adversaries, to Pompey the legion sent back and in his own name the fifteenth, which in Hither Gaul he had held, from the senate's decree he orders to be handed over.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Caesar, however, since the intentions of his enemies were perfectly clear, sent the legion back to Pompey and, in accordance with the Senate's decree, ordered the fifteenth legion, which he had stationed in Cisalpine Gaul, to be handed over in his own name.

sentences.latin: In eius locum tertiam decimam legionem in Italiam mittit quae praesidia tueretur, ex quibus praesidiis quinta decima deducebatur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: In its place the thirteenth legion into Italy he sends which the garrisons might protect, from which garrisons the fifteenth was being withdrawn.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: In its place the thirteenth legion into Italy he sends which the garrisons might protect, from which garrisons the fifteenth was being withdrawn.
sentences.naturalTranslation: In its place, he sent the thirteenth legion into Italy to protect the garrisons from which the fifteenth was being withdrawn.

sentences.latin: Ipse exercitui distribuit hiberna: C. Trebonium cum legionibus quattuor in Belgio collocat, C. Fabium cum totidem in Aeduos deducit.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself for the army distributed winter quarters: Gaius Trebonius with legions four in Belgium he places, Gaius Fabius with as many among the Aedui he leads.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself for the army distributed winter quarters: Gaius Trebonius with legions four in Belgium he places, Gaius Fabius with as many among the Aedui he leads.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He personally assigned winter quarters for the army: he stationed Gaius Trebonius with four legions in Belgium and led Gaius Fabius with the same number to the Aedui.

sentences.latin: Sic enim existimabat tutissimam fore Galliam, si Belgae, quorum maxima virtus, Aedui, quorum auctoritas summa esset, exercitibus continerentur.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Thus for he was thinking most safe would be Gaul, if the Belgae, of whom greatest the valor, the Aedui, of whom the authority highest was, by armies were held.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Thus for he was thinking most safe would be Gaul, if the Belgae, of whom the greatest valor, the Aedui, of whom the authority highest was, by armies were held.
sentences.naturalTranslation: For he believed that Gaul would be most secure if the Belgae, who possessed the greatest courage, and the Aedui, who held the highest authority, were kept in check by armies.

sentences.latin: Ipse in Italiam profectus est.
sentences.referenceTranslation: He himself into Italy set out.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He himself into Italy set out.
sentences.naturalTranslation: He himself set out for Italy.

sentences.latin: Quo cum venisset, cognoscit per C. Marcellum consulem legiones duas ab se remissas, quae ex senatus consulto deberent ad Parthicum bellum duci, Cn.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Whither when he had come, he learns through Gaius Marcellus the consul the legions two by him sent back, which from the senate's decree ought to the Parthian war to be led, to Gnaeus.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: Whither when he had come, he learns through Gaius Marcellus the consul the legions two by him sent back, which from the senate's decree ought to the Parthian war to be led, Gnaeus.
sentences.naturalTranslation: When he arrived there, he learned that through the consul Gaius Marcellus, the two legions he had sent backwhich by decree of the Senate were supposed to be led to the Parthian warhad been handed over to Gnaeus.

sentences.latin: Pompeio traditas atque in Italia retentas esse.
sentences.referenceTranslation: Pompey handed over and in Italy retained to have been.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: to Pompey handed over and in Italy retained had been.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Pompey and were being kept in Italy.

sentences.latin: Hoc facto quamquam nulli erat dubium, quidnam contra Caesarem pararetur, tamen Caesar omnia patienda esse statuit, quoad sibi spes aliqua relinqueretur iure potius disceptandi quam belli gerendi.
sentences.referenceTranslation: This having been done although to no one it was doubtful, what indeed against Caesar was being prepared, nevertheless Caesar all things to be endured to be he decided, as long as to him hope some was left of by law rather debating than of war waging.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: This having been done although to no one was it doubtful, what indeed against Caesar was being prepared, yet Caesar all things to be endured to be he decided, as long as to him hope some might be left by law rather of debating than of war waging.
sentences.naturalTranslation: Although after this action no one doubted what was being prepared against Caesar, he nevertheless decided that everything should be endured as long as some hope remained of settling the dispute through legal means rather than by waging war.

sentences.latin: Contendit
sentences.referenceTranslation: He hastened.
sentences.originalMITTranslation: He hastened
sentences.naturalTranslation: He set out in haste.
